site_title: NTUC unveils renewed workers’ compact in response to shifting societal, technological norms
summary: NTUC, Singapore's labour movement, has unveiled a "renewed workers' compact" with 10 recommendations for five groups of workers: youths, mid-career workers, caregivers, older workers, and vulnerable workers. The compact focuses on autonomy, adaptability, and assurance, with recommendations such as comprehensive support systems for youths, equal training opportunities for older workers, and progressive wage models for vulnerable workers. The NTUC aims to better support workers as Singapore transitions into a "super-aged" society with evolving priorities, and is engaging with various stakeholders to implement the compact's recommendations.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Singapore must tackle the shortfall in training and skills-building participation for older workers, to close the capacity gap, says NTUC deputy secretary-general Heng Chee How.
The government may consider a tiered approach, offering full support to SMEs and only partial support to the rest, since many larger companies do already offer some form of family care leave.
Employers understood the increasing necessity of caregiving leave, but said it would be challenging to bear the additional costs of implementing such a policy.
One top concern by workers is the desire for more support in upskilling for career development, said NTUC secretary-general Ng Chee Meng on Thursday (Sep 21).
NTUC secretary-general Ng Chee Meng calls on stakeholders, including employers and the government, to support workers managing work and caregiving.

site_title: The day the floodgates opened in the English Premier League
summary: Newcastle United broke the record for the largest away win in English Premier League history with an 8-0 thrashing of Sheffield United, becoming the first team to have eight different players on the scoresheet in a single match. This feat surpasses previous record-holders, including Manchester United's 9-0 win over Ipswich Town in 1995, and Leicester City's 9-0 win over Southampton in 2019. Newcastle's victory also highlights the rarity of 9-goal wins in the EPL, with only five instances since the league's formation in 1992.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
Liverpool has started the current season strongly and are second in the table after winning five of their first six matches.
Rugby has grown in popularity in the 200 years since, and now claims the title of the world’s third-largest sporting event after the Olympics and the FIFA World Cup.

site_title: Singapore household electricity, gas bills to rise as tariffs go up in Q4
summary: Singapore household electricity and gas bills are set to rise in the fourth quarter of 2023 due to increased tariffs. Electricity tariffs will increase by an average of 3.7% or 0.98 cents per kilowatt-hour (KWh), while gas tariffs will rise by 0.51 cent to 22.42 cents per KWh. The rises are attributed to higher energy and fuel costs, with energy costs comprising 76.5% of the electricity tariff. The increases will affect households from October 1 to December 31.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

Generic photos of residential buildings comprising of HDB and private property in the Dawson area taken at night on August 1, 2023

site_title: Evergrande sold yacht this year, say sources, as creditors sharpen focus on offshore assets
summary: Evergrande Group sold its luxury superyacht, Event, for approximately $32 million, further reducing the developer's offshore assets amid its worsening cash crunch and debt restructuring struggles. The sale, which occurred earlier this year, will limit foreign creditors' options in a potential liquidation process. Evergrande's offshore bondholders are sharpening their focus on these assets as the company's debt restructuring plan falters under investigation into founder Hui Ka Yan's "illegal crimes." The sale is the latest in a series of asset disposals by the company.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The yacht "Event", which is believed to be owned by China Evergrande, is docked in Hong Kong, China October 11, 2021. Picture taken October 11, 2021. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu/File Photo

site_title: Cost-of-living package leaves out firms; unsustainable to ‘permanently subsidise’ them: Lawrence Wong
summary: Singapore's new Cost-of-Living Support Package, totaling S$1.1 billion, aims to help lower to middle-income families cope with rising costs. The package includes cash payouts, vouchers, and rebates, but does not provide support to businesses, which Finance Minister Lawrence Wong said cannot be permanently subsidized. Instead, the government plans to help businesses become more productive and efficient in the upcoming Budget 2024, allowing them to adapt to rising costs without relying on subsidies.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
The package includes an additional S$200 in CDC Vouchers for all Singaporean households.
A kitchen worker washing cutlery under a running tap at a cafe in Raffles Place.

site_title: Europe: Shares end worst quarter in a year with minor gain
summary: Europe's pan-European Stoxx 600 index ended the quarter 2.5% lower, its worst performance in a year, despite a 0.4% gain on Friday. The index was boosted by a drop in eurozone inflation in September, which raised hopes that the European Central Bank will pause interest rate hikes. Tech stocks rose 1.1% and real estate shares jumped 2.7% after softer-than-expected inflation data. However, oil and gas shares fell 1.3% due to concerns over higher interest rates.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 index rose 0.4 per cent, while Spain’s IBEX index outperformed its peers, climbing 1.0 per cent on Thursday.

site_title: Three Arrows co-founder Zhu Su arrested at Changi Airport, sentenced to 4 months’ prison
summary: Zhu Su, co-founder of failed cryptocurrency hedge fund Three Arrows Capital, was arrested at Changi Airport and sentenced to four months' prison for his "deliberate failure" to comply with a court order. Fellow co-founder Kyle Davies was also sentenced to four months' imprisonment but his whereabouts remain unknown. The liquidators of 3AC will focus on recovering assets and maximizing returns for creditors during Zhu's prison sentence, following a committal order granted by the Singapore Courts.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai

Liquidators have taken unorthodox steps in an effort to get the 3AC co-founders to turn over information, including getting approval from Judge Martin Glenn to issue the subpoena to Kyle Davies (pictured) via Twitter, where he frequently posts.

site_title: China blocks executive at US firm Kroll from leaving the mainland: sources
summary: A senior executive at US risk advisory firm Kroll, Hong Kong-based managing director Michael Chan, has been barred from leaving the Chinese mainland due to an ongoing investigation. Chan, who is assisting the investigation, is still working and can move freely in mainland China. This move follows similar actions taken by Chinese authorities against foreign firms, including raids on US consultancy firms and fines for firms like Mintz Group. Concerns are growing among Western businesses about the darkening prospects in China amid slowing growth and tougher operating conditions.

images.alt_text: The ban comes as concerns grow among Western businesses about darkening prospects in China's economy at a time of slowing growth, coupled with new laws that make for tougher operating conditions.
Shih Wing Ching, chairman of Centaline, says local governments should be banned from selling land.
China’s slowdown has some government advisers in Beijing calling for deeper reforms, while others are advocating more robust state spending to bolster growth

US President Joe Biden signed the executive order last month which prohibits or restricts investments in Chinese entities involved in semiconductors and microelectronics, quantum information technologies and certain artificial intelligence systems.

site_title: China trade council asks US to “carefully consider” tech investment ban
summary: China's international trade council has urged the US to "carefully consider" its executive order banning or restricting investments in Chinese tech entities, citing vague and broad restrictions that could harm the global industrial chain. The order, signed by President Joe Biden, aims to protect national security and prevent US capital from aiding China's military. US financial firms have pushed for greater clarity on the proposed rules, which they say are too vague and put the onus of compliance on investors. The rules are expected to be implemented next year.

images.alt_text: The PMI figures are due to be released on Saturday.
Trade between the two countries jumped 37 per cent in the first seven months this year.
The country will boost macroeconomic controls and expand domestic demand in its push for “continuous improvement” of economy, says Chinese President Xi Jinping.

Pedestrians on Wall Street in New York, US, on Tuesday, Aug. 8, 2023. Stocks fell around the world as traders rushed into bonds after a raft of news on China, Italy and the US fanned worries about the financial system and the global economy. Photographer: Victor J. Blue/Bloomberg
The Cyberspace Administration of China (CAC) says it is considering waiving data export security assessments  for activities that do not contain personal information or important data.

Beijing’s careful managing of its ties with a top trading partner comes amid a broader push to stabilise geopolitical relationships, as an economic slowdown at home deflates expectations it will ever overtake the US as No 1.

site_title: UK banks wary of London housing projects amid £827 million value drop
summary: UK banks are becoming increasingly cautious about lending for housing development in London, cutting leverage ratios by up to 10 percentage points since the start of the year. This is due to market uncertainty, rising costs, and slumping demand. Land values in the city's upmarket areas, such as the Earls Court site, have fallen by 15% to £540 million, with some developers having to dramatically mark down land acquired during the boom. The downturn is expected to continue, with over half of homebuilders predicting a value drop this quarter.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Residential single family homes construction by KB Home are shown under construction in the community of Valley Center, California, U.S. June 3, 2021. REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo

site_title: Indonesia’s Fore Coffee sees Singapore as stepping stone to global expansion
summary: Indonesian coffee chain Fore Coffee aims to expand globally, starting with its upcoming store in Singapore at Bugis Junction. The company, which has 148 stores in Indonesia, plans to have 200 stores worldwide by the end of the year. Fore Coffee will offer a dine-in experience and sell coffee from Arabica beans with organic and fair-trade certifications, priced from S$4.50 per cup. The brand is targeting a 5% annual growth rate in Singapore's coffee market, which is projected to reach US$1.3 billion by 2027.

images.alt_text: Luckin Coffee's journey spells lessons for startups in South-east Asia.
Flash Coffee has raised a further US$50 million amid fiercer competition and after a round of layoffs in November 2022.
China's Luckin Coffee seeks US Chapter 15 bankruptcy protection

site_title: Larry Fink sees ‘large opportunities’ for deals to transform BlackRock
summary: BlackRock CEO Larry Fink sees "large opportunities" for deals to transform the company, which now oversees $9.4 trillion in assets, as it expands into private markets and alternatives. Fink notes that private money will play a crucial role in financing growth as democracies grapple with elevated fiscal deficits and excess debt. He expects 10-year borrowing costs to stay at 5% or higher due to embedded inflation and structural changes. Fink also warns of potential job losses from technological advancements, but believes businesses will move towards technology to boost productivity.

images.alt_text: At least 10 firms currently have applications pending with the SEC.
The BlackRock Future Innovators ETF, which launched in September 2020, is being liquidated in November.

site_title: Tax on empty homes: Can it ease rental supply crunch?
summary: A tax on vacant residential properties in Singapore could incentivize landlords to lease out their empty homes, increasing the rental market supply and potentially reducing rents. According to an Institute of Real Estate and Urban Studies (Ireus) article, the tax, similar to Vancouver's empty homes tax, could push "idle homes" into circulation, improving housing availability for renters. However, experts warn that the tax may also distort incentives for landlords, leading to a worsening of both availability and affordability of owner-occupied homes.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
Generic private properties around Orchard area.

site_title: Singapore, Malaysia and Thai conglomerates among region’s hardest hit by value erosion: Bain
summary: A report by Bain & Company found that conglomerates in mature markets such as Singapore, Malaysia, and Thailand have significantly lagged behind pure plays in South-east Asia over the past decade, experiencing value erosion. The report noted that pure plays outperformed conglomerates, with average annualized total shareholder returns (TSRs) of 4% compared to 11% for pure plays. Seven "all-weather stars" conglomerates, including VinGroup in Vietnam, outperformed their peers by investing in technology and restructuring to create value.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
South-east Asia conglomerates can increase exposure to higher growth sectors such as healthcare and tech to stay ahead
South-east Asia still a sweet lure for Ant's portfolio companies
Pandemic shakes up Singapore conglomerates

site_title: Turning point for the taxi industry?
summary: The Singapore taxi industry may be turning a corner as the Land Transport Authority (LTA) reviews the point-to-point (P2P) industry structure and regulatory framework. Grab's proposed takeover of Trans-cab Holdings, Singapore's third-largest taxi operator, could blur the lines between taxis and private-hire cars, offering a lifeline to the flagging industry. The acquisition could stabilize the driver supply for ride-hailing operators, reduce costs, and increase the value of the taxi business. However, concerns remain about the potential for culture clash and the industry's reliance on a stable driver supply.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Cheng Siak Kian, Group CEO, Comfort Delgro
The rebound in the number of private-hire cars comes at a time when there are fewer COEs to register vehicles.

site_title: Tokyo inflation slows, offering support for  Bank of Japan price outlook
summary: Tokyo's inflation rate slowed more than expected in September, with consumer prices excluding fresh food rising 2.5% compared to 2.8% in August. This data offers support for the Bank of Japan's view that prices are set to cool further, potentially leading to a revision of its price outlook. The slowdown is attributed to falling electricity and gas costs, as well as government subsidies. The Bank of Japan is likely to keep its ultra-easy monetary policy in place as inflation remains stronger than anticipated, and the country's central bank is expected to revise up its price outlook when it meets in October.

images.alt_text: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida says the economic stimulus package would include measures that counter issues such as inflation, and promote wage growth.
Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida said the economic stimulus package would include measures that counter issues such as inflation and depopulation.
Markets are focusing on whether BOJ governor Kazuo Ueda will offer any fresh signals on the timing of a policy shift.

site_title: Japan's economy minister says authorities must ensure end to deflation
summary: Japan's economy minister, Yoshitaka Shindo, stated that the country is no longer in deflation, but policymakers must ensure prices don't slide back into contraction. The economy is making steady progress towards ending deflation, but policymakers will closely watch key indicators like the output gap and labor costs before declaring a complete end. Despite the fragile economic recovery, the government and Bank of Japan have made efforts to pull Japan out of deflation, aiming for a 2% inflation target. Shindo will oversee a new economic package, balancing economic revival with debt reduction.

images.alt_text: In a wide-ranging speech at a forum, Srettha Thavisin said his government would improve infrastructure and water management, upgrade airports to boost tourism, expand free trade agreements to compete with neighbours, and make it easier for companies to hire more foreign workers in Thailand.

site_title: Hong Kong retail sales rise in August as mainland China tourists return
summary: Hong Kong's retail sales rose 13.7% year-over-year in August, driven by the return of mainland Chinese tourists. Sales by volume grew 11% from a year prior, surpassing the median estimate of 15.8% growth. Visitor arrivals reached 4.08 million in August, up 14% from the previous month. The government hopes a tourism recovery will fuel growth this year, despite challenges in regaining Hong Kong's appeal as a retail hub.

images.alt_text: The dragon is hoisted by hundreds of volunteers who dance and bound along the streets of the Tai Hang neighborhood in a raucous parade.
Hurt by surging interest rates, the city’s existing home prices have dropped 17 per cent from their peak in 2021.

site_title: Credit Suisse expects Q3 loss of US$1.6 billion from reclassifying loans
summary: Credit Suisse expects a third-quarter loss of US$1.6 billion from loan reclassifications linked to its non-core and legacy businesses. The bank also plans to wind down certain management arrangements, which may result in a loss of up to US$600 million in the same quarter. This comes after UBS agreed to buy Credit Suisse for a knockdown price of three billion francs, with up to five billion francs in assumed losses.

images.alt_text: UBS has grown its share the most, accounting for 41 per cent of the market this year.
FILE PHOTO: Logos of Swiss banks Credit Suisse and UBS are seen before a news conference in Zurich Switzerland, August 30, 2023.  REUTERS/Denis Balibouse/File Photo

site_title: HKMA official set to be named CEO of new HK$62b fund: sources
summary: Hong Kong is set to name Clara Chan, an executive director at the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, as the first CEO of a new HK$62 billion (S$10.8 billion) fund, the Hong Kong Investment (HKIC), to invest in businesses across the Greater Bay Area. Chan will oversee eight general partners in sectors including technology, healthcare, and financial services. The fund's aim is to promote the economy and industries, and enhance ties with Chinese mainland cities. The appointment could be made in the coming weeks, despite a spokesperson stating that open recruitment for the job is still ongoing.

images.alt_text: The Hong Kong Monetary Authority said it is premature to conclude whether the US rate hike cycle has been completed while the high interest rate environment is likely to last for some time.

site_title: Apple, China meet to discuss Beijing's crackdown on Western apps: sources
summary: Apple met with Chinese officials to discuss new rules restricting foreign apps on its app store in China. The officials stated that Apple must strictly implement the rules, which ban unregistered foreign apps. This compliance could lead to the removal of tens of thousands of apps from the app store. Apple has not commented on the matter, and experts warn of potential significant changes to its app store in China.

images.alt_text: Google is set to launch its latest Pixel device generation at an event on Oct 4.
Apple’s admirable sustainability initiatives will probably not be as potent a driver of its stock price over the next several months as sales of its newly launched iPhone 15.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Vang Shuiming, a key figure in the S$2.4 billion money-laundering case, denied bail in court. His associates, including three individuals with around S$412 million in assets under investigation, were also denied bail. Vang's family received passports from various countries through financial contributions. The police are currently investigating the associates' assets and seeking to freeze them.

images.alt_text: The package includes an additional S$200 in CDC Vouchers for all Singaporean households.

site_title: Dips in US core and ‘supercore’ inflation could bolster a Fed hold
summary: US core and "supercore" inflation rates have averaged near the Federal Reserve's 2% target for the last three months, a sign that price increases have continued to slow despite better-than-expected job and economic growth. Core personal consumption expenditures (PCE) rose 0.1% in August, while the "supercore" index, excluding services and housing costs, also rose 0.1%. This data bolsters the case for the Fed to hold interest rates steady at its upcoming meeting, potentially avoiding a recession and rising joblessness.

site_title: Evergrande’s extended yuan bonds are another risk hurdle for developer
summary: China Evergrande Group's unit, Hengda Real Estate, missed a 4 billion yuan onshore bond payment, raising concerns about the developer's ability to meet obligations. The missed payment, along with seven other yuan bonds totaling 45 billion yuan, adds to liquidation risks for the company. Evergrande scrapped creditor meetings and its chairman, Hui Ka Yan, is under police control, suspected of committing crimes. The company's shares plummeted 42% in three days before trading was halted. The payment miss questions the usefulness of recent debt extensions granted by Chinese investors.

images.alt_text: Hui Ka Yan was taken away by Chinese police earlier this month, and is being monitored at a designated location under so-called residential surveillance.

FILE PHOTO: Hui Ka Yan, chairman of Evergrande Real Estate Group Ltd, the country's second-largest property developer by sales, attends a news conference on annual results in Hong Kong, China March 29, 2016.      REUTERS/Bobby Yip/File Photo
The three suspended entities had a combined market value of HK$16.7 billion on Wednesday, down from HK$81.4 billion before their recent trading resumptions.
Evergrande sits at the centre of a years-long property crisis that has hurt the Chinese economy and hammered confidence in the housing market.
Hengda Real Estate Group fails to repay 4 billion yuan (S$748 million) in principal plus interest due on Sep 25.

site_title: Is it time to stop bingeing on real estate?
summary: Singapore's private home prices surged in the past three years, driven by a perceived housing shortage, but experts argue that the demand may be driven by fear and greed rather than a genuine need for housing. The "sell one, buy two" strategy, which encourages homeowners to sell their HDB flat and use the proceeds to buy multiple private residential properties, has contributed to the issue. With global warming and climate change posing significant threats, it may be wise for individuals to diversify their wealth holdings and prioritize sustainability over accumulating properties. Instead of endlessly bingeing on real estate, it's time to consider the impact on the planet and work towards creating a healthier environment for future generations.

site_title: Congestion at land checkpoints during long weekends, holidays not caused by Singapore: ICA
summary: Singapore's Immigration and Checkpoints Authority (ICA) has refuted claims that congestion at land checkpoints during long weekends and holidays is caused by Singapore. The agency cleared over 1.7 million passengers through the Woodlands and Tuas checkpoints during the August long weekend, using additional measures to ease crowding and manage traffic flow. ICA attributed congestion to slower clearance times at Malaysia's checkpoints, which can cause delays for cars cleared at Singapore's checkpoints. The agency emphasized the need to balance border security with efficient travel processing, citing the use of technology and risk assessment to detect potential issues.

images.alt_text: The government is looking at adopting the use of transhipment permits, similar to existing practices for air and sea transhipment, said Senior Minister of State for Transport Chee Hong Tat.

site_title: Former crypto star Sam Bankman-Fried faces US trial
summary: Sam Bankman-Fried, the former CEO of FTX, is set to go on trial in US federal court on Tuesday, facing seven counts of fraud that could result in decades in prison. Bankman-Fried, once worth $26 billion, was accused of diverting client funds to prop up Alameda Research, the company's crypto-focused investment arm. Prosecutors claim he also committed wire fraud, securities and commodities fraud, and money laundering, potentially affecting over a million victims. Bankman-Fried's defense strategy is expected to focus on his alleged incompetence and the influence of outside circumstances, with his ex-girlfriend and former Alameda executive Caroline Ellison cooperating with US authorities.

images.alt_text: Prosecutors say Sam Bankman-Fried stole billions of dollars in FTX customer deposits to plug losses at Alameda Research, a crypto-focused hedge fund he controlled.

site_title: Trump’s promise of lawlessness
summary: Donald Trump is running for president on a platform of lawlessness, promising to use state power against perceived enemies. This stance echoes his pardon of soldiers accused of war crimes during his presidency, which was met with criticism from military leaders. The US system's checks and balances are insufficient to deter leaders who seek to undermine the rule of law, and Trump's actions may set a precedent for further lawlessness.

images.alt_text: FILE — Former President Donald Trump speaks during the Pray Vote Stand summit at the Omni Shoreham Hotel in Washington, on Sept. 15, 2023. New York’s attorney general sued the president using a state law that grants her wide powers to pursue corporate wrongdoing. (Kenny Holston/The New York Times)

site_title: LVMH CEO Bernard Arnault under investigation for money laundering
summary: French billionaire Bernard Arnault, CEO of LVMH, is under investigation for money laundering at a luxury Alpine resort in Courchevel. The probe involves alleged activities of Russian oligarch Nikolai Sarkisov, who is suspected of acquiring a real estate portfolio through a complex deal involving companies in France, Luxembourg, and Cyprus. Arnault is accused of lending Sarkisov 18.3 million euros, allowing him to pocket a capital gain of 1.2 million euros. The investigation is led by France's financial intelligence unit, Tracfin, which has yet to determine if a crime was committed.

images.alt_text: Bernard Arnault's LVMH brands – 75 of them – are the stars of the luxury world, including Louis Vuitton, Christian Dior, Tiffany and Dom Perignon Champagne.
Some LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton brands have been official partners of global competitions.
The founder of LVMH had seen his wealth balloon for most of 2023 as share prices of European luxury companies surged.

site_title: Now it’s Bangkok’s fine dining scene that’s luring tourists to Thailand
summary: Bangkok's fine dining scene is gaining popularity, attracting tourists and boosting the city's tourism revenue. Restaurants like Le Du, a two-Michelin-starred Thai eatery, are drawing visitors with luxurious experiences alongside local street food. The city's high-end dining scene is also benefiting from improved supply infrastructure and lower operating costs. The Tourism Authority of Thailand aims for 20% of its revenue to come from food by 2027, with Bangkok restaurants expected to play a key role in this growth. The city's reputation as a destination for fine dining is solidifying, with several restaurants ranking on international and regional best restaurant lists.

images.alt_text: So far this year, Thailand has welcomed a total of 19 million visitors.

Despite only being released in August, "No More Bets" has become the third-most-popular film in China this year, raking in 3.8 billion yuan (S$712 million) and super-charging online discussion about the dangers of visiting Thailand.

site_title: LTA reallocates 300 more COEs for smaller cars in Oct to meet anticipated demand
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) has allocated an additional 300 COEs for smaller cars in October to meet anticipated demand following changes to the Vehicular Emissions Scheme. This increase brings the total available COEs to 780, a 23.9% increase from the previous average of 630 COEs. The reallocation aims to cater to the anticipated demand from car buyers following the September announcement of changes to the Vehicular Emissions Scheme.

site_title: Gold set for worst month in seven as traders bet on higher US rates
summary: Gold prices are set for their worst month in seven due to traders' expectations of higher US interest rates, which increases the opportunity cost of holding bullion. As of Friday, spot gold was up 0.1% at $1,866.41 per ounce, poised for a nearly 4% decline this month and its second consecutive quarterly drop. US dollar and Treasury yields are headed for their best quarters in four, despite recent fluctuations.

images.alt_text: Higher rates raise the opportunity cost of holding bullion, which is priced in US dollars and does not yield any interest.

site_title: Thai central bank chief says rates pause appropriate ‘for now’ after surprise hike
summary: The Bank of Thailand, led by Governor Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput, unexpectedly raised its key interest rate by a quarter point to 2.50%, the highest in a decade, in an effort to anchor inflation. However, the central bank chief stated that the current rate is appropriate for the economy and will remain neutral for now. The decision follows a slowdown in economic growth, with the central bank cutting its 2023 forecast to 2.8% and raising its 2024 outlook to 4.4%.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Bank of Thailand Governor Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput speaks during his first briefing on the economy and monetary policy after taking office in Bangkok, Thailand October 20, 2020. REUTERS/Chalinee Thirasupa/File Photo

site_title: India's Jaishankar says Canada has 'climate of violence' for Indian diplomats
summary: Indian Foreign Minister Subrahmanyam Jaishankar accused Canada of having a "climate of violence" and an "atmosphere of intimidation" against Indian diplomats, following Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's allegations that Indian agents may have had a role in the June murder of a Sikh separatist leader. The tensions between India and Canada are largely due to the presence of Sikh separatist groups in Canada advocating for an independent Sikh state. Jaishankar stated that making threats and intimidating diplomats is unacceptable.

images.alt_text: A memorial for Hardeep Singh Nijjar, a Sikh activist who was killed in Canada. Canada has accused India's government of sponsoring the murder.

A mural features the image of late Sikh leader Hardeep Singh Nijjar, who was slain on the grounds of the Guru Nanak Sikh Gurdwara temple in June 2023, in Surrey, British Columbia, Canada September 18, 2023. REUTERS/Chris Helgren

site_title: Singapore to formulate alternative-fuel standards by 2025
summary: Singapore aims to formulate alternative-fuel standards by 2025, including a methanol and ammonia bunkering standard and a hydrogen refuelling benchmark. The country plans to introduce or revise over 25 sustainability-related standards and accreditation programmes in the next two years. This move is part of Singapore's efforts to develop quality and standards in areas such as greenhouse gas reporting, decarbonisation, and renewable energy. The benchmarks are expected to support companies in their transition to cleaner energy sources.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Container ships and bulk carriers are seen in the shipping lanes off the coast of Singapore March 10, 2009.  REUTERS/Vivek Prakash/File Photo

site_title: US anti-discrimination agency sues Tesla over ‘pervasive’ racism
summary: The US Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) has filed a lawsuit against Tesla, alleging "pervasive" racism at the company's Fremont, California, car plant. The lawsuit claims that Black workers have endured racial slurs, hostility, and a hostile work environment since at least 2015. Tesla supervisors witnessed the abuse but failed to intervene, and workers who complained were retaliated against. The EEOC seeks unspecified damages, compensation for wronged workers, and an order for Tesla to curb racism at the factory.

images.alt_text: On a brand-by-brand basis, Tesla outsold its next 19 competitors by 10 to one or more during H1 2023, according to S&P Global Mobility data.

Tesla has pioneered the use of huge presses with 6,000 to 9,000 tons of clamping pressure to mould the front and rear structures of its Model Y in its “gigacasting” process that has slashed production costs.
Tesla has enjoyed perks in China that other international companies struggled to obtain, with the most notable being the state’s blessing to wholly own its domestic operations.
Thai PM Stretta says that Tesla is looking into an electric vehicle manufacturing facility while Microsoft and Google are looking at data centres.

Srettha Thavisin, Thailand's prime minister, during a Bloomberg Television interview in New York, US, on Wednesday, Sept. 20, 2023. Thailand will dole out 560 billion baht ($16 billion) to its 55 million adults in the next six months to spur domestic demand and investment, with new Prime Minister Srettha pitching pitching the revival of a sluggish economy as his government's top priority. Photographer: Stephanie Keith/Bloomberg
Tesla Chief Executive Officer Elon Musk gets in a Tesla car as he leaves a hotel in Beijing, China May 31, 2023.

site_title: Brokerages eye customer boost on TD Ameritrade retail fallout
summary: Brokerages in Singapore are bracing for an influx of new customers after TD Ameritrade announced it would stop serving retail investors from December. Several brokerages, including Tiger Brokers and Syfe, have seen an uptick in enquiries to transfer assets and open new accounts. Syfe forecasts picking up to a few thousand new accounts in the next few weeks, while others have set up dedicated sites to answer frequently asked questions by potential customers.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Schwab intends to use the sale proceeds for general corporate purposes.
TD Ameritrade Singapore will stop its services for retail investors from December this year.

site_title: As rate hikes near end, will a historic investor opportunity begin?
summary: As the US Federal Reserve nears the end of interest rate hikes, investors are poised for a transition to more benign monetary policy. Historically, yields on cash-like investments have decayed rapidly after the Fed ended hikes, while stocks and bonds have flourished. With the 10-year US Treasury yield up 40 basis points, long-term investors can now find attractive income opportunities in fixed income and stocks. A balanced strategy that combines defensive positions in dividend-paying stocks and high-quality bonds may also be attractive, particularly if the economy slows or falls into recession.

images.alt_text: “Progress on inflation is likely to be slow given the current level of monetary policy restraint,” US Federal Reserve governor Michelle Bowman says.
The Bank of England on Thursday announced its first pause on raising rates since December 2021, following a slight decline in UK inflation in August.

site_title: BlackRock, Invesco Bitcoin ETF applications again delayed by US SEC
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has delayed its review of applications from BlackRock, Invesco, and others seeking to list the first Bitcoin exchange-traded fund (ETF) in the US. This is the third delay for these firms, with the SEC having until mid-October to make a decision. At least 10 firms have applications pending with the SEC, and a recent court victory by Grayscale Investments has fueled speculation that a Bitcoin ETF may soon be approved, giving the winner significant first-mover advantage.

images.alt_text: If approved, Franklin plans to use Coinbase Global as custodian for the fund’s Bitcoin holdings and Bank of New York Mellon for cash.
The SEC has pushed back the decision dates for the three proposals by several weeks to mid-October.
A spot Bitcoin ETF would give investors exposure to the world’s largest cryptocurrency by market capitalisation without having to own it.

site_title: Vietnam’s economy expands 5.33% in Q3, but likely to miss full-year growth target
summary: Vietnam's economy expanded 5.33% in the third quarter, beating the previous three months' 4.05% growth but falling short of the full-year target. Retail sales rose 7.5% year-over-year, and consumer prices increased 3.66%. The January-September period saw a 4.42% growth, driven by the recovery in the tourism sector, improved manufacturing, and exports. The slower-than-expected growth suggests challenges ahead for the country's economy.

images.alt_text: Flags of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) at a hotel in Labuan Bajo, May 7, 2023.
Vietnam's property sector has come under pressure after a state crackdown on debt issuance following allegations of illegal activities.
Brazil's President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva says he wants to bring Mercosur members closer to Asian countries and highlighted there is room for trade with Vietnam to grow.
Luu Anh Tuan, Chairman of mining company VTRE in his Hanoi office with samples of rare earth oxides in Hanoi, Vietnam September 7, 2023. REUTERS/Francesco Guarascio
VNG is still aiming to carry out a New York listing, likely in the first half of 2024.

site_title: Japan’s August jobless rate flat at 2.7%
summary: Japan's unemployment rate remained steady at 2.7% in August, matching economists' median forecast. The seasonally adjusted unemployment rate and jobs-to-applicants ratio also remained unchanged. This marks the third consecutive month of stable jobless rates, indicating a stable labor market in Japan.

site_title: Long-serving US Democratic Senator Dianne Feinstein dies at 90
summary: US Democratic Senator Dianne Feinstein, 90, died Thursday night at her home in Washington, according to her office. Feinstein, a gun control advocate, spearheaded the first federal assault weapons ban and documented the CIA's torture of foreign terrorism suspects. She was a Washington trailblazer, becoming the first woman to head the Senate Intelligence Committee and the longest-serving woman senator. Feinstein's moderate-to-liberal record drew scorn from the left, but she remained committed to her values, defending the release of a report detailing CIA torture practices and criticizing Trump's handling of the 2020 election.

images.alt_text: A traffic barrier is seen front of the dome of the US Capitol as a government shutdown looms in Washington, DC on Sept 28, 2023.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly rise after Wall Street gains
summary: Asian markets mostly rose on Friday following Wall Street gains, driven by a drop in oil prices and US Treasury yields. Hong Kong jumped over 2% thanks to tech firms like Alibaba and JD.com, while Sydney, Singapore, Wellington, and Jakarta also rose. However, Tokyo and Manila declined. The optimism came after a smaller-than-expected rise in personal consumption and a still-healthy US economy, which may temper expectations of further interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man walks past a screen displaying the Hang Seng Index at Central district, in Hong Kong, China March 21, 2023. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu/File Photo

site_title: An entry fee may not be enough to save Venice from 20 million tourists
summary: Venice, a UNESCO World Heritage site, plans to implement a combination of strategies to tackle over-tourism, with an estimated 20 million visitors annually. Starting from 2024, day trippers will be charged a 5-euro fee, while overnight visitors will not. The city aims to manage visitor flow and reduce congestion, but the effectiveness of the fee remains uncertain, with some arguing it may not dissuade tourists. Research suggests that a combination of economic and non-economic measures, tailored to each destination, is the best approach to addressing over-tourism.

images.alt_text: (FILES) Visitors and tourists gather by the Grand Canal during the Venice carnival on February 11, 2023. UNESCO says not declaring Venice heritage 'in danger', on September 14, 2023. (Photo by Miguel MEDINA / AFP)

site_title: SIIC Environment appoints new CEO
summary: SIIC Environment, a water supply company listed on the Singapore Exchange, has appointed Zhu Dazhi as its new CEO. Zhu, 46, previously held deputy general manager positions at SIIC Management (Shanghai) and Shanghai Galaxy Investments. As CEO, he will oversee strategy, operations, and financial matters, and chair the executive committee and risk management committee. The appointment marks a new leadership chapter for the company.

images.alt_text: Generic pictures of the interior and exterior of SGX

site_title: SingLand to undertake partial redevelopment of Marina Square
summary: SingLand Group announced a partial redevelopment of Marina Square, part of its long-term strategy to unlock value from its assets. The project received provisional permission from the Urban Redevelopment Authority in Q3 and is currently working on obtaining further approvals. The timeline has not been determined, and SingLand shares ended flat at S$2.05 on the day of the announcement.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
The section of Marina Square along Raffles Link on Sept 13, 2023.

site_title: The first US land bubble and lessons from the Mount Tambora eruption
summary: The 1815 Mount Tambora eruption led to the US' first land price bubble, causing widespread speculation and ruin. The massive volcanic eruption cooled the planet by 0.5°C, repelling sunlight and disrupting climate patterns. This event holds lessons for investors today, highlighting the dangers of speculative bubbles and the impact of external factors on market prices. The eruption's effects on the climate were far more deadly than the estimated 70,000 lives lost, underscoring the importance of understanding the interconnectedness of economic and environmental systems.

images.alt_text: Mark J Higgins
Nike needs a new sneaker strategy
Some concepts from investment can help us understand the reasons to quit an existing job for a better one.

site_title: China economy improved further in September, satellite data shows
summary: China's economy showed signs of a stronger recovery in September, according to satellite data. Activity around shopping malls remained high, and cement manufacturing continued to increase. However, the property sector remains a drag on construction. Other indicators suggest a pickup in growth, with China's manufacturing PMI forecast to rise to 50.2 in September, marking an expansion in output. The country's economy is expected to meet its annual growth goal of slightly more than 5%.

images.alt_text: The country will boost macroeconomic controls and expand domestic demand in its push for “continuous improvement” of economy, says Chinese President Xi Jinping.

Chinese local government off-balance sheet debt, or hidden debt, is mostly concentrated in local government financing vehicles, set up to finance construction projects such as roads and social housing.
More Chinese are still reluctant to spend on overseas holidays, but how much they do spend domestically during this holiday will be a key gauge of consumer appetite.

FILE PHOTO: Paramilitary police officers stand guard in front of the headquarters of the People's Bank of China, the central bank (PBOC), in Beijing, China September 30, 2022. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Friday’s open, tracking Wall Street rally; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.3% on Friday, tracking a Wall Street rally, with gainers outnumbering losers 75 to 26. Banking stocks led the gains, including DBS, UOB, and OCBC, while Keppel Infrastructure Trust declined 3.2%. The rally follows overnight gains in the US, where stocks rose on easing Treasury yields and preliminary data showing German inflation rose less than expected.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Thai Beverage's incorporation of a new subsidiary in Hong Kong, SpiritsCo, comes after the group was reported to be exploring options for its spirits business.

site_title: Nike beats profit estimates as higher pricing pays off
summary: Nike topped Wall Street estimates for first-quarter profit, driven by higher prices of its sneakers and apparel. The company posted a profit of $1.45 billion, beating estimates of 75 US cents per share, despite missing revenue estimates. Inventories fell 10%, indicating successful reduction of excess product stocks ahead of the holiday season. Nike's strong brand and innovative products are expected to help it maintain premium pricing in a more promotional environment. Revenue rose 2% in North America, but fell short of expectations in China, where it rose 5% despite high youth unemployment and economic concerns.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Nike swoosh logo is seen outside the store on 5th Ave in New York, New York, U.S., March 19, 2019.   REUTERS/Carlo Allegri/File Photo

site_title: New Datapulse chairman’s cash offer turns unconditional with 60.3% shares acquired
summary: Datapulse Technology's chairman, Ang Kong Meng, has acquired 60.3% of the company's shares and warrants, making his cash offer unconditional. He had received 41.1 million shares and 4.4 million warrants as of September 28, bringing his total stake to 144.6 million shares and 54.4 million warrants. The offer price is S$0.09 per share, with warrants offered at S$0.01 apiece. The closing date has been set for October 3, with acceptances received after 5:30 pm on that day being rejected.

images.alt_text: Mia Pei
The offer price represents discounts of 3.2 per cent, 4.3 per cent and 5.3 per cent against the VWAPs per share for the three-month, six-month and 12-month period respectively.
After the board reconstitution, Ang Kong Meng has withdrawn his request to convene an EGM.

ICP, which has Travelodge Hotels (Asia) as one of its main operating subsidiaries, has received a requisition notice in part due to related party transactions between itself and Datapulse Technology, for which Aw Cheok Huat is Chairman.
The resolutions seek to remove four fellow board members and appoint two others to the board.

site_title: UK homes in debt on energy bills surges 36% this year: EDF Energy
summary: The UK's energy bills have surged 36% this year, with one in three households facing higher bills due to the upcoming price cap rise on October 1. EDF Energy reports that daily charges for direct debit customers have increased by 107% for electricity and 8.2% for gas since April 2021. To help vulnerable customers, EDF plans to roll back standing charges for 260,000 customers to pre-crisis levels this winter, citing the unfairness of the current system, which disproportionately affects smaller homes that use less power.

site_title: Philippines gives rice farmers US$224 Million in aid amid El Nino
summary: The Philippines is providing US$224 million in aid to rice farmers, primarily due to El Nino and rising production costs. Approximately 2.3 million farmers will receive 5,000 pesos each, sourced from excess rice import tariffs. An additional 700 million pesos will be allocated to 78,000 farmers under the social welfare department's cash subsidy program. The aid aims to mitigate the impact of higher rice prices on inflation in the country.

site_title: US consumer spending rises in August; underlying inflation slows
summary: US consumer spending rose 0.4% in August, driven by higher prices, with petrol prices peaking at $3.984 per gallon. Underlying inflation slowed, with year-on-year prices excluding food and energy falling below 4.0%. This moderation in inflation suggests the US economy may be cooling down, but the data still supports a strong economy. The revised July spending data showed a 0.9% increase, beating forecasts.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians on Wall Street in New York, US, on Tuesday, Aug. 8, 2023. Stocks fell around the world as traders rushed into bonds after a raft of news on China, Italy and the US fanned worries about the financial system and the global economy. Photographer: Victor J. Blue/Bloomberg

site_title: Inside JPMorgan’s year of being haunted by Jeffrey Epstein
summary: JPMorgan Chase agreed to pay $75 million to the US Virgin Islands, where Jeffrey Epstein had a private island, in a settlement related to the bank's ties to the deceased sex offender. The deal is a quarter of what the territory initially sought and comes after a year of intense scrutiny for JPMorgan. The bank's CEO, Jamie Dimon, took a combative approach, viewing the USVI as complicit in Epstein's crimes, and the firm ultimately agreed to implement measures to combat human trafficking. The settlement follows a separate agreement in June to pay $290 million to Epstein's victims.

images.alt_text: The US Virgin Islands says the enormous sum that propped up Epstein’s sex trafficking bolsters key allegations in its suit that JPMorgan knowingly benefited from the financier’s wrongdoing and ignored red flags.
The territory says it wants JPMorgan to pay a US$150 million civil fine, and give up at least US$40 million from its 15-year relationship with Epstein.

site_title: Hong Kong revives ‘living tradition’ of fire dragon dance
summary: Hong Kong revived its "living tradition" of the fire dragon dance after a three-year pandemic hiatus, with a raucous parade in the Tai Hang neighbourhood. Thousands of spectators watched as hundreds of volunteers danced and bounded along the streets, carrying a 67-metre dragon made of thousands of incense sticks. The ritual, recognized as an intangible cultural heritage, coincides with the Mid-Autumn Festival and is believed to have originated in 1880 to drive away the plague. The event marked a return to normalcy for the city, with many attendees expressing excitement and gratitude for the revival of the tradition.

images.alt_text: The nightlife campaign is the latest in a series of efforts to showcase Hong Kong and encourage consumption, which have so far fallen flat.
Under the scorching sun, 174 rowing teams competed aboard long boats topped by brightly coloured dragon heads.

Fhef ArChan Chan, the 37-year-old chef of Ho Lee Fook located in the glitzy Central district, is one of the city's most celebrated women chefs and among a handful of young innovators redefining Cantonese food.
Shops such as the popular Kwok Kam Kee bakery see long queues of festivalgoers eager to sample the Cheung Chau island's favorite sweet buns.

site_title: Our mysterious sense of smell and how AI can sniff out its secrets
summary: Researchers are studying the mysterious sense of smell, exploring how AI can be used to understand its secrets. The human nose can detect over 1 trillion smells, yet no two people perceive an odor the same way due to genetic differences in scent receptors. A graph neural network algorithm has been developed to map chemical structures to words describing smells, with potential applications in the fragrance industry. This technology aims to revolutionize olfaction, similar to how AI transformed drug discovery, and could change our relationship with this elusive sense.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Joyce Lian, founder of fragrance maker Scent Journer, sees her craft as a blend of art and science.

site_title: Money laundering accused Vang Shuiming denied bail; associates’ assets also under probe
summary: Vang Shuiming, accused of money laundering in a S$2.4 billion case, has three associates with S$412 million in assets under investigation. His brother, Wang Shuiting, is also wanted by Chinese authorities. Vang has various passports from countries he received through financial contributions, including one from Cambodia, which is currently unaccounted for. The prosecution applied for no bail, citing Vang's flight risk and substantial overseas assets. District Judge Brenda Tan denied bail, citing concerns about Vang's ability to relocate to another country.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah

site_title: Dealmakers see rebound after US activity buoys global M&A volumes
summary: US M&A activity rebounded in the third quarter, with dealmakers advising on deals worth $356.51 billion, a 35% jump from the same period last year. Global M&A volumes fell to $717.4 billion, down slightly from the previous year. Despite headwinds such as high-interest rates and increased antitrust scrutiny, dealmakers see a sustained recovery in the near term, driven by cash-flush buyers and a decrease in financing costs. Large private equity firms are preparing to get back to work, with a focus on take-private deals and debt-fuelled buyouts.

images.alt_text: Total M&A deals fell 65 per cent in Q3 to US$35 billion, the lowest 9M total since 2013.

site_title: Goldman pays US$3 million to CFTC over futures trading controls
summary: Goldman Sachs has agreed to pay US$3 million to settle allegations by the US Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) that the firm's internal controls failed to prevent a potentially disruptive futures trade. The CFTC alleged that Goldman's surveillance system malfunctioned and didn't properly suspend a transaction, and the firm omitted key information in responding to the agency's questions. The settlement follows a separate agreement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for sending incomplete trading data. Goldman did not admit or deny the allegations.

site_title: PM Lee highlights importance of high-quality, authoritative mainstream media at Zaobao centennial celebrations
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the importance of high-quality, authoritative mainstream media, citing Lianhe Zaobao as a prime example. At the centennial celebrations of Zaobao, PM Lee highlighted the newspaper's commitment to journalistic integrity, social cohesion, and providing a unique Singaporean perspective on global issues. He pledged the government's full confidence and support for Zaobao, ensuring its continued relevance and credibility in Singapore's multiracial society.

site_title: Philippines defending territory, not seeking trouble in South China Sea, says president
summary: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. defended the country's actions in the South China Sea, stating that the Philippines is not seeking trouble and will continue to defend its territory and fishers' rights. The country cut a 300-meter floating barrier installed by China, which blocked access to the disputed Scarborough Shoal. The US has backed Manila, with a senior defense official calling the move a "bold step." China has disputed the events, but observed less presence in the shoal since the cut. Marcos emphasized the Philippines will not surrender any territory to foreign powers.

images.alt_text: Journalists onboard a Philippines Coast Guard ship take photos of a China Coast Guard vessel, during a resupply mission for troops stationed at a grounded Philippines ship, in the South China Sea, Sept 8, 2023.

site_title: Biggest sell-off in 25 years hits Japan bonds as Bank of Japan loosens grip
summary: Japan's government bonds experienced their worst quarterly sell-off in over 25 years, with a 3% loss in the third quarter, due to the Bank of Japan's loosening grip on the market. Speculation suggests the BOJ will end its negative-rate policy early next year, despite leaders' assurances that stimulus is needed to support an economic recovery. This has led to a surge in benchmark 10-year and 30-year yields, and a global rout in debt, with investors fearing interest rates will stay high for longer.

images.alt_text: Tokyo data is a leading indicator of the national trend, suggesting the country’s inflationary momentum is also likely to continue softening.

site_title: The rise and fall of Evergrande founder Hui Ka Yan
summary: Chinese property developer China Evergrande Group's founder Hui Ka Yan, a 64-year-old billionaire, has been taken away by police and is being monitored under residential surveillance. The move suggests the company may have entered a new phase involving the criminal justice system, casting doubt on the future of the world's most indebted developer and Hui's own fate. Evergrande has faced setbacks to its restructuring plan, roiled financial markets, and raised the risk of a liquidation, with its stock price tumbling 99% from its peak in July 2020.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Hui Ka Yan, chairman of Evergrande Real Estate Group Ltd, the country's second-largest property developer by sales, attends a news conference on annual results in Hong Kong, China March 29, 2016.      REUTERS/Bobby Yip/File Photo
The three suspended entities had a combined market value of HK$16.7 billion on Wednesday, down from HK$81.4 billion before their recent trading resumptions.
Evergrande sits at the centre of a years-long property crisis that has hurt the Chinese economy and hammered confidence in the housing market.

site_title: Oil races towards US$100, but party may not last
summary: Oil prices have surged to a 10-month high, with Brent reaching $97.50 a barrel, driven by tight supply concerns and record global demand. However, experts warn that the recent rally may not last, with some predicting a potential "hard cap" of $100 a barrel. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) is expected to face a delicate balancing act in managing the oil market, as overly high prices could lead to increased demand destruction and harm economic growth. Despite this, oil prices are likely to moderate by year-end and potentially reach $83 a barrel in 2023, according to some forecasts.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
Brent crude futures closed US$2.59, or 2.8 per cent, higher at US$96.55 on Thursday.
Saudi Aramco is increasingly making deals in China to take advantage of the country’s huge demand.
Global oil benchmark Brent crude futures settled 50 cents higher at US$94.43 a barrel on Monday after rising as high as US$94.45.

site_title: Singapore stocks track Wall Street gains on Friday; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.3% or 10.42 points to 3,217.41 on Friday, tracking overnight gains on Wall Street. The STI is up 0.4% for the week. Gainers outnumbered losers 379 to 229, with 1.5 billion securities worth S$968 million changing hands. US markets ended higher overnight after a decline in US Treasury yields, while Chinese markets are stabilizing due to policy support.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Thai Beverage's incorporation of a new subsidiary in Hong Kong, SpiritsCo, comes after the group was reported to be exploring options for its spirits business.
On the Singapore Exchange,  gainers outnumber losers 75 to 26.

site_title: New Silkroutes places two units into creditors’ voluntary liquidation
summary: New Silkroutes Group's indirect subsidiaries, Healthsciences International (HSI) and HSI Dental, will be placed into creditors' voluntary liquidation following resolutions at an extraordinary general meeting. This move follows the sale of three clinics to Quantum Healthcare in February for S$1.7 million. Shares of New Silkroutes have been suspended since November 2021.

site_title: New Zealand consumer confidence lifts slightly, remains low
summary: New Zealand's consumer confidence index rose to 86.4 in September, a slight increase from August's 85.0, but still at low levels. Despite this, mortgage holders' confidence and house price expectations showed slight improvement. Economist Miles Workman attributed this to a decrease in pessimism among mortgage holders. The overall confidence level remains pessimistic, with a reading below 100 indicating pessimism.

site_title: Have some sympathy
summary: Sympathy, once considered a noble and humble emotion, has fallen out of favor, replaced by empathy. Empathy involves actively immersing oneself in another person's emotions and seeking to understand their perspective, whereas sympathy focuses on offering support from a distance. The shift in emphasis may be due to the rise of empathy as a superior sentiment, but critics argue that empathy requires personal experience to truly understand another's perspective. Some experts, like Pamela Paul, suggest that empathy can be "asking too much" and that a more rational, modulated response is needed, potentially involving a return to the idea of sympathy.

images.alt_text: Companies become toxic when managers stop having the conversations that make people feel seen, heard, appreciated, and invested.
Ask sincere questions, check your own biases, have empathy -- some ways to check if your business culture needs improvement.

site_title: UK economy stronger than first thought
summary: The UK economy has been revised upward, growing 2% in the second quarter, surpassing initial estimates and showing resilience despite the cost-of-living crisis. The country is now larger than previously thought, with GDP 1.8% above pre-Covid levels. Chancellor Jeremy Hunt attributed the growth to sticking to the plan to halve inflation this year, with the IMF forecasting the UK will grow more than Germany, France, and Italy in the longer term.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak claims that the UK has “stumbled into a (net zero) consensus about the future of the country that no one seems to be happy with”.

site_title: Citigroup has 'no room for bystanders' in reorganisation, CEO says
summary: Citigroup CEO Jane Fraser has announced the company's sweeping reorganisation, stating there's "no room for bystanders" as the bank embarks on its biggest overhaul in almost two decades. Discussions about layoffs have begun, with support staff in compliance and risk management potentially at risk. Fraser expects the US economy to achieve a soft landing, citing resilient consumer spending despite slowing pace among lower-income individuals. The company will update investors on estimated savings from the reorganisation in the fourth quarter.

images.alt_text: The transaction, the financial details of which were not immediately known, will also see Asia-focussed HSBC taking over “a few hundreds” of Citi’s China-based staff, said one of the sources.

site_title: BT Market Focus: Mixed trading week for markets (Ep 61)
summary: Singapore markets traded mixed this week ahead of a quiet economic calendar. Stocks performed relatively steadily, with no major news or events impacting the market. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a mixed trading week, with some sectors performing better than others. The podcast episode provides analysis from SGX and insights from The Business Times' newsdesk, offering a general overview of market movements and drivers.

images.alt_text: Interest rate and export data rule the week.
Which sectors benefited from an upbeat market this week?

site_title: SGX RegCo to investigate potential listing rule breaches by Regal International
summary: SGX RegCo will investigate potential breaches of listing rules by Regal International, a mainboard-listed company, following an independent review by Deloitte & Touche. The review found internal control weaknesses in Regal's acquisition and disposal procedures, as well as potential contraventions of the listing rules, including inaccurate disclosure and inadequate procedures. Regal's stock is currently suspended from trading, and the company will need to submit a proposal to SGX RegCo, providing clarity on its financial position and rectifying internal control weaknesses.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Shares of No Signboard have been suspended from trading since Jan 24, 2022

site_title: United Airlines to give conditional job offers to active-duty military pilots
summary: United Airlines plans to offer conditional job offers to active-duty US military pilots to join the airline as first officers upon completion of their service. The move aims to address the industry's pilot shortage, with the airline hiring over 4,000 new pilots in the past 24 months and expecting to add over 10,000 this decade. Military pilots won't need an airline transport pilot certificate at the time of application, but can obtain it before joining.

images.alt_text: The new China Eastern order is the largest order for the Chinese passenger plane, developed by Comac to rival Airbus' A320neo and Boeing’s 737 MAX single-aisle jet families.
The northern wing of Changi Airport's Terminal 2 opens on Thursday.
FILE PHOTO: An Airbus A321 aircraft of Bamboo Airways taxis at Noi Bai airport in Hanoi, Vietnam January 16, 2019. REUTERS/Kham/File Photo
Australia’s top court this month ruled that Qantas illegally sacked almost 1,700 ground workers during the pandemic, exposing the airline to compensation payments.
Air France-KLM says the deal will give it flexibility to allocate aircraft among its brands based on market or regulatory conditions.
Since pandemic travel curbs eased last year, a spike in flight cancellations, lost bags and telephone wait-times have frustrated Qantas passengers.
While Qantas Airways has emerged stronger from the pandemic, it has alienated its most important constituency: Australians.

site_title: Mortgage rates in US rise to highest in more than two decades
summary: US mortgage rates have reached their highest in over two decades, averaging 7.31% for a 30-year, fixed loan. This has led to increased pressure on potential buyers, causing a 7.1% decline in contracts to buy previously owned homes in August. Tightening inventory and rising mortgage rates are contributing to a record high in home values, with buyers facing a 58% increase in monthly mortgage payments since early 2022.

images.alt_text: White House chief economist Jared Bernstein speaks about the impact of a looming government shutdown with Economic Policy Institute president Heidi Shierholz, in Washington, Sept 27, 2023.
The US Senate voted 77-19 to begin debate on a measure that would fund the government through Nov 17.

site_title: Robert Kennedy Jr to run as independent, could complicate Trump, Biden 2024 contest
summary: US Presidential hopeful Robert F. Kennedy Jr. announced he will run as an independent in the 2024 election, potentially complicating the contest between President Joe Biden and Republican nominee Donald Trump. Kennedy had previously planned to challenge Biden for the Democratic nomination but now claims the party has "merged into one unit" with the Biden campaign. His independent bid could draw votes away from both Biden and Trump, and his campaign has raised concerns among Democrats about the potential impact on the election outcome.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden joins a picket line with members of the United Auto Workers union at a GM Service Parts Operations plant in Belleville, Michigan, Sept 26, 2023.
Robert F Kennedy Jr has set up a website to solicit donations and volunteers for a potential run.

site_title: Sony doubles down on virtual production business using its hardware muscle
summary: Sony is increasing its focus on virtual production business, which involves using LED panels to create immersive scenes for filmmakers and broadcasters. The company sees its edge from its hardware expertise and moviemaking experience, with the business growing by 35% annually. Sony is rolling out better panels and cameras, and offering "volumetric capture" services, and analysts believe the market is still in its infancy, providing opportunities for expansion. The company's virtual production business is expected to contribute a larger proportion of its sales in the future.

images.alt_text: “I will leave having been privileged to work on products that have touched millions of lives across the world,” says Jim Ryan, president and CEO of Sony Interactive Entertainment.
Sony cut its outlook on its image sensors and its movies divisions.
In April-June, Sony's operating profit slid 31 per cent to US$1.8 billion.

site_title: US government readies for imminent shutdown
summary: The US government is preparing for a potential shutdown on Saturday, with millions of federal employees and military personnel potentially furloughed or working without pay. The shutdown is due to a disagreement over a short-term funding deal and deep spending cuts, with a small group of hardline Republicans pushing back against short-term funding. If the shutdown occurs, hundreds of thousands of workers would be furloughed, and certain benefits like Social Security checks would not be affected, but workers could eventually stop showing up, impacting sectors like air travel.

images.alt_text: White House chief economist Jared Bernstein speaks about the impact of a looming government shutdown with Economic Policy Institute president Heidi Shierholz, in Washington, Sept 27, 2023.
The US Senate voted 77-19 to begin debate on a measure that would fund the government through Nov 17.
US stock markets sank more than one per cent on Tuesday amid the prospect for a government shutdown.
Unless House Speaker Kevin McCarthy succeeds in defusing the demands of Trumpist lawmakers, the US government will shut down at 12.01 am on Oct 1.

site_title: Credit Suisse sheds nearly 13% of workforce
summary: Credit Suisse has shed nearly 13% of its workforce, with 4,012 employees leaving the bank in the first half of 2023, up from 928 in the last six months of 2022. The bank's employee count fell to 33,968 at the end of June, down from 38,908 a year ago. This significant reduction in staff underscores the turmoil at the bank, which was taken over by UBS in a state-engineered rescue earlier this year.

images.alt_text: A decision has been made to wind down certain management arrangements, which may result in a loss of up to US$600 million in the third quarter of this year.
UBS has grown its share the most, accounting for 41 per cent of the market this year.
FILE PHOTO: Logos of Swiss banks Credit Suisse and UBS are seen before a news conference in Zurich Switzerland, August 30, 2023.  REUTERS/Denis Balibouse/File Photo

site_title: RBA to hold rate as Pimco sees hikes already hitting households
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) is expected to hold interest rates steady for a fourth consecutive meeting, citing concerns over the impact of rising borrowing costs on Australian households, which are the third most indebted in the developed world. The RBA will closely monitor inflation and the labor market, with economists predicting a relatively shallow downturn and a 50% chance of recession over the next 12 months. The decision comes as many Australian borrowers are being forced to switch to higher-rate loans due to expiring pandemic-era fixed mortgages.

images.alt_text: Australian banknotes in various denominations are arranged for a photograph in Sydney, Australia, on Monday, May 24, 2010. The Australian and New Zealand currencies slid for the sixth time in seven days against the U.S. dollar on concern Europe's debt crisis will  spread. Photographer: Ian Waldie/Bloomberg
Job vacancies fell by 8.9 per cent from the previous quarter to 390,400, the biggest decline and the lowest level in two years, figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics showed.
Retail sales have broadly flatlined over the year, rising just 1.5 per cent compared with a peak of 19.2 per cent year-on-year growth last August.

site_title: Singapore’s total population up 5% to record high of 5.92 million as at June
summary: Singapore's total population reached a record high of 5.92 million as of June, a 5% increase from the previous year. The citizen population grew 1.6% to 3.61 million, while permanent residents rose 3.7% to 540,000. The non-resident population grew 13.1% to 1.77 million, driven by increased hiring in the construction sector. The population is aging rapidly, with the proportion of 65-year-olds increasing to 19.1% and median age rising to 43.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
As the population ages, adding more migrants can help ensure Singapore remains economically vibrant.
The fall in resident employment is due to  the outflow from the end of seasonal hiring in food and beverage services and retail trade, says MOM.

The Ministry of Manpower holds a "guarded but hopeful" outlook for the labour market in 2023, with the emerging green economy bringing opportunities amid the global economic uncertainty, says Manpower Minister Tan See leng.

The resident population - comprising Singaporeans and permanent residents - increased in 2022, as more people who previously remained overseas continuously for 12 months or more returned to Singapore.

site_title: Europe: Shares snap five-day losing streak as miners gain
summary: Europe's shares snapped a five-day losing streak, rising 0.4% as mining stocks surged 2.2% led by Billerud AB's 5.0% gain. German inflation rose 4.3% in September, below expectations, boosting investor sentiment. Energy shares also gained 0.7% as crude prices jumped due to Opec+ output cuts. Utilities were the top losers, sliding 1.1%. The Stoxx 600 index rose, with Spain's IBEX index outperforming its peers.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.4 per cent to close at 33,666.34 on Thursday.

site_title: Uber, DoorDash lose bid to block New York City minimum wage for delivery workers
summary: A New York state judge rejected Uber, DoorDash, and Grubhub's bid to block a minimum wage law for app-based delivery workers. The law, set to take effect, requires companies to pay delivery workers $17.96 an hour, rising to nearly $20 in April 2025. The judge's decision allows the law to proceed pending the outcome of the companies' lawsuit, which they claim will lead to service area reductions and increased costs for customers and restaurants.

images.alt_text: Instacart's IPO was priced at US$30 per share after the company marketed it with a range of US$28 to US$30 per share.
Food delivery and ride hailing are Grab's primary sources of revenue.
Grab’s acquisition of foodpanda is likely to fall afoul of more than just competition commissions across the region, writes Garage correspondent Benjamin Cher.
Foodpanda's chief executive Jakob Angele said that the company needs to take a "more structured" approach in coming days.
A food delivery rider donning a Foodpanda raincoat with a GrabFood thermal food box. Grab could potentially buy part of Foodpanda's South-east Asian business.

site_title: Lawsuit against Clearbridge CEO, former unit in Jakarta withdrawn
summary: A civil lawsuit in Indonesia against Clearbridge Health CEO Jeremy Yee and former subsidiary Indo Genesis Medika (IGM) has been withdrawn. The lawsuit, filed by Indonesian biotechnology company Kreasi Putra Nusantara (KPN), was revoked on September 25 at the South Jakarta District Court. The case related to an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) of IGM held in 2022. Clearbridge shares rose 10.5% following the news. KPN was ordered to pay a court administration fee of 2.7 million rupiah.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai

site_title: Stocks to watch: ThaiBev, CDL, OUE Healthcare, Healthway Medical, Datapulse
summary: ThaiBev incorporated SpiritsCo, a new Hong Kong subsidiary, after exploring options for its spirits business. CDL purchased a portfolio of 25 Tokyo residential assets, its largest private rental sector transaction. OUE Healthcare's exit offer for Healthway Medical was declared unconditional after shareholders voted in favor of delisting. Datapulse Technology's chairman's offer to take the company private was also declared unconditional. Biolidics' sponsor UOB terminated its agreement, and shares of these companies resumed trading on Friday.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

A worker inspects boxes of Thai Beverage Pcl (ThaiBev) Chang beer as they move along the production line at the company's Beer Thip brewery in Bang Ban, Ayutthaya province, Thailand, on Friday, Oct. 5, 2012. ThaiBev, controlled by billionaire Charoen Sirivadhanabhakdi, was one of the companies that backed Heineken NV's offer to buy out Fraser & Neave Ltd.'s beer business. Photographer: Dario Pignatelli/Bloomberg

site_title: BlackRock joins Goldman in cloning JPMorgan’s blockbuster ETF
summary: BlackRock has launched the BlackRock Advantage Large Cap Income ETF (BALI), charging 35 basis points, to compete with JPMorgan Chase's top-performing JPMorgan Equity Premium Income ETF (JEPI). The new ETF tracks dividend-paying stocks and uses a call-writing strategy to generate income, following in JEPI's footsteps. With year-to-date inflows of $12.2 billion, JEPI has broken records and inspired a wave of copycat funds, including those from Goldman Sachs and REX Shares. BALI offers investors more growth potential, according to BlackRock.

images.alt_text: BlackRock increasingly seeks to position itself as a one-stop shop for investors offering equity, bond and money-market funds as well as alternative assets.
The deal aims to reduce combined claims of US$10 billion down to about US$2.5 billion of new bonds.
The select committee on China alleges BlackRock has five funds with more than US$429 million invested in Chinese companies acting against US interests.

site_title: US job market has been resilient in current tightening cycle: Federal Reserve’s Barkin
summary: Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond President Thomas Barkin stated that the US job market is resilient despite a tightening cycle, but inflation must decrease to ensure good job market prospects. Evidence suggests the job market will not suffer as much as in past Fed efforts to cool inflation. Barkin attributed the resilience to the job market to the Fed's efforts to manage inflation and maintain economic growth.

site_title: US: Stocks give up some gains as government shutdown nears
summary: US stocks closed mixed on Friday, reversing earlier gains ahead of a likely government shutdown starting this weekend. The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished down 0.5% at 33,507.50, while the S&P 500 ended down 0.3% at 4,288.13. A government shutdown, which would be the first since 2019, is expected to impact the economy, but it's not seen as a major factor driving stock prices. Investors remain cautious due to the Federal Reserve's ongoing battle against inflation, with interest rates remaining higher for longer.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - AUGUST 31: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange during morning trading on August 31, 2023 in New York City. Stocks on the major indexes opened up high amid the release of inflation data and Department of Labor’s jobs report. Both figures come weeks before the Federal Reserve holds their next interest-rate policy meeting. The gains have helped the major indexes cut their monthly losses.   Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Michael M. Santiago / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)
The S&P 500 opened higher by 28.48 points or 0.66 per cent at 4,328.18.

site_title: Epic Games is laying off roughly 900 employees
