summary: Epic Games is laying off approximately 900 employees, or 16% of its staff, amid a slowdown in the videogame industry due to inflation-weary gamers. The job cuts were announced in a memo to staff. The move comes as the company faces challenges from new entrants like Warner Bros Discovery and Apple's App Store rules. Epic Games is also in a legal battle with Apple since 2020 over antitrust rules.

images.alt_text: Foodpanda's chief executive Jakob Angele said that the company needs to take a "more structured" approach in coming days.
Roku has raised its quarterly revenue forecast, a sign that ad spending was continuing to improve thanks to cooling inflation and hopes of a pause in interest rate hikes.
T-Mobile's jobs cuts over the next five weeks will target corporate and back-office roles, and some technology jobs.
Google staff protesting against alleged union busting and layoffs outside the Kings Cross headquarters in London, Britain, April 4, 2023.

site_title: Oil eases 1%, reversing rally, on profit taking, interest rate worries
summary: Oil prices eased about 1% on Thursday, reversing a rally, due to profit-taking and concerns about high interest rates weighing on demand. Brent December futures fell 1.3% to settle at US$93.10 per barrel, while November futures fell 1.2% to US$95.38 per barrel. The decline followed 10-month highs, with traders taking profits after prices surged.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures closed US$2.59, or 2.8 per cent, higher at US$96.55 on Thursday.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher on softer inflation data
summary: US stocks opened higher on Friday, September 29, after a softer-than-expected inflation reading kept hopes alive for a pause in the Federal Reserve's rate hikes. The S&P 500 rose 0.66%, the Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.64%, and the Nasdaq Composite increased 1.03%. The positive start on Wall Street comes after a weaker-than-expected inflation metric, which may indicate a slowdown in the US economy.

site_title: China is selling so much to Russia that containers are piling up
summary: China's trade with Russia surged 37% in the first seven months of 2023, reaching $134.1 billion, with Chinese exports to Russia increasing by 73% to $62.54 billion. However, the influx of Chinese goods has led to a massive buildup of shipping containers in Russia, with 150,000 excess containers piling up at rail depots. This imbalance has a detrimental impact on container logistics, with used containers selling for less than half the price in Moscow compared to other parts of the world.

images.alt_text: The Cyberspace Administration of China (CAC) says it is considering waiving data export security assessments  for activities that do not contain personal information or important data.

site_title: China’s Nio explores investment, tech alliances with Mercedes: sources
summary: China's electric vehicle startup Nio has held exploratory talks with Mercedes-Benz for a potential tie-up, with Mercedes considering investing in Nio in exchange for technology and research and development capabilities. The talks have faced resistance within Mercedes, citing concerns over brand image and shareholder harmony. Nio has increased investment in self-developed technologies, including chips and batteries, amid efforts to survive a consolidating domestic industry. The talks align with a trend of closer collaboration between legacy automakers and new players as Chinese EV companies seek to sell innovations to established automakers.

images.alt_text: Nio, which is listed in New York, Hong Kong and Singapore said it has no reportable capital raising activity currently.
William Li, founder and chief executive officer of Chinese electric vehicle maker Nio, unveils the Nio Phone during a launch event for the company's first mobile phone in Shanghai.
The US$1 billion fundraising came three months after Nio raised US$738.5 million from Abu Dhabi government-backed firm CYVN Investments RSC through a share placement.
The Chinese company said that the notes will be its senior, unsecured obligations upon issue.
Nio proposes to issue US$500 million of convertible senior notes due 2029, with another US$500 million note offering due 2030.

site_title: Bankman-Fried may face 'very long sentence' if convicted, judge says
summary: US District Judge Lewis Kaplan warned Sam Bankman-Fried, the founder of bankrupt cryptocurrency exchange FTX, that he may face a "very long sentence" if convicted of stealing billions of dollars in customer deposits to plug losses at Alameda Research. Bankman-Fried, 31, faces seven counts of fraud and conspiracy and could receive up to 110 years in prison. His trial starts on October 3 and could last up to six weeks.

images.alt_text: The company and committees representing both US and foreign creditors have agreed that FTX should sell as much as US$100 million of crypto a week, depending on the market prices.
FTX was one of the world’s largest digital-asset trading platforms prior to its bankruptcy in November.

site_title: GameStop names billionaire Ryan Cohen as CEO in turnaround push
summary: GameStop has appointed billionaire Ryan Cohen as its new CEO and chairman, aiming to turn around the struggling videogame retailer. Cohen, who had previously joined the board and oversaw the company's pivot to e-commerce, will focus on brick-and-mortar stores and using them for online orders. The move follows Cohen's initial aggressive push for an online-focused model, which has been tempered. Despite concerns about the slow pace of change and Cohen's mixed record as an activist investor, GameStop's quarterly earnings showed a smaller-than-expected loss and revenue that beat estimates.

images.alt_text: GameStop has been hobbled by the video-game industry’s rapid shift to online distribution of games from physical discs.
GameStop has struggled to adapt to the increasing share of game sales conducted online and away from stores.

site_title: Uber Freight adds AI tools to compete in shrinking cargo market
summary: Uber Freight has introduced Insights AI, a tool that uses artificial intelligence to predict late shipments and suggest alternative routes, aiming to boost efficiency in the cargo market. The AI offering is part of the company's efforts to transform into a full-service transportation handler, following its US$2.25 billion acquisition of Transplace in 2021. With the goal of providing users with real-time insights to optimize their operations, Insights AI will enable shippers to analyze their own data and compare it to peer groups, increasing the potential for increased sales from software as a service.

images.alt_text: Food delivery and ride hailing are Grab's primary sources of revenue.
Uber’s cost controls ranging from layoffs to lower transaction costs and maintaining a steady headcount have helped the company maintain its target to post operating income profitability this year.
Nelson Chai’s pending departure caps a nearly five-year tenure for the financial-industry veteran that has included important milestones.

site_title: US: Stocks rally as Treasury yields retreat
summary: US stocks rallied on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 0.4% to 33,666.34, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes gaining 0.6% and 0.8%, respectively. The retreat in 10-year Treasury yields, a key benchmark for interest rates, brought relief to investors amid concerns about rising yields and inflation. Analysts expect the Federal Reserve to hold interest rates steady before cutting them next year, citing low initial jobless claims.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - SEPTEMBER 05: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) on September 05, 2023 in New York City. Stocks were down in morning trading as investors weigh recent economic news out of China and a surge in oil prices.   Spencer Platt/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by SPENCER PLATT / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: US adopts plan to phase out single-use plastics at national parks
summary: The US government has adopted a plan to phase out single-use plastics at national parks by 2032. The Interior Department, which oversees federally managed lands, aims to eliminate single-use plastics from water bottles, bags, and utensils. The move follows a 2022 initiative by Secretary Deb Haaland, which aimed to phase out single-use plastics within a decade. The plan includes installing water bottle filling stations, increasing recycling, and working with concession operators to reduce plastic waste. The Interior Department plans to update the plan in 2024 with step-down targets and additional details.

images.alt_text: In recent years, the restaurant industry has invested heavily in recyclable and biodegradable packaging, and some companies are not happy about having to pivot away from that.
Lego found that bricks made from recycled polyethylene terephthalate (RPET), would lead to higher carbon emissions.
Annual production of plastics has more than doubled in the past 20 years, to reach 460 million tons.
Experts estimate that 44 per cent of ocean plastic consists of plastic bags, bottles, food containers, cutlery and wrappers.

China’s petrochemical capacity will make up nearly a quarter of the world’s total by the end of this year, according to ICIS data. That’s a jump from five years ago, when it comprised just 14 per cent of global manufacturing capacity.

site_title: Oil settles lower but ends quarter up 28% on tight global supply
summary: Oil prices settled lower on Friday, with Brent November futures down 7 cents to $95.31 per barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate crude down 92 cents to $90.97 per barrel. Despite this, oil prices ended the quarter up 28% due to Opec+ production cuts. Investors took profits amid macroeconomic concerns, with prices forecast to average $89.85 per barrel in the fourth quarter and $86.45 in 2024. The US oil and gas rig count fell to its lowest since February 2022, indicating slowing production growth.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A long exposure image shows the movement of a crude oil pump jack in the Permian Basin in Loving County, Texas, U.S., November 23, 2019. Picture taken November 23, 2019. REUTERS/Angus Mordant/File Photo
The oil price surge is due to supply cuts by the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) and its allies.

site_title: Adobe hit with US$33.8 million patent verdict over digital licensing technology
summary: A US jury has awarded ViaTech Technologies nearly US$33.8 million in a patent verdict against Adobe, stating that Adobe's digital licensing technology for software like Acrobat and Photoshop infringes on ViaTech's patent rights. Adobe has expressed disappointment with the verdict, stating it will "explore all post-trial and appellate options."

images.alt_text: Adobe is adding generative AI features throughout its products.
The original commitments, which are announced in July, aim at ensuring that AI's power is not used for destructive purposes.
UK CMA says Adobe will not offer any proposals to address its concerns.
“We’re worried this deal could stifle innovation and lead to higher costs for companies that rely on Figma and Adobe’s digital tools,” CMA says.
Adobe says it will start offering Firefly to its corporate customers as part of Adobe Express, a tool aimed at helping business users who do not specialise in design to create images and documents.

site_title: Asian Development Bank unveils capital moves to boost lending by US$100 billion over a decade
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has unveiled new capital reforms, adjusting its risk appetite to expand lending commitments by nearly 40% to $36 billion annually over 10 years, unlocking $100 billion in new financing capacity. This move preserves its AAA credit rating while allowing it to tackle climate change, pandemics, and other global crises. The ADB's efforts follow similar measures by the World Bank, which aims to increase lending by $50 billion over a decade.

images.alt_text: The Cebu Cordova Link Expressway in Cebu City, the Philippines.  Asia Pacific will need sizable investments in industrials, utilities, waste management, renewables, data centres, education services, airports, highways and railways.

UN Secretary General Antonio Guterres talks to the media during a press conference on sidelines of the 43rd Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) Summit in Jakarta, Indonesia, 07 September 2023. Indonesia hosts the 43rd ASEAN Summit and related summits from 05 to 07 September

site_title: Geopolitical gyrations needed to deliver on net zero
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) emphasizes the need for stronger international cooperation to achieve net zero by the 2030s, particularly between the US and China, due to the epic scale of the climate change challenge. The IEA calls for a tripling of renewable power capacity, a 75% reduction of methane emissions, and a doubling of energy-efficiency enhancements. The agency also projects that clean-energy investment must rise from $1.8 trillion this year to $4.5 trillion annually by the early 2030s. A window of opportunity remains for achieving the Paris Agreement's target, but geopolitics could hinder progress, requiring "remarkable and enlightened diplomacy" to navigate the challenges ahead.

images.alt_text: In the Asia-Pacific, financing the managed phase-out of coal-fired power plants is one of the most pressing issues within the global energy transition, says Fang Eu-Lin, PwC Singapore’s sustainability and climate change leader.
Wealthy countries must now reach carbon neutrality in around 2045, five years early, and China should speed up by a decade to 2050.

site_title: OUE Healthcare’s exit offer for Healthway Medical turns unconditional in all respects
summary: OUE Healthcare's exit offer for Healthway Medical has turned unconditional after shareholders voted overwhelmingly in favor of delisting and constitution amendments, with over 99% of votes cast in favor. The exit offer, subject to Singapore Exchange approval, will result in Healthway Medical's delisting from the Catalist board on or after the close of the offer.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
OUE Healthcare's offer to privatise Healthway Medical garners acceptances amounting to 50.47 per cent of the company's total issued shares.

site_title: Abu Dhabi’s IHC to sell stake in Adani units
summary: IHC, Abu Dhabi's conglomerate, plans to sell its stakes in Adani Green Energy and Adani Energy Solutions, citing a portfolio rebalancing strategy. The sale, through units Green Energy Investment Holding and Green Transmission Investment Holding, comes after a $2 billion investment by IHC in the two companies last year. The exact buyer and extent of the investment are undisclosed, but the deal is part of IHC's efforts to divest from certain assets.

site_title: Biden warns US democracy in peril from ‘extremist’ Trump
summary: US President Joe Biden warned that democracy in the US is in peril due to "extremist" Donald Trump, who is driven by "vengeance and vindictiveness". Biden accused Trump of attacking the free press and rule of law, and urged Americans to stand up against threats to democracy. The warning came as Biden steered clear of commenting on Trump's multiple criminal indictments, but emphasized the country's risk of losing its democracy if Trump is re-elected. Biden also hailed the legacy of late Arizona senator John McCain, a Republican who was critical of Trump.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden joins a picket line with members of the United Auto Workers union at a GM Service Parts Operations plant in Belleville, Michigan, Sept 26, 2023.

FILE PHOTO: U.S. President Joe Biden speaks about his $2 trillion infrastructure plan during an event to tout the plan at Carpenters Pittsburgh Training Center in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, U.S., March 31, 2021. REUTERS/Jonathan Ernst
US President Joe Biden joins striking members of the United Auto Workers on the picket line outside the GM's Willow Run Distribution Centre in Belleville, Wayne County, Michigan, Sept 26, 2023.
The ruling by Judge Arthur Engoron is a setback for Donald Trump ahead of a trial in the civil case due to begin on Monday.

“The United States is committed to ensuring an Indo-Pacific region that is free, open, prosperous, and secure. We’re committed to working with all the nations around this table to achieve that goal,” Joe Biden says.
Moody’s rates the US government “Aaa” with a stable outlook, the highest creditworthiness it assigns to borrowers.
US President Joe Biden  will host a second summit with Pacific island leaders this week.

site_title: Issue 68: MAS champions carbon credits for retiring coal plants early; S-E Asia’s urgent adaptation needs
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) has proposed a framework for transition credits, which would allow investors of coal-fired plants to recover lost value if the plants are retired early. The credits could be issued to cover the economic gap between the plant's current value and its value after early retirement. MAS is seeking a pilot project to test the idea, which aims to accelerate coal phase-outs and support sustainable finance. The initiative also addresses the urgent need for adaptation measures in Southeast Asia, where floods, droughts, and heat risks are significant.

images.alt_text: Kenneth Lim
Aerial view show a deforested area of Amazonia rainforest in Labrea, Amazonas state, Brazil, on Sep 15, 2021.
Thirty per cent of the proceeds from the bond has been allocated to finance capital expenditure on the Cross Island and Jurong Region lines.
Joko Widodo says Indonesia has tremendous potential for carbon reduction efforts and its carbon market could grow to reach 3,000 trillion rupiah.
Jakarta, which has been battling worsening air quality for years, topped global pollution rankings several times last month, according to Swiss air quality monitor IQAir.
Annual production of plastics has more than doubled in the past 20 years, to reach 460 million tons.

site_title: Eurozone core inflation hits 1-year low, backing ECB pause
summary: Eurozone core inflation has hit a 1-year low of 4.5%, below expectations, supporting the European Central Bank's decision to keep interest rates on hold. This follows a drop in energy costs and a sharp slowdown in services inflation, which moderated to 4.3% from 5.2% in August. The data suggests that the ECB's campaign of interest rate hikes may be nearing its end, with economists and policymakers expecting a pause in further rate increases.

images.alt_text: A man shelters from the rain under an umbrella as he walks past the Euro currency sign in front of the former European Central Bank (ECB) building in Frankfurt am Main, western Germany, on July 27, 2023 ahead of thr ECB's monthly announcement on eurozone monetary policy. (Photo by Kirill KUDRYAVTSEV / AFP)
Bank lending to households rises just 1.0 per cent after 1.3 per cent in July, according to ECB.

site_title: Biolidics chairman to step down at later date amid search for replacement
summary: Biolidics chairman Gavin Mark McIntyre will step down on November 30, citing a desire to allow for a smooth handover of duties. The decision was made at the request of the company's board, which will use the additional time to identify and appoint a replacement. The move comes as the company also seeks a new sponsor, after United Overseas Bank terminated its continuing sponsorship agreement citing "commercial reasons."

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai

site_title: Microsoft-Google peace deal broke down over search on Duo
summary: A 5-year peace deal between Microsoft and Google broke down over their competing web-search businesses, specifically the Surface Duo smartphone. Microsoft was required to place a Google search widget on the device, rejecting its own Bing search engine, and prohibited from instructing users to switch to Bing. The companies' disagreement led to a "compromise" allowing both search engines to appear, but ultimately, the deal expired in 2021. This development is part of the US government's antitrust lawsuit against Google, which alleges the company has monopolized the online search market through contracts with Apple and smartphone makers.

images.alt_text: Apple has used Google as the default search engine in its Safari browser since 2003.
Thai PM Stretta says that Tesla is looking into an electric vehicle manufacturing facility while Microsoft and Google are looking at data centres.

site_title: Americans saved US$1.1 trillion less than previously thought from 2017-2022
summary: US households saved an estimated $1.1 trillion less than previously thought from 2017-2022, according to revised government data. The reduction stems from an accounting adjustment that lowered personal income from mutual funds and real estate investment trusts, resulting in an average savings rate of 8.3% annually, down from a previously estimated 9.4%. This change does not significantly impact the overall economic landscape, with inflation and GDP growth remaining largely unchanged.

images.alt_text: The Conference Board says its consumer confidence index drops to 103.0 this month from an upwardly revised 108.7 in August.

site_title: Xi says China to step up efforts to meet annual economic goals
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping vowed to step up efforts to meet the country's annual economic and social development targets, focusing on boosting macroeconomic controls and expanding domestic demand. Xi pledged to expand job creation, prevent major risks, and bring "more resilience and vitality" to the economy, which is projected to expand 5% in 2023. This comes as China's economy remains fragile, with property being a major challenge. Xi also reiterated China's push for peaceful development of cross-strait ties and unification with Taiwan.

site_title: Two companies lodge preliminary Catalist listing documents as IPO interest returns
summary: Two Singapore companies, Winking Studios and Sheffield Green, have lodged preliminary listing documents for Catalist, a junior stock exchange, signaling a potential return to the local initial public offerings (IPO) market. The companies aim to raise funds to expand globally, make strategic acquisitions, and explore AI in their respective sectors. If successful, this would bring the total number of IPOs on the Singapore market this year to five, following earlier listings of Ever Glory United, Pasture Holdings, and YKGI.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
US listings are perking up heading into the final three months of the year.

site_title: US pending home sales index slides to lowest level since 2020
summary: The US pending home sales index has slid to its lowest level since April 2020, down nearly 19% compared to a year earlier. The National Association of Realtors' index of contract signings fell 7.1% to 71.8 in August, citing higher mortgage rates and unaffordable housing markets as major contributors. Experts believe increased housing inventory and better interest rates are needed to revive the housing market.

images.alt_text: New home sales plunged 8.7 per cent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 675,000 units last month, according to the Commerce Department.
Existing home sales slip 0.7 per cent last month to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.04 million units
The National Association of Realtors (NAR) housing affordability index is unchanged at 87.8 in July, matching the lowest level in data back to 1989.
High mortgage rates have pushed homeownership further out of reach for many Americans.
US Commerce Department says a surge in new home sales, rising by 4.4 per cent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 714,000 units in July.
Home resales, which account for a big chunk of US housing sales, fall 16.6 per cent on a year-on-year basis in July.
People and companies have left California, or chosen not to move there, because housing is so much more expensive than in most of the US.
Many US homeowners lock in cheaper mortgage rates before borrowing costs start surging last year, leaving them reluctant to give up those loans.

site_title: Singapore’s vanishing S$3 chicken rice stokes inflation angst
summary: In Singapore, the rising cost of living has led to a shortage of affordable food options, particularly at hawker centers. Prices for dishes like chicken rice have increased by over 12% in the past two years, making it difficult for low-income residents like 69-year-old Zuo Jing Fa to afford meals. The government has introduced measures to support hawkers, including rent discounts and vouchers, but concerns remain about the impact of rising costs on the country's socio-economic safety net and the livelihoods of low-income Singaporeans.

images.alt_text: The package includes an additional S$200 in CDC Vouchers for all Singaporean households.
For the full year, the most likely outcome is for the economy to grow between 0 per cent and 0.9 per cent.
Food inflation rises/slips to x per cent on the year in July, against x per cent in June.

site_title: ThaiBev incorporates wholly-owned SpiritsCo subsidiary in Hong Kong
summary: Thai Beverage (ThaiBev) has incorporated a wholly-owned subsidiary, SpiritsCo, in Hong Kong with an initial share capital of HK$300,000. The investment was funded by internally-generated funds and follows reports in March that ThaiBev was exploring options for its spirits business, including an initial public offering in Singapore. This move comes after ThaiBev previously attempted to bring its brewery business, housed under BeerCo, to list in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim

site_title: Foreign investors dump US$6.1 billion of Japan stocks, most since SVB collapse
summary: Foreign investors have dumped US$6.1 billion of Japanese stocks, the largest amount since the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank in March, amid signs of risk aversion. The sales come as the market becomes more expensive after a strong rally, with the Topix index falling 2.2% last week. The increased selling is attributed to a rise in US interest rates, which has hurt sentiment and led foreign investors to reduce risk exposure and take profits. Japanese individual investors, however, have bought a net 661 billion yen, the most since late March.

images.alt_text: The Nikkei was down 1.73 per cent at 31,813.01, its lowest level since Aug 28, by Thursday's midday break.

site_title: US Q2 GDP growth unrevised at 2.1%; weekly jobless claims edge higher
summary: US GDP growth remained steady at 2.1% in the second quarter, driven by a resilient labor market and strong wage gains. Estimates for the July-September quarter are as high as 4.9%. The economy is being supported by a strong labor market, but a looming government shutdown and ongoing strike by the United Auto Workers union may sap momentum in the fourth quarter.

images.alt_text: White House chief economist Jared Bernstein speaks about the impact of a looming government shutdown with Economic Policy Institute president Heidi Shierholz, in Washington, Sept 27, 2023.

site_title: Chinese billionaire’s Bright Ruby-linked unit bags Far East Shopping Centre for about S$910 million
summary: Chinese billionaire Du Shuanghua's unit, Bright Ruby Resources, has secured the collective sale of Far East Shopping Centre for approximately S$910 million, below the guide price of S$928 million. The deal, subject to conditions, involves a 20% increase in gross floor area under the Strategic Development Incentive (SDI) scheme, allowing for a potential redevelopment of the site. This follows Bright Ruby's previous purchases of the Collyer Quay building and the Grand Park Orchard hotel.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
Located at 545 Orchard Road, the 999-year shopping centre sits on a site spanning 36,014 square feet zoned for commercial use.

site_title: Mubadala in talks with Temasek for stake buy in India's Manipal Hospitals
summary: Mubadala, an Abu Dhabi sovereign fund, is in talks with Temasek to acquire a stake of less than 10% in India's Manipal Hospitals for approximately $500 million, valuing the deal at $5 billion. The talks come as investor interest grows in India's booming healthcare market. Temasek, which owns 59% of Manipal, aims to retain its majority stake and sell a small portion to Mubadala, which is looking to expand its investments in the region, particularly in the Middle East and healthcare sector.

images.alt_text: The facade of the first flagship hospital of Manipal Healthcare Enterprises in Bengaluru, in South India.
The acquisition will bring Temasek’s total stake in the hospital chain to 59 per cent.

site_title: US dollar retreats from 10-month high, heat still on yen, euro
summary: The US dollar retreated from its 10-month high against a basket of peers, falling 0.3% to 106.3, after rising to a 10-month high on Wednesday. The euro rebounded 0.33% to US$1.0537, still near its January low of US$1.0482. The euro is weakening due to the stronger US dollar and the cyclical divergence between the US and European economies. The US dollar index is on track for its 11th straight week of gains, with yields extending their rise.

site_title: Biolidics’ sponsor UOB ends continuing sponsorship agreement
summary: Biolidics' sponsor, United Overseas Bank (UOB), has terminated its continuing sponsorship agreement with the company due to "commercial reasons". The new sponsor will be sought, with UOB remaining as sponsor until Dec 31 or a mutually agreed date. UOB stated it was unaware of any non-compliance with Catalist rules that had not been previously announced. Biolidics shares closed unchanged at S$0.013 before the announcement.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower on rate jitters; Powell on deck
summary: US stocks opened lower on Thursday, September 28, amid concerns over prolonged restrictive monetary policy. The Dow Jones fell 30.83 points, or 0.09%, to 33,519.44, while the S&P 500 dropped 4.86 points, or 0.11%, to 4,269.65. Investors are assessing economic data and awaiting Federal Reserve chief Jerome Powell's remarks.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - SEPTEMBER 05: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) on September 05, 2023 in New York City. Stocks were down in morning trading as investors weigh recent economic news out of China and a surge in oil prices.   Spencer Platt/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by SPENCER PLATT / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Australian dollar pinned near fresh 11-mth low, support shaky
summary: The Australian dollar is near a fresh 11-month low, hovering at US$0.6367, as Treasury yields surge and local retail sales and jobs data suggest an extended rate pause. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to hold rates steady in October, but may raise rates in May next year to keep up with other central banks.

images.alt_text: Wednesday's data vindicate the Reserve Bank of Australia’s stance that further tightening may be necessary and that it’s too early to declare victory against inflation.

site_title: Evergrande says chairman under criminal investigation
summary: Evergrande Group chairman Hui Ka Yan is under criminal investigation, according to the company, amid a debt-restructuring plan. The shares were suspended after a report of Hui's police surveillance, raising concerns about the company's future and potential liquidation. With over $300 billion in liabilities, Evergrande is a key player in China's struggling property sector, which accounts for a quarter of the economy. The company's restructuring plan now faces uncertainty, and analysts predict a higher risk of liquidation, potentially prompting government intervention to prevent systemic crisis.

images.alt_text: The three suspended entities had a combined market value of HK$16.7 billion on Wednesday, down from HK$81.4 billion before their recent trading resumptions.

site_title: FSG sell minority stake in Liverpool to private equity fund
summary: Liverpool FC has sold a minority stake to US private equity group Dynasty Equity, valued between $100 million and $200 million. The investment will help reduce debts incurred during the Covid pandemic, fund infrastructure projects, and enhance the transfer market. Liverpool owners Fenway Sports Group, led by John Henry, initially denied the club's sale but acknowledged the possibility of new shareholders. The investment maintains FSG's long-term commitment to the club, ensuring its financial resiliency and future growth.

images.alt_text: Liverpool's Portuguese striker #20 Diogo Jota (2nd L) celebrates with teammates after scoring his team third goal during the English League Cup third round football match between Liverpool and Leicester City at Anfield in Liverpool, north west England on September 27, 2023. site_title: China launches first cross-sea bullet train line near Taiwan Strait
summary: China has launched its first cross-sea bullet train line, the 277-km Fuzhou-Xiamen-Zhangzhou railway, near the Taiwan Strait. The high-speed rail, which can reach speeds of 350 km/h, will reduce travel time between Fuzhou and Xiamen to under an hour. The move aims to enhance investment opportunities and facilitate travel between China and Taiwan, although Taiwan has dismissed previous plans to link the island to the rail network, citing concerns over a Chinese debt trap.

images.alt_text: Indonesian President Joko Widodo (right) points towards a display showing the speed during a trial of the new Bandung-Jakarta high-speed train on Sep 13, 2023.

Joko Widodo, Indonesia's president, at Tegalluar station ahead of an interview in front of Jakarta-Bandung High-Speed Railway trains in West Java, Indonesia, on Tuesday, Sept. 19, 2023. Indonesia’s outgoing president said Southeast Asia’s largest economy can attain its fastest expansion in three decades under the next leader, who will build on the reforms he’s trying to cement. Photographer: Rosa Panggabean/Bloomberg
The 142-kilometre railway connecting the capital Jakarta to the city of Bandung is now to be commercially launched on Oct 1.
KCIC says more time was needed to ensure passengers’ safety and comfort.
An artist's impression of the Malaysia High Speed Rail (HSR) station in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.

site_title: China appoints Lan Foan as new finance ministry party chief
summary: China has appointed Lan Foan, 61, as the new finance ministry party chief, paving the way for him to become the next finance minister. Lan, previously the party chief of Shanxi province, will replace Liu Kun, who remains finance minister despite the change. The appointment suggests a potential shift towards a more expansionary policy stance, according to Zhiwei Zhang, chief economist of Pinpoint Asset Management.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People's Bank of China (PBOC) Deputy Governor Pan Gongsheng speaks at a news conference in Beijing, China March 3, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo/File Photo

site_title: Supreme Court sides Singapore coal trader in sanctions lawsuit against JPMorgan
summary: The Singapore Court of Appeal has ruled in favor of Kuvera Resources, a coal trader, in a lawsuit against JPMorgan, with the court upholding the validity and enforceability of a sanctions clause in a contract. The lawsuit, filed in 2022, sought $2.42 million in damages after JPMorgan refused to pay Kuvera under two letters of credit. The decision marks the first time a Singapore court has examined a sanctions clause in a contract.

images.alt_text: Mia Pei

China’s anti-espionage and data laws, as well as raids on US consultancies, have rattled investors.
Huawei last month released a premium smartphone powered by an advanced chip that it designed, and which was made by Shanghai-based Semiconductor Manufacturing International.

site_title: Audi Q8 Sportback e-tron review: Valuable joules
summary: The Audi Q8 Sportback e-tron has been put through a series of energy efficiency tests, with the author discovering that it can achieve a range of 683 km on a single charge. The car's updated batteries, rear motor, brakes, and software enable it to cover up to 600 km without recharging. The author's frugal driving methods, such as using cruise control and turning off the air-conditioning, allowed them to achieve this impressive range, surpassing the car's claimed 600 km.

images.alt_text: The LM's boxy body creates room for a vast interior, but Lexus has given it touches of opulence and privacy too.
Some radical improvements to the stylish Polestar 2 make it faster and more efficient.
The i4 eDrive35's exemplary fluidity is paired with supple ride quality.

site_title: Singapore Writers Fest: ‘Bolder, weirder, more niche’
summary: The Singapore Writers Festival will take place from November 17 to 26, marking the fifth and final year of director Pooja Nansi's tenure. The festival features a diverse range of literary luminaries, including Viet Thanh Nguyen, Gayatri Spivak, and Lemn Sissay, as well as graphic novelists and Marvel writers Fatimah Asghar and Eve L Ewing. The event aims to cater to a fragmented world of readers with a focus on niche and unconventional topics, including combat sports, ghost hunting, and hip-hop music.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Zhuang Hong Yi's art transcend mere aesthetics, revealing layers of intricate detail and storytelling that burst forth from the canvas.
STPI's new group show celebrates 21 years of creating works by over 100 artists..

site_title: Ant consumer finance arm to raise 4.5 billion yuan for growth
summary: Ant Group's consumer finance affiliate is raising 4.5 billion yuan from investors to revive growth after a multi-year regulatory crackdown. Ant Group will contribute 2.25 billion yuan, while other investors include Sunny Optical Technology Group and Transfar Zhilian. The move comes after the fintech giant was fined nearly US$1 billion and saw its valuation drop billions of dollars. The division, Chongqing Ant, will increase its registered capital to 23 billion yuan pending regulatory approval, with an estimated lending capacity of 620 billion yuan.

site_title: German inflation falls to lowest level since start of Ukraine war
summary: German inflation fell to 4.3% in September, its lowest level since the start of the Ukraine war, signaling a possible end to high inflation in Europe's largest economy. Consumer prices, excluding volatile items, decreased to 4.6% year-over-year, while food prices rose 7.5% and energy prices increased 1%. Analysts predict Germany's economy will shrink 0.6% this year due to rising interest rates and high inflation. The European Central Bank is closely monitoring eurozone inflation data, with expectations of a 4.5% rate in September, fueling a push for a pause in interest rate hikes.

Berlin has also put on indefinite hold plans to require more stringent building insulation standards, an effort to help prop up the ailing building industry.

site_title: 👶 If only I were a nepo baby…
summary: A Thrive newsletter article discusses the importance of quality over quantity in networking. Chloe Lim shares her experiences of feeling pressured to attend networking events and build a large contact base, but Eric Sim, founder of the Institute of Life, emphasizes that networking is about building mutually beneficial relationships, not collecting business cards. Research by Zippia shows that 85% of jobs are filled via personal and professional connections, and Sim offers tips on how to forge quality connections, including starting with immediate networks, understanding value, practicing reciprocity, personalizing interactions, and seeking out local business incubators.

images.alt_text: Chloe Lim

site_title: OpenAI, Jony Ive in talks to raise US$1 billion from SoftBank for ‘iPhone of AI’
summary: OpenAI is in talks with SoftBank and former Apple designer Jony Ive's company LoveFrom to develop the "iPhone of AI" with a potential $1 billion funding. OpenAI's CEO Sam Altman has tapped LoveFrom to create the company's first consumer device. Discussions are serious, but no deal has been agreed upon, with a formal announcement potentially several months away. SoftBank's Masayoshi Son is involved in the talks, looking to invest in AI technology. The partnership could draw on talent and technology from the three groups.

images.alt_text: The annual dividend rate of the class shares will fluctuate after the fifth year, and SoftBank has the right to repurchase them at an amount equal to the issue price.
The AI startup says its latest browsing feature will allow websites to control how ChatGPT can interact with them.

site_title: Michael Gambon, British actor who played Dumbledore, dies at 82
summary: Michael Gambon, the British actor known for his portrayal of Albus Dumbledore in the Harry Potter franchise, has died at 82. Gambon began his acting career on stage in the 1960s and went on to appear in notable films such as The Cook, the Thief, His Wife & Her Lover and The King's Speech. He played Dumbledore from 2004 to 2011 and downplayed praise for his performance, saying he simply played himself. Gambon won numerous awards, including four BAFTAs and two ensemble cast Screen Actors Guild Awards, and was knighted for services to drama in 1998.

site_title: China to waive security checks for some data exports
summary: China's Cyberspace Administration of China (CAC) proposes waiving data export security assessments for activities such as international trade, academic cooperation, and cross-border manufacturing that do not contain personal information or important data. The move aims to bring relief to affected companies and clarify laws governing data transfer abroad. The proposed rules are open to public comment until October 15, and are seen as a positive signal for foreign investment and trade into China, with some lawyers describing them as a "certain degree of relaxation" in data export regulation.

images.alt_text: European Commission Vice-President Vera Jourova attends a press conference on the EU-China High-Level Digital Dialogue in Beijing, China, Sept 19, 2023.

The Yahoo! Inc. logo is displayed on an Apple Inc. iPhone 5s and laptop computer in this arranged photograph in Washington, D.C., U.S., on Tuesday, April 15, 2014. Yahoo! Inc. expected to release earnings figures after the market close on April 15. Photographer: Andrew Harrer/Bloomberg
FBI chief Chris Wray earlier this month said China “has a bigger hacking programme than every other major nation combined”.
“China has not issued laws, regulations or policy documents that prohibit the purchase and use of foreign brand phones such as Apple’s,” says foreign ministry spokesperson Mao Ning.

The law bans the transfer of any information related to national security and interests, without defining those terms, while broadening the definition of spying to include cyberattacks against state organs or critical infrastructure.

site_title: Beauty firm Coty set for Paris debut after US$356 million offering
summary: Coty, a US-based beauty firm, successfully raised US$356 million through a second listing on Euronext Paris, significantly exceeding demand. The company's shares were priced at US$10.80, a 2% discount to Wednesday's close. This move is seen as a boost for the European market, which has been losing out to US companies. Coty's ties to France date back to 1904, and the company plans to use the proceeds to pay down debt and fund general corporate purposes. The listing is part of Coty's efforts to diversify its shareholder base and ensure liquidity in Paris.

images.alt_text: Global brands are being drawn to the world’s most populous country, betting that its young shoppers and rising affluence will fuel expansion over the longer term.

site_title: China Eastern Airlines to buy another 100 C919 airplanes
summary: China Eastern Airlines has signed a contract to buy 100 C919 airplanes from Commercial Aircraft Corporation of China (Comac), the largest order for the Chinese passenger plane. The Shanghai-headquartered carrier is the first user of the C919, having previously bought five jets. The new order, valued at an undisclosed amount, will be delivered in batches from 2024 to 2031. This is the largest order for the C919, rivaling Airbus' A320neo and Boeing's 737 MAX single-aisle jet families.

site_title: Sony PlayStation CEO Ryan to retire
summary: Sony Interactive Entertainment CEO Jim Ryan to retire in March 2024, after overseeing the successful launch of the PlayStation 5, which has sold 40 million units. Ryan cited the difficulty of balancing work in Europe and North America as a reason for his departure. Group CEO Kenichiro Yoshida praised Ryan as an inspirational leader, but noted that the gaming industry is moving quickly, making his tenure a bit short. Hiroki Totoki will serve as interim CEO until a permanent successor is found.

images.alt_text: In April-June, Sony's operating profit slid 31 per cent to US$1.8 billion.

Spending on video-game hardware was up 23 per cent in the first half of this year, but was flat on  content, as gamers stuck with proven franchises such as Activision Blizzard’s "Call of Duty" (above).
“Now PS5 supply is well-stocked and we are seeing that pent up demand finally being met.” says Sony Interactive CEO Jim Ryan.
Sony plans to have 12 live service game titles in its portfolio by fiscal 2026, up from just one in fiscal 2021, the Nikkei says.
Microsoft won’t exclude the popular shooter game from consoles offered by its top competitor Sony.

site_title: Dubai’s Emaar in talks to build housing projects in Saudi Arabia
summary: Dubai-based Emaar Properties is in talks with Saudi Arabia's housing ministry to develop large mixed-use housing projects, with a potential 4,000-unit project in the works if an agreement is reached. This follows a state push to boost homeownership in Saudi Arabia, which has awarded construction contracts worth $250 billion since 2016. Emaar has been involved in Saudi Arabian real estate developments for years and is also exploring opportunities to build a new city called Neom. However, the developer has expressed concerns about the need for government subsidies to ensure developers can achieve a return above 8% on their investments.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: General view of NEOM in northwestern Saudi Arabia, January 11, 2021. Picture taken January 11, 2021. REUTERS/Hamad I Mohammed/File Photo

site_title: BOE plans new lending tool for insurers and pension funds after 2022 market rout
summary: The Bank of England (BOE) is developing a new lending facility to provide liquidity to insurance companies and pension funds, including newly-resilient liability-driven investment (LDI) funds, following the 2022 market rout. This move aims to address the lack of support for non-bank financial institutions (NBFIs), which hold significant British government bonds and face shortages of buyers during market turmoil. The facility's design is underway, with the goal of lending to thousands of firms, but regulators warn that the program is not intended to reduce firms' need to manage day-to-day risks.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A general view of the Bank of England (BoE) building in London, Britain, August 4, 2022. REUTERS/Maja Smiejkowska

An elderly woman pushes a shopping trolley in the city centre of Liverpool, UK, on Tuesday, Sept. 27, 2022. The UK's stock and bond markets have lost at least $500 billion in combined value since Liz Truss took over as Prime Minister, with investor confidence shattered by a shock tax-cutting budget. Photographer: Anthony Devlin/Bloomberg

site_title: Tech thriller The Creator wants us to save ourselves
summary: The sci-fi thriller "The Creator" explores the consequences of humanity's actions in the face of technological advancement. Set in 2065, the film depicts a world where the Western world has declared war on artificial intelligence, while the people of "New Asia" continue to use AI, leading to a stark contrast in societal approaches. The story follows Joshua, an undercover American agent, as he uncovers the truth about the AI creator, Nirmata, and the devastating consequences of humanity's destructive potential. The film argues that technology itself has no agency, and it is human fear of its potential that drives our actions, leaving us to decide what to do with the power to create and destroy.

images.alt_text: The Hollywood strike is making things complicated for the Academy Museum of Motion Pictures' gala, an important fund-raiser that usually attracts Hollywood’s A-listers and moguls and raises more than US$10 million for the museum.

site_title: Volkswagen restarts production after suffering major IT outage
summary: Volkswagen has restarted production after a major IT outage impacted its German plants and global network, causing a halt in production at 6 sites. The incident began at 1030 GMT on Wednesday and was resolved overnight, with the company stating it was unlikely an external attack was the cause. The outage affected production at Volkswagen, Porsche, and Audi, with individual systems still being restarted. Shares fell 1.2% and the company declined to comment on the incident's cause or potential financial implications.

images.alt_text: Toyota restarted operations at its assembly plants in its home market on Wednesday last week, a day after the malfunction occurred.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Finance Minister Lawrence Wong announced a new S$1.1 billion support package to help Singaporeans cope with rising costs. The package includes cash, vouchers, and rebates for households, with an additional S$200 in CDC vouchers for all Singaporean households. Meanwhile, Pure Fitness and Pure Yoga's Suntec branches will close on Oct 8 due to insufficient members. A freehold residential site in District 9 is up for sale at S$95 million, and the yield on Singapore's latest six-month T-bill jumped to 4.07%.

images.alt_text: Generic pix of the a CDC Voucher (for use at Supermarkets) decal, seen at the NTUC Fairprice supermarket located at Blk 166, Bukit Merah Central on Feb 17, 2023.

site_title: STPI: From pulp dreams to prominence
summary: STPI, a Singapore-based creative workshop and art gallery, celebrates its 21st anniversary with a new group show featuring over 100 artists and 1,500 works. Founded in 2002 by Kenneth Tyler and Singapore government funding, STPI has emerged as a world-class institution, collaborating with top museums and participating in prestigious art fairs. Despite initial criticism over its acquisition of Western prints and funding, STPI has successfully navigated challenges and retained its status as Singapore's pre-eminent international art institution, with a roster of local and international artists.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Zhuang Hong Yi's art transcend mere aesthetics, revealing layers of intricate detail and storytelling that burst forth from the canvas.

site_title: Funding in South-east Asia tech ecosystem falls to five-year low in Q3 2023: Traxcn
summary: Funding in South-east Asia's tech ecosystem has plummeted to a five-year low in Q3 2023, with late-stage rounds dropping 57% year-over-year to US$395 million. This follows a spike in Q2 2023, when funding reached US$3.2 billion. Year-over-year, Q3 funding fell 66% from US$2.5 billion. This marks a challenging environment for startups in the region.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Fundraising in the local health and biomedical sciences sector fell from US$121 million in 2021 to US$89 million in 2022, according to an SGInnovate report.
More tech companies are being held for longer, contributing to a growing backlog of tech deals that will create a buyers' market.

site_title: CDL ventures into Tokyo’s private rented sector with 35 billion yen investment
summary: City Developments Limited (CDL) has invested 35 billion yen (S$321.9 million) in a portfolio of 25 Tokyo residential assets, marking its entry into the city's rental housing market. The portfolio, comprising 836 units, has an average occupancy rate of 97% and stable rental income. CDL's Japan residential portfolio now totals 38 assets with over 2,100 units and an asset value of over 70 billion yen. The investment is expected to benefit from a recovering economy, rising wages, and post-pandemic net migration into Tokyo.

site_title: McDonald’s resists EU push to mandate reusable packaging
summary: McDonald's is resisting the European Union's push to mandate reusable packaging for dine-in customers, citing concerns that the plan would amount to a reversal of efforts to reduce environmentally harmful plastics. The company has experimented with reusable cups in several European countries but found that many are not returned, with only 40% of cups in Germany and 25% in the Netherlands coming back. Environmental groups argue that recycling is not enough to fix waste problems and that reusable materials are needed to close the waste loop, but McDonald's claims that the plan would increase water use and electricity costs, making it harder to hit net zero by 2050.

images.alt_text: The McDonald's is raising royalty fees to 5 per cent from 4 per cent, starting Jan 1.
The McDonald’s offering follows a stream of new debt sales by blue-chip companies this week.
McDonald’s says its global comparable sales jump 11.7 per cent in the second quarter, handily beating analysts’ average estimate of an 8.88 per cent increase, according to Refinitiv IBES data.

site_title: Malaysia 2024 palm oil output to rise despite El Nino
summary: Malaysia's crude palm oil production is forecast to rise to 19 million tons in 2024, reversing a May prediction of a potential 1-3 million ton drop. The increase is attributed to more labor and mature plantations for harvesting, offsetting the impact of the El Nino weather pattern, which had a significant effect on production in 2016.

Malaysian palm oil exports to China are now expected to hit 3.2 million metric tons for 2023.
Malaysia currently imposes a windfall levy of 3 per cent on palm oil prices above 3,000 ringgit per tonne in peninsular Malaysia, and above 3,500 ringgit per tonne in Sabah and Sarawak.
