The deal comes as Malaysia – the world’s second biggest producer of palm oil – is expected to take a hit to output from the El Niño weather phenomenon, which brings prolonged hot and dry weather.

site_title: German economy to shrink 0.6% in 2023 before wages drive rebound
summary: Germany's economy is forecast to shrink 0.6% in 2023, its first full year of contraction since the pandemic, before rebounding to 1.3% growth in 2024 driven by rising wages and lower energy prices. The downward revision from April's forecast was mainly due to industry and private consumption recovering more slowly than expected. The struggles have contributed to erosion in Chancellor Olaf Scholz's ruling coalition and a surge in the popularity of the far-right AfD.

images.alt_text: “The robust expansion of employment seen over the past few months has come to a standstill,” says Ifo.

site_title: Delayed DBS PayNow transactions still not processed on Thursday
summary: DBS customers continued to experience issues with delayed PayNow transactions on Thursday, despite the bank's assurances that the issue was resolved. Customers reported issues with transactions being marked as "processing" but later rejected, with some businesses receiving unexpected refunds. DBS had processed all delayed transactions by 11:50 pm on Wednesday, but customers were still facing problems. The bank's customer service hotline advised customers to wait for updates, but some customers were left without access to their funds.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan

“The repeated inconvenience caused to the public is unacceptable. The additional capital requirement imposed at this time underscores the seriousness with which MAS treats this matter. DBS Bank must spare no effort in dealing with the underlying issues leading to these disruptions.,” said Ho Hern Shin, deputy managing director of financial supervision at MAS.
DBS chief apologises for recent banking services outage, review being done
DBS's PayNow service appears to be disrupted on Tuesday.

site_title: Oil giant Saudi Aramco announces first global LNG deal
summary: Saudi Aramco has announced its first global liquefied natural gas (LNG) deal, acquiring a minority stake worth $500 million in MidOcean Energy, managed by US investment firm EIG. The move marks Aramco's first international investment in LNG as it aims to expand beyond oil. CEO Amin Nasser expects strong demand-led growth for LNG in the energy transition journey, citing gas as a vital fuel and feedstock in various industries. The deal is part of Aramco's broader strategy to diversify its business and reduce reliance on oil.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Saudi Aramco sign is pictured at an oil facility in Abqaiq, Saudi Arabia, October 12, 2019. REUTERS/Maxim Shemetov//File Photo

site_title: Brokers’ take: DBS raises Sea’s target price after Indonesia bans social e-commerce
summary: DBS Group Research has raised its target price on Sea Ltd to US$78 from US$66 after Indonesia banned e-commerce transactions on social media platforms. The ban aims to protect offline merchants and marketplaces, and may hinder TikTok Shop's potential success in Indonesia. As a result, traditional e-commerce platforms like Shopee may benefit. DBS maintained its "buy" recommendation on Sea, while Citi Research has a "neutral" call and a target of US$50. The ban may also affect livestreaming activities on Shopee, but the company is expected to remain a net beneficiary.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
UBS projects GoTo's gross merchandise value to grow in Q3 after Gojek "marginally increased competitive intensity" in recent months.
FILE PHOTO: The TikTok logo is pictured outside the company's U.S. head office in Culver City, California, U.S.,  September 15, 2020.   REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo
It’s been a long funding winter, but venture capital firms are still actively raising capital, writes Garage journalist Daphne Yow.
Forrest Li, chief executive of Sea Group, reminded his staff in a memo that a "hard contest" is where the company has always thrived.

While TikTok Shop is fast emerging as a serious contender against incumbent e-commerce majors such as Shopee and Lazada in South-east Asia, Momentum Works also sees TikTok competing with Amazon in the US and Middle East.

The government says the move is aimed at protecting offline merchants and marketplaces in Indonesia, adding that predatory pricing on social media platforms is threatening small and medium-sized enterprises.
Indonesia is the first and biggest market for TikTok Shop, and online shopping has become the app’s fastest-growing feature with a burgeoning fan base in the country.

site_title: Chinese EV battery parts maker Londian planning US IPO: sources
summary: Shenzhen-based Londian Wason Energy Tech, a Chinese copper foil maker, is planning a US initial public offering (IPO) to raise about $500 million. The company, which supplies copper wire to EV battery makers Contemporary Amperex Technology and BYD, has benefited from the surge in demand for EV batteries. Londian is working with Citigroup and Goldman Sachs Group on the listing preparations, with a possible listing happening as early as next year.

site_title: Saudi Aramco to start talks to buy 10% in China refinery operator
summary: Saudi Aramco is set to discuss a potential 10% stake in Shenghong Petrochemical, a Chinese refining and petrochemical company, to boost its presence in China's huge energy market. This deal would give Aramco access to a 320,000 barrel-a-day integrated refinery and petrochemicals complex, and potentially secure long-term Saudi crude supplies to China. The agreement is part of Aramco's downstream strategy to increase conversion of Arabian crude oil to chemicals and expand into the Chinese market.

site_title: China kicks off US$137 billion plan to tackle LGFV debt risk
summary: China has launched a US$137 billion plan to address its local government financing vehicle (LGFV) debt risk by allowing provinces to swap high-interest, short-term debt for lower-interest, long-term bonds. The Inner Mongolia region will issue three refinancing bonds worth 66.3 billion yuan, with maturities between 3 to 7 years. The programme aims to resolve debt risks in high-debt pressure areas, but some economists call for more measures to address the core problem.

images.alt_text: Investors monitor stock prices at a securities exchange house in Shanghai, China on Friday, 31 December 2010.
By drawing up a list of LGFVs to be looked at, Chinese regulators hope to prevent them from raising money from new entities or shell companies – practices that could aggravate the debt problem.

site_title: Singapore concludes joint project using decentralised finance technology
summary: The Bank for International Settlements (BIS) and its partners, including the Monetary Authority of Singapore, have concluded a joint project called Project Mariana, which tested cross-border wholesale central bank digital currencies (CBDCs) using decentralized finance (DeFi) technology on a public blockchain. The project, developed by three BIS Innovation Hub centres and the central banks, aimed to explore the benefits and challenges of tokenisation and DeFi technologies. The outcome of the project will inform future developments in CBDCs and DeFi technologies.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
The market share of peer-to-peer digital asset platforms has dropped to 5 per cent, from a 2023 peak of 7 per cent in March.
Policymakers and regulators are concerned about linking digital assets to real economic value.
MAS also proposed a framework for digital asset networks, as well as the expansion of Project Guardian, which aims to test the feasibility of asset tokenisation and decentralised finance.

site_title: Chinese conglomerate Wanda in talks with backers to avert 30 billion yuan IPO repayment
summary: Dalian Wanda Group is in talks with investors to avoid repaying approximately 30 billion yuan (S$5.6 billion) to pre-IPO investors of Zhuhai Wanda Commercial Management Group if the unit fails to complete its initial public offering this year. The conglomerate is considering offering compensation instead of immediate repayment, potentially easing a liquidity crunch. The negotiations come as Zhuhai Wanda has yet to complete a listing in Hong Kong since it first filed for an IPO in 2021, and faces a regulatory requirement to repay the funds by the end of 2023.

images.alt_text: Shih Wing Ching, chairman of Centaline, says local governments should be banned from selling land.
Banks have been curbing lending to the real estate sector given rising financial distress in recent years.
Industrial output rises 4.5 per cent in August from a year earlier, according to data released by the National Bureau of Statistics (NBS).
The most recent stimulus resulted in a spurt of home sales in larger cities that is already losing momentum.
China has built the capital stock of a developed economy, effectively meeting housing demand – before reaching the associated income level.
Beijing is trying to revive confidence after the latest data showed home sales slumped for a third straight month, adding to deflation pressure.
Dalian Wanda has tapped Deutsche Bank for advice on the sale of Infront Sports & Media, the sources say.

site_title: China’s property sector a bubble that needed bursting: Hong Kong property broker Centaline
summary: China's property sector is facing a bursting bubble, with overbuilt, overleveraged, and overpriced markets. Centaline Group, a Hong Kong-based property brokerage, is owed 2 billion yuan in unpaid commissions to its agents, with some debts dating back over three years. Chairman Shih Wing Ching calls for a ban on local governments selling land to reduce supply and allow the market to digest accumulated housing supply. He believes the mainland market should have been pricked 10 years ago with such a restriction, and instead, the government's approach has only exacerbated the issue.

images.alt_text: Banks have been curbing lending to the real estate sector given rising financial distress in recent years.
The survey’s authors suggested to policymakers to implement “slightly more aggressive” monetary policies to stabilise the housing market in the short term.
While Country Garden has so far avoided defaulting, investors remain doubtful about its ability to survive China’s real estate crisis that shows no signs of abating.

site_title: YouTubers fuel housing crunch in one of Europe’s tiniest nations
summary: Andorra, a microstate between France and Spain, is experiencing a housing crisis fueled by wealthy expats, including YouTubers, who are driving up property prices. The influx of newcomers has led to a 30% increase in real estate prices since 2018, forcing locals to move to Spain. To address concerns, Andorran lawmakers are proposing a tax on non-resident property purchases, requiring applicants for residency to pass a Catalan language exam, and measures to create affordable housing. Critics fear these measures could encourage wealthy individuals to register as residents, turning Andorra into a tax haven.

images.alt_text:
mlsavills - The Whiteley



Source: Savills

site_title: Thailand’s August factory output falls 7.5% y-o-y, more than forecast
summary: Thailand's factory output declined 7.5% in August from the previous year, exceeding the forecasted 6.5% drop. The decline was attributed to a global economic slowdown affecting exports. This marks the second consecutive month of decline, following a 4.43% drop in July. The manufacturing production index (MPI) has been impacted by soft global demand, highlighting the challenges faced by Thailand's industry.

images.alt_text: A worker from Myanmar hangs up rubber sheets for drying in a small factory in Surat Thani. The southern Thai province has the biggest land area covered by rubber trees.

site_title: Yield on latest Singapore 6-month T-bill jumps to 4.07%
summary: Singapore's latest 6-month Treasury bill (T-bill) offered a cut-off yield of 4.07%, a jump from the previous 3.7% yield, marking the first time yields have crossed the 4% mark since January. Demand for the T-bills was down, with a bid-to-cover ratio of 1.76, and experts attribute the spike to concerns about further US interest rate hikes and the global economic outlook. The yield increase may be an anomaly, but it reflects the market's expectation of higher interest rates for longer, driven by rising US Treasury yields.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
All who applied non-competitively were allotted.
Holding cash may seem like a safer option during market volatility but is not ideal as it remains vulnerable to inflation.
The US Federal Reserve and other central banks have raised interest rates at a rapid rate since February last year in a bid to lower the inflation rate.

site_title: X CEO Yaccarino says Musk-owned platform could turn a profit next year
summary: X CEO Linda Yaccarino says the social media platform could turn a profit in early 2024, despite facing challenges in retaining advertisers due to its rapid changes and controversy surrounding billionaire owner Elon Musk. In the last 12 weeks, about 1,500 advertisers have returned, and 90% of the company's top 100 advertisers have come back. Yaccarino defended the company's progress and its efforts to improve safety, including the introduction of new content moderation tools. X is also facing lawsuits over unpaid rent and severance pay to laid-off employees.

images.alt_text: The last three months of the year have historically been X’s biggest revenue driver.

(FILES) This illustration photo shows a figurine displayed on the new Twitter logo rebranded as X reflected in smartphone screen, in Paris on July 27, 2023. Billionaire tech boss Elon Musk on August 25, 2023, said Twitter, rebranded X, was working to comply with new EU rules that force tech firms to protect users against illegal content. (Photo by JOEL SAGET / AFP)
Musk paid back the US$1 billion with interest to SpaceX in November.

site_title: Apple’s iPhone cedes ground to Google’s Pixel in Japan
summary: Google's Pixel phone has gained significant ground in Japan's smartphone market, with a record 12% market share in the June quarter, surpassing Apple's 46% share. The decline in iPhone sales is attributed to higher prices due to the yen's weakness, while the Pixel's affordability has made it a popular choice. Analysts attribute the shift to growing price sensitivity among Japanese consumers and the increasing competition from other brands. This trend is expected to continue, posing a challenge for Apple's dominance in the Japanese market.

images.alt_text: The Google Pixel Fold smartphone. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg
Some customers say that the back or side of the iPhone 15 Pro and Pro Max  becomes hot to the touch while gaming or when conducting a phone call or FaceTime video chat.
Waiting time for the iPhone 15 has quadrupled in China, Apple’s biggest overseas market.
The devices are going on sale in about 40 countries in its first wave, including in Australia, Hong Kong, mainland China, the US, UK and France.

site_title: HSBC to acquire Citigroup China consumer wealth business: sources
summary: HSBC is set to acquire Citigroup's China consumer wealth management business, managing over $3 billion in assets. The transaction will also involve HSBC taking over "a few hundreds" of Citi's China-based staff. This move is part of Citigroup's plan to wind down its China retail banking business, which was announced in December. The deal is a significant boost to HSBC's business in China, although the financial details are not immediately known.

site_title: Vedanta is preparing to de-merge sprawling operations
summary: Vedanta is preparing to de-merge its sprawling operations into several listed entities, aiming to reduce debt and improve financial management. The company, led by tycoon Anil Agarwal, plans to separate businesses including aluminium, oil and gas, iron ore, and steel, with Vedanta Resources remaining the holding company. The move is seen as a response to rising borrowing costs and a need to address debt of around $2 billion. The restructuring plan has sparked optimism among investors, with Vedanta's shares gaining 2% in Mumbai trading.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man walks past the logo of Vedanta outside its headquarters in Mumbai, India January 31, 2018. REUTERS/Danish Siddiqui/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: A man walks past the logo of Vedanta outside its headquarters in Mumbai, India January 31, 2018. REUTERS/Danish Siddiqui/File Photo/File Photo/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: A bird flies by the Vedanta office building in Mumbai August 16, 2010. REUTERS/Danish Siddiqui/File Photo

site_title: China sovereign debt sales surge to test PBOC liquidity support
summary: China has sold a record 1.2 trillion yuan (S$226 billion) of central government bonds in September, the highest monthly tally in 2023 and 60% higher than the average for the same period in the past three years. The surge in debt issuance is putting pressure on the People's Bank of China to keep funding conditions loose to support economic growth, which is facing a patchy recovery. The central bank has cut reserve requirements and injected cash into the money market to address liquidity concerns.

images.alt_text: The PBOC reaffirmed its stance of keeping the yuan stable and preventing the risk of currency overshooting.

FILE PHOTO: Paramilitary police officers stand guard in front of the headquarters of the People's Bank of China, the central bank (PBOC), in Beijing, China September 30, 2022. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Nikkei hits one-month low on Federal Reserve’s higher-for-longer rate woes
summary: The Nikkei index fell 1.73% to 31,813.01, its lowest level since August 28, due to concerns over the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes. Foreign investors sold Japanese shares worth 3 trillion yen, a record weekly net selling. Despite this, the Nikkei remains Asia's best performing stock exchange this year, up roughly 23%. The S&P 500 eked out a slim gain, while Japan's Finance Minister warned against speculative moves on the yen due to excessive currency volatility.

images.alt_text: Singapore shares edge up at Thursday’s open; STI up 0.1%
The pan-European Stoxx 600 index slipped 0.2 per cent on Thursday to close at a six-month low.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.2 per cent to 33,550.27 on Thursday.

site_title: Toyota global sales hit record high in August, along with output
summary: Toyota's global sales reached a record 923,180 vehicles in August, up 9% from last year, driven by improved supply conditions and increased demand. Global production also rose 4% to 924,509 vehicles. Sales growth was seen in Japan (45%) and South Korea (63%), but declined in Asia, particularly in China, where the company faces competition from Chinese EV makers. Toyota aims to produce 150,000 EVs this year and 600,000 in 2025, aiming to catch up with global EV frontrunners.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Toyota logo is seen at its booth during a media day for the Auto Shanghai show in Shanghai, China April 19, 2021. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: The Toyota logo is seen at its booth during a media day for the Auto Shanghai show in Shanghai, China April 19, 2021. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

Under new CEO Koji Sato, Toyota in June announced an ambitious plan to ramp up battery EVs, a big shift after years of criticism that the maker of the industry-leading hybrid Prius was slow to embrace fully electric technology.
Toyota’s India business has been the biggest beneficiary of its global partnership with Suzuki which allows the two Japanese carmakers to share technology and vehicles.

site_title: Pure Fitness and Pure Yoga’s Suntec branches to close Oct 8 due to insufficient members
summary: Pure Fitness and Pure Yoga branches at Suntec City will close on Oct 8 due to insufficient members, marking the latest in Singapore's gym industry closures. Despite multiple efforts to drive awareness and customer engagement, membership acquisitions proved challenging. This decision follows a string of similar closures in the industry, with Pure Group citing "challenging" membership acquisitions as the reason. The closure will affect the group's Suntec City locations.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Fenix Fitness' sole outlet at Raffles Place.
UFC Gym's flagship outlet in CityLink Mall., which shut without warning. It will be replaced by gym chain Anytime Fitness.
Haus Athletics first announced the closure of its OUE outlet on Apr 19, followed by the closure of its Cross Street Exchange outlet on Apr 24.

site_title: The priorities, purchasing habits and pain points of millennials
summary: Millennials, aged 27 to 42, are reassessing their priorities, with 47% planning to reduce luxury spending this year. Despite being employed full-time, only 30% identify as "career-focused." The generation is prioritizing personal growth, mental well-being, and passion projects over professional success. Online time has decreased by 45 minutes per day, with social media being the most dominant platform, spent 2 hours and 27 minutes daily. Influencers are trusted by 74% of millennials, but concerns over misinformation persist. The economic climate has led to increased financial stress, with 33% seeking ways to cut bills, and 29% anticipating worsening finances in the near future.

site_title: Singapore shares rise amid mixed regional trading on Thursday; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.2% on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) increasing 6.96 points to 3,206.99. Despite this, regional indices were largely down, with the Hang Seng Index falling 1.4% and the Nikkei 225 losing 1.5%. Losers outnumbered gainers 293 to 281, with 1.3 billion securities worth S$920 million changing hands.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
SGX logo in front of the SGX Centre building at Shenton Way.

site_title: Australia job vacancies tumble from record levels in latest quarter
summary: Job vacancies in Australia plummeted 8.9% from the previous quarter to 390,400, the lowest level in two years, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics. This marks a decline of 15% from a year ago, but still 71.5% higher than in February 2020. The unemployment rate also rose to 3.7%, up from a record low of 3.4%. Analysts attribute the decline to interest rate hikes constraining demand, and the Reserve Bank of Australia's efforts to curb inflation.

images.alt_text: Retail sales have broadly flatlined over the year, rising just 1.5 per cent compared with a peak of 19.2 per cent year-on-year growth last August.
Wednesday's data vindicate the Reserve Bank of Australia’s stance that further tightening may be necessary and that it’s too early to declare victory against inflation.

site_title: UBS takes lead in US$50 billion bond market left by Credit Suisse
summary: UBS has taken the lead in the US$50 billion Swiss franc bond market, accounting for 41% of the market share this year. The market has seen significant growth, with 46.5 billion Swiss francs (S$69.3 billion) of debt sales, the most in over a decade. This growth is attributed to lower Swiss borrowing costs and the franc being the top performer among Group-of-10 currencies. Rival banks such as Deutsche Bank and BNP Paribas have also increased their share of the market, filling the void left by Credit Suisse's demise in March.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Logos of Swiss banks Credit Suisse and UBS are seen before a news conference in Zurich Switzerland, August 30, 2023.  REUTERS/Denis Balibouse/File Photo
UBS acquired local rival Credit Suisse in a rescue that closed in June.
UBS has long been keen to grow its footprint in China that already includes a mutual fund joint venture and a private fund business.
As part of the integration process, UBS decides to absorb Credit Suisse’s Securities Research service, wrapping the business into its own research operations.

site_title: Northern wing at Changi Airport Terminal 2 opens
summary: Changi Airport's northern wing at Terminal 2 officially opened on September 28, 2023, after 3.5 years of upgrading and expansion works. The opening boosts Terminal 2's handling capacity from 23 million to 28 million passengers per annum, and Changi Airport's overall capacity from 85 million to 90 million passengers per annum. Several airlines, including Lufthansa, Swiss, and Singapore Airlines, began operating from the northern wing, and more airlines will move to Terminal 2 starting next month.

images.alt_text: Navene Elangovan

Singapore will resume operations of the fourth terminal at its main airport on Sep 13, the Changi Airport Group (CAG) said on Friday (Jul 22), as the Southeast Asian travel hub recovers from the more than two years of Covid-19 pandemic-induced disruptions.
Air China flight CA403 encountered smoke in its forward cargo hold and lavatory on its way to Changi Airport and had to make an emergency landing.
Generic image of tourists and travellers in Singapore Changi Airport.

site_title: Taiwan billionaire Pierre Chen puts up exclusive wines worth about US$50m for auction
summary: Taiwanese billionaire Pierre Chen is selling an estimated $50 million collection of exclusive wines through five auctions at Sotheby's over the next 12 months. The collection, which includes rare bottles from Burgundy, Champagne, and Italian producers, is being sold due to its size, with Chen stating that he wants to "share" his wine with others. The auctions are expected to be highly competitive, with prices potentially reaching $120,000 to $190,000 for a 1985 Domaine de la Romanée-Conti La Tâche. The sales are seen as a reflection of the growing demand for high-end wines in the secondary market.

images.alt_text: A commanding view of surrounding vineyards from the hotel Royal Champagne.

site_title: China’s Shengjing Bank in 176 billion yuan deal to sell assets to government-backed entity
summary: Shengjing Bank, a Chinese regional lender, has agreed to sell assets worth 176 billion yuan (S$33 billion) to Liaoning Asset Management, a government-backed entity. The deal aims to improve asset quality and lower non-performing loan ratios, with over 70% of the assets being loans. The sale is a response to the bank's 21.8% drop in net profit for the half-year, with net interest income slipping 1.3% to 15.32 billion yuan. The deal is expected to fund the purchase of assets by issuing special-purpose notes to the bank.

images.alt_text: Investors monitor stock prices at a securities exchange house in Shanghai, China on Friday, 31 December 2010.

site_title: US, Japan authorities warn of China-linked hacking group BlackTech
summary: US and Japanese authorities have warned multinational companies about the China-linked hacking group BlackTech, citing its capabilities in modifying router firmware without detection and exploiting domain-trust relationships. The group has been engaged in cyberattacks since 2010, targeting governments and tech-sector companies in the US and East Asia. The FBI has stated that China has a larger hacking program than any other major nation combined, amid rising tensions between the US and China. Companies are urged to review their internet routers to minimize the risk of potential attacks.

images.alt_text: Allegations that China hacked the State Department - along with two dozen other, mostly still unidentified organisations - have strained an already tense US-China relationship. Beijing has denied being behind the spying.
DBS and UOB say their new anti-malware features do not monitor customers’ phone activities, nor collect or store any personal data.
“Immediate measures were adopted to respond to this cybersecurity incident and to mitigate its impact,” says the ICC.
Hacking group ALPHV claimed the MGM hack in a post on its website on Friday, and warned MGM of further attacks if it didn’t strike a deal.

site_title: China shies away from confrontation with EU over EV probe
summary: China has avoided confrontation with the EU over an electric vehicle probe, instead opting for diplomacy and cooperation. Vice-Premier He Lifeng agreed to set up working groups on financial services and trade curbs, amid a broader push to stabilize geopolitical relationships. China's ties with the EU are crucial, with the bloc worth $900 billion to China, and Beijing seeks to maintain a positive relationship to attract foreign investment. The EU's probe into EV subsidies was met with mild rhetoric from China, which has struggled to respond to US sanctions and tariffs without scaring off foreign companies.

images.alt_text: A Chinese flag iin Pudong's Lujiazui Financial District in Shanghai, China. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: OUE Healthcare’s privatisation offer for Healthway Medical secures 50.47% valid acceptances
summary: OUE Healthcare's exit offer for Healthway Medical to take the company private at S$0.048 per share has secured 50.47% valid acceptances, fulfilling the minimum acceptance condition. The offer remains open for at least two weeks after shareholders' delisting approval. However, the exit offer will lapse if the proposed offeree resolutions are not approved at Healthway Medical's extraordinary general meeting, and if the Singapore Exchange agrees to the company's delisting application.

images.alt_text: The exit offer price represents a premium of about 45.5 per cent over Healthway Medical’s last traded price of S$0.033 on Jun 28.
No dividend was declared by OUE Healthcare’s board after the consideration of the group’s financial cash flow requirements.

site_title: Finally, there’s more money than fools in China
summary: Chinese consumers have shifted from a risk-taking, investment-oriented mindset to a more conservative approach, characterized by a steady decline in investment product preferences since the 2015 crash. Household deposits have reached a record 132 trillion yuan, while the preference for buying stocks, bonds, and trusts has decreased. This risk-off mentality creates challenges for the government, as it dampens policies aimed at boosting market sentiment, and is a stark contrast to the US, where households have a higher proportion of their wealth tied to the market.

images.alt_text: Developers are counting on the Golden Week to reverse a slump in home sales.
To escape the middle-income trap and keep a lid on social unrest, authorities must work out how to create better jobs for city dwellers.

site_title: Gold hovers near six-month low as US dollar, yields weigh
summary: Gold prices hovered near a six-month low due to the US dollar's strength and elevated Treasury yields, which increase the opportunity cost of holding bullion. Spot gold rose 0.1% to $1,876.89 per ounce, while US gold futures rose 0.17% to $1,894.20. Markets await US economic data for clues on the Federal Reserve's interest rate path.

images.alt_text: Higher interest rates raise the opportunity cost of holding bullion, which is priced in US dollars and does not yield interest.

site_title: Temasek’s True Light achieves close of US$3.3 billion for fund focused on Greater China
summary: Temasek's investment arm, True Light Capital, has secured US$3.3 billion for its inaugural flagship fund, True Light Fund I, focused on Greater China. The fund will invest in both mature manufacturers and next-generation battery developers, leveraging the Chinese electric vehicle industry. CEO Yeo Chee Kian is confident in China's resilience despite economic challenges, citing structural competitiveness, innovation, and a large domestic consumption market. True Light's investments will focus on "policy-aligned opportunities" and four long-term structural trends, with no pre-set allocations towards sectors or asset classes.

images.alt_text: Zhao Yifan

FILE PHOTO: An employee works on the production line of electric vehicle (EV) battery manufacturer Octillion in Hefei, Anhui province, China March 30, 2021. Picture taken March 30, 2021. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

site_title: Amazon is the apex predator of our platform era
summary: The US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) is taking on Amazon in a long-awaited lawsuit, with FTC Chair Lina Khan aiming to restore an approach to competition law that has been in decline since the Carter administration. Amazon is seen as the "apex predator" of the platform era, exploiting its digital flexibility to lock in and raid customers, and Khan's case seeks to curb the company's anti-competitive tactics, including its subsidies, advertising revenue, and treatment of workers. The lawsuit is seen as a critical moment in the battle to restore antitrust laws and curb corporate power.

images.alt_text: Last June, the US Federal Trade Commission filed a complaint against Amazon for “entrapping consumers” with its Prime subscription, which renews automatically and is complicated to cancel.
The FTC says that by buying video-game publisher Activision Blizzard, Microsoft would gain an unfair advantage in consoles and cloud-gaming.

site_title: Weary China traders look to Golden Week for buying opportunities
summary: China traders are optimistic about the upcoming Golden Week holiday, expecting a boost in travel, retail, and consumer spending. The eight-day national holiday, starting September 29, is expected to see over 21 million plane trips and a rebound in retail sales, potentially stabilizing the broader economy. While concerns about the property sector's debt troubles remain, some analysts predict specific sectors such as travel, entertainment, and retail could benefit from the peak spending season.

images.alt_text: Generic image of tourists and travellers in Singapore Changi Airport.
An easing of mortgage restrictions at the end of August triggered a spurt of home sales in larger cities that is already losing momentum.

site_title: AI chip crunch: startups vie for Nvidia’s vital component
summary: Nvidia's graphics processing unit (GPU) chips are crucial for generating AI models, but soaring demand has left startups struggling to secure the vital components. Companies like Amazon, Intel, and AMD are working on alternatives, but their efforts may take years to materialize. As the tech giants invest billions in AI, startups are forced to rely on Nvidia's products, leading to a shortage that's expected to persist until mid-2024. This scarcity is "sucking the oxygen" from the GPU market, making it challenging for companies to deliver on AI's promise.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of technology company Nvidia is seen at its headquarters in Santa Clara, California February 11, 2015. REUTERS/Robert Galbraith/File Photo
Micron expects the industry outlook to brighten considerably by 2025 – especially as artificial intelligence systems demand new types of more expensive memory chips.
Last year, the chipmakers had received authorisation from the US Commerce Department to supply equipment needed for chip production in China for a year without seeking additional licenses.

As in retail, where Amazon slowly built up control of every part of selling online – sourcing products, running the store, handling logistics – so too is Amazon looking to be involved at every layer of the AI industry.

While UMS suffered from weaker demand from its backend semiconductor customers in the first half year, Seet noted that the second half could remain equally weak as its key customer is unlikely to ramp up orders this year.
Luu Anh Tuan, Chairman of mining company VTRE in his Hanoi office with samples of rare earth oxides in Hanoi, Vietnam September 7, 2023. REUTERS/Francesco Guarascio
No stock symbolizes the chip industry’s success more than Nvidia, whose shares are tripling in 2023 as the company’s market value tops US$1 trillion.
The new Qualcomm routers will use a new standard called Wi-Fi 7 that id designed to help data flow faster around homes where scores of devices from phones to smart televisions often use Wi-Fi.

site_title: Evergrande suspends trading in Hong Kong after Hui concerns
summary: Evergrande Group suspended trading in Hong Kong, along with its property services and electric vehicle units, following a Bloomberg report that founder Hui Ka Yan was taken away by police. Hui is being monitored at a designated location under residential surveillance. The move marks a new phase in the saga, with setbacks to its restructuring plan and raises concerns over the company's fate, potentially leading to liquidation. The suspended entities have a combined market value of HK$16.7 billion.

site_title: District 9 residential development site for sale at S$95 million guide price
summary: A freehold residential site in District 9, Singapore, spanning 17,974 sq ft, is up for sale by public tender at a guide price of S$95 million. The site is located 100m away from Orchard Road and has an allowable gross plot ratio of 2.8. The new development can have a total GFA of 53,849 sq ft, and a pre-application feasibility study is not required for up to 66 apartment units. The site is ideal for an ultra-high-net-worth family to design and build their own development. The tender closes on November 8 at 3 pm.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Will the latest ABSD rate hike help lower new home prices?
The property at 20 Third Avenue is OK Lim's second Good Class Bungalow to be sold in the area.
Most new launches in the fourth quarter of this year will be in the suburbs.
Land site up for sale  in the Holland Rise good class bungalow (GCB) area.

site_title: Credit card spending surges to record in India in sign of stress
summary: Credit card spending in India reached a record high of 1.48 trillion rupees (S$24.4 billion) in August, up from July's 1.45 trillion rupees. This surge in spending is attributed to aggressive retail pushes by lenders in the under-banked market, where 1.4 billion people lack access to traditional banking services. Experts warn that the rising indebtedness and falling savings among Indians may lead to growing stress, particularly if economic growth slows later in the year, and defaults on credit cards become a concern.

site_title: Hong Kong finance chief hints at easing property market curbs
summary: Hong Kong's Financial Secretary Paul Chan hinted at easing property market curbs, citing a more favorable environment. The government is "constantly reviewing" the market with a pragmatic attitude, considering lifting restrictions that include a 15% stamp duty and 15% levy on non-resident buyers. Industry participants have called for removing these taxes to revive the ailing market, which has seen a 17% drop in home prices since 2021. Authorities have already relaxed mortgage rules for first-time buyers, but analysts say these measures will have limited impact on prices.

images.alt_text: Swire Properties Ltd.'s Opus Hong Kong, designed by architect Frank Gehry, stands on Stubbs Road in Hong Kong, China, on Friday, March 30, 2012. Swire Properties has completed Gehry's first residential project in Asia, Opus Hong Kong. Photographer: Jerome Favre/Bloomberg
Buyers currently must go through a test that ensures their income is enough to afford future rate increases if they take on mortgages.
Buyers currently must go through a stress test that ensures their income can afford future rate rises if they take on mortgages.

site_title: Australian retail sales cool, boosting case to extend rate pause
summary: Australian retail sales rose 0.2% in August, below expectations, indicating the Reserve Bank of Australia's rapid interest-rate increases are weighing on the economy. This slowdown in household spending aligns with downbeat consumer sentiment, bolstering the case for the RBA to maintain the interest rate at 4.1% at its upcoming policy meeting. The data also led to a slight decrease in the three-year government bond yield and a minor change in the Australian dollar.

images.alt_text: Wednesday's data vindicate the Reserve Bank of Australia’s stance that further tightening may be necessary and that it’s too early to declare victory against inflation.

Employment is already front and centre of RBA decision-making as policymakers repeatedly highlight that further interest-rate hikes will depend on incoming economic data on inflation, household spending and jobs.

site_title: London price cuts boost UK home discounts to highest since 2019
summary: House prices in London and southeast England dropped 1.5% year-on-year in August, with an average discount of nearly 5% to the asking price, the largest since March 2019. This is attributed to higher mortgage rates affecting buying power and prices. The UK's housing market is experiencing a "buyer's market" with more properties for sale, but viewing inquiries are still lower than last year, partly due to retreating inflation and a pause in Bank of England rate hikes. Zoopla expects further downward pressure on prices over the next two quarters.

images.alt_text: Jefferies estimates a 20 per cent contraction in London office usage due to post-pandemic hybrid working and increasing occupier preference for greener buildings in the suburbs.
Higher interest rates and inflation are now spreading London’s problem to the rest of the UK property market.

site_title: IPO optimism grows, fuelling hope for global recovery
summary: US IPOs are gaining momentum, with September poised to be the biggest month for fundraising since 2022, according to data from Bloomberg. Companies have raised $7.2 billion so far in September, accounting for 56% of global IPOs this month. Despite some disappointing listings, bankers are optimistic that the IPO market will accelerate in 2024, driven by a stable interest rate environment and a growing number of companies preparing to list. The market is expected to be more broad-based in 2024, with activity in Europe and Asia also showing signs of life.

images.alt_text: The Hong Kong exchange confirms that Alibaba can proceed with its proposed Cainiao spinoff and IPO.
AirTrunk’s chief executive officer Robin Khuda says: “The level of growth we are seeing right now is something we have not seen in 10 years.”
Arm surged on its first day on Wall Street and has fallen every day since then.

KKR bought BrightSpring in 2019 and merged it with PharMerica to create a diversified healthcare platform with comprehensive care capabilities across clinical, pharmacy and non-clinical support services.
VNG is still aiming to carry out a New York listing, likely in the first half of 2024.

site_title: UK homeowners say jump in interest rates will force more to sell
summary: UK homeowners are considering selling their properties due to rising interest rates, with nearly a quarter of mortgage holders considering a move and over 10% already having sold to cheaper properties. The Bank of England's benchmark lending rate is at its highest since 2008, causing households to cut back on spending and prioritize mortgage repayments. This could lead to a wave of forced sales, exacerbating the struggling housing market, with economists expecting further house price declines in the coming months.

images.alt_text: House prices in London and southeast England dropped about 1.5 per cent year-on-year in August, compared with small rises in northern regions such as Scotland.

site_title: Taiwan reveals first domestically made submarine in defence milestone
summary: Taiwan unveiled its first domestically developed submarine, the Narwhal, in a major step towards strengthening its defense and deterrence against China's navy. The submarine, which won't enter service for two years, is part of a broader effort to modernize Taiwan's armed forces amid China's daily military exercises. China's defense ministry called the strategy "idiotic nonsense." The move is seen as a significant milestone in Taiwan's defense development, but the country remains vulnerable to China's assertive actions in the region.

images.alt_text: FBI chief Chris Wray earlier this month said China “has a bigger hacking programme than every other major nation combined”.
Taiwanese Defence Minister Chiu Kuo-cheng speaks during a parliament session in Taipei, Taiwan April 6, 2023. REUTERS/Carlos Garcia Rawlins
China's Vice-President Han Zheng speaks during the 78th session of the United Nations General Assembly at United Nations headquarters in New York, New York, Sept 21, 2023.

site_title: Singapore shares edge up at Thursday’s open; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.1% at Thursday's open, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 3,201.63. Gainers outnumbered losers 53 to 43, with 54.1 million securities worth S$48.4 million changing hands. The most active counter by volume was Rex International, which climbed 4.7%. The market follows a mixed close in US and Europe markets overnight.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
A man walks in front of the Singapore Exchange building (SGX) on July 21, 2022.

site_title: Bitcoin’s refuge appeal being touted again with shutdown prospects rising
summary: Bitcoin is expected to rally amid increasing US federal government shutdown prospects, with some advocates likening the situation to the regional bank crisis in March, when the cryptocurrency jumped 25% in a month. The crisis led to the failure of three small- to mid-size US banks over five days. Bitcoin's price surge was attributed to its "safety hedge" appeal during times of financial uncertainty. Experts are now watching to see if Bitcoin will rally during periods of US economic and financial uncertainty, rather than just in a banking crisis context.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Representations of cryptocurrencies are seen in this illustration, August 10, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration
If approved, Franklin plans to use Coinbase Global as custodian for the fund’s Bitcoin holdings and Bank of New York Mellon for cash.

site_title: Holidays at home for record number of Chinese as economic slowdown bites
summary: A record number of Chinese are staying home for the Golden Week holiday, boosting domestic consumption but disappointing travel agents. The economic slowdown and weak job market have led to lower spending, with many preferring to stay within China or visit cheaper destinations like Thailand. The China Tourism Academy estimates over 100 million trips will be made during this year's Golden Week, with trains and flights expected to be packed. Domestic tourism is seen as a key gauge of consumer appetite, but the outbound market has only recovered to 60% of pre-pandemic levels due to high ticket prices and visa issues.

images.alt_text: Developers are counting on the Golden Week to reverse a slump in home sales.
The survey’s authors suggested to policymakers to implement “slightly more aggressive” monetary policies to stabilise the housing market in the short term.
The announcement from the politburo comes a day after party inspection teams concluded investigations into dozens of state-owned enterprises.

site_title: Apac Realty expands into Australia with ERA Queensland master franchise
summary: Apac Realty, a MAINBOARD-LISTED company, has expanded into Australia with the grant of the ERA Queensland master franchise. The move is seen as recognition of Australia's well-established real estate market and its long-term growth potential. ERA Queensland will have 17 agents across three offices in Brisbane, focusing on off-plan projects, high-end properties, and commercial sales. This marks the 12th market for Apac Realty, which operates in countries such as Singapore, Indonesia, and Malaysia.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim

site_title: Stocks to watch: SGX, Genting Singapore, Boustead Singapore
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is adjusting the conversion price of its guaranteed convertible bonds due 2024 to S$12.0532 from S$12.264. Genting Singapore's subsidiary Resorts World Sentosa was fined S$95,000 for breaches of anti-money laundering rules. Boustead Singapore requested an extension to provide details on its exit offer after the SGX Regulation issued a directive for the delisting of Boustead Projects. OUE Healthcare's offer to take Healthway Medical private turned unconditional after 50.47% of Healthway Medical shares were accepted. Apac Realty expanded to Queensland with a master franchise agreement.

site_title: A shifting landscape
summary: Singapore's property market is experiencing shifting dynamics, with foreign buying in the prime residential sector dwindling and local buyers holding the majority. Residential rentals are expected to ease, but certain segments will remain strong for landlords. The mass market condo segment is crucial for market stability, and executive condominiums are in high demand. The government's new public housing framework could influence buying behavior. As Singapore becomes a "super-aged" society by 2030, opportunities in the senior-living market are emerging, and family offices are investing in alternative assets, including strata-titled office space and industrial property.

site_title: How Singapore’s water tariffs compare with other countries
summary: Singapore's water tariffs have increased by 18.2% as of April 2025, with the global average increase in water tariffs being 8.2% in 2022-2023. This ranks Singapore 55th out of 188 nations. The country's high water tariff is attributed to factors such as limited space for rainwater collection, high operational costs, and expansion of the water supply system. Other countries with steep price hikes include Pakistan, Argentina, and Iran, with prices per cubic meter ranging from US$0.28 to US$8.78.

site_title: US economy facing headwinds from possible government shutdown: White House
summary: The US economy is facing headwinds from a possible government shutdown, student debt payments restarting, higher interest rates, and an autoworkers' strike, according to White House chief economist Jared Bernstein. Despite these challenges, the economy is expected to continue in a "pretty good way" due to a dynamic where wages are growing faster than prices, creating a persistent "flywheel."

site_title: Google, Meta and Apple set to win US approval for virtual reality devices
summary: US regulators are set to approve Google, Meta, and Apple's proposal to use the 6 GHz band for mobile virtual and augmented reality devices. The FCC chairwoman, Jessica Rosenworcel, announced the plan, citing its potential to foster innovation and improve consumer experiences. The devices, including goggles and in-car connections, will tap into airwaves currently used by Wi-Fi-enabled devices, allowing for faster data transfer and new applications. The FCC is expected to vote on the proposal on October 19, with a likely approval due to Rosenworcel's Democratic majority.

site_title: Apple iPhone 15 Pro users complain device can get too hot
summary: Some Apple iPhone 15 Pro and Pro Max users are complaining that their devices become hot to the touch, particularly during gaming or phone calls. The issue has been reported on Apple online forums and social media, with some users experiencing temperatures that can be felt through cases. Apple has referred customers to an old support article, which notes that overheating can occur due to intensive apps, charging, or setting up a new device. The cause of the issue is unclear, but it may be related to the new A17 chip or the titanium frame used in the latest models.

images.alt_text: The proposed class action lawsuit said Apple “coerces” people who use its smartphones, tablets and smart watches into using its own wallet for tap-and-pay transactions, unlike makers of Android-based devices that let people choose wallets such as Google Pay and Samsung Pay.
Apple has used Google as the default search engine in its Safari browser since 2003.

Waiting time for the iPhone 15 has quadrupled in China, Apple’s biggest overseas market.
The devices are going on sale in about 40 countries in its first wave, including in Australia, Hong Kong, mainland China, the US, UK and France.

site_title: UK car output ends six-month growth streak in August: SMMT
summary: UK car output decreased by 9.7% in August, ending a six-month growth streak, with 45,052 vehicles rolled out of factory lines, down from the year earlier. The decline was attributed to manufacturers pausing production to prepare for next-generation electric vehicles. Combined volumes of electrified vehicles rose 2.8% in August, while the industry body SMMT downplayed the decline, citing a "small and variable" month. The move comes as the UK's car industry faces economic uncertainty and rising interest rates.

images.alt_text: Signage saying ‘Electrifying Britain’ is seen on the outside of the Stellantis owned Vauxhall car factory in Ellesmere Port, Britain, September 20, 2023. REUTERS/Phil Noble

site_title:
Short-term pain could make way
for long-term gain in prime condos
summary: Singapore's prime condo market may still end 2023 in positive territory due to sellers' holding power. The latest cooling measures, including increased Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) rates, have dampened demand. Foreigner buying activities in the prime condo market have plummeted, with foreign demand falling to 4% of total transactions in July, a new monthly low since 2008. The CCR offers an interesting value proposition and potential margin of safety, making it an attractive option for investors.

site_title: SGX adjusts conversion price of 240 million euro convertible bonds in view of dividend
summary: SGX is adjusting the conversion price of its 240 million euro zero coupon guaranteed convertible bonds due 2024 to S$12.0532, effective from Oct 16, to account for a S$0.085 per-share dividend to be approved at its upcoming annual general meeting. The adjusted conversion price is lower than the current S$12.264. The dividend payout for FY2023 will be S$0.325 per share, higher than the S$0.32 per-share payout in FY2022.

site_title: Crypto exchange Kraken plans to offer trading in US-listed stocks
summary: Kraken, a 12-year-old cryptocurrency exchange, plans to offer trading in US-listed stocks and exchange-traded funds (ETFs) through its new division, Kraken Securities. The company holds regulatory permits in the UK and has applied for a US broker-dealer license. The service is expected to launch in 2024, targeting a crowded market with zero-commission players like Robinhood Markets and Public.com. This move comes after a "crypto winter" and follows other exchanges like FTX.US, which was shut down after offering stock trading.

images.alt_text: San Francisco-based Kraken is a top cryptocurrency exchange with daily trading volume of roughly US$650 million globally.

site_title: New Zealand business confidence turns positive in Sept, inflation concerns linger: ANZ survey
summary: New Zealand business confidence turned positive in September, with a net 1.5% of respondents expecting the economy to improve, up from a 3.7% pessimism level in August. Despite this, concerns about high inflation remain. The survey also showed a 10.9% of respondents expected their businesses to grow in the next 12 months. Economists note that inflation pressures are gradually waning, but the pace is uncertain.

site_title: ChatGPT users can now browse Internet, OpenAI says
summary: OpenAI has introduced a browsing feature for its ChatGPT users, allowing them to access the internet and interact with websites. This feature, available to Plus and Enterprise users, enables websites to control how ChatGPT interacts with them. The update, which includes voice conversations and image interactions, brings ChatGPT closer to popular AI assistants like Siri. This expansion comes as ChatGPT reaches 100 million monthly active users and sparks interest in OpenAI's valuation, with reports of potential sales of existing shares to investors.

images.alt_text: ChatGPT, a chatbot that can generate human-like responses based on user prompts, has helped AI’s popularity erupt.
OpenAI said it is adding voice and image capabilities to ChatGPT, which was previously limited to written prompts.
Since its debut last year, ChatGPT has been adopted by companies for a wide range of tasks from summarising documents to writing computer code.

site_title: Family offices turn attention towards alternative investments
summary: Family offices in the Asia-Pacific region, particularly in Singapore and Hong Kong, are shifting their investment strategies due to inflation and high debt costs. They are moving down the risk curve to pursue value-add and opportunistic strategies. According to the 2023 Global Family Office Compensation Benchmark Report, 59% of family offices in the region are based in Singapore, making it a hub for family offices. This trend highlights the changing investment priorities of family offices in the face of economic uncertainty.

site_title: S$1.1 billion support package with cash, vouchers, rebates to help Singaporeans with rising costs
summary: Singapore's government has announced a S$1.1 billion support package to help citizens cope with rising costs, including an additional S$800 million to the Goods and Services Tax (GST) Assurance Package. The package includes cash payouts, vouchers, and rebates for utility bills, with the aim of cushioning the impact of the GST hike to 9% in January 2024. The measures include a one-off cash payout of up to S$200, additional CDC vouchers, and public transport subsidies. The package aims to support lower to middle-income families and households with rising costs, with no need to dip into past reserves.

site_title: Mass market condo segment key to stability
summary: The mass market condo segment in Singapore is crucial for maintaining market stability. In 2023, private non-landed residential properties in the Outside Central Region (OCR) accounted for 46% of the market, with the proportion remaining stable since 2017. HDB upgraders, who account for a significant portion of demand, have seen a decline in the number of buyers with an HDB address, from 50% in 2017 to 20.5% in 2023. To address this, the government has introduced cooling measures, including higher Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) and Loan-to-Value Ratio (LTV) limits, to curb buying and ensure a stable supply of non-landed homes.

site_title: A brave new world for HDB buyers and sellers
summary: The HDB resale market in Singapore is expected to see the effects of the BTO flat reclassification on resale prices in the next decade. The new framework, announced by Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, aims to bridge the widening HDB price gap islandwide. The reclassification will limit resale prices of Plus and Prime flats, potentially favoring Standard flats. Existing resale flat owners are not affected, and demand remains resilient. The new framework is expected to moderate resale price growth and deter speculation, while also making it easier for HDB flat owners to upgrade to executive condominiums or private property.

site_title: Meta unveils AI assistant, Facebook-streaming glasses
summary: Meta unveiled AI assistant and Facebook-streaming glasses, MetaQuest 3, at the Meta Connect Developer Conference. The new products include AI-powered smart glasses and a virtual-reality headset, with a focus on low-cost or free AI integration into daily routines. Meta's Quest is the bestseller in the VR space, and the company's executives highlighted its affordability as a competitive advantage over Apple's upcoming headset. Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg emphasized the products' ability to bring together virtual and real worlds, with a focus on practical applications and user experience.

images.alt_text: Among the new products YouTube announces is a tool called Dream Screen that uses generative AI to add video or image backgrounds to short-form videos, which the company calls Shorts.

As in retail, where Amazon slowly built up control of every part of selling online – sourcing products, running the store, handling logistics – so too is Amazon looking to be involved at every layer of the AI industry.
By processing vast datasets, detecting patterns and incorporating multiple variables, AI can refine economic and monetary predictions.
Last June, the US Federal Trade Commission filed a complaint against Amazon for “entrapping consumers” with its Prime subscription, which renews automatically and is complicated to cancel.

site_title: Singapore biotech startups face funding drought, in search of patient capital
summary: Singapore biotech startups face a funding drought due to investors seeking greater certainty of returns. Fundraising in the human health and potential category declined from $1.75 billion in 2021 to $770,000 in 2022. This drop in funding has made it a "tough situation" for biotech startups, with CEO Carl Firth describing 2022 as "one of the worst years on record for biotech."

images.alt_text: Daphne Yow

site_title: Bruce Springsteen ‘on the mend’ but won’t return to tour until 2024
summary: Bruce Springsteen has postponed the remainder of his 2023 tour dates due to his ongoing treatment for peptic ulcer disease. The 74-year-old singer has continued to recover steadily and will continue treatment for the rest of the year. Rescheduled dates for the postponed shows will be announced next week, with refunds available for those unable to attend. Springsteen has been on tour with his E Street Band since the start of the year, with the tour set to resume in 2024.

site_title: Trump, Biden fight next year’s battle now in blue-collar Michigan
summary: US President Joe Biden and former President Donald Trump are locked in a battle for blue-collar votes in Michigan, a crucial swing state ahead of the 2024 presidential election. Biden has been visiting Michigan, supporting the United Auto Workers union's calls for higher wages, while Trump is focusing on his nationalistic promises and warning that electric cars will lead to job losses. Despite Biden's efforts, many workers, like auto worker Curtis Cranford, are skeptical of the Democrat's plans and are more likely to vote for Trump, citing concerns about immigration and abortion.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - US President Joe Biden joins a picket line with members of the United Auto Workers (UAW) union at a General Motors Service Parts Operations plant in Belleville, Michigan, on September 26, 2023. Some 5,600 members of the UAW walked out of 38 US parts and distribution centers at General Motors and Stellantis at noon September 22, 2023, adding to last week's dramatic worker walkout. According to the White House, Biden is the first sitting president to join a picket line. (Photo by Jim WATSON / AFP)

site_title: Europe: Shares fall for fifth day as real estate stocks tumble
summary: European shares fell for a fifth consecutive day, with the Stoxx 600 index slipping 0.2% to a six-month low. Real estate stocks tumbled after bearish comments on UK landlords and negative corporate updates from Dutch insurers and Swiss bank UBS. The market mood remained gloomy due to uncertainty over central banks' interest rate decisions and weakness in China's property sector. The Stoxx 600 is set for its first quarterly loss in four, with shares of Land Securities, British Land, and Derwent London falling by 3.4% to 4.3%.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.2 per cent to 33,550.27 on Thursday.

site_title: Apple ordered to face Apple Pay antitrust lawsuit
summary: US District Judge Jeffrey White has ordered Apple to face a private antitrust lawsuit over allegations that the company coerces users into using its Apple Pay wallet, stifling competition from Android-based devices. The lawsuit claims Apple's conduct forces banks and credit unions to pay excess fees, harms consumers, and reduces innovation. The plaintiffs can proceed with their case, which could result in billions of dollars in damages, with the judge allowing a "plausible" claim that Apple's conduct violates the Sherman antitrust law.

site_title: Ageing with dignity: opportunities in the senior-living market
summary: Singapore is poised to become a "super-aged" society by 2030, with nearly a quarter of citizens aged 65 and above. To meet the needs of seniors, public assisted-living housing, such as Community Care Apartments, is being incorporated into new Build-To-Order projects. This trend is expected to continue, driven by the government's initiatives to provide affordable housing options for the elderly. The senior-living market is seen as ripe for growth, with opportunities in land zoning for senior living developments.

site_title: Be a part of Singapore’s future food hub
summary: Singapore is developing its food security with the creation of the Northern Agri-Tech and Food Corridor, connecting the Agri-Food Innovation Park with the Senoko Food Zone and farms. To meet this goal, a freehold food factory development, Food Vision, is being built in Mandai. This 6,900 sqm development will offer dedicated facilities for food manufacturing, processing, packaging, and storage, catering to the growing demand for cloud kitchens and food delivery. Investors are drawn to the area due to its proximity to the food corridor and the government's initiatives to boost the food industry, with units priced from S$2.32 million.

site_title:
Singapore industrial: a bright spot 
in commercial real estate
summary: Singapore's industrial sector has emerged as a bright spot in the commercial real estate market, driven by demand for modern and efficient assets. Despite higher interest rates and uncertainty, the sector has seen strong growth in rents and prices, with the warehouse segment outperforming overall industrial rents. The shortage of supply, coupled with punitive Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty, has redirected investor interest to commercial real estate, including industrial assets. However, the sector's growth is expected to moderate with increasing supply, and the shine may not last due to higher costs and macroeconomic conditions.

site_title: Chinese hackers stole 60,000 emails from US State Department in Microsoft hack, Senate staffer says
summary: Chinese hackers allegedly stole 60,000 emails from US State Department accounts, including 10 different accounts, through a Microsoft hack earlier this year. The stolen emails involved East Asia and the Pacific policy work, with the victims' identities not disclosed. China denies involvement in the spying. The incident has strained the US-China relationship and raised concerns about the US government's reliance on a single IT vendor, Microsoft.

site_title: US: Stocks mixed as lofty bond yields remain a worry
summary: US stocks experienced a mixed session on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 0.2% to 33,550.27. Higher oil prices and rising Treasury bond yields, which pushed closer to 5%, weighed on markets. The S&P 500 remained flat at 4,274.51, while the Nasdaq Composite Index gained 0.3% to 13,092.85. Despite a pullback in yields, signs of economic resilience may lead to further interest rate hikes, according to analysts.

site_title: Behind the rise of landed property values
summary: In Singapore, the demand for more living space has led to the rise of larger built-up areas in landed properties, resulting in higher prices. New-build and rebuilt landed properties have seen a median price increase of 26% from 2018 to 2023, with land prices rising 60% for new detached houses and 28% for new semi-detached houses. The significant rise is attributed to strong demand, limited supply, and higher costs of quality homes. Despite a slowdown in sales momentum in 2023, the URA price index for landed homes is expected to continue its uptrend at a slower pace.

site_title: Oil climbs 3% as steep US crude stocks draw adds to supply concerns
summary: Oil prices surged 3% on Wednesday, reaching the highest settlement in 2023, due to a steep drop in US crude stocks, which compounded concerns of tight global supplies. Brent crude futures closed at $96.55, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures climbed to $93.68. The price increase follows recent supply concerns and comes ahead of a meeting of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC).

site_title: Smarter home solutions of the future
summary: City Energy's Küche range offers a suite of Internet of Things (IoT)-enabled home solutions, transforming living spaces into sophisticated and interconnected environments. Launched in March 2022, the collection includes smart appliances such as a gas hob, cooker hood, gas water heater, and oven, which can be controlled and monitored through the iAppliances app. These solutions aim to provide energy efficiency, security, and a modern lifestyle, while also being lower-carbon and affordable. The company partners with premium brands to bring in home and kitchen solutions, and plans to leverage these solutions for property developers catering to tech-savvy and eco-conscious homeowners.

site_title: International residential hotspots for the global investor
summary: Singaporean investors are shifting their focus to international residential hotspots due to the country's rising property prices and economic volatility. Established markets like the UK, Portugal, Australia, and Japan are gaining attention, with promising destinations including London, Lisbon, Sydney, and Tokyo. These countries offer attractive yields, capital growth, and stable rental markets, making them attractive alternatives to Singapore. With inflation and interest rates influencing market dynamics, investors are diversifying their portfolios to mitigate country-specific risks and capitalize on emerging opportunities.

summary: Pinetree Hill, a new condominium development in Singapore, is set for completion in 2027. Located in the Pine Grove private residential enclave, the 520-unit project offers modern living with a close-to-nature setting. Unit prices start from S$2,314 per square foot, and the development features a 12:1 ratio of landscaping to units. With proximity to schools, universities, and amenities, Pinetree Hill is an attractive option for young families and urban professionals, offering high upside potential for buyers.

site_title: IT problems halt production at Volkswagen factories
summary: Volkswagen's production was halted at least five factories in Germany due to IT problems starting at 12:30 pm GMT on Wednesday, with the issue still unresolved by evening. The company confirmed the disruption with a statement. The impact of the IT issues was significant, bringing production to a standstill at the VW brand plants in Germany.

site_title: Bank of England delays final Basel bank capital rules to July 2025
summary: The Bank of England has delayed the rollout of the final Basel bank capital rules to July 2025, aligning with the US Federal Reserve's plan. The decision aims to give firms more time to prepare, with a cut in the transitional period to ensure full implementation by 1 January 2030. The UK Finance industry body expressed concerns over the delay, urging the Prudential Regulation Authority to finalize requirements by Easter 2024.

images.alt_text: US Federal Reserve policymakers are holding the Fed’s benchmark rate at 5.25 per cent-5.50 per cent but are stressing that they will remain tough in an inflation fight they now see lasting into 2026.

site_title: Micron slides after predicting steeper loss than expected
summary: Micron Technology reported a steeper-than-expected loss in its first quarter, citing a continued industry slump. The company projected a loss of up to $1.14 per share, exceeding analyst estimates of a $0.96 loss. Despite this, Micron expects the industry outlook to improve by 2025, driven by growing demand for more expensive memory chips in artificial intelligence systems. Revenue is expected to start recovering in the first quarter, with sales predicted to range from $4.2 billion to $4.6 billion.

site_title: Respite for residential renters around the corner
summary: The private residential rental market in Singapore may have turned a corner, with rental growth slowing for a third consecutive quarter in Q2 2023. Rents rose 2.8% in Q2, compared to 7.2% in Q1 2023 and 7.4% in Q4 2022. Demand contracted, with rental volume falling 25,657 units in Q3 2022 to 19,699 units in Q2 2023. HDB flats remain in high demand, with total transactions rising 1.9% in Q2 2023. Rents may peak in H2 2023 due to increased housing supply, declining local demand, and a slowing economy.

This niche market offers advantages such as cost savings, flexibility, and potential for ownership and investment. However, challenges in maintenance and upkeep remain, and buyers should be mindful of these drawbacks.

site_title: Is the Singapore office market turning?
summary: Singapore's office market has shown resilience since the Covid-19 pandemic, but recent months have brought cautionary signs, including slower rental growth. Despite this, the prime CBD market is poised for recovery, with core CBD (Grade A) rents logging gains of 11.9% in 2021-2022. The government's forward-looking policies and agile response to the pandemic have contributed to the market's recovery, with islandwide office vacancy falling to a record low of 5% by the end of 2022. The market is expected to bounce back, driven by the hybrid-working trend and tech industry growth.

summary: LHN Logistics' voluntary unconditional general offer by Milkyway Chemical closed with 99.14% valid acceptances, paving the way for the company's delisting from the Catalist board. The offeror intends to compulsorily acquire remaining shares and will proceed with delisting upon completion. LHN Logistics went public in April last year at S$0.20 per share, with the offer price at S$0.2266 per share.

site_title: Jefferies revenue misses estimates on investment banking drag
summary: Jefferies' third-quarter revenue missed analyst estimates, falling short of $1.25 billion due to a 30% drop in advisory revenue. The firm attributed the decline to a challenging investment banking environment. Despite this, CEO Richard Handler expressed optimism that the company has "come off the bottom of the cycle" and expects momentum in investment banking to continue.

site_title: Healthier SG: From enrolment to execution
summary: Singapore's Healthier SG programme, launched in July, aims to shift the healthcare system's focus from treatment to prevention and deliver better healthcare value. To realise its potential, public healthcare clusters must transform by determining their desired care model, designing clinical and operational processes, and implementing organisational changes. This requires designing a funding model that aligns with the target care model, considering factors such as financing, incentives, and data analytics capabilities. The transformation will be challenging, given the clusters' current pressures and the unique operating context. An agile approach, with small, multidisciplinary teams and a focus on organisation-wide alignment, can help navigate the change and achieve better health outcomes.

images.alt_text: In his annual National Day Rally speech, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong gave Singaporeans reassurance on issues such as cost of living and jobs.
While enrolment in Healthier SG for patients and doctors alike remains voluntary, GP clinics have generally seen an increase in administrative costs arising from their participation.
The cruise industry could enjoy a boost from older adults with money to spend on travel.

site_title: The ‘one out of hell’ is back in Europe
summary: The far right is gaining power in Europe, with countries such as Italy, Finland, and Belgium governed by its forces. The trend is attributed to the decline of mainstream parties, which have become beholden to business interests at the expense of citizens. The rise of the far right is also linked to the erosion of left-wing parties and unions. The parties now focus on issues like immigration and welfare, while their leaders accept that Europe will no longer be a protagonist in the 21st century, instead seeking to protect itself from the rest of the world.

images.alt_text: FILE — The leader of the far-right party Alternative for Germany, AfD, Björn Höcke, speaks at a rally in Dresden, Germany, on Feb. 17, 2020. Höcke is viewed as one of the party’s most extreme figures. (Gordon Welters/The New York Times)

site_title: US: Wall St gains at open after previous session's mauling
summary: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 63.93 points, or 0.19%, to 33,682.81, following easing Treasury yields that boosted megacaps. Investors await US funding bill and inflation data this week to gauge the Federal Reserve's policy outlook.

site_title: Biden’s US$15 minimum wage for federal contractors blocked by US judge
summary: A US federal judge in Texas blocked President Joe Biden's executive order requiring US government contractors to pay workers a minimum wage of $15 an hour, citing a lack of congressional authority. The ruling, made by Republican appointee Judge Drew Tipton, paused the decision for 7 days to allow an appeal. The order, aimed at supporting blue-collar workers, was one of Biden's pro-labour moves since becoming president, but the judge found it exceeded the president's powers under the Procurement Act.

summary: City Energy's subsidiary Go by City Energy has seen a robust response a year after its launch, with over 100 EV charging stations set to be installed across Singapore by the end of 2023. The network also extends to Malaysia, with over 200 EV charging points available across the Causeway. Go users can access chargers via a common app, providing seamless cross-border charging and alleviating "range anxiety." Property developers benefit from no upfront fees, while real-time data collected from charge points helps with space-planning and efficiency.

Sevens Atelier promptly informed the market about the probe, releasing a four-paragraph announcement on Sep 20. In contrast, VCPlus has not made any public statements regarding the investigation.
