site_title: Shell CEO comes under pressure from within on renewables shift
summary: Shell CEO Wael Sawan faces internal pressure to maintain investments in renewable energy after two employees wrote an open letter criticizing his strategy to scale back investments in the sector. The letter, signed by Lisette de Heiden and Wouter Drinkwaard, expressed concern over the company's plans to slow investment in renewables and low-carbon business. Sawan responded, stating that "for an organisation at the crux of the energy transition, there are no easy answers," but reaffirming Shell's commitment to providing lower-carbon solutions and becoming a net-zero emissions company by 2050.

images.alt_text: Shell’s pullback reflects Sawan’s renewed commitment to the oil-and-gas business that generates most of company’s profits.
While Sinopec is not keen on acquiring Shell's Singapore assets, it is interested in participating in Saudi Arabia’s Jafurah shale gas project, says its president Yu Baocai.

Shell is targeting spending cuts over the next two years to boost profitability while remaining committed to achieving net-zero emissions by 2050. Those efforts include the review of energy and chemicals assets on Singapore’s Bukom and Jurong islands.

FILE PHOTO: The logo of British multinational oil and gas company Shell is displayed during the LNG 2023 energy trade show in Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada, July 12, 2023. REUTERS/Chris Helgren/File Photo

site_title: Microsoft says Apple used Bing offer as Google ‘bargaining chip’
summary: Microsoft claims Apple has used Google as the default search engine in Safari browser since 2003 as a "bargaining chip" to keep Bing from gaining traction, despite Microsoft's efforts to displace Google. Apple allegedly earns between $4 billion and $7 billion annually from the deal, which has allowed Google to maintain its monopoly over the online search market. Microsoft's head of advertising and Web services, Mikhail Parakhin, testified that it's "uneconomical" for Microsoft to invest in mobile search technology without a significant guarantee of distribution.

images.alt_text: Waiting time for the iPhone 15 has quadrupled in China, Apple’s biggest overseas market.
The devices are going on sale in about 40 countries in its first wave, including in Australia, Hong Kong, mainland China, the US, UK and France.
People who ordered the latest iPhone model line up outside an Apple store in Beijing, China, Sept 22, 2023.
Thai PM Stretta says that Tesla is looking into an electric vehicle manufacturing facility while Microsoft and Google are looking at data centres.
Microsoft executive Brad Smith says the firm will continue to work towards winning final approval to close the deal by Oct 18.
Microsoft's shares have outperformed the iPhone maker’s this month, bringing its market value closer to Apple, which is at the centre of a flareup in tensions with China.

site_title: China investor gloom on property reaches record, survey finds
summary: A record 31.7% of Chinese investors plan to cut their property investment over the next year, according to a survey, highlighting the sector's difficulties. Pessimism on property values and concerns over liquidity are driving this decision. The survey's authors suggest policymakers implement "slightly more aggressive" monetary policies to stabilize the housing market. Chinese property stocks have tumbled to their lowest levels since 2011, with investors showing optimism in other areas, such as domestic share prices and GDP growth.

images.alt_text: A construction site of a housing project in Ningbo, in China’s eastern Zhejiang province. The ailing property sector continues to be hobbled by liquidity woes and sluggish demand.

site_title: Chinese tycoon Chen Hongtian's seized Hong Kong condo sold for US$53.4 million
summary: Chinese tycoon Chen Hongtian's seized luxury Hong Kong condo, valued at HK$680 million (US$53.4 million), has been sold. The fifth-floor apartment in Opus Hong Kong was 39% lower than the reported valuation. Chen, chairman of Cheung Kei Group, has had assets seized by creditors amid China's property crisis, including a US$271 million mansion and a US$892 million commercial building. This sale is part of his efforts to repay creditors.

site_title: Executive condos are still residential market darlings
summary: Singapore's executive condos (ECs) remain in high demand despite rising prices, with 61% of new EC units sold in Bukit Batok's Altura project at an average price of S$1,433 per square foot. The median unit price of new ECs rose to S$1.44 million in 2023, driven by high land prices and construction costs. ECs offer a more affordable alternative to private condos, with a 47% price gap, and buyers may perceive good HDB upgrader demand in areas like Tengah. The EC market is seen as a safe haven for developers, with a stable demand pool and limited stock, and past trends show healthy profits for first owners of new ECs.

images.alt_text: Artist’s impression of Copen Grand, the first BCA Green Mark Platinum Super Low Energy executive condominium in Tengah Town.

site_title: PropertyBT: Why buy ECs? (Ep 23)
summary: Executive Condominiums (ECs) are gaining popularity in Singapore due to their hybrid nature between public and private housing. Experts suggest that buying a new EC home may be a wise choice for young couples, as they can be built in prime areas to meet private housing aspirations. However, the ideal time to sell an EC home is unclear, and market fluctuations may impact its value. Analysts recommend considering factors such as location, market trends, and personal financial goals when deciding whether to buy or sell an EC home.

images.alt_text: Is it wise to have much of your wealth tied up in Singapore homes?
Building new ECs in prime locations can help locals achieve private housing dreams.
Mass market homes tend to see more demand from HDB upgraders. But the number and proportion of buyers with an HDB address has declined in recent years.
Most new launches in the fourth quarter of this year will be in the suburbs.
Artist’s impression of Copen Grand, the first BCA Green Mark Platinum Super Low Energy executive condominium in Tengah Town.

site_title: US ‘Latino GDP’ at US$3.2 trillion would rank ahead of UK, India
summary: US Latinos contributed $3.2 trillion to the US economy in 2021, ranking fifth in the world, behind Germany and ahead of the UK and India. With high workforce participation, population growth, and increased productivity, Latinos saw incomes rise at an annualized rate of 4.7% from 2011-2021, contributing 20.9% to real GDP growth. The report highlights the significant economic contributions of Latinos in states like California, Texas, and New York, and suggests that uneducated immigration policies could hinder economic growth.

images.alt_text: Is white majority dead? It's risky to misread demographic trends

site_title: Las Vegas bartenders and servers move closer to a strike
summary: Las Vegas hospitality workers, representing over 53,000 employees, have voted 95% to authorise a strike if negotiations for a new contract fail. The Culinary Workers Union Local 226 and Bartenders Union Local 165 are seeking a five-year contract with historic wage increases, reduced workload quotas, and job security guarantees. A strike could bring 39 hotels, casinos, and resorts on the strip to a standstill, including Caesars Palace, Mandalay Bay, and Bellagio. Negotiations with MGM Resorts, Caesars Entertainment, and Wynn Resorts are set to begin next week.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden joins striking members of the United Auto Workers on the picket line outside the GM's Willow Run Distribution Centre in Belleville, Wayne County, Michigan, Sept 26, 2023.
The United Auto Workers is on strike against the nation’s largest automakers – the first time the union has hit every one of the Big Three at once.

The vote in Canada - with 54 per cent approving - came two days after the United Auto Workers expanded its US strike against General Motors and Stellantis while holding off against Ford, which the union said had done more to meet demands.
Tesla Chief Executive Officer Elon Musk gets in a Tesla car as he leaves a hotel in Beijing, China May 31, 2023.

site_title: Singapore to raise water price by 18% by April 2025 as costs climb
summary: Singapore's national water agency PUB will increase water prices by 18.2% starting April 2025, driven by substantially higher costs of production and supply, including a 37% rise in electricity market tariffs and 35% increase in construction costs. The price hike will affect businesses and households, with monthly water bills increasing by less than $25 for three-quarters of businesses and less than $10 for three-quarters of households. The government will also announce additional cost of living support to mitigate the impact.

images.alt_text: Singapore's water prices, as compared with other cities, in July 2023
On housing, accommodation inflation is up/down to x per cent in August, from July's x per cent.
The 40m-tall sludge digesters under construction at the Tuas Water Reclamation Plant, on Sep 21.

site_title: Chinese universities climb up leading global ranking
summary: Chinese universities have made a significant rise in the global rankings, with Tsinghua University climbing to 12th place and Peking University rising to 14th. This marks the first time two Chinese universities have entered the top 15. China now has seven universities in the top 100, up from two in 2018, and 30 in the top 400 list. The US remains dominant, with 13 universities in the top 20, while Britain's University of Oxford holds the top spot for the eighth consecutive year.

images.alt_text: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat (second from right) with (from left) Protege Ventures managing partners Sherwin Ng and Anaanya Bijay; SMU's VP of partnerships and engagement Lim Sun Sun; and Matrix Partners China founding managing partner David Su.

Education Minister Chan Chun Sing at the 38th Singapore Business Awards. He told business leaders that companies should be sharper about the kinds of skill sets and competencies they want from their people, rather than look at paper qualifications.
An additional NZ$128 million will be invested in the tertiary sector.
The Loy family is working with a financial adviser on the potential stake sale in the unit, which comprises Taylor’s University in Malaysia (above) and British University in Vietnam.

site_title: China starts local government debt swap programme
summary: China has launched a debt swap programme to allow local governments to swap "hidden" debt for bonds carrying lower interest costs, aiming to defuse risks from $9 billion of off-balance sheet borrowing. The programme, which will allow provincial governments to raise $187.5 billion via bond sales, is aimed at resolving debt risks in high-debt areas and improving financial stability. The move follows concerns that debt servicing costs are limiting local governments' ability to deliver fiscal support to the economy, potentially dragging on China's growth.

images.alt_text: Investors monitor stock prices at a securities exchange house in Shanghai, China on Friday, 31 December 2010.

site_title: China to step up anti-graft efforts for better economic development
summary: China's politburo has announced a stepped-up anti-corruption effort in state-owned companies and the financial sector to boost economic contributions. The move comes after party inspection teams concluded investigations into dozens of state-owned enterprises. The politburo emphasized the need to enhance core competitiveness and increase financial sector efforts to serve the real economy. The announcement follows a turbulent time in China, with the disappearance of former officials and ongoing tensions over national security and the economy. The goal is to establish a mentality of "red lines" and take effective measures to prevent major risks.

images.alt_text: Ni Huizhong is one of a string of sport officials to come under scrutiny in recent months as the ruling Communist Party wages an industry-wide anti-corruption drive.

site_title: Indonesia to sue UK agency for share of Airbus bribery case settlement
summary: Indonesia plans to sue the UK's Serious Fraud Office for a share of the 991 million euro (S$1.43 billion) Airbus bribery settlement. The settlement was part of a record US$4 billion agreement with France, Britain, and the US following a 3.5-year investigation into bribery and corruption allegations. Law Minister Yasonna Laoly stated that Indonesia is seeking fairness as a "victim country" that provided evidence during the investigation.

site_title: Shipping industry has no easy path towards decarbonisation, says UNCTAD
summary: The United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD) has stated that decarbonizing the shipping industry by 2050 is a complex task due to the lack of clarity on future clean fuels and regulatory systems. The global shipping fleet is aging, with over half of the vessels over 15 years old, and companies are hesitant to replace them due to the associated costs. Estimates suggest that decarbonization could increase annual fuel costs by 70-100% and require investments of $8-28 billion annually.

images.alt_text: Lloyd’s Register and Lloyd’s Register Foundation have commissioned a report, Global Maritime Trends 2050, from Economist Impact that analyses different future scenarios for shipping.

site_title: Malaysia PM Anwar considering Cabinet reshuffle
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim is considering a cabinet reshuffle, following discussions about a change in minister lineup. Anwar, who came to power in November last year, must reconcile the nation's limited fiscal space with ambitions to become a high-income nation within five years. He also recently expressed support for China's Huawei Technologies to secure contracts for Malaysia's second 5G network, despite security concerns raised by the US and EU. The 2024 spending plan is set to be presented on October 13.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim said the sustained rise in both FDI and domestic direct investments is a testament of the restored confidence of investors towards Malaysia’s growth outlook.

site_title: Climate transition funds soar more than 300% in the US
summary: Climate transition funds in the US surged 304% to $9.3 billion in the past 18 months, reaching a record $32 billion, despite speculation that ESG investments would be hindered by political backlash. Assets in global climate funds rose by almost a third to $534 billion in June, with Europe accounting for 84% of global assets. Despite this growth, many ESG funds face challenges in attracting new money, and climate funds as a whole only grew 4% in the period, with most widely held companies in climate portfolios being misaligned with the goal of limiting global heating to 1.5°C.

images.alt_text: Photo by Yen Meng Jiin: ESG, socially responsible investing, and impact investing
HSBC has stepped up expansion in China despite criticism from some lawmakers in the West of the bank’s conduct in the region.
Indonesian state utility Perusahaan Listrik Negara has set a target to phase out coal power plants by 2056, as part of the country’s goal to reach net zero carbon emission by 2060.
KPMG indicated that now is the time for companies to build and improve their ESG reporting processes and become ready for external auditing with assurance.

site_title: No Signboard submits revised trading resumption proposal
summary: No Signboard Holdings has submitted a revised trading resumption proposal to the Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) due to recent developments in the company. Trading in the shares of the Catalist-listed restaurant operator has been suspended since January 24, 2022, as it was unable to demonstrate that it can continue as a going concern. This is the second revision to the proposal, following one announced in January 2023.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
No Signboard outlet at Esplanade.

site_title: Sri Lanka fails to seal first review of IMF's bailout, talks to continue
summary: Sri Lanka failed to reach a staff-level agreement with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) in its first review of a $2.9 billion bailout package due to a potential shortfall in government revenue generation. The IMF said early signs of stabilisation are present, but full economic recovery is not assured, and growth momentum remains subdued. The team will continue discussions to reach a staff-level agreement in the near term, with a focus on strengthening tax administration and reducing tax exemptions to increase revenues.

images.alt_text: This picture taken on September 12, 2022, shows the city skyline as pictured from the observation deck of the Chinese-built Lotus Tower in Colombo. - A huge green and purple communications tower in Sri Lanka financed with Chinese debt that has become a symbol of the ousted Rajapaksa clan's closeness to Beijing will finally open this week, its operator said on September 12. (Photo by Ishara S. KODIKARA / AFP)

site_title: Kia, Hyundai recall 3.37 million US vehicles over fire risks
summary: Hyundai and Kia are recalling 3.37 million US vehicles due to engine fire risks. The recalls, covering various models from 2010-2017, are related to brake fluid leaks causing electrical shorts. Hyundai has reported 21 fires and 21 thermal incidents, while Kia has reported at least 10 confirmed fires. Owners are advised to park outside structures until repairs are complete, with dealers replacing the affected components. The recalls are expected to be notified to owners in November.

images.alt_text: SAN LEANDRO, CALIFORNIA - MAY 30: A new Hyundai car is displayed on the sales lot at San Leandro Hyundai on May 30, 2023 in San Leandro, California. A surge in Kia and Hyundai thefts began last year after viral videos appeared on social media sites showing how to exploit the lack of antitheft computer chips in the cars. Kia and Hyundai cars continue to be stolen more than three months after the auto manufacturers deployed software fixes to help curb the thefts.   Justin Sullivan/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by JUSTIN SULLIVAN / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: RWS fined S$95,000 by GRA for breaching AML rules again
summary: Genting Singapore's subsidiary Resorts World Sentosa (RWS) was fined S$95,000 by the Gambling Regulatory Authority (GRA) for breaching anti-money laundering (AML) rules between April 2022 and March 2023. The breaches involved failure to perform customer due diligence measures and enhanced due diligence measures. This is the second time RWS has been fined for AML rule breaches, with a previous fine of S$200,000 in the financial year ended March 2022.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Tourists taking pictures at the entrance of the casino at Resorts World Sentosa (RWS) on 2 Jan 2018.

site_title: US durable goods orders unexpectedly rise in August
summary: US durable goods orders unexpectedly rose 0.2% in August, reversing a decline. Non-defence capital goods orders surged 0.9%, a reversal of a 0.4% decline in July. Economists had forecast a 0.5% decline. The rise may reflect higher prices, and manufacturing, which accounts for 11.1% of the economy, continues to slow due to higher borrowing costs. The US central bank has raised interest rates by 525 basis points since March 2022, and a strike by the United Auto Workers union could further pressure manufacturing.

site_title: The ins and outs of fractional property investing
summary: Straits Trading, a subsidiary of Straits Trading Company, launched two fractional property investment products linked to physical properties in District 10, Singapore. The minimum investment amounts are S$500,000 for a freehold Good Class Bungalow and S$200,000 for a 999-year leasehold condominium unit. Investors can expect annualized returns of 7.61% and 9.5%, respectively, after a five-year holding period. This model allows individual investors to diversify their holdings and frees them from managing properties on their own. However, investors must exercise due diligence and be aware of the risks, including market fluctuations and potential losses.

images.alt_text: Real estate blockchain firm Fraxtor obtains capital markets services licence from MAS
Real estate tokenisation - what does it mean for investors?
Keith Ong, CEO, RealVantage
Real estate investment platform RealVantage bags capital markets services licence from MAS
Fraxtor receives in-principle approval from MAS to deal in capital market products
A digital real estate market is taking shape in the brave new world of the metaverse. Decentraland is one of a few virtual players vying for early dominance.

The underlying properties being offered are a freehold Good Class Bungalow (GCB) located at 8A Cable Road, Chatsworth Park (pictured), and a 999-year leasehold condominium unit in Duchess Residences at Bukit Timah.

site_title: Boustead Singapore seeks extension to provide exit offer details
summary: BOUSTEAD Singapore is seeking an extension to provide details of its exit offer for Boustead Projects, a condition set by the Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) due to the issuer's failure to ensure at least 10% of shares are held by the public. The regulator directed the company to make a fair and reasonable exit offer within a month. BOUSTEAD Singapore's chairman and CEO, Wong Fong Fui, was exempt from the offer, holding shares through nominees. The extension request comes after SGX RegCo issued a directive for the delisting of Boustead Projects.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
In its notice of compliance, SGX RegCo also directed Boustead Projects, and/or Boustead Singapore to make an exit offer to the shareholders that is “fair and reasonable”

site_title: UBS, Credit Suisse face growing probe over alleged Russian sanctions evasion
summary: The US Department of Justice is investigating Credit Suisse and UBS over alleged Russian sanctions evasion, with the probe focusing on compliance failures that allowed Russian clients to evade sanctions. The investigation began as a series of subpoenas and has since developed into a full-scale probe, with the DOJ briefing US-based lawyers for UBS about Credit Suisse's alleged exposure to sanctions violations. The probe covers restrictions imposed after Russia's 2022 invasion of Ukraine and previous rounds, and may not result in charges or a settlement, although it comes at a delicate time for UBS, which is absorbing thousands of employees from Credit Suisse.

images.alt_text: UBS acquired local rival Credit Suisse in a rescue that closed in June.

site_title: US crypto industry comes to Washington, but faces uphill struggle: analysis
summary: US crypto companies are lobbying lawmakers on Capitol Hill to advance industry-friendly laws, but face an uphill struggle due to competing bills and a Senate crackdown on money laundering. Despite spending nearly $13 million on federal lobbying in the first half of 2023, crypto companies' efforts to push through bills defining security and commodity regulations may be hindered by lawmakers' focus on curbing money laundering and terrorist financing. Industry leaders, including Coinbase CEO Brian Armstrong, are meeting with lawmakers to urge passage of bills, but progress appears uncertain.

images.alt_text: Indian accounts that “no longer meet our updated standards” will be disabled on Sep 25, says Coinbase.
Coinbase Prime is a full-service prime brokerage platform that lets institutions execute trades and custody assets.
The NFA approval, filed by Coinbase almost two years ago, opens the door for the company to enter an untapped market.
Binance says the process would take a year to complete and would involve selling its assets to CommEX.
BlockFi unsecured creditors could get between roughly 35 per cent to 63 per cent of what they’re owed, according to an August court filing.
The combined reserve portfolios of the two largest stablecoins – Tether and USDC – was US$114 billion as at June 2023, with over 60 per cent in T-bills and 25 per cent in repo.

site_title: China expects 2023 economic growth of slightly more than 5%, says PBOC adviser
summary: China is expected to achieve economic growth of slightly more than 5% in 2023, according to a PBOC adviser. This contradicts concerns of "Japanification," a term referring to Japan's economic stagnation in the 1990s, as China's economic situation is distinct. Adviser Wang Yiming stated that China remains in the medium-to-high growth stage, with the government setting a growth target of around 5% for 2023.

site_title: Price of sustainable fuel likely to remain high: Iata head
summary: International Air Transport Association (IATA) head Willie Walsh states that sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) will likely remain more expensive than kerosene, despite large-scale production. Walsh believes SAF will always be priced at a premium to kerosene, which could deter airlines from meeting their carbon emission targets. IATA previously estimated that SAF could contribute 65% to reducing aviation emissions to net-zero by 2050.

images.alt_text: Willie Walsh, Director General of the International Air Transport Association (IATA), speaks during IATA annual meeting in Istanbul, Turkey June 5, 2023. REUTERS/Dilara Senkaya
FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: Passengers walk inside a duty free shop at Paris Charles de Gaulle airport in Roissy-en-France near Paris, France, December 2, 2021. REUTERS/Sarah Meyssonnier/File Photo

Climate activists hold a sign that reads "Schiphol stop polluting" as they protest outside a court where the aviation industry is instituting summary proceedings against the government over plans to limit flights at Amsterdam's Schiphol Airport for environmental reasons in Haarlem on March 21, 2023.

site_title: Japan broadcaster NHK drops disgraced boy band agency
summary: Japan's national broadcaster NHK has dropped ties with boy band agency Johnny & Associates, citing the agency's admission to decades-long sexual abuse by founder Johnny Kitagawa. The move comes after a BBC documentary and an external panel report sparked a probe and soul-searching. Brands such as McDonald's Japan, Nissan, and Kirin have already dissociated themselves from the agency. NHK will suspend making new offers until the agency takes concrete steps to compensate victims and prevent abuse. This may impact the agency's top stars from appearing in NHK's popular "Kohaku Uta Gassen" music show.

images.alt_text: The Foreign Correspondents’ Club of Japan, which hosted a press conference by the accuser, Kauan Okamoto (top), said the company also failed to respond to its invitations to comment.

site_title: Toyota plans third India plant, new SUV as domestic sales surge
summary: Toyota plans to build a third car plant in India, expanding production capacity by up to 30% and aiming for 200,000 vehicles per year. The new plant, which will start with a capacity of 80,000-120,000 vehicles, will be launched in early 2026 and be an anchor product for the new factory. Toyota's India sales have surged due to its partnership with Suzuki, with the new SUV, codenamed 340D, set to be launched in early 2026. The expansion comes as Toyota seeks to increase production capacity to 500,000 vehicles per year by the end of the decade.

images.alt_text: Toyota’s India business has been the biggest beneficiary of its global partnership with Suzuki which allows the two Japanese carmakers to share technology and vehicles.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall as weak sentiment lingers; STI down 0.5%
summary: Singapore stocks declined 0.5% on Wednesday, led by the three local banks - DBS, OCBC, and UOB - which fell 0.2%, 0.1%, and 0.6% respectively. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,200.03. The top gainer was Jardine Cycle & Carriage, which rose 1.6%. Weak sentiment was attributed to China's softer August industrial profits and lingering property sector risks.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah
Generic pictures of the interior and exterior of SGX

site_title: Crypto firm Binance pulls out of Russia
summary: Binance, a leading cryptocurrency firm, has announced it will sell its Russian business, citing the need to exit the market due to regulatory hurdles and compliance issues. The process, expected to take a year, involves selling assets to CommEX. The decision follows US authorities' investigation into possible sanctions violations and Binance's previous denials of breaking sanctions. The firm's move is the latest in a series of regulatory challenges facing the company, which has faced severe hurdles since crypto markets collapsed.

images.alt_text: MUFG has been discussing with multiple parties about using its blockchain platform, Progmat, to mint stablecoins tied to foreign currencies.
Tighter regulations generally have prompted many traditional financial institutions to hold back on offering cash to crypto services and vice versa, says Binance CEO Changpeng ‘CZ’ Zhao.
Binance Holdings has been shedding executives and other employees in recent months as well.
Binance will gradually suspend BUSD support over the coming months, starting with some services in September.
The access to MoonPay would provide an alternative way for Binance.US’s users to convert US dollars to crypto.

site_title: German firms less willing to hire amid lacklustre economy: Ifo
summary: German companies' willingness to hire new staff decreased to 95.8 points in September, the lowest since February 2021, due to a lack of orders and declining sectors. This comes amid recession fears in the European largest economy. Ifo head Klaus Wohlrabe stated that companies will hire again once the economy recovers, but demographic changes and an ageing society may deprive the labour market of workers in the medium term.

site_title: US mortgage rate climbs to 22-year high of 7.41%, curbing demand
summary: US mortgage rates surged to a 22-year high of 7.41% in the week ended Sep 22, according to Mortgage Bankers Association data. This led to a decline in home-purchase applications to 144.8, one of the lowest readings in decades. Despite high borrowing costs, home prices continue to rise due to limited supply. Builders are offering incentives to attract buyers to new construction, but high rates are curbing demand. The Federal Reserve is unlikely to lower rates, with Chairman Jerome Powell stating that borrowing costs will remain elevated if inflation doesn't recede.

site_title: Mitsubishi Motors to exit from China production:  Nikkei
summary: Mitsubishi Motors is exiting China production, finalizing arrangements with local joint venture partner Guangzhou Automobile Group. The plant in Hunan province will likely be converted to an electric vehicle production base. The decision comes after weak sales and a significant drop in vehicle sales in China, with just under 32,000 units sold last year. Talks with shareholders are ongoing, but no decisions have been made about the future of the China business.

images.alt_text: Renault and Nissan finalised at the end of July the terms of a restructured alliance after months of negotiations.
Mitsubishi made no changes to its full-year results forecast as the impact from the extraordinary loss had already been incorporated into a previously announced outlook “to a certain extent”.
Mitsubishi, which is also a junior partner in an alliance with France’s Renault and Nissan Motor, said it will roll out 16 new models over the next five years.

site_title: Singapore rises to fifth place in Global Innovation Index 2023
summary: Singapore has risen to fifth place in the Global Innovation Index 2023, up two spots from last year. The US and Switzerland retained their top spots, while Sweden moved up to second place. The country topped 11 out of 80 indicators, including government effectiveness, ICT access, and venture capital. Global corporate R&D expenditure reached a record $1.1 trillion in 2022, driven by ICT companies. However, disparities in innovation are growing, with some sectors attracting significant funding while others, especially small businesses, are struggling.

images.alt_text: Daphne Yow
China’s anti-espionage and data laws, as well as raids on US consultancies, have rattled investors.

NEW YORK, NEW YORK - AUGUST 31: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange during morning trading on August 31, 2023 in New York City. Stocks on the major indexes opened up high amid the release of inflation data and Department of Labor’s jobs report. Both figures come weeks before the Federal Reserve holds their next interest-rate policy meeting. The gains have helped the major indexes cut their monthly losses.   Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Michael M. Santiago / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)
Singapore has moved up a spot in the Global Innovation Index and maintains its leadership position in the region.

site_title: US dollar in command as euro and pound slide to 6-month low
summary: The US dollar surged to a 10-month high, reaching 106.49 on the US dollar index, as investors anticipated higher US interest rates. The euro and pound slid to 6-month lows, with the euro falling 0.3% to US$1.0534 and sterling easing 0.2% to US$1.2134. The dollar's strength was driven by the prospect of higher US rates, with 10-year yields reaching a 16-year high of 4.566%. This has put pressure on the yen, which slipped to an 11-month low, prompting speculation of potential intervention from the Bank of Japan.

site_title: Asian Games card players bridge yawning generation gap
summary: The Asian Games have seen a bridge competition that bridges the generation gap, with players ranging from 70-year-old Masood Mazhar to 23-year-old Chen Kuan-hsuan. The game, a tactical card game, has never become old for Mazhar, who began competing in the 1980s. The competition aims to draw in younger players, who are often discouraged by the time commitment required to play well. Mazhar believes that bridge is an addiction, with players constantly seeking more, and hopes to inspire more young people to take up the game.

images.alt_text: Pakistan’s Masood Mazhar (R) plays at men’s team qualification Bridge event during the Hangzhou 2022 Asian Games in Hangzhou, in China’s eastern Zhejiang province on September 27, 2023. (Photo by ADEK BERRY / AFP)

Taiwan’s Chen Kuan Hsuan poses for a photograph after playing Bridge women’s team event during the Hangzhou 2022 Asian Games in Hangzhou, in China’s eastern Zhejiang province on September 27, 2023. (Photo by ADEK BERRY / AFP)

site_title: Bank of Thailand raises key rate, cuts growth outlook
summary: The Bank of Thailand's monetary policy committee raised its one-day repurchase rate by 25 basis points to 2.50% for an eighth consecutive meeting, despite slowing economic growth and rising global uncertainties. The central bank cut its 2023 economic growth forecast to 2.8% and raised its 2024 forecast to 4.4%, citing shrinking exports and lower investments. The decision was seen as a surprise by economists, with only six predicting a quarter-point hike. The central bank also lowered its inflation forecast to 1.6% for 2023 and 2.6% for 2024.

images.alt_text: Thai baht banknotes of various denominations sit inside a drawer for an arranged photograph at a Super Rich 1965 Co. currency exchange store in Bangkok, Thailand, on Thursday, Aug. 22, 2013. Thailand's baht fell to the weakest level since August 2010 after Federal Reserve minutes showed officials support a cut in stimulus this year should the U.S. economy improve. Photographer: Dario Pignatelli/Bloomberg

site_title: Piaget jewellery heist suspects arrested in France: source
summary: French police have arrested five people, including veteran jewel thief Aissa Bendjaber, in connection with the August 1 robbery of a Paris store of luxury brand Piaget. The gang made off with 10-15 million euros worth of jewellery and watches, with no one hurt during the heist. Bendjaber, nicknamed "The Borsalino man," is suspected of participating in several high-profile heists totaling millions of euros. The arrest marks the latest in a series of robberies targeting luxury goods stores in the heart of Paris, including a recent Bulgari store heist.

images.alt_text: Scammers set up companies and bank accounts in Singapore remotely during Covid-19
Last year, hackers stole crypto worth as much as US$3.8 billion, making it the worst year on record, according to blockchain researchers Chainalysis.
Wang Bingang (left) and Wang Liyun, who is believed to be his wife, have not been seen for about a month.

site_title: In major blow to TikTok, Indonesia bans e-commerce transactions on social media
summary: Indonesia has banned e-commerce transactions on social media platforms, effective immediately, in a move aimed at protecting offline merchants and small businesses from predatory pricing. The ban affects TikTok, which has 125 million active users in Indonesia and is investing billions of dollars in the country's e-commerce market. The regulation requires e-commerce platforms to set a minimum price for imported items and adhere to local standards, giving TikTok one week to comply or face closure.

images.alt_text: Indonesia is the first and biggest market for TikTok Shop, and online shopping has become the app’s fastest-growing feature with a burgeoning fan base in the country.
FILE PHOTO: The TikTok logo is pictured outside the company's U.S. head office in Culver City, California, U.S.,  September 15, 2020.   REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo
Indonesia, with a population of more than 270 million, accounted for nearly US$52 billion worth of e-commerce transactions last year.

site_title: Malaysia's switch to dual 5G network can allow participation by Huawei: Anwar
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim announced that the country will switch to a dual 5G network, allowing China's Huawei to participate more effectively. This move comes despite warnings from the European Union and US about risks to national security and foreign investment. The switch is expected to provide a balance between Western and Eastern technology, breaking a monopoly held by a single state-run network. The decision aims to increase competition and improve the country's telecoms infrastructure.

images.alt_text: Aerial view of Kuala Lumpur city skyline.

site_title: Delayed PayNow transactions should be processed by Wednesday: DBS
summary: DBS announced that customers with delayed Fast and PayNow transactions should expect them to be completed by Wednesday. The bank stated that as of 7:30 pm on Tuesday, its services were returned to normal, and transactions made since then have been successful. The status of completed transactions will be reflected in customers' transaction histories, and the bank will provide a further update later on Wednesday.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan

“The repeated inconvenience caused to the public is unacceptable. The additional capital requirement imposed at this time underscores the seriousness with which MAS treats this matter. DBS Bank must spare no effort in dealing with the underlying issues leading to these disruptions.,” said Ho Hern Shin, deputy managing director of financial supervision at MAS.
DBS's PayNow service appears to be disrupted on Tuesday.
Experts say that banks should re-examine their goals and culture to ensure that the development of their digital platforms are not compromised.

site_title: What matters most to millennials
summary: A recent report found that despite three-quarters of millennials being employed full-time, less than a third identify as "career-focused." Millennials prioritize spending on what they deem important, with no signs of belt-tightening. The report also highlights the importance of finding a balance between career and family life. The findings are reflected in various lifestyle articles, including the return of the Singapore Writers Festival and a review of the new sushi-kaiseki restaurant, Suzuki.

site_title: India market regulator examining proposal for extended derivative trading hours
summary: India's market regulator, Sebi, is examining a proposal by the National Stock Exchange (NSE) to extend trading hours for index derivatives from 6 pm to 9 pm IST. If approved, the extended hours would help investors hedge risks. The Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) is prepared to facilitate evening trades, but a final decision has not been taken. Sebi is assessing whether the extended hours will fuel high derivative trading volumes and ensure smooth trade settlements.

images.alt_text: The Indian stock market and the Nifty 50 Index are expected to maintain their bullish outlook, fuelled by structural changes and geopolitical trends.

site_title: EC World Reit defers H1 distribution indefinitely due to ‘insufficient funds’
summary: EC World Reit, a China-focused real estate investment trust, has deferred its first half FY2023 distribution to unitholders indefinitely due to insufficient funds. The trust's manager cited the sponsor's inability to pay overdue rent owed to ECW Group, totaling over S$27.3 million, as the reason for the deferral. The company is working to address the situation, including exploring a repayment plan, evaluating market rental rates, and potentially divesting properties to meet its pre-payment obligations under facilities.

images.alt_text: Fu Heng Warehouse is one of four properties owned by the ECW Group, which the sponsor group owes outstanding rent receivables for.
Fu Heng e-commerce warehouse in Hangzhou, owned by EC World Reit. The China-focused Reit has 10 business days to top up the offshore interest reserve.
Fu Heng e-commerce warehouse in Hangzhou, owned by EC World Reit. The China-focused Reit has fully repaid its onshore interest expenses due on Sep 20.
Above: Stage 1 Properties of Bei Gang Logistics, one of six properties in EC World Reit’s portfolio.

site_title: Japan, Petronas to discuss storing Japanese CO2 in Malaysian sites
summary: Japan and Malaysia's state oil firm Petronas agreed to discuss storing Japanese CO2 in Malaysian sites as part of Japan's drive to tackle climate change. The two sides signed a memorandum of cooperation on carbon capture and storage (CCS) in 2028, with Japan aiming to reach a CO2 storage capacity of 6-12 million tonnes by 2030. The move could lead to similar talks with other Asian nations, with over 500 CCS projects globally, but more work is needed to meet the goal of utilizing all these projects.

images.alt_text: A Petroliam Nasional Bhd. (Petronas) gas station stands in front of the Petronas Twin Towers, second right, in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, on Friday, Feb. 27, 2015. Petronas, the Malaysian state oil company preparing for a leadership transition in April, reported a loss in the fourth quarter following crude's plunge. Photographer: Charles Pertwee/Bloomberg

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's PUB announced a 18.2% water price hike by April 2025, with a S$0.50 increase per cubic meter, to cover rising production and supply costs. Meatable plans to launch cultivated pork products in Singapore by Q2 2024. Rental volumes for condos and HDB flats fell in August, while Singapore rose to 5th place in the Global Innovation Index 2023, and ASEAN and EU are closer to a regional free trade agreement. Singapore shares ended lower, down 0.5%, on Wednesday.

site_title: Tesla's rivals scrap for thin slices of US EV sales: analysis
summary: Tesla outsold its next 19 US competitors by 10 to one or more in the first half of 2023, according to S&P Global Mobility data. Global automakers are launching new electric vehicles and battery plants, but few are selling at high enough volumes to support full-scale assembly plants. Tesla's Model Y and Model 3 are among the few models selling at sufficient volumes to support production. This poses a challenge for Tesla's growing rivals in the US market, with Ford's decision to halt a planned $3.5 billion battery plant in Michigan highlighting the issue.

images.alt_text: Tesla has pioneered the use of huge presses with 6,000 to 9,000 tons of clamping pressure to mould the front and rear structures of its Model Y in its “gigacasting” process that has slashed production costs.
Tesla has enjoyed perks in China that other international companies struggled to obtain, with the most notable being the state’s blessing to wholly own its domestic operations.

site_title: To tackle food insecurity, look beyond agriculture to peacebuilding and preventing war
summary: Global food security has become a massive problem due to climate change, conflicts, and droughts. A record 349 million people are acutely hungry, with this number projected to reach 600 million by the end of the decade. The Ukraine war and natural disasters have exacerbated the crisis, leading to shortages and higher prices of food staples. To tackle food insecurity, experts recommend focusing on peacebuilding and preventing war, as well as investing in sustainable agriculture and promoting healthy diets. The UN's Food and Agriculture Organization has identified 20 priority areas, including green innovation and gender equality, to improve food security and address the root causes of hunger.

images.alt_text: Prices for rice, a staple for half the world, has surged to the highest in almost 15 years after India began curbing exports.
An IMF spokesperson says the global lender would continue to carefully monitor ongoing developments in the region and their impact on global food insecurity.

site_title: Qantas chairman rejects resignation calls
summary: Qantas chairman Richard Goyder has rejected calls for his resignation amid scandals over high ticket prices, illegal ground staff layoffs, and allegations of selling cancelled flights. Pilots and a shareholder group had urged his resignation, but Goyder maintained the confidence of major shareholders and the board, citing significant challenges ahead. The Australian transport minister's decision to block Qatar Airways' request for extra flights has also sparked controversy. Goyder will continue to serve as chairman, but may review his decision if confidence is not maintained.

images.alt_text: Australia’s top court this month ruled that Qantas illegally sacked almost 1,700 ground workers during the pandemic, exposing the airline to compensation payments.
Since pandemic travel curbs eased last year, a spike in flight cancellations, lost bags and telephone wait-times have frustrated Qantas passengers.
Qantas Airways expects a further A$50 million impact due to non-fuel-related foreign exchange changes in the first half of the current fiscal year.
Qantas is facing a regulatory lawsuit accusing it of breaching consumer law by selling fares for 8,000 flights that were cancelled in mid-2022.

site_title: China’s central bank to use ‘precise, forceful’ policy to bolster recovery
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China, has reaffirmed its stance of keeping the yuan stable and preventing currency overshooting. The bank will implement "precise and forceful" monetary policy adjustments to support the economy, which is recovering with increasing momentum despite challenges such as insufficient demand, a property downturn, and high debt. The bank will guide banks to lower borrowing costs, support banks to replenish capital, and promote private investment and affordable housing.

images.alt_text: Former PBOC chief Yi Gang recommends “appropriately increasing” macroeconomic policies, “effectively supporting” the expansion of domestic demand and “promoting a virtuous economic cycle.”

FILE PHOTO: Paramilitary police officers stand guard in front of the headquarters of the People's Bank of China, the central bank (PBOC), in Beijing, China September 30, 2022. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo/File Photo
The one-year loan prime rate (LPR) was kept at 3.45 per cent, while the five-year LPR was unchanged at 4.20 per cent.

site_title: Eurozone money supply shrinks as ECB turns off taps
summary: The eurozone's money supply shrank by 11.9% in August, the largest drop on record, as banks reduced lending and depositors locked up savings amid the European Central Bank's efforts to combat inflation. Interest rates were raised to record highs, and banks withdrew liquidity, leading to a decrease in lending to households and businesses. The ECB's tightening cycle may fuel a recession debate, with economists predicting a contraction in GDP in Q3 and stagnation in the final quarter of the year.

images.alt_text: The ECB is still some distance from hitting its inflation goal, though figures due this week are likely to show a steep decline in both headline and underlying measures of consumer-price gains.
The manufacturing PMI has been sub-50 since mid-2022 and the latest headline index dips to 43.4 from 43.5.
The European Commission says a flash estimate shows eurozone consumer morale decreased to -17.8 this month from -16.0 in August.
Without that fillip, more factory weakness might raise the prospect of the region as a whole suffering another contraction.
During a Sep 13 speech, European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen said the European Central Bank is "working hard to keep inflation under control".
Pricing in derivatives markets indicated that traders see a 62 per cent chance that the ECB will leave interest rates at 3.75 per cent; and a 38 per cent chance of a 25 bp increase.

site_title: Whole-of-system commitment needed to close climate adaptation financing gap
summary: The world is still short of addressing the climate adaptation gap, with public and private sectors lacking adequate funding. The Paris Agreement's Global Stocktake report found that the current rate of warming necessitates addressing loss and damage, which requires a system-wide solution. The estimated annual adaptation needs are between $160 billion and $565 billion by 2030 and 2050, but international adaptation finance for developing countries was only $28.6 billion in 2020. To close the financing gap, countries need to prioritize adaptation, shift public resources, and better model loss and damage, with governments, insurers, and the private sector working together to address the urgent need.

site_title: Asean and EU ‘one step closer’ to regional free trade agreement: Vivian Balakrishnan
summary: Singaporean Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan stated that the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) and the European Union (EU) are "one step closer" to a regional free trade agreement (FTA) following efforts by the Singaporean-German Chamber of Industry and Commerce. The negotiations will be complex due to Asean's diversity, but the logic of such an agreement is obvious. No specific timeline was provided for the negotiations.

images.alt_text: Goh Ruoxue
One-fifth of Germany's trade is with Indo-Pacific region
German-Singapore business ties grow stronger

site_title: Meatable to launch first cultivated pork products in Singapore by Q2 2024
summary: Meatable, a Dutch food-tech company, plans to launch its first cultivated pork products in Singapore by Q2 2024, subject to regulatory approvals. The company has partnered with contract manufacturer Esco Aster and will sell products that are 33% cultivated meat, with the rest being plant-based. Meatable's patented technology can cultivate pork products in eight days, and the initial launch will be on a small scale, with select restaurants and retailers carrying the products. The company aims to scale up production in 2025 and sell its products widely in Singapore, with prices similar to organic meats.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher

site_title: Ex-Morgan Stanley bankers win coveted role on Alibaba unit IPO
summary: Alibaba Group Holding is turning to Ampere Partners, a boutique firm founded by former Morgan Stanley bankers, as the financial adviser for the initial public offering of its logistics unit, Cainiao Smart Logistics Network. The listing could raise at least $1 billion, potentially delivering a significant win for Ampere, which has cultivated longstanding relationships with the Chinese tech giant. This role may also lead to more work for Ampere as Alibaba proceeds with listings for its six units being spun off, leveraging the boutique firm's connections to secure more deals.

site_title: Taking the leap from Singapore to Africa
summary: Singapore companies are increasingly venturing into Africa, driven by the continent's large, young population and rich natural resources. Enterprise Singapore has seen a surge in projects in Africa, with over 100 Singaporean companies operating in 40 countries. Nivesal, an engineering-solutions provider, has signed a memorandum of understanding with the Kenya Investment Authority to advise the Kenyan government on boosting manufacturing. The company's "manufacturing-in-a-box" model provides turnkey solutions, capturing a larger slice of the overall pie. The Kenya-Singapore Bilateral Investment Treaty provides a hedge against risk, offering protection on investments and non-discriminatory treatment.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo

site_title: London office market in ‘rental recession’ as vacancies hit 30-yr high
summary: London's office market is experiencing a "rental recession" as vacancies hit a 30-year high, with Jefferies estimating a 20% contraction in office usage due to post-pandemic hybrid working and preference for greener buildings in the suburbs. Empty space in the West End, City, and Canary Wharf business districts has reached a record high, with landlords losing pricing power as tenants offload surplus space. This trend is expected to continue, with retail and office spaces being the next casualties of the shift towards hybrid working and sustainable living.

images.alt_text:
A general view of the Prive, My Private Island, , luxury condominiums in Aventura, Florida, on May 22, 2017.

site_title: Country Garden faces US dollar, ringgit bond interest deadlines
summary: Country Garden Holdings, a Chinese developer, faces US dollar bond interest deadlines, including a $40 million coupon due in January. The company has a 30-day grace period before a default could be called. This comes as investors doubt its ability to survive China's real estate crisis, which shows no signs of abating. Country Garden has missed interest payments in the past and its US dollar bonds have slid to distressed levels. The company's operations in smaller cities, which have been harder hit by the housing slump, are also a concern.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A logo of Chinese developer Country Garden is pictured in Tianjin, China August 18, 2023. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: A logo of Chinese developer Country Garden is pictured in Tianjin, China August 18, 2023. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo
China's No.1 private developer will have a 30-day grace period to pay the coupon before it would be considered in default.
Forest City houses fewer than 10,000 people - about 1 per cent of its target.

site_title: Crypto blowup in Hong Kong tests its embrace of retail trading
summary: Hong Kong authorities have arrested at least 11 people, including a social media influencer, in a crackdown on JPEX, an unlicensed cryptocurrency platform accused of defrauding investors of HK$1.5 billion (S$262 million). The platform had operated before Hong Kong introduced a new regulatory framework, which prohibits firms without a license from marketing to the public. The incident highlights the challenges of regulating the cryptocurrency industry, which is prone to scams and volatility, and raises concerns about the safety of retail trading.

images.alt_text: JPEX’s troubles cast a spotlight yet again on the regulatory and legal showdowns in the crypto world, which has been trying to tout the potential of blockchain technology.
Hong Kong securities regulator warns that JPEX is advertising itself as a 'licensed and recognized platform,' but has neither applied for nor received a license in the city.

site_title: China developer stocks head for lowest levels since 2011
summary: China's property developer stocks are heading for their lowest levels since 2011 due to liquidity woes and sluggish demand. The Bloomberg Intelligence gauge of developer shares fell 2.5% on Wednesday, with CIFI Holdings Group tumbling 55% after a months-long suspension. The sector's decline has erased all gains since China's reopening rally in October 2022, and investors are bracing for further troubles among distressed builders. The sector's recovery is expected to be hindered by negative headlines and a lack of buyer confidence during the Golden Week holidays.

site_title: Dubai starts repaying bailout loan as part of huge debt cutback
summary: Dubai has begun repaying a $20 billion bailout loan from Abu Dhabi and its central bank as part of a debt cutback effort. The move follows an economic recovery, which has lowered Dubai's total debt to 25% of its gross domestic product. Over the past year and a half, Dubai has paid a combined $28.5 billion, with $20 billion going to Abu Dhabi and the central bank. The repayment is part of Dubai's efforts to reduce its debt burden, which was nearly 90% in 2009.

images.alt_text: The Gate building, centre left, in the Dubai International Financial Centre (DIFC) in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, on Monday, July 5, 2021. Credit Suisse AG Chairman Antonio Horta-Osorio has vowed to undertake a global corporate strategy review after taking over in the wake of a pair of disasters. Photographer: Christopher Pike/Bloomberg

site_title: Asia’s research publishing pioneer now courts younger readers
summary: World Scientific Publishing, a Singapore-based pioneer in English-language research publications, is expanding into children's books to attract a younger generation of readers. Founded in 1981 by physicist Phua Kok Khoo and his wife, Doreen Liu, the company has grown to become Asia's largest English-language scientific, technical, and medical publisher, releasing over 600 new titles annually. The company is now exploring digital piracy, which has resulted in significant losses, but is working to refine its editorial processes and invest in more efficient software to combat the issue.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Maha's managing director Chew Chin Seong is aiming for green and sustainable chemicals to account for 80 per cent of the company's revenue by 2025.

site_title: UBS seeks to wipe out 1.8 billion euros tax fine at top French court
summary: UBS Group will appeal a French court's 1.8 billion euros ($2.6 billion) tax fine for helping wealthy French clients stash funds in Swiss accounts. The conviction, nearly two years old, upholds a finding of illegal money laundering but halves the initial fine. The Cour de Cassation will examine UBS's guilt, penalty, and damages award, with a possible verdict in several months. The bank's acquisition of Credit Suisse in June has added complexity to the integration process.

images.alt_text: UBS has long been keen to grow its footprint in China that already includes a mutual fund joint venture and a private fund business.
As part of the integration process, UBS decides to absorb Credit Suisse’s Securities Research service, wrapping the business into its own research operations.
Although UBS completed the takeover of Credit Suisse in June, it still needs approvals from regulators in markets where both banks operate to complete the process.

site_title: New York’s hottest steakhouse was a fake, until Saturday night
summary: New York's most popular steakhouse, Mehran's Steak House, was actually a fake restaurant created by friends as a prank. The restaurant had a near-perfect Google rating and was booked for months, with over 900 people on the waiting list. However, the restaurant was opened for one night only at an event space in the East Village, with untrained chefs serving a four-course menu. The food received mixed reviews, with some diners praising the steak while others sent theirs back. The friends behind the restaurant were exposed when a hospitality manager and a brand manager at a brewery arrived with skeptical intentions and realized the location was an event space.

images.alt_text: Meatable is looking to sell its cultivated pork products in Singapore by Q2 2024, subject to regulatory approvals.

site_title: Youth vs Europe: 'Unprecedented' climate trial kicks off at rights court
summary: Six young people, aged 15 and 18, from Portugal, are taking 32 European countries to court over alleged failure to act on climate change, claiming it's a human rights violation. The case, filed in 2020, is the largest climate case at the European Court of Human Rights. A hearing began on September 27, 2023, with a ruling expected in the first half of 2024.

images.alt_text: Closing the financing gap for climate adaptation requires a system-wide approach.
The summer Antarctic sea ice extent also hit a record low in February, breaking the previous mark set in 2022.
Wealthy countries must now reach carbon neutrality in around 2045, five years early, and China should speed up by a decade to 2050.

site_title: Banks must find balance with AI in financial markets
summary: Banks are increasingly embracing artificial intelligence (AI) to refine economic and monetary predictions, but the lack of macroeconomic research in AI programs poses a concern. Private institutions are profiting from public investment in open-source innovation, while central banks rely on microfounded econometric models for macroeconomic forecasts. The failure to predict inflation trends has led to calls for greater cooperation between fiscal and monetary policy. Policymakers can benefit from AI's ability to process vast datasets and detect patterns, but a harmonious integration of macro- and micro-finance is crucial for improved outcomes.

images.alt_text: Some of those caught out wrong about disinflation have blamed it on applying standard economic models.
Google, Microsoft and Alphabet logos and AI Artificial Intelligence words are seen in this file illustration taken, May 4, 2023.

site_title: Japan yields drift as traders seek balance between hawkish Fed, dovish BOJ
summary: Japan's benchmark 10-year government bond yield remained flat at 0.74% on Wednesday, following a mixed session as investors sought to balance the "higher for longer" outlook for overseas interest rates against the Bank of Japan's dovish stance. The US 10-year Treasury yield retreated to 4.3516% after reaching a 16-year peak. The BOJ reaffirmed its ultra-loose monetary policy, contradicting the Federal Reserve's hawkish stance. Market expectations suggest a potential 30 basis-point rate hike within the year.

images.alt_text: Kazuo Ueda. Photographer: Akio Kon/Bloomberg

site_title: Crypto lender BlockFi cleared to repay customers through liquidation plan
summary: BlockFi, a failed crypto lender, has received bankruptcy court approval for its liquidation plan, which could result in customers receiving a portion of their owed funds by the end of the year. The plan, supported by a customer interests committee, allows for unsecured creditors to receive between 35% to 63% of their owed amount, with the final amount determined by the outcome of disputes with FTX and other crypto firms. BlockFi's liquidation plan is seen as a milestone, potentially repaying customers faster than other bankrupt crypto firms.

images.alt_text: Kroll warns customers of Genesis, FTX and BlockFi about potential phishing scams that could seek unauthorised access to their crypto wallets.
BlockFi, which is liquidating, has said litigation with FTX, Three Arrows and a few other crypto firms could affect the amount its customers are repaid by US$1 billion.

site_title: Hollywood gala will welcome striking stars, but not studio bosses
summary: The Academy Museum of Motion Pictures gala, typically attended by Hollywood's A-listers and moguls, will proceed with a star-studded lineup, including Meryl Streep, Oprah Winfrey, Michael B Jordan, and Sofia Coppola. Despite the ongoing actors' strike, executives from the studios being struck will not attend, and Streep has received approval from her union to participate. The event aims to raise millions for the museum, which is crucial for its educational and community outreach programs, and will not focus on any particular project or company.

images.alt_text: Despite the tentative deal in hand, the writers guild encouraged members to join the striking actors’ picket lines, which will begin again on Tuesday.

site_title: Brokers’ take: UBS upgrades GoTo to ‘buy’ on cheap valuation, improving environment
summary: UBS Securities Asia has upgraded its rating on GoTo Group to "buy" from "neutral", citing an attractive risk-reward due to an improving operational environment and low stock valuation. The stock's enterprise value-to-sales ratio is 1.9 times, compared to peers Grab (2.3 times) and Sea (1.2 times). UBS projects GoTo's gross merchandise value to grow 2% in Q3, with full-year margins expected to reach 0.5% of GTV. The upgrade follows recent measures by Gojek to increase competitive intensity and the Indonesian government's decision to ban TikTok Shop.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Grab and Food Panda delivery riders at Bishan Junction 8 shopping mall on Aug 18, 2022.

Gojek riders wait for their delivery orders at a distribution centre in Surabaya on May 17, 2021, as Gojek and Tokopedia unveiled a merger to form GoTo Group, creating the largest tech firm in the world's fourth most populous country. (Photo by Juni Kriswanto / AFP)
Should GoTo acquire and successfully run a food delivery business in Singapore, it could help invigorate its share price.
The group says it hopes to remove the barriers to accessing financial services through the app.

site_title: BlackRock sees insurers betting on credit, paring private equity
summary: BlackRock found that 89% of US$29 trillion insurance executives plan to invest more in private markets, with a focus on direct lending, over the next two years. They will cut back on private equity and real estate, citing market volatility and unrealized losses. Insurers are prioritizing flexibility and seeking higher yields, particularly in investment-grade private debt and asset-backed strategies. BlackRock is positioning itself as a one-stop shop for investors offering equity, bond, and alternative assets, with a reorganized alternatives unit and recent acquisitions to capitalize on the expected growth in private credit.

images.alt_text: BlackRock headquarters at 50 Hudson Yards in New York. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

site_title: China growth target hangs in balance while economists cut forecasts
summary: China's economy is projected to meet its 5% growth target for 2023, according to a Bloomberg survey of 78 economists, although the ongoing property crisis poses a risk of a miss. The survey suggests a 10 basis point downgrade from an earlier poll, with analysts citing property as the biggest challenge. A separate survey found 17 economists naming "real estate" as the top issue, with 15 predicting home purchases will continue falling until at least the beginning of next year. The property market could take up to a year to recover, and policymakers are implementing fiscal and monetary support measures to address structural imbalances.

images.alt_text: China's industrial profits increased 17.2 per cent from a year earlier, reversing trend after declining in the past five months, according to data published on Wednesday.
Unfinished apartment buildings in Zhengzhou. The city’s difficulties – including a lack of work, falling property prices and banking instability – are acute examples of those facing China at large.
People dine at a shopping mall in Beijing on August 12, 2023. (Photo by Jade Gao / AFP)

site_title: China’s industrial profits rebound sharply as economy stabilises
summary: China's industrial profits surged 17.2% in August, reversing a five-month decline, as the economy stabilizes. This marks the fastest pace of growth since at least 2022. The increase in industrial production and easing of producer price deflation boosted profits, suggesting demand is improving. Economists have downgraded their growth forecasts for China to 5% expansion, citing a major risk to the outlook in the ongoing housing market slump.

images.alt_text: The three companies were designated as a result of their business practices involving Uyghur minorities and other persecuted groups, the US Department of Homeland Security said in a statement.

Economic growth in China is being dragged down by a beleaguered property market, but extreme weather and growth in economic activity in other sectors have driven demand for electricity and coal higher.
Total gold imports via Hong Kong are up 49.6 per cent on a monthly basis at 45.237 tons, but lower than 71.855 tons in August 2022.
Unfinished apartment buildings in Zhengzhou. The city’s difficulties – including a lack of work, falling property prices and banking instability – are acute examples of those facing China at large.

site_title: Tree-hugging AI to the rescue of Brazilian Amazon
summary: Brazilian scientists have launched a pilot project using small, AI-powered "curupiras" boxes tied to tree trunks in the Amazon rainforest to detect and prevent deforestation. The sensors can relay data up to 1 km via satellite to a central point, allowing agents to be deployed in real-time to address threats. The project, financed by Hana Electronics, has shown promising results and aims to add hundreds of sensors to detect smoke and heat from forest fires. This initiative comes as Brazilian President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva has vowed to end illegal deforestation in the Amazon by 2030.
