The summer Antarctic sea ice extent also hit a record low in February, breaking the previous mark set in 2022.

site_title: GuGong withdraws IP injunction application; No Signboard ordered to pay S$6,500
summary: No Signboard's controlling shareholder GuGong has withdrawn its intellectual property (IP) injunction application against the company, five days after both parties reinstated their IP sales and purchase agreement. The High Court ordered No Signboard to pay GuGong S$6,500 in legal costs, including reasonable disbursements. The agreement pertains to a disagreement over a settlement offer, which included reinstating IP sales and purchase, as well as an independent contractor agreement. No Signboard's board is currently seeking legal advice on arbitration proceedings.

images.alt_text: Facade of No Signboard Seafood restaurant at Esplanade

Expediting the completion of the proposed investment will allow the company to utilise the full investment amount to settle its liabilities upon completion to meet its working capital requirements for the next 18 months, said the company.
No Signboard's board said that it has also applied for an injunction to prevent Sam Lim, GuGong and the company from taking steps to pass resolutions within the notice of requisition.
Su was appointed as a non-executive director of No Signboard as part of his acquisition of a 20 per cent stake in the company.
If No Signboard was trying to soothe rattled investors with its latest clarification announcement, it failed to do a good job.

site_title: Australia’s inflation accelerates, keeping rate hike in play
summary: Australia's inflation accelerated to 5.2% in August, exceeding economists' estimates, and vindicating the Reserve Bank of Australia's stance to hike interest rates at least one more time. The data, which includes volatile items, showed annual inflation eased to 5.5% from 5.8%. The Reserve Bank has raised interest rates 12 times since May 2022 and is now in data-dependent mode, with new Governor Michele Bullock set to review the economy next week. This data supports the RBA's cautious approach to tightening monetary policy compared to other countries.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A worker delivering parcels pushes a trolley past the Reserve Bank of Australia building in central Sydney, Australia, March 7, 2017.  REUTERS/David Gray/File Photo

site_title: Companies least ready for ESG disclosures find balancing goals with profit expectations a challenge: KPMG poll
summary: A KPMG poll found that companies least ready for ESG disclosures struggle to balance ESG goals with profit expectations. The poll, based on the inaugural KPMG ESG Assurance Maturity Index, revealed that three-quarters of companies surveyed are not ready for external auditing of their ESG data, with the remaining quarter having significant work to do. The index measured five areas of ESG reporting maturity, highlighting the need for companies to improve their ESG reporting processes and become ready for external auditing.

images.alt_text: Mia Pei

ESG concept of environmental social and governance (top). ESMA’s proposal, first unveiled in November, requires that a fund calling itself “ESG” have at least 80 per cent of its assets promoting environmental, social and governance goals.
It is vital for companies to provide transparent information that offers perspective in their annual reports, says Dr Hanny Kusnadi.
The Monetary Authority of Singapore is conducting a public consultation on a proposal for a code of conduct for ESG rating and data providers.
Combining ESG ratings with needs and context on the ground allows an investor to consider opportunities that might otherwise be excluded on a single dimension.

site_title: Evergrande’s billionaire chairman Hui is under police surveillance
summary: China Evergrande Group's billionaire chairman Hui Ka Yan is under police surveillance, according to sources. He was taken away by police earlier this month and is being monitored at a designated location. Hui's residential surveillance is a type of police action that doesn't involve formal detention or arrest, but restricts his ability to leave or communicate without approval. This move is part of a new phase involving the criminal justice system, following setbacks to Evergrande's restructuring plan and financial market volatility.

images.alt_text: Hengda Real Estate Group fails to repay 4 billion yuan (S$748 million) in principal plus interest due on Sep 25.
The worsening crisis has fuelled concerns among some global money managers that Chinese assets are becoming “uninvestable”, amid weak governance and disclosure practices.
Shares of Evergrande, which has more than US$300 billion in liabilities, fell as much as 23.6 per cent to HK$0.42, in a broader market down 0.6 per cent.
With more than US$300 billion in total liabilities, including offshore debt, Evergrande has been at the centre of a property debt crisis.

site_title: Amazon makes a shrewd move in the AI arms race
summary: Amazon has made a significant move in the AI arms race by investing $1.25 billion in San Francisco-based Anthropic, a leading AI startup, with a potential $4 billion valuation. Anthropic will use Amazon's Trainium and Inferentia computer chips to build and deploy its models, a potential competitor to Nvidia's dominant AI technology. The deal positions Amazon's cloud division, AWS, as a viable alternative for AI tasks that don't require full Nvidia capabilities, and could help Amazon catch up in the AI industry.

images.alt_text: Amazon’s employees and cloud customers will gain early access to technology from Anthropic as part of the deal, which they can infuse into their businesses.

Cutting out intermediaries like Nvidia, AMD, and Intel allows companies to optimise chips specifically for their unique tasks whether it’s streaming videos, serving up search queries, or managing massive databases.

site_title: Condo, HDB rental volumes fall in August as rents soften: SRX, 99.co
summary: Condo and HDB rental volumes in Singapore fell in August, with condo leasing volumes decreasing 7.6% to 6,730 units and HDB leasing volumes dropping 10.1% to 2,997 flats. Condo rents softened by 1% and HDB rents rose 0.1% month-on-month. The condo market is showing signs of stabilisation, with rents trending sideways for the sixth consecutive month. Analysts attribute the decline to increased competition from newly completed condos and slowing employment growth.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
All regions recorded month-on-month gains in condo rents

site_title: Chinese demand drives deals at world’s largest coal conference
summary: China's demand for thermal coal is driving deals at the world's largest coal conference in Indonesia, with imports expected to rise to a record 329 million tonnes this year and 378 million tonnes in 2024. Economic growth in China is being dragged down by a beleaguered property market, but extreme weather and growth in other sectors are driving demand for electricity and coal. The surge in Chinese demand is expected to delay a peak in global coal use, as miners supply coal at competitive prices.

images.alt_text: Smoke and steam billows from the coal-fired power plant owned by Indonesia Power, next to an area for Java 9 and 10 Coal-Fired Steam Power Plant Project in Suralaya, Banten province, Indonesia, July 11, 2020.
Jakarta, which has been battling worsening air quality for years, topped global pollution rankings several times last month, according to Swiss air quality monitor IQAir.
It is estimated that Indonesia’s long-term goal of decarbonising its power sector will require an investment exceeding US$200 billion over the next 10 to 15 years.

site_title: BOJ’s July debate highlights rift in view on rate hike timing
summary: The Bank of Japan's July meeting highlighted a rift among policymakers over when to end negative interest rates, with some members suggesting the target of 2% inflation could be met by early 2024. The central bank maintained its ultra-loose policy settings but took steps to allow long-term borrowing costs to rise more freely. Market players now expect the BOJ to begin phasing out its stimulus programme later this year or in 2024, as inflation continues to rise above the 2% target.

images.alt_text: The yen has drifted lower to 148.58 against the US dollar, the weakest since November.
Kazuo Ueda. Photographer: Akio Kon/Bloomberg

Markets are focusing on comments from Governor Kazuo Ueda’s briefing, to be held after the bank’s two-day policy meeting, for clues on how soon the bank could phase out the massive stimulus programme of his predecessor.

site_title: US to indefinitely extend China waiver for South Korean chipmakers: Yonhap
summary: The US Commerce Department is expected to indefinitely extend a waiver allowing South Korean chipmakers Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix to supply US chip equipment to China without seeking additional licenses. This waiver was granted last year for one year. The US will update its "validated end user" list to include the companies, making it unnecessary for them to obtain permission for separate export cases. The move is aimed at enabling the companies to upgrade their equipment for future production needs.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Semiconductor chips are seen on a printed circuit board in this illustration picture taken February 17, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: China’s Trina Solar plans US$400 million Vietnam plant after US sanctions: sources
summary: China's Trina Solar plans to invest $400 million in its third factory in Vietnam, spanning 25 hectares of industrial land, with production set to begin in 2025. The move comes after the US imposed punitive duties on Trina's products made in Thailand, aiming to boost exports to the US. This expansion would solidify Trina's position as one of the world's largest solar panel makers in Vietnam.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: A worker inspects solar panels at a solar farm in Dunhuang, 950km (590 miles) northwest of Lanzhou, Gansu Province September 16, 2013. Picture taken on September 16, 2013. REUTERS/Carlos Barria/File Photo

site_title: China lists mobile app stores that comply with new rule, but Apple missing
summary: China's Cyberspace Administration of China (CAC) has released the names of 26 mobile app stores that have completed filing business details to regulators, signaling the enforcement of new rules expanding oversight of mobile apps. The app stores include those operated by companies such as Tencent, Huawei, and Samsung, but Apple's App Store is not on the list. This move is part of Beijing's expanding oversight of smartphone and mobile app usage, with the CAC aiming to regulate app stores and ensure compliance with new rules.

images.alt_text: Last year, the chipmakers had received authorisation from the US Commerce Department to supply equipment needed for chip production in China for a year without seeking additional licenses.
Credit also grew more than expected, potentially suggesting some stability in household demand for mortgages as authorities work to bolster the real estate market.

site_title: World Bank chief vows to tackle ‘dysfunctionality’ at development lender
summary: World Bank President Ajay Banga vowed to reform "dysfunctionality" among the development lender's leadership, pledging to refocus its mission to better address climate change challenges. Banga proposed altering the bank's twin mandate to prioritize "the elimination of poverty, but on a livable planet" due to the intertwined nature of crises.

images.alt_text: PT Indo Raya Tenaga, the developer of the Suralaya plants, has said it plans to power some of the new capacity with ammonia, along with coal, to reduce emissions.
An IMF spokesperson says that a domestic debt rework “is among the several issues identified as challenges to debt restructuring.”

site_title: Gold lingers near one-month low as US dollar keeps momentum
summary: Gold prices hovered near a one-month low, trading at US$1,900.49 per ounce, as the US dollar firmed on interest rate concerns. The US dollar traded near a 10-month high against its major peers, with Treasury yields remaining elevated. The Federal Reserve's preferred inflation gauge, the PCE price index, is set to be released on Friday, which could impact gold prices.

images.alt_text: Total gold imports via Hong Kong are up 49.6 per cent on a monthly basis at 45.237 tons, but lower than 71.855 tons in August 2022.
Higher interest rates weigh on non-interest-paying bullion, which is priced in US dollars.

site_title: Adani Ports to buy back another US$195 million of 2024 bond
summary: Adani Ports and Special Economic Zone announced a buyback of up to $195 million of its 2024 bond, priced at $975 per $1,000 principal, to rebuild investor confidence after a Hindenburg Research report alleged malfeasance. The bond, which has $520 million in principal outstanding, will be funded from cash reserves. This is the company's second tender offer for the 2024 notes in a few months, and the announcement bucks the global trend of companies repurchasing less debt due to rising interest rates.

images.alt_text: Signage atop the Adani Group headquarters in Ahmedabad, India, on Wednesday, June 21, 2023. US authorities are looking into what representations Adani Group made to its American investors following a scathing short seller’s report that accused the company of using offshore companies to secretly manipulate its share prices. Photographer: Prakash Singh/Bloomberg

site_title: Stocks to watch: Boustead Singapore, H2G Green
summary: Boustead Singapore's real estate unit, Boustead Projects, has been directed to delist with a "fair and reasonable" offer under the Singapore Exchange Regulation. The company rose 1.2% following the announcement. Meanwhile, H2G Green's CEO, Lim Shao-Lin, has been arrested for an offence under the Employment of Foreign Manpower Act and has surrendered his passport, prompting the company to request a trading halt. The halt was later lifted on Wednesday.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

site_title: PwC Australia external review assails ‘whatever it takes’ culture
summary: PwC Australia has commissioned an external review that found a "whatever it takes" culture led to a former partner leaking confidential national tax plans to win clients. The review identified poor practices, including a lack of oversight and accountability, and an "overly collegial" culture that made staff reluctant to call out misbehaviour. The firm will appoint outsiders to senior roles, including the board, and link partner pay to integrity. PwC Australia expects to implement all 23 recommendations by December 2025, including appointing an external chief risk officer and revamping firm culture.

images.alt_text: KPMG is the latest of the so-called Big Four firms to introduce cuts in the UK.
Industry players and observers that spoke to BT said the police bust – the largest AML operation in Singapore’s history – should be viewed in a positive light.
The firm has been dogged since January by a national scandal over revelations a former partner leaked confidential tax documents which were then used to drum up work around the world.
Bangalore’s attractiveness as a tech and engineering hub has driven up the rising cost of doing business, while manufacturing firms in particular are jostling for space.

site_title: ARA H-Trust to refinance US$270.8 million loan facilities
summary: ARA US Hospitality Trust, also known as ARA H-Trust, is refinancing US$270.8 million of its debt facilities, including a US$244.3 million three-year term loan facility and a US$8.5 million four-year term loan facility. The refinancing includes the extension of term loan facilities to US$198.5 million maturing in 2026 and US$51 million maturing in 2027, and the introduction of a US$30 million three-year revolving credit facility. A mandatory pre-payment event will be triggered if ARA Asset Management ceases to own at least 51% of the issued share capital without majority lender consent.

images.alt_text: ARA H-Trust expects the outlook for the US lodging market to remain optimistic, outweighing economic uncertainty and geopolitical risks.
"Bleisure" travel, where travellers combine a work trip with an extended holiday, has helped boost post-pandemic demand for hotels, says Lee Jin Yong, CEO of ARA H-Trust's managers.

Lee Jin Yong, CEO of the manager of ARA US Hospitality Trust. The stapled group reports on Tuesday a 5.2% increase in H1 DPS.

site_title: Jazzing up the accounting profession
summary: Singapore's accounting and finance sector faces a talent crunch due to economic volatility and technological innovations. Industry insiders argue that a reframing of the profession, focusing on strategic advising, ethical governance, and sustainability, can attract and retain a new generation of professionals. Key players call for clear career progression, good remuneration, and compensation benefits to address the issue. Technology will also play a crucial role, enhancing audit quality and promoting confidence in business and capital markets. Revitalizing the profession requires swift and thoughtful interventions to draw in fresh talent and position the sector for the future.

images.alt_text: Companies demonstrating robust ESG practices typically feature decisive leadership by the board in establishing a clear direction, strategy and implementation of strong governance.

site_title: Stablecoin issuers risk disrupting funding markets: JPMorgan
summary: JPMorgan warns that stablecoin issuers could disrupt funding markets by competing with the US$5.64 trillion money-market fund industry for assets such as Treasury bills, potentially pushing rates below the current 5.3% offered by the Federal Reserve's overnight reverse repo facility. As stablecoins seek to park cash in liquid assets, their growth risks crowding out other buyers and intensifying supply-and-demand imbalances, leading to shortages and lower rates. This could expose the traditional financial system to turbulence in the crypto space, particularly if a run occurs in the short-term rates space.

images.alt_text: MUFG has been discussing with multiple parties about using its blockchain platform, Progmat, to mint stablecoins tied to foreign currencies.
Stablecoins are seen as a bridge between highly volatile cryptocurrencies and fiat currency, which is the government-issued money that we use in everyday transactions.

site_title: India’s Byju’s to merge businesses, slash around 5,500 jobs: ET
summary: Indian education firm Byju's plans to cut around 5,500 jobs as part of a restructuring effort amid business setbacks, including auditor and board member resignations. The job cuts will primarily affect senior positions and are expected to be implemented later this week or early next week. The move is aimed at decreasing costs and will not impact Byju's subsidiaries. The company's India business has been experiencing a series of challenges, including a valuation drop to US$22 billion last year.

site_title: Airbnb CEO urges Parisians to put homes up for rent for Olympics
summary: Airbnb CEO Brian Chesky is urging Parisians to list their homes on the platform to help contain prices during the 2024 Olympics, which are expected to draw up to half a million visitors. With fears that prices could skyrocket, Chesky believes more listings will keep prices reasonable. The company aims to prioritize listings with the best value for money, making Airbnb more affordable than hotels for travelers. This move comes amid competition between short-stay holiday rentals and longer-term rentals for residents.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Airbnb logo is seen displayed in this illustration taken, May 3, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Asia: Markets swing but US rate outlook feeds uncertainty
summary: Markets in Asia fluctuated on Wednesday as investors grappled with uncertainty over the US Federal Reserve's interest rate outlook. Despite a two-day slump, Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks rose on bargain-buying, while Manila and Jakarta also gained. However, Tokyo, Sydney, and other major Asian cities fell. The US dollar strengthened against peers, amid concerns over a potential government shutdown in Washington and the ongoing economic uncertainty. The Federal Reserve is expected to consider further interest rate hikes to combat inflation, which remains above target.

images.alt_text: Bull statues are placed in font of screens showing the Hang Seng stock index and stock prices outside Exchange Square, in Hong Kong, China, August 18, 2023. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu

site_title: Tesla working on ‘gigacasting’ tech to mould underbody in one piece: report
summary: Tesla is working on an upgrade to its "gigacasting" technology, which involves molding almost all vehicle underbody parts in one piece using huge presses with 6,000-9,000 tons of clamping pressure. This innovation is expected to slash production costs, following the company's successful implementation of "gigacasting" for the front and rear structures of its Model Y. The upgrade is reportedly being developed for the Shanghai factory, where Tesla has already implemented "gigacasting" for the rear of the Model Y since 2020, cutting related costs by 40%.

site_title: Arts and culture open up business opportunities in Vietnam
summary: Singapore entrepreneurs can participate in Spotlight Singapore's week-long mission trip to Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam from Oct 19-25, 2023. The trip aims to explore business opportunities and challenges in Vietnam through a mix of conferences, matching sessions, and site visits. Participants will also experience Vietnamese culture, including historical and cultural sites, arts, and performances. Vietnam's growing middle-class and push towards digitalization present opportunities for startups and SMEs in the green, digital, and renewable energy sectors, with Singapore companies already being the largest foreign investors in the country.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Past editions of Spotlight Singapore have taken place in cities such as Hong Kong, Tokyo, Moscow, Delhi and Cape Town (above).

site_title: Renault ends common purchasing agreement with Nissan and Mitsubishi
summary: Renault has ended its common purchasing agreements with Nissan and Mitsubishi to create a more agile structure, adapting to regional automotive markets with differing regulations. The move follows a restructured alliance finalized in July, which freed both companies to focus on navigating the industry landscape. Renault will now have a separate electric vehicle business, Ampere, while Nissan contemplates a grim outlook for foreign automakers in China. The decision aims to enhance decision-making speed and competitiveness in the rapidly changing industry.

images.alt_text: The new goal of going fully electric in Europe by 2030 brings Nissan in line with alliance partner Renault.
FILE PHOTO: Logo of the Nissan Motor Co. is displayed at the 44th Tokyo Motor Show in Tokyo, Japan, November 2, 2015.   REUTERS/Issei Kato/File Photo
Both Renault and Nissan are under pressure as competition from Tesla and Chinese EV makers intensifies.

site_title: Shutdown looms as US Senate, House take dueling tacks on funding
summary: The US government is on the brink of a shutdown as the Senate and House take opposing approaches to funding. The Senate voted 77-19 to fund the government through November 17, while the House plans to push forward with a partisan measure that will only fund a portion of the government. The standoff is fueled by disagreements over border and immigration restrictions, with Democrats opposing the tough measures. Hundreds of thousands of federal workers will be furloughed if the two sides fail to reach an agreement, and the shutdown could have negative impacts on the country's credit rating.

images.alt_text: US stock markets sank more than one per cent on Tuesday amid the prospect for a government shutdown.
Unless House Speaker Kevin McCarthy succeeds in defusing the demands of Trumpist lawmakers, the US government will shut down at 12.01 am on Oct 1.
The Senate is scheduled to advance a stopgap spending measure on Tuesday.
Moody’s rates the US government “Aaa” with a stable outlook, the highest creditworthiness it assigns to borrowers.

site_title: First-time home buyers can’t afford to live in London anymore
summary: London's housing market has become unaffordable for first-time homebuyers due to high interest rates and inflation. According to Halifax, only 24,323 Londoners purchased a house for the first time between January and August 2023, a 9% drop from 2013. Nationwide, first-time buyer numbers have fallen 22% from last year, with the Bank of England's interest rate increases slowing the housing market. Average house prices have fallen 2% to £288,030, but deposit requirements remain high, making it difficult for first-time buyers to enter the market.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The company logo of construction company Redrow is pictured on a flag at a new housing development near Manchester northern England, April 7, 2016. REUTERS/Phil Noble/File Photo
Loans in arrears climb 13 per cent in the second quarter and are now 28.8 per cent higher than a year ago, according to Bank of England.
London rents are likely to grow even faster in the next two years, largely due to more landlords in the city relying on increasingly costly financing.

site_title: Trump committed fraud by inflating value of assets: judge
summary: A New York judge ruled that Donald Trump and his sons Eric and Don Jr committed fraud by inflating the value of the Trump Organization's assets for years, resulting in "hundreds of millions of dollars in ill-gotten savings and profits." The ruling is a setback for Trump ahead of a trial in the civil case due to begin on Monday. New York state Attorney General Letitia James is seeking $250 million in penalties and the removal of Trump and his sons from the management of the Trump Organization.

site_title: Days from government shutdown, US budget talks threaten Ukraine aid
summary: The US Congress is racing against time to avoid a partial government shutdown, with a Sept 30 deadline looming. White House plans for $24 billion in war aid for Ukraine are at risk if a deal is not reached. The Senate released a draft budget measure, but hardliners in the House are unlikely to accept it, threatening to furlough hundreds of thousands of federal employees and disrupt government services. The shutdown could also impact Ukraine's aid, with the House hardliners opposing further funding.

images.alt_text: Unless House Speaker Kevin McCarthy succeeds in defusing the demands of Trumpist lawmakers, the US government will shut down at 12.01 am on Oct 1.
The Senate is scheduled to advance a stopgap spending measure on Tuesday.

Pimco's group chief investment officer Daniel Ivascyn says medium- and longer-term quality bonds with a 10 to 20 year duration could experience capital appreciation if interest rates fall.

site_title: Taylor Swift 'Eras' tour concert film going global
summary: Taylor Swift's concert film, "Eras Tour," is set to be released in over 100 countries on October 13, breaking the record for pre-sales in the US with $37 million in one day. The film is expected to exceed $100 million in North America during its opening weekend, making it a potential contender for the biggest film of the fall season. Swift's tour, which began in March, is expected to become the first to break the $1 billion mark, with performances resuming in November.

images.alt_text: Taylor Swift greets fans during the MTV Video Music Awards on Sep 12, 2023. The upcoming symposium explores themes such as the phenomenon of Swift fandom and the economic impacts of Swift’s touring and cultural prominence.
"Taylor Swift: The Eras Tour" is slated for theatrical release on Oct 13 and has already broken the record for pre-sales in the United States in one day, with US$37 million in revenue.

site_title: ChatGPT maker value rockets in funding talks: report
summary: OpenAI's value has skyrocketed to between $80 billion and $90 billion in talks with potential investors, nearly tripling its worth from a year ago. The company, behind the popular generative AI platform ChatGPT, is adding voice and image capabilities to the platform, which will be rolled out to users over the coming weeks. Microsoft has invested billions in OpenAI, sparking an AI race among tech firms. The company makes money by charging for access to enhanced ChatGPT versions and licensing the underlying technology to businesses.

images.alt_text: Since its debut last year, ChatGPT has been adopted by companies for a wide range of tasks from summarising documents to writing computer code.
Amazon’s employees and cloud customers will gain early access to technology from Anthropic as part of the deal, which they can infuse into their businesses.
Among the new products YouTube announces is a tool called Dream Screen that uses generative AI to add video or image backgrounds to short-form videos, which the company calls Shorts.
OpenAI has relied on mountains of texts found online to power its chatbot but has not specified exactly which sites and writings have been used.
OpenAI said the latest version of its tool will have more safeguards such as limiting its ability to generate violent, adult or hateful content.

site_title: US new vehicle sales to rise in September
summary: US new vehicle sales are projected to rise 13% in September to nearly 1.3 million units, driven by sustained demand despite rising interest rates and a United Auto Workers (UAW) strike against major automakers. Inventory levels are up 63% due to pent-up demand. Cox Automotive has raised its full-year new-vehicle sales forecast to 15.3-15.4 million units.

site_title: Support for adult education, ITE grads among upcoming Forward Singapore proposals: DPM Wong
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong has outlined three priorities for Singapore's upcoming Forward Singapore report: improving the lives of the middle class, helping lower-income segments, and enabling social mobility. The government plans to boost support for adult education, including SkillsFuture Credit top-ups for mid-career workers and training allowances for attending full-time courses. The report also aims to tackle inequality and uplift lower-income segments, with a focus on ITE graduates, and promote social mobility, particularly for disadvantaged children.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong will become the deputy chairman of GIC.

site_title: Thailand relaxes rules on non-resident baht transactions
summary: Thailand's central bank, the Bank of Thailand, has relaxed rules on non-resident baht transactions to improve the ease of doing business. The non-resident qualified company (NRQC) scheme now allows non-residents to make cross-border payments and manage baht liquidity without requiring supporting documents for each transaction. This move aims to reduce bureaucracy and lower transaction costs, making it easier for non-residents to conduct transactions related to the baht. The change is part of the bank's effort to develop Thailand's foreign exchange ecosystem.

images.alt_text: The Thai baht has fallen 2.8 per cent in September to be the worst-performing currency in Asia, while the nation’s sovereign bonds have also underperformed.

site_title: Biden makes history by joining US picket line
summary: US President Joe Biden became the first sitting president to join a picket line, standing with striking auto workers at a General Motors facility in Michigan. The visit, on the eve of Republican candidate Donald Trump's visit to the state, aimed to boost Biden's pro-union credentials and counter Trump's efforts to woo working-class voters. Biden used a bullhorn to urge workers for better pay and conditions, and agreed with their demand for a 40% increase. The visit was seen as a strategic move to sway blue-collar voters ahead of the 2024 election.

site_title: US hopes Europe will join ‘race to top’ on green subsidies
summary: The US hopes Europe will adopt similar measures to its Inflation Reduction Act to drive a "race to the top" on green subsidies, a senior US official said. The US understands EU concerns about the act, which provides massive subsidies for domestic green tech manufacturing, but emphasizes the technology's benefits to all and the need for collective action. The US and EU will discuss issues like managing AI risks, diversifying supply chains, and Ukraine's reconstruction during economic talks in Berlin, with the goal of encouraging a global green transition.

images.alt_text: Wealthy countries must now reach carbon neutrality in around 2045, five years early, and China should speed up by a decade to 2050.

site_title: Europe’s arsenal of democracy needs an upgrade
summary: Europe's defense industry is in need of an upgrade to meet the demands of the ongoing war in Ukraine, with stocks of key Western weapons systems running low. The European Union has allocated billions of euros to support Ukraine, but more needs to be done to address the inefficiencies and fragmentation among EU states. Experts recommend increasing coordination with NATO, standardizing ammunition, and reducing regulatory barriers to improve the system, which is critical for saving Ukraine, deterring aggression, and preventing future wars.

images.alt_text: North Korea's leader Kim Jong Un is likely to head by armoured train later this month to Vladivostok, on Russia’s Pacific coast not far from North Korea, to meet with Vladimir Putin.
Cluster munitions could boost Ukraine’s counteroffensive to reclaim territory seized since Russia invaded in February 2022.

site_title: US restricts imports from three more Chinese companies tied to forced labour
summary: The US has restricted imports from three more Chinese companies linked to forced labor of Uyghur minorities, bringing the total number of entities on the list to 27. The companies, Xinjiang Tianmian Foundation Textile, Xinjiang Tianshan Wool Textile, and Xinjiang Zhongtai Group, were added due to their business practices involving Uyghur minorities and other persecuted groups. The move aims to eliminate goods made with forced labor from the US supply chain, amid US concerns over China's human rights abuses in Xinjiang.

images.alt_text: China’s anti-espionage and data laws, as well as raids on US consultancies, have rattled investors.
The formation of the groups was agreed during talks in July between US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen (left) and Chinese Vice-Premier He Lifeng (right) in Beijing.

site_title: Volkswagen cuts EV output at German sites as demand craters
summary: Volkswagen is reducing electric vehicle production at two German plants due to declining demand and shrinking government subsidies. Production of the ID 3 and Born electric models will be cut at the main EV factory in Zwickau until October 16, and at a small-scale plant in Dresden for the first two weeks of October. The move comes as European consumers face higher energy and living costs, as well as concerns about charging infrastructure and battery range. The German government's decision to end subsidies for electric cars in company fleets also contributed to the decline.

site_title: US bank deposits drop year-over-year for first time ever: S&P
summary: US bank deposits dropped 4.8% year-over-year to $17.3 trillion for the first time since 1994, according to an S&P Global Market Intelligence report. Higher interest rates led to withdrawals from checking and savings accounts, with Charles Schwab experiencing the largest decrease of 31.1% due to outflows from brokerage accounts. The rate environment and bank failures contributed to the decline, with Bank of Montreal's deposits gaining the most after its acquisition of Bank of the West.

site_title: OpenAI, at boosted valuation, in talks to sell existing shares to investors: sources
summary: OpenAI, the company behind the popular chatbot ChatGPT, is in talks to sell existing shares to investors at a valuation of $80-90 billion, according to sources. This would make OpenAI one of the world's most valuable private companies, following a previous share sale at a valuation of $30 billion. The proposed deal is part of the company's strategy to cash in on its rising value, which has been fueled by the success of ChatGPT.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: ChatGPT logo is seen in this illustration taken, February 3, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
OpenAI said it is adding voice and image capabilities to ChatGPT, which was previously limited to written prompts.
Since its debut last year, ChatGPT has been adopted by companies for a wide range of tasks from summarising documents to writing computer code.
OpenAI has relied on mountains of texts found online to power its chatbot but has not specified exactly which sites and writings have been used.
OpenAI said the latest version of its tool will have more safeguards such as limiting its ability to generate violent, adult or hateful content.

site_title: Oil prices rebound, settle higher on worries about tight supply
summary: Oil prices rebounded on Tuesday, with Brent crude futures settling 67 cents higher at $93.96 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures settling 71 cents higher at $90.39 a barrel. The rebound came as expectations of tighter supply outweighed concerns about a weak economic outlook. Russia eased its petrol and diesel export ban, while oil supply remains tight due to production cuts by Russia and Saudi Arabia. The US Federal Reserve reiterated its commitment to fight inflation, signaling tight monetary policy may persist longer than anticipated.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled 2 US cents higher at US$93.29 a barrel.

site_title: US says Amazon running illegal monopoly in online retail
summary: The US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) sued Amazon, accusing the online retailer of running an illegal monopoly by strong-arming sellers and stifling potential rivals. The FTC alleges Amazon punishes companies that sell items at lower prices and coerces sellers into signing costly logistics services. Amazon has rejected the premise of the case, calling it "wrong on the facts and the law." The lawsuit is a test for the Biden administration's efforts to curb big tech's power and is symbolic for FTC Chair Lina Khan, who has questioned the effectiveness of antitrust laws in the digital age.

images.alt_text: China has long been a major exporter of a host of consumer products, but this latest export trend, of its e-commerce marketplace dynamics to the rest of the world, has shaken up online shopping globally.
Amazon’s employees and cloud customers will gain early access to technology from Anthropic as part of the deal, which they can infuse into their businesses.
The ad-supported offer will kick off in the US, UK, Germany and Canada early next year, before France, Italy, Spain, Mexico and Australia during 2024, Amazon says.
Amazon has been accused of having too much power over the some 2 million merchants who use its platform, which captures almost 38 per cent of all US online spending.

Amazon director of smart home Charlie French speaks during the Amazon Devices and Services event at the HQ2 campus in Arlington, Virginia on Sept 20, 2023. Amazon previewed a push into generative artificial intelligence with new features for its Alexa voice assistant.

site_title: Candy Crush Saga hits US$20 billion revenue milestone, maker King says
summary: Candy Crush Saga, a popular mobile game, has reached a revenue milestone of US$20 billion since its 2012 launch. The game, which has been downloaded 5 billion times, has maintained its appeal through frequent updates and a "freemium" model, where players can spend money to boost performance or watch ads to gain moves. Maker King, which was acquired by Activision Blizzard in 2016, attributes the game's success to its ability to reignite old games and keep them relevant for years, proving the enduring appeal of mobile games.

images.alt_text: Sony plans to have 12 live service game titles in its portfolio by fiscal 2026, up from just one in fiscal 2021, the Nikkei says.
The FTC says that by buying video-game publisher Activision Blizzard, Microsoft would gain an unfair advantage in consoles and cloud-gaming.

“We’re grateful to the court in San Francisco for this quick and thorough decision and hope other jurisdictions will continue working towards a timely resolution,” Microsoft president Brad Smith says.

Microsoft charges 25 million-plus Game Pass subscribers US$10 to US$15 a month to play over 400 games across the Xbox game console, Microsoft’s Windows PC operating system, smart TVs, tablets and smartphones.

site_title: German economic institutes forecast 0.6% GDP contraction this year: sources
summary: German economic institutes forecast a 0.6% GDP contraction in 2023 due to rising interest rates and high inflation. Inflation is expected to be 6.1% this year and fall to 2.6% next year. The institutes predict a 1.3% GDP growth in 2024, down from 1.5% previously, with the economy expected to shrink in the summer quarter before picking up again.

images.alt_text: Cars are parked in front of the entrance to Volkswagen's production site building in Dresden; the Ifo institute's September business climate index stands at 85.7, a decline from a revised 85.8 in August.
One in five property companies has reported cancelling building projects in August, while 11.9 per cent face financing difficulties, according to a recent survey.
Germany’s industry, which is heavily exposed to exports, has been particularly hard hit by weak demand from China and its prospects for recovery remain weak.

site_title: Europe: Higher yields weigh on shares, luxury stocks enter bear market territory
summary: European shares fell 0.6% on Tuesday, closing at an 11-week low, amid surging bond yields and concerns over a sputtering Chinese economy. Technology and real estate stocks were particularly affected, with technology stocks sliding 2.0% and luxury goods stocks falling 20.05% into bear market territory. The Stoxx 600, a pan-European index, hit a 12-year high for its benchmark 10-year government bond yield, which edged up to 2.796%. Investors remain cautious ahead of interest rate decisions from the Federal Reserve and European Central Bank.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 1.1 per cent to 33,618.88 on Tuesday.

site_title: Indonesia looking to import 1 million tonnes of rice from China
summary: Indonesia plans to import 1 million tonnes of rice from China to bolster its stockpiles amid the impact of El Niño weather, which is expected to shrink rice output by 5-7% this year. The country aims to import 2.3 million tonnes of rice, with China being the primary supplier. This move is part of efforts to mitigate the effects of drought and extreme weather events on rice harvests in key growing regions across Asia.

images.alt_text: Workers unload sacks of rice imported from Thailand from a cargo ship at Malahayati Port in Krueng Raya, Indonesia's Aceh province, on June 22, 2023. (Photo by CHAIDEER MAHYUDDIN / AFP)

site_title: Citibank raises US$5 billion in first bank-level bond since 2019
summary: Citibank raised US$5 billion in its first bank-level bond sale since 2019, tapping the investment-grade market as deposits recede from pandemic-era highs. The bank sold fixed- and floating-rate notes in three parts, including a US$2.5 billion five-year fixed-rate tranche yielding 1.18 percentage points over Treasuries. This follows debt sales by Bank of America, Morgan Stanley, and Wells Fargo & Co in recent months, as Citigroup seeks to diversify its funding sources.

images.alt_text: Citigroup, which has about 16,000 employees in the UK, says it is moving into phase two of its plans to rationalise its banking structure.
“We started with the need to simplify our structure and our management routines, and therefore the job cuts are the output,” says Citi's chief client officer David Livingstone.
The product – known as Citi Token Services – will transform customers’ deposits into digital tokens that can be sent instantly anywhere in the world, according to Citigroup.

The logo of Citigroup Inc. at the entrance to the bank's office in Paris, France, on Monday, Feb. 27, 2023. Citigroup is building a new trading floor in Paris as the Wall Street giant prepares to nearly double its staff in the French city. Photographer Benjamin Girette/Bloomberg

site_title: NTUC calls for equal training opportunities, job redesign for older workers
summary: NTUC has called for equal and protected training opportunities and age-universal job redesign for older workers in Singapore. Despite 92% of older workers being interested in training, 63% feel they have fewer opportunities compared to younger workers. The union urges employers to implement Company Training Committees and provide protected training time. They also recommend redesigning jobs to be age-universal and strengthening retirement adequacy, particularly for lower-income workers.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
The government may consider a tiered approach, offering full support to SMEs and only partial support to the rest, since many larger companies do already offer some form of family care leave.
Employers understood the increasing necessity of caregiving leave, but said it would be challenging to bear the additional costs of implementing such a policy.

site_title: US: Stocks fall after lackluster consumer data
summary: US stocks fell 1.1% on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropping to 33,618.88. The decline was attributed to weak consumer confidence data, which fell to 103 from 108.7 in August, and concerns over elevated interest rates weighing on growth. The S&P 500 tumbled 1.5% and the Nasdaq Composite Index lost 1.6%. Investors are worried about the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes and a possible government shutdown, while individual companies such as Amazon and Cintas also faced negative impacts.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., September 11, 2023.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Latin America’s growth conundrum
summary: Latin America's economic growth has been stagnant for decades, with only a few countries narrowing the gap between their per capita income and the US since 1960. The region faces barriers such as fiscal, debt, and inflation problems, as well as institutional design issues that hinder governance and trust in institutions. Despite some countries achieving low inflation and financial stability, sustained growth remains elusive. To break the cycle of low credibility and performance, Latin America needs a coordinated effort involving technocratic reforms and bold political leadership to restore trust and rebuild state capacities.

images.alt_text: Brics purports to represent the Global South, which accounts for 47 per cent of the world's population and 37 per cent of its gross domestic product.
Visitors take photographs at the Mirante do Sesc Avenida Paulista viewpoint in Sao Paulo, Brazil. High mobile penetration rates in South America present opportunities for Singapore companies.

site_title: H2G Green CEO arrested for offence relating to employment of foreign manpower
summary: H2G Green CEO, Lim Shao-Lin, has been arrested for an offence under the Employment of Foreign Manpower Act, related to false information provided by an employee, Yu Huajie, who was convicted for providing false information in his employment pass application. Lim has surrendered his passport and is out on bail, with a court date set for October 5. The company has stated that Lim is suitable to continue carrying out his duties as CEO and executive director.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
From left to right: Minister for Transport S Iswaran; Formula One Group chief executive Stefano Domenicali; and HPL co-founder and managing director Ong Beng Seng.

site_title: JPMorgan’s UK bank Chase to ban crypto transactions
summary: JPMorgan's UK bank Chase will ban crypto transactions starting October 16 due to an increase in crypto scams targeting UK consumers. The move comes amid long-running concerns over the use of cryptocurrencies in online scams. This decision follows similar restrictions imposed by other UK lenders, including NatWest and Santander. Chase has attracted over 1.6 million customers to its mobile app-based service since its launch in Britain two years ago.

images.alt_text: Last year, hackers stole crypto worth as much as US$3.8 billion, making it the worst year on record, according to blockchain researchers Chainalysis.
The launch is coming at a time of heightened US regulatory scrutiny of cryptocurrencies, where the SEC has targeted exchanges and other digital-assets projects.
A forrmer Deutsche Bank investment banker pleaded guilty to fraud on Tuesday.
JPEX’s troubles cast a spotlight yet again on the regulatory and legal showdowns in the crypto world, which has been trying to tout the potential of blockchain technology.
Hong Kong securities regulator warns that JPEX is advertising itself as a 'licensed and recognized platform,' but has neither applied for nor received a license in the city.

site_title: US dollar hits 10-month high as US yields spike, yen recovers from dip
summary: The US dollar reached a 10-month high of 106.2 due to rising US yields, which have pushed the US dollar index to its highest level since late November 2022. Higher yields boosted the greenback's appeal, while the Japanese yen recovered from an early dip. Federal Reserve policymaker Neel Kashkari's comments that interest rates should rise again and be held "higher for longer" contributed to the increase in yields, reaching a 10-year high of 4.566%.

site_title: World’s mega-rich betting on US renters to grow their billions
summary: Ultra-wealthy individuals and firms are doubling their investments in US apartments, betting on the long-term growth of rents in major cities. With a broad housing shortage, apartment building prices have fallen amid the commercial-property downturn, making it an attractive time for investors. Billionaires like Amancio Ortega and Eyal Ofer are snapping up deals, seeking to capitalize on the trend. A commercial-property slowdown has created a gap for these investors, who can pay with cash or secure financing. The sector is poised for growth, with experts predicting a return to stability and increasing rents in coming quarters.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A newly constructed home available for sale is pictured in a new housing development area in Vista, California March 20, 2012. REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo

site_title: CDL should consider splitting its business, listing a trust to realise shareholder value
summary: City Developments Ltd (CDL), a 60-year-old real estate company, has seen its share price undervalued by 34% compared to its net asset value (NAV) per share. Despite its solid business, including a strong reputation as a housing developer and a launch pipeline of over 1,100 homes in Singapore, the group's share price has retreated 19.9% year-to-date. To create lasting shareholder value, CDL should consider splitting its business into two, with the development business privatized and the investment property and hotel business held under a listed entity.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee

Present on stage are guest-of-honour Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance Lawrence Wong (7th from left), CDL executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng (6th from left), CDL Group CEO Mr Sherman Kwek (5th from left), together with CDL board of directors and CDL Key Management.
"We make mistakes sometimes, once in a blue moon. But that is good; we are not perfect," says CDL executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng.

site_title: US new home sales tumble in August
summary: US new home sales plummeted 8.7% to 675,000 units in August, exceeding expectations. The 30-year fixed mortgage rate surged above 7% and averaged 7.19%, the highest since 2001, reducing affordability for potential buyers. New home sales rose 5.8% year-over-year but fell in the West, Midwest, and South, while rising in the Northeast. The median new house price declined 2.3% to $430,300, and it would take 7.8 months to clear the existing supply of houses.

images.alt_text: Existing home sales slip 0.7 per cent last month to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.04 million units
The contract rate on an adjustable mortgage increases by more than a quarter of a percentage point to 6.59 per cent, the highest in Mortgage Bankers Association (MBA) data back to early 2011.
The National Association of Realtors (NAR) housing affordability index is unchanged at 87.8 in July, matching the lowest level in data back to 1989.
High mortgage rates have pushed homeownership further out of reach for many Americans.
FILE PHOTO: A newly constructed home available for sale is pictured in a new housing development area in Vista, California March 20, 2012. REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo

site_title: Trumpists spoil for another dead-end government shutdown
summary: US government shutdown looms unless House Speaker Kevin McCarthy can defuse demands from Trumpist lawmakers, who seek to cut over $100 billion from federal discretionary spending. The current spending law expires on September 30, and hundreds of thousands of federal workers would be furloughed if no agreement is reached. A shutdown could shave off more than 1% of annualized economic growth and hurt the Republican party in the coming elections.

images.alt_text: The Senate is scheduled to advance a stopgap spending measure on Tuesday.
Despite economic and foreign policy successes, Biden is faring badly in opinion polls of voters.

site_title: Investors continue to flock into US private debt: Pitchbook
summary: Global investors pledged $94.9 billion to private debt funds in the first half of 2023, surpassing last year's $91.4 billion, with North America accounting for 75.4% of global activity. Fundraising in North America and Europe remained steady, while Asia's market share declined to 1.6%. Direct lending and mezzanine debt were the most popular financing types, with 32% and 27.9% of total fundraising, respectively. The private debt industry's robust inflows are seen as positive news, despite a looming recession and higher interest rates.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. dollar banknotes are displayed in this illustration taken, February 14, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Pimco's group chief investment officer Daniel Ivascyn says medium- and longer-term quality bonds with a 10 to 20 year duration could experience capital appreciation if interest rates fall.
A term sheet in circulation shows that Stanmore Resources is seeking to borrow US$1.1 billion for its acquisition of the Daunia coal mine from BHP.
Global investors are increasingly targeting private allocations across portfolios to hedge against ongoing uncertainty in the macro-economy.
Alternative investments are generally perceived to carry higher risk; investors will need to fully understand the features, upside and downside of the assets they are contemplating.
hourglass, money, time

site_title: China’s gold imports via Hong Kong bounce back in August
summary: China's gold imports via Hong Kong rebounded in August with a 49.6% monthly increase to 45.237 tons, but still lower than 71.855 tons in August 2022. The People's Bank of China extended its streak of central bank gold purchases for a tenth straight month, and retail demand for gold surged in August. The gold premium in China hit record highs, driven by supply restrictions and strong physical buying, with imports expected to pick up from next month.

images.alt_text: Higher interest rates weigh on non-interest-paying bullion, which is priced in US dollars.
Spot gold was mostly unchanged at US$1,924.54 per ounce by 0051 GMT, while US gold futures fell 0.1 per cent to US$1,944.30.

The unravelling of the relationship between gold and real interest rates could be a paradigm shift for the precious metal, leaving investors struggling to calculate its “fair value” in a world where the old equations don’t seem to apply.
Spot gold eased 0.1 per cent to US$1,927.63 per ounce by 0327 GMT, while US gold futures shed 1 per cent to US$1,947.80.
Spot gold was steady at US$1,930.51 per ounce by 0319 GMT, holding below its highest level since Sept 5 reached on Tuesday.
US gold futures were flat at US$1,953.90.
US gold futures were up 0.2 per cent to US$1,949.30 on Monday.
Bullion was on track for a weekly decline of 0.4 per cent after having touched its lowest level since Aug 23 on Thursday.
Bullion on the Shanghai Gold Exchange traded at a premium of more than US$120 an ounce on Thursday (Sep 14).

site_title: Michael Jackson moonwalk hat sells for 77,640 euros
summary: The black fedora worn by Michael Jackson during his historic Moonwalk performance in 1983 sold for 77,640 euros at an auction in Paris, exceeding its estimated price of 60,000 to 100,000 euros. This marks one of the highest prices paid for a music memorabilia item. The sale follows a series of auctions featuring items from other famous musicians, including Freddie Mercury, with a total of 46.5 million euros raised for Sotheby's.

images.alt_text: A Fedora hat that belonged to US singer Michael Jackson, made of wool and lined with silk, is displayed before being put on sale at auction, in Paris, on September 12, 2023. The hat is among items that will be auctioned at the Drouot Paris auction house on September 26, 2023. (Photo by Geoffroy VAN DER HASSELT / AFP)

A Fedora hat that belonged to US singer Michael Jackson, made of wool and lined with silk, is displayed before being put on sale at auction, in Paris. It's expected to fetch between US$64,000 and US$107,000.
Sher-Gil’s 1937 painting The Story Teller sold for the equivalent of US$7.44 million.
The dinosaur skeleton, which will be shown to the public in mid-October before the sale, is expected to fetch up to 1.2 million euros (S$1.7 million).
The "Black Sheep Jumper" designed by Sally Muir and Joanna Osborne and worn on several occasions by Britain's late Princess Diana, at Sotheby's auction house in London, Britain on July 17, 2023.

"Sermon on the Mount" by Frans Francken the Younger. Some experts believe this 17th-century work, now up for sale, was originally stolen by the Nazis, but no clues to its pre-war owner have turned up after years of searching.
An electric guitar once owned by Nirvana frontman Kurt Cobain (left) is expected to fetch upward of US$200,000 at an auction later in August.
Conceived in 2021 in the studio of British illustrator Ralph Steadman, the artwork called 'Five' was completed this year.

site_title: JPMorgan sees India in its top 3 fastest-growing Asia markets in 2024
summary: JPMorgan sees India as a top 3 fastest-growing Asia markets in 2024, alongside Australia and Japan, with the country expected to grow 6.5% in the financial year ending March 31, 2024. India is trying to attract global corporations, including by offering tax and other incentives, and has already seen production shifts from China. Despite a slowdown in China, JPMorgan's business volumes remain resilient, with the bank expanding its investment banking team and commercial banking division in India.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A general view of Mumbai's central financial district, India June 13, 2017. REUTERS/Danish Siddiqui/File Photo

site_title: US consumer confidence drops to a four-month low on outlook
summary: US consumer confidence dropped to a four-month low in September, reaching 103, down from an upwardly revised 108.7 in August. The Conference Board's gauge of current conditions rose to 147.1, but expectations fell to 73.7, the lowest since May. The reading below 80 signals a recession within the next year, despite economists' confidence in avoiding one. Consumers expressed concerns over rising prices, interest rates, and the labour market, with many having run down their savings and facing higher borrowing costs.

images.alt_text: S&P Global says its flash US Composite PMI index, which tracks the manufacturing and service sectors, dips to a reading of 50.1 in September from a final reading for August of 50.2.
Existing home sales slip 0.7 per cent last month to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.04 million units

Shipping containers and cranes at the Port of Savannah in Savannah, Georgia, US, on Saturday, Sept. 9, 2023. The US economy has been looking so solid lately that Federal Reserve officials will probably need to double their projection for growth in 2023 when they publish an updated outlook later this month. Photographer: Elijah Nouvelage/Bloomberg
Consumer Sentiment Index drops to 67.7 this month from a final reading of 69.5 in August, according to The University of Michigan's preliminary reading.
The August reading for manufacturing was up just 0.1 per cent, “held back” by a five per cent decline in motor vehicles and parts.

site_title: Adidas tests upper limit of running market with US$500 shoe
summary: Adidas has released the Adizero Adios Pro Evo 1 running shoe, priced at $500 per pair, targeting elite runners. Weighing 138 grams, the shoes are designed for speed, not durability, and are intended for a single marathon-distance race. The shoes' high price tag raises questions about their affordability for amateur runners, with some speculating that only a few will be able to justify the cost. The shoes' release follows a "supershoe" war among sports brands, with Nike's equivalent shoe priced at $275 less.

images.alt_text: Analysts warn that consumer stocks are about to lose their shine as risks build for the sector; Nike shares have fallen 11 per cent this month alone.
The end of Adidas’s lucrative partnership with the rapper last October has added to the sportswear giant’s recent troubles.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as rate worries keep Treasury yields elevated
summary: Wall Street opened lower on Tuesday as investors continued to worry about the Federal Reserve's restrictive monetary policy and its impact on the economy. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 144.20 points, or 0.42%, to 33,862.68, while the S&P 500 dropped 24.56 points, or 0.57%, to 4,312.88. The Nasdaq Composite fell 90.36 points, or 0.68%, to 13,180.96.

site_title: UBS and China’s ICBC to explore banking, wealth management ties
summary: UBS and China's Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) signed a memorandum of understanding to explore collaborations in asset management, wealth management, and investment and corporate banking. This move comes after UBS scaled back its expansion plans in China earlier this year due to economic headwinds and geopolitical tensions. The partnership aims to strengthen UBS's presence in China and expand its reach in overseas markets.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. Dollar and Chinese Yuan banknotes are seen in this illustration taken January 30, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo/File Photo
The shrinking margins were due to the effects of prime rate reductions and the “continuously increasing proportion of time deposits,” ICBC said in a statement.
ING alleges that ICBC has breached contract terms because it released export documents for copper transactions without collecting payment.
As part of the integration process, UBS decides to absorb Credit Suisse’s Securities Research service, wrapping the business into its own research operations.
Although UBS completed the takeover of Credit Suisse in June, it still needs approvals from regulators in markets where both banks operate to complete the process.
The 4.25-year, six-year and 11-year bonds are all benchmark size, making the deal at least a total of US$1.5 billion, and are all callable a year before maturity.
UBS targets the integration to be finished by the end of 2025.

site_title: Sri Lanka's revenue shortfall worries IMF team
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) expressed concerns over Sri Lanka's revenue shortfall, estimated at around $312 million, despite meeting most of the requirements for a $2.9 billion loan program. The IMF delegation met with President Ranil Wickremesinghe and other officials, but further deliberations are needed. Sri Lanka has made progress on domestic debt restructuring and is close to meeting debt restructuring requirements. The IMF review is part of a four-year loan deal aimed at supporting the country's economic recovery from its worst crisis in seven decades.

images.alt_text: This picture taken on September 12, 2022, shows the city skyline as pictured from the observation deck of the Chinese-built Lotus Tower in Colombo. - A huge green and purple communications tower in Sri Lanka financed with Chinese debt that has become a symbol of the ousted Rajapaksa clan's closeness to Beijing will finally open this week, its operator said on September 12. (Photo by Ishara S. KODIKARA / AFP)

site_title: Philippines' Marcos rejects rice tariff cut
summary: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. rejected a proposal to lower tariffs on imported rice due to forecasts that world prices for the grain will fall. The proposal, which would have reduced tariffs from 35% to 0-10%, was made by the finance and economic planning departments to ease pressure on inflation. Marcos stated that tariffs are generally lowered when prices are going up, and that now is not the right time to lower tariffs. The government-imposed ceilings on retail prices for rice will remain in effect.

images.alt_text: This aerial photo taken on June 27, 2023 shows farmers working at a rice field in Haian, in China's eastern Jiangsu province. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT

site_title: DBS PayNow transactions experience delays on Tuesday
summary: DBS PayNow service experienced delays on Tuesday, with customers facing issues transferring funds from 3 pm onwards. The issue was resolved by 4:30 pm. This is the fourth incident in less than two years, following previous outages in May and March. The bank assured customers that delayed transactions would be processed by the end of the day.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
DBS chief apologises for recent banking services outage, review being done

“The repeated inconvenience caused to the public is unacceptable. The additional capital requirement imposed at this time underscores the seriousness with which MAS treats this matter. DBS Bank must spare no effort in dealing with the underlying issues leading to these disruptions.,” said Ho Hern Shin, deputy managing director of financial supervision at MAS.
DBS and UOB say their new anti-malware features do not monitor customers’ phone activities, nor collect or store any personal data.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Mainland Chinese outbound air ticket bookings for the upcoming Golden Week holiday have placed Singapore as the sixth top international destination. This marks a recovery in travel bookings, surpassing the level recorded for the Labour Day holiday period. In contrast, Singapore's factory output fell 12.1% year on year in August, and condo resale prices rose 1% in August, reversing a two-month decline. Additionally, UOB and DBS are introducing new anti-malware app features to combat scams, and TSH Resources made its SGX debut with an initial trade price of S$0.305.

site_title: Thai Cabinet approves US$5.3 billion in new borrowing for fiscal year 2024
summary: Thailand's Cabinet has approved US$5.3 billion in new borrowing for the 2024 fiscal year to finance a budget deficit and infrastructure development projects. The borrowing is part of a wider debt management plan, which includes restructuring existing debt and debt repayments. The new borrowing aims to address the country's fiscal deficit and support economic growth through infrastructure development.

images.alt_text: A prospective buyer climbs up sacks of rice to collect a sample during a pre-auction rice inspection at the warehouse of the Boonnapa rice mill in Chock Chai, Nakhon Ratchasima province, Thailand, on Monday, Jan. 26, 2015. Thailand, the biggest exporter of rice, stockpiled 17.8 million metric tons after former Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra spent $27 billion since 2011 buying at above-market prices to aid farmers. Photographer: Dario Pignatelli/Bloomberg

site_title: Looking into shipping’s future
summary: A report from Lloyd's Register and Lloyd's Register Foundation, "Global Maritime Trends 2050," analyzes different future scenarios for shipping, predicting four feasible futures: a gradual transition, rapid tech-driven transition, regionalized and fragmented transition, and delayed transition. The report highlights the importance of decarbonization, with key global ports potentially unusable by 2050 without urgent action. It also forecasts increased regionalization, with African countries potentially becoming the dominant supplier of seafarers by 2050 and women making up 25% of all seafarers by 2050. The report aims to kick-start a multi-year research program to create a safe and sustainable maritime sector.

images.alt_text: A ship transits through the Miraflores locks in the Panama Canal. The waterway is experiencing its worst drought in 70 years, leading to a backlog of vessels and long waiting periods.

A fire broke out on the Fremantle Highway on Jul 25, killing one crew member and prompting a massive effort to extinguish the flames. A significant chunk of the global container shipping industry is backing a programme focused on reducing cargo fires and loss.

site_title: Home prices in US hit record high, erasing recent decline
summary: US home prices reached a record high in July, erasing recent declines. The national gauge of prices increased 0.6% from June, with a 5.3% gain so far this year, offsetting the 5% decline from last year's peak. High mortgage rates, hovering around 7%, have discouraged sellers, leaving buyers competing for a limited supply of homes. The number of homes for sale decreased 7.9% from last year, with Chicago, Cleveland, and New York posting the biggest annual gains, while Las Vegas and Phoenix saw declines of 7.2% and 6.6% respectively.

images.alt_text: Existing home sales slip 0.7 per cent last month to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.04 million units

site_title: China’s travel recovery picks up pace with Golden Week holiday
summary: Mainland Chinese travelers have stepped up their bookings for the upcoming Golden Week holiday, with international air ticket bookings reaching 61% of pre-pandemic levels. Japan tops the list of destinations, followed by South Korea, Thailand, the UK, and the US. Singapore ranks sixth, with bookings 32% above pre-pandemic levels. Tourism Malaysia and Thailand are intensifying marketing efforts to attract Chinese visitors, while Thailand has introduced a visa-free scheme for Chinese travelers. Despite a recovery in air travel, factors such as travel restrictions, lower flight capacity, and changing travel preferences continue to limit the Chinese outbound travel market.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Changi Airport is linked to 25 cities in mainland China and served by 12 airlines, compared to 37 city links and 16 carriers before the pandemic.
While domestic tourism in China has rebounded above pre-Covid levels, international travel is still well below.
In August, China retained its spot as the top source of visitors to Singapore, followed by Indonesia, Malaysia, India and Australia.

site_title: Chipmaker ASML to set up base in Japan’s Hokkaido to support new Rapidus plant
summary: ASML, a Dutch semiconductor equipment maker, plans to set up a base in Japan's Hokkaido to support production at a chip plant for Japanese startup Rapidus. The base will have a customer support team for Rapidus, with 50 ASML engineers initially installed on a prototype line. This move supports Rapidus' goal to manufacture custom-made, leading-edge microchips using ASML's EUV lithography tools. The partnership aims to help Japan break into the market for high-end microchip manufacturing, with the Japanese government providing billions of yen in funding.

images.alt_text: Cutting out intermediaries like Nvidia, AMD, and Intel allows companies to optimise chips specifically for their unique tasks whether it’s streaming videos, serving up search queries, or managing massive databases.
ASML is due to report second-quarter earnings on Wednesday.

site_title: David McCallum, The Man from U.N.C.L.E. actor, dies at 90
summary: David McCallum, the Scottish actor best known for his roles in "The Man from U.N.C.L.E." and "NCIS," has died at 90. McCallum's part in the spy series, where he spoke only a few lines, launched his international fame. He went on to star in numerous TV shows, including "NCIS," for which he won over a new generation of fans. McCallum's acting career spanned seven decades, and he was a gifted actor and author, beloved by many around the world. He died of natural causes.

images.alt_text:
FILE PHOTO: British actor David McCallum discusses his new drama series "Navy NCIS"
with television critics during the CBS television network presentation
at the Television Critics Association Summer press tour in Hollywood
July 21, 2003. The series, which premieres Fall 2003, is about the
Navy's criminal investigation service with McCallum portraying a
medical examiner. REUTERS/Fred Prouser/File Photo

site_title: OCBC to discontinue Pay Anyone app; services consolidated on main digital banking app
summary: OCBC Bank will discontinue its Pay Anyone app in October and consolidate its services on the main OCBC Digital app. The app, which allowed customers to send and receive funds, withdraw cash at ATMs, and perform other transactions, will be replaced by the OCBC Digital app. All past transactions will be displayed in the account's transaction history, and customers are recommended to download the OCBC Digital app. The move aims to provide a consolidated user experience, with customers able to fulfill their banking needs through one app.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Payments are made directly from OCBC customers’ Singapore bank accounts to China merchants that are part of the Alipay+ ecosystem.
DBS and UOB say their new anti-malware features do not monitor customers’ phone activities, nor collect or store any personal data.
SMS messages, which are not encrypted, can be intercepted and read by fraudsters in a number of ways.
OCBC said on Thursday (Sep 7) that within a month, more than 30 customers reported malware in sideloaded apps compromising their Android mobile phones.

site_title: Lockdowns and their impact on emerging markets
summary: A recent study found that COVID-19 lockdowns had minimal impact on mortality rates and excessive costs, particularly in emerging markets like China. Contrary to widespread support for lockdowns, epidemiological experts initially believed they were ineffective and undesirable. The UK's Imperial College model predicted high mortality rates, but its flaws were later exposed. Studies show that voluntary changes in behavior, such as social distancing, played a significant role in mitigating the pandemic, while harsher restrictions generated substantial costs with negligible health benefits. The lockdowns are considered a "global policy failure of gigantic proportions."

images.alt_text: person, suit, medical

site_title: Don’t let emotions sabotage your investment goals
summary: Investors often sabotage their goals due to emotional biases, including overconfidence, hindsight bias, confirmation bias, and loss aversion. These biases can lead to poor investment decisions, such as glossing over risks, holding onto losing stocks, and failing to redeploy funds. To mitigate these biases, investors can keep an investment journal, draw up pros and cons lists, and actively seek out diverse information. By being aware of these emotional pitfalls and adopting a rational approach, investors can learn to manage their emotions and become more successful.

images.alt_text: hand, write, pen
Sysma Holdings’ controlling shareholders were successful in privatising the builder of high-end landed homes at an offer of S$0.168 apiece despite the offer was said to be not fair nor reasonable.
greenhouse, planting, spring

site_title: TD Ameritrade Singapore to stop serving retail investors from Dec 1
summary: TD Ameritrade Singapore will stop serving retail investors from December 1, shifting focus to accredited investors. The company cited a need to "better serve the unique needs of local investors" and will introduce changes such as a monthly maintenance fee of $50 from October 27. Retail investors will need to close their accounts before the end of the year, with options to liquidate positions and withdraw assets. TD Ameritrade will waive transfer or wire fees for entire account transfers or wire withdrawals until the end of the year.

images.alt_text: Samantha Horton, Syfe's chief business officer will continue to lead the Australia market in the wake of the resignations.
The brokerage also said that it will contact clients affected by the settlement fee change to arrange for refunds.

site_title: Tesla’s China exports in crosshairs of EU anti-subsidy probe
summary: The European Union has launched an anti-subsidy probe into Chinese electric vehicle exports, with Tesla being a key player in the investigation. The probe aims to determine if China has subsidized Tesla and other domestic manufacturers, including BYD, SAIC Motor, and Nio, to level the playing field for the EU's industry. The EU is concerned that Chinese companies have received tax breaks, cheap loans, and other forms of assistance that have given them an edge in the market. The probe has the potential to reshape the competitive dynamics in the world's second-largest EV market after China.

site_title: Asian Games put China tech giants on podium after long crackdown
summary: China's tech giants, including Alibaba, have benefited from the Asian Games in Hangzhou, their home city, after a long crackdown on the industry. Alibaba runs the Games' cloud computing system, and its representatives are celebrating "a pioneer in China's Internet economy" on day trips to the company's campus. Despite a series of moves against tech firms, including fines and rule changes, officials have subtly shifted their tone, with Chinese Premier Li Qiang calling for a "fair and competitive market environment." This shift has allowed companies like Alibaba and Tencent to shine at the Games, with Alibaba's partnership deals signed before the crackdown.

images.alt_text: This week, hundreds of elite gamers are descending upon the scenic city of Hangzhou, near Shanghai, to represent their countries at the 19th Asian Games.
Tencent over recent years has made inroads in Japan’s guarded entertainment industry.

China has long been a major exporter of a host of consumer products, but this latest export trend, of its e-commerce marketplace dynamics to the rest of the world, has shaken up online shopping globally.
Cainiao is the logistics arm of Alibaba and operates over 300 international routes, partnering more than 3,000 logistics partners.
Alibaba has “confidence in Turkey’s sound economic fundamentals” and has already invested US$1.4 billion in the country’s biggest e-commerce marketplace.

site_title: SGX RegCo directs Boustead Projects to delist, with exit offer that is fair and reasonable
