summary: The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has directed Boustead Projects to delist due to insufficient public ownership, with less than 10% of shares held by the public. An exit offer must be made within a month, deemed fair and reasonable by an independent financial adviser. Boustead Singapore had previously announced a voluntary takeover offer in February, but the final offer price was deemed "not fair but reasonable" by the adviser. The company has been granted extensions to comply with listing rules, but failed to restore its free float by the deadline, leading to the notice of compliance and delisting.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Boustead Projects is alleged to have breached a contract and preventing its subcontractor from carrying out works according to the original contract schedule.
Boustead Projects  shares have been suspended since Mar 28.

site_title: Alibaba to spin off Cainiao logistics unit for Hong Kong IPO
summary: Alibaba Group Holding is set to spin off its logistics unit, Cainiao Smart Logistics Network, through an initial public offering (IPO) in Hong Kong. The Hong Kong exchange has confirmed that Alibaba can proceed with the proposal, with the company to retain over 50% ownership. The IPO is expected to raise at least $1 billion, with banks including Citic Securities and JPMorgan Chase involved in the deal. This move is part of Alibaba's historic overhaul, splitting into six main units, following the departure of its former CEO and chairman.

images.alt_text: People visit the booth of Alibaba's logistics unit Cainiao at the 2021 China International Fair for Trade in Services (CIFTIS) in Beijing, China September 3, 2021. REUTERS/Florence Lo

site_title: China’s economy set to avoid Japanese-style deflation
summary: China's economy appears to be avoiding a Japanese-style deflation, with a recent survey showing prices recovering and signs of a resumption of growth. The all-sector price index reached 50.9 in September, the highest level in 14 months, indicating a slight increase in prices. This contradicts fears of a prolonged period of low or negative growth, with data company World Economics stating that the signs of a resumption of growth are looking more positive. The economy has been recovering since August, with improved factory production, retail sales, and credit demand, but challenges remain due to a lingering property crisis.

images.alt_text: China has long been a major exporter of a host of consumer products, but this latest export trend, of its e-commerce marketplace dynamics to the rest of the world, has shaken up online shopping globally.

site_title: Thai protest leader gets four-year prison term for royal insult
summary: A Thai court sentenced pro-democracy activist Arnon Nampa to four years in prison for violating the country's royal insult law. Arnon, who led a movement calling for monarchy reform, was found guilty of making a speech that defamed the king in 2020. He denies wrongdoing and is seeking bail while an appeal is filed. The sentence carries a punishment of up to 15 years in prison, but Arnon was acquitted of seven other charges and fined 200,000 baht. The ruling has sparked concerns about freedom of speech in Thailand.

images.alt_text: Pannika Wanich, an activist with the progressive Move Forward Party will be banned from enrolling in politics for the rest of her life.

Vacharaesorn (L) and Chakriwat Vivacharawongse, Thailand's King Maha Vajiralongkorn's sons, greet members of the media after a surprise visit recently to the kingdom after living abroad for 27 years. Vacharaesorn wants open discussion of Thailand's royal defamation laws.

site_title: Why China may struggle to escape stagnation
summary: China's economic stagnation is exemplified in the city of Zhengzhou, where a manufacturing district is vacant due to a labor shortage, lockdowns, and banking instability. The city's difficulties, including low GDP per capita and falling property prices, are a microcosm of China's broader economic issues. Despite recent stabilization in economic data, Zhengzhou's experience suggests that China will struggle to escape stagnation and that a long recovery is likely. Local reforms, such as easing joblessness and relaxing the hukou system, have been implemented, but the country's central government still needs to address the underlying issues to boost long-run growth.

images.alt_text: An easing of mortgage restrictions at the end of August triggered a spurt of home sales in larger cities that is already losing momentum.
To escape the middle-income trap and keep a lid on social unrest, authorities must work out how to create better jobs for city dwellers.
FILE PHOTO: A construction site of residential buildings by Chinese developer Country Garden is pictured in Tianjin, China August 18, 2023. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo

site_title: South Korea, Japan, China to hold summit at 'earliest' possible time
summary: Senior officials from South Korea, Japan, and China agreed to hold a summit of their leaders at the earliest convenient time, potentially in December. They also agreed to hold a trilateral meeting of their foreign ministers in the next few months. This comes as South Korea seeks to revive three-way summits with Japan and China, which have stalled since 2019. The talks aim to improve relations between the three countries, following recent tensions, including a US-led push for curbs on chip sales targeting China's tech sector.

images.alt_text: Unfinished apartment buildings in Zhengzhou. The city’s difficulties – including a lack of work, falling property prices and banking instability – are acute examples of those facing China at large.
Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida said the economic stimulus package would include measures that counter issues such as inflation and depopulation.

site_title: China’s e-commerce discount race to the bottom puts incumbents under pressure
summary: China's e-commerce platforms, including Pinduoduo and Temu, are dominating the global market with their discount strategies, driven by economic insecurity and a slower-than-expected retail recovery. These platforms are flooding the Western world with cheap goods, putting pressure on incumbents like Amazon. Analysts predict this trend will continue, with TikTok Shop also entering the market, further fueling the "value-for-money battle." As a result, e-commerce executives are focusing on price pressures, and giants like Alibaba and JD.com are investing heavily in their discount platforms to compete.

images.alt_text: Indonesia is the first and biggest market for TikTok Shop, and online shopping has become the app’s fastest-growing feature with a burgeoning fan base in the country.

SingPost's Singapore CEO Neo Su Yin (left) and FedEx Express Singapore's managing director, Eric Tan (right). Both companies are conducting a trial for SingPost post offices to accept FedEx parcels at POPStop counters.
Ministers have repeatedly said that e-commerce sellers using predatory pricing on social media platforms are threatening offline markets in Indonesia.

site_title: Global proxy voting database: An idea whose time has come?
summary: A new database, OxProx, has been launched to provide a publicly accessible and searchable platform for global proxy voting records, promoting responsible investments and transparency in the proxy voting system. Founded by Ian Robertson, OxProx gathers and compares proxy voting records among asset owners and asset managers worldwide, addressing concerns of a duopoly in the industry dominated by ISS and Glass Lewis. The database aims to inform stakeholders and shareholder advocacy groups on how to approach and hold firms and investors accountable for ESG decisions, driving positive change in corporate outcomes.

images.alt_text: Toyota is facing pressure from green investors and climate activists who have criticised it for being slower than rivals to embrace all-battery electric vehicles.
Glass Lewis made the recommendation against Toyota's chairman Akio Toyoda (above) at a time when board independence has been under greater scrutiny from investors.
Sabana Industrial Reit's NTP+ at 151 Lorong Chuan

site_title: Germany slashes debt issuance by 31 billion euros in Q4
summary: Germany has reduced its Q4 debt issuance by 31 billion euros, cutting bond issuance by 8 billion euros and bill sales by 23 billion euros compared to a previous plan. This move aims to ease pressure on German bond yields, which have risen to multi-year highs due to concerns about the European Central Bank's interest rate hikes. The reduced issuance volume will trim total sales for the year by 45 billion euros to about 500 billion euros, still a record.

site_title: Japan finance minister warns markets as yen nears intervention danger zone
summary: Japanese Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki warned of potential intervention to curb excessive currency volatility, as the yen nears a 150 per US dollar threshold. Suzuki stated that "excessive volatility is undesirable" and Japan is closely monitoring currency moves with urgency. The yen has fallen to its weakest since October 2022, prompting a mini rally after Suzuki's warning. Japan is seeking G7 ally approval for intervention, but analysts doubt the US will support such action due to concerns over high inflation.

images.alt_text: The yen falls 0.17 per cent to 148.66 per US dollar, touching its lowest since late October.
Kazuo Ueda. Photographer: Akio Kon/Bloomberg
The yen drops as low as 148.42 to the US dollar, nearing the 150-mark at which analysts have said government intervention to prop up the currency is likely.
FILE PHOTO: A woman counts Japanese 10,000 yen notes in Tokyo, in this February 28, 2013 picture illustration.  REUTERS/Shohei Miyano/Illustration/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Government-funded caregiving leave can help level the playing field for SMEs as employers
summary: The government of Singapore may consider a tiered approach to statutory paid caregiving leave, offering full support to small and medium enterprises (SMEs) and partial support to larger companies, as many already provide family care leave. This would help level the playing field for attracting talent and address the issue of equity, as most people have ageing parents but not all have children to care for. Implementing such a policy would benefit worker welfare, improve the labour market, and support the state's encouragement of family care and active ageing.

images.alt_text: NTUC secretary-general Ng Chee Meng calls on stakeholders, including employers and the government, to support workers managing work and caregiving.
Employers understood the increasing necessity of caregiving leave, but said it would be challenging to bear the additional costs of implementing such a policy.

site_title: Scammers set up companies and bank accounts in Singapore remotely during Covid-19
summary: Scammers exploited relaxed COVID-19 rules in Singapore to set up companies and transfer $3.4 million to local bank accounts, with stolen funds originating from overseas companies. Chinese national Liang Jiansen was fined S$9,000 for his role in registering these companies. This scheme took advantage of remote registration processes during the pandemic.

site_title: Bamboo Airways pilots start exiting as Vietnamese carrier struggles to pay wages: sources
summary: Bamboo Airways, Vietnam's third-largest airline, is experiencing pilot exodus due to late salary payments. About 30 foreign pilots left the airline in the last two months, accounting for over 10% of its total pilot staff in June. The airline has undertaken drastic restructuring efforts, including route network, fleet, and human resources adjustments. This exodus is a significant blow to the airline's operations, highlighting the financial struggles of Vietnam's third-largest airline.

images.alt_text: Vietnam's property sector has come under pressure after a state crackdown on debt issuance following allegations of illegal activities.
Singapore entrepreneurs keen on doing business in Vietnam can sign up for Spotlight Singapore’s week-long mission trip to Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City, which will take place from Oct 19 to 25.
Brazil's President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva says he wants to bring Mercosur members closer to Asian countries and highlighted there is room for trade with Vietnam to grow.
Luu Anh Tuan, Chairman of mining company VTRE in his Hanoi office with samples of rare earth oxides in Hanoi, Vietnam September 7, 2023. REUTERS/Francesco Guarascio
Vietnam seeks to collect emissions-based environmental protection fees from greenhouse-gas-emitting facilities
LEGO's planned carbon-neutral factory in Vietnam

site_title: Private equity is piling debt on itself like never before
summary: Private equity firms are taking on record amounts of debt, with some borrowing up to 19% interest, to meet fund commitments or enable succession planning. These high-cost loans, often backed by assets like future income, are becoming increasingly common as the industry faces a drought of deals and dwindling cash. Lenders, such as Carlyle Group, are doing more business than ever, with demand expected to swell seven-fold to $700 billion by the end of the decade. Experts warn of potential risks to the industry and financial system, citing concerns over margin calls and collateral seizure.

images.alt_text: Inflation and the high cost of debt has led family offices to move down the risk curve to pursue value-add and opportunistic strategies.
Fundraising in the local health and biomedical sciences sector fell from US$121 million in 2021 to US$89 million in 2022, according to an SGInnovate report.

site_title: Funding Societies raises US$27 million in debt from institutional investors
summary: Funding Societies, a fintech platform, has raised US$27 million in debt funding from institutional investors, including AlteriQ Global and Aument Capital Partners. The funds will support underserved small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in its five operating markets, including Singapore, Indonesia, Thailand, Malaysia, and Vietnam. The company aims to deepen its financing propositions and build on its existing solutions, which have achieved over US$3.2 billion in business financing and serve about 100,000 SMEs.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Funding Societies co-founder and group chief executive Kelvin Teo

site_title: More buzz for hotels and investment market
summary: Singapore's hotel sector appears strong, with international visitor arrivals up 80% year-on-year in August and exceeding 9 million for the first eight months. Average room rates and revenue per available room jumped 32.8% and 27.2% respectively in July, with analysts attributing the growth to Singapore's reputation as a premier destination for hosting major events and wealth creation in South-east Asia and India. However, concerns over climate change and potential tax implications on air travel may impact the sector's long-term outlook.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
The near and medium-term outlook for Singapore’s hotel sector appears strong, writes senior correspondent Leslie Yee.

site_title: Vietnam property woes deepen as major developer spars with creditors
summary: Vietnam's property sector is facing turmoil due to a state crackdown on debt issuance following allegations of illegal activities. Developer Novaland Investment Group has failed to pay interest on a US$300 million bond, sparking a dispute with creditors. The company has proposed a debt-restructuring plan and is negotiating with bondholders, but its shares have slumped 26% this month. The situation has raised concerns about international investors' confidence in Vietnam, adding to the country's already struggling property sector.

images.alt_text: Luu Anh Tuan, Chairman of mining company VTRE in his Hanoi office with samples of rare earth oxides in Hanoi, Vietnam September 7, 2023. REUTERS/Francesco Guarascio

site_title: Apple’s FineWoven fabric emerges as its biggest misfire of 2023
summary: Apple's FineWoven fabric, introduced as a leather alternative, has been met with criticism for being prone to scratches and stains, despite being made from 68% post-consumer recycled material. Reviewers have expressed disappointment with the product's feel, citing an almost-slippery texture and poor durability. The fabric has been panned by bloggers, reviewers, and even some Apple fans, who describe it as a "biggest misfire" of 2023. The premium price of $59 for a FineWoven iPhone case has also been a point of contention.

images.alt_text: Waiting time for the iPhone 15 has quadrupled in China, Apple’s biggest overseas market.

site_title: Singapore stocks end flat amid regional declines
summary: Singapore stocks ended flat on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) inching down 0.01% to close at 3,215.07. Regional indices, including the Hang Seng Index and Nikkei 225, declined, while the FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI rose 0.2%. Concerns over China's economic stability, driven by the financial crisis at China Evergrande Group, resurfaced, with Beijing prioritizing technological self-sufficiency and financial stability over economic growth.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Generic pictures of the interior and exterior of SGX

site_title: Brokers’ take: Maybank upgrades UMS to ‘buy’ on stronger order momentum
summary: Maybank Securities has upgraded UMS Holdings to "buy" with a raised price target of S$1.44, citing a potential order rebound in FY2024 due to an industry recovery and an expected increase in components orders. The brokerage believes UMS will benefit from a new contract with LAM Research and a secured future for shareholders, with a 4.5% yield expected for FY2024. However, the second half of 2023 remains weak due to the key customer's unlikely order ramp-up this year.

images.alt_text: Mia Pei
Output from the linchpin electronics cluster tumbles 20 per cent year on year in August.
No stock symbolizes the chip industry’s success more than Nvidia, whose shares are tripling in 2023 as the company’s market value tops US$1 trillion.
There are signs that the semiconductor industry is stabilising.
UMS chairman and chief executive Andy Luong said that while near term conditions for the semiconductor industry may remain cloudy, he expects the industry’s mid to longer-term prospects to brighten.

site_title: To merge or not to merge
summary: Grab's potential acquisition of foodpanda's food delivery business in South-east Asia may face hurdles due to competition commissions and investor concerns about sustainability. Grab's recent strong investor sentiments and narrowing losses may be disrupted by the acquisition, which could also lead to layoffs. Competition commissions have previously imposed restrictions on Grab's acquisitions, and the company may struggle to integrate foodpanda's business units. The deal's impact on Grab's share price and overall growth is uncertain, and investors are now prioritizing sustainability over growth.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
It’s been a long funding winter, but venture capital firms are still actively raising capital, writes Garage journalist Daphne Yow.

Unlike the traditional business models of yore – such as real estate and commodities – tech companies focus heavily on clever code and nifty intellectual property, writes Garage correspondent Sharanya Pillai.
While the IPO market could recover, there is a hitch: the public markets may not be able to match the valuations that these companies are seeking, writes Garage correspondent Sharanya Pillai.
Healthtech Biofourmis appears to have crested the wave it was riding, writes Garage correspondent Benjamin Cher.
In this week's issue, Garage correspondent Claudia Chong ponders why ride-hailing giant Grab decided to buy a traditional taxi company.

site_title: Teetering China property giants undercut Xi’s revival push
summary: China's property developers, including China Evergrande Group, are facing fresh challenges that are jeopardizing President Xi Jinping's efforts to revive the housing market. The sector is struggling with debt restructuring, missed bond payments, and dwindling sales, leading to investor confusion over the government's unified plan to stabilize the market. The upcoming Golden Week holiday period, crucial for the industry's sales, is now at risk, with analysts warning that a prolonged slump could last up to a year and hinder China's economic recovery.

images.alt_text: Banks have been curbing lending to the real estate sector given rising financial distress in recent years.

site_title: US House to press forward with spending cuts despite shutdown risk
summary: The US House of Representatives is set to advance spending cuts despite the risk of a partial government shutdown, which could occur by October 1. The Republican-controlled House is pushing for steep cuts, but they are unlikely to pass the Democratic-controlled Senate. Hundreds of thousands of federal workers could be furloughed, and services will be suspended if a stopgap spending bill is not passed. The House will instead advance legislation reflecting conservative priorities, which are likely to be rejected by the Senate.

images.alt_text: Moody’s rates the US government “Aaa” with a stable outlook, the highest creditworthiness it assigns to borrowers.

site_title: Thailand approves US$908 million plan to suspend farmers' debts for 3 years
summary: Thailand's cabinet has approved a US$908 million plan to suspend debt repayments for 2.7 million farmers for three years, starting October 1. The suspension will cover both principal and interest payments, and farmers who have kept up with interest payments can also borrow up to 100,000 baht from the state-owned Bank for Agriculture and Agricultural Cooperatives. The aim is to ease the burdens of farmers and help them "come back strong" after a sluggish economy weighed down by declining exports and falling investor confidence.

images.alt_text: The Thai baht has fallen 2.8 per cent in September to be the worst-performing currency in Asia, while the nation’s sovereign bonds have also underperformed.

site_title: Antarctic winter sea ice hits ‘extreme’ record low
summary: Antarctic sea ice has reached a record low this winter, with the US National Snow and Ice Data Center (NSIDC) reporting a maximum extent of 16.96 million square kilometers, the lowest since satellite records began in 1979. This marks a decline of about 1 million square kilometers from the previous winter record set in 1986. The rapid deterioration of sea ice in the Arctic has been exacerbated by climate change, which is warming the region four times faster than the global average. This shift is expected to have dire consequences for animals reliant on the sea ice, including penguins.

images.alt_text: A professor of the British Antarctic Survey explaining a graph on the state of the Antarctic sea ice over the years in Cambridge in June.

site_title: UK and EU to discuss post-Brexit EV tariffs ahead of deadline
summary: UK and EU officials will meet on September 27 to discuss post-Brexit tariffs on electric vehicles (EVs), with a deadline looming on a potential delay. The proposed 10% tariff, set to apply from next year, would hit EVs traded between the UK and EU if less than 45% of their value comes from the region. UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak and European carmakers seek to extend the phase-in period by three years to develop the battery supply chain, citing potential losses of 4.3 billion euros to the sector.

images.alt_text: Electric vehicles have become a major focal point of global trade tensions in recent weeks as Europe frets that its automakers will lose out to Chinese manufacturers in the transition to less polluting cars.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Phillip Securities initiates ‘buy’ on ST Engineering as defence spending rises
summary: Phillip Securities has initiated a "buy" recommendation on ST Engineering with a target price of S$4.50, citing rising defence spending and revenue visibility for the technology and engineering group. Defence spending increased in FY2021 and FY2022, and is expected to rise further in FY2023. The group's MRO business and aircraft parts are also expected to benefit from the recovery in the aviation sector. Additionally, the US-acquired Transcore is on track to be earnings accretive, with a potential project in New York Congestion Pricing project expected to contribute to the company's growth.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
The commercial aerospace segment of ST Engineering experiences strong year-on-year growth by 32 per cent
Both Citi Research and RHB Research expect a dividend yield of 4.2 per cent from ST Engineering, for FY2023.

site_title: Rich nations, China must accelerate race to net zero: IEA
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) warns that wealthy countries must reach carbon neutrality by 2045, five years early, and China should accelerate its efforts to 2050 to meet the Paris goal of limiting warming to 1.5°C. The agency also emphasizes the need for a "huge policy-driven ramping up of clean energy capacity" and cautions that a delayed response to climate change would force the world to rely on expensive and unproven carbon removal technologies, potentially overshooting the CO2 budget.

images.alt_text: Joko Widodo says Indonesia has tremendous potential for carbon reduction efforts and its carbon market could grow to reach 3,000 trillion rupiah.
Regulators say external auditing of sustainability-related data is crucial for giving investors information free of misleading environmental claims, known as greenwashing.
Climate protestors in New York City during Climate Week in September. The idea that environmental goals can be aligned with economic growth is losing favour among researchers.

site_title: Malaysia-listed TSH Resources closes at S$0.295 on SGX debut
summary: Malaysia-listed TSH Resources has made its debut on the Singapore Exchange (SGX), closing at S$0.295 after opening at S$0.305. The secondary listing aims to expand the company's shareholder base, improve trading liquidity, and attract wider research coverage. Chairman Kelvin Tan said the move will facilitate a new phase of development for the company, which engages in oil palm cultivation and processing. The listing does not involve new share issuance and will allow the company to access a broader investor base and strengthen its regional and international visibility.

images.alt_text: Navene Elangovan
Malaysia currently imposes a windfall levy of 3 per cent on palm oil prices above 3,000 ringgit per tonne in peninsular Malaysia, and above 3,500 ringgit per tonne in Sabah and Sarawak.
Generic shots of SGX
Nio says it has "no reportable capital raising activity" in response to media reports that the company is considering raising capital from investors.

site_title: Mercedes S-Class, Porsche stand to lose most in China tariff row
summary: The European Union's probe into China's electric-vehicle subsidies may lead to tit-for-tat tariffs, putting Mercedes-Benz Group, BMW, and Porsche at greatest risk. These German luxury carmakers rely heavily on China for sales of high-end models like the S-Class and Cayenne SUV, which are mainly imported. China accounted for over 30% of global sales for BMW's 7-series and Mercedes' S-Class last year, and the EU's move could expose Mercedes-Benz Group's biggest moneymakers to significant losses.

images.alt_text: Mercedes is looking to expand its Alabama plant to produce the all-electric GLC from 2026.
Qualcomm will provide voice command chips for BMW cars and supply chips for the upcoming 2024 Mercedes E class models in the US.
Mercedes is under pressure to bolster its lineup after disappointing sales in China forced the company to cut prices on some of its electric models.

site_title: Indonesia to pursue legal action against palm firms that use land illegally
summary: Indonesia's government plans to take legal action against palm oil companies using land illegally if they don't submit required paperwork by November. The country has identified 3.3 million hectares of palm oil plantations in forest areas, resulting in 42 trillion rupiah ($3.7 billion) in losses. Under a 2020 law, plantations meeting certain requirements and paying fines can be recognized as legal. If companies fail to comply, they will face legal action, according to Senior Minister Mahfud MD.

site_title: Asia: Markets on back foot on growing US rate, China worries
summary: Markets in Asia fell on Tuesday as investors grew concerned about the US Federal Reserve's possible interest rate hikes and the impact on the global economy. US Treasury yields reached 16-year highs, pushing the US dollar higher and fueling worries of a recession. The threat of a government shutdown in Washington also added to the concerns, with Moody's warning of negative implications for the US credit rating. Meanwhile, China's property sector woes continued, with Evergrande missing a bond repayment and a government warning of intervention in the yen market.

images.alt_text: Asian stock markets struggled in early exchanges on Monday, with Hong Kong off more than one per cent while Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Wellington, Singapore and Jakarta were also lower.

site_title: Hollywood's video game performers authorise strike if labour talks fail
summary: SAG-AFTRA, the union representing film and television actors, has authorized a strike if negotiations with gaming companies fail. 98.32% of voting members supported the strike, citing concerns over pay, medical treatment, and protection against artificial intelligence. The union is seeking wage increases, better rest periods, and safeguarding of performers' rights in the face of AI. Negotiations are set to begin with major gaming companies, including Activision Blizzard and Electronic Arts, after the writers union reached a preliminary agreement with studios last week.

images.alt_text: Despite the tentative deal in hand, the writers guild encouraged members to join the striking actors’ picket lines, which will begin again on Tuesday.

site_title: TikTok shopping ambitions face blow as Indonesia plans curbs
summary: Indonesia plans to curb TikTok's online shopping ambitions by prohibiting direct e-commerce payments on its platform, citing a need to protect micro, small, and medium enterprises. The move, set to be implemented as soon as Tuesday, means companies will only be able to advertise products but not conduct transactions. This is a major blow to TikTok's plans to expand in the country, where it has a burgeoning fan base and is testing its online shopping feature. The regulation is part of tightened trade regulations aimed at keeping local businesses competitive.

images.alt_text: Ministers have repeatedly said that e-commerce sellers using predatory pricing on social media platforms are threatening offline markets in Indonesia.
FILE PHOTO: The TikTok logo is pictured outside the company's U.S. head office in Culver City, California, U.S.,  September 15, 2020.   REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo
TikTok launched its Shop marketplace tab in the US this week, continuing the expansion of a commerce business that is the company’s most promising new source of revenue growth.
TikTok’s more than 150 million users in the US will now be able to see videos and live streams with links to purchase items on their feed

site_title: Dimon warns world not ready for 7% Fed rate: Times of India
summary: US Federal Reserve Chairman Jamie Dimon warns that the world may not be prepared for a worst-case scenario of Federal Reserve benchmark interest rates hitting 7% and stagflation, citing potential stress in the system. Dimon, who believes rates may need to rise further to fight inflation, says the difference between 5% and 7% rates would be more painful for the economy than going from 3% to 5%.

images.alt_text: The Senate is scheduled to advance a stopgap spending measure on Tuesday.
Moody’s rates the US government “Aaa” with a stable outlook, the highest creditworthiness it assigns to borrowers.

site_title: China says willing to play ‘constructive’ role in Apec’s success
summary: China's Foreign Minister Wang Yi said the country is willing to play a "constructive" role in the success of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec) summit in San Francisco. Wang opposed "wanton" expansion of military alliances that squeeze the security space of other countries, without naming any country. This comes as China's President Xi Jinping missed the G20 summit in India, prompting US criticism that China is "giving up" on the G20 and building an alternative world order. A meeting between Xi and US President Biden is expected at Apec.

images.alt_text: China’s anti-espionage and data laws, as well as raids on US consultancies, have rattled investors.

site_title: India reassures confidence in Aadhaar after Moody’s questions its reliability
summary: India's Ministry of Electronics & IT has reassured confidence in its Aadhaar digital identification system after Moody's raised concerns about its reliability, particularly in hot climates. Moody's reported issues with authorisation and biometric reliability, but the ministry disputed these claims, citing examples of direct money crediting to workers' accounts without biometric authentication. The government also pointed out the availability of alternative biometric submission methods, such as face and iris authentication. No breach has been reported from the Aadhaar database, and the Supreme Court upheld the system's validity in 2018.

images.alt_text: The Reserve Bank of India ordered the withdrawal of the 2,000-rupee note on May 19, giving people until the end of September to exchange or deposit them with banks.
The move buttresses India’s aspirations for a bigger global heft as it boasts one of the world’s fastest rates of economic growth and positions itself as an alternative to China.
Prices for rice, a staple for half the world, has surged to the highest in almost 15 years after India began curbing exports.

site_title: Condo resale prices reverse slide in August, led by suburban gains: SRX, 99.co
summary: Condominium resale prices in Singapore rose 1% in August, reversing a two-month decline, led by gains in suburban locations. The OCR saw the highest resale price gain of 1.6%, followed by the RCR at 1.3%, while the CCR's resale prices dipped 0.1%. Year-on-year, condo resale prices were 7.6% higher. The number of sub-sale transactions increased 0.5% in August, driven by the lack of new launches. Experts expect the resale market to remain resilient over the next few months, with a median capital gain of S$311,000 in August.

images.alt_text: Samuel Oh

site_title: UOB, DBS roll out new anti-malware app features in fight against scams
summary: Singaporean banks DBS and UOB are introducing new anti-malware features in their banking apps to combat scams. The features, set to roll out progressively, will restrict access to customers' accounts if they are using apps with "risky permissions settings" or if malware is detected. The measures do not monitor customers' phone activities or collect personal data, and customers will be notified if their accounts are restricted. The banks' efforts follow the Association of Banks in Singapore's announcement of enhanced security measures and a recent advisory by the Singapore Police Force on a new variant of malware scams.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
SMS messages, which are not encrypted, can be intercepted and read by fraudsters in a number of ways.
OCBC to continue with physical tokens as it weighs fraud risks to customers
DBS, UOB to continue offering physical tokens on request
Singapore banks see higher requests for physical tokens in January

site_title: Binance seeks to launch stablecoins in Japan with MUFG unit
summary: Binance plans to launch stablecoins denominated in US dollars, euros, and yen in Japan in 2024, partnering with Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group's trust banking arm. Japan legalized stablecoin issuance in June, and the market is expected to grow to $45.92 billion. Binance must obtain a license in Japan to issue the stablecoins, which can be used for cryptocurrency trading and payment services.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People are reflected in the logo of Mitsubishi UFJ  Financial Group's bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ (MUFG) in Tokyo, Japan, May 16, 2016. REUTERS/Thomas Peter/File Photo

site_title: Biden makes new pledges to Pacific island leaders as China’s influence grows
summary: US President Joe Biden hosted a summit with Pacific island leaders, reaffirming the US commitment to a free, open, and secure Indo-Pacific region. The US pledged $200 million in funding for climate change projects, economic growth, and public health. Biden also announced recognition of two Pacific islands, the Cook Islands and Niue, and called for increased engagement with the region to counter China's influence. The sides agreed to hold another summit in 2025 and regular political engagements. Despite progress, some Pacific island leaders, including Solomon Islands Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare, skipped the summit due to ties with China.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden during a a meeting with the President's Board of Advisors on Historically Black Colleges and Universities in the Roosevelt Room of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Monday, Sept. 25, 2023. Biden recently highlighted how his administration has lowered prescription drug prices, invested in Historically Black Colleges and Universities, and was working to close the racial wealth gap and reduce the disparity in employment for Black Americans. Photographer: Yuri Gripas/Abaca/Bloomberg

site_title: US will have 18 ETFs launched this week for 2023 weekly record
summary: The US is set to launch a record 57 new exchange-traded funds (ETFs) this month, surpassing the 53 that arrived in September 2022. The new ETFs include 18 scheduled for launch this week, with notable providers such as Capital Group, Brookstone Asset Management, and Dimensional Fund Advisors. This marks a significant increase from last year's total of 433 ETF launches and follows a record 481 launches in 2021. The surge in ETF launches is expected to contribute to a weekly record of 18 new ETFs.

site_title: Nio says it has ‘no reportable capital raising activity’ currently, amid reports of funding plan
summary: Chinese electric vehicle maker Nio stated it has "no reportable capital raising activity" amid reports of a potential $3 billion funding plan from investors. The company recently closed a $1 billion convertible notes offering and its shares in Singapore have fallen 20.5% over the past five trading days. Nio's shares in Singapore dropped 6.4% on Monday, closing at $8.24.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim

site_title: IMF board clears Suriname review, sees advance in China debt talks
summary: The IMF board has cleared Suriname's review, allowing the country to withdraw $52 million from its $630 million program. The IMF sees progress in debt talks with China, Suriname's only creditor without a debt agreement, with both sides committed to reaching an agreement by the next review. Despite not meeting all performance criteria, the board approved a waiver for corrective measures taken by the government. The government will use the released funds for budget support, and the IMF is optimistic about the advancement in debt talks.

site_title: Vietnam interested in trade deal with Mercosur, says Brazil’s Lula
summary: Brazilian President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva announced that Vietnam has expressed interest in a trade deal with Mercosur, a bloc of Brazil, Argentina, Paraguay, and Uruguay. Lula aims to deepen cooperation between Brazil and Vietnam in sectors like agriculture, education, and defense, with agreements already signed covering these areas. He also plans to discuss the topic with Mercosur members to bring them closer to Asian countries. This move comes as Mercosur tries to finalize a trade deal with the European Union, with Lula pushing for its completion by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: Luu Anh Tuan, Chairman of mining company VTRE in his Hanoi office with samples of rare earth oxides in Hanoi, Vietnam September 7, 2023. REUTERS/Francesco Guarascio

site_title: Qantas gets first sell rating as cost of fixing brand mounts
summary: Qantas received its first sell rating in a year from CLSA's Justin Barratt, citing the airline's rising costs and reputation damage. The airline's shares fell 2.7% after the downgrade, with analysts cutting stock-price forecasts due to increased passenger investment and fuel costs. Qantas faces near-term headwinds, including a court ruling exposing the airline to compensation payments for illegally sacking 1,700 ground workers and a potential record fine of A$250 million from the competition watchdog.

images.alt_text: Since pandemic travel curbs eased last year, a spike in flight cancellations, lost bags and telephone wait-times have frustrated Qantas passengers.
Qantas Airways expects a further A$50 million impact due to non-fuel-related foreign exchange changes in the first half of the current fiscal year.
Qantas is facing a regulatory lawsuit accusing it of breaching consumer law by selling fares for 8,000 flights that were cancelled in mid-2022.

site_title: Indonesia’s president launches carbon emissions credit trading
summary: Indonesia's President Joko Widodo launched the country's first carbon emission credit trading system, aiming to fund greenhouse gas emissions cuts and become a major global player. The system, facilitated by the Indonesia Stock Exchange, traded 13 credits worth 460,000 tonnes of CO2e, priced at 69,600 rupiah per tonne. The government plans to expand the market, cap emissions in other sectors, and adopt international standards. The move is part of Indonesia's goal to reach carbon neutrality by 2060 and capitalize on its vast potential for nature-based carbon reduction efforts.

images.alt_text: Indonesia is the first and biggest market for TikTok Shop, and online shopping has become the app’s fastest-growing feature with a burgeoning fan base in the country.

Jokowi will complete his second and final term in office next year but his manoeuvres to install his relatives in positions of political influence have raised eyebrows in a country that only 25 years ago broke free of authoritarian rule.
Ministers have repeatedly said that e-commerce sellers using predatory pricing on social media platforms are threatening offline markets in Indonesia.

site_title: Moody’s warns US government shutdown bad for country’s credit
summary: Moody's warns a US government shutdown would harm the country's credit, citing rising pressures on US government debt affordability due to higher interest rates. The agency rates the US government "AAA" with a stable outlook, but a shutdown would disrupt services and furlough hundreds of thousands of federal workers. Moody's analyst William Foster says the lack of effective fiscal policy response to rising pressures could lead to a negative outlook and downgrade, further evidence of the US's weakened fiscal policymaking.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden  will host a second summit with Pacific island leaders this week.

Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell speaks during a news conference following a Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting in Washington, DC, on Sept 20, 2023. The Federal Reserve left its benchmark interest rate unchanged while signaling borrowing costs will likely stay higher for longer after one more hike this year.

site_title: Economists cut Singapore growth forecast after factory output dives 12.1% in August
summary: Singapore's factory output fell 12.1% year on year in August, contracting at a faster rate than in July. The decline was driven by a 20% year-on-year drop in electronics output, the linchpin cluster. Factory output excluding the biomedical sector slipped 13.3% year on year. This marks the 11th consecutive month of contraction, with the weakest year-on-year reading since November 2019. Economists have cut their growth forecast for Singapore due to the decline.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh

ST01622013-1304864423
/Desmond Foo/Faith /
ymadd: Budget profiles - Add-Plus, an electronics manufacturing company that makes printed circuit boards, has invested 200k in a new machine that will be able to conduct checks on its end products as well as ensure initial inputs meet the required specifications. This will help the firm save time and improve the quality/consistency of its products. (the machine is called the ?SPEA? Flying probe tester)

BLK 35 #04-06 Marsiling Industrial Road 3

site_title: A hidden US-China decoupling in private equity
summary: Private equity firms in the US are facing increasing scrutiny from investors due to China's anti-espionage and data laws, as well as raids on US consultancies. This has led to a decoupling of US-China dealmaking, with North American investors pulling back from investing in China-focused private equity funds. To address this, private equity groups are trying to find ways to appease both US and Chinese investors, including creating separate funds or restricting Chinese involvement. This shift marks a long-term change in global capital flows and forces dealmakers to take on a more political role.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Nio, TSH Resources
summary: Nio, a Chinese electric vehicle maker, has denied raising capital from investors, despite media reports suggesting a potential US$3 billion raise. The company reported the close of its US$1 billion convertible senior note offering. In contrast, TSH Resources will commence trading on the Singapore Exchange's mainboard on Tuesday after its secondary listing by way of introduction.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

FILE PHOTO: The logo of NIO seen on an ET7 car model is pictured at the NIO House, the showroom of the Chinese premium smart electric vehicle manufacture NIO Inc. in Berlin, Germany August 17, 2023. REUTERS/Annegret Hilse/File Photo

site_title: Gold adrift as investors await more data for US Fed rate clues
summary: Gold prices fell 0.1% to $1,914.61 per ounce as the US dollar and Treasury yields rose, with investors awaiting a key consumer inflation report for more cues on the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike plans. The US dollar reached a 10-month high, while 10-year Treasury yields hit a 16-year peak. Investors expect a majority of Fed policymakers to see one more rate hike in the next three months, but price in only a 50% chance of further tightening in 2023.

images.alt_text: Spot gold was mostly unchanged at US$1,924.54 per ounce by 0051 GMT, while US gold futures fell 0.1 per cent to US$1,944.30.

site_title: Industrial metals drop on outlook for China construction, rates
summary: Industrial metals, including copper, iron ore, and aluminum, dropped due to concerns over China's property market and inflationary pressures. Demand for steel is expected to weaken ahead of the National Day holiday period, with fewer buyers replenishing inventories and expecting further price softening. China's ongoing economic malaise and lack of significant funding commitments to support the construction industry have led to a decline in commodity prices, with iron ore prices potentially reaching $90 a ton.

images.alt_text: An easing of mortgage restrictions at the end of August triggered a spurt of home sales in larger cities that is already losing momentum.

site_title: Spotify tests voice translation feature for podcasts
summary: Spotify is testing an AI-powered voice translation feature for podcasts, allowing them to be translated into Spanish, French, and German with a natural style. The feature, powered by Microsoft-backed OpenAI, will be available on select catalog episodes and future releases. The goal is to expand the audience of shows and tap into new users, following Spotify's aggressive spending on its podcast business. The feature marks the company's latest attempt to capitalize on generative artificial intelligence, amid rising interest rates and inflation.

images.alt_text: Spotify is also raising the audience threshold that conventional podcasters must meet to qualify for those ads to 1,000 unique Spotify listeners over the past 60 days from 100.

site_title: China property recovery up to a year away, ex-PBOC adviser says
summary: China's property market recovery is expected to take up to a year, according to former PBOC adviser Li Daokui. Sales in major cities may return to growth in 4-6 months, while smaller cities may take 6-12 months to recover. Li proposes a mechanism to increase bank lending to property developers to cushion them through the downturn, requiring approximately $18.7 billion. He also suggests policies to boost demand for consumer goods and housing could be more effective in supporting the economy than interest rate cuts.

images.alt_text: This photo taken on August 17, 2022 shows a woman ferrying a child in a vehicle through a residential complex in Beijing's Shangdi neighbourhood. (Photo by Noel CELIS / AFP)
An easing of mortgage restrictions at the end of August triggered a spurt of home sales in larger cities that is already losing momentum.
Hengda Real Estate Group fails to repay 4 billion yuan (S$748 million) in principal plus interest due on Sep 25.
The worsening crisis has fuelled concerns among some global money managers that Chinese assets are becoming “uninvestable”, amid weak governance and disclosure practices.
Sentiment has worsened dramatically in recent days as investors brace for years of pain from the ailing sector, with policy support failing to resolve liquidity woes.

site_title: Europe: China, rate woes send stocks to one-month lows
summary: European stocks slid 0.6% on Monday, marking their third consecutive decline, due to concerns about interest rates staying high and a slowing Chinese economy. Luxury stocks were particularly affected, with LVMH and Kering shedding 2.6% and 4.5%, respectively. The European Central Bank signaled a pause in October, while the Federal Reserve struck a hawkish tone, further weighing on investor sentiment. Longer-dated eurozone bond yields rose, with Germany's 10-year yield hitting its highest since 2011.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 index fell 0.3 per cent, touching its lowest in more than a week, with the construction and materials sector amongst the top decliners, down 1.0 per cent.

site_title: Three-quarters of firms globally are not ready for new ESG rules, KPMG finds
summary: Three-quarters of global firms are not prepared for new ESG rules, according to a KPMG report. The European Union, US, and global regulations are set to kick in in time for the 2024 reporting season, requiring listed companies to disclose climate-related information. External auditing of sustainability data is crucial to prevent "greenwashing" and provide investors with accurate information. Regulators emphasize the importance of this auditing process, highlighting the need for companies to be ready to comply with the new rules.

images.alt_text: architecture, skyscraper, glass facades

site_title: Oil prices settle near flat in choppy trade; Russia eases fuel export ban
summary: Oil prices settled near flat on Monday, with Brent crude futures rising 2 US cents to US$93.29 a barrel. The relaxation of Russia's fuel export ban and concerns over interest rates curbing demand contributed to the flat trade. Despite a hawkish Federal Reserve, oil prices fell last week after Saudi Arabia and Russia extended production cuts. A stronger US dollar and supply constraints, including a US refinery shutdown, also weighed on prices. Analysts expect better economic data from China to lift sentiment, but technical resistance remains at November 2022 highs.

images.alt_text: Brent futures settled three cents lower at US$93.27 a barrel. It fell 0.3 per cent in the week, breaking a three-week streak of gains.

site_title: China’s ailing property market faces key test over Golden Week
summary: China's property market faces a key test over the Golden Week holiday period, which starts on September 29. Recent mortgage restrictions easing in August sparked a brief surge in home sales in larger cities, but momentum is now fading. Developers rely on cash from sales to meet debt obligations, and a slowdown in home sales weighs on China's economic recovery. Experts say property sales this year have been lackluster, and accelerating transactions in the next two months will be crucial for developers to avoid taking a bigger hit.

images.alt_text: Hengda Real Estate Group fails to repay 4 billion yuan (S$748 million) in principal plus interest due on Sep 25.
The worsening crisis has fuelled concerns among some global money managers that Chinese assets are becoming “uninvestable”, amid weak governance and disclosure practices.
Sentiment has worsened dramatically in recent days as investors brace for years of pain from the ailing sector, with policy support failing to resolve liquidity woes.

site_title: India to cut floor price for basmati rice exports: sources
summary: India plans to lower the floor price for basmati rice exports to $850 a tonne, down from $1,200 a tonne, to boost sales and help farmers. The decision aims to address a sharp drop in overseas sales of the premium aromatic grain. India fixed the floor price last month to prevent non-basmati rice from being exported as basmati. The move is expected to help farmers and India retain its pre-eminent position in the global basmati rice market.

images.alt_text: Thai farmers, however, are happier these days because they are now receiving 12,000 baht (S$456) per tonne of paddy (or unhusked) rice that they sell on the market, compared to the usual price of 9,000 baht.
Prices for rice, a staple for half the world, has surged to the highest in almost 15 years after India began curbing exports.

site_title: Air France-KLM says it plans to buy 50 Airbus A350 jets
summary: Air France-KLM plans to order 50 Airbus A350 long-haul jets, with options for an additional 40, in its largest-ever wide-body purchase. The deal, worth several billion US dollars, aims to give the airline flexibility in allocating aircraft among its brands based on market or regulatory conditions. The aircraft will be delivered between 2026 and 2030, replacing Airbus A330 jets and most of its older Boeing 777s.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: KLM airplanes are seen parked at Schiphol Airport in Amsterdam, Netherlands April 2, 2020. REUTERS/Piroschka van de Wouw/File Photo
An Air France-KLM aircraft takes off from Toulouse-Blagnac Airport in Toulouse, France.Photographer: Matthieu Rondel/Bloomberg

site_title: Social media inspires Japanese women to dash into rickshaw pulling
summary: Japanese women are taking on a traditionally male-dominated profession by pulling rickshaws in Tokyo, inspired by social media. Led by 21-year-old Yuka Akimoto, a handful of women have joined the profession, offering tours and engaging with tourists. They require physical strength and extensive knowledge of the city to succeed. These female rickshaw pullers have gained a strong local and international following, breaking down barriers in a traditionally male-dominated field. Their unique approach has brought attention to the profession and encouraged more women to take on the role.

images.alt_text: So far this year, Thailand has welcomed a total of 19 million visitors.
Thailand, South Korea, Malaysia, Singapore, Australia and the UK are among the most popular overseas destinations.

site_title: Tech-enabled coffee chains eyeing Singapore as prized battleground for supremacy
summary: Tech-enabled coffee chains, such as Luckin Coffee, are expanding into Singapore, aiming to conquer the market with their innovative blend of physical storefronts and mobile app ordering. Companies like Kopi Kenangan and Pickup Coffee are also entering the market, seeking to capitalize on Singapore's high coffee consumption per capita. However, the aggressive expansion model that has worked for Luckin in China may not be as successful in Singapore, where overheads are high and consumers are savvy. The competition is expected to be fierce, with potential price wars, and companies must balance quality control, pricing, and branding to succeed in the market.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
Indonesian coffee chain Kopi Kenangan raises US$96m, becomes latest unicorn
Luckin Coffee employees preparing baijiu liquor-flavoured latte, the latest product in collaboration with Chinese liquor brand Kweichow Moutai, in a Luckin Coffee shop in Beijing on Monday (Sep 4).
Flash Coffee has raised a further US$50 million amid fiercer competition and after a round of layoffs in November 2022.

site_title: Sunak seeks new UK net-zero settlement in face of ‘green-lash’
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak is seeking a new net-zero settlement amidst growing criticism of the country's climate goals. He announced a delay of the planned ban on new UK petrol and diesel car sales to 2035, sparking industry and opposition criticism. Sunak also plans to give more time for people to transition from gas boilers to heat pumps and scrapped plans to force landlords to upgrade property energy efficiency. The move is seen as an attempt to address the "green-lash" – a backlash to environmental policies – and maintain investor confidence.

images.alt_text: “We’re going to ease the transition to electric vehicles. You’ll still be able to buy petrol and diesel cars and vans until 2035,” says Britain's Prime Minister Rishi Sunak .
The British government is expected to approve the development of Rosebank, near Scotland’s Shetland Isles as well as other sites in the nearby North Sea.

site_title: Singapore shares open muted on Tuesday; STI down 0.01%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 0.31 point or 0.01% to 3,215.09 on Tuesday, with gainers outnumbering losers 51 to 47. The most actively traded stock, Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, rose 0.6% to S$1.72. The broader market saw 25.7 million securities worth S$47.8 million change hands. The STI's performance was largely unaffected by the mixed global market trends.

images.alt_text: Nio says it has "no reportable capital raising activity" in response to media reports that the company is considering raising capital from investors.

site_title: Valentino chairman gives gloomy outlook for luxury sector
summary: Luxury goods demand is expected to decline due to a slow recovery in China, where severe lockdowns in 2022 hurt demand. According to Valentino chairman Rachid Mohamed Rachid, the industry's troubles are mounting, with US department stores struggling and China failing to meet expectations. The market is expected to grow 5-12% this year, down from 20% in 2022. This gloomy outlook is fueling talk of consolidation, with recent deals including Kering's acquisition of Valentino and Tapestry's purchase of Michael Kors parent Capri Holdings.

images.alt_text: Barclays analyst Carole Madjo reduces her recommendation on France’s LVMH to equal-weight from overweight and the firm lowered its view on the sector to neutral from positive.

site_title: Nike faces risks from consumer squeeze, China: Jefferies
summary: Nike faces risks from slowing consumer spending in the US, particularly with the return of student loan payments in October, which could dent spending by up to $9 billion monthly. Analysts also warn of choppy sales trends in China, citing ongoing headwinds. As a result, Jefferies analysts downgraded their ratings on Nike, Foot Locker, and Urban Outfitters to "hold" from "buy", citing a broader risk to the consumer sector. This comes as consumer stocks are seen losing their shine due to increasing risks and uncertainties.

site_title: Apple supplier Pegatron to halt ops at India plant for second day after fire
summary: Apple supplier Pegatron halted operations at its Indian factory for a second day after a fire broke out on Sunday, citing a "spark incident" that is currently under control. The factory, which assembles about 8,000-12,000 iPhones per day, was not given a reason for the halt. Multiple fire engines were brought in to douse the fire, which caused black smoke and led to a crowd gathering outside. Pegatron, which accounts for 10% of Apple's iPhone production in India, has halted production for a second day amid an ongoing investigation.

images.alt_text: Waiting time for the iPhone 15 has quadrupled in China, Apple’s biggest overseas market.
The devices are going on sale in about 40 countries in its first wave, including in Australia, Hong Kong, mainland China, the US, UK and France.
People who ordered the latest iPhone model line up outside an Apple store in Beijing, China, Sept 22, 2023.

site_title: Year-end peak shipping season expected to be flatter amid global headwinds
summary: Industry players expect this year's peak shipping season to be relatively flat due to macroeconomic conditions limiting retail spending and retailers holding excess inventory. A historic drought at the Panama Canal, which handles 5% of global trade, may also disrupt supply chains. While some uptick in shipping is expected, global trade may not experience a traditional peak season, with consumer demand dampened by high inflation and rising interest rates.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong
Maersk transports goods for retailers and consumer companies such as Walmart, Nike and Unilever, and is seen as a barometer for global economic and corporate health.
CMA CGM’s second-quarter net income fell about 83 per cent to US$1.3 billion from a record US$7.6 billion in the same three months of the previous year.

site_title: Getty Images to debut its own artificial intelligence image generator
summary: Getty Images is launching an AI image generator tool, developed with Nvidia, to produce original content without copyright concerns. The tool will use Getty's own data, excluding news photos, and will not incorporate trademarked material or assets without permission. The move aims to prevent deepfakes and sidestep legal issues. The AI-generated images will receive Getty's usual license to use the content and indemnification against lawsuits.

images.alt_text: Among the new products YouTube announces is a tool called Dream Screen that uses generative AI to add video or image backgrounds to short-form videos, which the company calls Shorts.
OpenAI said the latest version of its tool will have more safeguards such as limiting its ability to generate violent, adult or hateful content.
Intel says that it is building a new supercomputer that would be used by Stability AI, a startup that makes image-generating software.

site_title: China Evergrande misses payments on 4 billion yuan onshore bond
summary: China Evergrande Group's flagship unit, Hengda Real Estate Group, missed a 4 billion yuan onshore bond payment due on September 25. The company cited financial difficulties and cancelled creditor meetings, delaying its proposed restructuring. This move adds uncertainty to the fate of the struggling developer, which faces a potential liquidation hearing in Hong Kong on October 30. Evergrande had previously promised to "actively" negotiate with bond holders to find a solution. The missed payment follows previous failures to make interest payments on a 2020 yuan bond.

site_title: ECB rates to stay restrictive as long as needed: Lagarde
summary: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde reaffirmed that interest rates will remain elevated to control inflation, aiming to return to a 2% target in a timely manner. This decision comes as the economy struggles, with rates having increased 10 straight times to 4%. Lagarde stated that future decisions will ensure key interest rates remain at "sufficiently restrictive levels for as long as necessary" to tame consumer prices.

images.alt_text: US Federal Reserve policymakers are holding the Fed’s benchmark rate at 5.25 per cent-5.50 per cent but are stressing that they will remain tough in an inflation fight they now see lasting into 2026.
The ECB, as well as BOE, faces a bigger dilemma than the US Federal Reserve because prices in Europe are still rising fast and growth is slowing.
Thursday’s 25-basis-point increase pushes the rate the ECB pays on bank deposits to 4.0 per cent, the highest level since the euro currency was launched in 1999.

site_title: Germany unveils relief measures to prop up construction industry
summary: Germany's Chancellor Olaf Scholz has unveiled a 45 billion euro relief package to prop up the construction industry, which has been struggling due to high interest rates and rising costs. The package includes 18 billion euros for affordable housing until 2027, and the government has put on hold plans to require more stringent building insulation standards, a move demanded by the industry. The government aims to offer better depreciation options for the housing industry to speed up construction and address the construction backlog.

images.alt_text: One in five property companies has reported cancelling building projects in August, while 11.9 per cent face financing difficulties, according to a recent survey.

site_title: US: Stocks end higher, ending losing streak
summary: US stocks ended higher on Monday, snapping a four-day losing streak, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.1% at 34,006.88. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also gained 0.4% and 0.5%, respectively. Investor sentiment improved despite concerns over a possible US government shutdown and high interest rates, with Moody's warning that a shutdown would negatively impact the country's top-tier credit rating. Analysts also cited elevated US Treasury yields and worries over the China property sector as factors limiting gains.

images.alt_text: A Wall Street street sign in front of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, U.S., on Monday, Jan. 4, 2021. In a historic year that marked a rapid plunge into bear market territory and a swift recovery into the bull zone, high-flying technology stocks and electric-vehicle pioneer Tesla Inc. were standout trades.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average falls 56.25 points, or 0.17 per cent, at the open to 33,907.59.

site_title: OpenAI’s ChatGPT will ‘see, hear and speak’ in major update
summary: OpenAI's ChatGPT is set to receive a major update, enabling voice conversations and image interaction. The feature, available for Plus and Enterprise plan subscribers in two weeks, will allow users to engage in voice conversations, access images, and troubleshoot issues. The update is seen as a significant step towards ChatGPT rivaling popular AI assistants like Apple's Siri. The new features have various applications, including accessibility and creative uses, and will be integrated with existing capabilities such as document summarization and code writing.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: ChatGPT logo is seen in this illustration taken, February 3, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: KPMG to cut 125 UK consulting jobs as client demand drops
summary: KPMG UK is cutting 125 consulting jobs in response to falling client demand and challenging economic conditions. The move, representing 2.3% of staff, follows similar cuts by rival firms Deloitte and EY. PwC has also reduced pay increases and bonuses. The cuts are part of a broader trend among the Big Four firms, which are adapting to a challenging market.

site_title: Goldman, HSBC join forces with other banks on client disclosures
summary: Goldman Sachs and HSBC are among a group of five banks, including Barclays and BNP Paribas, adopting a common global approach to disclosing clients' stock positions. The initiative, called Endoxa, aims to streamline efforts and lower costs by using automation to minimize reporting risks. The group is working with RegTech specialist Droit to develop a common digital code for consistent compliance. The move is expected to enhance transparency and reduce the risk of misinterpretation of reporting rules, ultimately benefiting retail investors.

images.alt_text: The Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) and the Bank of England’s Prudential Regulation Authority say their proposed measures would boost diversity and inclusion to support healthy work cultures, reduce groupthink and unlock talent.
The SEC fines Goldman for providing incomplete and inaccurate "blue sheet data".
Anti-malware security measures on banking apps will aid banks in detecting the presence of malware on customers’ devices and trigger additional actions, said ABS.

The group representing the US banking industry, argues that banks cannot appropriately respond to the proposal put forward by the Federal Reserve, FDIC and Office of the Comptroller of the Currency without that analysis.

site_title: Malaysia plantation company TSH Resources to commence trading on SGX on Sep 26
summary: TSH Resources, a Bursa Malaysia-listed oil palm plantation company, will commence trading on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) mainboard on September 26. The secondary listing aims to expand the company's shareholder base, improve trading liquidity, and attract wider research coverage. The listing does not involve any new share issuance, and shares will be fully fungible across both exchanges. The company posted revenue of RM1.3 billion for FY22 and profit after tax of RM525 million.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Generic shots of SGX

site_title: China sets 2023 rare earth mining quota at 240,000 tonnes, up 14% yoy
summary: China has set a record high rare earth mining quota of 240,000 tonnes for 2023, a 14% increase from last year. The move is seen as a supply indicator and reflects the country's efforts to maintain its dominance in the global rare earth market. The increased quota is expected to lead to lower prices of rare earths, which has contributed to shrinking profits among major producers. China's annual quota for smelting and separation of rare earths also rose by nearly 14% to 230,000 tonnes.

images.alt_text: Luu Anh Tuan, Chairman of mining company VTRE in his Hanoi office with samples of rare earth oxides in Hanoi, Vietnam September 7, 2023. REUTERS/Francesco Guarascio
China accounts for 70 per cent of the world's mine production of rare earths in 2022, followed by the US, Australia, Myanmar, and Thailand, US Geological Survey (USGS) data shows.

site_title: Penguin International privatisation bid falls short with 88.92% shareholding
summary: Penguin International's privatisation bid fell short, closing with 88.92% shareholding, short of the 90% threshold for compulsory acquisition. The consortium, led by Aleph Tav, had offered S$0.83 per share, but failed in its second attempt to privatise the marine and offshore services provider. The bid was extended six times before the close on September 25. Shares rose 0.6% on the announcement, ending at S$0.835.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
James Tham, Managing Director of Penguin International

site_title: Mercedes applies for tax relief for projects at two US plants
summary: Mercedes-Benz has applied for tax breaks for potential projects at two US plants, including an expansion of its Alabama plant to produce the all-electric GLC from 2026, and the construction of fully electric delivery vans and medium-sized luxury transporters at its South Carolina plant. The company is also considering producing the all-electric GLS at the Alabama plant. A final decision is expected later this year or early next year under the Inflation Reduction Act.

site_title: Bond market starting to believe ECB higher-for-longer pledge
summary: The European Central Bank's (ECB) pledge to keep interest rates higher for longer is gaining traction in the bond market. Traders are selling German 10-year government securities at the fastest pace since February, driving the yield to its highest since 2011. This move reflects the ECB's challenge in balancing inflation control with the risk of triggering a recession. Data due this week is expected to show a steep decline in consumer-price gains, further solidifying the ECB's stance.

images.alt_text: Pricing in derivatives markets indicated that traders see a 62 per cent chance that the ECB will leave interest rates at 3.75 per cent; and a 38 per cent chance of a 25 bp increase.

site_title: Nissan says all new models coming to Europe will be fully electric
summary: Nissan has announced its intention to transition all new models launched in Europe to fully electric vehicles by 2030, aligning with its alliance partner Renault. This goal, which also includes selling only electric vehicles on the continent by 2030, aims to reduce the company's environmental impact. Nissan has already confirmed plans to manufacture an EV model at its Sunderland plant in northern England, and the company plans to electrify 98% of its sales in Europe by 2027. This move brings Nissan in line with other major automakers such as Ford and Stellantis, which also plan to be fully electric in Europe by 2030.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Logo of the Nissan Motor Co. is displayed at the 44th Tokyo Motor Show in Tokyo, Japan, November 2, 2015.   REUTERS/Issei Kato/File Photo
Both Renault and Nissan are under pressure as competition from Tesla and Chinese EV makers intensifies.
Starting in 2025, Nissan will equip its EVs with the Tesla-developed North American Charging Standard (NACS) port, as it targets 40 per cent of US vehicle sales to be fully electric by 2030.
The automakers announced a framework agreement in February and had aimed to finalise the deal as early as March.

site_title: After India’s surprise rice ban, Thailand’s exporters see prices of the food staple stabilising
summary: Thailand's rice exporters see global prices stabilizing after India's surprise ban on non-basmati rice shipments in July, which led to a surge in prices. Pakistan's increased rice supplies in September helped normalize prices, and Thai farmers are now receiving higher prices for their paddy, up to 12,000 baht per tonne. Global rice prices have dropped from a 12-year high of US$646 per tonne to US$612 per tonne, comparable to those in 2008. The Thai Rice Exporters Association expects prices to stabilize, with the country's main rice harvest in November and December showing no signs of damage from dry weather.

images.alt_text: Prices for rice, a staple for half the world, has surged to the highest in almost 15 years after India began curbing exports.
Any nationalists who tried to advocate a wholesale rejection of “foreign” dietary elements would surely be met with both condemnation and ridicule.
Thailand's economy is expected to grow 2.8 per cent this year, but PM Srettha Thavisin has a target of 5 per cent annual growth.
Erratic rains and drought in many parts of the world are hampering crops, reducing supply and driving up costs.

site_title: Screenwriters reach deal with studios to end strike
summary: The Writers Guild of America reached a tentative deal with entertainment companies, ending a 146-day strike that has contributed to a shutdown of television and film production. The deal includes increases in compensation for streaming content, concessions on minimum staffing for television shows, and guarantees that artificial intelligence technology will not encroach on writers' credits and compensation. The deal must be approved by guild members, but it represents a significant step towards stabilizing the industry, which has been upended by the streaming revolution. The strike by actors remains unresolved, with tens of thousands of actors continuing to picket.

images.alt_text: US director Michael Chaves arrives for a special screening of "The Nun II" at the Regal LA Live in Los Angeles, California, on Aug 30, 2023.

site_title: In transition: Singapore’s green-hub goals
summary: Singapore aims to recast itself as a clean-energy hub, leveraging its strategic port and refining capabilities to connect energy producers to consumers in the green transition. The city-state seeks to meet its net-zero by 2050 goals, prioritizing decarbonization of its power sector and promoting low-carbon hydrogen as a key fuel. International collaborations and a robust hydrogen supply chain are also underway, with biofuels and carbon credits potentially drawing global companies to Singapore. Experts emphasize the need for an early mover advantage in green energy technologies to maintain Singapore's long-held position in the energy and chemicals sector.

images.alt_text: Plans are underway to transform Jurong Island - the pulse of Singapore's energy and chemicals sector - into a space that operates sustainably and exports sustainable products globally

site_title: Jokowi’s son named youth party chair
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo's son has been named the chairman of a youth party, a move seen as strengthening the outgoing leader's bid to build a political dynasty ahead of elections next year. This appointment, made on September 25, has raised eyebrows in the country that broke free from authoritarian rule 25 years ago. Widodo's manoeuvres to install his relatives in positions of power have been criticized, sparking concerns about the erosion of democratic values. The president's son's new role is expected to play a significant role in the upcoming elections.

images.alt_text: “Hopefully, this decade can be seen as an acceleration toward Golden Indonesia 2045,” says Indonesian President Joko Widodo.

site_title: EU set to propose rules to allow Germany e-fuels for cars
summary: The European Union is set to propose rules allowing the use of e-fuels in cars, enabling Germany to extend the use of internal combustion engines until 2035. The draft regulations ensure that e-fuels, made from captured carbon dioxide and renewable electricity, emit no new greenhouse gases. Carmakers must ensure vehicles can distinguish between e-fuels and conventional fuel, and vehicles will be subject to conformity checks. The use of conventional biofuels will be prohibited, and the e-fuels are expected to be limited to high-end vehicles due to their high cost.

images.alt_text: German Chancellor Olaf Scholz announces plans for Germany to lead Europe by implementing a law mandating 80 per cent of service stations to offer fast-charging options of at least 150 kilowatts for electric cars.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower on lingering concerns over elevated rates
summary: US stocks fell at the open on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 56.25 points, or 0.17%, at 33,907.59. Concerns over interest rates staying higher for longer kept the 10-year Treasury yield buoyant. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also fell, with the S&P 500 down 9.44 points, or 0.22%, and the Nasdaq down 39.27 points, or 0.30%. Investors await economic data and Federal Reserve policymakers' remarks throughout the week.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's accommodation inflation decreased to 4.4% in August, down from 4.6% in July. Economists expect the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) to maintain its monetary policy settings at the October meeting. Investment banking fees fell 20% year-to-date, while M&A value reached a decade low. Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong will become deputy chairman of GIC on October 1, and Singapore shares rose 0.3% on Monday amid softer inflation data.

site_title: Britain proposes diversity and misconduct rules for financial firms
summary: Britain's financial regulators proposed guidance for financial firms to tackle sexual harassment and bullying, with new requirements for diversity and inclusion.
