Firms must develop a diversity strategy, collect data on staff characteristics, and set targets to improve diversity. The measures aim to boost diversity and inclusion, reduce groupthink, and unlock talent, with the FCA publishing final rules in 2024.

images.alt_text: The British hedge fund has grappled with redemptions since the FT and Tortoise Media on Jun 8 jointly reported allegations by 13 women that Crispin Odey had sexually assaulted or harassed them over a 25-year period.

site_title: Eco-city development in Riau at risk as Indonesia pledges to prioritise community
summary: Indonesia's President Joko Widodo has directed a harmonious resolution to protests on Rempang Island against an eco-city development, prioritizing the rights of the community displaced by the project. The proposed Rempang Eco-City, a joint venture between government and local companies, has been met with resistance from island residents who oppose relocation. The development aims to boost economic growth and create jobs, but the government has agreed to consider alternative solutions, including relocating residents to nearby Galang Island.

images.alt_text: epa10771144 Indonesian President Joko Widodo (C) and First Lady Iriana Widodo (R) arrive in Chengdu, capital of southwest China's Sichuan Province, 27 July 2023. President Widodo arrived in Chengdu to attend the opening ceremony of the 31st summer edition of the FISU World University Games and a visit to China.  EPA-EFE/XINHUA / Jiang Hongjing CHINA OUT / UK AND IRELAND OUT  /       MANDATORY CREDIT  EDITORIAL USE ONLY

site_title: Malaysia boosts China palm oil exports under EU pressure
summary: Malaysia is increasing palm oil exports to China by 500,000 tonnes a year due to EU pressure to combat deforestation. The country aims to export 3.2 million metric tons of palm oil to China in 2023. This move is seen as a way to counter European curbs on the commodity, with Malaysia's Plantation and Commodities Minister Fadillah Yusof stating that the increase will "definitely" help the country counter the EU's restrictions. The deal between Malaysian palm oil firm Sime Darby Oils International and Chinese state-owned Guangxi Beibu Gulf International Port Group will facilitate the increased exports.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A worker loads fresh fruit bunches of oil palm tree into a wheelbarrow during harvest at a palm oil plantation in Kuala Selangor, Selangor, Malaysia April 26, 2022. REUTERS/Hasnoor Hussain/File Photo

site_title: Yen falls to fresh 11-month low against US dollar, focus on intervention risks
summary: The Japanese yen fell 0.17% to a fresh 11-month low of 148.66 against the US dollar, amid concerns over potential intervention by the Bank of Japan. The yen's decline comes after the BOJ maintained ultra-low interest rates and Governor Kazuo Ueda emphasized the need for data-driven decision-making. The US dollar index rose 0.06% to 105.64, while the euro edged 0.1% lower to US$1.0633. Market analysts warn that a yen overshoot could prompt renewed interventions to strengthen the currency.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Japanese yen and U.S. dollar banknotes are seen with a currency exchange rate graph in this illustration picture taken June 16, 2022. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Grab shutters investment products AutoInvest and Earn+
summary: Grab is shutting down its GrabInvest business and its two investment products, AutoInvest and Earn+, due to being commercially unviable. The decision follows an extensive review and customers are instructed to withdraw their monies by October 13. The GrabInvest business only served the Singapore market, with Grab not expanding the products to other regions. The move marks the end of Grab's investment offerings.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher

A GrabFood delivery man walking past the company logo in the new Grab office at Marina One West Tower on May 28, 2018. Ride-hailing app Grab holds a media briefing to share about its plans and direction.

site_title: Japan to compile economic package in October to ease inflation pain
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida plans to compile an economic stimulus package in October to address inflation and promote wage growth. The package will include measures to counter inflation, support sustainable wage and income growth, and encourage domestic investment. Kishida aims to shift Japan's economy away from cost-cutting practices, focusing on growth and wage increases instead. The size and substance of the extra budget remain unclear, and Kishida has not ruled out dissolving parliament to call a snap election.

images.alt_text: Improvements are needed for corporate governance, lowering entry barriers and boosting asset classes as foreign investors show a rising interest in Japan, says Prime Minister Fumio Kishida.

site_title: Slump in UK retail sales eases in September
summary: The UK retail sales slump has eased in September, with a headline balance rebounding to -14 from a two-year low of -44 in August, according to the Confederation of British Industry's survey. Retailers expect a modest improvement in sales in the coming months, with the October sales balance reaching a three-month high of -8. The recent lower-than-expected inflation figures are seen as a positive factor for retailers heading into the autumn and winter trading period. This easing of sales slump is a fresh blow to UK Prime Minister Rishi Starmer.

images.alt_text: The window display at Cardews of Oxford in Oxford, England on Sept. 1, 2023. At Cardews, which boasts that it is the “oldest established supplier of fresh roasted coffees and fine teas in Oxford,” staff members agreed that people were increasingly seeking coffee. (Gabriella Demczuk/The New York Times)

site_title: What you need to know about investigations involving Sevens Atelier, VCPlus
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) are investigating Sevens Atelier and VCPlus for potential offences under the Securities and Futures Act. Sevens Atelier was ordered to provide documents and information related to its former executive chairman and CEO, Richard Koh Chye Heng, and its current CEO, Jeffrey Hong Eng Leong. VCPlus was also ordered to provide information and documents, including its business dealings with Sevens Atelier in 2021 and 2022. The investigations are ongoing, with both companies' executives cooperating with the authorities.

images.alt_text: Hot stock: VCPlus shares jump 14.3% on plans to raise funds via security token offering
VCPlus furthers fintech ambition with S$5 million acquisition
SGX-ST had asked Sevens Atelier for updates on the progress of the probe, among other queries.
SGX RegCo noted that between Apr 29 and Jul 8, a small group of accounts were responsible for over 70 per cent of the buy volume in Seven Atelier shares.

site_title: Picasso masterpiece begins pre-auction tour in Dubai
summary: A Picasso masterpiece, Femme a la montre, began a pre-auction tour in Dubai, marking the first time a painting of this caliber has been exhibited in the UAE in half a century. The 1932 portrait, valued at at least $120 million, is part of a two-day exhibition before traveling to Hong Kong and London. The UAE aims to establish itself as a cultural powerhouse with this high-profile event.

images.alt_text: "The Tilled Field" by Joan Miro. One brand of cadmium yellow paint is likely most responsible for degradation observed in Miro’s work.
Sher-Gil’s 1937 painting The Story Teller sold for the equivalent of US$7.44 million.

site_title: Hong Kong crypto firm hit by US$200 million hack
summary: A Hong Kong-based crypto firm, Mixin, reported a hack resulting in the loss of approximately US$200 million in cryptocurrency. The attack targeted Mixin's cloud service provider's database, with hackers stealing funds worth around this amount. This incident follows a record-breaking year of cryptocurrency thefts, with hackers stealing US$3.8 billion worth of crypto last year, according to blockchain researchers Chainalysis. Mixin has one million users and describes itself as a network for transferring digital assets.

site_title: US SEC collects Wall Street's private messages as WhatsApp probe escalates: sources
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has collected thousands of staff messages from over a dozen major investment companies, including Carlyle, Apollo, and Blackstone, in an escalating probe into Wall Street's use of unapproved messaging apps. The move marks an expansion of the two-year investigation into potential breaches of record-keeping rules, which initially targeted broker dealers and netted over $2 billion in fines. The probe now includes investment advisers, raising scrutiny for the companies and executives involved.

images.alt_text: With the Fed pledged to keep interest rates at current levels for longer and deposits continuing to leave, the risk that bank reserves will deplete is increasing.
The SEC fines Goldman for providing incomplete and inaccurate "blue sheet data".

site_title: Saudi Arabia takes a step closer to achieving nuclear power
summary: Saudi Arabia took a significant step towards advancing its nuclear power program, announcing it will have wider access to international inspectors to account for atomic materials. The move comes after the country implemented broader monitoring guidelines with the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) and rescinded outdated rules that hindered its program. The change will allow Saudi Arabia to access supplies of fissile material, operate its first reactor, and support its first tender for nuclear power plants. This development has raised concerns about proliferation, following comments by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, who warned that Saudi Arabia could enrich its own nuclear materials if Iran develops a nuclear bomb.

images.alt_text: Saudi Arabia is in talks to raise the funds after its budget deficit widened in the second quarter as the government raised spending on social benefits and projects meant to diversify its economy.

site_title: Indonesia may issue regulations on social media e-commerce this week
summary: Indonesia is set to issue regulations on social media e-commerce, targeting sellers using predatory pricing on platforms like TikTok, which threaten offline markets. President Joko Widodo announced the move, citing the need to balance technology's economic potential with existing economies. The regulation, being formulated by the trade ministry, aims to ban mixing social media and social commerce, and is seen as a response to concerns raised by ministers and officials.

images.alt_text: During deliberations with lawmakers, the government and the budget committee approve most of the budget assumptions in the original proposal.

site_title: Inside Vietnam's plans to dent China's rare-earths dominance
summary: Vietnam plans to restart its Dong Pao mine, one of the world's largest rare-earths mines, with a Western-backed project that could rival China's dominance. The project, involving Australia's Blackstone Minerals, aims to develop Vietnam's rare-earths supply chain, including refining ores into metals used in magnets for electric vehicles and smartphones. Vietnam's government plans to launch tenders for multiple blocks of the mine before the end of the year, with the goal of producing 5-15% of China's projected output by the end of the decade.

images.alt_text: Luu Anh Tuan, Chairman of mining company VTRE in his Hanoi office with samples of rare earth oxides in Hanoi, Vietnam September 7, 2023. REUTERS/Francesco Guarascio

site_title: Booking’s 1.6 billion euro Etraveli deal blocked by EU watchdogs
summary: The European Commission has blocked Booking.com's 1.6 billion euro acquisition of Etraveli Group, citing that the deal would strengthen Booking's dominant position and risk higher costs for hotels and consumers. The veto means hotels and travelers will have more options, preserving competitive prices and innovation in the travel industry. Booking Holdings plans to appeal the decision, calling it "wrong on both the facts and law." The EU's decision is rare, with competition officials opting for remedies rather than outright bans.

images.alt_text: Booking.com is headquartered in Amsterdam but it is a subsidiary of Booking Holdings, which is based in the United States.
Amadeus’ new Traveller Behaviour Report found that Singaporean travellers will prioritise human interaction and on-trip experiences in the next 10 years.
Airbnb says more travellers are coming back to cities, its traditional stronghold, with bookings for high-density urban listings up 13 per cent.
Booking reported an adjusted profit of US$11.60 per share in the quarter ended Mar 31, compared to analysts’ estimate of US$10.61 per share.
Booking Holdings booked over 95 million room nights in January 2023.

site_title: Philippines seeks at least US$1 billion from retail bond offer
summary: The Philippine government aims to raise at least $1 billion from an onshore offer of US dollar-denominated retail bonds, with a 5.5-year maturity. The government also plans to issue a sukuk bond worth at least $1 billion, likely in the last quarter of 2023. Investors will receive tax-free coupon payments, making the investment "a good opportunity." The onshore retail bond offer will be the second of its kind in the Philippines, following a $1.6 billion maiden issue in 2021. The offer period is from September 27 to October 6.

images.alt_text: The Philippines is among Asia’s fastest-growing economies, beating growth expectations in the first quarter.

site_title: Chinese tourists get VIP welcome as Thai visa waiver programme begins
summary: Thailand has launched a visa waiver programme for Chinese nationals, aiming to boost its struggling tourism industry. The programme, which runs until February 2024, is expected to draw 2.88 million Chinese visitors, a significant increase from this year's 2.34 million. Chinese tourists will receive a VIP welcome, including performances and meet-and-greets with Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin. The move is seen as a response to China's post-pandemic economic woes, which have led to a decline in Chinese tourists visiting Thailand.

images.alt_text: Thailand, South Korea, Malaysia, Singapore, Australia and the UK are among the most popular overseas destinations.
While domestic tourism in China has rebounded above pre-Covid levels, international travel is still well below.

site_title: Singapore prime office rents weaken in Q3, outlook mixed
summary: Singapore's Grade A office rents in the central business district (CBD) fell 0.3% quarter-over-quarter in Q3, marking the first decline in nine straight quarters. The decline was attributed to economic uncertainty and a softening in demand for office space. Average rents for CBD Grade A space dropped to S$11.29 per square foot (psf) per month, with over 15 assets commanding lower rents in Q3 compared to Q2. Despite this, leasing activity in the core CBD picked up, with net absorption reaching 0.11 million sq ft in Q3, according to CBRE.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
Pixgeneric-Second day of the "circuit-breaker”

site_title: Qantas drops on new CEO’s A$80 million fix to Joyce’s legacy
summary: Qantas' new CEO Vanessa Hudson has introduced an A$80 million plan to address customer issues that plagued the airline under her predecessor Alan Joyce. The plan includes increased spending on on-board catering, call-centre staffing, and loyalty-point flight redemptions, following a surge in flight cancellations, lost bags, and telephone wait-times since pandemic travel restrictions eased last year. The move aims to restore the airline's battered reputation and address customer concerns that Joyce's focus on profits came at the expense of customer satisfaction.

images.alt_text: Alan Joyce, chief executive officer of Qantas Airways Ltd., speaks during a news conference in Sydney, Australia, on Thursday, Aug. 24, 2023. Qantas ordered dozens more long-range Boeing Co. and Airbus SE jets in a bid to keep pace with a post-pandemic travel boom that's delivering record profits. Photographer: Lisa Maree Williams/Bloomberg

site_title: Indians have five days to deposit 240 billion rupees in soon-to-be-withdrawn banknotes
summary: The Reserve Bank of India has ordered the withdrawal of the 2,000-rupee note by September 30, giving people five days to deposit or exchange the notes worth approximately 240 billion rupees (S$2.9 billion). The note, introduced in 2016 to remonetise the economy, has become a storage of value and is no longer commonly used. The move is part of the RBI's "clean note policy" to replace soiled notes within four to five years.

site_title: Dive into the iridescent art of Zhuang Hong Yi
summary: Chinese-Dutch artist Zhuang Hong Yi's solo exhibition "Iridescence" is now on display at REDSEA Gallery in Singapore, featuring 25 artworks that blend Eastern and Western influences. The exhibition showcases Zhuang's unique three-dimensional paintings made from hundreds of folded rice paper flowers, which change colors depending on the angle of view. Born in 1962, Zhuang drew inspiration from his childhood experiences in China and later studied art in the Netherlands, where he developed his distinctive style. The exhibition is a testament to Zhuang's global recognition and artistic legacy.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Hiroshi Senju's Waterfall On Colors will be displayed at Sundaram Tagore, one of the six galleries that BT readers can to visit on the exclusive Canvas & Cabernet art and wine crawl.
ArtScience Museum's latest show "Notes From The Ether.: From NFTs To AI" tracks the rapid development of digital art in recent years.

site_title: DHL and Sasol join hydrogen firm HH2E on sustainable jet fuel project
summary: German logistics giant DHL, energy firm HH2E, and South African petrochemicals firm Sasol have signed an agreement to set up a joint initiative to produce sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) in eastern Germany, aiming for 200,000 tonnes per year by 2030. The goal is to meet EU climate targets and was announced at the National Aviation Conference in Hamburg, where German Chancellor Olaf Scholz emphasized the importance of expanding SAF production. Aircraft manufacturer Airbus is also set to join the consortium, with the companies planning to specify technical and financial planning by 2025.

images.alt_text: LOGISTICS giant DHL will charge private customers more for parcel deliveries from Jul 1 as labour and transport costs have made price increases unavoidable, said the company on Monday (Jun 13).
LOGISTICS player DHL Express Singapore is on its way to more sustainable delivery as it is adding 80 electric vans to its fleet of 10 electric vehicles.

site_title: Aviva to buy AIG's UK life insurance business for £460 million
summary: Aviva has agreed to buy AIG's UK life insurance business, AIG Life UK, for £460 million, its largest acquisition to date. The deal will add 1.3 million individual protection customers and 1.4 million group protection members to Aviva's portfolio. The transaction is expected to close in the first half of 2024, subject to regulatory approvals. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move to strengthen Aviva's position in the UK market and support "capital-light growth".

images.alt_text: Logo for Aviva plc, a British insurer.

site_title: Huawei disappoints viewers by not discussing Mate 60 phones at product launch
summary: Huawei failed to discuss its Mate 60 smartphone series at a product launch event, despite millions of viewers tuning in. The event showcased new products, including a gold smartwatch and a smart car, but the lack of Mate 60 details sparked widespread criticism online. CEO Richard Yu mentioned the Mate 60 Pro in his opening remarks, but did not elaborate on its capabilities. The event's timing was seen as symbolic, marking the two-year anniversary of Huawei's rotating chairwoman Meng Wanzhou's return to China.

images.alt_text: Huawei has in recent weeks unveiled new smartphones that use advanced chips, which analysts say are domestically made.
Huawei currently accounts for 59 per cent of Germany’s 5G RAN networks, according to a survey by  telecommunications consultancy Strand Consult.
“We don’t have any evidence that they can manufacture seven-nanometre (chips) at scale,” US Secretary of Commerce Gina Raimondo says at a US House hearing.
Huawei may launch a 5G version of its mid-ranged Nova around October or November, says the IT Times.
Huawei’s latest phones have ignited celebration in China and consternation in the US, thanks to their advanced made-in-China processor.

site_title: Berlin takes closer look at sale of MAN gas turbine division to China
summary: Germany's economy ministry is reviewing the sale of MAN Energy Solutions' gas turbine division to a Chinese company, CSIC Longjiang GH Gas Turbine Co. The sale has raised concerns about national security, and if the ministry concludes that it poses a threat, the federal government could still ban the sale. The review is an in-depth examination of the potential impact on Germany's national security, with no timeline provided for the outcome.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTOl The skyline of the banking district is pictured in Frankfurt, October 21, 2014. REUTERS/Ralph Orlowski

site_title: Yen sinks to 10-month low after BOJ stresses need to keep easy policy
summary: The yen has reached a 10-month low of 148.58 against the US dollar, following the Bank of Japan's (BOJ) statement that it needs to maintain stimulative policies due to economic uncertainties. BOJ Governor Kazuo Ueda and Deputy Governor Shinichi Uchida emphasized that the economic recovery and price trends are too precarious for a near-term rate hike, citing high uncertainties around wage gains and inflation. The comments appeared to be an extension of the BOJ's efforts to walk back policy change expectations, supporting the yen's decline.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Japanese 10,000 yen notes line up in Tokyo, in this February 28, 2013 picture illustration.  REUTERS/Shohei Miyano/File Photo/File Photo
The yen drops as low as 148.42 to the US dollar, nearing the 150-mark at which analysts have said government intervention to prop up the currency is likely.
Kazuo Ueda. Photographer: Akio Kon/Bloomberg

site_title: Acquisitions in alternative asset capabilities pay off for Franklin Templeton
summary: Franklin Templeton's acquisition strategy has paid off, with its alternative assets under management (AUM) growing from $15 billion in 2018 to $260 billion by the end of 2022. The firm has acquired several companies, including Putnam Investments and Legg Mason, to expand its capabilities and fill product gaps. Net inflows into alternatives reached $4 billion in the third quarter, while net outflows occurred in equity and fixed income. CEO Jennifer Johnson believes the trend towards private markets is not reversing, driven by companies choosing to stay private longer and pressure to report quarterly earnings.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua
If approved, Franklin plans to use Coinbase Global as custodian for the fund’s Bitcoin holdings and Bank of New York Mellon for cash.

site_title: Singapore shares rise on Monday amid softer inflation data; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.3% on Monday, driven by softer inflation data, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing at 3,215.4. Headline inflation slipped to 4% and core inflation to 3.4%, prompting speculation that the Monetary Authority of Singapore may extend its pause on monetary policy tightening. The top gainer was Thai Beverage, while Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust was the biggest loser. Regional markets were mixed, with the Nikkei 225 up 0.9% and the Hang Seng Index down 1.8%.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Singapore shares open lower on Monday; STI down 0.2%
Frasers Centrepoint Trust, which owns Nex mall in Singapore, is divesting most of its stake in Malaysia's Hektar Reit.

site_title: China bans Nomura senior investment banker from leaving mainland: sources
summary: China has banned Charles Wang Zhonghe, a senior Nomura Holdings investment banker, from leaving the mainland due to his involvement in the investigation into top tech dealmaker Bao Fan and his former colleague Cong Lin. The ban is part of growing concerns among Western businesses about China's slowing economy and tougher operating conditions. Wang, who oversees Nomura's investment banking operations in China, must stay on the mainland to assist with the investigation. The move is the latest in a series of exit bans imposed on foreign business professionals in China.

images.alt_text: A man reacts on a street, amid a hot day in Shanghai, China July 31, 2023. REUTERS/Aly Song
The bank aims to boost assets under its international wealth management business to US$35 billion from US$15 billion by March 2025.

site_title: How Asia-Pacific data centres can become more sustainable
summary: Data centres in the Asia-Pacific region have significant growth prospects, driven by rapid population growth and young populations. However, the sector faces sustainability challenges, with data centres consuming 3-4% of global greenhouse gas emissions and large amounts of energy and water. To address this, DC operators are making commitments to sustainability, such as the EU Climate Neutral Data Centre Pact, and implementing measures like energy-efficient cooling systems and renewable energy sources. Active investing in the sector is expected to push sustainability standards higher, making DCs a key part of the transition to a low-carbon economy.

images.alt_text: AIMS Apac Reit was among the best performing S-Reits in the year-to-date.

site_title: Japan PM Kishida to reform asset management to lure foreign investors
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida announced plans to reform asset management to attract foreign investors, aiming to shift households from savings to assets. Improvements in corporate governance, lowering entry barriers, and boosting asset classes are needed. This move comes as foreign investors show rising interest in Japan, despite the country ranking 21st in global financial hubs, down from 16th last year. The government aims to promote Japan as a key international financial center through a promotional campaign. Funds under management in Japan have grown by 50% over the past three years to approximately $7.4 trillion.

site_title: Asian: Markets struggle as traders prepare for higher rates
summary: Asian stock markets struggled on Monday, with Hong Kong and Shanghai falling more than one percent, while Sydney, Seoul, Wellington, Singapore, and Jakarta also declined. Investors are anticipating potential interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve, which could keep borrowing costs at three-decade highs. Traders are waiting for comments from policymakers to gauge their intentions, as speculation grows that rates will be lifted again before the end of the year.

images.alt_text: Singapore shares open lower on Monday; STI down 0.2%

site_title: Risks rising for US consumer stocks: Morgan Stanley analyst
summary: US consumer stocks, which have gained 26% this year, are facing a downturn as risks build, according to Morgan Stanley analyst Michael Wilson. The sector's outperformance has slowed, with stocks tumbling 6% last week and 44% trading below their 200-day moving average. Wilson cites slowing consumer spend, rising delinquencies, and higher gas prices as contributing factors. Goldman Sachs analysis also predicts the sector will underperform the S&P 500 by 7 percentage points over the next 12 months, and Jefferies analysts have downgraded several retailers.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Tesla's Model 3 is displayed during an event a day ahead of the official opening of the 2023 Munich Auto Show IAA Mobility, in Munich, Germany, September 4, 2023. REUTERS/Angelika Warmuth/File Photo

site_title: Singapore investment banking fees down 20% year to date, M&A value falls to decade low
summary: Singapore investment banking fees have declined by 20% year-to-date, totaling US$585.2 million in the first three quarters of 2023. This represents a 70% drop from the same period in 2022. DBS bank earned the most fees, taking in US$73.6 million, while M&A values have fallen to a decade low, reaching US$10.2 billion.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
The exit of bankers at places like Credit Suisse and Barclays and cuts at Goldman and Morgan Stanley mean hiring opportunities for others.
A forrmer Deutsche Bank investment banker pleaded guilty to fraud on Tuesday.

site_title: Evergrande liquidation risk rises after creditor meeting scrapped
summary: Evergrande Group's restructuring plan is at risk of collapse after scrapping key creditor meetings and failing to meet regulator requirements to issue new bonds. The company's offshore debt restructuring, worth at least $30 billion, is now uncertain, with creditors facing a potential "downward revision" in terms and longer repayment periods. Evergrande faces a Hong Kong court hearing on October 30, which could lead to liquidation. The company's shares plummeted 25% on Monday, and China's property crisis deepens, with other developers facing similar winding-up lawsuits and a gauge of Chinese property stocks tumbling for the first time in nine months.

images.alt_text: Shares of Evergrande, which has more than US$300 billion in liabilities, fell as much as 23.6 per cent to HK$0.42, in a broader market down 0.6 per cent.

site_title: SP Group wins tender for first district cooling project in Thailand
summary: SP Group, in a joint venture with Banpu Next, has won a tender to design, build, own, and operate the first district cooling project in Thailand, at Government Complex Centre Zone C in Bangkok. The project will save about S$1.6 million in electricity costs yearly and achieve 20% energy savings, reducing emissions by up to 3,000 tonnes annually. The system will operate 14,000 refrigeration tonnes and provide chilled water to the complex's 660,000 square meters, with plans to explore additional sustainable solutions, including EV buses and solar power systems.

images.alt_text: SP Group, Banpu Next in clean energy solutions tie-up; eyes Asia-Pacific region
Keppel sky sign taken at Ocean Financial Centre.

site_title: China hosts biggest e-sports moment with Tencent at the wheel
summary: China is hosting the 19th Asian Games, featuring competitive video games as a medal event for the first time. The event, organized by Tencent, aims to boost national pride and showcase China's e-sports industry. The tournament will feature seven multiplayer titles, including games developed or published by Tencent, and is expected to attract hundreds of elite gamers from around the world. The event is seen as a key part of China's post-Covid comeback strategy, with e-sports expected to generate significant revenue through sponsorships, merchandise sales, and broadcasting rights.

images.alt_text: The Games will be staged at 54 venues – 14 newly constructed – mostly in Hangzhou but also extending to cities as far afield as Wenzhou, 300 kilometres south.

site_title: Hong Kong mortgage rule easing seen doing little to lift market
summary: Hong Kong's relaxed mortgage rules for first-time homebuyers of new properties under construction are unlikely to boost the property market, analysts say. The new rules allow buyers to put down smaller deposits, but a potential increase in mortgage rates before year-end may limit the impact. Citigroup analyst Ken Yeung expects a "negligible" effect on demand, while Bloomberg Intelligence notes that the move may encourage more buyers to acquire new apartments, potentially decreasing secondary home prices. The move is the latest effort by Hong Kong authorities to support the housing market, which has slumped due to high borrowing costs.

images.alt_text: Buyers currently must go through a stress test that ensures their income can afford future rate rises if they take on mortgages.
Some residents of Redhill Peninsula in Hong Kong’s Tai Tam district have been evacuated after record rains caused a landslide and brought to light the possibility of illegal structures.

site_title: Brokers’ take: OCBC starts coverage on Boustead Singapore with ‘buy’ call
summary: OCBC Investment Research initiated coverage on Boustead Singapore with a "buy" call, citing undemanding valuations, above-average yield, and exposure to secular megatrends such as the "silver tsunami" in Asia Pacific. Analyst Ada Lim notes the company's healthy balance sheet, strong net cash position, and potential for cash deployment through investments and acquisitions. The research house values Boustead Singapore at a fair value of S$1.05, representing a 40% discount to net asset value.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
The entrance of Boustead Singapore’s office.

As part of the contract, wholly-owned subsidiary Boustead International Heaters will design, engineer and supply the generators for a floating production, storage and offloading vessel, to be deployed in Latin America.
Boustead Projects is alleged to have breached a contract and preventing its subcontractor from carrying out works according to the original contract schedule.
Revenue for the second half rose 8 per cent on year to S$314.8 million, largely due to higher contribution from the energy engineering dividsion and an improving outlook for the energy sector.

SGX Regco told Boustead Projects that it must restore its free float after its shares are suspended at the close of the takeover offer. Otherwise, Boustead Projects would be directed to delist and provide an exit offer which is deemed fair and reasonable.

site_title: Property firm China Oceanwide gets liquidation order in Bermuda
summary: A Bermuda court has issued a winding-up order against China Oceanwide Holdings, a Chinese property developer struggling with debt issues in the US. The order was filed in June 2022, citing $175 million of unpaid loan principal, and liquidators have been appointed. This is the latest court-ordered liquidation of a Chinese developer amid the country's property debt crisis, following similar efforts against at least two other firms in Hong Kong.

site_title: Apple’s cheapest iPhone surges in popularity after upgrades
summary: Apple's cheapest iPhone model, the iPhone 15, has seen a surge in popularity due to significant upgrades, resulting in quadrupled waiting times for deliveries in China, its largest overseas market. The iPhone 15 Pro Max also experienced record pre-order waiting times, with the ultra-premium model being the most coveted in China. Analysts attribute the increased demand to the upgrades, which may have come at the cost of other iPhone options, such as the 15 Plus and 15 Pro.

site_title: Germany’s housing sector slumps into crisis
summary: Germany's housing sector is in crisis, with one in five property companies cancelling building projects in August and 11.9% facing financing difficulties, according to a recent survey. The sector is struggling due to a sharp rise in interest rates and raw material costs, forcing developers to halt construction and leaving buyers with financial losses. Chancellor Olaf Scholz has called for talks with the property sector to jump-start construction, while the government has announced plans to offer aid to help families get on the property ladder. Experts warn that the sector will struggle to meet demand, pushing up rents and further eroding households' purchasing power.

images.alt_text: Residential property prices fall by 9.9 per cent year on year, the steepest decline since the start of data collection in 2000, the federal statistics office said.
The Germany statistics office attributes the decline in demand to high building costs and difficulties in getting financing, factors that have deepened stress across the broader sector.

site_title: How a storied national airline became reviled in its own country
summary: Qantas Airways, Australia's national carrier, has alienated its most important constituency: Australians. Despite emerging from the pandemic stronger and more profitable, Qantas has faced criticism over unreliable flights, high prices, and allegations of unfair labor practices. The airline has apologized for selling tickets for cancelled flights and laid off hundreds of workers, while handing out large paychecks to its CEO and board of directors. Labor unions and lawmakers are calling for the board to resign, with some calling for the company to be held accountable for its actions.

images.alt_text: Qantas Airways and Singapore Airlines aeroplanes viewed from the viewing gallery of Changi Airport Terminal One on December 26, 2017.
Qantas Airways expects a further A$50 million impact due to non-fuel-related foreign exchange changes in the first half of the current fiscal year.
Qantas is facing a regulatory lawsuit accusing it of breaching consumer law by selling fares for 8,000 flights that were cancelled in mid-2022.

Alan Joyce, chief executive officer of Qantas Airways Ltd., speaks during a news conference in Sydney, Australia, on Thursday, Aug. 24, 2023. Qantas ordered dozens more long-range Boeing Co. and Airbus SE jets in a bid to keep pace with a post-pandemic travel boom that's delivering record profits. Photographer: Lisa Maree Williams/Bloomberg
Qantas is seeking an extension for the alliance with China Eastern, which allows the two companies to coordinate passenger and cargo movement between Australia and China.
Qantas Airways now faces penalties and compensation payments to affected workers fired during the Covid-19 pandemic.
FILE PHOTO: Qantas aircraft are seen on the tarmac at Melbourne International Airport in Melbourne, Australia, November 6, 2018. REUTERS/Phil Noble/File Photo
Plagued by a series of controversies, Qantas Airways CEO Alan Joyce has brought forward his retirement by two months.

FILE PHOTO: A Virgin Australia Airlines plane is seen at Kingsford Smith International Airport the morning after Australia implemented an entry ban on non-citizens and non-residents intended to curb the spread of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) in Sydney, Australia, March 21, 2020.  REUTERS/Loren Elliott/File Photo
The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission alleged that Qantas kept selling tickets for an average of 16 days after it had cancelled flights for reasons often within its control.

site_title: SoftBank to raise over 120 billion yen via bond-type shares
summary: SoftBank plans to raise up to 120 billion yen (S$1.1 billion) via Japan's first public offering of bond-type class shares, with a dividend rate of 2-4% for the first five years. The funds will be used for growth investments in telecommunications and information technologies. The shares will be listed on the Tokyo Stock Exchange and are expected to attract retail buyers due to SoftBank's strong name recognition and tax exemptions.

images.alt_text: Arm Holdings, which had opened at US$56.10, notched a 24.68 per cent gain to close at US$63.59, giving the British chip designer a valuation of US$65 billion.
Arm is still considering raising the price range of its initial public offering as well.

Masayoshi Son's once-exalted reputation as an investor is badly tarnished, but the irrepressible founder of Japan's SoftBank is hoping that the mega-IPO of Arm this week might bring back the good times.

site_title: China developer slump deepens to US$55 billion as debt woes mount
summary: China's property developer slump worsened to US$55 billion in valuation losses this year, with stocks tumbling 6.4% as concerns over a possible Evergrande Group liquidation added to industry stress. Evergrande's shares fell 25%, while China Aoyuan Group slumped by a record 76%. The sector's woes worsened despite policy support, with investors bracing for years of pain and a potential default by Country Garden Holdings. The industry's debt woes continue to mount, with China Oceanwide Holdings facing liquidation and Ping An Real Estate's high-yield bond index declining for the first time this month.

images.alt_text: Buyers currently must go through a test that ensures their income is enough to afford future rate increases if they take on mortgages.
At least three Chinese developers have been ordered wound up by courts in Hong Kong amid the country’s property debt crisis.

site_title: The great sovereign debt conundrum
summary: Kenyan President William Ruto proposed a 10-year "grace period" on interest payments for African countries at the inaugural Africa Climate Summit, addressing the issue of sovereign debt. International capital flows, primarily in the form of debt, have driven development success but can be a double-edged sword if debts accumulate and debt-servicing burdens increase without corresponding repayment capacity. This can lead to severe consequences, as seen during the Covid-19 pandemic. The proposal aims to alleviate the debt burden and improve the well-being of borrower countries.

images.alt_text: Kenya's President William Ruto addresses delegates at the close of the Africa Climate Summit (ACS) 2023 at the Kenyatta International Convention Centre (KICC) in Nairobi, Kenya, September 6, 2023. REUTERS/Monicah Mwangi
An IMF spokesperson says that a domestic debt rework “is among the several issues identified as challenges to debt restructuring.”

Joko Widodo, Indonesia's president, at Tegalluar station ahead of an interview in front of Jakarta-Bandung High-Speed Railway trains in West Java, Indonesia, on Tuesday, Sept. 19, 2023. Indonesia’s outgoing president said Southeast Asia’s largest economy can attain its fastest expansion in three decades under the next leader, who will build on the reforms he’s trying to cement. Photographer: Rosa Panggabean/Bloomberg

site_title: CapitaLand Ascott Trust completes sale of four French properties for 44.4 million euros
summary: CapitaLand Ascott Trust sold four French properties for 44.4 million euros, exceeding the book value by 63% and yielding 4% based on FY2022 earnings. The sale generated 34.1 million euros in net proceeds. This move is part of the company's portfolio reconstitution strategy.

images.alt_text: Mia Pei
Serena Teo, chief executive officer of CapitaLand Ascott Trust's managers

Guest of honour and Minister of Health Ong Ye Kung noted that CEOs and boards of today have more things to worry about, amid an increasing emphasis on the “less tangible but crucial aspects”, such as environmental, social and governance (ESG) related considerations.

Clas intends to acquire The Cavendish London, a hotel, from its sponsor. The stapled group will allocate about S$170.2 million in gross proceeds from its fundraising exercise to finance the acquisition.

site_title: Foreigners set for bigger play in US$1 trillion India bond market
summary: India's $1 trillion government bond market is set for a significant influx of foreign investment after being included in JPMorgan Chase's emerging markets index. This milestone event is expected to prompt billions of dollars in foreign inflows, with Goldman Sachs predicting over $40 billion in purchases over the next 18 months. The inclusion is seen as a boost to India's aspirations for a bigger global presence, but also increases scrutiny from foreign investors, potentially leading to greater market volatility.

images.alt_text: Prices for rice, a staple for half the world, has surged to the highest in almost 15 years after India began curbing exports.

Nirmala Sitharaman, India's finance minister, speaks during a news conference in New Delhi, India, on Wednesday, Feb. 1, 2023. Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s government unveiled a pre-election India budget that cut personal income taxes to boost consumption while ramping up infrastructure spending to spur growth in an economy touted as a “bright star” amid a gloomy global outlook. Photographer: Prakash Singh/Bloomberg

site_title: Champagne days for Singapore hotels, but climate change poses a big risk
summary: Singapore's hotels are experiencing a surge in demand, with average room rates and revenue per available room rising 12.8% and 28.3% year-over-year, respectively, in July. The city-state's strong performance is attributed to its popularity as a premier destination for hosting major events, international visitor arrivals exceeding 9 million for the first eight months, and efforts to upgrade tourism offerings. However, climate change poses a significant risk, with potential swingeing taxes on global aviation that could reduce leisure travel and push businesses to conduct virtual interactions, impacting the industry's long-term prospects.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
In August, China retained its spot as the top source of visitors to Singapore, followed by Indonesia, Malaysia, India and Australia.
More than 264,000 fans attended the three-day Singapore Grand Prix this year, which was won by Ferrari's Carlos Sainz.

site_title: Lawrence Wong to become deputy chairman of GIC from Oct 1
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong will assume the post of deputy chairman of the Government Investment Corporation (GIC) on October 1. He will assist the current chairman, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, in overseeing GIC's long-term asset allocation and portfolio performance. Wong has also served as chairman of GIC's Investment Strategies Committee since July 7.

images.alt_text: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong said the wealthy in Singapore are expected to “do their part, pay their dues and give back to society”.
China makes up 22 per cent of the portfolio of Temasek, which is ranked among the top 10 investors in the world with net portfolio value of S$382 billion.
FILE PHOTO: A signage of Singapore’s sovereign wealth fund GIC is pictured at their office in Singapore July 13, 2023. REUTERS/Edgar Su/File Photo

site_title: Economists expect MAS to maintain monetary policy settings amid easing headline and core inflation
summary: Economists expect the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) to maintain its monetary policy settings at the October meeting, citing a cooling inflation trend for the fourth consecutive month. Headline CPI slipped to 4% yoy, while core inflation dropped to 3.4% yoy, offsetting private transport inflation's increase. Analysts note that while inflation remains high, the easing trend suggests MAS may reduce the Singapore dollar's nominal effective exchange rate slightly, but most expect policy to remain unchanged.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Food inflation rises/slips to x per cent on the year in July, against x per cent in June.
Contractions of manufactured export growth hurt major exporting economies in South-east Asia.

site_title: Australia considers new, broader definition of full employment
summary: Australia is considering a broader definition of full employment to address labor market data gaps and achieve inclusive full employment, where everyone who wants a job can find one without searching for too long. The government aims to tackle underutilization and promote sustainable employment, with 31 future reform directions guiding policymaking. This comes after an independent review recommended the Reserve Bank of Australia consider price stability and full employment in its decision-making. The government plans to enhance labor market data and analytics to support its agenda, with nine immediate steps to be taken, including accelerating apprenticeships and backing social enterprises.

images.alt_text: The RBA has described Australia’s labour market as tight with the unemployment rate hovering in a 3.4 per cent to 3.7 per cent range since June last year despite the rate hikes.
The RBA estimates the jobless rate, which is tracking at 3.7 per cent, would need to rise to around 4.5 per cent to help return inflation to its target band of 2 per cent to 3 per cent.

site_title: Landlord SBB gets 8 billion Swedish kronor cash boost in Brookfield deal
summary: SBB, a Swedish landlord, has agreed to sell a 1.16% stake in its education division to Brookfield Asset Management, making the Canadian investor the majority shareholder. The deal, worth 8 billion Swedish kronor, will provide SBB with a cash injection to repay a 14 billion kronor inter-company loan. The transaction is part of a larger reorganisation to split SBB into three business units, with the education division operating on a standalone basis.

images.alt_text: The building housing the headquarters of Samhallsbyggnadsbolaget i Norden AB (SBB) in Stockholm, Sweden, on Friday, May 19, 2023. Last week saw the board of SBB appoint Leiv Synnes, 52, to the helm of the Stockholm-based company. Photographer: Jonas Ekblom/Bloomberg
The SBB headquarters in Stockholm. Photographer: Jonas Ekblom/Bloomberg

site_title: Evergrande shares sink after saying it is unable to issue new debt
summary: Evergrande shares plummeted 23.6% to HK$0.42 after the embattled developer stated it was unable to issue new debt due to an ongoing investigation into one of its subsidiaries. The company, with over $300 billion in liabilities, is struggling with restructuring plans and faces pressure from China's securities regulator. This development raises concerns about the company's ability to meet its obligations and further weakens its already fragile financial situation.

images.alt_text: With more than US$300 billion in total liabilities, including offshore debt, Evergrande has been at the centre of a property debt crisis.
China’s property sector, once the pillar of the economy, has slumped since 2021 when real estate giant China Evergrande Group defaulted on its debt obligations following a clampdown on new borrowing.
With more than US$300 billion in total liabilities, including offshore debt, Evergrande has been at the centre of a property debt crisis.
Hui Ka Yan, the billionaire founder of China Evergrande Group, could wind up keeping almost 42 per cent of his shares in the world’s most indebted developer, according to a restructuring proposal.

The outlook change on real estate firms reflects uncertainties over their ability to achieve stable operating performance and credit metrics to support its ratings over the next 12-18 months, Moody’s says.

FILE PHOTO: A logo of Chinese developer Country Garden is pictured in Tianjin, China August 18, 2023. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo

site_title: Thailand’s central bank to hold rates in Sept after seven straight hikes: poll
summary: Thailand's central bank, the Bank of Thailand, is expected to hold its key policy rate at 2.25% in September, marking the end of a year-long tightening cycle, according to a Reuters poll. Despite slight inflation in August, it remained below the central bank's 1-3% target range for a fourth consecutive month. Economists predict the Bank of Thailand will keep rates unchanged through 2024, with only a few expecting one final hike.

images.alt_text: The Thai baht has fallen 2.8 per cent in September to be the worst-performing currency in Asia, while the nation’s sovereign bonds have also underperformed.

Thai farmers, however, are happier these days because they are now receiving 12,000 baht (S$456) per tonne of paddy (or unhusked) rice that they sell on the market, compared to the usual price of 9,000 baht.
Thai PM Stretta says that Tesla is looking into an electric vehicle manufacturing facility while Microsoft and Google are looking at data centres.

site_title: Amazon steps up AI race with up to US$4 billion deal to invest in Anthropic
summary: Amazon is investing up to $4 billion in Anthropic, a high-profile AI startup, to compete with cloud rivals. Amazon's employees and cloud customers will gain early access to Anthropic's technology, which they can infuse into their businesses. The deal also sees Anthropic committing to rely primarily on Amazon's cloud services. The immediate investment is $1.25 billion, with the option for further funding of $2.75 billion. The partnership aims to accelerate Amazon's efforts in artificial intelligence.

images.alt_text: Amazon director of smart home Charlie French speaks during the Amazon Devices and Services event at the HQ2 campus in Arlington, Virginia on Sept 20, 2023. Amazon previewed a push into generative artificial intelligence with new features for its Alexa voice assistant.

site_title: FedEx customers can drop off parcels at SingPost PopStops in trial
summary: SingPost has signed a memorandum of understanding with FedEx Express to allow FedEx customers to drop off parcels at SingPost post offices at no additional charge through PopStop counters. The three-month trial will start on September 25, with parcels being handed over to FedEx daily. This partnership aims to increase parcel delivery options for FedEx customers in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
SingPost says its latest rate increment reflects the escalating costs of maintaining the postal service.
SingPost Centre at 10 Eunos Road 8 near Paya Lebar MRT station on Nov 03, 2020. Can be used for stories on mail, postage, post, postman, courier, parcel, envelope, stamp and delivery.
About 86 per cent of SingPost’s revenue is now generated internationally.

site_title: Qantas flags hit from higher fuel prices
summary: Qantas Airways expects a $200 million increase in fuel costs due to higher fuel prices, with a further $50 million impact from foreign exchange changes. The airline will invest $80 million to address customer pain points, including improving call centre services and increasing frequent flyer seats. This comes after the company faced reputational damage from selling tickets on cancelled flights. Qantas reported an annual underlying profit before tax of $2.47 billion for the fiscal year ended June 30.

site_title: Secret ‘James Bond’ tunnels may become a tourist attraction
summary: Australian-born Angus Murray has bought the secret "James Bond" tunnels beneath central London for £220 million, planning to turn them into a tourist attraction "as iconic as the London Eye". The tunnels, built in 1941-1942, were used as deep shelters during the London Blitz and later by the Special Operations Executive, an espionage organization that inspired the creation of James Bond. Murray plans to create immersive experiences with giant screens, partnering with Hollywood studios and manufacturers, and aims to attract 2 million visitors annually, generating £60 million in revenue.

images.alt_text: Thailand, South Korea, Malaysia, Singapore, Australia and the UK are among the most popular overseas destinations.
Hotels near the downtown race circuit generally expect their F1 takings to exceed pre-Covid levels, and possibly those of 2022.

site_title: UK state bank swings to £135 million loss on sliding tech prices
summary: The British Business Bank (BBB) reported a loss of £135 million in the year till March, down from a £453 million profit in the prior year, due to a decline in startup valuations. The bank had to unwind unrealised gains on its equity portfolio, reflecting a broader downturn. CEO Louis Taylor attributed the loss to a return to "reality" after a significant gain in the previous year. The BBB has backed over 90,000 businesses since its founding in 2014 and currently has stakes in 1,200 companies.

images.alt_text: ivdrop - Commuters make their way over London Bridge towards the City of London, U.K., on Thursday, Sept. 30, 2021. site_title: Gold flat as markets assess US Fed’s interest rate outlook
summary: Gold prices remained steady at $1,924.54 per ounce, unchanged from the previous week, as investors assessed US Federal Reserve officials' warning of further interest rate hikes ahead of a consumer inflation gauge due later this week. US dollar hovered near a six-month high, while benchmark 10-year Treasury yields neared their 16-year peak. The Fed's preferred inflation gauge, the personal consumption expenditures (PCE) price index, is set to be released on September 29.

images.alt_text: The unravelling of the relationship between gold and real interest rates could be a paradigm shift for the precious metal, leaving investors struggling to calculate its “fair value” in a world where the old equations don’t seem to apply.

site_title: Capcom sees game sales in India passing those in China in decade
summary: Capcom, a video game studio, aims to sell over 100 million copies of games annually, with a significant portion coming from games released in past fiscal years. The company's chief operating officer, Haruhiro Tsujimoto, predicts that Capcom will sell more copies of games in India than in China within a decade, citing the rapidly growing Indian gaming market and its large population. Tsujimoto attributes India's exponential growth to the increasing number of college students who enjoy games and the developing economy.

images.alt_text: The Capcom Co. booth at the Tokyo Game Show in Chiba, Japan, on Thursday, Sept. 21, 2023. The show runs through to Sept. 24. Photographer: Kiyoshi Ota/Bloomberg

site_title: EU businesses ‘questioning their position’ in China: trade commissioner
summary: European Union businesses are questioning their positions in China due to the country's new security laws and politicization of trade. EU Trade Commissioner Valdis Dombrovskis warned that companies struggle to understand compliance obligations, decreasing business confidence and deterring new investments. The EU is not seeking economic decoupling from China, but must protect itself, Dombrovskis said during a speech in Beijing. This comes as business confidence reaches a low point, with a recent report by the European Chamber of Commerce showing the lowest levels in decades.

images.alt_text: European Commission Executive Vice President Valdis Dombrovskis speaks at the Bund Summit in Shanghai, China September 23, 2023. REUTERS/Jason Xue
Huawei currently accounts for 59 per cent of Germany’s 5G RAN networks, according to a survey by  telecommunications consultancy Strand Consult.
Zeekr started European sales of two models just weeks ago and plans to add another seven by 2025.

Valdis Dombrovskis, who is also the bloc’s trade commissioner, is on a four-day visit to China seeking more balanced economic ties with the EU.

site_title: How are CPF interest rates determined, and how have they trended?
summary: The Central Provident Fund (CPF) interest rates are determined by the government, with Ordinary Account rates pegged at the higher of the three-month average of major local banks' deposit rates or a legislated minimum rate of 2.5% per annum. The Special, MediSave, and Retirement accounts earn the 12-month average yield of 10-year Singapore Government Securities plus 1%, or the 4% interest floor, whichever is higher. The interest rates have trended downward since the 1980s, with the Special and MediSave accounts experiencing a 4% increase in 2023, while the Retirement account has maintained a 4% rate since 2023. The government extended the 4% interest rate floors for these accounts until the end of 2024.

images.alt_text: Jeanette Tan
The extension provides certainty for CPF members amid the uncertain interest rate environment.
PM Lee Hsien Loong speaking at the National Day Rally 2023.
PM Lee, photographed by Terence Tan
The recent CPF scam cases were flagged in a joint statement by the CPF Board, GovTech and the police on Jun 29.

site_title: India-Canada clash should be a wake-up call for countries that are home to diaspora communities
summary: India and Canada have clashed over allegations that India's government may have sponsored the murder of a Sikh activist in British Columbia. India has denied the charges, citing lack of evidence, while also criticizing Canada for hosting extremist networks. Canada has accused India of sponsoring terrorism, which India has dismissed as "absurd". The dispute highlights tensions between countries with significant diaspora communities, with many calling for greater awareness of these issues.

Hardeep Singh Nijjar (top), 45, was shot dead outside a Sikh temple on June 18 in Surrey, a Vancouver suburb with a large Sikh population, three years after India had designated him as a “terrorist”.

site_title: As green growth loses traction among researchers, ‘post-growth’ thought is no longer a fringe position
summary: Researchers are shifting away from the "green growth" paradigm, where environmental goals align with economic growth, and towards a more holistic approach to sustainable development. The idea is losing favor, with European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen's speech highlighting a growing recognition of the need for a more nuanced approach. This shift is driven by concerns that green growth may not be sufficient to address climate change, with some arguing that it can actually exacerbate environmental problems. A more comprehensive dialogue on sustainable development is now considered necessary.

images.alt_text: NYPD officers block activists protesting outside the Federal Reserve Bank of New York during a demonstration calling for the U.S. government to take action on climate change and reject the use of fossil fuels during Climate Week in the Financial District of New York City, New York, U.S., September 18, 2023. Anti-capitalist protests ahead of the World Trade Organization ministerial meeting in Geneva in June 2022. But neither the philosophy of degrowth nor libertarian belief in decentralised finance can solve the problems of capitalism.
Degrowth pushes for the downscaling of harmful industries and the flourishing of helpful ones that address social needs, justice, care and sustainability, its proponents say.

site_title: Mercatus said to have put 18 assets in HDB estates up for sale at S$265m guide price
summary: Mercatus, a unit of NTUC Enterprise, has put 18 commercial properties in HDB estates up for sale with a total indicative price of around S$265 million. The 170,000 sq ft portfolio has full occupancy, with about 80% leased to NTUC FairPrice. The properties are in locations such as Bukit Merah Central, Kallang Bahru, and Bishan, and will be sold with existing long-term tenancies in place. Market watchers estimate the entry net yield at slightly above 4.5%.

site_title: Stocks to watch: FCT, Clas, Sheng Siong, LHN Logistics, Geo Energy
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust divested 143.9 million units of Hektar Reit in Malaysia for RM128.1 million, reducing its stake to 2.1%. CapitaLand Ascott Trust completed the divestment of four French serviced residences for S$64.6 million, exceeding book value. Sheng Siong inked a lease agreement for a new store in China, while LHN Logistics faces S$993,853 claims and Geo Energy Resources secured US$220 million in term loan facilities.

site_title: How to build psychological safety in a workplace with toxic culture
summary: Companies become toxic when managers stop having conversations that make employees feel seen, heard, appreciated, and invested. Behaviours such as verbal abuse, dictatorial behaviours, and avoidance of conflict are signs of a toxic culture. To build psychological safety, companies should prioritize regular, open, and empathetic communication with employees. By doing so, managers can prevent toxic behaviours and foster a positive work environment. This approach is crucial for creating a culture where employees feel valued and empowered to contribute effectively.

images.alt_text: If you're struggling to get your employees on board with transformation, you might need to relook at how you lead.
Superiors should take care to let staff know that they are not expected to take on work outside the job scope as long as they perform well in daily duties.
The working assumption that current corporate wellness programs are sufficient for the times is being severely tested.
While posturing can help one in the short term to build up confidence, cracks will start to appear in the long run if one does not have the capability required.

Workers and employers need to agree on the ground rules of the new workplace and foster a culture and environment that promotes employee retention and engagement, as well as organisational performance.
If you're looking for a job, it might be worth seeking out a workplace that prioritises employee wellbeing over job performance.
Setting an expectation that it’s OK (or even necessary) to work beyond your contracted hours disadvantages those that need more flexibility, such as carers, who are typically women.
Your relationship with your boss can make or break you, so it's important to either keep a good one, or move on quickly.
The reward of a better-quality workplace environment, culture and relationships will make the effort of complaining, or establishing a positive feedback culture, worthwhile.
Toxic positivity occurs when our response to our own or someone else’s predicament comes across as a lack of empathy and dismisses emotions instead of affirming them.

site_title: No Signboard reinstates agreements with largest shareholder GuGong
summary: No Signboard has reinstated its agreement with largest shareholder GuGong to engage GuGong's services for operational matters and sell its trademarks and brand name. The agreements, which were previously terminated in March 2023, were reinstated after a High Court granted an order for their reinstatement. The agreements include setting up new outlets in Asia and assisting in the transition of daily operations to a new management. A hearing has been fixed to deal with the withdrawal of an injunction application related to the intellectual property sale.

site_title: Biden to host Pacific island leaders in US charm offensive vs China
summary: US President Joe Biden will host a second summit with Pacific island leaders this week, part of a US charm offensive to counter China's growing influence in the region. The meeting will include diplomatic recognition for two Pacific islands, infrastructure investments, and honors for regional leaders. The US aims to strengthen its ties with the islands and limit Chinese inroads, following a first summit at the White House last year.

site_title: As Singapore’s society evolves, our attitudes towards ‘basic needs’ can change too
summary: Singapore's government is hesitant to implement a universal wage floor to ensure lower-wage workers earn decent wages, citing concerns that setting it too low would benefit fewer workers than the Progressive Wage Model. A recent study found that Singaporeans' perceptions of basic living standards have evolved, with a family of four needing at least S$6,693 a month to afford a basic standard of living. The government also argues that a single poverty line could have unintended consequences and that employers should bear more responsibility for supporting workers.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Monday; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 5.7 points or 0.2% to 3,199.12 on Monday, amid concerns over prolonged elevated global interest rates. The broader market saw losers outnumber gainers 43 to 35. Asian stocks followed Wall Street and Europe's closures, with banking stocks experiencing mixed trade. Globally, the S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average also fell, with the Nasdaq Composite Index losing 0.1%.

site_title: Flexible work arrangements not only help women, but also Singapore’s economy
summary: Singapore's economy faces significant challenges with the country's aging population and declining birth rate, projected to have one in four residents aged 65 and up by 2030. The Majulah Package aims to support seniors, but excludes women who aren't in the workforce, with over 150,000 eligible for an annual bonus. To encourage women's return to work, flexible work arrangements (FWAs) are seen as crucial, with guidelines to be introduced in 2024. Employers must also change their mindset and provide fair performance management to prevent bias and prejudice, making FWAs available to all caregivers, male or female.

site_title: Founder of Chinese gambling website linked to Singapore’s S$2 billion money laundering case
summary: Wang Bingang, a 34-year-old Chinese national, is linked to Singapore's S$2 billion money laundering case. He founded the Hongli International gambling website in 2012, which operated from the Philippines and Cambodia, targeting Chinese gamblers. Wang Bingang was arrested in 2015 and sentenced to three years in prison, but it's unclear if he has served the term. His associates, including Wang Baosen and Wang Cailin, are also linked to the case, with assets seized or frozen totaling S$2.4 billion. The investigation is part of a broader crackdown on online gambling in Singapore and China.

site_title: Lego abandons effort to make oil-free bricks: FT
summary: Lego, a Danish toymaker, has abandoned its effort to create oil-free bricks due to higher carbon emissions from using recycled polyethylene terephthalate (RPET). The company had aimed to replace oil-based plastic bricks with sustainable materials by the end of the decade, but found it impossible to achieve the same color, shine, and sound. Lego's CEO, Niels Christiansen, stated that the company tested hundreds of materials and could not find an alternative.

site_title: China central bank adviser proposes structural reforms to revive economy
summary: China's central bank adviser, Liu Shijin, proposes structural reforms to revive the economy, citing limited room for monetary policy easing. He suggests demand-side reforms to give migrant workers access to public services and supply-side reforms to ignite entrepreneurship in emerging industries. China's economy is struggling with weak consumption, falling exports, and a property debt crisis, and Liu believes that structural reforms can aid immediate growth and inject long-term momentum. The proposals aim to give clearer recognition to private businesses and address the government's efforts to revive investor confidence.

images.alt_text: Global funds as a whole have slashed their China stock positioning to the lowest since October, which to some means more room for potential buying.

summary: A recent Asia PE-VC Summit and Formula 1 Singapore Grand Prix inspired a discussion on building a successful company. Experts shared key takeaways for leaders, including being an authentic leader, seizing opportunities in challenging situations, knowing one's purpose, embracing change, and leading oneself and a dream team. Key quotes from the discussion include the importance of resilience, a clear sense of purpose, and staying adaptable to succeed in today's fast-paced world of work.

site_title: Criminal groups from China spreading out to South-east Asia, including Singapore: experts
summary: Chinese criminal groups have expanded their operations to South-east Asia, including Singapore, to launder money and engage in human trafficking. The syndicates, which originated in China and moved to the Philippines in the early 2010s, have set up bases in countries like Australia, Cambodia, and Myanmar. These groups have been involved in large-scale scam operations, online gambling, and human trafficking, with estimated billions of dollars in capital. Authorities have stepped up cooperation to tackle transnational crime, including money laundering, human trafficking, and cyberscams, with joint operations and deportations of Chinese nationals.

site_title: Worst may be over for Thai baht as Srettha prioritises economy
summary: Thailand's Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin's announced economic growth measures are expected to boost the country's currency, the Thai baht. Analysts predict a rebound in the baht to 34 per US dollar by year-end, surpassing current levels. The Thai baht has fallen 2.8% in September due to concerns over government borrowing for cost-of-living relief measures. However, strategists believe the medium-term outlook for the currency is constructive, driven by tourism growth and pro-growth policies. A potential Bank of Thailand interest rate hike could also support the baht's value.

site_title: Nasa capsule carrying asteroid samples touches down in Utah
summary: A NASA capsule carrying asteroid samples touched down in the Utah desert on September 24, marking the US's first sample return mission of its kind. The OSIRIS-REx mission, launched in 2016, collected a large sample of rocks and dust from asteroid Bennu in 2020. The capsule, weighing around 250 grams, contains the largest sample ever collected from an asteroid, providing scientists with a unique opportunity to study the solar system's early materials. The recovered rocks will help researchers understand the solar system's formation and inform future exploration and potential asteroid mining missions.

site_title: Geo Energy secures US$220 million term loan for expansion
summary: Geo Energy Resources, an Indonesian coal producer, secured a US$220 million term loan from Bank Mandiri to fund acquisitions, working capital, and capital expenditure requirements. The loan carries an interest rate of 8.5% per annum, pegged to the Term Secured Overnight Financing Rate (SOFR) plus 3.25%. The loan will support the company's expansion plans, including ramping up production levels and developing the Triaryani mine, which has reserves of almost 300 million tonnes. The loan will provide the group with strong working capital and liquidity.

site_title: North American box office hits a low point for the year
summary: The North American box office experienced a low point for 2023, with top film "The Nun II" earning an estimated $8.4 million. Industry watchers attributed the poor results to ongoing strikes by Hollywood screenwriters and actors, which David A. Gross described as "not good" and unlikely to end soon. This marks a month of poor box office performance, raising concerns about the industry's future.
