site_title: Chinese EV maker Zeekr sweeps into Europe amid subsidy spat
summary: Chinese electric vehicle maker Zeekr has begun European sales of two models, the 001 sedan and X compact SUV, with plans to add seven more by 2025. The company's European head, Spiros Fotinos, credits its parent company, Zhejiang Geely Holding Group, for giving Zeekr an "important headstart" in the market. However, Zeekr's ambitions may be hindered by a European Union investigation into state aid to Chinese EV makers, which could lead to import tariffs on Chinese EVs.

images.alt_text: Electric vehicles have become a major focal point of global trade tensions in recent weeks as Europe frets that its automakers will lose out to Chinese manufacturers in the transition to less polluting cars.
Zeekr says the final deal size would depend on financial market conditions later this year.

site_title: US stocks flash recession warning as trouble spreads to industrials
summary: US stocks, particularly small-cap and industrial shares, are experiencing a downturn, raising recession concerns. The S&P 500 Industrials index has dropped 8% since its peak in August, while the Russell 2000 Index has lost 11% from its July high. Investors are pulling money from equity funds at the fastest pace since December. However, some analysts believe earnings season may be more influential than interest rate hikes, and forecasters predict economic growth will slow until the middle of next year before picking up again.

images.alt_text: The tech-heavy Nasdaq 100 has dropped more than 5 per cent so far in September, on track for a back-to-back loss and its worst monthly showing of 2023 as high-flyers such as Tesla and Microsoft stumble.

site_title: European carmakers dial up pressure on post-Brexit EV tariffs
summary: European carmakers are urging the European Commission to delay post-Brexit tariffs on electric vehicles, citing a potential reduction of 480,000 cars in production over three years. The tariffs, set to take effect in January, could harm the industry, with the EU launching an investigation into Beijing's financial support for the EV industry. The European Automobile Manufacturers' Association is pushing for a delay to protect the region's automakers from losing out to Chinese manufacturers in the transition to less polluting cars.

images.alt_text: China has become a global powerhouse in electric cars: It’s expected to account for about 60 per cent of the world’s 14.1 million new passenger EV sales this year.

The United Auto Workers may well see the current moment as its last chance to stay relevant before more of the industry switches to electric vehicles, which are less mechanically complicated and so less labour-intensive to make.

site_title: Banks fearing a liquidity crunch pay more to cling to cash
summary: US banks are increasing deposits to protect their cash holdings, with some paying up to $675 billion to safeguard against future runs on deposits. The risk that bank reserves will deplete is growing due to continued deposit outflows and the Fed's pledge to keep interest rates at current levels. This could force the Fed to halt quantitative tightening earlier than intended, leading to potential funding pressure. Banks have been holding additional reserves above the lowest comfortable level, with some preferring to hold reserves above the level in September 2019, which is estimated to be around $2.5 trillion.

images.alt_text: The Bank of England on Thursday announced its first pause on raising rates since December 2021, following a slight decline in UK inflation in August.

site_title: Canada autoworkers approve Ford offer as US strike goes on
summary: Canadian autoworkers have approved a three-year contract with Ford, providing a 15% wage increase over three years, including a 10% boost the first year. The 54% approval vote came two days after the United Auto Workers expanded its US strike against General Motors and Stellantis, while holding off against Ford. The US strike, now in its second week, has drawn intense attention and is expected to impact the US economy. US President Joe Biden is set to join a UAW picket line in Michigan on Tuesday, ahead of a potential 2024 presidential candidate Donald Trump.

images.alt_text: The autoworkers’ union will expand its strike against parts distribution centres across the US at GM and Stellantis.

The United Auto Workers may well see the current moment as its last chance to stay relevant before more of the industry switches to electric vehicles, which are less mechanically complicated and so less labour-intensive to make.
Tesla Chief Executive Officer Elon Musk gets in a Tesla car as he leaves a hotel in Beijing, China May 31, 2023.

site_title: Millions to take to skies as China gears up for long Golden Week
summary: China is gearing up for a record-breaking Golden Week holiday, with over 21 million people expected to take flights in the next eight days. Airfares are climbing, with some routes seeing fares double or more due to the increased popularity of destinations like Xinjiang and Tibet. The eight-day holiday also allows for longer travel, with 37% of travelers planning to stay in their destinations for six to eight nights. This is the first time the Golden Week holiday has seen a significant increase in travel since the pandemic.

images.alt_text: While domestic tourism in China has rebounded above pre-Covid levels, international travel is still well below.

site_title: SingPost, SBS Transit may not see lasting boost from transport fare, postage rate hikes
summary: SingPost and SBS Transit may not see long-term benefits from recent fare and postage rate hikes, as companies are limited in their ability to adjust pricing in response to shifting demand and costs. Despite the hikes, SingPost's mail volumes have declined by over 40% since 2019, leading to a 70.3% decline in earnings. The higher postage rates will not halt the decline in postal volumes, and SingPost is working with the Infocomm Media Development Authority to develop a long-term strategy to make its postal operations commercially sustainable.

images.alt_text: Ben Paul
SingPost says its latest rate increment reflects the escalating costs of maintaining the postal service.
DBS expects ComfortDelGro's bottomline to be boosted by higher earnings from its subsidiary, SBS Transit in FY2024.
The overall cost of bus and train rides will go up by 7 per cent.

site_title: Singapore is Japan’s top property investor in 2023
summary: Singapore became Japan's top property investor in 2023, with total inflows of nearly US$3 billion, according to Knight Frank. The yen's weakness and growing demand in logistics and hospitality industries drew investors, including Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC, which spent US$800 million on warehouses. Foreign investors also put significant money into hotels, with US$2 billion spent on deals so far this year. The post-pandemic tourism boom and low borrowing costs contributed to the interest in Japan's real estate sector.

images.alt_text: The yen drops as low as 148.42 to the US dollar, nearing the 150-mark at which analysts have said government intervention to prop up the currency is likely.

site_title: WealthBT: How responsible is your portfolio? (Ep 30)
summary: WealthBT podcast series discusses responsible investing with Evelyn Yeo from Pictet Wealth Management Asia. Key themes include climate impact, climate risks, and elements to ensure investments have impact. Evelyn emphasizes the importance of responsible investing, citing the need to protect and grow wealth while considering social and environmental factors. The conversation highlights the need for impact investing, with Evelyn discussing key elements in the responsible investing process.

images.alt_text: Dong Chen from Pictet talks us through the major forecasts or expectations of asset class returns.
Evelyn Goh, head of Asia Investments from Pictet Wealth management Asia talks to wealth editor Genevieve Cua about how to address the world's needs with your capital

site_title: F1, major events shouldn’t ignore attendees’ travel emissions
summary: Singapore plans to fine-tune its carbon emission management for Formula One (F1) and Meetings, Incentives, Conferences, and Exhibitions (MICE) events, including the recently concluded F1 Grand Prix. The country aims to include attendees' travel emissions in the reporting, which could be significant, as a back-of-the-napkin estimate suggests it could be 18 times the reported emissions. Many event organizers, including the Singapore F1 Grand Prix, do not count spectators' travel emissions, citing lack of influence. However, the US Environmental Protection Agency has offered guidelines for reporting travel emissions, and the Net Zero Carbon Events initiative is reviewing its stance on inclusion.

images.alt_text: Kenneth Lim
Singapore's 2022 Formula 1 Grand Prix is estimated to have produced 2,372 tCO2e.
Singapore Grand Prix has switched to energy-efficient LED track lightings that reduce electricity use by at least 30 per cent, said Manpower Minister Tan See Leng in parliament on Tuesday.
Lendlease is also pushing for an industry-wide data-sharing platform for the secure exchange of digitised, verified Scope 3 emissions data across value chains.

site_title: Sunak may scrap part of UK rail link before Tory conference
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak may scrap part of the HS2 high-speed rail link, a key section connecting Birmingham with Manchester, as he prepares for the Conservative Party conference. The project's initial London to Birmingham stretch estimate has increased by over £8 billion. Sunak is also expected to announce policy changes on housing, infrastructure, and immigration, as he shifts into election mode ahead of a vote due before January 2025.

images.alt_text: The part of the line running into central London would also be delayed, as part of cost-saving measures, Transport Minister Mark Harper said.

site_title: Japan to discuss carbon storage with Malaysia: Nikkei
summary: Japan plans to discuss carbon storage with Malaysia, aiming to store 120-240 million tonnes of carbon dioxide per year underground to become carbon neutral by 2050. Economy minister Yasutoshi Nishimura will meet Petronas executives in Japan on September 25 to sign a project memorandum, marking Japan's first attempt to transport and store emissions overseas. The project is expected to start in 2028.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for September 22, 2023, highlights fluctuating dynamics in the Pacific and Atlantic tanker and dry bulk markets. The Panamax sector experienced positive gains initially but saw some gains eroded by the end of the week. The Pacific market displayed stability but later softened due to a decline in the FFA market, while the Atlantic remained relatively quiet. The report notes that the week saw fluctuating dynamics in various sectors, including Panamax, Ultramax/Supramax, Handysize, and Suezmax. The clean fuel market also saw a turnaround in rates across the board, with the VLCC market experiencing increased cargo requirement and slightly bolstered rates.

images.alt_text:
lng / ST20210823_202127136955 / Alphonsus Chern //

Generic photograph of a Liquefied Natural Gas (LNG) tanker. 23 August 2021.

site_title: Amid concerns of a Chinese debt trap, Indonesia’s first high-speed railway to finally open
summary: Indonesia's first high-speed railway, the Kereta Cepat Jakarta Bandung (KCJB), will commence commercial operations on October 1 after four years of delays. The 142 km railway, funded by China's Belt and Road Initiative, will reduce travel time between Jakarta and Bandung to 40 minutes from three hours. However, concerns over a potential Chinese debt trap have been raised, with the project's budget ballooning to $7.3 billion, exceeding the initial projection of $6.07 billion. The Indonesian government has recently issued a regulation allowing the use of state funds as a loan guarantee for the project.

images.alt_text: Elisa Valenta
Indonesian President Joko Widodo (right) points towards a display showing the speed during a trial of the new Bandung-Jakarta high-speed train on Sep 13, 2023.
The 142-kilometre railway connecting the capital Jakarta to the city of Bandung is now to be commercially launched on Oct 1.
A bullet train bound for Jakarta during a trial at the Tegalluar station in Bandung on May 22, 2023.

site_title: China to set up strategic emerging industry fund
summary: China is planning to set up a strategic emerging industry fund worth at least 100 billion yuan (S$18.7 billion) to invest in strategic sectors such as artificial intelligence, new energy, new materials, and biotech. The fund, managed by Reform Holdings Corp, has received investment intentions from over 20 government-owned enterprises, provincial administrations, and social capital. It is expected to start operating within the year, as part of Beijing's efforts to reform state-owned enterprises.

site_title: Wilmar chairman Kuok, QAF MD Lin Kejian continue to build interests
summary: Wilmar International chairman Kuok Khoon Hong increased his deemed interest in the global agri-business from 13.42% to 13.44% after acquiring 766,700 shares at S$3.69 per share. QAF joint group managing director Lin Kejian acquired 945,600 shares at an average price of S$0.824 per share, increasing his total interest in QAF from 48.82% to 48.98%. Meanwhile, institutions were net sellers of Singapore stocks with S$205 million of net institutional outflow, while 24 primary-listed companies conducted buybacks with a total consideration of S$22.1 million.

images.alt_text: Generic shots of SGX

site_title: Private equity won’t diversify your portfolio
summary: Private equity investments are often touted as a way to diversify a portfolio, but they can actually increase risk and may not offer the promised benefits. Private equity funds typically rely on leverage, which can amplify returns but also increase risk. Research suggests that private equity returns are highly correlated with those of the public markets, making it difficult to achieve true diversification. Additionally, the fees associated with private equity investments can be high, making cheaper alternatives more attractive. As interest rates rise, the private equity industry is already shrinking, and investors should be cautious of its potential risks.

images.alt_text: Inflation and the high cost of debt has led family offices to move down the risk curve to pursue value-add and opportunistic strategies.

site_title: Singapore unlikely to make caregiving leave mandatory despite NTUC recommendation: observers
summary: Singapore is unlikely to make caregiving leave mandatory, despite the National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) recommending it to help workers care for elderly, disabled, or ill family members. Employers say the additional costs would be challenging to bear without government financial support. The NTUC suggested defining "family members" as blood, marriage, or adoption, covering chronic illnesses and both physical and mental conditions, but did not specify the amount of leave.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Tessa Oh
Younger caregiver taking care of elderly at Toa Payoh Hub on Aug 23, 2019.

site_title: Shein shifts shipping strategy to bring China-made goods closer to US shoppers
summary: Shein, the fast-fashion e-commerce giant, is shifting its shipping strategy to bring China-made goods closer to US shoppers, aiming to compete with established retailers on delivery times. The company has seen a significant increase in ocean shipments of apparel, soaring 2,000% in the last two years, and plans to expand its US storage space to reduce wait times. This move comes as Shein eyes an initial public offering and seeks to improve its delivery times to match those of retailers like Amazon.

images.alt_text: A Bloomberg investigation last year found scientific evidence that cotton produced in the Xinjiang region, which has been linked to forced labour, was present in clothing sold by Shein.

site_title: One year since Truss-powered crash, ghost of weak pound is back
summary: The British pound is facing a potential downward trajectory against the US dollar, following the Bank of England's surprise decision to keep interest rates on hold. This move has refocused market concerns on the UK's economic fundamentals, which remain tepid despite the impact of last year's crisis fading. Analysts predict sterling could fall 5% to 1.17 by year-end and 1.11 by the second half of next year, with some warning of a sharper slide if positions are unwound further.

images.alt_text: The yen drops as low as 148.42 to the US dollar, nearing the 150-mark at which analysts have said government intervention to prop up the currency is likely.

site_title: FEHT eyes maiden overseas acquisitions, but Singapore will remain key focus
summary: Far East Hospitality Trust, a Singaporean Reit, plans to remain a "very Singapore-centric" entity with a small proportion of overseas assets. CEO Gerald Lee sees Singapore's hospitality sector as a key growth engine, despite the global rebound. The trust is eyeing overseas acquisitions in developed markets such as Australia, Japan, and the UK, with a focus on assets already held by its sponsor Far East Organization. Lee believes the trust can benefit from a cleaner balance sheet and strong market conditions.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim

site_title: Switzerland needs another major local bank: Swatch CEO
summary: Swatch Group CEO Nick Hayek believes Switzerland needs another major local bank, citing the loss of Credit Suisse as a threat to the country's banking stability. He suggests that UBS Group should have retained a 30-40% ownership of Credit Suisse and encouraged major Swiss companies to take stakes. Hayek regrets the takeover, which he believes will lead to foreign lenders entering the market. He praises the return of Sergio Ermotti as CEO of the combined banks, citing his Swiss heritage and understanding of the country's culture.

site_title: China Evergrande unable to meet qualifications for issuance of new notes
summary: China Evergrande, a property developer with over $300 billion in total liabilities, has stated it cannot meet qualifications for issuing new notes under its debt restructuring plan. The decision comes amid an investigation into its flagship onshore unit, Hengda Real Estate Group, for suspected information disclosure violations. As of end-July, Hengda had over $52 billion in unpaid debts and 1,931 pending litigation cases. The group's chairman advises holders and potential investors to exercise caution when dealing with the company's securities. The move raises concerns about the property debt crisis in China.

site_title: AUDUSD expected to rebound before resuming downtrend
summary: The Australian dollar (AUDUSD) has lost 20% of its value against the US dollar since February 2022, hovering around 0.64, and is down by over 5% year-to-date. Despite a lack of evidence for a lasting bullish reversal, analysts project a short-term rebound before the pair resumes its downtrend, which they believe is indicated by a descending channel on the weekly chart. This downtrend is expected to continue into the end of the year, testing the lower support band of the channel.

images.alt_text: The Aussie rose 0.3 per cent to US$0.6472 on Monday, having climbed 0.7 per cent last week to as far as US$0.6522.

site_title: 2 VCPlus executives assisting CAD, MAS in probe related to Sevens Atelier
summary: VCPlus' executive director and head of subsidiary are assisting in the investigation by the Monetary Authority of Singapore and Commercial Affairs Department into offences under the Securities and Futures Act, related to dealings with Sevens Atelier in 2021 and 2022. VCPlus has provided information and documents, and both executives have surrendered their passports and will take leave of absence pending the outcome. Sevens Atelier has also been ordered to provide documents in connection with certain announcements made by the company.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
SGX-ST had asked Sevens Atelier for updates on the progress of the probe, among other queries.

site_title: Yields spike and gold shrugs. What’s driving bullion now?
summary: Gold prices have shown resilience despite soaring inflation-adjusted interest rates, with spot gold only down 0.5% on Thursday, the highest since 2009. Analysts attribute the metal's stability to voracious central bank buying, particularly by China, and investors' continued bets on a US economic slowdown. Despite models suggesting gold is overvalued, some analysts believe the metal's relationship with interest rates has been reset at a higher base, potentially leading to further gains if yields or the US dollar drop.

images.alt_text: Spot gold was steady at US$1,930.51 per ounce by 0319 GMT, holding below its highest level since Sept 5 reached on Tuesday.

site_title: Nature-based solutions critical to S-E Asia’s adaptation to global warming
summary: South-east Asian countries must prioritize adaptation investments in response to climate change, particularly in areas such as floods, droughts, and chronic heat. Nature-based solutions, including coral reef preservation and mangrove swamp restoration, are considered effective and cost-effective measures. Governments and private entities must work together to implement system-wide policy changes and integrate climate resilience into urban planning and economic development. A holistic approach to climate risk and opportunities is needed, with investments in measures such as flood-resilient developments and climate-resilient infrastructure.

images.alt_text: A partially submerged building is seen following heavy rains caused by Typhoon Haikui in Xiamen, in China's southern Fujian province on September 6, 2023. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT

site_title: Thailand expects Tesla, Google, Microsoft to invest US$5 billion
summary: Thailand expects investments of at least US$5 billion from Tesla, Google, and Microsoft. Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin announced the potential investments, which would boost the country's flagging economy. Tesla is considering an electric vehicle manufacturing facility, while Microsoft and Google are looking at data centers. This fresh investment comes as Thailand's economy is expected to grow by 2.8% this year, less than previously projected due to weaker exports. The country has been offering incentives to EV and battery makers to remain a regional auto center.

images.alt_text: Thai prime minister Srettha Thavisin's government plans to boost growth with tourism, waiving visa requirements for Chinese over five months to draw in more visitors.

site_title: Data centre firm AirTrunk mulls IPO at A$10 billion value: report
summary: AirTrunk, an Australian data centre operator, is considering an initial public offering (IPO) valued at over A$10 billion, according to a report by the Australian Financial Review. The company's CEO, Robin Khuda, cited "remarkable" growth in the industry, driven by rising demand for cloud-based services and the development of artificial intelligence computing. AirTrunk has already secured a A$4.6 billion sustainability-linked loan, and Macquarie Capital and other banks are expected to be appointed as joint lead managers for the potential IPO.

images.alt_text: Asia has been no exception to a global decline in loan deals this year, an outcome of rising interest rates and concerns about slowing economic growth and China’s property debt crisis.

site_title: European crypto asset manager CoinShares starts US hedge fund division
summary: CoinShares, a European cryptocurrency asset manager, has launched a US hedge fund division, CoinShares Hedge Fund, available to qualified US investors. The move comes as the US SEC targets exchanges and digital assets projects amid heightened regulatory scrutiny. CoinShares' CEO Jean-Marie Mognetti believes the market is fertile for the hedge fund due to monetary policy and macro uncertainty, aiming to deliver outperformance. The firm's proprietary trading division will be integrated into the new division, which will focus on Bitcoin and Ether.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Representations of cryptocurrencies are seen in this illustration, August 10, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration

site_title: Major Indonesia coal plant back near capacity despite pollution concerns
summary: Indonesia's Suralaya coal-fired power plant has restored nearly full capacity, despite pollution concerns. The plant was ordered to reduce output to curb air pollution in Jakarta, which has been battling worsening air quality for years. Jakarta topped global pollution rankings several times last month, according to a Swiss air quality monitor. The move comes ahead of a regional summit and a US visit by Indonesian President, but does not address underlying pollution issues.

images.alt_text: Indonesian President Joko Widodo says domestic investors in Nusantara, the new capital, must be prioritised over foreign ones.
The decision to hold rates is consistent with BI’s stance to ensure inflation stays within target range in 2023 and 2024, BI governor Perry Warjiyo says.
During deliberations with lawmakers, the government and the budget committee approve most of the budget assumptions in the original proposal.

site_title: Jungkook, stars draw fans to Global Citizen Festival despite rain
summary: Jungkook's performance at the Global Citizen Festival drew a large crowd, despite rain, with thousands gathered in Central Park to support global development aid. Jungkook and Brazil's Anitta performed hits like "Still With You" and "Funk Rave," while rappers Busta Rhymes, Common, and Lauryn Hill paid tribute to hip-hop's 50th anniversary. The festival aimed to increase funding for global issues like poverty and climate change, with leaders like French President Emmanuel Macron pledging $150 million to the International Fund for Agricultural Development.

images.alt_text: The survey's Singapore respondents cite sea-level rise as the top concern among climate change impacts that the city state is exposed to.

site_title: As planet gets warmer, ski gondola maker goes urban
summary: Austrian company Doppelmayr, known for ski resort gondolas, is shifting its focus to urban cable car projects as cities seek to decarbonize public transport systems. The company now accounts for 20% of its sales with urban mobility, with projects in London, Mexico City, and La Paz. Doppelmayr's cable cars are three times cheaper than tramways, using less land and requiring minimal on-site work. Cities like Paris and Bolivia have adopted the technology, citing its clean, quiet, and regular transportation benefits.

images.alt_text: The reduced rainfall linked to El Nino means a higher risk of wildfires and hazardous haze.

site_title: Dollar up as data highlights US economic resilience; yen slumps
summary: The US dollar advanced against a basket of currencies, with the US dollar index on pace for a weekly gain of about 0.3%, its 10th straight week of gains. Data from S&P Global showed the US Composite PMI index at 50.1 in September, barely above the 50 level separating expansion and contraction. This defies projections of a recession and outpaces other major economies, including Europe, which saw economic activity fall more quickly than expected. The yen slumped, near the 150-mark, as the Bank of Japan kept interest rates in negative territory, while sterling fell 0.47% after data showed the UK economy slowed sharply.

images.alt_text: The yen drops as low as 148.42 to the US dollar, nearing the 150-mark at which analysts have said government intervention to prop up the currency is likely.

site_title: No deal yet as Hollywood writers, studios talk for third straight day
summary: Hollywood writers and top studio executives met for a third straight day to try and end a work stoppage that has shut down film and TV production for 144 days. The strike, which began in May, involves 11,500 WGA members demanding higher pay and residuals in the streaming TV era, as well as limits on artificial intelligence use. No agreement was announced as of late Friday, with union members and studio executives continuing talks. The Writers Guild of America (WGA) and the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers (AMPTP) had no comment on the outcome.

images.alt_text: The streaming platforms have offered to provide the WGA with the total number of hours viewed for each made-for-streaming show in confidential quarterly reports.
Writers Guild of America and Screen Actors Guild members and supporters on a picket line outside Paramount Studios in Los Angeles, California.

site_title:
Even China’s 1.4 billion population can’t fill 
all its vacant homes: former official
summary: China's property sector, once a key driver of the economy, has severely declined since 2021 due to debt defaults and a crackdown on new borrowing. As of August, 648 million square meters of unsold homes remain, equivalent to 7.2 million homes, according to the National Bureau of Statistics. Former official He Keng estimates that 1.4 billion people (China's population) could fill these homes, suggesting that even the country's massive population cannot fill the vacant apartments. This stark reality contrasts with the official narrative that China's economy is "resilient".

images.alt_text: With more than US$300 billion in total liabilities, including offshore debt, Evergrande has been at the centre of a property debt crisis.

site_title: For Tesla and Musk, auto strike carries benefits and risks
summary: The US auto industry is facing a strike by the United Auto Workers (UAW) against major automakers, including Ford, General Motors, and Stellantis, which could benefit Tesla, the electric vehicle (EV) maker. Tesla's CEO, Elon Musk, has attacked unions, but the UAW is trying to organize its factory workers, which could lead to significant wage increases and benefits. Tesla's financial performance, with a 60% share in the US EV market and a $2.7 billion profit, makes it a tempting target for unions, but Musk's history of illegally threatening employees and firing organizers poses risks.

images.alt_text: The United Auto Workers may well see the current moment as its last chance to stay relevant before more of the industry switches to electric vehicles, which are less mechanically complicated and so less labour-intensive to make.
Labourers work next to electricity pylons in Mumbai, India. The country has boosted electricity supplies to towns and villages, but still faces peak-time shortages as demand surges.
Hours before its release on Amazon, advance orders had made Elon Musk the site’s best-selling book in the United States.
Tesla has been mentioning how Dojo gives it an edge in AI and self-driving technology since at least 2021.
The hands-free level three allows for autonomous driving in certain conditions such as heavy traffic or motorway speeds up to 60 kilometres per hour.

site_title: Recycling plastic not enough, warns UN environment chief
summary: The UN Environment chief, Inger Andersen, warns that relying solely on recycling plastic is not enough to address the issue of plastic pollution, as the production of plastics has more than doubled in the past 20 years to 460 million tons. The current rate of recycling, only 9%, is insufficient to halt the flow of plastic waste into oceans, which is crucial for human health. A new international treaty on plastic pollution, set to be finalized by the end of 2024, aims to reduce single-use plastics and rethink the production of plastic products, including considering alternative forms such as powdered or compressed versions.

images.alt_text: Jakarta, which has been battling worsening air quality for years, topped global pollution rankings several times last month, according to Swiss air quality monitor IQAir.
The reduced rainfall linked to El Nino means a higher risk of wildfires and hazardous haze.
The survey's Singapore respondents cite sea-level rise as the top concern among climate change impacts that the city state is exposed to.

site_title: Hong Kong relaxes mortgage rules as property market falters
summary: Hong Kong relaxes mortgage rules for first-time home buyers of properties under construction valued up to HK$10 million (S$1.75 million), reducing the required down payment to 10% from 70%. The move aims to boost the first-hand property market, but experts say it won't stimulate the overall market unless the government relaxes the stress test requirement. The city's property market has been impacted by high borrowing costs, with home prices dropping 17% from their peak in 2021.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong apartments housing property Photographer: Lam Yik/Bloomberg

site_title: Adidas boss apologises for controversial Ye comments
summary: Adidas CEO Bjorn Gulden apologized for speculating that Kanye West didn't mean his anti-Semitic remarks, which ended their lucrative partnership. Gulden stated he didn't think West was a bad person, but his comments came across that way. Adidas reaffirmed its decision to end the partnership, citing unacceptable comments. The company is selling off Yeezy items, with proceeds going to organizations like the Anti-Defamation League and charities.

images.alt_text: The Adizero Adios Pro Evo 1 is Adidas’ lightest ever racing shoe.

Sales of surplus Yeezy shoes generated around 400 million euros in the second quarter, helping Adidas to reduce its predicted loss for the year to 450 million euros, down from the 700 million euro loss previously expected.

FILE PHOTO: The Adidas logo is pictured during celebrations for German sports apparel maker Adidas' 70th anniversary at the company's headquarters in Herzogenaurach, Germany, August 9, 2019. REUTERS/Andreas Gebert/File Photo

site_title: Australia government aims for sustainable, inclusive full employment
summary: Australia's Labor government will announce a new objective for full employment, aiming for sustained and inclusive full employment to guide future economic policy. The goal is to ensure everyone who wants a job can find one without searching for long. The move comes as the unemployment rate is around historic lows, but millions face barriers to employment. The government will outline policy directions to tackle underutilization in the labor market and invest in skills and tertiary education sectors.

images.alt_text: Australia's budget surplus is the first by a Labor government since 1989-90 when Paul Keating was treasurer. That fiscal position was rapidly unwound as the nation slid into a deep recession in 1991.

Flavio Macau, associate dean of School of Business and Law at Edith Cowan University, says what the government is doing is bringing more money into the market, which is not a bad thing, but it’s not bringing more capacity to the market.

site_title: AI fantasy fades as Wall Street reels from real-world rate jump
summary: The US stock market is experiencing a downturn due to the Federal Reserve's decision to keep interest rates high to combat inflation. Real-world borrowing costs have jumped, making it more expensive for companies to borrow and increasing the cost of doing business. This has led to a decline in tech stocks, with the Nasdaq 100 dropping over 5% in September. The Fed's goal of tightening financial conditions is seen as a threat to the trillion-dollar artificial intelligence (AI) promise, which has masked a big threat in this era of Federal Reserve hawkishness.

images.alt_text: The withdrawals came as this year’s stock rally, powered by AI optimism, lost momentum. Chipmaker Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing has fallen more than 11 per cent since a June high.
The study found that more than three-quarters of Singaporean workers who use AI at work have passed off generative-AI work tasks as their own work, while more than half have done this multiple times.

site_title: Why can’t Americans buy cheap Chinese EVs?
summary: The US is unable to buy cheap Chinese electric vehicles due to profitability concerns from US automakers. Unlike Europe and China, the US lacks affordable EV options, with around 50 models available, compared to nearly triple that in China. The issue is partly due to investments in electrification, with US carmakers focusing on premium models and trucks. China, however, is expected to account for 60% of the world's 14.1 million new passenger EV sales this year, with many affordable options available.

images.alt_text: BYD has no plans to enter the US passenger-car market but it’s selling electric buses in the country.
The autoworkers’ union will expand its strike against parts distribution centres across the US at GM and Stellantis.

site_title: Apple’s iPhone 15 goes on sale in test of holiday resurgence
summary: Apple's iPhone 15 went on sale in 40 countries, including Australia, China, the US, UK, and France, marking a test of whether the new design and modest smartwatch changes can boost sales. Initial online sales indicate high demand, with new iPhone 15 models not arriving until mid-November in several countries. Long lines formed in Dubai, Australia, and China, showing customers willing to brave crowds to be among the first to own a new iPhone. The iPhone 15 Pro and Pro Max models are expected to be the biggest sellers throughout the year, with Apple shares rising 1.4% to US$176.42.

images.alt_text: People who ordered the latest iPhone model line up outside an Apple store in Beijing, China, Sept 22, 2023.

site_title: Real estate crisis triggers new alarms over China’s shadow banks
summary: China's shadow banks, including trust firms like Zhongrong, are facing concerns over their financial stability amid a real estate crisis. Dozens of payments to investors have been missed, with some investments potentially at risk. Zhongrong attributed the delay to "multiple internal and external factors" but did not provide a timeline for payment. The crisis has raised concerns about the financial health of Zhongzhi Enterprise Group, which manages $140 billion in assets, and its potential collapse.

images.alt_text: The logo of Zhongrong Dingxin is seen on the office building of Zhongrong International Trust, a trust company partially owned by Zhongzhi Enterprise Group, in Beijing, China August 22, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo

site_title: KKR-backed BrightSpring is said to revive IPO seeking US$1 billion
summary: KKR-backed healthcare services provider BrightSpring has confidentially refiled for a US$1 billion IPO, according to people familiar with the matter. The company, which serves 350,000 patients daily in 50 US states, withdrew its initial public offering plan last year due to a souring market. BrightSpring has re-engaged Goldman Sachs and KKR's capital markets division as lead bookrunners for the offering, with a planned listing for the fourth quarter. The move follows a trio of closely watched US IPOs that have warmed up the market after a nearly two-year freeze.

images.alt_text: Reliance Retail is India’s biggest retailer whose operations stretch from selling groceries to electronics, and include foreign partnerships with brands.
FILE PHOTO: Trading information for KKR & Co is displayed on a screen on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, U.S., August 23, 2018. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo

site_title: New-look Gucci goes back to the classics
summary: Gucci's new creative director Sabato de Sarno debuted his first collection in Milan, marking a return to the brand's classic, feminine aesthetic. The "Ancora" collection features leather, coats, and minimalist designs, aiming to relaunch the luxury brand after Alessandro Michele's departure. The event was attended by A-listers Julia Roberts and Ryan Gosling, and Kering's new CEO Jean-Francois Palus will oversee the brand's temporary management. The collection's impact will be evaluated by the end of 2024, with analysts predicting a potential increase in turnover and profits.

images.alt_text: Bluebell is seeking improvements at Kering’s Gucci business as well as organisational changes and potential deals.
Kering last year saw sales rise nine per cent on a comparable basis, with Gucci’s sales edging up only one per cent.
Chanel's regal Tweed Royal necklace.

site_title: US: Stocks fall again, extending losing streak
summary: US stocks fell for the fourth consecutive day, with the S&P 500 closing at 4,320.06, down 0.2% for the day and 2.9% for the week. The decline was attributed to anticipation of persistently elevated interest rates. Despite flirting with positive territory, major indices retreated throughout the day, extending the losing streak.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rises 6.66 points, or 0.02 per cent, at the open to 34,077.08.

site_title: China smelters keep Q4 copper guidance price at six-year high
summary: China's top copper smelters maintained their Q4 copper concentrate processing treatment and refining charges (TC/RCs) at a six-year high of US$95 per metric ton and 9.5 cents per pound. The rate is unchanged from the third quarter and highest since 2017, driven by expectations of ample supply in the market. The global copper concentrate market is forecast to register a surplus this year and next before entering supply tightness from 2025, mainly due to a production ramp-up at the Canadian miner Teck Resource's Quebrada Blanca Phase 2 copper project.

images.alt_text:
Copper wires are sorted in order to be put through a machine which compacts the copper into bales which can then be transported and recylcled by third parties. The factory that does this is Tsing Yi Enterprises at
Sungei Kadut Street 3.

site_title: Arm and Instacart add to losses after lukewarm analyst reports
summary: Arm Holdings and Instacart's stocks fell on Friday after receiving lukewarm analyst ratings, deepening their recent losses. Arm's shares dropped 1.7% to $51.23, while Instacart's fell 2.1% to $30.02, both below their initial public offering (IPO) prices. Analysts at BTIG and Susquehanna assigned "neutral" ratings, citing heavy competition and lower margin revenue, further fueling doubts about a revival in IPOs after an 18-month drought.

images.alt_text: Arm Holdings shares closed at US$55.17 on Tuesday, after touching a high of US$69 on Friday.

A screen displays the logo of Softbank's Arm, chip design firm, during the company’s initial public offering (IPO) at Nasdaq Market site in New York, U.S., September 14, 2023. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid
Instacart's IPO was priced at US$30 per share after the company marketed it with a range of US$28 to US$30 per share.

site_title: Stronger investment curbs are needed to counter China, McCaul says
summary: US Foreign Affairs Committee Chairman Michael McCaul says stronger investment curbs are needed to counter China, citing recent breakthroughs in Chinese technology. McCaul proposes tightening restrictions on US firms' investments in China beyond President Biden's earlier proposals. He suggests imposing sanctions on individual Chinese firms and curbing spending on a sector-wide basis, including semiconductors, AI, and quantum computing. McCaul's efforts come after Huawei's success in releasing a premium smartphone powered by an advanced Chinese-designed chip.

images.alt_text: Huawei has in recent weeks unveiled new smartphones that use advanced chips, which analysts say are domestically made.
Huawei currently accounts for 59 per cent of Germany’s 5G RAN networks, according to a survey by  telecommunications consultancy Strand Consult.
“We don’t have any evidence that they can manufacture seven-nanometre (chips) at scale,” US Secretary of Commerce Gina Raimondo says at a US House hearing.

site_title: Central banks in no rush to cut interest rates
summary: Central banks, including the US Federal Reserve, Bank of England, and others, have signaled that interest rates will remain high for a while, with few cuts expected in the near future. Despite a slight decline in UK inflation, the Bank of England paused rate hikes, and the US Fed left room for another increase before year-end. This firm stance reflects a compromise between growth and inflation, leaving uncertainty about the level of inflation next year.

images.alt_text: British homeowners are struggling with rising mortgage rates.
The decision to hold rates is consistent with BI’s stance to ensure inflation stays within target range in 2023 and 2024, BI governor Perry Warjiyo says.

FILE PHOTO: Bank of Thailand Governor Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput speaks during his first briefing on the economy and monetary policy after taking office in Bangkok, Thailand October 20, 2020. REUTERS/Chalinee Thirasupa/File Photo

Eli Remolona, Governor of the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas, speaks at an event at the Central Bank in Manila, Philippines, on Friday, July 28, 2023. Remolona said upside risks to inflation persist, in comments that indicate the monetary authority is open to further tightening. Photographer: Lisa Marie David/Bloomberg
Philip Lowe, governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA), attends a hearing before the House of Representatives economics committee in Canberra, Australia, on Wednesday, Dec. 2, 2020.
Chairman of the Swiss National Bank (SNB) Thomas Jordan pointed to rising inflationary pressures and the danger of price increases becoming entrenched.

site_title: EU does not want to decouple from China but must protect itself: EU trade chief
summary: The European Union has no intention of decoupling from China, but needs to protect itself when its openness is abused, said Valdis Dombrovskis, EU trade commissioner. The EU posted a record bilateral trade with China last year, but it is "very unbalanced" due to a trade deficit of almost 400 billion euros. Dombrovskis is on a four-day visit to China seeking more balanced economic ties and to address tensions over geopolitics and trade. The EU is investigating Chinese-made electric vehicle imports that benefit from state subsidies, but says it wants fair competition.

images.alt_text: Huawei last month released a premium smartphone powered by an advanced chip that it designed, and which was made by Shanghai-based Semiconductor Manufacturing International.
The formation of the groups was agreed during talks in July between US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen (left) and Chinese Vice-Premier He Lifeng (right) in Beijing.

site_title: Four industrial S-Reits among best performing in the year to date
summary: Four industrial Real Estate Investment Trusts (REITs) - AIMS Apac Reit, Mapletree Logistics Trust, Mapletree Industrial Trust, and CapitaLand Ascendas Reit - are among the best performing S-Reits in the year to date, with an average total return of 9.1% and combined net institutional fund inflows of $18.9 million.

images.alt_text: S-Reits now recognise the importance of addressing environment and sustainability matters to ensure the delivery of steady distributions in the long term.

site_title: Oil ends week lower as demand concerns face Russia supply ban
summary: Oil prices ended the week lower due to concerns over demand and Russia's fuel export ban. Brent futures fell 0.3% to $93.27 a barrel, breaking a three-week streak of gains, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 0.5% to $90.03 a barrel. The decline was attributed to profit-taking and market worries over supply constraints.

images.alt_text: Brent futures for November delivery settled down 23 cents to US$93.30 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude (WTI) settled 3 cents lower to US$89.63 on Thursday.

site_title: Europe: Shares clock weekly decline as higher-for-longer rates loom
summary: Europe's pan-European Stoxx 600 index fell 0.3% on Friday, marking its lowest in over a week, amid concerns about global interest rates remaining elevated for longer. The construction and materials sector led the decline, falling 1.0%. Europe's benchmark stock index logged a weekly decline of 1.9%, as investors became risk-averse following central banks' hints to keep borrowing costs high. The decline is attributed to higher-for-longer interest rates, affecting investor sentiment.

site_title: China market gloom spurs fund managers to scour hidden gems
summary: Global fund managers are looking for value in Chinese stocks amid a market slump, with many slashing their China stock positioning to the lowest since October. Despite the market's worst performance in three years, some funds see a contrarian signal in the pessimism towards Chinese assets. They're focusing on companies like industrial-cyclical stocks, healthcare firms, and tech giants, which are undervalued and have potential for growth. Experts say the market's extreme pessimism presents opportunities for potential buying, particularly as signs of economic stabilization emerge.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view of a giant display of stock indexes, following the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak, in Shanghai, China October 24, 2022. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

site_title: Tuas water reclamation plant on track to open in 2026 amid rising costs, boosting recycled water supply
summary: Singapore's Tuas Water Reclamation Plant is on track to open in 2026, boosting the country's recycled water supply. The plant can treat 650,000 cubic meters of domestic sewage water per day and 150,000 cubic meters of industrial used water. With the current operational plants, the total treated water will be 1.97 million cubic meters daily. However, the project comes with higher costs, with PUB citing a 35% increase in construction costs, 33% increase in chemicals, and 18% increase in manpower and maintenance costs.

site_title: Sevens Atelier responds to SGX queries on CAD and MAS investigation
summary: Sevens Atelier, a Singapore property consultancy firm, has responded to queries from the Singapore Exchange Securities Trading (SGX-ST) regarding an investigation into an offence under the Securities and Futures Act. The Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) and Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) have ordered the firm to provide documents and information related to the investigation, including emails and attachments from former executives. The firm's former executive chairman and CEO, Richard Koh, and two other executives, Lim Xiu Fang and Tang Yao Zhi, have been interviewed by authorities and have not been arrested or formally charged.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Sevens Atelier is assisting the Commercial Affairs Department and the Monetary Authority of Singapore with investigations.

site_title: Goldman Sachs, Malaysia attempt fresh settlement to end 1MDB scandal
summary: Goldman Sachs and Malaysia are attempting a fresh settlement to resolve the 1MDB scandal, three years after the bank agreed to pay over $5 billion for its role in the scandal. Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim is open to negotiations, stating that a settlement is possible due to "flexibility" in discussing the deal. However, Anwar remains cautious, warning Goldman against assuming the lawsuit threat is a bluff, and has expressed dissatisfaction with the existing deal, particularly regarding the quantum and clauses.

images.alt_text: epa10134267 Malaysia's former prime minister Najib Razak (C) speaks to his supporters during a break in his final appeal trial outside the Federal Court in Putrajaya, Malaysia, 23 August 2022. The Malaysia highest court has scheduled hearings through 26 August 2022 to hear Najib's appeal of his convictions for criminal breach of trust, abuse of power and money laundering over the alleged theft of 4.4 billion Euro from 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB), a state fund he co-founded as premier in 2009.  EPA-EFE/AHMAD LUQMAN ISMAIL
Ng, 51, was convicted in March 2022 on bribery and money laundering conspiracy charges.

Roger Ng, a former banker for Goldman Sachs, permanently prohibited from performing any regulated activity under the Securities and Futures Act, and from providing any financial advisory services under the Financial Advisers Act.

Goldman Sachs in 2020 admitted to its role in the biggest foreign bribery case in US enforcement history, reaching multiple international settlements in the billions of dollars to end probes into its fundraising for 1MDB.

site_title: Xi to open Asian Games as China targets sporting glory
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping will declare the Asian Games open on September 23, marking the start of a major sporting event with over 12,000 competitors from 45 nations. The games, held in Hangzhou, are seen as a soft power exercise for China, featuring a large delegation and a packed stadium. Despite a row between India and China over accreditation, the hosts are favored to top the medals table, with a nearly 900-strong delegation. The games will feature 40 sports, including new disciplines, and are considered a success for promoting sports and development in the region.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - People gather at the promenade of Qiantang River to watch the light show of the Hangzhou Olympic Sports Centre Stadium (C), ahead of the 2022 Asian Games in Hangzhou in China's eastern Zhejiang province on September 19, 2023. (Photo by Philip FONG / AFP)

In choosing life in China, many rich 20-somethings face minute scrutiny in a precarious world. Beijing is tightening its grip on wealth as inequalities widen and China’s much-vaunted social mobility loses steam.

site_title: China Evergrande defers scheme meeting to reassess terms of proposed restructuring
summary: China Evergrande has deferred a scheme meeting to reassess the terms of its proposed offshore debt restructuring, citing disappointing sales and a need to meet creditor demands. The company, which has over $300 billion in total liabilities, had initially announced plans for the restructuring of $22.7 billion in offshore debt. The meeting was scheduled for September 25 and 26, but Evergrande now plans to reassess the terms, which require approval from 75% of creditors. This move could add to the company's woes, which have been exacerbated by a property debt crisis in China.

site_title: EU set to veto Booking purchase of Etraveli: source
summary: The European Union is expected to block Booking.com's $2.38 billion bid to acquire Etraveli Group, citing concerns over the acquisition's impact on the market for finding hotels and other accommodation online. The European Commission launched an investigation in 2022 and has since expressed multiple concerns, including worries over its impact on competitors and higher costs for hotels or customers. A decision could come as soon as Monday, with the EU warning that the deal could divert demand from cheaper alternatives and limit competition in the hotel online travel agency market.

images.alt_text: Airbnb says more travellers are coming back to cities, its traditional stronghold, with bookings for high-density urban listings up 13 per cent.
Booking reported an adjusted profit of US$11.60 per share in the quarter ended Mar 31, compared to analysts’ estimate of US$10.61 per share.

site_title: Goodyear Tire to cut 700 jobs, sell retail stores in Asia-Pacific
summary: Goodyear Tire & Rubber plans to cut 700 jobs and sell approximately 100 retail stores and fleet locations in its Asia-Pacific segment as part of a rationalization plan. The move aims to improve operating income by $50-55 million by 2025 and increase profitability in Australia and New Zealand operations. The plan, part of a broader restructuring effort, is expected to be completed by the end of 2024, with estimated pre-tax charges of $55-65 million.

images.alt_text: The company’s standalone profit rose to 336.1 million rupees for the quarter ended Mar 31, from 173.9 million rupees a year ago.
The reductions will target salaried employees, representing about 5 per cent of such positions across the company, according to a statement on Friday (Jan 27).

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint Trust to divest 143.9 million units in Malaysia’s Hektar Reit, cuts holding to 2.1%
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) is divesting 143.9 million units in Hektar Reit, a Malaysia retail-focused Reit, for RM128.1 million (S$37.4 million), reducing its holding to 2.1% of the total units. The divestment is deemed non-core to FCT's portfolio and investment strategy, with proceeds to be used for capital management and investments consistent with its core suburban retail strategy. The transaction is expected to be completed in the fourth quarter of 2023.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Changi City Point, which comprises three storeys and one basement level, has a net lettable area spanning 208,453 square feet,

site_title: More rate hikes needed to ensure ‘timely’ inflation control: Fed governor Bowman
summary: US Federal Reserve governor Michelle Bowman stated that the central bank needs to raise interest rates further to control inflation in a "timely way." She expects inflation to remain above the 2% target "at least until the end of 2025" and believes progress on inflation will be slow due to current monetary policy restraint. Bowman supported the decision to hold benchmark interest rates steady, but noted a risk that energy prices could rise further, reversing progress made. At least 13 Fed officials anticipate rate cuts by 2024.

images.alt_text: S&P Global says its flash US Composite PMI index, which tracks the manufacturing and service sectors, dips to a reading of 50.1 in September from a final reading for August of 50.2.

US stocks wobbled after the Fed meeting, with the S&P 500 ending down on the day. But worse, the big initial public offerings that hit the market in the past 10 days are dropping back to earth despite big opening day rallies.

Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell speaks during a news conference following a Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting in Washington, DC, on Sept 20, 2023. The Federal Reserve left its benchmark interest rate unchanged while signaling borrowing costs will likely stay higher for longer after one more hike this year.
US policymakers project unemployment rising to 4.1 per cent at the end of next year from 3.8 per cent now, with growth slowing to 1.5 per cent in 2024 from 2.1 per cent in 2023.
US Federal Reserve policymakers are holding the Fed’s benchmark rate at 5.25 per cent-5.50 per cent but are stressing that they will remain tough in an inflation fight they now see lasting into 2026.

site_title: Carousell well-capitalised, with ‘healthy’ narrowing of losses: CEO
summary: Carousell Singapore, a well-funded online classifieds operator, remains optimistic despite an uncertain economic climate. CEO Quek Siu Rui stated that the company has the support of long-term investors and is not considering an initial public offering (IPO) as its only option to raise capital. With a valuation of US$1.1 billion, Carousell has narrowed its losses, with Quek expecting a "healthy decline" in losses this year. The company has recently acquired several units, including Refash and Ox Street, and is integrating them into its operations, with a new headquarters that includes inspection facilities for mobile phones and luxury bags.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
E-commerce startup founded by ex-Carousell, Fave executives launches with US$36m funding
In December alone, at least 1,115 individuals were cheated on classifieds platform Carousell by fake buyers.

site_title: Goldman to pay US$6 million to settle SEC charges over deficient trading data
summary: Goldman Sachs agreed to pay US$6 million to settle US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) charges for providing deficient trading data, known as "blue sheet data." The SEC fined Goldman for failing to provide complete and accurate data, which is crucial for enforcing regulations and protecting investors. The settlement marks the latest effort by the SEC to penalize Wall Street firms for non-compliance with core record-keeping and compliance rules. Goldman said it is pleased to have resolved the matter.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher with focus on Fed speakers, economic data
summary: US stocks opened higher on Friday, September 22, driven by concerns over interest rates and anticipation of data and comments from the Federal Reserve. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 6.66 points, or 0.02%, to 34,077.08, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained, with the S&P 500 up 11.74 points, or 0.27%, and the Nasdaq up 63.19 points, or 0.48%. Investors await the Fed's next steps amid economic uncertainty.

site_title: India rice export ban fuelling risk of unrest in Asia, Africa: UN
summary: India's rice export ban has led to a surge in global rice prices, reaching their highest in nearly 15 years, and fueling concerns about food insecurity in Asia and Africa. The top shipper accounted for 40% of the global rice trade, and soaring prices are raising concerns about potential conflict or social unrest, particularly in Africa. The International Fund for Agricultural Development warns that export bans can have a significant impact on food security, particularly for the most vulnerable populations, and may lead to unrest.

images.alt_text: Erratic rains and drought in many parts of the world are hampering crops, reducing supply and driving up costs.
According to the Thai Rice Exporters Association, prices for Thai white rice 5 per cent broken, an Asian benchmark, jumped to US$648 a tonne in early August.
A rice seller in Hanoi, Vietnam. The impact of India's rice export ban has reverberated across South-east Asia.

FILE PHOTO: Farmers plant rice seedlings that are part of a breeding program for late-maturing varieties, at the International Rice Research Institute, in Los Banos, Laguna province, Philippines, January 18, 2023. REUTERS/Lisa Marie David/File Photo

Rice inflation in the South-east Asian nation has increased at the fastest pace in almost five years in August, reviving memories of a 2018 shock that led to the end of a two-decade-old limit on imports.
The Food and Agriculture Organization’s (FAO) price index averages 121.4 points in August against a revised 124.0 for the previous month.
Rice export restrictions by India have sent shock-waves across Asia, prompting worried consumers to implement measures to secure supply and contain rising food costs.
The Philippines will be the hardest hit by the recent rise in rice prices, according to a research note by OCBC Bank.

Rice for sale at a market in Mandaluyong, the Philippines, on Monday, Sept. 5, 2022. Philippines inflation rate rose 6.3% from a year earlier in August, the Philippine Statistics Authority said in a statement on its website. Photographer: Iya Forbes/Bloomberg
The threat to rice comes as shipment curbs by top exporter India and extreme weather tighten supplies globally, with prices in Asia jumping near to the highest level in almost 15 years.

site_title: Yen slumps as BOJ keeps policy ultra-loose, US dollar set for 10th weekly rise
summary: The Japanese yen plummeted to a 10-year low of 148.42 against the US dollar, driven by the Bank of Japan's decision to keep interest rates at -0.1% and the Federal Reserve's signal that US borrowing costs will stay high. Analysts expect the yen to drop further, potentially prompting government intervention. Meanwhile, the US dollar index is on track for its 10th consecutive weekly increase, fueled by rising US Treasury yields and weak economic data from France and the UK.

site_title: China’s BYD Americas chief says UAW strike ‘damages’ industry
summary: BYD Americas chief Stella Li stated that the UAW strike "damages" the US auto industry, hindering President Joe Biden's efforts to attract manufacturing investment. BYD, a Chinese electric vehicle maker, has no plans to enter the US passenger-car market but sells electric buses and has partnered with Mexican retailers and conglomerates for vehicle sales and charging stations. The company is considering constructing an EV factory in Mexico and has already launched a new vehicle in the country. Li believes Mexico's governors welcome BYD's investment and are eager to attract the company.

images.alt_text: The autoworkers’ union will expand its strike against parts distribution centres across the US at GM and Stellantis.
BYD's partnership model, similar to that pursued by Japanese carmakers in some South-east Asian countries decades ago, is helping it build market share rapidly.
Led by BYD, Chinese carmakers will almost double their share of the auto market to 33 per cent by the end of the decade, according to UBS analysts.
BYD will also announce Dolphin pricing on that date.

site_title: Sheng Siong to open 6th store in China
summary: Sheng Siong, a Singaporean supermarket company, has signed a lease agreement to open its 6th store in China, located in Kunming. The new 83,624 sq ft store is expected to be operational by the end of 2024, adding to the company's existing 5 stores in China. This marks a significant expansion for Sheng Siong in the Chinese market, but is not expected to have a significant impact on its financial performance for the 2023 financial year.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim

site_title: Canada retail sales drop 0.3% in sign of consumer slowdown
summary: Canada's retail sales dropped 0.3% in August, the first decline since March, according to Statistics Canada. The decline follows a 0.3% increase in July, which missed expectations. Higher interest rates, mortgage payment renewals, and high fuel prices are contributing to the slowdown. Economists attribute the decline to the impact of higher interest rates on consumer spending, with the Bank of Canada holding borrowing costs steady. The central bank's next rate decision is due on October 25, with most economists expecting no change.

site_title: US announces new economic working groups with China
summary: The US Treasury Department announced two new working groups with China, focusing on economic and financial policy, to stabilize relations between the world's biggest economies. The groups, agreed upon during talks in July, will discuss macroeconomic issues and regulatory stability. The formation comes after strained relations, including the downing of a US balloon by Chinese forces in February, and follows high-level contacts between the two countries. The groups will meet at the vice-minister level and report to US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen and Chinese Vice-Premier He Lifeng.

images.alt_text: Global investors are fleeing the Chinese equity market amid a slew of concerns - from China’s fragile economy to the ongoing property crisis and worsening ties with the US.
China consumer prices fell 0.3 per cent in July from a year earlier, in the first instance of deflation since the depths of the Covid pandemic in early 2021.

site_title: McDonald’s to raise royalty fees for new US restaurant operators
summary: McDonald's is raising royalty fees for new US franchise operators to 5% from 4%, starting January 1, for the first time in nearly three decades. The change aims to maintain the company's competitive edge and offer opportunities to independent small business owners and their families. Existing franchisees and those transferring or rebuilding locations will be exempt from the change. The move will not affect payments made to the company, which will be referred to as "royalty fees" instead of "service fees".

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The McDonald's company logo is seen on the front of a restaurant in London, Britain, December 10, 2021. REUTERS/May James

site_title: Intel hit with 376 million euro antitrust fine in decades-old case
summary: Intel has been fined 376 million euros by the European Union for antitrust practices between 2002 and 2006. The initial 1.06 billion euro fine was reduced to zero in 2009 but was reinstated after the European Commission found Intel illegally excluded rivals from the market. The company was accused of paying HP, Acer, and Lenovo to halt or delay rival products, and the General Court confirmed that Intel abused its dominant market position. The European Commission has appealed the ruling to the EU Court of Justice.

images.alt_text: A business publication has reported that Google executives have set a goal earlier this year to move away from Broadcom after a prolonged stand-off over the price it pays for chips.
No stock symbolizes the chip industry’s success more than Nvidia, whose shares are tripling in 2023 as the company’s market value tops US$1 trillion.

site_title: US business activity nears standstill in September, survey says
summary: US business activity nearly came to a standstill in September, with the services sector idling at its slowest pace since February and new order activity at its lowest level this year, according to a survey by S&P Global. The Composite PMI index fell to 50.1, negligibly above the 50 level separating expansion and contraction. Despite this, job growth and consumer spending remained strong, and the Fed's interest rate hike may not have triggered a recession as expected. The Fed left interest rates unchanged, but indicated borrowing costs will remain high next year.

images.alt_text: Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell speaks during a news conference following a Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting in Washington, DC, on Sept 20, 2023. The Federal Reserve left its benchmark interest rate unchanged while signaling borrowing costs will likely stay higher for longer after one more hike this year.
US policymakers project unemployment rising to 4.1 per cent at the end of next year from 3.8 per cent now, with growth slowing to 1.5 per cent in 2024 from 2.1 per cent in 2023.

Shipping containers and cranes at the Port of Savannah in Savannah, Georgia, US, on Saturday, Sept. 9, 2023. The US economy has been looking so solid lately that Federal Reserve officials will probably need to double their projection for growth in 2023 when they publish an updated outlook later this month. Photographer: Elijah Nouvelage/Bloomberg
Janet Yellen also said that surveys of companies showed that demand for labour was softer, and that was helping to bring down core inflation.
Consumer Sentiment Index drops to 67.7 this month from a final reading of 69.5 in August, according to The University of Michigan's preliminary reading.
The August reading for manufacturing was up just 0.1 per cent, “held back” by a five per cent decline in motor vehicles and parts.

site_title: Amazon says ads coming to Prime Video streaming in 2024
summary: Amazon plans to introduce ads on its Prime Video streaming service in early 2024, starting in the US, UK, Germany, and Canada, with additional countries to follow in 2024. The ad-supported offer will be available for a standard Prime subscription, with an additional fee for ad-free content. The price of the standard Prime subscription will remain unchanged. This move aims to generate new revenue as the company seeks to slow subscriber growth and combat password sharing.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Media are seen in front of an Amazon Prime Video logo during an Amazon Prime Video India launch event in Mumbai, India, April 28, 2022. REUTERS/Francis Mascarenhas

site_title: Michael Bloomberg outlines succession plan for media empire
summary: Former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg, 81, has outlined a succession plan for his media empire Bloomberg LP, stating his philanthropic foundation will inherit the multibillion-dollar company after his death. The foundation will sell the company over the first five years due to tax laws. Bloomberg holds an 88% stake in the company, which generated over $12 billion in revenue in 2022, and has no immediate plans to sell. He aims to continue working for 3-5 more years, focusing on blocking new petrochemical plants to combat climate change.
