Singapore’s planned offering is part of a bid, announced last year, to raise as much as S$35 billion of environment-focused financing by 2030.

site_title: US: Stocks drop as possible government shutdown adds to angst
summary: US stocks dropped on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 1.1% to 34,070.42, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes also falling 1.6% and 1.8% respectively. The decline was attributed to concerns over a potential US government shutdown and lofty interest rates, with the Federal Reserve hinting at further rate hikes. Large-cap companies, including Amazon, Alphabet, and Tesla, were particularly weak, while cybersecurity firm Splunk surged 20.8% after announcing an acquisition deal.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average falls 108.65 points, or 0.32 per cent, at the open to 34,332.23.

site_title: Singapore shares fall at Friday’s open, tracking global retreat; STI down 0.6%
summary: Singapore stocks opened weaker on Friday, following global retreats. The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.6% or 20.11 points to 3,182.7, with losers outnumbering gainers 78 to 19. Seatrium was one of the most active counters, losing 1.5% or S$0.002 to S$0.132. The market's decline was attributed to overnight losses on Wall Street and Europe.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Homegrown electronics brand Creative is known for products such as the SXFI Air Bluetooth headphones.

site_title: 19 Canninghill Piers units, S$26 million South Beach penthouse linked to associates of money-laundering suspects
summary: Associates of 10 foreigners arrested in a multi-billion-dollar money-laundering case in Singapore have purchased several luxury condominium units, including 19 units at Canninghill Piers valued at S$85 million. The units were bought by two foreign nationals with names matching those on the list of arrested individuals. Ten units were purchased by a single associate, while nine units were bought by two associates in different stacks. The police have issued prohibition of disposal orders for over 110 properties and 62 vehicles, totaling S$1.2 billion in estimated value.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
Assets seized or issued with prohibition of disposal orders have risen to more than S$2.4 billion in relation to the latest money-laundering probe, says the Singapore Police Force.
The recent money laundering probe has thrown the purchase of uncompleted residential units at Canninghill Piers into a limbo.

site_title: MAS to raise deposit insurance cap to S$100,000 from April 2024
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will raise the maximum deposit insurance (DI) coverage per depositor to S$100,000 from S$75,000, effective April 1, 2024. This increase is in response to feedback on a consultation paper issued in June, with MAS noting that the current cap already covers 91% of insured depositors. The decision aims to protect small depositors, while excluding foreign currency deposits to align with the aim of protecting core savings. The move is also seen as a response to global concerns over bank runs, following the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank earlier this year.

images.alt_text: Mia Pei
Generic picture of Singapore financial buildings landscape
The D-SII framework comes into effect on Jan 1, 2024 to facilitate the annual impact assessment of insurers based on their size, interconnectedness, substitutability and complexity.
MAS said that the move was not in response to stresses faced by some banks abroad this year.

site_title: Brokers’ take: CGS-CIMB upgrades China Sunsine to ‘add’ as outlook brightens
summary: Brokerage firm CGS-CIMB upgraded its rating on China Sunsine Chemical to "add" from "hold" due to a 21% month-on-month increase in rubber accelerator prices, driven by rising raw material costs and increased utilisation from domestic tyre producers. The company is expected to achieve half-on-half improvement in H2 gross profit margins, reaching 24.6%, and its FY2024 earnings-per-share estimates were raised by 9-10%. The target price was set at S$0.47, representing 60% of the research house's book value estimate, considered undemanding at current valuations.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Tyre-makers have also been hit by China's Covid-19 control measures.

site_title: Australia confirms budget surplus in 2023, first in 15 years
summary: Australia has recorded its first budget surplus in 15 years, with an underlying cash surplus of A$22.1 billion in the 12 months through June 2023. The surplus was driven by an ultra-tight labor market and elevated commodity prices. However, the government expects the books to slip back into the red as mineral prices retrace and monetary policy tightens, pushing up unemployment. Treasurer Jim Chalmers attributed the surplus to the government's responsible budget management, which has taken pressure off inflation and interest rates.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This picture taken on February 22, 2015 shows Rupert Murdoch arriving at the 2015 Vanity Fair Oscar Party in Beverly Hills, California. - Media mogul Rupert Murdoch admitted in a deposition that hosts on his Fox News network promoted the false claim that the 2020 election was stolen from Donald Trump, court documents show. (Photo by ADRIAN SANCHEZ-GONZALEZ / AFP)
Qantas is facing a regulatory lawsuit accusing it of breaching consumer law by selling fares for 8,000 flights that were cancelled in mid-2022.

Flavio Macau, associate dean of School of Business and Law at Edith Cowan University, says what the government is doing is bringing more money into the market, which is not a bad thing, but it’s not bringing more capacity to the market.

After sharply cutting rates to an all-time low of 0.1 per cent to stimulate growth during the pandemic, the RBA has commenced 400 bps of rate hikes to an 11-year high of 4.1 per cent in little over a year.

site_title: Japan’s Aug inflation stays above BOJ target for 17th month
summary: Japan's core consumer price index, excluding volatile fresh food and fuel costs, rose 3.1% in August from a year earlier, staying above the Bank of Japan's 2% target for a 17th consecutive month. This steady inflation rate suggests broadening price pressure, potentially leading to an exit from ultra-easy monetary policy. The Bank of Japan concludes its policy meeting on Friday, with markets focusing on hints from Governor Kazuo Ueda on when the central bank might phase out stimulus.

site_title: US soft landing is unlikely, former Federal Reserve officials Kohn, Warsh say
summary: Former Federal Reserve officials Donald Kohn and Kevin Warsh expressed disagreement on whether the US central bank can achieve a "soft landing" of the economy. Policymakers project a 4.1% unemployment rate by the end of 2024, with growth slowing to 1.5% in 2024. Kohn suggests raising interest rates, while Warsh warns against further rate hikes, citing rates may have already peaked. The Fed's decision to leave policy unchanged on Wednesday, despite signaling a potential rate increase later this year, has sparked uncertainty about the central bank's next move.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - People walk before the United Nations headquarters and the city skyline of New York, in Queens on September 19, 2023, during the 78th United Nations General Assembly. (Photo by Ed JONES / AFP)

site_title: Japan’s Daikin says new UK net zero plan will undermine investment and growth
summary: Daikin, the world's largest air conditioning manufacturer, says UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's new net zero plan will undermine investment and growth, making it harder to achieve Britain's goal of becoming a net zero carbon economy by 2050. The plan slows the transition to heat pumps from gas boilers and excludes hybrid systems, which Daikin claims will have a significant impact on green jobs and foreign investments. The company's residential sales manager, Henk van den Berg, stated that the policy update will undermine confidence and hinder the growth of green jobs.

images.alt_text: “We’re going to ease the transition to electric vehicles. You’ll still be able to buy petrol and diesel cars and vans until 2035,” says Britain's Prime Minister Rishi Sunak .

(FILES) Britain's Prime Minister Rishi Sunak leaves 10 Downing Street in central London on July 19, 2023 on his way to take part in the weekly session of Prime Minister's Questions (PMQs) in the House of Commons. The UK government said on July 31, 2023, it would issue "hundreds" of new oil and gas licences in the North Sea to secure energy reserves while still aiming for net zero carbon emissions by 2050. (Photo by JUSTIN TALLIS / AFP)

British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's comments follow British media reports that he was set to water down plans to phase out gas boilers from 2035 and delay the ban on the sale of new petrol and diesel cars due in 2030.

site_title: YouTube announces AI-enabled editing products for video creators
summary: YouTube is introducing AI-enabled editing products for video creators, including Dream Screen, a tool that uses generative AI to add video or image backgrounds to short-form videos. The company also announced new AI-powered production tools for editing both short- and long-form videos. These features aim to attract more users and creators to the platform, competing with TikTok and Instagram Reels, and provide creators with tools for AI-powered insights, automatic dubbing, and music assistance.

images.alt_text: Google says that the new features will let people look up flight information, map routes and watch relevant videos – all from one ongoing chat with Bard.
YouTube has signed up Universal Music as its first partner for the Incubator, and will work with artistes including Anitta, ABBA’s Björn Ulvaeus, and Max Ricther.
YouTube had in April introduced new features for its premium users including letting them host Google Meet sessions to watch videos on the platform together with other users.

site_title: Bank of England halts run of interest rate hikes as economy slows
summary: The Bank of England halted its interest rate hike run due to the slowing British economy, but stated it would continue to monitor inflation. The Monetary Policy Committee voted 5-4 to keep the bank rate at 5.25%, citing signs of impact on the labour market and real economy. The central bank cut its economic growth forecast for the July-September period to 0.1% and noted weakness in the housing market. Governor Andrew Bailey emphasized the need to ensure inflation returns to normal, despite a recent fall in inflation.

images.alt_text: “Today’s news shows the plan to deal with inflation is working – plain and simple,” says UK finance minister Jeremy Hunt.

site_title: Cisco beefs up cybersecurity play with US$28 billion Splunk deal
summary: Cisco Systems agreed to buy cybersecurity firm Splunk for approximately $28 billion, representing a 31% premium to Splunk's last closing price. The deal aims to boost Cisco's software business and capitalize on the rising use of artificial intelligence. The acquisition is expected to accelerate revenue growth and gross margin expansion at Cisco, with the deal set to close by the end of 2024, subject to regulatory approvals.

images.alt_text: Cisco’s gross margin has been a bright spot. I
Cisco is a major supplier of networking equipment including ethernet switches, which connect devices such as computers, laptops, routers, servers and printers to a local area network.

site_title: US existing home sales fall in August; house prices rise
summary: US existing home sales fell 0.7% in August to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.04 million units, missing economists' forecasts. Tight supply and rising mortgage rates boosted home prices, with the median existing house price increasing 3.9% to $407,100. Sales declined in the South and West, while the Midwest and Northeast saw slight increases. Home resales dropped 15.3% year-over-year, and homebuilder confidence slumped to a five-month low in September.

images.alt_text: Shipping containers and cranes at the Port of Savannah in Savannah, Georgia, US, on Saturday, Sept. 9, 2023. The US economy has been looking so solid lately that Federal Reserve officials will probably need to double their projection for growth in 2023 when they publish an updated outlook later this month. Photographer: Elijah Nouvelage/Bloomberg
Federal Reserve officials are gathering on Tuesday for a two-day meeting that could see them raise rates again to lower inflation sustainably back to a two per cent target.
Consumer Sentiment Index drops to 67.7 this month from a final reading of 69.5 in August, according to The University of Michigan's preliminary reading.
The August reading for manufacturing was up just 0.1 per cent, “held back” by a five per cent decline in motor vehicles and parts.

With inflation still above its 2 per cent target and economic growth solid, US central bankers probably will retain a bias towards tighter policy at their Sep 19-20 meeting even as they hold rates steady.
The Commerce Department says the unchanged reading in business inventories follows a 0.1 per cent dip in June.
FILE PHOTO: A worker pours hot metal at the Kirsh Foundry in Beaver Dam, Wisconsin, U.S., April 12, 2018. Picture taken April 12, 2018.  REUTERS/Timothy Aeppel

site_title: China VP warns at UN of ‘strong will’ on Taiwan
summary: China's Vice-President Han Zheng warned at the UN of Beijing's "strong will" on Taiwan, emphasizing the country's sovereignty and territorial integrity. He reiterated China's stance that Taiwan is an "inalienable part" of China, while expressing a preference for peaceful reunification. Han also spoke on Ukraine, calling for a "cessation of hostilities" and a resumption of peace talks. The comments come amid concerns that China is preparing to seize Taiwan by force, with US officials voicing alarm over China's military buildup.

images.alt_text: epa10875595 China's Vice President Han Zheng speaks during the 78th session of the United Nations General Assembly at United Nations Headquarters in New York, New York, USA, 21 September 2023.  EPA-EFE/SARAH YENESEL

site_title: South Korea lawmakers vote to pave way for opposition leader’s arrest
summary: South Korea's opposition-controlled parliament voted 149-136 in favor of allowing prosecutors to serve an arrest warrant against Democratic Party leader Lee Jae-myung, who faces bribery and breach of duty charges. Lee will now face court to contest his arrest. The motion was accepted with six abstained votes and four invalid votes.

images.alt_text: House prices rose 0.29 per cent in the capital, Seoul, and 0.30 per cent in the greater capital area in August; both rose 0.15 per cent in July.

FILE PHOTO: A currency dealer works in front of an electronic board showing the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) at a dealing room of a bank in Seoul, South Korea, March 13, 2020. REUTERS/Kim Hong-Ji
The Korean Railway Workers’ Union is seeking improved pay and working conditions and an expansion of the KTX bullet train services to include lucrative routes to southern Seoul.
Growing household debt is one reason the BOK has kept a tightening bias while holding its policy rate at a restrictive level.

Protestors shout slogans during a rally in front of the Japanese Embassy in Seoul to call on the Japanese government; the government has launched a voucher programme offering up to 20,000 won to shoppers who buy seafood.

site_title: Europe: Shares slide as hawkish central banks spark interest rate jitters
summary: European shares slid 1.3% on Thursday due to rising bond yields and central banks' hawkish stance on interest rates. The Stoxx 600 index fell, with travel and leisure stocks down 3.2% and mining stocks 2.6%. Euro zone bond yields reached multi-month highs, while the UK's FTSE 100 lost 0.7%. Despite some positive individual stock performances, the overall market trend was downward, with the European Central Bank's governing council member indicating that interest rates may remain stable.

site_title: Rupert Murdoch steps down as chairman of Fox, News Corp
summary: Rupert Murdoch, 92, has stepped down as chairman of Fox Corp and News Corp, ending a 7-decade career in media. His son Lachlan Murdoch will become the sole chairman of News Corp and continue as chair and CEO of Fox. Murdoch scrapped a plan to merge Fox and News Corp, which would have reunited his media empire. He will be appointed chairman emeritus of both companies.

site_title: Nvidia, other US chip stocks stall over valuation, industry worries
summary: US chip stocks, including Nvidia, have stalled after a strong 2023 rally, with shares declining amid concerns over steep valuations, rising Treasury yields, and industry worries. The Philadelphia Semiconductor index has dropped 7% this month, while Nvidia's shares have declined 14% in September. Industry-specific issues, such as tensions between the US and China over semiconductors, are also weighing on the group. Despite some chip stocks sitting on substantial gains for the year, investors are advised to look for dividend-paying companies with strong balance sheets trading at reasonable valuations.

images.alt_text: Nvidia is projected to generate about US$38 billion in free cash flow in fiscal 2025.
As Nvidia has grown stronger in the market for chips that work with massive amounts of language data, the harder it has become for companies attempting to build competing chips.

Cutting out intermediaries like Nvidia, AMD, and Intel allows companies to optimise chips specifically for their unique tasks whether it’s streaming videos, serving up search queries, or managing massive databases.

site_title: Eurozone consumer confidence falls to -17.8 in September
summary: Eurozone consumer confidence plummeted to -17.8 in September, down 1.8 points from August, according to the European Commission. This marks a significant decline, exceeding economists' expectations of a fall to -16.5. In the European Union as a whole, consumer sentiment also decreased by 1.6 points to -18.7.

site_title: US current account deficit narrows in Q2
summary: The US current account deficit narrowed to $212.1 billion in Q2, a 1.1% decrease from the previous quarter, its lowest level since 2021. The deficit was offset by surpluses in services and primary income, with exports of goods and services increasing and imports decreasing. The decline in both exports and imports was largely driven by a decrease in industrial supplies and materials, primarily petroleum and products. The deficit remains large but has no impact on the dollar due to its status as the reserve currency.

images.alt_text: Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell speaks during a news conference following a Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting in Washington, DC, on Sept 20, 2023. The Federal Reserve left its benchmark interest rate unchanged while signaling borrowing costs will likely stay higher for longer after one more hike this year.

site_title: Noa Lounge’s colourful Mediterranean fare brings in the chi-chi crowd
summary: Noa Lounge, a Mediterranean restaurant at the Mondrian hotel in Singapore, has attracted the "chi-chi crowd" with its colorful fare. Chef-owner Alain Devahive brings solid cooking to the trendy F&B enclave. The restaurant features a unique bar with ceiling-high shelves of alcohol and offers appetizers such as muhamarra, smoked sea bass carpaccio, and hummus. Critics praise the combination of earthy chickpeas and briny sardines in the hummus. Noa Lounge is now open for lunch and dinner from Wednesday to Sunday.

images.alt_text: Meta's new minimalist interiors.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as hawkish Fed lifts yields, growth stocks fall
summary: US stocks opened lower on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 108.65 points, or 0.32%, to 34,332.23. This followed the Federal Reserve's signal of another potential rate hike this year, which knocked down growth stocks. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also fell, with the S&P 500 down 27.84 points, or 0.63%, and the Nasdaq Composite down 141.07 points, or 1.05%. The decline was attributed to a jump in Treasury yields.

site_title: EC World Reit extends trading suspension, needs time to ‘resolve uncertainties’
summary: EC World Reit has extended its trading suspension until it resolves uncertainties about its financial position. The Reit's manager cited concerns about current liabilities exceeding assets by S$117.9 million and S$133.2 million, as well as outstanding borrowings and overdue rent receivables. The suspension will give the Reit time to work on resolving these issues, ensuring that unitholders have sufficient information to make informed decisions. The manager will provide updates on developments and will seek to lift the suspension when it is appropriate.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Fu Heng e-commerce warehouse in Hangzhou, owned by EC World Reit. The China-focused Reit has fully repaid its onshore interest expenses due on Sep 20.

site_title: Formula 1 champion Lewis Hamilton co-designs IWC chronograph watch
summary: Lewis Hamilton co-designs IWC's limited-edition Portugieser Tourbillon Rétrograde Chronograph watch, the third special-edition IWC design by Hamilton since 2014. The watch features a teal-colored dial with 12 diamond hour markers, a platinum case, and a sapphire crystal back showcasing the IWC-manufactured 89900-calibre automatic movement. The watch incorporates three complications, including a chronograph function and a retrograde date display, and is limited to 44 pieces. Hamilton's design is a nod to his F1 racing number, with the Portugieser Tourbillon Rétrograde Chronograph set to be highly sought after.

images.alt_text: It took one Pierce Brosnan to propel the Seamaster (above) into the mainstream.

This year, Cartier has applied that concept to the Tank Louis Cartier line, upping the luxe quotient in the process. The red (Cartier calls it Bordeaux) and green lacquered dials are now borne on yellow gold cases, giving them a resolutely vintage vibe.

site_title: Tesla proposes building battery storage factory in India: sources
summary: Tesla has proposed building a battery storage factory in India, aiming to support the country's growing demand for electric vehicles and renewable energy systems. The proposal, submitted to Indian officials, includes the "Powerwall" system, which can store power from solar panels or the grid for use at night or during outages. Despite initial enthusiasm, Indian officials have expressed concerns over the high cost of the system and have suggested that Tesla work on reducing prices to make the products more competitive. The proposal's fate remains uncertain, but Tesla is keen to expand its presence in India beyond electric vehicles.

images.alt_text: Tesla and India reopened dialogue in May following a year-long impasse.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims unexpectedly fall
summary: US jobless claims unexpectedly fell to 201,000 for the week ended Sept 16, below economists' forecasts of 225,000. The decline may be short-lived due to a partial strike by the UAW union affecting automobile manufacturers. The labour market remains tight, with claims in the lower end of their range for the year. The Federal Reserve held interest rates steady, but a further rate increase is projected by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: US Federal Reserve Board Chairman Jerome Powell takes questions from the media during a press conference following a Federal Open Market Committee meeting, at the Federal Reserve in Washington, DC, USA, on Sep 2023. Even his optimistic statements sounded gloomy.

site_title: Stylish bars in Asia to swing by
summary: In Asia, stylish cocktail bars offer a unique experience for travelers. Four notable bars include Folklore in Tokyo, specializing in traditional Japanese beverages, and Upstairz Bar in Osaka, featuring modern design and Japanese whisky. The Aubrey in Hong Kong boasts stunning views of Victoria Harbour, while Nuss Bar in Bangkok combines local ingredients and unique decor. These bars offer a taste of their respective cities, with elegant settings and creative cocktails that cater to solo and group travelers, including those seeking a relaxing evening after a long day.

site_title: Chevron accepts arbitration terms in dispute at Australia LNG plants
summary: Chevron has accepted the Fair Work Commission's (FWC) terms to resolve a dispute with unions over pay and conditions at two liquefied natural gas (LNG) projects in Australia. The deal could end work stoppages at the Gorgon and Wheatstone LNG operations, which supply around 7% of the global LNG market, and potentially ease rising gas prices. The FWC had strongly recommended the parties accept its proposals to end work stoppages, and Chevron has informed the commission of its acceptance.

images.alt_text: Chevron Australia said despite “meaningful negotiations” this week, unions continued to ask for terms well above industry standards.

site_title: Qantas chairman refuses to quit amid investor pressure
summary: Qantas chairman Richard Goyder has refused to step down despite investor pressure following a regulatory lawsuit accusing the airline of breaching consumer law by selling fares for 8,000 cancelled flights in mid-2022. The company's CEO Alan Joyce has already resigned, and major investors want Goyder to continue as chairman, citing confidence in the Qantas board. The competition regulator's allegations have sparked concerns over Qantas' consumer protection practices.

images.alt_text: Alan Joyce, chief executive officer of Qantas Airways Ltd., speaks during a news conference in Sydney, Australia, on Thursday, Aug. 24, 2023. Qantas ordered dozens more long-range Boeing Co. and Airbus SE jets in a bid to keep pace with a post-pandemic travel boom that's delivering record profits. Photographer: Lisa Maree Williams/Bloomberg
Qantas is seeking an extension for the alliance with China Eastern, which allows the two companies to coordinate passenger and cargo movement between Australia and China.

site_title: Moody’s revises outlook on four Chinese real estate firms to ‘negative’
summary: Moody's has revised the outlook on four Chinese real estate firms to "negative" from "stable", citing uncertainties over their ability to achieve stable operating performance and credit metrics. This change reflects mounting debt in the country's property sector, which is struggling with growth-related challenges. The rating agency's action comes just a week after it revised the outlook on the country's property sector to "negative".

images.alt_text: A construction site of residential buildings by Chinese developer Country Garden is pictured in Tianjin, China August 18, 2023. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang

site_title: Azerbaijan attack stirs fears of new war in Europe’s backyard
summary: Azerbaijan launched a military offensive on Armenian positions in the separatist region of Nagorno-Karabakh, sparking concerns of a new war in the EU's backyard. The conflict began after weeks of negotiations, and a shaky ceasefire was agreed on Wednesday. The situation has significant implications for European energy security, following Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Azerbaijan, rich in oil and natural gas, has been strengthened by its ties with the EU, but its authoritarian regime has raised concerns. Russia's role in the conflict remains unclear, with some speculating that President Putin may be trying to force a change in Armenia's policy or regime.

images.alt_text: (FILES) A view of an Azerbaijani checkpoint recently set up at the entry of the Lachin corridor, the Armenian-populated breakaway Nagorno-Karabakh region's only land link with Armenia, by a bridge across the Hakari river on May 2, 2023. Azerbaijan on July 11, 2023 temporarily shut its checkpoint at the sole road linking breakaway Nagorno-Karabakh region with Armenia, accusing the Armenian branch of the Red Cross of smuggling. Armenia and Azerbaijan have fought two wars over the mountainous enclave of Karabakh that left tens of thousands dead. Moscow brokered a ceasefire after the latest bout of fighting in 2020 and posted peacekeepers along the Lachin corridor. (Photo by Tofik BABAYEV / AFP)

site_title: Pound, Swiss franc slide as central banks pause hikes; US dollar holds firm
summary: The pound and Swiss franc fell to their lowest levels in months as central banks paused interest rate hikes. The Bank of England kept rates steady, while the Swiss National Bank also held rates unchanged, despite inflation concerns. The US dollar rose to a 6.5-month high, with the Federal Reserve signaling a more restrictive policy stance. The yen also weakened, with the Bank of Japan expected to keep rates steady at its upcoming meeting.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Wads of British Pound Sterling banknotes are stacked in piles at the Money Service Austria company's headquarters in Vienna, Austria, November 16, 2017. REUTERS/Leonhard Foeger//File Photo

site_title: Thailand’s new PM vows to end the ‘free use’ of cannabis
summary: Thailand's new Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin has vowed to restrict the use of marijuana for medical purposes, aiming to rewrite the law and regulate cannabis for medical use only. The move comes after thousands of weed shops opened across the country since Thailand decriminalized cannabis last year. Srettha's administration seeks to address the issue within six months, amid concerns about recreational use and the economic benefits of the cannabis industry. The government's decision is seen as a shift towards a harder line on cannabis, with potential implications for the country's budding cannabis tourism and the black market.

images.alt_text: Thailand's cannabis industry is projected to be worth up to US$1.2 billion over the next few years, with thousands of businesses springing up since last year’s legalisation.

site_title: VinFast discloses revenue surge in first report since blockbuster debut
summary: VinFast, a Vietnamese electric-vehicle maker, reported a 131.2% revenue surge in its first quarterly report, driven by a fivefold increase in vehicle deliveries to domestic customers. The company delivered 9,535 vehicles in the second quarter, posting revenue of 7.95 trillion Vietnamese dong (S$450 million). Despite a net loss of 12.54 trillion Vietnamese dong, the startup's valuation reached about US$85 billion, surpassing major US automakers Ford and General Motors.

site_title: A reclusive home for a multigenerational family
summary: A 12-member, multigenerational Yeo family in Singapore has built a unique, three-storey dwelling that reflects their strong family values and personalities. Designed by architect Christina Thean, the 16,000 sq ft home features a stone-cold façade with sharp angles, but opens up to a beautiful internal courtyard and pool deck. The design allows for both family unity and individual privacy, with each sibling having their own private space. The family, who value their social lives, entertain frequently, but also prioritize their time together. The home was completed in 2021 and has been well-received by the family, who appreciate the careful balance of space and aesthetics.

site_title: Capella’s heritage star in Sydney
summary: Capella's luxury hotel in Sydney, situated in a heritage building, combines architecture, history, art, and culture. The hotel brand went through significant effort and expense to rehabilitate and repurpose the conservation property, ensuring a high-end experience for guests. The hotel's design, interior, art, restaurants, pool aesthetics, and room amenities were carefully considered to align with its luxurious atmosphere, reflecting the brand's commitment to delivering exceptional service and an immersive experience. This unique blend of heritage and luxury sets the hotel apart from others in the industry.

site_title: How does an architect build his own home?
summary: Architect Chaw Chih Wen has designed his own home to promote sustainability and connection with nature, using a 1957 intermediate terrace in Singapore as a test bed. The single-storey house features an open internal courtyard, cross-ventilation, and natural light, reducing the need for air-conditioning and artificial illumination. Chaw aimed to reintroduce retro-style mechanisms, such as ventilation blocks and sliding doors, to his design, capitalizing on the environment's ingenuity. The house has become a haven for the couple, allowing them to host friends and family, and interact with their neighbors, embodying the philosophy of "subjecting ourselves to what the environment gives us."

site_title: Canada's losing productivity streak adds to inflation problem
summary: Canada's productivity growth has been declining over the past three years, falling in eleven of the last 12 quarters, which may hinder the Bank of Canada's efforts to control inflation. With inflation rising to 4% in August, the central bank has forecast that it will return to its 2% target in the middle of 2025. Rising unit labor costs, driven by accelerating wage growth, are adding to inflation pressures, and the economy may be forced to choose between reducing headcount or tightening monetary policy further.

images.alt_text: The consumer price index rises 0.4 per cent on a month-over-month basis in August, according to Statistics Canada.

site_title: YG Entertainment shares down 13% after report of Blackpink members leaving label
summary: YG Entertainment shares dropped 13% after a report claimed that some Blackpink members are leaving the label, with only one member renewing her contract. The news sparked speculation about Thai-born member Lisa's potential solo career. The agency has stated that contract renewal talks are ongoing, but nothing has been confirmed. Blackpink recently completed a worldwide tour, performing over 60 shows. The group's future is uncertain, with fans and industry observers waiting for further updates on the situation.

images.alt_text: Blackpink members (from left: Jisoo, Jennie, Lisa and Rose) performing at the National Stadium, 13 May 2023.

site_title: Amanda Toh-Steckler: Taking on haute couture with Dior
summary: Amanda Toh-Steckler, a 51-year-old fashion enthusiast, has made a colorful splash in the style world with her eclectic ensembles. A former marathon runner and supercar collector, she prioritizes comfort, color, and context in her outfits, which often feature clean lines and bold prints. Toh-Steckler's fashion journey began 10 years ago, and she has since developed a relationship with luxury brand Dior, collaborating on a stunning haute couture gown that combines her personal style with the brand's aesthetic.

site_title: Yen’s real effective exchange rate falls to record low
summary: The yen's real effective exchange rate has reached a record low, falling 12% this year against the dollar, making it the worst performer among its Group-of-10 peers. This decline is attributed to the Bank of Japan's ultra-easy monetary regime, which has weakened the currency. The yen's drop is fueling inflation, but it's not driven by domestic demand, and its benefits for export competitiveness are waning. The central bank is expected to stand pat at its upcoming policy decision, while the government is monitoring developments and considering steps to address the issue.

images.alt_text: Japan spent more than 9 trillion yen (S$83.1 billion) intervening in currency markets last year to arrest the yen’s decline, buying yen in September and October.

site_title: Swiss central bank surprises with rate pause as tightening tames inflation
summary: The Swiss National Bank (SNB) surprised by pausing its monetary tightening, defying expectations of another interest-rate hike to avoid constriction on a stalled economy. The key rate remains at 1.75%, and policymakers led by President Thomas Jordan stated that further tightening may become necessary to counter remaining inflationary pressure. The decision widens the gap in rates with its peers and maintains a "higher for longer" stance, aligning with the Federal Reserve's outlook.

images.alt_text: Switzerland, whose banks make it the world’s biggest manager of offshore wealth, has long sought to fight its old image as a place for criminals to stash ill-gotten gains.
The year-on-year increase in consumer prices is below the 2.2 per cent rate in May and below the 1.8 per cent forecast in a Refinitiv poll.

site_title: 🍞 Let’s get that bread
summary: A job candidate shares a personal anecdote about an internship interview where they initially seemed unprepared but later impressed the interviewer by asking thoughtful questions. The lesson learned is that asking questions during an interview demonstrates interest and engagement, and is a crucial aspect of the hiring process. Experts advise researching the company, anticipating and preparing responses to common questions, and practicing with a friend or recording oneself to deliver confident answers.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore is deemed South-east Asia's most likely climate leader, according to a survey. The city-state's respondents cite sea-level rise as the top concern among climate change impacts. The Singapore government has extended the 4% interest rate floor for CPF accounts until Dec 31, 2024, and will also extend the Electric Vehicle Early Adoption Incentive scheme until 2025. Additionally, the NTUC has called for increased upskilling support for workers, including training allowances and expanded subsidies for courses.

site_title: Anime Studio Ghibli acquired as it struggles to find Miyazaki successor
summary: Studio Ghibli, the renowned anime studio behind films like Spirited Away and My Neighbor Totoro, has been acquired by Nippon Television Holdings as part of an effort to ensure its future. The network will become a 42% voting rights holder, supporting the studio's management while respecting its autonomy. The move comes after Hayao Miyazaki, the studio's leading director and visionary, declined to take on the responsibility of running the studio. The deal was made to protect the studio's ability to make films, following Miyazaki's retirement.

site_title: Russia imposes temporary restrictions on fuel exports
summary: Russia has introduced temporary restrictions on fuel exports, including petrol and diesel, to stabilize the domestic market and prevent unauthorised "grey" exports. The restrictions aim to reduce fuel shortages and prices, particularly in rural areas where fuel is crucial for agriculture. The move follows a surge in fuel prices due to maintenance at oil refineries, bottlenecks on railways, and the weakness of the rouble. The restrictions are seen as a step to mitigate a potential large-scale fuel crisis ahead of the presidential election in March.

images.alt_text: “The Saudi-Russian alliance is proving a formidable challenge for oil markets,” says the IEA.
Brent futures for November delivery fell 81 cents, or 0.9 per cent, to settle at US$93.53 a barrel on Wednesday.
Brent crude futures settled 9 cents lower at US$94.34 a barrel on Tuesday.
Global oil benchmark Brent crude futures settled 50 cents higher at US$94.43 a barrel on Monday after rising as high as US$94.45.

site_title: Unprofitable China EV maker Nio unveils phone pitched at drivers
summary: Chinese electric vehicle maker Nio has unveiled its first mobile phone, targeting its loyal customer base with a phone that syncs with Nio cars to act as a key fob, view information, and control functions. The Android-based handset will be priced from 6,499 yuan, with initial deliveries expected to be limited due to supply constraints. Nio, which has yet to turn a profit from its main auto business, aims to boost sales and bolster its balance sheet through the phone release.

images.alt_text: The Chinese company said that the notes will be its senior, unsecured obligations upon issue.

site_title: Singapore market slides after Fed’s hawkish hold; STI dips 1.2%
summary: The Singapore market slid 1.2% on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) dipping to 3,202.81 points, after the US Federal Reserve's hawkish stance signaled an incoming additional interest rate hike at the end of the year. The Fed left its policy rate range unchanged at 5.25-5.50%, the highest in 22 years. Most real estate investment trusts and banking stocks declined, while Yangzijiang Shipbuilding rose 4.2%.

Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell speaks during a news conference following a Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting in Washington, DC, on Sept 20, 2023. The Federal Reserve left its benchmark interest rate unchanged while signaling borrowing costs will likely stay higher for longer after one more hike this year.

site_title: ECB policymakers warn about stubborn inflation
summary: ECB policymakers have warned that inflation remains stubbornly high in the eurozone, with upside risks, and may only be brought under control when it consistently falls below the 2% target. Despite a pause in interest rate hikes, policymakers consider the possibility of further increases, citing core inflation remaining high. Latvian central bank chief Martins Kazaks argued that recent energy price increases create an upside risk for inflation, and rates should only be cut when inflation projections start to undershoot the target.

site_title: 20 wines under US$20: Bottles for all seasons
summary: New York Times article discusses the misconception of seasonal wine preferences, suggesting that conventional wisdom on drinking whites or reds during specific times of the year may lead to missing out on great choices. The author, Eric Asimov, prefers to drink wines based on their weight, which often correlates with color, rather than the season. He recommends exploring a wide range of wines under $20 to find the perfect pairing for any season.

Total wine production in France is expected to reach nearly 45 million hectolitres this year.

The tiny martini has been popular in the US since before the pandemic, offering drinkers a break from the cocktails which had ballooned in size in the 90s and noughties.

site_title: This is La Panthere’s world
summary: Cartier's La Panthere collection, featuring the iconic feline emblem, continues to captivate fans with its sleek and strong design. Since its introduction in 1914, the panther has evolved from abstract representations to modern, graphic creatures, representing the brand's allure and mystique. La Panthere encompasses various categories, including jewellery, watches, perfume, and accessories, symbolizing the animal's magnetism, independence, and vitality. The collection continues to enchant and inspire, solidifying its place as Cartier's signature emblem.

site_title: Game of Thrones author, other writers sue ChatGPT creator over copyrights
summary: Game of Thrones author George RR Martin, along with other best-selling fiction writers, have filed a class-action lawsuit against OpenAI, accusing the company of violating their copyrights to fuel its generative AI chatbot ChatGPT. The lawsuit claims that OpenAI used their books "without permission" to train ChatGPT's language models, endangering fiction writers' ability to make a living. The plaintiffs seek a ban on the use of copyrighted books to develop language models and damages.

images.alt_text: OpenAI said the latest version of its tool will have more safeguards such as limiting its ability to generate violent, adult or hateful content.
The Competition and Markets Authority proposed principles will underpin its approach to AI when it assumes new powers in the coming months to oversee digital markets.

site_title: Asia: Markets sink, dollar gains as Federal Reserve hints at further rate hike
summary: Asian markets plummeted on Thursday, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, Shanghai, and other markets suffering losses, as the Federal Reserve hinted at further interest rate hikes this year. The Fed's "dot plot" guide suggested another rate hike and just two cuts next year, contrary to market expectations. The dollar surged against peers, hitting a 10-month high against the yen, and oil prices fell as investors weighed the impact of higher US rates.

images.alt_text: Singapore stocks open Thursday lower; STI down 0.4%

site_title: China tests new property model in Xi’s flagship city amid crisis
summary: China is testing a new property model in the Xiong'an New District, a city built by President Xi Jinping to stabilize the housing market. The model requires all homes to be built before they can be sold, a departure from the current pre-sale system. This shift aims to reduce debt in the real estate sector and address delays in homebuilding, which have led to developer defaults. The policy is seen as a test bed for future reforms and may be applied to low-tier cities first.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A logo of Chinese developer Country Garden is pictured in Tianjin, China August 18, 2023. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo

site_title: India stops processing visas in Canada
summary: India has suspended the issuance of visas in Canada amid a diplomatic row over allegations that Indian agents were involved in the June murder of a Sikh separatist near Vancouver. The move comes after Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau demanded India treat the allegations "with utmost seriousness." India denies any involvement in the killing and accuses Canada of turning a blind eye to radical Sikh nationalists. The suspension of visas is the latest tit-for-tat diplomatic expulsions between the two countries.

images.alt_text: Hardeep Singh Nijjar (top), 45, was shot dead outside a Sikh temple on June 18 in Surrey, a Vancouver suburb with a large Sikh population, three years after India had designated him as a “terrorist”.

site_title: UK might solve its housing shortage by 2100
summary: The UK is facing a severe housing shortage, with a need for 300,000 new homes per year to meet demand. Despite this, the country has built less than any other Western European nation in the past six decades. The UK's planning system, which vests decision-making power in local councils, is a major barrier to increased supply, leading to "not in my back yard" (Nimby) phenomenon. A zoned planning system, similar to those used in Austria, Germany, and Italy, could help small developers and self-builders, but would require a national conversation among the main political parties.

images.alt_text: Rents are rising fastest in London as they catch up from a slump during the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Singapore banks step up checks on China clients with ‘investment-linked’ passports
summary: Singapore banks are increasing scrutiny of clients with Chinese passports and investment-linked passports from high-risk countries, following a crackdown on money laundering involving over S$2.4 billion. Police investigations have seized assets, including cash, cryptocurrencies, and properties, and at least 10 wealthy individuals of Chinese origin have been arrested and charged. Some lenders are reviewing new account openings and transactions, while others are evaluating whether to take fresh funds from clients with similar profiles on a case-by-case basis. The move is part of an extension of Singapore's existing anti-money laundering framework.

images.alt_text: MPs have filed various questions on the “most serious, if not the worst” money-laundering case in Singapore.
Assets seized or issued with prohibition of disposal orders have risen to more than S$2.4 billion in relation to the latest money-laundering probe, says the Singapore Police Force.
The 10 accused in the case.

site_title: Incentives for electric vehicles extended until 2025; lower rebates for some cars
summary: The Electric Vehicle Early Adoption Incentive (EEAI) scheme in Singapore has been extended until 2025, with a lower cap on the rebate for next year. Rebates for selected cleaner energy cars under the Vehicular Emissions Scheme will also be lowered, with a cap of S$5,000 for Band A2 cars. The rebate for Band A1 cars remains unchanged at S$25,000. The changes aim to encourage the adoption of cleaner energy cars while ensuring the schemes remain progressive.

images.alt_text: More electric heavy goods vehicles (eHGVs) will enter the Singapore market in 2023, but incentives and infrastructure developments are needed to boost adoption.

Under new CEO Koji Sato, Toyota in June announced an ambitious plan to ramp up battery EVs, a big shift after years of criticism that the maker of the industry-leading hybrid Prius was slow to embrace fully electric technology.

site_title: UBS cuts nearly 70% Credit Suisse researchers in Hong Kong: sources
summary: UBS has cut around 70% of the Hong Kong-based staff headcount at Credit Suisse's securities research unit as part of its integration process. The move will absorb Credit Suisse's Securities Research service into UBS's own research operations, with less than 10 researchers focusing on Hong Kong and China equities joining the UBS team. Two former Credit Suisse managing directors, Charles Zhou and Kenneth Fong, are among those joining UBS, bringing some junior researchers with them.

images.alt_text: Although UBS completed the takeover of Credit Suisse in June, it still needs approvals from regulators in markets where both banks operate to complete the process.

UBS’ assets are now about twice the size of the Swiss economy after the government-brokered takeover of its former rival Credit Suisse, raising concerns that the bank will be too big to rescue.
UBS plans to cut more than half of Credit Suisse’s 45,000-strong employee base.
UBS has begun fully integrating its former rival just months after it finalised a historic deal that came after Credit Suisse almost collapsed in March.
Like UBS, Credit Suisse was listed among 30 international banks deemed too big to fail because of their importance in the global banking architecture.
UBS is set to eliminate a few hundred roles that include relationship managers in Hong Kong and Singapore, the majority within teams newly acquired from Credit Suisse.

site_title: Brewer AB InBev signals new focus on Michelob Ultra amid light beer rivalry
summary: Anheuser-Busch InBev has elevated Michelob Ultra to the status of "global brand" in an effort to compete with Dutch rival Heineken, according to an investor presentation. The move comes as light beers gain traction due to growing consumer demand for low-calorie options. The company now sees Michelob Ultra as a major player, while positioning Corona as its "leading horse" globally and focusing on its alcohol-free version, Corona Cero. This shift in focus aims to capitalize on the growing light beer market.

The revolutionary tipple, developed at Fritsche’s brewery in the German town of Neuzelle, was made with just two ingredients: powder and water.
Heineken stuck to its outlook for adjusted operating profit to grow organically by mid- to high-single digits this year.

site_title: Vietnam's VinFast to deliver EVs to Europe this year as EU probes China rivals
summary: Vietnamese electric vehicle maker VinFast plans to deliver 3,000 of its VF8 crossovers to France, Germany, and the Netherlands in the fourth quarter of this year, following regulatory approval. This expansion represents a four-fold increase from its previous target and comes as the European Union considers imposing tariffs on Chinese EV makers, creating a possible gap in the market. The move could make VinFast's cars more competitively priced if punitive duties on China-made EVs are imposed.

images.alt_text: The Government is extending the Electric Vehicle Early Adoption Incentive scheme to 2025.

site_title: China approves export licences for chip materials gallium, germanium
summary: China's commerce ministry has approved export licences for gallium and germanium products, with more still being reviewed, following new export controls that took effect in August. The controls, aimed at restricting access to materials used in high-tech microchips, require exporters of dual-use items and technologies to obtain a licence. China's exports of wrought germanium rose 58% in the first eight months of 2023, while gallium shipments fell 58% over the period. The move is part of an escalating trade war between China and the US over access to these materials.

images.alt_text: Under the new rules, exporters of germanium and gallium products now need to obtain an export licence for dual-use items and technologies, meaning those with potential military and civilian applications.
Rare earth is a prized group of 17 minerals used in consumer electronics and military equipment.
The price of gallium has surged over 50 per cent since China unveiled restrictions in early July.
China accounts for 70 per cent of the world's mine production of rare earths in 2022, followed by the US, Australia, Myanmar, and Thailand, US Geological Survey (USGS) data shows.

site_title: Taiwan cuts GDP outlook on weak global demand, keeps rates unchanged
summary: Taiwan's central bank cut its 2023 economic growth forecast to 1.46% due to weak global demand, but predicted a rebound in 2024 with growth of 3.08%. The bank kept interest rates unchanged at 1.875% as inflationary pressures cool. The move follows the US Federal Reserve's decision to keep rates steady, and economists expect the central bank to maintain a cautious stance. Taiwan's economy slipped into recession in the first quarter, but returned to growth in the second quarter at 1.36% year-on-year.

images.alt_text: A silicon wafer made by Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) is arranged for a photograph at the company's headquarters in Hsinchu, Taiwan, on Wednesday, Jan. 16, 2013. site_title: China gas demand seen up 8% on economic recovery, easing fuel cost: CNOOC research
summary: China's natural gas demand is expected to grow by 8% this year to 396.4 billion cubic meters, driven by the country's economic recovery and cooling global LNG prices. Imports of liquefied natural gas (LNG) and pipeline gas are forecast to increase, with LNG imports reaching 70.79 million metric tons and pipeline gas reaching 69.5 billion cubic meters. The growth is higher than analyst forecasts and comes after a rare decline in 2022. China's total gas demand is expected to peak at 700 billion cubic meters by 2040.

images.alt_text: China's Premier Li Qiang speaks during the 26th ASEAN-China Summit at the 43rd ASEAN Summit in Jakarta, Indonesia, on September 6, 2023. Yasuyoshi Chiba/Pool via REUTERS

site_title: Hong Kong central bank leaves interest rate unchanged, tracking Fed move
summary: Hong Kong's central bank left its base rate unchanged at 5.75% as it tracked the US Federal Reserve's decision to keep interest rates steady. The US projected another rate hike by year-end and tighter monetary policy in 2024. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority noted it's premature to conclude the US rate hike cycle is complete, with the high interest rate environment expected to last. The Hong Kong dollar remains stable, and interbank rates may remain high for some time.

site_title: Economists aren’t buying Australia’s ambitious housing plans
summary: Australian governments have unveiled plans to construct 800,000 new homes over the next decade to address the nation's housing crisis. However, economists say the plans are unlikely to make a significant dent in the problem due to a supply crunch. Increased funding and demand are expected to exacerbate existing constraints on building materials, workers, and land, leading to higher prices and a shortage of affordable housing. Experts suggest that immigration levels need to be calibrated to the housing industry's ability to supply homes, and that tighter monetary policy may eventually ease supply-side constraints.

site_title: Indonesia’s parliament approves Jokowi’s  3,325.1 trillion rupiah budget
summary: Indonesia's parliament approved President Joko Widodo's 2024 budget of 3,325.1 trillion rupiah, a 64.5% increase from last year, to support economic growth and stable prices amid global challenges. The budget includes energy subsidies to address escalating oil prices and aims to reduce unemployment to 5% and poverty to 6.5-7.5%. The fiscal deficit is expected to be 2.29% of GDP, with economic growth forecast at 5.2% in 2024.

site_title: NTUC calls for allowance, paid time off to attend courses
summary: NTUC has called on the government to provide more support for workers to upskill and reskill, including training allowances and paid time off for courses. The union recommends employers offer skills allowances and protected time off for self-initiated training. NTUC secretary-general Ng Chee Meng emphasized the need for career development support, citing worker concerns. The union's recommendations aim to boost workforce development and adaptability in Singapore's competitive job market.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
NTUC secretary-general Ng Chee Meng calls on stakeholders, including employers and the government, to support workers managing work and caregiving.
Minister for Transport Dr Tan See Leng encourages retailers to adapt to shifting consumer demands.

MOM and MTI will closely monitor indicators of shortage for each occupation and track local graduate outcomes for the SOL occupations.

site_title: Philippines extends rate pause to shield growth as prices jump
summary: The Philippine central bank maintained its benchmark interest rate at 6.25% for a fourth consecutive meeting, defying expectations of a potential quarter-point increase. This decision aims to shield the country's growth from rising inflation, which is driven by food supply shocks, particularly rice prices. The economy expanded slower than expected in the last quarter, and the Asian Development Bank has downgraded its growth forecast to 5.7% for this year. The decision is seen as a response to India's export restrictions and domestic traders' hoarding of rice, which have pushed up prices.

site_title: Indonesia central bank holds rates, keeps focus on rupiah
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, left its benchmark interest rate at 5.75% in its latest monthly meeting, maintaining its stance to keep inflation within the 2-4% range. Governor Perry Warjiyo said the decision aligns with the bank's commitment to bolstering the rupiah to counteract imported inflation and mitigate global financial market volatility. The bank anticipates the Federal Reserve will raise its benchmark interest rate in November, which may pressure foreign capital flows and necessitate a policy response.

images.alt_text: Last week, the central bank announced that it would hold twice weekly auctions of Bank Indonesia Rupiah Securities.
Bank Indonesia can sufficiently anchor the rupiah through its “Operation Twist” bond market interventions, propping up short-term yields to lure inflows, according to governor Perry Warjiyo.
Like many of its Asian peers, BI was forecast to start cutting rates in the first quarter of 2024.
BI governor Perry Warjiyo says monetary policy remains focused on ensuring inflation stays within target and the rupiah currency remains stable.

site_title: Tech stocks, bond yields could see upside on hawkish US Fed stance
summary: The US Federal Reserve maintained its hawkish stance, keeping interest rates unchanged and signaling a tighter monetary policy. This move is expected to boost bond yields and growth sector equities, with tech stocks potentially seeing gains due to valuation re-rating. Analysts from various firms, including DBS, JPMorgan, and Nomura, remain optimistic on the long-term outlook for the markets, citing the potential for rate cuts and a sustained economy.

site_title: Gloomy predictions from Fed chair Powell mean no future shocks
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell delivered a stern warning to investors, predicting a prolonged struggle to control inflation and potentially a recession. Despite leaving interest rates unchanged, Powell's comments emphasized the need for further rate hikes to rein in strong economic activity. The central bank now forecasts one more rate increase this year and reduced expectations for rate cuts in 2024. Powell's message was seen as "hawkish pause," with the policy-sensitive two-year Treasury yield closing at a 17-year-high, and the S&P 500 falling 2% from its peak.

site_title: Gold prices dip as US Fed hardens hawkish policy stance
summary: Gold prices fell 0.1% to $1,927.63 per ounce, while US gold futures dropped 1% to $1,947.80, as the US Fed signaled another rate hike and reduced expectations of monetary policy easing. The Fed's hawkish stance, combined with a strong US dollar and rising bond yields, led to downward pressure on gold prices. The US dollar index reached its highest level since March 9, and two-year Treasury yields hit a 17-year high.

images.alt_text: Spot gold was steady at US$1,930.51 per ounce by 0319 GMT, holding below its highest level since Sept 5 reached on Tuesday.

site_title: Ex-Morgan Stanley prime broker plans US$3 billion Asia hedge fund
summary: Kurt Baker, a former Morgan Stanley executive, is launching a US$3 billion Asia-focused hedge fund, 30th Century Partners, with plans to start trading in June 2024. The firm will have eight to 10 investment teams and focus on Asia, with India, China, and Japan as its largest markets. Baker's approach will involve diversification and a mix of strategies, including macro trading, equity arbitrage, and systematic strategies, aiming to capitalize on regional growth and diversification opportunities in a challenging macroeconomic environment.

site_title: Transition finance is a key part of Standard Chartered’s future road map
summary: Standard Chartered is focusing on transition finance as a key part of its future roadmap, driven by its commitment to reaching net-zero carbon emissions in operations by 2025 and financing activity by 2050. The bank provides innovative financing solutions, including climate risk assessment, ESG advisory, and transition finance, to support clients in decarbonizing high-emitting sectors. Standard Chartered's head of client coverage, Freddy Ong, sees opportunities in the sector and believes a people-centric agenda is necessary to unlock the full potential of its workforce, including training programs and mobility opportunities.

site_title: New Zealand second-quarter GDP expands faster than expected
summary: New Zealand's GDP expanded 0.9% in the June quarter, exceeding analysts' forecasts of 0.5%. The growth rate is higher than the 0.0% expansion in the first quarter, avoiding a technical recession. Annual growth increased to 1.8%, above expectations of 1.2%. The stronger-than-expected expansion is expected to worry the central bank, which may keep interest rates high to control inflation, potentially for a longer period than anticipated.

images.alt_text: The RBNZ projects inflation will slow to 2.7 per cent by the third quarter of 2024, from 6 per cent currently, assuming the economy contracts again.

The New Zealand government forecast a budget deficit of NZ$11.38 billion (S$9.14 billion) for the fiscal year ending June 30, 2024, larger than a deficit of NZ$7.56 billion forecast at the budget in May.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SGX, Sevens Atelier
summary: The Singapore Exchange's regulatory arm is consulting the public on proposed amendments to its Futures Trading Rules and other rulebooks. SGX shares rose 0.1% to S$9.95, while Sevens Atelier shares remained unchanged before resuming trading after a halt. The property consultancy company was ordered by the Commercial Affairs Department and the Monetary Authority of Singapore to assist with an investigation into an offence under the Securities and Futures Act.

site_title: Minimum 4% interest rates extended for some CPF accounts to end-2024
summary: The Singapore government has extended the 4% interest rate floor for Special, MediSave, and Retirement Account monies until Dec 31, 2024. This move aims to provide certainty for CPF members in the uncertain interest-rate environment. Savings in Special and MediSave Accounts will earn 4.04% interest in the fourth quarter of 2023, while Ordinary Account interest remains unchanged at 2.5%. The concessionary interest rate for HDB housing loans also remains unchanged at 2.6%. The government will continue to monitor the interest-rate environment to ensure the pegged rates remain relevant.

summary: OpenAI unveiled Dall-E 3, its latest text-to-image tool, which uses ChatGPT to generate images based on user prompts. The new version has added safeguards to limit violent, adult, or hateful content and can translate nuanced requests into detailed images. Dall-E 3 will be available to ChatGPT Plus and Enterprise customers in October. The tool also includes mitigations to decline requests for public figures or living artists' styles.

site_title: A Hong Kong property billionaire with a big family dilemma
summary: Hong Kong property billionaire Adrian Cheng is facing an existential crisis as his family's empire, New World Development, struggles with rising interest rates and China's property market woes. The company's bonds are yielding double digits, and its leverage ratio is 80%, much higher than its peers. Cheng is trying to disrupt the business by investing in luxury projects, but investors are skeptical. The family's reputation is also at risk, with a blogger accusing New World of "disguising equity as debt" and pledging away commercial projects for financing at high interest rates.

site_title: Insurtech startup bolttech raises additional US$50 million in Series B funding
summary: Bolttech, a Singapore-based insurtech startup, has raised an additional US$50 million in Series B funding, bringing its total funding to US$246 million. The new investment, led by impact investor LeapFrog, will support the company's global growth strategy, particularly in emerging markets. Bolttech plans to use the funds to expand its operations and capitalize on growing demand for insurance technology solutions.

site_title: Singapore wealth management players unfazed by money laundering probe
summary: Singapore's wealth management industry remains unfazed by the country's largest anti-money laundering operation, with authorities seizing assets worth S$2.4 billion. Industry players view the probe as a positive step, enhancing Singapore's position as a hub for the region's richest, as it demonstrates the country's strong regulatory framework and commitment to integrity. The probe is seen as a necessary measure to prevent illicit activities without stifling legitimate business endeavors.

site_title: Singapore stocks open Thursday lower; STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks opened Thursday lower, with the Straits Times Index (STI) falling 0.4% to 3,228.96. The broader market saw losers outnumber gainers 69 to 26, with 28.6 million securities worth S$41.1 million changing hands. US stocks slumped overnight following the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision, while European stocks advanced in a broad-based rally. Local banks, including DBS, UOB, and OCBC, opened in negative territory.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
The Singapore Exchange's regulatory arm is consulting the public on proposed amendments to its Futures Trading Rules and other rulebooks.

site_title: Singapore is South-east Asia’s most likely climate leader: survey
summary: Singapore is considered the most likely climate leader in South-east Asia, according to a survey by Iseas – Yusof Ishak Institute. 38.7% of respondents believe Singapore has the potential to be the region's climate leader, citing sea-level rise as the top concern. The city-state also has the highest approval ratings for its efforts to address climate change, with 69.9% of respondents saying they consider it an urgent national priority. In contrast, only 24.8% of regional respondents share Singapore's views, highlighting a "marked decline in the perception of threat urgency" in the region.

site_title: EC World Reit repays onshore interest expenses in full after tapping interest reserves
summary: EC World Reit, a China-focused real estate investment trust, has fully repaid its onshore interest expenses of around S$2.1 million after tapping into its interest reserves. The move comes as the trust's units remain suspended from trading due to an outstanding rent receivable of over 145.8 million yuan owed by its sponsor Forchn Holdings Group. There are ongoing talks between lenders and EC World Reit to address the rent issue, which the trust had previously flagged as a high risk of non-collection.

site_title: Google recruiting propels Zurich home prices past London, Paris
summary: Zurich's housing market has surged past London and Paris, with apartment prices reaching near-record levels of over 18,000 euros per square meter, driven by high demand from companies like Google. The Swiss financial hub's tight housing market has offset interest rate hikes, with prices rising 5.8% in August, the biggest increase in 16 months. This trend contrasts with other European cities, where prices are either stagnant or declining. The imbalance is attributed to Zurich's unique combination of high salaries, beautiful surroundings, and limited housing supply, making it an attractive destination for expats and locals alike.

images.alt_text: An SBB AG passenger train passes traditional hillside residential apartment buildings in Zurich, Switzerland, on Tuesday, Sept. 19, 2023. With demand in the Swiss financial hub stoked in part by a Google hiring spree, apartments in the central Zurich district are being listed at near record levels of more than €18,000 ($19,000) per square meter, more than double London. Photographer: Pascal Mora/Bloomberg
The old town of Gamla Stan in Stockholm. Swedish public housing is carefully conceptualised to be spacious and have leisure spaces such as playgrounds.

site_title: Sevens Atelier assisting CAD and MAS in probe
summary: Sevens Atelier, a property consultancy company, is assisting authorities with an investigation into an offence under the Securities and Futures Act. The Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) and Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) ordered the company to provide documents and information related to certain announcements made between 2021 and 2022, including changes in share ownership and executive appointments. The company stated it will fully cooperate with the investigation and make further announcements as necessary.

images.alt_text: SGX RegCo noted that between Apr 29 and Jul 8, a small group of accounts were responsible for over 70 per cent of the buy volume in Seven Atelier shares.

site_title: Brokers’ take: CGS-CIMB expects Yangzijiang margins to improve as ship prices rise, steel falls
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's margins are expected to improve in FY2024-25 due to rising ship prices and falling steel prices. Global newbuild containership prices have increased by around 30% since May 2021, while steel prices have retreated by about 40%. The research team raised its target price to S$1.96 from S$1.87 and maintained its "add" call on the counter. This improvement is attributed to the group's climb up the shipbuilding value chain.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
A ship under repair at a Yangzijiang shipyard in China.
Ren Letian, chief executive of Yangzijiang Shipbuilding. He said the group is looking at multiple ways to improve its operational efficiency and project management, as it has 181 vessels to deliver.

site_title: Japan to pull together pillars of economic package early next week: PM
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida announced plans to pull together the pillars of an economic package early next week, aiming to counter issues such as inflation and depopulation. The package is expected to include measures to stabilize domestic demand and accelerate economic growth. Kishida's comments follow similar remarks by newly inaugurated Economy Minister Yoshitaka Shindo, who noted positive signs emerging in the economy. The government's move aims to enter a new phase of economic growth and stability.

site_title: Toshiba says US$14 billion takeover bid by JIP has succeeded
summary: Toshiba has accepted a $14 billion takeover bid from Japan Industrial Partners (JIP), ending years of battles with overseas activist shareholders. The deal, valued at 2 trillion yen ($18.5 billion), will put the electronics-to-power stations maker in domestic hands. JIP's consortium, including 20 Japanese companies, plans to retain CEO Taro Shimada and his management team. The deal paves the way for Toshiba to pursue its long-term strategy with a stable shareholder base, resolving complex relationships with various stakeholders.

site_title: Amazon empowers Alexa with generative AI
summary: Amazon has empowered its Alexa voice assistant with generative artificial intelligence (AI), aiming to deliver complex content, such as poems or essays, in seconds with verbal commands. The move follows ChatGPT's lead and is part of Amazon's push into the AI market. The new features will be showcased as Amazon steps into the AI competition dominated by Google, Microsoft, and ChatGPT. This update is expected to streamline Alexa's technology and enhance its capabilities.

site_title: Qualcomm enters new Wi-Fi router market in deals with Charter, EE
summary: Qualcomm is entering the Wi-Fi router market with deals signed by Charter Communications and the UK's EE, starting next year. The new routers will utilize Wi-Fi 7, designed to enhance data flow in homes with multiple devices. Qualcomm's devices will also prioritize traffic from specific apps and services, while ensuring speed boosts remain after traffic leaves the carrier's network. The company's acquisition of OptiCore Technologies aims to bolster its networking capabilities.

site_title: China eases visa application process to attract foreign visitors
summary: China has simplified its visa application process to attract more foreign visitors, following the country's rebound in domestic tourism above pre-Covid levels. Applicants now only need to list recent travel history and the highest educational level reached, reducing the time spent filling out forms. The move aims to facilitate people-to-people exchanges and promote China's high-quality development and opening up.

images.alt_text: In August, China retained its spot as the top source of visitors to Singapore, followed by Indonesia, Malaysia, India and Australia.

site_title: ExxonMobil sees US$16 billion in earnings for fuels, chemicals by 2027
summary: ExxonMobil forecasts US$16 billion in earnings for motor fuels and chemicals by 2027, a US$4 billion increase from current levels. The company attributes this growth to a massive expansion of refining capacity and focus on higher margin chemicals. Executives predict petrol demand will peak later than expected, remaining at a plateau for several years. This growth is driven by rising demand and ExxonMobil's strategic investments in refining and chemicals.

site_title: SGX RegCo consults on rule changes to futures, securities trading, derivatives clearing
summary: SGX RegCo is seeking market feedback on proposed rule changes to its Futures Trading Rules, Singapore Exchange Securities Trading (SGX-ST) rules, and Singapore Exchange Derivatives Clearing (SGX-DC) rules. The changes aim to align with the new FTR and include updates on admission and registration of trading members, customer margining, automated trading, and termination of membership. The consultation period ends on October 11, with the proposed changes expected to improve clarity and readability of the rules.

site_title: China exported no germanium, gallium in Aug after export curbs
summary: China's exports of germanium and gallium products plummeted in August due to new export controls. No wrought germanium or gallium products were exported in August, a significant drop from July. The controls, implemented on August 1, require exporters to obtain licenses for dual-use items, and permit applications take 45 working days to process. Chinese spot gallium prices fell 9% in August, while germanium prices rose 1%. The controls aim to restrict the export of materials used in making high-tech microchips, amid an escalating war between Beijing and Washington.

images.alt_text: Rare earth is a prized group of 17 minerals used in consumer electronics and military equipment.

From Tuesday, exporters of these products need to apply for export licences for dual-use items and technologies – those with potential military as well as civil applications, according to China’s Ministry of Commerce.

site_title: Oil prices ease 1% after Federal Reserve warns of higher rates for longer
summary: Oil prices fell about 1% to a one-week low on Wednesday after the US Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged, but hinted at further rate increases by the end of the year, boosting hawkish expectations. Brent futures for November delivery fell 81 cents to settle at US$93.53 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude (WTI) for October delivery fell 92 cents to settle at US$90.28.

site_title: Assets involved in anti-money laundering probe balloon to S$2.4 billion
summary: Singapore's police force announced a significant anti-money laundering probe, with assets seized totaling S$2.4 billion. This includes bank accounts (S$1.127 billion), cash (S$76 million), cryptocurrencies (S$38 million), and 204 electronic devices. Prohibition of disposal orders were issued against over 110 properties and 62 vehicles, with an estimated value of S$1.24 billion. Ten foreign nationals, carrying passports from countries such as Cambodia and China, were slapped with money laundering-related charges and denied bail.

The 10 accused in the case.
