site_title: Luye Medical considers sale of oncology business in Singapore, sources say
summary: Luye Medical Group is considering selling its oncology business, OncoCare Cancer Centre, with seven clinics in Singapore, to a potential buyer worth US$300-400 million. The process is at an early stage, with preliminary interest from healthcare firms and financial investors. This move comes as demand for private medical services in Asia increases due to a rising middle class and aging population. The divestment would be part of a wave of health-care deals in the region, following similar announcements from other companies, including TE Asia Healthcare Partners and Sime Darby.

site_title: Facing fares row, Ryanair hit by new antitrust probe in Italy
summary: Italy's antitrust agency opened an investigation into Ryanair for possible abuse of a dominant market position, amid a dispute over domestic flight prices. The airline, which operates the largest carrier in Italy, is accused of exploiting its power to limit travel agencies' ability to offer accommodation and transport services. Ryanair has already reduced domestic flights to Sicily and Sardinia, citing government price caps. The airline's CEO, Eddie Wilson, welcomed the investigation, calling for transparency and considering other aspects. The probe follows a similar antitrust investigation in the UK.

images.alt_text: EasyJet’s CEO Johan Lundgren says Nats had let down airlines all through the summer and caused more than a months’ worth of disruptions.

site_title: All BTS members renew contracts with Hybe: agency
summary: K-pop sensation BTS has renewed their contracts with agency Hybe, with all seven members agreeing to remain with the label after completing their mandatory military service. The group, which debuted in 2013, has been credited with generating billions of dollars for South Korea and boosting the country's cultural image. The new contracts, which were renewed in a regulatory filing, do not disclose details on their duration or expiration dates, but it is expected that the members will remain with Hybe even after completing their 18-month military duty, potentially leading to a reunion around 2025.

images.alt_text: Riize comprises six Koreans and a Japanese aged 19 to 22.

site_title: Hunter Biden to appear in court on Oct 3 on gun charges
summary: Hunter Biden, 53, will appear in a Delaware court on October 3 to face three counts of making false statements related to a 2018 gun purchase. He had sought to avoid appearing in person, citing concerns about disrupting the courthouse arrival with his Secret Service escort. A federal judge rejected his request, stating that the defendant should not receive special treatment. The charges stem from claims made on forms that Hunter Biden was not using drugs illegally at the time of the purchase.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Hunter Biden, son of U.S. President Joe Biden, departs federal court after a  plea hearing on two misdemeanor charges of willfully failing to pay income taxes in Wilmington, Delaware, U.S. July 26, 2023. REUTERS/Jonathan Ernst/File Photo
Despite economic and foreign policy successes, Biden is faring badly in opinion polls of voters.

site_title: Amazon scraps planned merchant fee with antitrust suit looming
summary: Amazon has scrapped its planned 2% fee on merchants who don't use its shipping services, amid an escalating antitrust investigation. The fee was set to take effect on October 1 and was seen as a brazen move by Amazon to extract more money from online sellers. The decision comes as the US government is poised to file an antitrust lawsuit against Amazon, focusing on its alleged efforts to coerce merchants into using its logistics services. The move suggests Amazon is being cautious about extracting more money from merchants.

images.alt_text: Amazon director of smart home Charlie French speaks during the Amazon Devices and Services event at the HQ2 campus in Arlington, Virginia on Sept 20, 2023. Amazon previewed a push into generative artificial intelligence with new features for its Alexa voice assistant.

Instacart's IPO was priced at US$30 per share after the company marketed it with a range of US$28 to US$30 per share.

site_title: US: Stocks fall as Fed signals it may hike rates again
summary: US stocks fell as the Federal Reserve kept interest rates unchanged but signaled it could lift rates again this year, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.2% at 34,440.88. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also declined, 0.9% and 1.5% respectively, amidst uncertainty over future rate hikes. The move was seen as a surprise, with investors waiting for a clearer signal on future monetary policy.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rises 57.77 points, or 0.17 per cent, at the open to 34,575.50.

site_title: PM Sunak waters down Britain’s climate goals
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak has watered down Britain's climate goals, delaying targets for changing cars and domestic heating to ease "unacceptable costs" on households. The government will now aim to reach net zero emissions by 2050, but has pushed back the ban on new petrol and diesel cars to 2035 from 2030, and eased the transition to heat pumps. Sunak cited a lack of public support for previous rapid net zero targets as the reason for the delay, citing a potential "backlash" against the wider mission.

images.alt_text: Britain's Prime Minister Rishi Sunak delivers a speech during a press conference on the net zero target, at the Downing Street Briefing Room, in central London, on September 20, 2023. The UK looked set to backtrack on policies aimed at achieving net zero emissions by 2050 with Prime Minister Rishi Sunak expected to water down some of the government's green commitments. The move comes amid growing concern over the potential financial cost of the government's policies to achieve net zero carbon emissions by mid-century.     JUSTIN TALLIS/Pool via REUTERS

site_title: China ex-PBOC head calls for policy boost to hit 5% growth goal
summary: China's former central bank chief Yi Gang calls for increased policy support to achieve the government's 5% growth goal, citing the economy's still-recovering stage and weak confidence. Yi recommends "appropriately increasing" macroeconomic policies to boost domestic demand and promote a virtuous economic cycle. The comments come as policymakers weigh the effectiveness of measures taken to shore up growth, with economists downgrading forecasts and highlighting ongoing issues such as a property crisis. Yi's remarks come after the Politburo signaled more support for the economy's recovery.

site_title: Climate crisis has ‘opened the gates to hell’, UN chief tells summit
summary: UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres warned world leaders that the climate crisis has "opened the gates to hell" during a summit, citing rising greenhouse gas emissions and record temperatures. Despite the urgency, China and the US were absent, and Britain rolled back its net-zero policies. Greenhouse gas emissions continue to rise, with fossil fuels subsidized at US$7 trillion annually, and extreme weather events intensify. The summit's absence of major polluters and lack of concrete action raise concerns about the effectiveness of global efforts to address the crisis.

site_title: US: Wall St gains at open as yields slip ahead of Fed rate verdict
summary: US stocks rose at the open on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 57.77 points, or 0.17%, to 34,575.50. Treasury yields retreated ahead of a potential pause in the Federal Reserve's policy tightening campaign, but concerns over prolonged rate hikes kept investor sentiment cautious. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher, with the S&P 500 rising 8.86 points, or 0.20%, and the Nasdaq gaining 32.07 points, or 0.23%.

site_title: Europe’s power industry warns ageing grids risk green goals
summary: Europe's power industry has warned that to meet the EU's clean energy targets by 2030, average annual investments in electricity grids must be at least 84% higher than in 2021, requiring €584 billion per year. Much of this investment will come from private sources, while public funding should focus on upgrading grids quickly over longer-term infrastructure projects. With 40% of Europe's power distribution grids over 40 years old, upgrades are necessary to distribute power from local solar panels and wind farms.

images.alt_text: It is estimated that Indonesia’s long-term goal of decarbonising its power sector will require an investment exceeding US$200 billion over the next 10 to 15 years.

With European economies strained by higher interest rates, there are fears that some gas demand might never come back.

site_title: SGX CEO Loh Boon Chye elected new chairman of World Federation of Exchanges
summary: SGX CEO Loh Boon Chye has been elected as the new chairman of the World Federation of Exchanges (WFE) for a 2-year term. He was previously the WFE's vice-chairman. The appointments were made at the WFE's 62nd general assembly in London, with seven new board directors elected. Loh will focus on promoting the WFE's mission of fostering a transparent, collaborative, and innovative ecosystem for global financial markets, particularly in areas of market infrastructure resiliency, mutual market connectivity, and sustainability and inclusion.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
All business lines except for indices will be under Syn's purview in the new role.

site_title: Europe: Shares advance as bond yields ease ahead of Fed’s interest rate decision
summary: European shares rose 0.9% on Wednesday as government bond yields fell, with real estate stocks advancing 2.2% and the Stoxx 600 index adding 0.9% after two consecutive sessions of losses. In Britain, gilt yields declined and the pound dropped after data showed a slowdown in high inflation, potentially leading to the Bank of England pausing interest rate hikes. The US Federal Reserve is set to release its interest rate decision later, with investors expecting a decision to stand pat.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.2 per cent lower at 34,440.88 after the Federal Reserve kept interest rates unchanged but signaled it could lift rates again this year.

site_title: UAW strikes at automakers highlight skyrocketing US CEO pay
summary: The United Auto Workers (UAW) union is striking at Ford, General Motors, and Stellantis, seeking a 40% increase in worker pay over four years, mirroring the 40% rise in CEO pay at the companies in the same period. The UAW's request aims to address the growing disparity between CEO and worker pay, which has increased from under 40 to nearly 400 to 1 in the last four decades. The strikes come as President Joe Biden's economic plan aims to "make things more fair" for workers and voters, but the White House lacks leverage to stave off a potential long-term walkout.

images.alt_text: Hakeem Jeffries, Democratic Minority Leader of the US House of Representatives, walks the picket line with striking United Auto Workers members outside the Ford Motor Michigan assembly plant in Wayne, Michigan, Sept 17, 2023.

With workers at all of the Big Three coordinating strike action for the first time – including a demand for pay increases of 40 per cent over a four-year contract – the automakers could face a far more disruptive stoppage.

United Auto Workers union members gather for a rally after marching in a parade on Sep 4, 2023. The union is in contract negotiations with Ford, General Motors, and Stellantis, and the current UAW contract expires on Sep 14.

A week long strike could shave off US$480 million from GM’s earnings
The raises, negotiated in the 2019 contract with the UAW, lift the pay of the workers by US$4.33 an hour, or US$9,000 a year, according to Ford.

site_title: Rising stars in music and style
summary: The article features rising stars in music, style, and design, including Thai model-singer Mint Pattarasaya and Singaporean actor-singer Alfred Sun, who discuss the intersection of style and substance. The issue also explores architecture and interior design, highlighting a luxurious hotel in Sydney and design-centric bars in Tokyo and Bangkok. Additionally, a multi-generational family's three-storey bungalow and an architect's sustainable home are featured, showcasing how design can balance style and practicality.

site_title: The great monetisation of corporate Singapore
summary: Major Singapore companies are selling off non-essential assets to tap into the next growth cycle. Following years of diversifying their portfolios, companies like Singtel and Keppel Corp are focusing on their core businesses and monetizing assets to fuel growth. Singtel has agreed to sell a 20% stake in its regional data centre business for up to S$1.1 billion to US private equity giant KKR, while Keppel Corp has already monetized nearly S$5 billion of assets and aims to hit S$10 billion to S$12 billion by 2026. This asset monetization strategy is expected to strengthen companies' balance sheets and provide funds for new growth opportunities.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
Suresh Sundararajan, the CEO of Olam's incubation and venture building arm Nupo Ventures.
A worker at the primary sorting line at SembWaste’s Materials Sorting Facility in Tuas.
Maybank Securities cuts its price target to S$3.50 from S$3.65, while upgrading its call to “buy” from “hold” with the view that CLI’s risk-reward profile is now favourable.
This investment puts the enterprise value of Singtel’s overall RDC business at S$5.5 billion.

site_title: US Fed leaves rates unchanged, sees tighter policy through next year
summary: The US Federal Reserve left its benchmark interest rate unchanged, but signaled borrowing costs will likely stay higher for longer after one more hike this year. The Fed projects rates to fall by only half a percentage point in 2024, with the federal funds rate falling to 5.1% by the end of the year and 3.9% by the end of 2025. The central bank's main measure of inflation is projected to drop to 3.3% by the end of this year, to 2.5% next year, and to 2.2% by the end of 2025.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index, which measures the currency against a basket of rivals, is 0.1 per cent lower at 105.00.
Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell has signaled that Fed leaders would prefer to wait to evaluate the impact of past increases on the economy as they near the end of their rate-hiking campaign.
US lawmakers have until midnight on Sept 30 to reach an agreement, before funding for government services is due to dry up.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.2 per cent lower at 34,440.88 after the Federal Reserve kept interest rates unchanged but signaled it could lift rates again this year.

site_title: US dollar edges down before Fed decision, sterling falls on cooling UK inflation
summary: The US dollar edged lower on Wednesday ahead of the Federal Reserve's rate decision, while sterling slid due to increased bets that the Bank of England will pause its interest rate hikes. The US dollar index fell 0.1% to 105.00, while the pound dropped 0.23% to US$1.2364. Economists expect the Fed to keep rates unchanged, while the BOE is expected to raise rates again, but with a 25bp hike possibly marking the peak in the cycle.

site_title: Investment market seeing more buzz for office buildings, malls and hotels
summary: A growing wave of excitement is seen in Singapore's property investment scene, with investors eyeing office buildings, malls, and hospitality assets amid high borrowing costs. The Seletar Mall, a 27-story mall in suburban Sengkang, is expected to be put on the market at a guide price of S$500 million. TE Capital is in due diligence for a potential purchase of VisionCrest Commercial, a 11-storey office building in Penang Road, valued at around S$460 million. Meanwhile, Hong Kong-based Gaw Capital Partners is evaluating an offer of about S$240 million for its Hotel G Singapore.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala
Skinny yields on CBD office buildings in Singapore can be justified, as many knowledge workers spend much time working out of physical offices.

This bungalow in the Nassim Road GCB Area was completed about a decade ago. It changed hands earlier this year for S$88 million or S$3,917 psf on land area.

site_title: UK signals green policy delays to not 'bankrupt the people'
summary: The UK is delaying some of its net-zero policies to ease the financial burden on households. Prime Minister Rishi Sunak plans to push back a ban on new petrol and diesel cars to 2035 from 2030, citing a need for a "proportionate" approach to hitting net-zero emissions by 2050. The decision was met with both anger and relief from lawmakers and car companies, with some warning that delaying the ban could "bankrupt the British people". The move aims to balance environmental goals with economic concerns.

images.alt_text: British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's comments follow British media reports that he was set to water down plans to phase out gas boilers from 2035 and delay the ban on the sale of new petrol and diesel cars due in 2030.

site_title: Chevron, unions again fail to reach deal to halt Australian LNG strikes
summary: Chevron and unions failed to reach a deal to halt strikes at the company's two LNG facilities in Western Australia. Despite "meaningful negotiations," unions requested terms above industry standards. A workplace tribunal will meet on Friday to decide whether to intervene and halt the strikes, which began on September 8. The Fair Work Commission ordered talks to resolve pay and conditions disputes.

site_title: Doctors in England step up strike action over pay
summary: Doctors in England have stepped up strike action over pay, with thousands of appointments and operations postponed amid a growing pandemic backlog. The strike, involving consultants and junior doctors, is part of a broader industrial action in the UK driven by soaring inflation. The dispute with the government is over below-inflation pay rises, with hospital chiefs warning of patient safety risks. The strikes come as the UK faces its biggest cost-of-living crisis in a generation, with food, housing, and other costs spiralling out of control.

images.alt_text: Shoppers pass an entrance to a Marks and Spencer Group Plc store on Oxford Street in London, UK, on Friday, June 23, 2023. UK retail sales rose unexpectedly in May, indicating strength in the economy that the Bank of England fears may be feeding inflation. Photographer: Carlos Jasso/Bloomberg
“Today’s news shows the plan to deal with inflation is working – plain and simple,” says UK finance minister Jeremy Hunt.

site_title: China mounts defence as market swoon spurs foreign fund exodus
summary: China's central bank has vowed to maintain liquidity, while local fund managers are placating bond investors amid a debt market loss. The nation is stepping up share buybacks and paying out record dividends to revive investor confidence. Despite efforts to boost sentiment, global funds have continued to flee the mainland market, pulling 23 billion yuan from onshore stocks this month. Policymakers expect their efforts to pay off in the coming years, and analysts see the measures as a step in the right direction to avoid financial and property problems.

images.alt_text: Chinese companies may further increase their payouts after the country’s securities watchdog urged domestic companies to pay good dividends.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's international visitor arrivals dropped to 1.31 million in August, largely due to seasonal tourism demand. The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) recommended flexible work arrangements and statutory paid caregiving leave for workers with elderly family members. Vietnam's rapidly aging population has opened new opportunities for investors, while former New Silkroutes CEO Goh Jin Hian was among four charged with false trading. The police also partnered with six banks to avert scam losses of over S$17 million.

site_title: Why don’t people leave bad jobs?
summary: A report by the Low Pay Commission (LPC) in the UK found that nearly one in five minimum wage workers were underpaid in 2022, with 43 cases involving underpayments lasting two years or more. Workers often fear leaving bad jobs due to uncertainty about their next employment, limited job security, and the impact on their universal credit benefits. The LPC suggests that policies giving workers more security, such as predictable schedules and employment rights, may not lead to less flexibility, but rather make the labour market less flexible at the bottom end.

images.alt_text: Use a company-provided machine or email and the likelihood is that you are being monitored from the moment that you log on in the morning to the moment you log off at night.
More important than the amount of time you spend in the office, is what you show up in office to accomplish.

Filipino seamen at work. The country is the world's single largest supplier of such workers. They accounted for the second-highest number of nationalities affected by the illegal practice of coercing these workers to pay "fees" to be assigned work.

site_title: HSBC to make US$1 billion in funding available to climate-tech startups
summary: HSBC is allocating US$1 billion to support emerging climate-tech companies worldwide, focusing on EV charging, battery storage, sustainable food and agriculture, and carbon removal technologies. The financing aims to reduce carbon emissions and help early-stage climate tech companies scale real-world solutions. According to HSBC CEO Barry O’Byrne, access to finance is crucial for climate tech companies to succeed. This move is part of the bank's efforts to help combat climate change.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A logo of HSBC is seen on its headquarters at the financial Central district in Hong Kong, China August 4, 2020. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu//File Photo

site_title: Disney, challenged elsewhere, plans to spend US$60 billion on parks and cruises
summary: Disney plans to invest $60 billion over the next decade, doubling its previous 10-year spending on parks and cruises. The investment will generate an estimated $10 billion in profit this year, up from $2.2 billion a decade ago. However, the company's parks division faces challenges, including a potential expansion delay at Walt Disney World due to a legal battle with Florida's governor and struggles at its overseas parks. Despite these concerns, Disney's CEO has identified the parks division as a key growth engine, highlighting the company's resilience despite the pandemic's impact.

images.alt_text: The parks business has become a reliable profit engine for Disney and has helped cushion losses in the Disney+ streaming business, which is expected to become profitable only next year.
The discussions come after Disney CEO Bob Iger said in July the company could sell some of its traditional TV assets, which have struggled for years due to the rise of streaming services.
Disney+ has been losing customers to price increases, as well as collapsing demand in India after the company failed to win cricket streaming rights.

site_title: China pledges to accelerate introduction of more economic policies
summary: China has pledged to accelerate the introduction of more economic policies to consolidate its economic recovery, following better-than-expected figures in key sectors such as bank lending, industrial production, and consumption gauges. The decision was made at a Cabinet meeting chaired by Premier Li Qiang, with the goal of further opening up the economy and deepening reforms. China's $18 trillion economy is expected to continue growing, despite a wobbling property sector, as policymakers aim to maintain momentum and support business enthusiasm. The country will continue to prioritize economic growth and stability.

images.alt_text: Chinese companies may further increase their payouts after the country’s securities watchdog urged domestic companies to pay good dividends.

site_title: Ericsson bets on new software to spur 5G revenue growth
summary: Ericsson partners with Deutsche Telekom to offer network application programming interface (API) software, enabling telecom operators to generate revenue from new use cases based on mobile networks. The software, using the Vonage platform, will help developers create new features such as boosting 5G speed and preventing fraud. Revenue from mobile network APIs is predicted to grow to over $20 billion by 2028, according to telecom research firm STL Partners. Ericsson views the API business as a standalone business, aiming to make it profitable by itself.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Huawei logo is seen at its booth during the Mobile World Congress in Shanghai, China June 28, 2023. REUTERS/Nicoco Chan/File Photo
Intel has lost its lead in manufacturing the smallest and most power-efficient semiconductors to rivals such as Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing.
Ericsson has seen overall margins erode as growth now mainly comes from fiercely price competitive markets such as India rather than high-margin markets like the US.

site_title: Total to invest US$300 million in JV with Adani Green Energy
summary: TotalEnergies plans to invest $300 million in a 50-50 joint venture with Adani Green Energy, marking the first public deal between the two since fraud allegations against Gautam Adani's business empire. The investment will deepen Total's presence in India's fast-growing energy market and give Adani Green more means to develop new renewable energy projects.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of French oil and gas company TotalEnergies is seen at the company's headquarters skyscraper in the financial and business district of La Defense, near Paris, France September 14, 2023. REUTERS/Gonzalo Fuentes/File Photo

site_title: Toshiba says JIP's US$14 billion tender offer set to succeed
summary: Toshiba announces that a US$14 billion tender offer by Japan Industrial Partners (JIP) to take the company private is forecasted to be successful. The offer, launched last month, required at least two-thirds of shareholders to tender their shares. JIP's bid of 4,620 yen (S$42.59) per share would put Toshiba in domestic hands after years of battles with overseas activist shareholders. The company has received a report confirming the offer's success, paving the way for Japan's largest deal of the year.

site_title: Hot stock: Nio drops as much as 11.6% on US$1 billion notes issuance
summary: Nio's shares plummeted to a 90-day low after announcing a US$1 billion fundraising through two-tranche convertible bonds. The company plans to use the proceeds to pare debt and strengthen its balance sheet. The shares closed at US$8.80, down 11.1% or US$1.10, after the deal was priced at 3.875% and 4.625% interest rates for six-year and seven-year notes, respectively. Despite near-term share price pressure, analysts expect Nio's business to improve with stronger vehicle sales and a scheduled launch of a mid-market brand.

images.alt_text: Mia Pei
The Chinese company said that the notes will be its senior, unsecured obligations upon issue.
Nio proposes to issue US$500 million of convertible senior notes due 2029, with another US$500 million note offering due 2030.
BYD, Xpeng, Great Wall Motor and others hope dealerships will quickly help them mobilise robust sales and service networks as they try to establish reputations for quality and reliability.

site_title: Singapore shares end Wednesday little changed ahead of Fed’s rate decision
summary: Singapore shares ended Wednesday with a slight 0.04% increase, reaching 3,242 points, after paring losses during the day. The market remains cautious ahead of the US Federal Reserve's rate decision, with analysts expecting scrutiny of economic projections and policy rates. Key indices in the region were mostly down, and some stocks, such as ST Engineering, rose due to potential gains from industry demand shifts. Nanofilm Technologies' share price slipped under S$1, and Seatrium's shares closed flat.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
The SGX logo at SGX Centre 1 located along Shenton Way on March 3, 2023.
Arm Holdings shares closed at US$55.17 on Tuesday, after touching a high of US$69 on Friday.
The Stoxx 600 index held steady at 456.52 points on Tuesday.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average declined 0.3 per cent to 34,517.73 on Tuesday.

site_title:
What are stablecoins, and 
steps taken to mitigate their risks
summary: Stablecoins are digital currencies pegged to a specific asset class, such as a currency or commodity, reducing price volatility. They bridge the gap between volatile cryptocurrencies and fiat currency, making them suitable for everyday transactions. Regulators, including the Monetary Authority of Singapore and the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, have finalized frameworks to oversee single-currency stablecoins. However, concerns over risks and regulatory arbitrage persist, with experts calling for improved trust and safety measures to broaden adoption.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Binance will gradually suspend BUSD support over the coming months, starting with some services in September.

site_title: UN Sustainable Development Goals need overhaul of global financing mechanisms
summary: The UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) are in "deep trouble" with progress at a disappointing and abysmal level, particularly in addressing poverty, inequality, and climate change. The COVID-19 pandemic, global hunger, and climate disasters have hindered efforts, with the current global financing mechanism estimated to need a $4 trillion annual increase. The SDGs' financing needs are not being met due to inequities in the current system, and calls for reform of multilateral development banks and international financial institutions are growing, with the UN aiming to scale up financing for SDGs by ramping up affordable long-term financing.

site_title: Singtel partners Drew & Napier, Blackpanda to provide SMEs with cybersecurity training
summary: Singtel has launched the Cyber Elevate Programme, a two-day workshop for Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to equip them with knowledge and legal understanding to handle cyberattacks. The programme, funded by SkillsFuture Singapore, provides a fee subsidy of up to 90% for SMEs, with a maximum fee of $3,000. After completing the programme, SMEs will be eligible for one-time support from law firms Drew & Napier and incident-response company Blackpanda in the event of a cyberattack. The programme aims to address the fact that 40% of cyberattacks target SMEs, with phishing and ransomware attacks being the most common.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo

Formula One governing body FIA has introduced new regulations in recent years designed to mitigate safety and environmental concerns, but also level the playing field and foster competition in a sport that sometimes sees too much domination from a specific team or driver.
Growing connectivity and digitisation are central to the rising threat of malware developments.
Not only are the potential avenues of cyber attack growing, the potential consequences and costs of such attacks are also expanding significantly

site_title: UK house prices post weakest increase since 2012
summary: UK house prices experienced their weakest 12-month increase since 2012, rising 0.6% to £290,000 in July, according to the Office for National Statistics. The slowdown is attributed to higher interest rates, which are stretching affordability and cooling the market. Despite this, prices are not expected to crash, with economists predicting a peak-to-trough fall of around 6%. Tenants are also feeling the squeeze, with private rental prices rising 5.5% in August, the largest increase since 2016.

images.alt_text: Rents are rising fastest in London as they catch up from a slump during the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Hundreds of buyers queue up for Dubai's US$5 million palm-island homes
summary: Hundreds of buyers queued up in 38°C heat outside Nakheel PJSC's sales centre in Dubai to purchase luxury villas on the Palm Jebel Ali island, priced from 18.7 million dirhams ($6.93 million). The villas, which were initially launched two decades ago but never built, are now being sold by the government-backed developer. The cheapest plots of land are selling for about 40 million dirhams. Buyers, mostly from Russia and India, were eager to secure the luxury homes, with some brokers pleading with staff to let them into the heavily-guarded offices.

images.alt_text: This image shows high-rise buildings in Dubai, on February 18, 2023. - Home to towering skyscrapers and ultra-luxury villas, Dubai saw record real estate transactions in 2022, largely due to an influx of wealthy investors, especially from Russia. (Photo by Karim SAHIB / AFP)

site_title: Police partner six banks to avert scam losses of over S$17 million
summary: The Singapore Police Force partnered with six banks to combat scams, averting over S$17.1 million in losses. A month-long joint operation used robotic process automation technology to identify and alert scam victims through SMS alerts, disrupting over 800 ongoing scam cases. The operation also blacklisted over 600 PayNow numbers, preventing potential losses of S$70,000. The collaboration improved outreach and prevented further losses, with victims receiving alerts to cease further monetary transfers.

images.alt_text: Anti-malware security measures on banking apps will aid banks in detecting the presence of malware on customers’ devices and trigger additional actions, said ABS.
The four-month joint operation between SPF and OCBC sent out SMS alerts to over 2,800 of scam victims, all of which were OCBC customers.
Banks should take the lead in fighting scams as they are the best positioned and the best resourced: WP chairperson Sylvia Lim.

site_title: Singapore beats Hong Kong to become ‘world’s freest economy’ for first time
summary: Singapore has become the world's freest economy for the first time, surpassing Hong Kong, according to the Economic Freedom of the World Index. Hong Kong fell to second place due to eroding judicial independence, while Singapore, Switzerland, New Zealand, and the US rounded out the top five. The report's findings signal Hong Kong's struggle to maintain its reputation as a global financial center amid years of pandemic isolation and political instability.

images.alt_text: In August, China retained its spot as the top source of visitors to Singapore, followed by Indonesia, Malaysia, India and Australia.

ST20220901-202296305043-Lim Yaohui-pixport/
Quay cranes and containers at PSA Pasir Panjang Terminal on Sept 01, 2022.

“The main driver for investments was actually the semiconductor super cycle,” says Economic Development Board (EDB) managing director Jacqueline Poh.
For the full year, the most likely outcome is for the economy to grow between 0 per cent and 0.9 per cent.

site_title: Move over, tech giants – bureaucrats can innovate too
summary: Modern policymakers are combining national security and industrial policy to promote technological dominance and restrict competitors, particularly China. Innovative laws such as the US Chips and Science Act and Japan's Economic Security Promotion Act aim to shore up domestic technological strengths and hinder China's efforts. Countries like the US, Japan, and South Korea are introducing or enhancing measures to screen investments, control exports, and protect data. This trend is expected to continue, potentially leading to bifurcation in the technology sector and increased sensitivity and complexity.

images.alt_text: Purdue University's clean rooms in West Lafayette, Indiana, US, July 10, 2023. Indiana has little experience with semiconductors, but the Biden administration has promised to unleash opportunity in the heartland of America through the US$52 billion CHIPS Act.
Governments are doling out enormous subsidies to manufacturers, especially chipmakers and those behind green technologies.

site_title: German interior ministry wants to force 5G operators to slash Huawei use
summary: Germany's interior ministry plans to force telecoms operators to reduce Huawei's 5G network presence by 2026, aiming to limit the Chinese company's share to 25% of RAN and transport networks. Currently, Huawei accounts for 59% of Germany's 5G RAN networks. The ministry's approach, which includes removing all critical components from Chinese vendors, aims to address concerns about sabotage or espionage. However, some lawmakers have criticized the plan as arbitrary, prioritizing city dwellers over rural areas.

images.alt_text: Huawei has in recent weeks unveiled new smartphones that use advanced chips, which analysts say are domestically made.
“We don’t have any evidence that they can manufacture seven-nanometre (chips) at scale,” US Secretary of Commerce Gina Raimondo says at a US House hearing.
Huawei may launch a 5G version of its mid-ranged Nova around October or November, says the IT Times.
Huawei’s latest phones have ignited celebration in China and consternation in the US, thanks to their advanced made-in-China processor.
Huawei started selling its latest high-end smartphones Mate 60 and Mate 60 Pro at the end of last month.

site_title: Finland’s housing prices still have room to drop: OP Group
summary: Finland's housing market is expected to remain flat in 2024 before recovering in 2025 with a 2.5% annual gain, according to OP Group. Home prices are forecast to drop 5-7% this year due to a wobbly economy and higher borrowing costs. The market has held up better than in some peers, but a 20% decline in transactions since last autumn shows no immediate signs of improvement. The Finnish Financial Supervisory Authority has warned of real estate risks to banks due to nearly 60% of their lending being tied to residential and commercial property.

site_title: Thai lawmakers plan fresh push to tighten use of cannabis
summary: Thai lawmakers plan to pass a new law regulating the use of cannabis for medical and research purposes, targeting an industry projected to be worth up to $1.2 billion. The law, expected to take a year to finalize, will cover permits for growing plants, sales, and distribution, as well as measures against public use in temples, schools, and amusement parks. The law will not include recreational use, with Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin supporting only medical use. The move aims to address the lack of regulations after the narcotic was legalized last year without proper rules.

images.alt_text: Thailand's cannabis industry is projected to be worth up to US$1.2 billion over the next few years, with thousands of businesses springing up since last year’s legalisation.

site_title: Sweden’s property hopes dashed as convertible bond sale pulled
summary: Sweden's commercial property sector faced a setback as a landlord, K-Fast Holding, scrapped a 300 million kronor (S$36.7 million) convertible bond sale due to lack of demand. This is amidst a surge in borrowing costs over the past 18 months, pricing many over-leveraged property companies out of the capital markets. The cancellation follows a tentative funding revival in the sector, with some issuers successfully tapping the domestic bond market. The move highlights ongoing challenges for Swedish landlords seeking to refinance debt and shore up their balance sheets.

images.alt_text: The old town of Gamla Stan in Stockholm. Swedish public housing is carefully conceptualised to be spacious and have leisure spaces such as playgrounds.

site_title: ADB cuts South-east Asia growth forecasts for 2023 and 2024 on weaker export demand
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has downgraded its growth forecasts for South-east Asia in 2023 and 2024 due to weaker export demand, high commodity prices, and tightened global financial conditions. The region's growth is expected to slow, with major economies such as Cambodia, Laos, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, and Vietnam posting lower growth than predicted. However, Brunei, Indonesia, and Thailand are expected to perform better due to brighter domestic demand prospects. The ADB also revised its inflation forecast for South-east Asia to 4.2% for 2023 and 3.3% for 2024, citing adverse weather and currency depreciation.

images.alt_text: Goh Ruoxue
The Asian Development Bank cut China’s growth forecast for 2022 to 3.3 per cent from 5.0 per cent, as Beijing pursues a zero-Covid strategy that has devastated the world’s second-largest economy.
The Asian Development Bank cut Vietnam's growth forecast for 2023 as weaker external demand weighs on manfuacturing output.

site_title: China companies pay out record dividends amid market plunge
summary: Chinese companies are set to pay out record dividends this year, with total payouts exceeding 1.5 trillion yuan (S$280.4 billion) so far, surpassing last year's 1.27 trillion yuan. This surge in dividend payments is aimed at boosting investor confidence amid an outflow of foreign funds. As a result, dividend yields for companies on the CSI 300 Index have surpassed 10-year sovereign bond yields for the first time. The move is seen as a response to the securities watchdog's urging for domestic companies to pay good dividends.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A logo of Chinese developer Country Garden is pictured in Tianjin, China August 18, 2023. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo

site_title: Biden is fighting for his political life
summary: President Joe Biden is facing a political crisis despite achieving economic and foreign policy successes. Unemployment is at historic lows, real incomes are rising, and inflation is falling, contradicting predictions of an impending recession. Growth in the current quarter is booming at nearly 5% and the housing market has not collapsed. However, Biden's approval ratings remain low, with pundits struggling to explain the shift in his public image.

images.alt_text: US lawmakers have until midnight on Sept 30 to reach an agreement, before funding for government services is due to dry up.
Polls show that most Republicans view the criminal charges against Donald Trump, 77, as politically motivated, making the topic a tricky one to navigate for his rivals.

site_title: Thai ex-MP banned for life for 'disrespecting monarchy'
summary: A Thai politician, Pannika Wanich, has been banned from enrolling in politics for life for "disrespecting the monarchy" through decade-old photos deemed disrespectful to King Maha Vajiralongkorn. Wanich, an activist with the progressive Move Forward Party, has faced numerous lawsuits over allegations of royal defamation. Thailand's strict royal defamation laws have been criticized for silencing dissent, and Wanich's case highlights the country's strict enforcement of these laws.

images.alt_text: Move Forward Party leader and former prime ministerial candidate Pita Limjaroenrat arrives to address a crowd during a rally on Jomtien Beach in Pattaya on July 22, 2023. (Photo by Jack TAYLOR / AFP)

site_title: India’s HDFC Bank gets rare analyst downgrade on loan growth concerns
summary: HDFC Bank, India's largest private sector bank, has been downgraded to neutral from buy by Nomura Holdings due to concerns over loan growth pressures and return on assets. The stock fell as much as 4.2% and is the NIFTY 50 Index's worst performer. Analysts cited the bank's lowered revision of business absorbed from its parent as a reason for the downgrade, predicting no upside over the next 12 months. The shares have fallen 6% in two trading sessions.

images.alt_text: HDFC’s gross non-performing assets are among the lowest compared with its private-sector peers.

site_title: Gold stalls as Fed caution keeps investors at bay
summary: Gold prices remained steady at US$1,930.51 per ounce as investors held off on buying amid caution over the US Federal Reserve's policy decision and its updated economic outlook. Fuel price surges added to inflation concerns, increasing expectations that the Fed will keep interest rates on hold but reassess its hawkish stance. The Fed's rate-setting policy committee is set to release its new policy statement and interest rate decision, with Chair Jerome Powell scheduled to hold a press conference.

images.alt_text: US gold futures were flat at US$1,953.90.

site_title: Vietnam’s speedy transition to being an aged society opens new doors for investors
summary: Vietnam, which became an ageing society in 2015, will officially be an aged one by 2035, according to the World Bank. The country's population aged 60 and above makes up 11.9% of its 100 million population in 2019, expected to more than double to 25% by 2050. This rapid ageing is faster than other countries such as Japan, Italy, and Sweden. The shift poses challenges for investors and policymakers, but also presents opportunities for those willing to adapt to the changing demographics.

images.alt_text: Strings of closed down stores and spaces offered for rent along the Nguyen Hue walking street located in Central District 1, the most vibrant commercial area of Vietnam’s Ho Chi Minh City

site_title: South Korea’s Hyundai Global Service aims to raise US$1 billion in IPO: sources
summary: Hyundai Global Service, a marine services arm of South Korean shipbuilder Hyundai Heavy Industries Holdings, is set to raise up to US$1 billion in an initial public offering (IPO) in the first half of 2024. The company is targeting a valuation of US$3 billion to US$4 billion, backed by private equity giant KKR. Hyundai Global Service provides marine aftersales, retrofit solutions, and digital transformation services, and its IPO is the latest in a series of listings by KKR-backed companies in Asia.

images.alt_text: This investment puts the enterprise value of Singtel’s overall RDC business at S$5.5 billion.
Reliance Retail is India’s biggest retailer whose operations stretch from selling groceries to electronics, and include foreign partnerships with brands.
Paramount Global has announced the sale of publisher Simon & Schuster to private investment giant KKR.
FILE PHOTO: Trading information for KKR & Co is displayed on a screen on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, U.S., August 23, 2018. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo
Arm Holdings shares closed at US$55.17 on Tuesday, after touching a high of US$69 on Friday.
As until the IPO filing, a total of S$5.8 million funding was obtained by Ryde from venture capital companies.

site_title: Thailand plans higher borrowing in 2024 to boost economy
summary: Thailand's new government plans to borrow 2.4 trillion baht (S$90.8 billion) for fiscal year 2024, a 9% increase from the current year, to stimulate a sluggish economy. The government aims to sell up to 272 billion baht of government bonds and 180 billion baht of treasury bills in the fourth quarter of 2023. The borrowing will be financed through various means, including government bonds, treasury bills, savings bonds, bond switching, and promissory notes, to support stimulus spending and revive the economy, which is expected to grow 2.8% this year, down from the finance ministry's previous projection of 3.5% growth.

images.alt_text: Thailand's economy is expected to grow 2.8 per cent this year, but PM Srettha Thavisin has a target of 5 per cent annual growth.

site_title: Car COE premiums hit new highs; Cat A at S$105,000, Open category at S$144,640
summary: Singapore's certificate of entitlement (COE) premiums for cars reached new highs in the latest tender exercise. The COE premium for smaller cars set a record at S$105,000, while larger car COE climbed to S$140,889. The Open category COE premium also reached an all-time high at S$144,640, with the commercial vehicle COE premium increasing by 1.1% to S$83,801. The motorcycle COE premium dipped by 1.84% to S$10,700. These record highs reflect the ongoing surge in COE prices, driven by increasing demand and limited supply.

site_title: Qantas ex-CEO Alan Joyce to get tenfold higher pay of US$13.8 million for 2023
summary: Qantas' former CEO Alan Joyce will receive a $13.8 million pay package for 2023, a 10-fold increase from the previous year. However, his compensation could be subject to adjustments and clawback due to regulatory challenges over alleged illegal ticket sales, which have damaged the airline's reputation. Joyce retired earlier this month, bringing forward his retirement by two months. The airline has also reduced short-term incentives for senior executives by 20% to reflect the customer and brand impact of the cumulative events.

site_title: Former New Silkroutes CEO Goh Jin Hian among four charged with false trading
summary: Four individuals, including former New Silkroutes CEO Goh Jin Hian, have been charged with false trading in Singapore. They allegedly manipulated NSG securities prices between February 2018 and August 2018 by placing orders and executing trades to push up prices. Goh faces 39 charges, including eight related to his personal trading account. If convicted, each individual may face up to seven years in jail or a fine of up to SGD 250,000.

images.alt_text: Navene Elangovan
MAS opened 136 cases and took 455 other actions during the period of reporting, it said in its latest enforcement report.
New Silkroutes Group focused on transforming into a healthtech play
New Silkroutes Group says its proposed investment is an opportunity to enter China's transportation industry.

site_title: Indonesia attorney-general launches graft probe into palm oil fund agency
summary: Indonesia's Attorney-General's Office has launched a corruption investigation into the country's palm oil fund agency, overseeing export levies on the commodity, from 2015 to 2022. Fifteen people have been questioned in the probe, which focuses on alleged unlawful activities linked to the determination of Indonesia's monthly biodiesel price index.

site_title: UK inflation unexpectedly falls, raising questions about BOE rate plan
summary: UK inflation unexpectedly fell to 6.7% in August, the lowest since February 2022, raising questions about the Bank of England's interest rate plan. The drop was driven by a decrease in hotel and airfare prices, offset by a rise in fuel and alcoholic drink taxes. Investors now see a 45% chance of the BOE pausing rate hikes on Thursday, down from 20% before the data was released. The BOE had forecast a rise to 7.1% in August, but the drop may ease pressure on families and businesses.

images.alt_text: Increases in basic pay deals in the UK fell to a median 5 per cent in the three months to the end of August compared with the same period in 2022, human resources data provider XpertHR said.

site_title: Vietnam’s four pillars and revolving-door posts
summary: Vietnam's government is experiencing a "white-knuckle" politics, with zero tolerance for leaders involved in controversy or performance issues. The four pillars of governance - president, prime minister, general secretary of the Communist Party, and chairman of the national assembly - are under scrutiny, particularly Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh, whose performance is being closely watched by the party amid slowing economic growth. The country's collective form of leadership is seen as robust, but the system may need to rediscover the camaraderie and unity of the past, as the ruling party continues to fill vacant positions and investigates corruption cases.

images.alt_text: Sources say that Vietnam's likely failure to meet its 6.5 per cent gross GDP growth target could be career-damaging for Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh.

Vietnam’s economy is already marked by private entrepreneurialism. The Vingroup conglomerate has achieved a global profile since the early 2000s and operates across sectors including automobiles, real estate and retail.

site_title: Japan may intervene on yen again; BOJ should ditch easy policy: ex-financial diplomat
summary: Japan may intervene again to support the yen if it declines further, former top currency diplomat Takehiko Nakao said, and urged the Bank of Japan to ditch or modify its ultra-easy policy settings to prevent further depreciation. Last year, Japan spent over nine trillion yen intervening in currency markets, buying yen in September and October. The yen is currently trading around 147.77 against the US dollar, and prolonged monetary easing risks depreciating the yen further, with benefits to exports offset by increased import prices and cost of living.

images.alt_text: Japan's exports fell 0.8 per cent year-on-year in August, slower than economists’ median estimates of 1.7 per cent decline.
The euro has been gradually losing steam over the last two months, since hitting a 15-month high, as the ECB has neared the end of its current cycle of rate rises.
The pact, extended on Sep 18, with Malaysia having the option to exchange the Malaysian ringgit for the Japanese yen, according to BOJ.

site_title: Marine and offshore industry sets course for decarbonisation
summary: Singapore's marine and offshore industry is shifting towards decarbonization, with over 100 local companies participating in or exploring projects in maritime decarbonization and offshore renewables. The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore has set a target for harbour craft and pleasure craft sectors to achieve net-zero emissions by 2050. Companies such as Strategic Marine, C-LNG Solutions, and Meds Venture are expanding or diversifying their energy use to include low-carbon fuels and renewable sources. The industry is also investing in technologies like hybrid propulsion systems, liquefied natural gas, and synthetic LNG, with the government's commitment crucial in driving demand for clean solutions.

The Global Centre for Maritime Decarbonisation and the Society for Gas as a Marine Fuel inks a two-year partnership to develop guidelines on the use of ammonia as a marine fuel.
Singapore completed its first ship-to-ship bunkering operation in July this year. Methanol can cut carbon dioxide emissions by up to 95 per cent when produced from renewable electricity.

site_title: China leaves benchmark lending rates unchanged as expected
summary: China maintained its benchmark lending rates, leaving the one-year loan prime rate (LPR) at 3.45% and the five-year LPR at 4.20%, as expected. This decision reflects economic stabilization and a weakening yuan, limiting further monetary easing efforts. The rates have been unchanged since August, when China cut the one-year benchmark rate. The moves are expected to influence mortgage pricing and new, outstanding loans in China.

site_title: Asia: Markets sink with Wall Street as rate fears grow ahead of Federal Reserve decision
summary: Asia's stock markets plummeted on Wednesday as investors grew concerned the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates again or keep them high for an extended period. Despite inflation dropping, a fresh spike in oil prices and a robust labor market eroded optimism about future rate cuts. Hong Kong, Tokyo, Shanghai, and other regional markets declined, with many closing midday. The decline follows a summer of fading hopes for rate cuts and a strong economy.

images.alt_text: The SGX logo at SGX Centre 1 located along Shenton Way on March 3, 2023.

site_title: NTUC calls for flexi-work, statutory paid leave for workers who are caregivers
summary: The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) has called for flexible work arrangements and statutory paid caregiving leave to support workers managing work and caregiving. NTUC secretary-general Ng Chee Meng urges employers and the government to provide flexible work arrangements, such as remote work, flexible hours, and job redesign. The organization also recommends disclosing flexible work arrangement details in job advertisements. Ng Chee Meng sees this as a "win-win" situation for both workers and employers.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
To help workers stay employable, NTUC has formed over 1,455 Company Training Committees (CTCs) and trained more than 100,000 workers across various sectors, said secretary-general Ng Chee Meng.

site_title: Iron ore drifts higher, but China property woes limit upside
summary: Iron ore futures rose 0.5% on the Dalian Commodity Exchange, and 1.4% on the Singapore Exchange, as China's economic stimulus efforts and improved economic indicators boosted market confidence. The benchmark iron ore price held above $120 per ton, despite concerns over China's struggling property sector. The Asian Development Bank revised its economic growth forecast for developing Asia to 4.7% for this year, citing the weakness in China's property sector.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man walks by an iron ore blending site at Dalian Port, Liaoning province, China September 21, 2018. REUTERS/Muyu Xu/File Photo/File Photo
The most-traded January iron ore on China’s Dalian Commodity Exchange ended daytime trade 0.2 per cent lower at 871.50 yuan (S$163.15) per ton.

site_title: Economist Song Seng Wun takes on economic adviser role at CGS-CIMB
summary: Economist Song Seng Wun has been appointed as Singapore economic adviser at CGS-CIMB, bringing 30 years of experience covering three regional and global recessions and focusing on the Asean-5 economies. He will enhance CGS-CIMB's presence in Singapore, providing economic commentary and insights to clients. Song joins from CIMB Private Banking, where he worked from 2015 to 2023, and has previously worked at Merrill Lynch, Warburg Dillon Read, and ABN Amro.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Choo Oi Yee, chief executive of ADDX, said assets under management for private markets are slated to nearly double to US$18.3 trillion in 2027 from US$9.3 trillion in 2021.

site_title: US lifts gloves import ban on Supermax, units after forced labour remediation
summary: The US Customs and Border Protection (CBP) has lifted the import ban on Malaysia-listed glove manufacturer Supermax Corporation and its subsidiaries, effective immediately. The ban was imposed in 2021 due to suspected forced labor in their supply chain, but the company demonstrated remediation efforts. This move allows Supermax's disposable gloves to enter the US market, provided they comply with US laws.

site_title: High-rises sweep Sao Paulo, but boom casts shadows
summary: A controversial urban planning law in Brazil's Sao Paulo in 2014 has led to a surge in high-rise construction, but critics say it has failed to provide affordable housing for low- and middle-income families. The law has resulted in the demolition of historic buildings and homes, with residents like Rosanne Brancatelli fighting to preserve their neighborhoods. Despite city hall's efforts to revise the plan, concerns remain about the impact on the city's social crisis, with thousands of homeless people, and the loss of cultural heritage sites.

site_title: Huawei unit ships Chinese-made surveillance chips in fresh comeback sign: sources
summary: Huawei's chip design unit, HiSilicon, is shipping Chinese-made surveillance chips to manufacturers, marking a fresh sign the company is finding ways to circumvent four years of US export controls. Shipments began this year, with at least some customers being Chinese. This comes after Huawei unveiled new smartphones using domestically made chips, sparking analysts to say the company is adapting to the export restrictions. The move suggests Huawei is exploring alternative ways to maintain its chip production despite US sanctions.

images.alt_text: Arm Holdings shares closed at US$55.17 on Tuesday, after touching a high of US$69 on Friday.

US Secretary of State Antony Blinken and Chinese Vice-President Han Zheng shake hands while meeting in New York City on Sept 18, 2023, ahead of the 78th United Nations General Assembly.

site_title: International Criminal Court reports cybersecurity ‘incident’
summary: The International Criminal Court (ICC) reported a cybersecurity incident, where unusual activity was detected on its computer network at the end of last week. The court took immediate measures to respond and mitigate the impact, but details on the severity and resolution of the hack remain unclear. The ICC is a permanent war crimes tribunal in The Hague, with 17 ongoing investigations in various countries. The incident may have compromised sensitive documents, including evidence and witness information, but the court is prioritizing the continuation of its core work.

site_title: Japan land prices rise on chipmaking factories, tourism rebound
summary: Japan's land prices rose 1% in the year to July 1, accelerating from a 0.3% increase the previous year, driven by the construction of semiconductor factories and a rebound in tourism. Residential land values gained 0.7%, while commercial sites jumped 1.5%. This marks the second consecutive year of price growth, with rural areas seeing a 0.1% increase in residential land prices, the first rise in 31 years, and commercial locations rising for the first time in four years.

images.alt_text: Rapidus will work with IBM with the aim of starting mass production of two-nanometre node chips from 2027.

site_title: Japanese companies warm up to employee stock incentives
summary: Japanese companies are warming up to employee stock incentives as a tool to retain talent and boost share prices. ANA Holdings, Omron, and Sony Group are among major firms offering shares to employees, following a regulator's request to pay more attention to share price performance. The practice has doubled in the last five years, with 966 Japanese companies now offering equity-based compensation, but lags behind the US and Germany. Experts say labour laws limiting the use of stocks as wages hinder its adoption, but more flexibility could accelerate its spread.

summary: Chinese electric vehicle maker Nio priced US$1 billion of six-year and seven-year convertible senior notes at 3.875% and 4.625%, respectively. The notes, valued at US$500 million each, have an initial conversion premium of 30% and will close on or about September 22, 2023. The initial conversion rate is 89.9685 American Depositary Shares (ADSs) per US$1,000 principal amount, equivalent to an initial conversion price of US$11.12 per ADS.

site_title: Australia’s housing crisis worsens by the day
summary: Australia's housing crisis worsens, with Sydney becoming the second least affordable housing market in the world, behind Hong Kong. The crisis is fueled by a shortage of rental properties, with less than 1% available, and rising rents, with house prices surging 16% and apartments 20% in the past year. The government estimates 900,000 additional dwellings need to be built by 2041 to cope with an influx of arrivals. Building pipelines are near record lows, and construction firms are folding due to surging costs. Authorities propose limited measures, but experts say hundreds of thousands of new homes are needed to address the crisis.

images.alt_text: With about 25 per cent of the mortgage market, Commonwealth Bank remains the largest player.

site_title: Japan‘s exports extend declines as China slowdown bites
summary: Japan's exports fell 0.8% year-on-year in August, slower than expected, due to a slowdown in China's demand for steel and heavy oil. This marks the second consecutive month of annual declines, sparking fears of a downturn. Shipments to China, Japan's largest trading partner, fell 11% year-on-year, while exports to the US rose 5.1%. The trade data dashes hopes for an export-led recovery, with imports falling 17.8% and the trade balance recording a deficit of 930 billion yen.

site_title: Singapore shares hold steady at Wednesday’s open; STI up 0.04%
summary: Singapore shares held steady at Wednesday's open, with the Straits Times Index (STI) edging up 0.04% to 3,242.09. The market saw a gainers-to-losers ratio of 49 to 35, driven by banking stocks, including DBS, UOB, and OCBC. The performance follows subdued European and overnight US market movements, with investors awaiting the Federal Reserve's next decision on interest rates.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Thomson Medical has until Dec 10 to restore its public free float.

site_title: UK Labour leader – and potential next PM – makes mark internationally
summary: UK Labour leader Keir Starmer is building international support ahead of the next UK general election, where he is seen as a strong contender to become prime minister. Starmer has met with world leaders, including French President Emmanuel Macron and German Chancellor Olaf Scholz, and has expressed a desire for a "progressive moment" in UK politics. His focus on embedding left-of-centre policies on issues such as immigration, climate change, and economic policy, is seen as a key challenge for the progressive moment. Starmer aims to restore the UK's reputation on the world stage and has identified an "axis of insecurity" to tackle, including the cost of living crisis and climate change.

images.alt_text: Liz Truss has remained on the fringes of UK politics following her short, disastrous term as prime minister, but her comments echo concerns held by other members of the Tory party.

site_title: Arm shares post third daily loss with IPO buzz fizzling, short sellers hovering
summary: Arm Holdings shares closed at $55.17 on Tuesday, marking their third daily decline as investor interest in the company's IPO fizzled out. The stock underperformed the Philadelphia semiconductor index, closing down 4.9% and 25% lower than its IPO price. Analysts have expressed concerns over valuation and the need for evidence of the company's impact from artificial intelligence (AI) demand. Short sellers have started taking bets against the stock, with 5 million shares on loan, indicating a potential sell-off in the long term.

site_title: Building sustainable businesses amid a complex environment
summary: Companies adopting robust environmental, social, and governance (ESG) practices are driven by decisive leadership and a clear direction. These organizations are increasingly committed to reporting their ESG performance, despite challenges in the complex global landscape of climate and sustainability reporting. To meet enhanced standards, companies need to improve their reporting practices with complete, reliable, standardized, and verifiable data. Simplifying ESG reporting requirements and fostering a culture of transparency are also crucial. Effective governance and leadership from the board and senior management are key to driving ESG adoption and meaningful disclosures.

images.alt_text: While the responsibility for elevating social sustainability spans the organisation, this effort has to be driven by the board and senior management.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower ahead of Fed policy meet, Instacart debut
summary: Wall Street's main indexes opened lower on Tuesday ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy meeting, with investors awaiting the Nasdaq debut of grocery delivery app Instacart. The S&P 500 fell 0.18%, the Dow Jones dropped 0.15%, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 0.44%. Investors are also monitoring China's GDP growth, which is expected to slow, and its impact on policymakers.

site_title: Singapore court orders Credit Suisse unit to pay Georgia ex-PM Ivanishvili US$743 million
summary: A Singapore court ordered a unit of Credit Suisse to pay Georgian billionaire Bidzina Ivanishvili US$743 million for failing to safeguard his assets. The decision is a blow to Credit Suisse, which was taken over by UBS in June to prevent a financial collapse. The court revised down the amount from an earlier judgement of US$926 million, citing an earlier settlement and avoiding "double recovery". Credit Suisse plans to appeal the ruling.

images.alt_text: (FILES) A photograph shows a logo of Credit Suisse bank in Zurich, on March 23, 2023. The marriage of UBS and Credit Suisse was hastily arranged to prevent a global financial meltdown -- but the resulting megabank could cause domestic problems in Switzerland, the central bank admitted on March 23, 2023. site_title: Yellen says US growth needs to slow due to full employment
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said the US economy needs to slow down to align with its potential growth rate, as it operates at full employment, and to bring inflation back to target levels. She noted that demand-supply imbalances in the labor market have abated and that surveys show softer demand for labor, contributing to lower core inflation. Yellen also expressed concerns about China's economy, saying authorities should use fiscal and monetary policy space to avoid a major slowdown that could impact the US economy.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen addresses a news conference during a G20 finance ministers' and Central Bank governors' meeting at Gandhinagar, India, July 16, 2023. REUTERS/Amit Dave/File Photo

“I don’t see any signs that the economy is at risk of a downturn,” says US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen.
US lawmakers have until midnight on Sept 30 to reach an agreement, before funding for government services is due to dry up.

site_title: Federal Reserve set to pause rate hikes, but don’t count out another increase
summary: The Federal Reserve is expected to pause interest-rate hikes for the second time this year, following a slowing in inflation, and will keep rates steady at a 22-year high of 5.25-5.5%. Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell has signaled that leaders prefer to wait to evaluate the impact of past increases before considering another increase as early as November. The decision is based on the economy's resilience and inflation still above the 2% target.

images.alt_text: Federal Reserve officials are gathering on Tuesday for a two-day meeting that could see them raise rates again to lower inflation sustainably back to a two per cent target.

site_title: Taylor Swift takes on Hollywood
summary: Taylor Swift's concert documentary, "Taylor Swift: The Eras Tour," is set for a theatrical release on October 13, breaking the record for pre-sales in the US with $37 million in revenue. The film's success could exceed $100 million in its opening weekend, making it a potential contender for the biggest film of the autumn season. Swift's unconventional release, directly working with AMC, bypasses traditional film studios, fueling Hollywood's concerns. The documentary is part of Swift's efforts to control her master rights, a strategy that has also led to her re-recording her first six albums, generating an estimated $740 million in her net worth.

images.alt_text: (From left) Taylor Swift receives the Best Pop award from NSYNC's members Joey Fatone, Lance Bass, Justin Timberlake and JC Chasez during the 2023 MTV Video Music Awards at the Prudential Centre in Newark, New Jersey, Sept 12, 2023.
The hugely popular Taylor Swift, 33, is expected to set a record for the first billion-dollar tour thanks to her career-spanning Eras Tour.
US singer-songwriter Taylor Swift performing in Inglewood, California, one of the stops in her ongoing Eras Tour.

site_title: Ex-Deutsche Bank investment banker pleads guilty to crypto fraud
summary: A former Deutsche Bank investment banker, Rashawn Russell, pleaded guilty to crypto fraud, admitting to misappropriating funds from investors he promised large returns from cryptocurrency trading. Russell faces up to 30 years in prison and will pay over $1.5 million in restitution. He claimed to run a cryptocurrency fund, R3, and used investor funds for personal expenses, including gambling. The US Justice Department said Russell's scheme defrauded clients who trusted him, and prosecutors are part of a broader effort to crack down on fraud involving digital assets.

images.alt_text: UBS targets the integration to be finished by the end of 2025.
DBS Group CEO Piyush Gupta said banks had already been more cautious over the last 15 years since the global financial crisis.
The partnership means Deutsche Bank can start its work on offering custody of digital assets to clients.

site_title: UK pay deals lose more steam as Bank of England meets on rates
summary: The UK's pay deals lost steam, with basic pay increases falling to a median 5% in the three months to August, down from 5.4% in July. This marks the first decline in 2023. According to XpertHR, pay awards across the economy reached levels not seen in three decades earlier this year. Despite this, pay awards remain below consumer price inflation, which economists expect to have increased to 7.0% in August. The Bank of England is set to raise interest rates to 5.5% on Thursday, its 15th rate hike, amid inflation pressures.

images.alt_text: If Donald Trump wins the 2024 US election, the shock would be greater than in 2016, as Team Trump will be able to hit the ground running.
