British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's comments follow British media reports that he was set to water down plans to phase out gas boilers from 2035 and delay the ban on the sale of new petrol and diesel cars due in 2030.

site_title: 40% of Singaporeans use AI at work; 76% of them pass it off as their own: study
summary: A study by Salesforce found that 40% of Singaporean office workers use generative AI in their work, with 76% passing it off as their own. Many respondents admitted to using platforms banned by their employers, highlighting a lack of understanding of ethics and safety practices in AI use. The survey, conducted among 1,000 workers, revealed limited knowledge of practices promoting ethics and safety in AI usage. This raises concerns about the misuse of AI and the need for education and awareness about its responsible use.

images.alt_text: Jeanette Tan
Depending on how the technology is harnessed at the workplace, AI could give rise to a myriad of legal pitfalls for the unsuspecting.
Whether the world is ready for it or not, AI has become a democratic force for leaders to seek ways to extend the benefits of its capabilities across enterprises.
If the antitrust case against Google leaves it no less formidable than before it started, startups will reconsider going up against the behemoth and its mammoth peers.
Salesforce is betting that interest in artificial intelligence will fuel a new cycle of tech investment.
Chairman Truong Gia Binh says Vietnam can build on its strong position in AI and both the country and his company can grow faster in the digital sector.
Alibaba first unveiled Tongyi Qianwen in April, saying at the time that the AI large language model, which is similar to ChatGPT, would be integrated into all business applications.

Intel Corporation corporate vice president and general manager for Asia Pacific and Japan Steve Long said the world is going into a generational shift where “AI will be everywhere and it is prevalent.”
Alibaba joined a global race this year to stake out a spot in the emergent field of AI, considered critical to advancing not just tech companies but national strategic imperatives.

When using AI, organisations should also adopt a “human-in-the-loop” approach, which calls for people to give feedback to the AI algorithms in place. As humans have more empathy and contextual understanding of the situation, this allows for better detection of ambiguous and sensitive situations.
Meta is aiming for its new AI model to be ready next year, the Wall Street Journal said, adding it will be several times more powerful than its commercial version dubbed Llama 2.

site_title: UBS names South Korea, India, others as ‘slow’ on Credit Suisse approval
summary: UBS has identified several countries as being "slow" to grant regulatory approvals needed to complete its takeover of Credit Suisse, including South Korea, India, Ireland, and Saudi Arabia. The Swiss banking giant's internal document, dated September 6, warns that uncooperative regulators could jeopardize the timeline of the parent bank merger and other transactions. The process could take up to 18-22 months in South Korea, two years in Ireland, and 12 months in Saudi Arabia, with Russia potentially never obtaining a "change in control" approval.

images.alt_text: The bonds have been sold over the past few years to finance debt-for-nature swaps, through which sovereigns refinance their debt in exchange for marine conservation pledges. Credit Suisse and BOA labelled the bonds “blue” to reflect those commitments.
The 4.25-year, six-year and 11-year bonds are all benchmark size, making the deal at least a total of US$1.5 billion, and are all callable a year before maturity.

site_title: Intel says newest laptop chips, software will handle generative AI
summary: Intel has announced a new chip and software that will enable laptops to run generative AI chatbots without relying on cloud data centers. The "Meteor Lake" chip, set to be released in December, will support this capability, allowing businesses and consumers to test AI technologies like ChatGPT locally. This move aims to democratize AI and provide a more private and cost-effective solution, potentially gaining Intel ground on Nvidia in the AI chip market.

images.alt_text: Intel Corporation corporate vice president and general manager for Asia Pacific and Japan Steve Long said the world is going into a generational shift where “AI will be everywhere and it is prevalent.”
US Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo delivers her speech at a reception with US Industry and Chinese government officials, Beijing, China, Aug 28, 2023.
Intel said its “Sierra Forest” chip will have 240 per cent better performance per watt than its current generation of data centre chip, the first time the company has disclosed such figures.
Tower Semiconductor is a fraction of the size of Intel and TSMC in terms of revenue, but it makes components for big customers such as Broadcom.

Intel’s surprise second-quarter profit and its strong earnings and margin forecasts suggest the personal computer market slump is nearing an end, sparking a surge in its stock and the wider chip sector.

site_title: UK set to backtrack on net zero policies
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak is set to backtrack on net zero policies, aiming to achieve the 2050 target "in a better, more proportionate way". Plans to phase out gas boilers by 2035 and ban new petrol and diesel cars by 2030 may be watered down or delayed. This move is expected to trigger dissent within the Conservative Party, with some MPs preparing letters of no confidence. Critics, including Labour and environmental groups, warn the U-turn could lead to increased dependence on foreign oil, job losses, and economic instability.

images.alt_text: If Donald Trump wins the 2024 US election, the shock would be greater than in 2016, as Team Trump will be able to hit the ground running.
Northern Ireland's economic growth has been driven partly by a “peace dividend” since the 1998 Good Friday agreement, which ushered in a significant increase in tourism, investment, and business
Ursula von der Leyen has not yet stated whether she will seek a second term as president of the European Commission.
Liz Truss has remained on the fringes of UK politics following her short, disastrous term as prime minister, but her comments echo concerns held by other members of the Tory party.

site_title: Surge in COE prices negates weaker yen’s effect on Japanese car prices
summary: A weaker Japanese yen has led to lower prices for Japanese cars in Singapore, with savings of around S$2,100 on a mainstream car costing 2.5 million yen. However, the rise in certificate of entitlement (COE) premiums has "massively outweighed" this effect, resulting in higher overall prices for Japanese cars in consumers' eyes. The price of Category A COEs rose 26.3% in September, wiping out the cost savings from the weaker yen.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong
Certificate of Entitlement (COE) prices for bigger, more expensive cars have set new records after consecutive increases in August 2023.
Major authorised car dealers have anti-money laundering measures in place, but parallel imports and used cars offer more leeway for money laundering due to less scrutiny.

site_title: Oil prices ease after hitting 10-month highs as investors take profits
summary: Oil prices eased after reaching 10-month highs, with Brent crude futures settling 9 cents lower at $94.34 a barrel. The price surge followed extended production cuts from Saudi Arabia and Russia, but investors took profits after three consecutive gains. Global benchmark Brent crude is expected to trade in a range of $90-100 per barrel, with a year-end target of $95 per barrel. US oil output is set to fall to 9.393 million barrels per day in October, and US crude stockpiles decreased by 5.25 million barrels last week.

images.alt_text: Global oil benchmark Brent crude futures settled 50 cents higher at US$94.43 a barrel on Monday after rising as high as US$94.45.

site_title: US government at rising risk of shutdown with Congress in deadlock
summary: The US government is at risk of a potential shutdown, with lawmakers struggling to agree on a short-term spending bill. Funding for government services is set to expire on September 30, unless an agreement is reached. A shutdown could impact hundreds of thousands of workers, causing closures of parks, museums, and other federal properties. The White House is seeking $24 billion in military and humanitarian aid for Ukraine, but some House Republicans oppose the plan. This marks the second time in recent months that the US faces a financial gridlock, with a 35-day shutdown in 2018-2019 being the longest in US history.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The dome of the U.S. Capitol is reflected in a window on  Capitol Hill in Washington, U.S., April 20, 2023. REUTERS/Amanda Andrade-Rhoades/File Photo

FILE PHOTO: U.S. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen addresses a news conference during a G20 finance ministers' and Central Bank governors' meeting at Gandhinagar, India, July 16, 2023. REUTERS/Amit Dave/File Photo
Federal Reserve officials are gathering on Tuesday for a two-day meeting that could see them raise rates again to lower inflation sustainably back to a two per cent target.
Geopolitics remained a major concern for many firms, with US-China tensions cited as a top business challenge by 60 per cent of the survey’s 325 respondents.

site_title: Parliament to consider Iswaran’s MP status only after investigation outcomes are revealed
summary: Singapore's Parliament has decided to consider the case of Member of Parliament S Iswaran after the outcome of ongoing corruption investigations is revealed, rather than taking action prematurely. The decision was made after Leader of the House Indranee Rajah opposed a proposal to suspend Iswaran, citing the need for a fair and firm approach. Parliament will now wait for the investigation outcomes before making a decision on Iswaran's MP status, allowing for due process and upholding the rule of law.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Systems are composed of human beings and “sometimes, something will still go wrong” however comprehensive the safeguards are, says Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong.
PM Lee said in Parliament on Wednesday (Aug 2) that in the matter of the extramarital affair between former Speaker Tan Chuan-Jin and MP Cheng Li Hui, he should have "forced the issue" earlier.

site_title: US lawmaker to urge chip industry group to reduce China investments: source
summary: US Representative Mike Gallagher plans to urge the Semiconductor Industry Association to tighten US rules that cut off the sale of advanced artificial intelligence chips to China, covering less advanced chips as well. This comes after US rules enacted last October were put in place to restrict the sale of advanced AI chips to China. Gallagher's meeting with the industry group aims to express concerns over US investments in China's chip industry.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen addresses a news conference during a G20 finance ministers' and Central Bank governors' meeting at Gandhinagar, India, July 16, 2023. REUTERS/Amit Dave/File Photo
Federal Reserve officials are gathering on Tuesday for a two-day meeting that could see them raise rates again to lower inflation sustainably back to a two per cent target.
US Secretary of State Antony Blinken and Chinese Vice-President Han Zheng shake hands while meeting in New York City on Sept 18, 2023, ahead of the 78th United Nations General Assembly.
US lawmakers have until midnight on Sept 30 to reach an agreement, before funding for government services is due to dry up.

site_title: US has no evidence Huawei can produce advanced smartphones in large volumes: commerce secretary
summary: US Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo stated at a House hearing that the US has no evidence Huawei can produce advanced smartphones with seven-nanometre chips in large volumes. This comes after Huawei released a phone with a chip that analysts believe was made with a breakthrough technology by SMIC. The Commerce Department is working to obtain more information about the chip, which may violate trade restrictions. Some Republicans suggest ending all technology exports to Huawei and SMIC.

images.alt_text: Huawei may launch a 5G version of its mid-ranged Nova around October or November, says the IT Times.
Huawei’s latest phones have ignited celebration in China and consternation in the US, thanks to their advanced made-in-China processor.
Huawei started selling its latest high-end smartphones Mate 60 and Mate 60 Pro at the end of last month.

Nearly a week after the release of Mate 60 Pro by Huawei Technologies, a Chinese telecommunications giant that has been the target of US sanctions and export controls for years-there are still more questions than answers about its development and what comes next.
Huawei announced on its official online store that it would start taking orders for the new Mate 60 Pro smartphone from 10.08 am (0208 GMT) with delivery by Oct 9.
Huawei's latest Mate 60 Pro is powered by a new advanced chip made by China's SMIC using 7nm technology, a breakthrough for the duo despite US sanctions.

site_title: Europe: Shares end flat as energy gains limit losses; central bank decisions in focus
summary: European shares ended flat on Tuesday, with the Stoxx 600 index holding steady at 456.52 points. Energy stocks advanced 1.0% due to rising crude prices, while industrials and technology stocks declined. Investors are cautious ahead of central bank decisions, including the US Federal Reserve on Wednesday. Euro zone consumer inflation in August was slightly lower than expected, but remains above the European Central Bank's target. The ECB reiterated that interest rates will stay at 4% for an extended period, despite some policy hawks calling for higher rates.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average declined 0.3 per cent to 34,517.73 on Tuesday.

site_title: Amazon develops version of cashierless tech for clothing stores
summary: Amazon has developed a version of its cashierless technology, Just Walk Out, specifically for clothing stores, utilizing radio frequency identification (RFID) tags to track apparel. The technology, previously used in convenience and grocery stores, automatically charges customers upon exiting the store. The system has been piloted at fan shops in Seattle sports arenas and is being deployed at a few dozen Go stores and Fresh outlets. The move aims to expand the technology beyond its current use cases, but it remains unclear how many apparel retailers will adopt the RFID-enabled system.

site_title: Thomson Medical granted 3 months to restore public float
summary: Thomson Medical Group has been granted three months by the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to restore its public float, which has fallen below 10 per cent. The company must have its public float restored by December 10, 2023, and is allowed to continue trading its shares during this period. Thomson Medical reported that its public float had dropped to 9.98 per cent, below the required 10 per cent threshold.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Thomson Medical Group plans to raise public float to 10 per cent.

site_title: US: Stocks dip ahead of Federal Reserve decision
summary: US stocks declined 0.3% on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling to 34,517.73, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index dipping 0.2% each. Investors are on edge ahead of the Federal Reserve's decision on interest rates, which is expected to keep rates unchanged but may lead to further hikes later in 2023. Markets are also monitoring Treasury bond yields and the oil market. The tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index lost 0.2% after Disney fell 3.6% and Intel dropped 4.3% on earnings news.

images.alt_text: A child touches a Wall Street sign near the New York Stock Exchange in New York, U.S., on Wednesday, Oct. 20, 2010. The U.S. government's bailout of financial firms through the Troubled Asset Relief Program provided taxpayers with higher returns than they could have made buying 30-year treasury bonds. Photographer: Jin Lee/Bloomberg

site_title: Courtrooms: a growing arena in the climate fight
summary: Courtrooms are increasingly being used as a battleground in the fight against climate change, with governments, laws, and companies being targeted for their roles in the crisis. A historic Dutch decision ordered Shell to reduce CO2 emissions by 45% by 2023, a decision the oil major is appealing. Meanwhile, six Portuguese youths have lodged a case against 32 countries at the European Court of Human Rights, accusing governments of moving too slowly in addressing climate change. The cases have led to policy changes, with Singapore aiming to ink a carbon credits transfer agreement with its first Asean country by 2025.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Shell logo is seen in this illustration taken May 1, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: No shame in exiting failed investments in search of better rewards elsewhere
summary: A commercial robo-advisory firm, MoneyOwl, has wound down due to high operating costs and low revenue generation. Its decision to exit the business is seen as a mark of wisdom, as it acknowledges the company's lack of profitability. This move also highlights the "disposition effect" in behavioural finance, where investors hold onto losing assets for too long. In contrast, investors should be willing to cut their losses and redeploy resources to more promising ventures, rather than holding onto underperforming investments.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Generic pictures of SGX

site_title: Indonesia’s energy transition deal needs ‘low rates’ of financing: report
summary: Indonesia's energy transition plan, the Just Energy Transition Partnership (JETP), faces complications due to rising borrowing costs, which may hinder the country's goal of decarbonizing its power sector. A report by Zero Carbon Analytics suggests that international funders should consider providing more grants or low rates of financing to support the plan, as current discounted rates may not be sufficient. The US$20 billion JETP aims to support Indonesia's decarbonization efforts, but it faces roadblocks, including a delay in the release of its comprehensive investment and policy plan. The report recommends expanding funding sources, including China and Middle Eastern countries, and leveraging domestic resources to meet the country's long-term energy transition needs.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
PT Indo Raya Tenaga, the developer of the Suralaya plants, has said it plans to power some of the new capacity with ammonia, along with coal, to reduce emissions.

The OJK would consider to expand the green label to loans for coal-fired power plants used by industries that make products considered sustainable, such as batteries for electric vehicles, says OJK chief Mahendra.
Indonesia is the biggest emitter in South-east Asia by a long shot, thanks to vast coal reserves and a power-station construction boom over the past decade or so.
Indonesian finance minister Sri Mulyani says one of the toughest barriers to progress on a US$20 billion coal phase-out fund for the country is how much will come in the form of grants.
The JETP is supposed to provide affordable financing to help the country speed up a transition towards renewable energy and away from coal. But there are still significant disagreements.
The JETP is a deal to speed up Indonesia's move away from coal – by buying out power plants and restructuring debt, so they can be closed early.
Indonesian state utility Perusahaan Listrik Negara has set a target to phase out coal power plants by 2056, as part of the country’s goal to reach net zero carbon emission by 2060.
Coal barges to be pulled along Mahakam river in Samarinda, East Kalimantan province, Indonesia, in August 31, 2019.

site_title: Cryptoverse: Stablecoins sag in the dog days of summer
summary: Stablecoins, a type of cryptocurrency pegged to real-world assets, have seen their market capitalization decline to its lowest point in over two years, with a loss of nearly 10% this year. The decline is attributed to subdued trading volumes and a weaker US dollar. However, Tether, the largest stablecoin, has bucked the trend, with its value reaching an all-time high of $83.8 billion in July. Experts attribute Tether's stability to its popularity in emerging markets.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin has ended positive on Sunday (Sep 17) for the first week in five, and increased as much as 3.7 per cent to US$27,418 on Monday.
If approved, Franklin plans to use Coinbase Global as custodian for the fund’s Bitcoin holdings and Bank of New York Mellon for cash.
The SEC has pushed back the decision dates for the three proposals by several weeks to mid-October.
Hong Kong securities regulator warns that JPEX is advertising itself as a 'licensed and recognized platform,' but has neither applied for nor received a license in the city.
Ant is a major investor in A&T, who has invested in some of crypto’s hottest startups.
FILE PHOTO: Representations of cryptocurrencies Bitcoin, Ethereum and DogeCoin are placed on PC motherboard in this illustration taken, June 29, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/File Photo
Tighter regulations generally have prompted many traditional financial institutions to hold back on offering cash to crypto services and vice versa, says Binance CEO Changpeng ‘CZ’ Zhao.

site_title: UK banks press BOE to soften stricter capital rules
summary: UK banks are pushing the Bank of England (BOE) to soften stricter capital rules, citing concerns they would harm the economy, particularly in small and medium-sized enterprise lending and green lending. NatWest's finance director, Katie Murray, described the planned rule changes as "very bad" for the UK economy. The BOE is consulting on the latest round of international standards agreed by the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision, which set reserves banks must keep as a cushion against losses.

images.alt_text: The UK’s economic outlook has darkened since June, bolstering arguments that 14 consecutive rate hikes are beginning to take their toll on output.

site_title: China appeals WTO ruling over its retaliatory tariffs on US imports
summary: China has appealed a World Trade Organization (WTO) ruling that found its retaliatory tariffs on US imports, worth $3 billion, to be inconsistent with international trade rules. The ruling, made last month, also determined that the US tariffs on Chinese steel and aluminum were unjustified. China's appeal will now block the US ability to move forward and request financial compensation. The WTO's appeals tribunal, which has been frozen since 2019, will need to be reactivated to resolve the case.

images.alt_text: The director-general of the World Trade Organization Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala in Berlin on Monday (Sep 4).  She encouraged western economies to shift production facilities into nations from the global south as a way of building resilience in global supply chains after three years of historic disruptions.

site_title: Singapore fines firm, two citizens for exporting sonar system to Myanmar
summary: A Singapore court fined Hydronav Services S$1.13 million for exporting a sonar system to Myanmar in 2018 without a permit. Two employees, Wui Ong Chuan and Poiter Agus Kentjana, were fined S$45,000 and S$35,000 respectively for their roles in the export. The equipment was used by the Myanmar Navy Hydrographic Centre, with no evidence it was used for military purposes. The case highlights Singapore's strict export controls on "strategic goods".

images.alt_text: Asean leaders in a group photo after the opening of the 43rd Asean Summit. With the exception of Myanmar, representatives from all member states attended the opening ceremony, two high-level sessions and a forum focused on promoting cooperation in the Indo-Pacific region.

site_title: Microsoft eyes Apple’s spot as world’s largest stock
summary: Microsoft's shares have outperformed Apple's this month, narrowing the gap between their market values. Microsoft's market value is now closer to Apple's due to its strong growth prospects in cloud computing and artificial intelligence. Analysts predict Microsoft may overtake Apple due to its more attractive investment profile, citing lower China risk and better growth prospects. Despite still having a significant gap, Microsoft's market value is closing in on Apple's.

images.alt_text: “With data privacy, security, and compliance as our core priorities, we have a unique opportunity to help organisations responsibly innovate,” Microsoft chief commercial officer Judson Althoff says.

FILE PHOTO: A Microsoft logo is seen a day after Microsoft Corp's $26.2 billion purchase of LinkedIn Corp, in Los Angeles, California, U.S. June 14, 2016. REUTERS/Lucy Nicholson/File Photo/File Photo/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: A view shows a Microsoft logo at Microsoft offices in Issy-les-Moulineaux near Paris, France, January 25, 2023. REUTERS/Gonzalo Fuentes/File Photo
In the Circuit interview, Microsoft’s CEO Satya Nadella cautions that the real AI impact is yet to be seen.

site_title: Country Garden leaves bondholders in dark as interest unpaid
summary: Country Garden Holdings, a Chinese developer, has failed to pay dollar bond interest to holders, leaving them in the dark. The company had to pay $15.4 million of interest by Monday but two holders have yet to receive the payment. Country Garden has a 30-day grace period before a default can be called, following a broader property debt crisis. The company has been plagued by financial issues, with $1.36 trillion of total liabilities, and has sought to extend repayments on several notes.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A logo of Chinese developer Country Garden is pictured in Tianjin, China August 18, 2023. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo

site_title: Euro gains, yen struggles in central bank-packed week
summary: The euro rose 0.4% to a 15-month high against the US dollar, driven by a report that the European Central Bank may discuss draining excess liquidity in the banking system, potentially tightening monetary policy. The yen, meanwhile, fell to a 10-month low against the dollar due to expectations that the Bank of Japan will maintain its ultra-low interest rates. Despite the euro's gains, analysts believe it may not be enough to reverse its weakening trend, and the yen's weakness is expected to continue.

site_title: Google adds ChatGPT rival Bard to Gmail, YouTube, Docs and more
summary: Google has integrated its Bard chatbot into various services, including Gmail, YouTube, and Docs, allowing users to look up flight information, map routes, and watch relevant videos in a single chat. This move follows Microsoft's integration of ChatGPT into its Office suite and comes after Google's executives faced scrutiny from regulators. The integration does not compromise enterprise customers' data, and users can double-check Bard's responses by viewing source material via Google's search engine. This update aims to further Google's dominance in generative artificial intelligence.

site_title: Singapore’s F1 race has its detractors, but healthy ticket sales prove event has plenty of legs
summary: Singapore's Formula 1 Grand Prix has seen healthy ticket sales, with 264,108 fans attending the event this year, exceeding expectations despite the closure of the Bay Grandstand. The event has proven to be a successful and popular stop on the Formula 1 calendar, with record-breaking attendance in 2022 and a continued strong demand for tickets. The Singapore Grand Prix has been a mainstay on the city-state's sporting calendar for 15 years, and its seven-year contract extension until 2028 has been deemed wise given the strong demand.

images.alt_text: Ferrari's Spanish driver Carlos Sainz Jr celebrating on the podium after winning the Singapore Formula One Grand Prix.

F1 driver Lewis Hamilton (fifth from left) met with children from UBS Singapore’s community partners through various social service agencies on Sep 14, 2023. With them is UBS Singapore country head Jin Yee Young (second from right).
Hotels near the downtown race circuit generally expect their F1 takings to exceed pre-Covid levels, and possibly those of 2022.

site_title: Global debt hits record US$307 trillion, debt ratios climb: IIF
summary: Global debt has reached a record US$307 trillion in the second quarter of 2023, according to the Institute of International Finance (IIF). This marks a US$10 trillion increase in the first half of 2023 and a US$100 trillion rise over the past decade. The global debt-to-GDP ratio has climbed to 336% for a second consecutive quarter, surpassing prior declines. Rising interest rates have curbed bank credit, but markets such as the US and Japan have driven the increase.

images.alt_text: Growth will ease to 2.7 per cent in 2024 after an already “sub-par” expansion of 3 per cent in 2023, according to the latest OECD forecasts.
Breaking it down regionally, US and Asian equity funds have inflows of roughly US$9.7 billion and US$1.62 billion, respectively.
Luigi Speranza, chief economist and global head of Markets 360, BNP Paribas, says that the weakness in the European market is overstated.
The Investor Agenda says governments continue to see climate change as separate to, and less important than, other aspects of economic and fiscal policy.
An IMF spokesperson says that a domestic debt rework “is among the several issues identified as challenges to debt restructuring.”
IMF says global debt appears to have returned to its historical upward trend and managing debt vulnerabilities should be key.

In Europe, where a larger part of financing comes from banks, firms have started feeling the pinch from the fastest tightening cycle in a decade and the amount spent on finance costs rose by a sixth at constant exchange rates.

site_title: IMF sees Europe’s slowdown in line with expectations
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has confirmed that Europe's economy is weakening in line with forecasts, with manufacturing output slowing and services sector growth expected to follow. Germany, Europe's largest economy, is at risk of underperformance due to factors such as the rapid shift away from Russian fossil fuels, global trade fragmentation, and an aging society. Inflation in the euro area remains above the ECB's target, with Kammer stating that inflation control is the top priority. The IMF's European director, Alfred Kammer, and European Central Bank's director general, Oscar Arce, agree that the region's growth is sluggish.

images.alt_text: IMF says global debt appears to have returned to its historical upward trend and managing debt vulnerabilities should be key.

site_title: No evidence banks are closing accounts due to political beliefs, says UK watchdog
summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has found no evidence that banks have closed accounts due to people's political views, contrary to claims made by former Brexit Party leader Nigel Farage. The FCA investigated 34 banks and building societies from July 2022 to June 2023 and found that the most common reasons for account declines were due to inactivity or concerns about financial crime. The FCA will continue to investigate and gather more data to better understand the reasons behind account closures.

images.alt_text: The watchdog has already observed how volatility during the trading day has doubled and amplified compared to during the 2008 global financial crisis.

site_title: Disney plans to nearly double spending on parks to US$60 billion over 10 years
summary: Disney plans to nearly double its spending on parks to $60 billion over 10 years, with CEO Bob Iger describing the parks as a "tremendous business" for the company. The investment aims to appeal to the 700 million Disney fans who have yet to visit a theme park, with over 1,000 acres of land available for future development globally. The parks business has become a reliable profit engine for Disney, cushioning losses in the Disney+ streaming business, which is expected to become profitable next year.

images.alt_text: The discussions come after Disney CEO Bob Iger said in July the company could sell some of its traditional TV assets, which have struggled for years due to the rise of streaming services.
Disney+ has been losing customers to price increases, as well as collapsing demand in India after the company failed to win cricket streaming rights.
Lucasfilm sold its Sandcrawler building in Singapore to US private equity giant Blackstone Group in 2021. It once served as its regional headquarters.
Walt Disney CEO Bob Iger sparks industry buzz about company's television business not being core.
Since the launch of Disney+ in November 2019, the world’s largest entertainment company had sought to attract streaming subscribers with unsustainably low prices.

site_title: Canadian inflation jumps; October rate hike bets rise
summary: Canada's annual inflation rate jumped to 4.0% in August, the highest since April, driven by a 0.8% year-on-year increase in petrol prices. This exceeds the Bank of Canada's 2% target and fuels speculation of another interest rate hike. The consumer price index rose 0.4% on a month-over-month basis, surpassing forecasted 0.3% growth. This marks the 11th consecutive month of inflation above the Bank's target, raising concerns about the central bank's ability to control inflation.

images.alt_text: “Our government is going to do everything in our power to make sure food prices stabilise. This meeting today is part of that effort,” says Canada Finance Minister Chrystia Freeland.
The number of homes trading hands across the country declines 4.1 per cent in August from July, according to seasonally adjusted data released by the Canadian Real Estate Association.
The value of residential real estate in Canada rises 2.0 per cent in the April to June period.
Policymakers led by Bank of Canada governor Tiff Macklem keep the benchmark overnight lending rate at 5 per cent, the highest level in 22 years.

site_title: Yellen says US 'soft landing' can weather strike, government shutdown, student loan risks
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said a "soft landing" for the US economy can withstand near-term risks, including a United Auto Workers strike, government shutdown, and student loan repayment resumption. Yellen notes that the labor market is cooling in a healthy way, without mass layoffs, and that the economy is making progress in reducing inflation while maintaining a strong labor market and consumer spending. The Federal Reserve is set to meet on Tuesday to weigh its options on rate hikes, amid concerns about the potential impact of these risks on the economy.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen addresses a news conference during a G20 finance ministers' and Central Bank governors' meeting at Gandhinagar, India, July 16, 2023. REUTERS/Amit Dave/File Photo

site_title: US single-family housing starts tumble in August
summary: US single-family housing starts fell 4.3% in August to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 941,000 units, likely due to the resurgence of mortgage rates weighing on demand for new construction. The average 30-year fixed mortgage rate is around 7.18%, the highest since March 2002, and is pushing buyers to the sidelines. Housing starts for projects with five units or more dropped 26.3% to 334,000 units, while overall starts tumbled 11.3% to 1.283 million units.

images.alt_text: LEMONT, ILLINOIS - JUNE 21: A home is constructed at a housing development on June 21, 2023 in Lemont, Illinois. US housing starts climbed more than 20% last month which has helped lumber futures climb nearly 9% over the same period. According to the National Association of Home Builders, volatile prices of lumber products in recent years have caused the average price of a new single-family home to increase by more than $14,000.   Scott Olson/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by SCOTT OLSON / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)
The contract rate on an adjustable mortgage increases by more than a quarter of a percentage point to 6.59 per cent, the highest in Mortgage Bankers Association (MBA) data back to early 2011.

site_title: Golden Energy and Resources’ offeror exercises right of compulsory acquisition
summary: Duchess Avenue, a wholly-owned subsidiary of Star Success, has exercised its right to compulsorily acquire all shares of Golden Energy and Resources (Gear) by the close date of Aug 15. The offeror's initial offer price was S$0.16 per share, later raised to S$0.181 per share. As of Aug 10, Gear received 97.21% valid acceptances, and the consideration for acquired shares will be credited directly into designated bank accounts for Singapore dollars. Gear will become a wholly-owned subsidiary of Duchess Avenue and be delisted from the Singapore Exchange at a later date.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
The exit offer closes on Aug 15, 5.30pm.

site_title: Singapore shares fall as cautious investors await Fed’s next move
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.7% on Tuesday, Sep 19, in line with most regional indices, as investors awaited the US Federal Reserve's next move. Despite this, oil and gas sector counters rose, bucking the decline in the Straits Times Index, driven by higher oil demand and output cuts. Fed officials are expected to hold interest rates at their current level, with investors cautious about potential surprises.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Singapore shares muted at Tuesday’s open; STI up 0.03%

site_title: Asset managers rebuffed as EU cracks down on use of ‘ESG’
summary: The European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) is pushing forward with a proposal to restrict the use of "ESG" and "sustainable" in fund names, despite industry opposition. The plan, unveiled in November, requires 80% of assets in "ESG" funds to promote environmental, social, and governance goals and 50% in "sustainable" funds. Industry giants, including BlackRock and Goldman Sachs, have criticized the proposal as unworkable, citing the lack of a clear definition of sustainability. The move may lead to widespread reclassifications across Europe's $11 trillion fund market, potentially affecting fund flows and triggering outflows from asset managers forced to stop using these terms.

images.alt_text: An aerial view of forest land being cleared in Indonesia's West Kalimantan. The new framework by TNFD paves the way for a new focus around creating a “nature-positive” economy.

site_title: Japan, Malaysia renew bilateral currency swap pact
summary: Japan and Malaysia have renewed their bilateral currency swap arrangement of up to $3 billion to enhance regional financial stability. The pact, extended on September 18, allows for exchange of currencies for US dollars and the Malaysian ringgit for the Japanese yen. This move aims to promote regional financial stability and follows Japan's recent revival of a $10-billion currency swap deal with South Korea. The agreement has no end date marked.

site_title: Thai king's son urges open discussion of royal insult law
summary: Thai King Maha Vajiralongkorn's son, Vacharaesorn Vivacharawongse, has called for open discussion of Thailand's strict royal defamation laws, also known as 112, which can carry heavy jail sentences. He attended an exhibition in New York highlighting people prosecuted under the law, stating that "everyone should share their opinions based on different experiences." This comes amid ongoing protests and calls for reform, with critics arguing the laws have been used to silence dissent.

images.alt_text: King Maha Vajiralongkorn and his close family are protected by some of the world’s strictest royal defamation laws, with each charge carrying a possible 15-year jail term.

site_title: Post-Covid, weak demand still main hurdle to Singapore’s ‘30 by 30’ food goal
summary: Singapore's goal to produce 30% of local food needs by 2030 remains unmet due to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic and weak demand, according to industry players. Local vegetable farms contributed only 3.9% of Singapore's food consumption in 2022, down from 4.5% in 2019. The pandemic led to a decline in demand for locally sourced food from hotels, restaurants, and airlines, making it challenging for local farms to meet their needs.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
According to the Thai Rice Exporters Association, prices for Thai white rice 5 per cent broken, an Asian benchmark, jumped to US$648 a tonne in early August.

site_title: Malaysia’s August exports decline 18.6% due to slower global demand
summary: Malaysia's August exports declined 18.6% year-on-year to RM115.2 billion, driven by slower global demand and high base effects, according to government data. This is the sixth straight month of a decline in exports since March, with the last growth seen in February. Economists expect the weakness in external trade to continue in the coming months.

images.alt_text: Tan Ai Leng
Malaysia’s central bank says the country's economy will continue to grow, on the back of resilient domestic expenditure and robust tourism activities.
Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim tabled the Mid-Term Review of the 12th Malaysia Plan in the Parliament on Monday (Sep 11).

site_title: Starbucks opens US$220 million plant outside Shanghai
summary: Starbucks has opened a US$220 million development outside Shanghai, the largest investment the company has made in a project outside the US. Despite a record low optimism among US businesses in China due to the sluggish economy and Washington-Beijing tensions, Starbucks' CEO Laxman Narasimhan expressed confidence in the company's future in China, stating that "Starbucks' best days are ahead in China." The new "Coffee Innovation Park" includes a roasting plant and distribution center, serving Starbucks' China stores exclusively.

images.alt_text: The world’s largest coffeehouse chain has targeted its younger, wealthier US customer base by launching new drinks and promoting food options that have helped drive up average customer sales.

site_title: India rejects Canada's suspicions on role in Sikh leader's murder
summary: India has rejected Canada's suspicions that New Delhi's agents were involved in the murder of Sikh separatist leader Hardeep Singh Nijjar, who was shot dead outside a temple in Surrey three years after being designated a "terrorist". Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau stated that authorities were "actively pursuing credible allegations" linking India to the murder, but India dismissed the claims as "absurd". The incident has strained diplomatic ties and trade relations between the two countries, with each nation expelling a diplomat in a tit-for-tat move.

images.alt_text: Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau (centre) was due to return home on Sunday after laying a wreath at a memorial to Indian independence leader Mahatma Gandhi, but a mechanical fault kept him in India overnight.

site_title: AllianceBernstein joins bond bulls camp with 2.5% call on yields
summary: AllianceBernstein predicts the US Federal Reserve's hiking cycle is nearing its end, with yields expected to ease next year, potentially reaching 2.5% by the end of 2024. The investment manager expects at least four rate cuts, with 10-year Treasuries offering a return of almost 20% if yields drop to 2.5%. This prediction joins a growing camp of bond bulls, with other firms like Invesco and JPMorgan Asset Management also calling for a turning point in the US bond market.

images.alt_text: Worries about bond “maturity walls” come around every so often, but the high-yield market has become so big and diverse that it is hard to imagine a scenario in which companies simply can’t borrow new funds.
Growth will ease to 2.7 per cent in 2024 after an already “sub-par” expansion of 3 per cent in 2023, according to the latest OECD forecasts.

site_title: Thailand’s ancient town of Si Thep added to world heritage list
summary: Thailand's ancient town of Si Thep, a 1,500-year-old complex of temples and monasteries, was added to UNESCO's world heritage list on September 19, marking Thailand's first cultural site recognition since 1992. The site, located in Phetchabun province, is home to a unique collection of historical buildings. Thai Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin expressed gratitude for the decision, but an expert warned that the complex is not ready for an influx of tourists. The recognition aims to preserve the site's cultural and historical significance for future generations.

images.alt_text: Belgian Beer World will open on Saturday (Sep 9) in the neoclassical former Brussels Stock Exchange.
A school of fish swim above a finger coral colony as it grows on the Great Barrier Reef off the coast of Cairns, Australia October 25, 2019. REUTERS/Lucas Jackson REFILE - CORRECTING TYPE OF CORAL
Venice, known for its canals and cultural sites, has been struggling with mass tourism for years.

site_title: Hong Kong's June-August unemployment rate unchanged at 2.8%
summary: Hong Kong's seasonally adjusted unemployment rate remained unchanged at 2.8% for the June-August period, according to the government. Secretary for Labour and Welfare Chris Sun attributed the stability to the ongoing recovery of inbound tourism and local consumption, which is expected to support the labour market in the coming months. The jobless rate had also remained the same for the May-July period.

site_title: Hong Kong’s crypto push gets blunt warning as probe erupts
summary: Hong Kong's crypto push has been dealt a blow as a probe into JPEX, a trading platform that has ensnared social media influencers, erupts. The platform's troubles cast a spotlight on regulatory and legal showdowns in the crypto world. The Securities and Futures Commission warned JPEX of being an unregulated entity, and over 1,400 complaints were made to local police involving $128 million. Six people were arrested on suspicion of conspiracy to defraud. Hong Kong's Chief Executive John Lee has promised to address the issue, but the scandal suggests the city's goal of creating a crypto hub won't be smooth sailing.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong securities regulator warns that JPEX is advertising itself as a 'licensed and recognized platform,' but has neither applied for nor received a license in the city.

site_title: China’s BYD rides on partnerships to expand EV sales in South-east Asia
summary: China's BYD has rapidly expanded its electric vehicle (EV) sales in South-east Asia, surpassing rivals including Tesla, with over 26% market share. The company's success is attributed to a partnership model with local conglomerates, allowing it to expand reach, test consumer preferences, and navigate complex government regulations. BYD's focus on brand proliferation comes at the cost of lower profit margins. The company has invested nearly $500 million in a new factory in Thailand, and is expanding its presence in the region through partnerships with established players such as Sime Darby and Ayala Corp.

images.alt_text: Under new CEO Koji Sato, Toyota in June announced an ambitious plan to ramp up battery EVs, a big shift after years of criticism that the maker of the industry-leading hybrid Prius was slow to embrace fully electric technology.
BYD, Xpeng, Great Wall Motor and others hope dealerships will quickly help them mobilise robust sales and service networks as they try to establish reputations for quality and reliability.
Beijing originally cut taxes in 2009 for EVs and then began exempting them entirely from the vehicle purchase tax in 2014.
Tackling China’s subsidies – even if proven – will also not change the view that Chinese vehicles are technologically advanced and Europe’s carmakers have been slow to adapt and innovate.

site_title: MAS reports S$20.8 million in penalties, 39 convictions from 2022 to mid-2023
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has reported S$20.8 million in penalties and 39 convictions from January 2022 to mid-2023, the highest amount since MAS began publishing its Enforcement Report in 2019. The penalties include S$7.1 million for anti-money laundering-related breaches and nearly S$13 million for market abuse cases. Notable actions include a record S$12.6 million civil penalty against Noble Group for disclosure-related offences and prohibition orders on the co-founders of Three Arrows Capital for failing to ensure regulatory compliance.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Noble and its subsidiary were discovered to have applied an incorrect accounting treatment to long-term marketing agreements by classifying them as financial instruments instead of service contracts.
DBS Group CEO Piyush Gupta said banks had already been more cautious over the last 15 years since the global financial crisis.

site_title: Panama Canal backlog could impact US Christmas retail sales
summary: The Panama Canal is experiencing its worst drought in 70 years, resulting in a backlog of vessels and long waiting periods, potentially impacting US Christmas retail sales. The waterway's reduced capacity has caused concerns among shipping and logistics industries, with some predicting a shortage of goods. A UK-based courier service, ParcelHero, warned that the issue may lead to a Christmas sales shortage. The crisis is expected to continue, affecting global supply chains and potentially leading to increased costs for consumers.

images.alt_text: A fire broke out on the Fremantle Highway on Jul 25, killing one crew member and prompting a massive effort to extinguish the flames. A significant chunk of the global container shipping industry is backing a programme focused on reducing cargo fires and loss.
Bulk carriers are even less well-known to the public than container ships, but their role in feeding the world has been highlighted by Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

Cargo ships wait in the anchor zone to cross the Panama Canal from the Pacific entrance near Panama City, Panama, on Sept 1, 2023. Ships have been waiting for days as the congestion to cross from both sides  increase due to the intense droughts in the country.

site_title: Japan’s central bank will keep stimulus for now as risks grow
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) is expected to maintain ultra-low interest rates and monetary stimulus for now, amid growing risks from China's economic woes and global interest rate hikes. BOJ Governor Kazuo Ueda will likely reassure markets that stimulus will stay, at least for now, as inflation remains above 2% target. The central bank will maintain its short-term interest rate target of -0.1% and 10-year bond yield around zero%, with no consensus on when to end negative rates or shift away from massive stimulus.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Japan’s ultra-loose monetary policy, which was aimed at “buying time” to push through structural reforms, will eventually end as inflation accelerates, Japanese industry minister Yasutoshi Nishimura said on Tuesday.
Orders from manufacturers fell 5.3 per cent in July, the largest decline in eight months, due to weak demand for computers from industries including electric machinery, auto and chemicals.

Recent auctions have been weak as even long-term buyers wait for an eventual rise in yields after the BOJ, so far an outlier among hawkish global central banks, tweaked its yield curve control policy late in July.

The sharp rise in the yield came as investors reacted to BOJ governor Kazuo Ueda’s interview with the Yomiuri newspaper, published on Saturday, in which he said the central bank could end its negative interest rate policy when its 2 per cent inflation goal is in sight, indicating possible rate hikes by year-end.
According to Bank of Japan policymaker Junko Nakagawa, it's hard to say when inflation could hit the bank’s 2 per cent inflation target in a sustainable manner.

site_title: Thailand launches probe into Chinese rolled steel imports
summary: Thailand launches an investigation into Chinese rolled steel imports for allegedly evading anti-dumping measures. The probe covers hot-rolled steel sheets from 17 Chinese manufacturers. The move follows a complaint from four Thai steel makers. The investigation aims to determine if the imports were made to avoid paying anti-dumping duties.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) reported 136 cases and 455 actions from January 2022 to June 2023, resulting in S$20.8 million in penalties, 39 convictions, and 18 prohibition orders. The government aims to fine-tune carbon emission management for the Formula 1 Grand Prix and Mice industry. A fare hike could boost ComfortDelGro's FY2024 profit by S$11 million, according to DBS Group Research. The global task force finalized a framework for nature-related financial disclosures, and Singapore shares fell 0.7% as investors await the Federal Reserve's next move.

images.alt_text: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) building in the Central Business District (CBD) at 12.35pm on 27 May 2020.

site_title: No, Europe won't be ready for Trump 2.0 either
summary: European Union leaders are unprepared for a potential second Donald Trump presidency, despite Foreign Minister Annalena Baerbock's claims of better preparedness. Trump's supporters and MAGA think tanks have had four years to prepare detailed staff lists and policy papers, which would enable him to purge off-message civil servants and implement policies that align with his personal interests. A Trump presidency would likely lead to a revolution in US domestic and foreign policy, posing a significant threat to the transatlantic alliance and shared democratic values.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump is also promoting a universal reciprocal tariff that would see the United States imposing tariff rates on foreign goods equivalent to what the exporting country charges on US goods.
T-shirts with an image depicting the mugshot of former president Donald Trump have appeared on retail shelves, like in this store in Los Angeles, California.

site_title: Why Miro’s yellows have lost their brilliance
summary: Researchers have found that a specific brand of cadmium yellow paint, Cadmium Yellow Lemon No 1 by Lucien Lefebvre-Foinet, is likely responsible for the degradation observed in artworks by Spanish artist Joan Miro. The paint, used in the 1970s, contains poor crystallinity, leading to fading and a chalky appearance over time. This discovery highlights the issue of cadmium yellow paint degradation, which affects not only centuries-old artworks but also mid-20th-century pieces, contradicting expectations that the problem would have been resolved by the time.

images.alt_text: Sher-Gil’s 1937 painting The Story Teller sold for the equivalent of US$7.44 million.
Okuda Yuta of Mizuma Gallery is one of several artists whose creations will be on display during the art and wine crawl for BT readers.

site_title: Volvo to end diesel car production by early 2024
summary: Volvo, majority owned by China's Geely, will end production of remaining diesel models by early 2024, marking its transition towards becoming an all-electric carmaker. The company has committed to going fully electric by 2030, as previously stated. This move aligns with Volvo's goal of becoming a leader in the electric vehicle market, and it is one of the first legacy carmakers to take this step.

images.alt_text: (L-R) Joseph Heng general manager UD Trucks Singapore; Anna Engblom, managing director Volvo Trucks - South-East Asia & Japan; Gino Marzola, managing director DSV Air & Sea Singapore & Malaysia.

site_title: OECD warns of global economic slowdown amid rising interest rates
summary: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) has warned of a global economic slowdown amid rising interest rates, predicting a 2.7% growth rate in 2024, down from 3% in 2023. The slowdown is attributed to China's pandemic rebound disappointing, tighter monetary policy, and persistent inflation. The OECD cautions against easing up on interest rates, recommending that monetary policy remains restrictive until underlying inflation pressures abate. Regional forecasts also indicate a contraction in Germany's economy and a slowdown in US expansion to 1.3% in 2024.

images.alt_text: The UK’s economic outlook has darkened since June, bolstering arguments that 14 consecutive rate hikes are beginning to take their toll on output.
“Our government is going to do everything in our power to make sure food prices stabilise. This meeting today is part of that effort,” says Canada Finance Minister Chrystia Freeland.
“The correction is not complete, and more is expected to drive down retail inflation in its September reading,” says Reserve Bank of India.
Thursday’s 25-basis-point increase pushes the rate the ECB pays on bank deposits to 4.0 per cent, the highest level since the euro currency was launched in 1999.
The consumer price index remains well below the government’s official target of around 3 per cent for the year.
Jobs at highest risk were defined as those using more than 25 of the 100 skills and abilities that AI experts consider can be easily automated.

The headline gauge for the advanced economies that encompasses rich countries around the world falls to 6.5 per cent in May, while a so-called core index that strips out food and energy is at 6.9 per cent.

site_title: Chinese developer Sunac seeks Chapter 15 protection in New York court
summary: Chinese property developer Sunac China Holdings has filed for Chapter 15 protection in a US bankruptcy court, seeking to shield itself from creditors. The company's $9 billion offshore debt restructuring plan was approved by creditors on Monday, marking the first such approval for a major Chinese developer. This move comes as part of a string of Chinese property developers that have defaulted on offshore debt payments since 2021, amid a liquidity crisis in the sector.

site_title: UK inflation expected to tick up, complicating talk of Bank of England pause
summary: The UK's inflation rate is expected to rise to 7% in August, marking the first acceleration since February, according to a Bloomberg survey. This increase is attributed to fuel price fluctuations. The Bank of England (BOE) is set to raise interest rates by 25 basis points on Thursday, despite speculation that the bank may pause after its next increase. Economists attribute the decision to the risk of continued price increases while the broader economy stalls, potentially leading to "stagflation." The decision complicates Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's plans to cut inflation and increase growth ahead of a general election.

images.alt_text: The ECB, as well as BOE, faces a bigger dilemma than the US Federal Reserve because prices in Europe are still rising fast and growth is slowing.

All but one of 65 economists polled by Reuters in recent days predict the Bank of England will raise Bank Rate to 5.5 per cent on Thursday (Sep 21) from 5.25 per cent, which would mark its highest level since 2007.

site_title: At least one car dealer under probe in billion-dollar money-laundering case
summary: A police probe into the S$1 billion money-laundering case has extended to the auto dealing sector, with at least one player reportedly being questioned by authorities. Luxury items and cash were seized, and prohibition of disposal orders were issued against properties and cars. The probe aims to uncover the source of the funds involved in the billion-dollar money-laundering case.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek

site_title: Allure of Asia credit: income, quality, diversification
summary: Asia credit has maintained positive performance in 2023, offering competitive risk-adjusted returns compared to global developed market bonds. Despite concerns about China's property market and sluggish growth expectations, recent policy support and economic data indicate early signs of improvement in Chinese industrial activity. The Asia-Pacific credit market is robust, with limited supply and robust demand, and offers an attractive yield exceeding 6% with a shorter duration of 4.5 years. Pictet Wealth Management maintains a constructive outlook on Asia credit, viewing it as an appealing source of high-quality income for investors.

images.alt_text: Geopolitics remained a major concern for many firms, with US-China tensions cited as a top business challenge by 60 per cent of the survey’s 325 respondents.

site_title: Swiss watch exports rebound in August, led by strong US demand
summary: Swiss watch exports rebounded in August, rising 4% to 1.8 billion Swiss francs, driven by a 13.5% surge in US demand. This marks the first monthly increase in over two years, despite higher prices and slowing economic growth. The US, Hong Kong, and UK were the strongest markets, while China's exports fell 27% for the second consecutive month. The industry is still on track for a better performance than 2022, with brands raising prices to counter higher input costs and boosting sales and profits.

site_title: Fare hike could lift ComfortDelGro’s FY2024 profit by S$11 million: DBS
summary: DBS estimates a FY2024 bottom line improvement of S$14.7 million for SBS Transit due to impending fare hikes, translating to an S$11 million increase in ComfortDelGro's net profit. The fare hike is expected to boost contributions from ComfortDelGro's bus and train businesses, contributing to its FY2024 profit.

images.alt_text: Navene Elangovan
The board has proposed a final dividend of 5.45 Singapore cents per share for H2 2022, SBS Transit said.
The overall cost of bus and train rides will go up by 7 per cent.
Net profit for the three months ended Mar 31 rose to S$15.8 million, from S$15.5 million in the year-ago period, according to a business update on the Singapore Exchange.
Cheng Siak Kian, Group CEO, Comfort Delgro

site_title: BT BAF beneficiaries share stories of triumph over hardship
summary: Eight former recipients of the Business Times Budding Artists Fund (BT BAF) have come together to share their stories of hardship and triumph in a new theatre production, "I AM ____". The play, launched in 2023, aims to inspire others facing similar challenges by showcasing the impact of the fund on the lives of over 22,000 talented children from low-income families. The play, presented by Souljourn, runs from Sep 29 to Oct 1 at the Goodman Arts Centre's Black Box Theatre.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

Winners of previous 13-19 Art Prize include Fairfield Secondary School student Chua Rui Yan's painting titled Monotony (oil on canvas, 84 x 60 cm), depicting of our fraught relationship with technology.

site_title: PBOC sells more yuan bills in Hong Kong, tempers downward yuan pressure
summary: China's central bank, the PBOC, sold 15 billion yuan (S$2.8 billion) worth of six-month yuan-denominated bills in Hong Kong at a record-high coupon rate of 3.38%, aiming to stem rapid yuan declines. This is the highest coupon rate since 2018 and 114 basis points higher than the previous auction. The move is seen as a way to soak up yuan liquidity and make it more expensive to short the yuan, amid tight liquidity conditions in the offshore market.

images.alt_text: The yuan has bounced 0.9 per cent to the US dollar since it touched a 16-year low earlier this month, partly due to the central bank’s intensified efforts to stem rapid declines.

site_title: With Singapore Turf Club on its last legs, concerns surface over fundraising drying up
summary: The Singapore Turf Club (STC) is set to close in March 2027, hosting its last race in October 2024, amid concerns over the impact on charities and beneficiaries relying on its fundraising efforts. The club sponsors or contributes to around 20 charity organizations annually, including the Community Chest and Beyond Social Services. Its closure may lead to a funding shortfall for charities and affect related businesses, such as horse owners, breeders, and tourism businesses. The Tote Board, which channels STC's surpluses, remains confident its overall fundraising efforts will not be impacted.

images.alt_text: While the Singapore Turf Club's impending closure deals an undeniable blow to the racing community, we need not romanticise the institution of horse-racing.
In line with government efforts to optimise land use, the land where the Singapore Turf Club in Kranji sits will be redeveloped for housing and other developments.
The Singapore Turf Club's closure comes amid shrinking audiences and prize purses.
The Singapore Turf Club's current site in Kranji will be returned to the government by March 2027 to make way for housing and other developments in the area.

site_title: Gold hits 2-week high as Fed policy meet grabs attention
summary: Gold prices reached a two-week high on Tuesday, with spot gold steady at $1,932.32 per ounce, ahead of the US Federal Reserve's policy meeting. The dollar weakened 0.1% against its rivals, making gold less expensive for overseas buyers. Despite expectations of unchanged interest rates, Fed Chair Powell's speech may highlight ongoing inflation risks, potentially affecting gold's appeal if rates rise to control inflation.

images.alt_text: A one kilogram gold bar sits on top of silver bars at London bullion dealers Gold Investments Ltd. in this arranged photograph in London, U.K., on Thursday, April 4, 2013. Gold traders are split on whether bullion will plunge into its first bear market since 2008 as economies improve or rally as central banks buy more debt. Photographer: Simon Dawson/Bloomberg
US gold futures were up 0.2 per cent to US$1,949.30 on Monday.

site_title: Michael Jackson's moonwalk hat up for auction
summary: A fedora hat belonging to Michael Jackson, worn during his iconic moonwalk dance in 1983, is up for auction in Paris on September 26. The black wool hat, lined with silk, is expected to fetch between $64,000 and $107,000. The sale comes as music memorabilia has become a big business, with recent auctions fetching high prices for items owned by Freddie Mercury and Noel Gallagher. The hat's sale is expected to be one of several notable items, including a guitar owned by T-Bone Walker and a suit worn by Depeche Mode's Martin Gore.

images.alt_text: A Fedora hat that belonged to US singer Michael Jackson, made of wool and lined with silk, is displayed before being put on sale at auction, in Paris, on September 12, 2023. The hat is among items that will be auctioned at the Drouot Paris auction house on September 26, 2023. (Photo by Geoffroy VAN DER HASSELT / AFP)
The "Black Sheep Jumper" designed by Sally Muir and Joanna Osborne and worn on several occasions by Britain's late Princess Diana, at Sotheby's auction house in London, Britain on July 17, 2023.

site_title: Bank of Singapore trust business sees significant post-Covid lift
summary: Bank of Singapore's wealth and trust planning business has seen a significant post-Covid lift, with the number of ultra-high net worth (UHNW) clients setting up trusts expected to more than double this year. The establishment of trusts has also led to a substantial increase in assets under management, with the value of assets in trusts set up in the last three years accounting for almost 20% of the bank's entire trust portfolio. The surge is attributed to clients seeking to address estate and succession issues, as well as risk management, particularly among young entrepreneurs.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua
A deep conversation with your financial adviser is a must before you decide on a trust for legacy planniing.

site_title: OCBC to enable QR payments in China via Ant Group partnership
summary: OCBC Bank has partnered with Ant Group to enable QR payments in China via its OCBC Digital app, starting from September 22. The feature, already available in Malaysia and South Korea, allows customers to make payments directly from their Singapore bank accounts to China merchants part of the Alipay+ ecosystem. This move aims to address the issue of unfavourable foreign exchange rates and mark-up fees faced by tourists in China, with competitive exchange rates to be offered. The partnership is expected to boost China travel to Singapore, particularly ahead of the Asian Games in Hangzhou.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai

The central banks have been progressively working on connecting their cross-border payment systems via options such as QR (quick response)-codes and fast-payment, allowing their residents to make payments in each other’s countries using local currencies with ease.

site_title: China's ex-Foreign Minister Qin Gang was ousted after alleged affair, WSJ reports
summary: China's former Foreign Minister Qin Gang was ousted after an internal Communist Party investigation found he engaged in an extramarital affair throughout his tenure as China's ambassador to the US. The affair allegedly resulted in the birth of a child in the US. Qin was replaced by diplomat Wang Yi in July after a mysterious one-month absence from duties. The investigation is now focusing on whether the affair compromised China's national security.

site_title: Singapore to ‘fine-tune’ carbon emission management for F1, Mice events
summary: Singapore aims to halve its carbon emissions from Formula 1 and Mice events by 2028 through sustainability audits and measures such as reducing energy consumption and increasing renewable energy use. A similar audit will be conducted for this year's Singapore Grand Prix, which will focus on reducing energy consumption, increasing renewable energy use, and powering on-site generators with alternative fuels. The Mice industry will also begin tracking its waste and carbon emissions from this year.

images.alt_text: Goh Ruoxue
Singapore's 2022 Formula 1 Grand Prix is estimated to have produced 2,372 tCO2e.

Minister of State Alvin Tan for the Ministry of Trade and Industry & Ministry of Culture, Community and Youth, giving an opening address without a blazer at a launch event of the MICE Sustainability Roadmap at Sands Expo & Convention Centre.

site_title: Lendlease launches new protocol for Scope 3 emissions
summary: Lendlease has launched a new protocol for Scope 3 emissions, accounting for 90% of its global carbon footprint. The protocol, launched during Climate Week NYC, outlines the group's reporting boundaries and categories for upstream and downstream emissions. Lendlease is pushing for industry-wide data-sharing and verification of Scope 3 emissions data, aiming to address emissions from value chains. The company aims to achieve "Absolute Zero" by 2040, excluding carbon offsets, and net-zero emissions by 2025 for Scope 1 and 2.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Land isn’t the only factor when it comes to green cost premiums; what kind of project gets built on the land matters, too.
Lendlease's statutory loss after tax for the year came in at A$232 million, compared to A$99 million reported a year ago, the company said.
Lendlease Reit's acquisition of Jem in Jurong East has led to a rise in property operating expenses and finance costs.
Besides tried-and-tested renewable energy options such as solar and wind, the transition focus could lead to greater acceptability around liquefied natural gas as a transition fuel.

Even if companies have to take on higher costs now, it would still pale in comparison with projections of up to US$23 trillion in annual losses by 2100, if the world fails to correct its path in bringing down global emissions, notes Charlie Knaggs from ERM.
Pollution, Smoke, Environment, Credit: Pixabay
S-Reits now recognise the importance of addressing environment and sustainability matters to ensure the delivery of steady distributions in the long term.

site_title: China’s Huawei set to re-enter mid-range 5G phone market
summary: Huawei is reportedly set to launch a 5G version of its mid-range Nova phone in October or November, according to the IT Times. This move would mark the technology giant's return to the mid-range 5G market, which it had been restricted from entering since 2019 due to US sanctions. The company has been using stockpiled chips to launch limited batches of 5G models. The new phone's launch would be another sign of Huawei's ability to overcome US sanctions and expand its product offerings.

site_title: Bank of Japan’s policy aimed at ‘buying time’ will eventually end: industry minister
summary: Japanese industry minister Yasutoshi Nishimura stated that the Bank of Japan's ultra-loose monetary policy, aimed at "buying time" to push through structural reforms, will eventually end as inflation accelerates globally. The policy, which has been in place since the Covid-19 pandemic and Russia's invasion of Ukraine, will normalize as inflation continues to rise.

site_title: The importance of investment moats
summary: A well-established company with a "wide moat" can consistently generate high returns on equity and pay dividends, increasing its value over time. This is crucial for investors to understand, as dividends are not just a trinket, but a vital component of total shareholder return, which combines stock-price appreciation and reinvestment of dividends. Businesses with moats, such as those with strong brand recognition, patents, or intangible assets, can maintain their market position and pay rising dividends, even during economic downturns. Investing in such companies and reinvesting dividends can lead to long-term growth and wealth creation.

images.alt_text: Swiss food giant Nestle was the world’s biggest dividend payer, followed by British bank HSBC and German automaker Mercedes-Benz.

site_title: Asean kicks off its first-ever joint military drills in Indonesia
summary: Asean launched its first-ever joint military drills in Indonesia's South Natuna Sea, focusing on maritime security and disaster relief. The 5-day non-combat operation involves all 10 Asean member countries, including East Timor, amid rising tensions in the South China Sea. The exercise aims to develop military skills, humanitarian assistance, and disaster relief capabilities. The drills are part of efforts to strengthen regional security and cooperation.

site_title: Asia: Markets drop ahead of Federal Reserve decision, oil prices push on
summary: Asian stocks dropped on Tuesday, with Tokyo leading losses, ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy decision and upcoming meetings of the Bank of England and Bank of Japan. Despite Wall Street's flat performance, investors are cautious, with some expecting the Fed to hold interest rates steady but others anticipating further hikes to combat inflation. Oil prices, driven by production cuts by Saudi Arabia and Russia, are also a concern, with Brent closing in on $100 a barrel.

site_title: MOF to consider having solely age-based components in Majulah Package
summary: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) is considering making parts of the Majulah Package available solely based on age, without considering income or other factors. The $7 billion package, announced in this year's National Day Rally, provides Central Provident Fund (CPF) bonuses to 1.4 million Singaporeans aged 50 and above with lower incomes and less wealth. Senior Minister of State for Finance Chee Hong Tat said the package was designed to support those with lower incomes and less wealth, and MOF will consider suggestions from MPs to finalize the package, which includes three components: Earn and Save bonus, retirement savings top-up, and Medisave top-up.

site_title: EU says lack of clarity in China’s data laws is concerning

The EU's Vera Jourova expressed concerns about the impact on businesses, citing the expansion of China's counter-espionage law and the lack of definitions for important data. Jourova proposed creating an information link to help EU businesses understand the law and avoid compliance issues. The EU and China will continue to maintain open communication channels despite disagreements, with the EU seeking to create a fair and transparent business environment.

site_title: Bond mountaineers easily scale the maturity wall

Worries about the "Great Maturity Wall" have been overdone, as companies have quietly extended their debt calendars, whittling down the number of maturing bonds by 38% since 2023. The market's macroeconomic outlook has improved, and the economy remains resilient, with fewer economists projecting a recession in the next two quarters.

site_title: Chinese police detain staff of Evergrande wealth unit
summary: Chinese authorities have detained staff members of Evergrande Financial Wealth Management, a unit of the debt-laden developer at the center of China's property crisis. The detentions come amid a broader crackdown on alleged corruption in the finance industry and a campaign to protect consumers. Evergrande shares plummeted 25% after the detentions, with the stock extending this year's decline to 63%. The company confirmed the detentions but said operations would not be affected. The move is seen as a new phase in the saga surrounding Evergrande, which has been struggling with debt and missed payments.

Temasek is also collaborating with universities to invest in commercializing deep-tech ventures, part of its strategy to build a "future-ready" portfolio.

summary: Singapore's updated Comirnaty Covid-19 vaccine targeting the current XBB 1.5 variant may arrive by end-October, according to Senior Minister of State for Health Janil Puthucheary. The monovalent vaccine has been approved for those six months and above. Vaccines remain key in keeping Covid-19 at bay, with the MOH continuing to recommend a booster dose for the medically vulnerable and healthy persons aged 12-59. site_title: En bloc hopes revive amid a risk-averse market
summary: Developers have taken a risk-averse stance in recent state land sales, with two large plots up for offer. Pine Grove's 890,000 sq ft plot is now priced at S$1.95 billion, while Island View's 72-unit condo is offered at a reserve price of S$575 million. These deals come after months of no collective sales, with land betterment charges weighing heavily on effective acquisition costs. The risk-averse approach suggests a cautious market, but the recent surge in condo launches may indicate a potential shift in sentiment.

site_title: Sunac, Country Garden debt deals bring respite for China's property sector
summary: China's property sector has received some relief with debt deals from Sunac and Country Garden, two major developers. Sunac won approval from creditors to extend its US$9 billion offshore debt restructuring plan, while Country Garden secured an extension on a onshore bond. The deals bring some breathing room for Chinese developers, but the outlook remains uncertain due to a decline in home sales and house prices. Beijing's efforts to revive the sector, including support measures, may help stimulate demand, but a sustainable rebound is questioned due to uncertain job outlook and increased housing supply.

site_title: Strong earnings and attractive yields weigh in favour of bank bonds
summary: Singapore bank bonds remain popular due to strong earnings and attractive yields, despite being the most controversial at the beginning of the year. The financial sector accounts for 74.4% of SGD issuances, with HSBC issuing the most SGD corporate bonds in 2023. Senior and Tier-2 subordinated bonds offer lower risk and attractive yields, while AT1 perpetual bonds pose a risk of loss absorption and non-call. Investors should remain cautious of AT1 bonds and consider the possibility of non-calls, especially in an elevated interest-rate environment.
