site_title: Odds of moderate US recession are higher than what markets are pricing in: Pimco
summary: Pimco's former vice-chair of the US Federal Reserve, Richard Clarida, says the odds of a moderate US recession are higher than what the markets are pricing in. A government shutdown and fiscal dysfunction in Washington could lead to a recession, with fiscal policy playing a significant role in interest rates. Pimco is increasing its interest rate exposure and adding to its position in inflation-linked bonds. An unexpected surge in company defaults, particularly among small and medium-sized enterprises, is a "black swan" risk for global financial markets, according to Pimco's chief investment officer for fixed global income.

images.alt_text: Dan Ivascyn, group chief investment officer, Pimco.
Pimco global economic adviser Richard Clarida says the US Federal Reserve is likely to hike rates two more times this year.
The probability is low for a meaningful rebound in China property bonds.
Pimco CIO Daniel Ivascyn notes that when rates have risen in the past, a lag of five or six quarters for the impact to be felt has been the norm.

site_title: Gold prices edge up ahead of likely Federal Reserve rate pause
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,928.19 per ounce, driven by investors anticipating a pause in interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. Asian shares fell, making gold more attractive ahead of policy decisions. The expected economic calendar, including Fed forecasts, may reflect growing faith in an economic soft landing, but a likely one more rate hike. Gold prices have been boosted by Chinese gold prices hitting record highs and physical gold premiums soaring to new highs.

images.alt_text: Bullion on the Shanghai Gold Exchange traded at a premium of more than US$120 an ounce on Thursday (Sep 14).

site_title: Smaller contractors may be hit harder by new requirement for suitable accommodation
summary: Singapore's new rule requiring employers to provide proof of acceptable accommodation for non-Malaysian work permit holders may disproportionately affect smaller contractors, who rely on the available market for accommodation. With dormitories fully occupied, smaller contractors may resort to budget hotels and hostels, costing around S$80 to S$100 per day. Larger industry players can opt for housing migrant workers within their own construction temporary quarters. The requirement aims to mitigate the supply shortage demand and support subcontractors, but companies must plan ahead to secure beds for workers.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
The additional requirement comes as work permit holders in these sectors surpass pre-Covid-19 levels by 19 per cent, MOM says.

site_title: Australia swelters in spring heat wave, temperatures set to break records
summary: A severe heat wave is affecting large parts of Australia's southeast, including Sydney, with temperatures expected to peak 16°C above the September average. Several early spring records are likely to be broken, and a stronger cold front is expected to bring relief on Wednesday. The heat wave has already taken its toll, with 26 people hospitalized and 40 treated for heat exhaustion during the Sydney marathon on Sunday. Authorities have warned of heightened bushfire risks, with about 50 grass or bushfires burning across New South Wales.

images.alt_text: The Sydney Harbour Bridge is seen shrouded by smoke in Sydney on September 13, 2023, as a smoky haze blankets Australia's scenic Sydney Harbour, after a ring of controlled blazes burned on the city's fringes in preparation for the looming bushfire season. (Photo by Steve CHRISTO / AFP)

The Sydney Harbour Bridge is seen shrouded by smoke in Sydney, Australia on Sept 13, 2023 after a ring of controlled blazes burned on the city's fringes in preparation for the looming bushfire season.

site_title: Clan associations push back over negative epithets from money-laundering blitz
summary: Singaporean clan associations are pushing back against negative epithets following a recent money laundering blitz, which targeted individuals from Anxi county, a region in southern Fujian province known for its historical ties to crime. The police arrested 10 foreigners, mostly from Anxi, and seized over S$1.8 billion in assets, fueling reports describing Anxi as a "fraudsters' hometown." Clan association leaders and members of the Hokkien community are defending their heritage, pointing out that many have contributed to Singapore's development and are not representative of the entire region.

images.alt_text: Some of the S$1.8 billion of assets seized by the police.
The 10 accused in the case.
DBS Group CEO Piyush Gupta said banks had already been more cautious over the last 15 years since the global financial crisis.

site_title: Over 3,500 new private homes set to be launched in Q4
summary: Over 3,500 new private homes are set to be launched in Singapore's fourth quarter, with prices expected to hold at current levels despite slowing sales. Analysts predict median prices of S$2,074 to S$2,903 per square foot in different regions. Developers are likely to keep prices high due to high financing and construction costs. Despite easing construction costs, rising interest rates and geopolitical uncertainties may deter developers from lowering prices, leading to a more stable pricing landscape in the near future.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
Developers sold just 394 units in August, 72.1 per cent lower than July's sales figures.
The new HDB framework that emphasises homes are for living may greatly benefit today's young seniors.
Data from the Singapore Courts shows the number of mortgage actions filed in court has more than halved in the past five years.

site_title: US auto union chief warns ready to ‘amp up’ strike if no deal
summary: US auto union chief Shawn Fain warned that a historic strike at top three car manufacturers will expand if wage offers aren't improved. The UAW is demanding a 40% pay raise over four years, while companies have offered around 20%. Fain stated that companies have "no excuse" for not resolving salary disputes given their massive profits. The standoff has fed debate in Washington over President Biden's economic policies ahead of the 2024 election.

images.alt_text: With workers at all of the Big Three coordinating strike action for the first time – including a demand for pay increases of 40 per cent over a four-year contract – the automakers could face a far more disruptive stoppage.

site_title: Foxconn aims to double jobs, investment in India over next 12 months
summary: Foxconn, the world's largest contract electronics manufacturer, aims to double its workforce and investment in India by next year, according to V Lee, the company's representative in India. The company has already invested $600 million in two projects in Karnataka, employing 40,000 people in its existing iPhone factory in Tamil Nadu. Foxconn chairman Young Liu sees significant potential in India, with plans for "several billion dollars in investment" beyond the initial $600 million. This move comes as Foxconn seeks to diversify away from China.

images.alt_text: Xiaomi was once an unrivalled leader in India’s smartphone market but lost steam after facing heightened regulatory scrutiny and overexpanding its product portfolio.
While the vast majority of iPhone 15s will come from China, that would be the first time a latest generation, India-assembled device is available on the first day of sale.
China has in recent years grown more concerned over data security and has rolled out new laws and compliance requirements for companies.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, CapitaLand Investment, SIA, First Sponsor
summary: Global investment firm KKR is committing up to S$1.1 billion for a 20% stake in Singtel's regional data centre business, valuing the business at S$5.5 billion. This deal puts KKR in line for a 25% stake by 2027. Meanwhile, CapitaLand Investment acquired a logistics property in South Korea for S$112 million, and Singapore Airlines reported 34,900 fewer passengers in August compared to July. First Sponsor Group acquired an office building in Rotterdam for S$90.6 million.

site_title: Strong upward momentum for oil seen amid volatile market
summary: Brent crude oil prices are expected to average $93 per barrel in 4Q 2023, up from $86 in August, driven by tight supplies and rising demand despite a volatile macroeconomic backdrop. The US Energy Information Administration attributes the price increase to deficiencies in global oil inventories. However, the market remains cautious, with risks including inflationary pressure and a potential economic slowdown, which could impact global demand.

images.alt_text: International benchmark Brent futures dipped 18 cents to settle at US$91.88 a barrel on Wednesday.
Oil prices are on track for their biggest quarterly increase since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine in the first quarter of 2022.

site_title: Trump says he hopes Meadows will remain ‘loyal’ to him in election case
summary: Former US President Donald Trump expressed hope that his former White House chief of staff Mark Meadows, a co-defendant in a racketeering indictment in Georgia, remains "loyal" to him. Meadows pleaded not guilty in the case, which accuses those charged of a criminal conspiracy to overturn Trump's 2020 election loss. Trump's comment may attract new interest, as prosecutors could push to have some defendants plead guilty and become witnesses against others involved.

site_title: Lens on Singapore: Confronting challenges with K Shanmugam (Ep 3)
summary: Minister K Shanmugam discusses Singapore's challenges, including complacency and economic difficulties, in a podcast conversation. He expresses concerns over the country's reliance on its past success and the need for new policies to drive future growth. Shanmugam also touches on the impact of rising religiosity and the role of national media in shaping public opinion, highlighting the need for a balance between policy and public sentiment.

site_title: First Sponsor units acquire Rotterdam property for 62 million euros
summary: First Sponsor Group and its units acquired an office building in Rotterdam, Netherlands, Allianz Tower, for 62 million euros. The property is fully leased to insurance agency Allianz Nederland Groep until 2035. First Sponsor paid a preliminary share purchase price of 15.6 million euros for Rotali BV, which holds the title to the property, and its portion of the deal translates to a 33% stake in the company. The acquisition is expected to expand the company's recurrent income base without material impact on earnings per share.

images.alt_text: Skyline in Rotterdam, Netherlands.

site_title: Regulators are trying to stop greenwashing before it gets worse
summary: Regulators worldwide are cracking down on greenwashing, a practice of misleading consumers on sustainability. Since 2021, the Advertising Standards Authority (ASA) in the UK has banned three fossil fuel advertising campaigns and ads from companies like Oatly and Unilever. Globally, regulators are taking action, with the US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) updating its guidelines on sustainable claims and the Australian Competition & Consumer Commission (ACCC) prioritizing sustainability communication. Despite efforts, greenwashing remains a challenge, with many claims lacking verification or detail. Regulators are pushing back, with some calling for a more holistic approach, like the tobacco control treaty, to prohibit all fossil fuel advertising.

images.alt_text: Besides tried-and-tested renewable energy options such as solar and wind, the transition focus could lead to greater acceptability around liquefied natural gas as a transition fuel.

People rally to end fossil fuels ahead of the 78th United Nations General Assembly and Climate Ambition Summit in New York on Sept 17, 2023.

site_title: ‘Nun II’ narrowly outscares ‘Haunting in Venice’ in North American theatres
summary: "The Nun II" narrowly outscores "A Haunting in Venice" in North American theatres with an estimated US$14.7 million, a US$200,000 lead over the latter. The ninth chapter in the "Conjuring" series, starring Taissa Farmiga and Jonas Bloquet, has a lukewarm domestic opening, according to analyst David A Gross, who notes that the movie won't lose money after playing in foreign markets due to its US$60 million budget.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: The not so bumpy path to financial freedom (Ep 151)
summary: Financial experts Stephanie Chiaw and Adriana Chia discuss the concept of financial freedom and abundance, highlighting differences and similarities between the two. They also address concerns from the Financial Freedom index and opportunities during market volatility. The conversation emphasizes the importance of protecting one's wealth and provides general financial tips. The experts conclude that despite market volatility, achieving financial freedom and abundance is possible with the right strategies and mindset.

site_title: Can old dogs learn new tricks? A look at BT’s journey to attract Gen Zs
summary: The Business Times' Thrive initiative, launched to cater to young adults, has faced challenges in establishing its brand identity and understanding its audience. After eight months, the team has made progress in creating a distinct identity, toning down memes, and incorporating explainers and comic strips into their content. A survey and focus group discussions revealed that the target audience is predominantly young adults, with 75% aged 35 and below. The team now focuses on expanding its capacity, particularly in event outreach and video content, to build a larger and more engaged community.

site_title: Ex-prime minister Truss blames UK stagnation on groupthink
summary: Former UK Prime Minister Liz Truss is set to blame the country's stagnant economy on "economic consensus" and claim she would have spent £35.5 billion less during her term than her successor Rishi Sunak. Truss will also criticize Sunak's spending, saying her own plans would have saved £35.5 billion over two years. The comments echo concerns within the Tory party and come as Sunak faces criticism from both right and left, with Labour looking to capitalize on the divisions.

summary: The Business Times' podcast "Editors Talk" features a conversation between Claressa Monteiro and Vivien Shiao, young audience editor, about reaching young audiences and future-proofing the media. The duo discusses the challenges of curating content for this demographic, building loyalty, and utilizing data analytics. They also look ahead to next year's initiatives to engage young audiences. The conversation highlights the importance of adapting to the changing media landscape and evolving to meet the needs of younger consumers.

site_title: Changi clocks over half a million passenger movements between Singapore and China in August
summary: Changi Airport in Singapore recorded 510,000 passenger movements between Singapore and China in August, a 72% recovery of pre-pandemic levels. This marked the first time passenger movements to and from China crossed the half-million mark since the pandemic. Improved travel restrictions in China contributed to the growth, making China the third-largest market for Changi Airport, accounting for 10% of total passenger traffic. Scheduled flights between Singapore and China have recovered to 76% of pre-pandemic levels.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
China regained its spot as the top source of visitors to Singapore in July, with 231,326 tourists visiting from the country.

site_title: Singtel sees S$1.1 billion KKR deal bringing new customers, technologies to the table
summary: Singtel has agreed to a S$1.1 billion investment deal with KKR, valuing its regional data centre business at S$5.5 billion. The deal will give Singtel access to KKR's global customers and data centre cooling technologies. Singtel's CEO Bill Chang said the investment will enable the company to serve global clients and tap into KKR's stable of data centre cooling solutions providers. The investment puts the enterprise value of Singtel's RDC business at S$5.5 billion, and KKR has the option to increase its stake to 25% by 2027.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
Mia Pei

site_title:
US dollar down after data but set 
for ninth straight weekly climb
summary: The US dollar declined 0.08% to 105.32 against the US dollar index, but remained poised for a ninth consecutive weekly gain. Consumer sentiment in the US dropped to 67.7 in September, but inflation expectations were seen as lower. The yen weakened to a 10-month low, while the euro rose 0.2% to $1.0666. The Federal Reserve is expected to keep interest rates unchanged, with a 97% expectation of no action, and the dollar is expected to continue its upward trend against the yen.

images.alt_text: The US dollar slips around 0.1 per cent against the offshore yuan, with the pair at 7.2801.

site_title: Lessons from the late Elizabeth Sam and Gloria Lee
summary: Two pioneering women in the banking and finance industry, Gloria Lee and Elizabeth Sam, have left a lasting legacy. Lee, founder of Kim Eng Securities, proved that being underestimated can be a strength, using her humility and self-deprecation to gain the respect of her peers. Sam, a pioneer leader at Singapore's central bank, emphasized the importance of being professional, focusing on being spectacular at the job, and putting aside doubts about being a woman in a male-dominated field. Both women also highlighted the importance of self-awareness, being aware of one's weaknesses, and not letting physical attributes hold you back.

images.alt_text: Jeanette Tan
Elizabeth Sam had over four decades of experience in the financial sector.
Gloria Lee founded stock brokerage Kim Eng Holdings, which was sold to Malaysia’s Maybank in 2011.

site_title: BT Future of Finance: How tech will change the future of financial services (Ep 1)
summary: UOB's head of group personal finances, Jacquelyn Tan, discusses how the bank is using technology to support consumer aspirations during volatile financial times. The bank is digitizing and deploying AI in targeted ways, providing assistance to Singaporeans. Tan aims to empower consumers to make informed financial decisions, ultimately supporting their aspirations. This approach is part of UOB's efforts to innovate in the financial services industry.

images.alt_text: Heng Koon How from UOB discusses blockchain shock waves.

site_title: China police detain some Evergrande wealth management staff
summary: China police have detained some staff at Evergrande Financial Wealth Management Co, a unit of the world's most indebted property developer China Evergrande Group. The detention is part of an ongoing investigation into financial crimes. General manager and legal representative Du Liang was identified as one of the suspected criminals during 2021 protests. Evergrande is facing a crisis in China's property sector, with a string of debt defaults since late 2021, and has delayed making a decision on offshore debt restructuring. The police urged investors to report any further financial crimes.

site_title: Order book shows methanol’s sure rise as a marine fuel
summary: Singapore's first ship-to-ship methanol bunkering operation was completed in July, with the fuel offering a 95% reduction in carbon dioxide emissions when produced from renewable electricity. A new report by Norwegian ship certifier DNV predicts methanol could become the world's third-most used marine fuel within months, with an order book 20 times larger than existing methanol-fuelled ships. This would push the uptake of methanol to 8% of the global fleet, up from 0.05%.

The maritime sector's power requirements are enough to stretch the capacity of other green sources.

Singapore has been at the forefront of bunker licensing and adopting mandatory mass flow meters, but not everywhere has been receptive to this approach.
Shipping transports around 90 per cent of world trade and accounts for nearly 3 per cent of the world’s carbon dioxide emissions.

site_title: Ferrari’s Carlos Sainz wins 2023 Singapore Grand Prix
summary: Carlos Sainz Jr. of Ferrari won the 2023 Singapore Grand Prix, ending Formula One leader Max Verstappen's record run of 10 consecutive wins. Sainz, who started on pole position, held off McLaren's Lando Norris and Mercedes' Lewis Hamilton to secure his first victory of the season. The win shattered Red Bull's dream of going unbeaten and marked a significant upset in the championship. The event attracted a record 264,108 spectators, despite lower-than-expected turnout.

site_title: Climate protesters in New York and across the globe send message to United Nations
summary: Thousands of climate protesters gathered in New York's Midtown, Manhattan, on September 17, 2023, ahead of the UN General Assembly, calling for an end to fossil fuel use and a declaration of a climate emergency. With signs reading "End Fossil Fuel Use" and "Fossil Fuels Kill," protesters waved drums and banners to convey their message to world leaders, including President Joe Biden. The event marked the beginning of "Climate Week," with the aim of raising awareness about the urgent need to transition away from fossil fuels and mitigate the effects of climate change.

site_title: S-E Asia climate investment opportunities still sound, but speed bumps abound
summary: S-E Asia climate investment opportunities remain uncertain due to legacy issues, bureaucratic red tape, and poor access to climate financing. Analysts warn that if the world fails to correct its path in bringing down global emissions, companies could face up to $23 trillion in annual losses by 2100. The outlook for energy transition companies depends on the maturity of their technology, with renewable energy solutions like wind and solar being more confident than hydrogen.

Besides tried-and-tested renewable energy options such as solar and wind, the transition focus could lead to greater acceptability around liquefied natural gas as a transition fuel.

In the Asia-Pacific, financing the managed phase-out of coal-fired power plants is one of the most pressing issues within the global energy transition, says Fang Eu-Lin, PwC Singapore’s sustainability and climate change leader.

site_title: How to be a good leader? Be a good human, says LinkedIn’s Dan Shapero
summary: LinkedIn COO Daniel Shapero shares his career lessons, which include being a good human, learning from others, and taking calculated risks. He recounts his early days in startups, where he faced a rocky start but learned valuable lessons from people he worked with. Shapero emphasizes the importance of following people you think you can learn from and being willing to take a big step to learn something important, such as stepping down from a VP role to learn product knowledge. He also stresses the value of celebrating and rewarding people who embody the company's values and promotes a culture of inclusivity, as seen in LinkedIn's 50/50 gender distribution.

images.alt_text: Jeanette Tan
A video thumbnail from Feon Ang's new video series called "At The Table", with its first episode featuring Georgette Tan, Roshni Cheung, and Minister for Communications and Information Josephine Teo.
Job seekers need to go beyond a good CV to land opportunities.
A LinkedIn office in San Francisco, California, US, on Wednesday, May 3, 2023.

Reid Hoffman, a venture capitalist, at the Greylock Offices in San Francisco, Calif. on May 10, 2023. Few are as involved in so many different artificial intelligence efforts as Hoffman, a Silicon Valley investor who co-founded LinkedIn.

Last year, more than 161,000 people were laid off from technology companies and startups, according to Layoffs.fyi, a site that tracks job cuts. So far this year, more than 148,000 people have been laid off.

Tech bosses like Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff like to refer to the company and staff as family, but trying to sell themselves as a family requires a suspension of disbelief that’s insulting to the talent they are trying to attract.

Hung Truong, who remembers feeling relieved after sharing online about his layoff from Lyft at the start of the pandemic, at his home in Seattle on Nov 8, 2022. As Twitter, Meta and other companies that helped create a culture of more workplace transparency slash their work forces, some laid off employees are very publicly using those social media platforms to critique their former employers.
In experiments conducted around the world from 2015 to 2019, LinkedIn randomly varied the proportion of weak and strong contacts suggested by its “People You May Know” algorithm

CEOs have long studied how to deliver good news and bad news. They’ve trained themselves to pitch big ideas and shoot down middling ones. Now they have a new skill to learn: the art of being vulnerable.
Retaining talent in the newsroom goes beyond attractive pay and hours, to creating an environment that nurtures passion for journalism.

site_title: Stroll out of Singapore GP following horror qualifying crash
summary: Lance Stroll pulled out of the Singapore Grand Prix due to a crash in qualifying, where he lost control after running over kerbs and crashed into barriers. The remains of his car bounced back onto the track, but he escaped injury. Stroll was cleared by the medical team but the Aston Martin team decided he wouldn't participate in the Singapore Grand Prix to recover fully ahead of the Japanese Grand Prix. The team faces a significant repair job on the car and Stroll will focus on recovery for next weekend's event.

images.alt_text: Hotels near the downtown race circuit generally expect their F1 takings to exceed pre-Covid levels, and possibly those of 2022.

site_title: Climate urgency will push South-east Asia to confront fuel subsidies, LNG, offsets
summary: South-east Asia will likely confront fuel subsidies, liquefied natural gas (LNG) as a transition fuel, and carbon offsets due to growing climate urgency, according to a recent Paris Agreement's first global stocktake report. The report found global greenhouse-gas emission curbs are far short of mitigation pathways to avoid catastrophic temperatures. The upcoming COP28 conference in Dubai may lead to policy changes, including increased focus on renewable energy and LNG as a transition fuel, potentially increasing acceptability in coal-dependent South-east Asian countries.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
Janice Lim

Even if companies have to take on higher costs now, it would still pale in comparison with projections of up to US$23 trillion in annual losses by 2100, if the world fails to correct its path in bringing down global emissions, notes Charlie Knaggs from ERM.
An aerial view shows a vehicle driving along a flooded street in New Port Richey, Florida, on August 30, 2023, after Hurricane Idalia made landfall.
The amount of greenhouse gas emissions mitigated by current policies fall far short of what is required to avoid crossing critical global warming temperature thresholds.
The first comprehensive progress review of the 2015 Paris Agreement has found that the world is not on target to curb global warming.
PM Lee notes that more private funds are needed to combat the “existential” threat of climate change.

In the Asia-Pacific, financing the managed phase-out of coal-fired power plants is one of the most pressing issues within the global energy transition, says Fang Eu-Lin, PwC Singapore’s sustainability and climate change leader.
The Investor Agenda says governments continue to see climate change as separate to, and less important than, other aspects of economic and fiscal policy.

site_title: Bank of England readies what may be its final rate hike
summary: The Bank of England is set to raise interest rates to 5.5% on September 21, its highest level since 2007, as a cooling economy and inflation concerns prompt policymakers to tighten monetary policy. All but one economist polled by Reuters predict the move, which would rank fourth in Britain's biggest tightening cycles of the last century. The decision comes as the economy shows signs of weakening, with data showing a steeper-than-expected drop in economic output in July.

images.alt_text: Britain's economy grew 0.2 per cent in the second quarter, helped by monthly growth of 0.5 per cent in June.

site_title: WHO chief pushes China for ‘full access’ to determine Covid’s origins: FT
summary: WHO chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus urged China to provide full access to information on the origins of Covid-19, stating that all hypotheses remain on the table until China cooperates. Ghebreyesus has been pressing China since the pandemic began, and a second WHO team is ready to investigate. The origins of the virus, first identified in Wuhan, China in December 2019, remain a mystery, with many suspecting it spread from a live animal market. Ghebreyesus's comments come as the world updates vaccines to combat emerging variants.

site_title: Vietnam stock market expected to lead Asean performance
summary: Vietnam's stock market is expected to outperform its Asean peers, with a gain of 18% in the year to date. This can be attributed to rising liquidity, improving valuations, and the government's efforts to improve governance and macroeconomic fronts. Market watcher Quan Trong Thanh, head of research at Maybank Investment Bank Vietnam, notes that the country's stock market has already outperformed regional markets. The outperformance is also linked to a spell of overselling in the fourth quarter of last year amid policy tightening and panic over the country's property and bond markets.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Vietnam's trade-reliant economy is vulnerable to continued soft growth in key trading partners, which are suffering from the prolonged high-interest rate environment, analysts said.
Vietnam's VinFast is the first in South-east Asia to sell its car brand in the US.
Singapore and Vietnam have made progress in existing partnerships, as well as agreed to explore new areas of cooperation, said Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong.

site_title: Raffles Medical eyes China healthcare growth but stays prudent on expansions
summary: Raffles Medical Group is focusing on steady growth despite a slowdown in medical tourism due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The company has seen a 70% recovery in medical tourism to pre-pandemic levels, with 25% of patients coming from about 120 countries. Raffles Medical is expanding into China, with seven hospitals and clinics, and is not in a race to grow, preferring to diversify. The company's executive chairman, Dr. Loo Choon Yong, believes that quality healthcare, particularly for serious illnesses, is key to attracting patients. Raffles Medical has a strong balance sheet and increasing management and clinical strengths, allowing it to grow or acquire opportunities as needed.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah
An analyst noted that Malaysia’s healthcare infrastructure has “started to narrow against Singapore”, which has long been the preferred medical destination in the region.
A screen of profitable companies with growing earnings and gearing levels under 50 per cent reveals that only 32 companies listed on the SGX managed to grow their dividends over the past five years.
Thomson Medical Group plans to raise public float to 10 per cent.

site_title: Fed will leave rates alone, but changes in Powell’s statement could be just as scary
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to leave interest rates unchanged at a 22-year high of 5.25-5.5% during its next meeting on September 20. Despite this, Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's post-meeting statement could still cause a surprise, as investors had anticipated an end to rate hikes. Consumer inflation accelerated in August, with energy prices rising due to the ongoing Ukraine war and global supply chain disruptions. Economists warn that inflation may not be going away, and Powell's statement could potentially dampen the stock market rally if it hints at further rate hikes.

images.alt_text: Which sectors benefited from an upbeat market this week?
US public discourse focuses heavily on the Fed and creates an exaggerated sense of what monetary policy alone can deliver.

With inflation still above its 2 per cent target and economic growth solid, US central bankers probably will retain a bias towards tighter policy at their Sep 19-20 meeting even as they hold rates steady.
Mortgage costs have climbed over the past year as the Federal Reserve sought to tame inflation by raising its benchmark rate.

site_title: Race Against Cancer exceeds S$1.25 million donation target, raises goal to record high
summary: The 15th edition of the Singtel-Singapore Cancer Society (SCS) Race Against Cancer exceeded its initial donation target of S$1.25 million, raising over S$1.5 million. The event drew over 5,000 participants and featured a 5km "fun run", 10km, and 15km competitive categories, as well as a virtual run. Funds raised will support cancer treatment subsidies, welfare assistance, and research. Singtel donated S$250,000 to SCS' Help the Children and Youth programme. The event aims to rally the community to support the cancer community and raise awareness for cancer.

images.alt_text: The event concluded five getai edutainment roadshows to promote digital literacy.

Temasek Trust's Desmond Kuek says PAA "will harness the strengths, ideas and best practices of members and partners to jointly pioneer philanthropic innovations, to realise our bold ambitions as an alliance to prime Asia as a force for good".

site_title: China’s Zhongrong exposed to struggling property developers: FT
summary: Zhongrong International Trust Co, a giant of China's $3 trillion shadow finance industry, has lent money to struggling property developers, fueling fears of spillover effects. The company has missed payments on some trust products, including $1.6 billion in claims against Sunac, a property developer that defaulted in 2022. Zhongrong's real estate investment exposure accounts for 10.7% of its assets under management. The company's delays in payments have raised concerns about the stability of the financial system and potential risks to the real estate sector.

images.alt_text: Industrial output rises 4.5 per cent in August from a year earlier, according to data released by the National Bureau of Statistics (NBS).

site_title: Swiss vote on plan to nationalise UBS proposed
summary: Switzerland is set to hold a vote on a proposal to partially nationalize UBS Group, with a proposed constitutional amendment giving the federal government majority control over large banks deemed "systemic importance." The move comes as UBS' assets are now twice the size of the Swiss economy, raising concerns about the bank's size and potential impact on the country's economy. The initiative, led by a school headmaster, aims to address concerns about the bank's potential failure in a crisis, with supporters hoping to collect 100,000 signatures within 18 months.

images.alt_text: UBS targets the integration to be finished by the end of 2025.

site_title: Apple’s sustainability show cannot hide that bottom line is at the heart of its initiatives
summary: Apple's sustainability initiatives, showcased at its recent Wonderlust event, may not drive its stock price as significantly as sales of its newly launched iPhone 15. The company aims to reduce its carbon footprint to zero by 2030, but investors are likely to focus on sales and product performance. Apple's efforts, while admirable, are seen as a means to gain a competitive advantage in tapping capital, rather than a primary driver of its stock price. The company's sales of the iPhone 15 are expected to be a major factor in its short-term stock performance.

images.alt_text: Ben Paul
The iPhone 15 Pro is presented during the 'Wonderlust' event at the company's headquarters in Cupertino, California, U.S. September 12, 2023. REUTERS/Loren Elliott
“China has not issued laws, regulations or policy documents that prohibit the purchase and use of foreign brand phones such as Apple’s,” says foreign ministry spokesperson Mao Ning.
The new iPhone 15 goes on sale online in China on Alibaba’s Tmall marketplace on Sep 15, and in-stores on Sep 22.
Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company's (TSMC) logo is seen while people attend the opening of the TSMC global R&D center in Hsinchu, Taiwan July 28, 2023. REUTERS/Ann Wang
The fund — which was a collaboration between BlackRock, SGX and the MSCI –  has assets under management of US$426 million.
China is seeing shipment delays to November for all iPhone 15 Pro Max models, while the UK is showing seven- to eight-week delays for some versions of the device.

site_title: The latest cool amenity? A name brand. How about Porsche?
summary: The market for name-brand luxury condominium units is projected to grow 12% annually between 2023 and 2026, according to a report from Knight Frank. Developers like Gil Dezer are capitalizing on this trend, creating branded residences from luxury car and couture brands such as Porsche, Bentley, and Armani. These luxury condos are not only sought after for their high-end amenities but also as status symbols, with prices expected to rise accordingly.

images.alt_text: Land site up for sale  in the Holland Rise good class bungalow (GCB) area.

site_title: US auto talks at 'critical phase' as political pressure grows
summary: US auto talks are in a "critical phase" as workers at Big Three automakers, including Stellantis, General Motors, and Ford, coordinate strike action for pay increases of 40% over a four-year contract. The United Auto Workers (UAW) warned the strike could spread, posing a significant disruption to the industry. Politicians are staking out positions on the labor issue, which could have a national impact. Both sides issued cautious statements, with Stellantis calling the talks "critical." A resolution is crucial to avoid a prolonged strike that could affect the US automotive industry.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: "UAW on strike" picket signs lay on a pile of wood outside the General Motors Detroit-Hamtramck Assembly in Hamtramck, Michigan, U.S. October 25, 2019.   REUTERS/Rebecca Cook/File Photo

site_title: How soaring childcare costs are crushing New Yorkers
summary: Soaring childcare costs are crippling New York households, with many families struggling to afford basic necessities. A recent example is Crystal Springs, who left her high-paying job due to exorbitant childcare costs. Social workers, educators, and parents are speaking out about the issue, which is particularly pronounced in New York City. The city's high cost of living, combined with stagnant wages, is leaving many families feeling financially strained and forced to make difficult choices.

images.alt_text: Prospective home buyers leaving a property for sale in a neighborhood in Clarksburg, Maryland on Sept 3, 2023.
As the population ages, adding more migrants can help ensure Singapore remains economically vibrant.

site_title: GSK secures FDA approval for new blood cancer treatment
summary: GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) has received FDA approval for its new blood cancer treatment, momelotinib, for patients with myelofibrosis who have anemia. The treatment, acquired from Sierra Oncology for $1.9 billion, is expected to generate sales of over $1 billion annually. GSK plans to price it at a premium to its main rival, ruxolitinib, due to the significant burden of anemia in patients with myelofibrosis, which can reduce life expectancy.

images.alt_text: The drug, also known as tirzepatide, has also been in the spotlight for its potential to treat obesity.

site_title: A 1.37t yuan exodus shows China’s heft fading in world markets
summary: China's massive outflow of funds from its stocks and bonds has diminished its market's influence in global portfolios. Foreign holdings of Chinese equities and debt have fallen by 17% to 1.37 trillion yuan ($188 billion) since a December 2021 peak. This decline coincides with China's economic slump due to Covid restrictions, a property market crisis, and tensions with the West, accelerating its decoupling from the global market.

images.alt_text: Industrial output rises 4.5 per cent in August from a year earlier, according to data released by the National Bureau of Statistics (NBS).

site_title:
GHY’s Guo Jingyu raises stake 
as group eyes turnaround, profitability
summary: GHY Culture & Media Holding Co. has raised its stake in the company after acquiring 41,990,000 ordinary shares from a third-party seller for 80 million yuan. The acquisition increased GHY's direct interest in the company from 59.60% to 63.51%. GHY's latest half-year results showed revenue surged 58% to S$32.7 million and gross profit increased by 110% to S$10.6 million. The company aims to turn around and achieve profitability in FY23.

images.alt_text: Generic shots of SGX

site_title: Slack CEO is ready to ride AI wave
summary: Slack CEO Lidiane Jones asserts that her company is equally suited to excel in AI as Microsoft, citing the quality of its data as the key ingredient in the technology's magic formula. Following the launch of ChatGPT, Slack has rapidly developed AI-powered features, including the ability to summarize content and automate administrative tasks. Jones believes the company's open platform and access to third-party AI tools, such as Claude and ChatGPT, are its strengths, setting it apart from Microsoft's Teams.

images.alt_text: A screen displays the logo of Softbank's Arm, chip design firm, during the company’s initial public offering (IPO) at Nasdaq Market site in New York, U.S., September 14, 2023. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Why diamonds are losing their allure
summary: Diamonds, once a stable investment option, have lost their allure due to enormous volatility. De Beers, a long-time diamond supplier, has reduced prices by 40% for two-to-four carat uncut stones, sparking concerns about the future of the market. The rise of lab-grown diamonds, which can be made at a fraction of the cost, has further eroded demand. As a result, investors may reconsider diamonds as a stable investment option, while consumers may find better deals on lab-grown alternatives.

images.alt_text: The difference between a natural diamond (right) and one grown in a lab. De Beers says selling lab-grown diamonds is not a sustainable market.
De Beers describes the first diamonds as “a key milestone”.

site_title: World Cup fanfare masks an existential threat to rugby
summary: The Rugby World Cup in France is facing an existential crisis due to concerns over head injuries and their potential link to chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE). Despite efforts to introduce new rules and technologies to reduce head contact, many experts believe the risks remain high. A lawsuit by hundreds of former players in the UK has raised the possibility of financial compensation for neurological injuries, including dementia. The sport's participation has plummeted in the UK, while globally, participation is up 11%, driven by younger players and women. To thrive, rugby must find a solution to its neurological health concerns.

images.alt_text: Fiji’s Reapi Ulunisau (with the ball) in action against Canada during the HSBC Canada Rugby Sevens tournament in Vancouver on March 5, 2023.

site_title: Discount airlines slam UK air traffic control for disruption
summary: Discount airlines EasyJet and Ryanair have criticized the UK's air traffic control provider, Nats, for causing disruptions during the summer travel season. Nats CEO Martin Rolfe is being called for a change in leadership after a staffing shortage at London's Gatwick Airport led to schedule disruptions and cancellations. The latest issue occurred less than three weeks after Nats experienced an air-traffic outage, with the airlines citing a persistent pinch-point in the industry. Nats attributes the recent outage to a software anomaly, but airlines dismiss the explanation as insufficient.

site_title: Chinese EV makers pin hopes on Europe’s fading auto dealers
summary: Chinese electric vehicle makers BYD, Xpeng, and Great Wall Motor are shifting their focus to establishing dealership networks in Europe, aiming to boost sales and establish reputations for quality and reliability. Despite EU efforts to restrict imports of cheap Chinese EVs, the companies face a significant challenge in winning over European consumers who are unfamiliar with their brands. Industry expert Daniel Kirchert notes that Chinese carmakers must demonstrate that their vehicles are comparable to Tesla at a lower price to gain traction in the market. Dealerships are seen as a key factor in achieving this goal.

images.alt_text: China is accused of flooding global markets with electric cars that have artificially low prices because of huge state subsidies.

site_title: Nvidia cash geyser can cover buybacks and vital R&D
summary: Nvidia is generating a record-breaking $38 billion in free cash flow in fiscal 2025, surpassing its spending on research and development and stock buybacks. Despite concerns that the company's massive buyback allocation would leave it short on R&D funds, analysts believe Nvidia's financial strength will allow it to maintain its technological lead and reward shareholders. The company's ability to spend as much as rivals like AMD and Intel on product development is expected to keep it ahead in the market for AI accelerators.

images.alt_text: As Nvidia has grown stronger in the market for chips that work with massive amounts of language data, the harder it has become for companies attempting to build competing chips.
The deals with two of India’s largest business houses will help the Nvidia deepen inroads to the emerging AI ecosystem of the South Asian nation.

site_title: Arm’s IPO lures retail traders seeking exposure to AI
summary: Arm, a chip design firm, successfully completed its initial public offering (IPO) on September 14, 2023, attracting a large number of retail traders seeking exposure to the artificial intelligence (AI) sector. The company's stock surged 25% on its first day of trading, outpacing demand for other retail favorites like Tesla and Nvidia. This IPO marks a significant event in the market, as it provides a platform for individual investors to participate in the growing AI frenzy, paving the way for more deals in the coming weeks.

site_title: UBS on US$1 billion quest to avoid Deutsche Bank’s IT missteps
summary: UBS is integrating Credit Suisse's domestic business into its own IT framework, a task notorious for running behind schedule and over budget, as seen in Deutsche Bank's troubled Postbank integration. UBS aims to finish the integration by the end of 2025, targeting a cost of $1 billion to $3 billion, depending on the technology's state. The integration poses a significant challenge, with the potential to cost billions of dollars, tie up staff, and impact the bank's brand, similar to Deutsche Bank's experience with Postbank.

images.alt_text: UBS plans to cut more than half of Credit Suisse’s 45,000-strong employee base.

site_title: Can you spot the difference between l and I?
summary: Cybercriminals use "lookalike" domains and email addresses to deceive users by exploiting everyday computing activities. These variations, often small differences in font or case, can be difficult to notice. In 2022, Singapore's SingCERT handled 8,500 phishing attempts, doubling from the previous year. Domain name system (DNS) security solutions can help combat these threats by customizing and configuring lists of lookalikes to scan for and protect against. Implementing such solutions can strengthen security and protect valuable login pages, brand reputation, and consumer lives in the digital landscape.

images.alt_text: MGM Resorts shut down some computer systems due to a cyber attack.
Users should not take unnecessary risks by sideloading apps from third-party sources on the same device as their banking apps.
Facade of SingPost Centre at Eunos Road near Paya Lebar MRT station on Nov 3, 2020.

site_title: Apple iPhone 15 Pro Max deliveries slip to November in sign of demand
summary: Apple's new iPhone 15 Pro Max pre-orders have seen shipment delays to November, with US deliveries slipping to mid-November and UK, China, Canada, and India experiencing seven- to eight-week delays. The delays affect all storage capacities of the high-end Pro Max model, which starts at $1,199. The standard iPhone 15 Pro with a smaller screen is also seeing delays, while the iPhone 15 Plus in pink is available immediately. The strong demand for the Pro Max model suggests Apple's pricing strategy is not deterring customers.

images.alt_text: Apple iPhone 15 and Apple iPhone 15 Max on display during an event at Apple Park campus in Cupertino, California, US, Sept 12, 2023.
The iPhone 15 Pro is presented during the 'Wonderlust' event at the company's headquarters in Cupertino, California, U.S. September 12, 2023. REUTERS/Loren Elliott
The new iPhone 15 goes on sale online in China on Alibaba’s Tmall marketplace on Sep 15, and in-stores on Sep 22.
“We will issue a software update for users in France to accommodate the protocol used by French regulators. We look forward to iPhone 12 continuing to be available in France,” says Apple.
Apple was already phasing out the iPhone 12 just as the issue flared up.
Apple has faced a number of security issues in recent months.

site_title: US FAA cuts minimum flight requirements at New York airports through late 2024
summary: The US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has extended cuts to minimum flight requirements at New York City-area airports through October 2024, citing staffing issues at the New York Terminal Radar Approach Control (N90). The waiver allows airlines to not fly some flights while retaining slots, providing relief to airlines facing delays due to government staffing shortages. The FAA continues to work on a long-term solution to address chronic low levels of fully certified air traffic controllers at N90.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: American Airlines aircraft sit on the tarmac at LaGuardia airport following a reservation system outage in New York, April 16, 2013. REUTERS/Carlo Allegri/File Photo

site_title: US retailer holiday hiring to drop to levels last seen in 2008
summary: US retailers plan to hire 410,000 seasonal workers for the holiday season, the lowest number since 2008, due to increased labor costs and consumer uncertainty. This is a 26% decline from the 519,400 jobs added in the last quarter of 2022. Retailers have already announced just 8,000 planned hires, a significant drop from 258,201 in 2022. The slow hiring trend is attributed to dwindling household savings and worries over the economy, leading to cautious consumer spending.

images.alt_text: Australia's jobless rate held steady at 3.7 per cent, matching forecasts from analysts, while the participation rate surged to 67.0 per cent, the highest since records began in 2013.

British Chancellor of the Exchequer Jeremy Hunt holds a Ministerial Statement at the House of Commons in London, Britain, June 26, 2023. UK Parliament/Jessica Taylor/Handout via REUTERS THIS IMAGE HAS BEEN SUPPLIED BY A THIRD PARTY MANDATORY CREDIT. IMAGE MUST NOT BE ALTERED.

site_title: Five past, present directors of 8Telecom given SGX reprimand for breaching listing rules
summary: Five past and present directors of 8Telecom International Holdings have been given a public reprimand by the Singapore Exchange for breaching listing rules. The directors, including Liu Lu, Zhang Yuanyuan, and Xiang Ying, were found to have failed to conduct due diligence on target companies and disclose material information. Three directors are prohibited from being appointed as director and/or executive officer for two years, while another former executive director, Tiffany Gong Qian, must provide a signed written undertaking not to seek corporate directorship for one year. Trading in 8Telecom's shares has been suspended since September 2019.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek

SGX RegCo's reprimand is in relation to new developments in Nutryfarm's potential restructuring of third-party loans into convertible bonds, which were not disclosed to shareholders in a timely manner.

site_title: Bernard Arnault built a luxury empire on ‘desirability’. Who will inherit it?
summary: Bernard Arnault, the head of LVMH, has built a luxury empire on "desirability." He has raised his five adult children to take over the company, with each having a 20% stake. His eldest son Antoine is in charge of communications and image, while his eldest daughter Delphine is chair and CEO of Christian Dior Couture. Arnault has ensured the family's control of LVMH by raising the mandatory retirement age to 80 and creating a corporate structure that locks in his children's control. However, Arnault's success has brought challenges, including growing economic inequality and a faltering Chinese economy, which may impact LVMH's desirability.

images.alt_text: Bernard Arnault, in front of a painting by Jean Dubuffet, outside his office at the Paris headquarters of LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton on July 6, 2023. With brands like Tiffany, Dom perignon and Louis Vuitton, LVMH turned Arnaud into one of the worldÕs richest men. (Dmitry Kostyukov/The New York Times)
Barclays analyst Carole Madjo reduces her recommendation on France’s LVMH to equal-weight from overweight and the firm lowered its view on the sector to neutral from positive.

site_title: US homebuyers cancel purchases at highest rate in 10 months
summary: US homebuyers canceled nearly 60,000 purchases in August, the highest rate in 10 months, due to rising borrowing costs. Mortgage rates surpassed 7% for the first time since November, leading to a 16% share of canceled deals. Despite sluggish sales, home prices rose 3% in August to a median price of $420,846, as buyers compete for a limited supply of homes. Experts predict prices will remain high as long as rates remain high, limiting the supply of homes for sale.

site_title: Corporate borrowers are giving in to high rates: Wells Fargo
summary: Corporate borrowers are taking advantage of high interest rates, with over $110 billion of bonds sold globally last week. According to Wells Fargo, companies are "willing to lean in" to tap US debt markets despite elevated borrowing costs. Finance chiefs see signs that interest rates will remain high for a prolonged period, prompting the Federal Reserve to consider one more interest-rate hike this year and staying at the peak level next year. This has led to a robust issuance of bonds across both high-grade and junk debt markets.

site_title: S-Reits raise their sustainability reporting standards
summary: S-Reits in Singapore have raised their sustainability reporting standards, with 91% of the sector meeting climate-related disclosures and 46% of disclosures meeting quality standards. A joint study by EY and the Reit Association of Singapore found that diversified S-Reits have the highest coverage and quality scores, outperforming global peers. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and SGX launched ESGenome, a disclosure portal to collect consistent and comparable ESG data, which has been adopted by several S-Reits. This move aims to promote transparency and support the creation of ESG-related financial products.

images.alt_text: During H12023, Clar's Singapore acquisitions that were completed include The Shugart, a business park property at 26 Ayer Rajah Crescent.

site_title: Hawaii revises down wildfire death toll
summary: Hawaii's wildfire death toll has been revised downward from 115 to 97, according to the state's governor, Josh Green. The decrease was attributed to scientists' efforts to identify the remains of victims, including those who fled with pets or were in cars. The number of people unaccounted for has decreased from 123 to 31. The revised figures come as authorities face criticism over their handling of the disaster, including delayed warnings and a slow recovery effort for the thousands left homeless.

images.alt_text: The fire-ravaged town of Lahaina on the island of Maui in Hawaii, US, Aug 15, 2023.
Volunteers sort through donated food items at an emergency aid distribution point for victims of last week's wildfire in Lahaina, on the Hawaiian island of Maui.

site_title: TikTok plans steep holiday discounts, bringing Amazon price war
summary: TikTok plans a month-long holiday discount campaign, offering up to 50% off on Black Friday and Cyber Monday, to lure shoppers to its new online marketplace. The campaign aims to compete with Amazon and Walmart, and TikTok will subsidize discounts to entice sellers' participation. The company aims to sell $20 billion in merchandise globally this year and is targeting US shoppers projected to spend $284 billion during the holiday period.

images.alt_text: EU regulator highlight in its ruling how children signing up had TikTok accounts set to public by default, meaning anyone could view or comment on their content.
FILE PHOTO: The TikTok logo is pictured outside the company's U.S. head office in Culver City, California, U.S.,  September 15, 2020.   REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo

site_title: US: Wall Street ends sharply lower as chipmakers, mega caps slide
summary: US stocks ended sharply lower on Friday as chipmakers dropped due to weak consumer demand and rising Treasury yields. The S&P 500 fell 1.22% to 4,450.32 points, while the Nasdaq declined 1.56% to 13,708.34 points. Major chipmakers like Nvidia, AMD, and Broadcom dropped 3-4% as the United Auto Workers' union launched strikes at General Motors, Ford, and Chrysler factories. Treasury yields edged higher ahead of the Federal Reserve policy meeting next week, with traders betting on a rate hold in September.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - AUGUST 25: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange during morning trading on August 25, 2023 in New York City. Stocks opened up higher as Wall Street awaits a speech from Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell’s at the Jackson Hole Economic Symposium.   Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Michael M. Santiago / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: In Rwanda, crypto gains ground as investment asset class and for transactions
summary: Rwanda's crypto scene is gaining ground despite the government's ban on banks facilitating transactions. Locals like Max Mucyo, a 22-year-old agriculture student, are investing in cryptocurrencies and using profits to fund daily necessities and university fees. Mucyo discovered crypto through YouTube tutorials and now invests regularly. The government's ban is seen as an opportunity for the crypto scene to blossom, driven by Rwanda's digitalising economy.

images.alt_text: Genesis announced earlier this month that it was winding down spot trading services provided by Genesis Global Trading.
Hong Kong securities regulator warns that JPEX is advertising itself as a 'licensed and recognized platform,' but has neither applied for nor received a license in the city.
Three Arrows Capital co-founders Kyle Livingston Davies (pictured) and Zhu Su have been issued nine-year prohibition orders by MAS.

site_title: Women's tennis returns to China after Peng Shuai boycott
summary: Women's tennis tournaments are returning to China after a nearly two-year boycott, with the WTA resuming events in Guangzhou on September 18. The decision comes despite concerns over player Peng Shuai's safety and the alleged risks of holding events in China. The WTA had initially suspended activities in China in 2021 following Peng's allegations of sexual assault, but later resumed tournaments in April citing economic interests. The return of tennis to China is expected to attract attention, but few top-20 stars are expected to attend.

images.alt_text: “We have not been able to achieve everything we set out for, but we have been in touch with people close to Peng and are assured she is living safely with her family in Beijing,” the WTA said.
Tennis: WTA threatens to pull out of tournaments in China over Peng

site_title: Morgan Stanley to keep some of its contentious preferred shares
summary: Morgan Stanley has decided to keep some of its preferred shares, which were originally sold 10 years ago and had a fixed coupon rate. The bank had announced in April that some of the instruments would retain their original fixed rate instead of switching to a floating benchmark, causing some investors to miss out on potential higher dividend payments. As a result, Morgan Stanley will skip the first call option of a $862.5 million issue with a 7.125% fixed coupon, which is set to expire on October 15.

images.alt_text: In one of the biggest anti-money laundering operations in Singapore, the Singapore Police Force (SPF) rounded up a group of foreigners who had amassed about $1.8 billion worth of assets in the city-state.
FILE PHOTO: A street sign stands near the Morgan Stanley worldwide headquarters building in New York May 8, 2009. REUTERS/Lucas Jackson/File Photo

site_title: EU hits TikTok with big fine over child data
summary: The European Union has fined Chinese-owned social media platform TikTok 345 million euros (US$369 million) over child data breaches. The fine stems from a two-year investigation by Ireland's Data Protection Commission, which found TikTok's platform settings and age verification measures were inadequate. The regulator criticized the platform's default setting of public accounts for children and lack of verification for parents linking to their teenage offspring. TikTok has 30 days to bring its processing into compliance with EU rules.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The TikTok logo is pictured outside the company's U.S. head office in Culver City, California, U.S.,  September 15, 2020.   REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo
TikTok’s more than 150 million users in the US will now be able to see videos and live streams with links to purchase items on their feed
TikTok Shop will be competing with Amazon.com to sell a target of US$20 billion in merchandise this year.
In the coming months, TikTok and NCC say they will engage with policymakers across Europe to explain how the system will work in practice.

While TikTok Shop is fast emerging as a serious contender against incumbent e-commerce majors such as Shopee and Lazada in South-east Asia, Momentum Works also sees TikTok competing with Amazon in the US and Middle East.

As demand for cremation increases in the United States, TikTok influencers on the hashtag #gravetok are hoping to inspire a new generation of cemetery enthusiasts who can help conserve the country's past.

site_title: The science and art of celebrity branding
summary: A bank's choice of celebrity endorsement can spark controversy, as DBS's logo on Indian badminton players sparked discussions on whether it should have chosen local players instead. Brands must balance quantitative metrics, such as Q Scores, with cultural expectations to select the right ambassador. While celebrity endorsements can positively impact consumer perceptions, they also risk backlash if not chosen carefully. The art of selection involves considering factors like values, community expectations, and local connections to avoid faux pas and maintain brand integrity.

bitcoin, money, decentralized

site_title: Chevron LNG strikes to have limited near-term impact on US gas prices: analysts
summary: Chevron's LNG strikes in Australia, which began on September 14, are expected to have limited near-term impact on US gas prices due to low domestic demand. The strikes, targeting LNG exports, are unlikely to affect prices in the short term, but could lead to upward pressure on US and European prices if the strikes continue until winter. The facilities continued exports on Friday, according to LSEG data.

images.alt_text: The Gorgon carbon capture project in Australia.
