Royal Golden Eagle’s (RGE) sustainability-linked interest rate swap is used as a partial hedge for its sustainability-linked loans, which raises the possibility of the resources group getting penalised twice if it misses its sustainability targets.
The way that Singapore designs its sustainable aviation fuel offtake framework will have implications on the competitiveness of Changi Airport and Singapore Airlines.
Sun Cable's Australia-Asia PowerLink project would have been the longest undersea high voltage direct current transmission cable in the world if it was completed today.

site_title: Issue 36: Singapore reviews offsets; Asean business picks profit first
summary: Singapore is reviewing its voluntary carbon market, including Nature-Based Global Emissions Offsets, amid concerns over the validity of forestry carbon credits. Reports have questioned the accuracy of Verra's credits, which account for over 90% of global rainforest offsets. The Singapore government plans to publish a whitelist of eligible credits, while traders are shifting away from avoidance credits to forest restoration credits. Financial institutions in Asia prioritize profit over climate, and the current market slump may lead to improvements in voluntary carbon markets, but also poses risks for organizations relying on offsets.

images.alt_text: Kenneth Lim

Royal Golden Eagle’s (RGE) sustainability-linked interest rate swap is used as a partial hedge for its sustainability-linked loans, which raises the possibility of the resources group getting penalised twice if it misses its sustainability targets.
The way that Singapore designs its sustainable aviation fuel offtake framework will have implications on the competitiveness of Changi Airport and Singapore Airlines.
Most long-serving independent directors at Singapore-listed companies were re-elected in 2021 under the two-tier voting system.
Sun Cable's Australia-Asia PowerLink project would have been the longest undersea high voltage direct current transmission cable in the world if it was completed today.
Most investors in Asia still aren’t making significant deployments into sustainable assets, although the number is expected to grow in the coming years.

site_title: Disney holds preliminary talks with Nexstar on ABC TV network sale: sources
summary: Disney has held preliminary talks with Nexstar on a potential sale of its US TV network ABC, following CEO Bob Iger's July statement that the company could sell some traditional TV assets due to the rise of streaming services. Media entrepreneur Byron Allen has also submitted a $10 billion bid to acquire ABC, local stations, and FX and National Geographic cable channels. The discussions are preliminary and may not lead to a deal, with a Disney spokesperson stating the company is open to considering strategic options for its linear business.

images.alt_text: Disney+ has been losing customers to price increases, as well as collapsing demand in India after the company failed to win cricket streaming rights.
Netflix lost more than a million subscribers in the first half of 2022. But its ad-supported service has added over 15 million subscribers.
FILE PHOTO: The 76th Cannes Film Festival - 2023 Kering Women In Motion Awards - Cannes, France May 21, 2023. Salma Hayek and Francois-Henri Pinault pose. REUTERS/Gonzalo Fuentes/File Photo

Netflix held the fan screening of “One Piece,”  at the Santa Monica Pier in Santa Monica, Calif., on Aug. 24, 2023. The “One Piece” franchise is enormously popular, with more than 516 million books sold and numerous anime series and movies released. (Yuri Hasegawa/The New York Times)
FILE PHOTO: Taylor Swift performs at the iHeartRadio Wango Tango concert in Carson, California, U.S., June 1, 2019. REUTERS/Mario Anzuoni//File Photo
Roku has raised its quarterly revenue forecast, a sign that ad spending was continuing to improve thanks to cooling inflation and hopes of a pause in interest rate hikes.

site_title: South Korea house prices climb for second month in August
summary: South Korea's housing market experienced its second consecutive month of price increases in August, with a nationwide house transaction price index rising 0.16% from July. Prices rose 0.29% in Seoul and 0.30% in the greater capital area, while other regions saw a 0.02% increase, the first since June 2022. This follows a 0.03% increase in July, marking the biggest percentage gain since December 2021.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An apartment complex which is currently under construction is seen in Seoul, South Korea, August 30, 2016. REUTERS/Kim Hong-Ji/File Photo

site_title: China’s August industrial output, retail sales growth beat expectations
summary: China's industrial output and retail sales grew at a faster pace in August, beating expectations with a 4.5% increase in industrial output and a 5.5% increase in retail sales. This growth marks the quickest pace since April, but tumbling investment in the property sector threatens to undercut support efforts. Chinese policymakers face a challenge in reviving growth amid persistent weakness in the property industry, a faltering currency, and weak global demand for manufactured goods.

images.alt_text: Men walk near a sign of the G 77 + China Summit during the inauguration of the press room in Havana, on September 13, 2023. (Photo by YAMIL LAGE / AFP)
Bullion on the Shanghai Gold Exchange traded at a premium of more than US$120 an ounce on Thursday (Sep 14).
The outlook downgrade comes amid a string of debt defaults by China's cash-squeezed developers.

site_title: Xiaomi supplier to open smartphone plant as India pushes local
summary: Xiaomi supplier Dixon Technologies India is opening a new smartphone factory in New Delhi, investing over 4 billion rupees over three years. The 300,000-square-foot factory will produce Xiaomi smartphones, marking a shift for the Chinese company as India pushes local assembly partners. This move follows Xiaomi's earlier partnership with Optiemus Electronics to make Bluetooth earphones. Dixon aims to become India's response to Foxconn, Apple's Taiwanese supplier, and is expanding its product portfolio beyond smartphones.

images.alt_text: Xiaomi Corp. Mi smartphones on display inside the AliExpress plaza retail store, operated by Alibaba Group Holding Ltd., in Barcelona, Spain, on Wednesday, Jan. 13, 2020. U.S. officials deliberated but ultimately decided against banning American investment in Alibaba and Tencent Holdings Ltd., a person familiar with the discussions said, removing a cloud of uncertainty over Asia’s two biggest corporations. Photographer: Angel Garcia/Bloomberg
Xiaomi commits US$10 billion to decade-long automobile venture, targets H1 2024 for initial car mass production.

site_title: DBS CEO Gupta says China ‘consequential’ to bank’s strategy
summary: DBS Group Holdings CEO Piyush Gupta emphasized China's long-term importance to the bank despite short-term challenges. The bank continues to invest in China, focusing on sectors like electronic vehicles and technology. Gupta stated that with the right opportunities, growth can still be found, requiring the bank to be nimble and adaptable.

images.alt_text: DBS Group CEO Piyush Gupta said banks had already been more cautious over the last 15 years since the global financial crisis.
Singapore’s DBS Group taps the US dollar bond markets for the first time in nearly two years as it raises US$1.5 billion.

Witnessing the MOU signing were Piyush Gupta (first from left), CEO of DBS and Loh Chin Hua, CEO of Keppel; signing the MOU were Tan Su Shan (first seated from left), Group Institutional Banking, DBS and Louis Lim, CEO, Real Estate Division, Keppel.

site_title: Huawei used years-old Hynix memory tech in Mate 60 phones
summary: Huawei's latest Mate 60 phones use years-old SK Hynix memory modules, available since at least 2021, despite US sanctions on the company. The discovery has sparked consternation in the US, with Washington officials launching a probe into the Mate 60 Pro and its processor. Republican lawmakers have called for a complete cut-off of Huawei and its chipmaker, Semiconductor Manufacturing International, from American suppliers, citing the ineffectiveness of the sanctions. Hynix has denied doing business with Huawei since the sanctions were imposed and is investigating the matter.

site_title: Excessive monetary policy communications may undermine the Fed
summary: The US Federal Reserve is facing a communications challenge ahead of its September meeting, where markets expect rates to remain unchanged. However, the Fed must balance welcoming new data while avoiding giving markets a false sense of security. Public discourse heavily focuses on the Fed, creating an exaggerated impression that monetary policy alone can deliver stability. The Fed should emphasize that it cannot do the job alone, citing factors outside its control such as supply shocks and fiscal policies. This could compromise the Fed's independence and ability to serve as a flexible tool for stabilization.

images.alt_text: A nozzle is replaced on a fuel dispenser at a gas station in La Puente, California, on September 7, 2023. US gas prices this week hit the highest levels in a decade as the summer holiday season winds down, with rising crude-oil prices a likely contributing factor to higher gas prices. (Photo by Frederic J. BROWN / AFP)

With inflation still above its 2 per cent target and economic growth solid, US central bankers probably will retain a bias towards tighter policy at their Sep 19-20 meeting even as they hold rates steady.

NEW YORK, NEW YORK - AUGUST 25: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange during morning trading on August 25, 2023 in New York City. Stocks opened up higher as Wall Street awaits a speech from Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell’s at the Jackson Hole Economic Symposium.   Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Michael M. Santiago / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: DoorDash to switch listing to Nasdaq
summary: DoorDash to switch listing to Nasdaq, trading on September 27. The delivery firm, which debuted in December 2020, will retain the symbol "DASH" and move from the New York Stock Exchange. This move comes as Instacart is expected to debut on the Nasdaq later this month, benefiting from the pandemic-driven shift to online ordering. DoorDash has lifted its annual core profit forecast for the second time, citing continued growth.

site_title: PBOC adds more cash into economy as recovery gathers pace
summary: The People's Bank of China (PBOC) added 191 billion yuan (S$36.3 billion) to the financial system via a one-year policy loan and 34 billion yuan via a 14-day money-market loan to accelerate economic recovery. The central bank kept the MLF borrowing cost unchanged at 2.5% after a surprise 15-basis-point cut last month. This move comes as data shows encouraging signs of growth momentum, with August industrial production and retail sales beating expectations. The PBOC aims to solidify the economic recovery and revive risk appetite among investors.

images.alt_text: A worker operates machines at a textile factory in Nantong in eastern China's Jiangsu province on Sept 14, 2023.
FILE PHOTO: The headquarters of the People's Bank of China, the central bank, is pictured in Beijing, China, February 3, 2020. REUTERS/Jason Lee/File Photo
People’s Bank of China has warned some lenders of their huge US dollar purchases on behalf of their corporate clients.
The PBOC has set firmer-than-expected daily guidance rates to stem the yuan’s decline.

site_title: JPMorgan seeks to back startups after dealmaking wins in India
summary: JPMorgan Chase plans to expand its business beyond dealmaking to support India's growing startup ecosystem. The bank aims to partner with pioneering companies, particularly those with a large consumer orientation, and develop new products and services. JPMorgan has focused on building relationships with clients over the past few years, ranking first in stock sales this year. The bank plans to explore opportunities in sectors such as green energy, manufacturing, and outsourcing, with a focus on wholesale banking.

images.alt_text: The proposal to require US banks to set aside more capital to guard against risk was “hugely disappointing” and involved a “lack of transparency” from regulators about the rationale, JPMorgan Chase Jamie Dimon said in New York.
JPMorgan has developed several applications using blockchain.

The US Virgin Islands says the enormous sum that propped up Epstein’s sex trafficking bolsters key allegations in its suit that JPMorgan knowingly benefited from the financier’s wrongdoing and ignored red flags.

site_title: Aussie regulator moves to block Qantas-China Eastern Airlines cooperation
summary: Australia's competition regulator plans to deny authorisation for Qantas Airways and China Eastern Airlines to coordinate passenger and cargo movement between Australia and China, citing concerns that it would lessen competition and lead to higher airfare prices. The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) Commissioner Anna Brakey expressed concerns that the alliance would provide both companies an "incentive to increase prices." Qantas had sought an extension for the alliance, but the ACCC is moving forward with a draft order to deny authorisation.

images.alt_text: Qantas Airways now faces penalties and compensation payments to affected workers fired during the Covid-19 pandemic.
FILE PHOTO: Qantas aircraft are seen on the tarmac at Melbourne International Airport in Melbourne, Australia, November 6, 2018. REUTERS/Phil Noble/File Photo
Plagued by a series of controversies, Qantas Airways CEO Alan Joyce has brought forward his retirement by two months.
The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission alleged that Qantas kept selling tickets for an average of 16 days after it had cancelled flights for reasons often within its control.

The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission said in a court filing that Qantas broke consumer law when it sold tickets to more than 8,000 flights between May and July 2022 without disclosing they had been cancelled.

site_title: ECB hike crosses rubicon of pain with Lagarde warning of hard times
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) raised its deposit rate to 4% for the 10th consecutive time, marking a significant hike in interest rates. The move aims to curb inflation, which remains above 5%, but has been met with warnings of a potential recession and sluggish growth. ECB President Christine Lagarde acknowledged that growth will be "very, very sluggish" and forecasts suggest the economy may shrink. Financial markets are already betting on a reversal, with investor views shifting in favor of a rate cut as early as June.

images.alt_text: On Thursday, the ECB is also expected to cut its growth projections for this year and next, leading some economists to argue it should hold off from raising rates this month.

A majority of economists, 39 of 69, in the Sept 5-7 poll predicted no change to the deposit rate on Thursday while 30 said the ECB’s Governing Council would hike it by a quarter-point to 4.00 per cent.
ECB chief economist Philip Lane says slowing in goods and services gauges are welcome and that underlying pressures will keep weakening.
Lagarde and her colleagues are still waiting to weigh the ECB’s in-house economic forecasts, which are a key piece to the puzzle of rate decisions.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Friday; STI up 0.5%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.5% at the open on Friday, tracking global markets higher, with the Straits Times Index climbing 16.57 points to 3,266.08. Gainers outnumbered losers 73 to 26, with heavily traded counters like Seatrium, Marco Polo Marine, and Rex International rising. Local banks also opened higher, with DBS, OCBC, and UOB gaining 0.1%, 1%, and 0.7% respectively.

images.alt_text: LHN Limited says it has occupancy rates of 85 per cent to 100 per cent of three of its co-living locations in Singapore.

site_title: Sea CEO rallies staff as Shopee’s competitors close in
summary: Sea CEO Forrest Li has rallied his staff as the company faces increasing competition from e-commerce rivals, including TikTok Shop, which aims to quadruple its global merchandise sales to $20 billion. Li reminded staff that a "hard contest" is where the company thrives, citing its history of success as an underdog. Despite a 29% share drop following Sea's Q2 results, Li said the company will take on competition from a strong position, having achieved financial independence, and may incur losses in some quarters as part of a strategic plan.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
The rise of TikTok Shop is viewed as the biggest threat to Shopee's hold on e-commerce in South-east Asia by Sea.
Sea has reported yet another profitable quarter, as gross profit margins improve in its e-commerce segment.

site_title: Deutsche Bank links with Swiss crypto firm for custody services
summary: Deutsche Bank has partnered with Swiss crypto firm Taurus to offer custody services for digital assets. The partnership will enable Deutsche Bank to start providing custody services to clients. The accord was part of a planned launch announced by Deutsche Bank's global head of securities services, Paul Maley, in a February interview. The move is part of the bank's expansion into digital custody services, as the digital asset space is expected to encompass trillions of US dollars of assets.

site_title: Singapore’s anti-money laundering regime sound, but banks can ‘dial up scrutiny’ on property financing: DBS’  Gupta
summary: DBS Group CEO Piyush Gupta stated that Singapore's anti-money laundering regime is sound, but banks can "dial up scrutiny" on property financing. Since the global financial crisis, banks have invested in anti-fraud technology and AI to better understand customers and detect suspicious transactions. However, Gupta noted that even with a 99.99% catch rate, some illicit activity can still slip through. He suggested increasing scrutiny on property financing, as it is a sector targeted by criminals to launder ill-gotten gains.

images.alt_text: One of the two buildings in London that were sold together for more than S$73m to New Yihao, a company that lists Su Haijin as shareholder.
Olam’s announcement confirms a media report that bond was posted for a director of its Nigerian unit.
The 10 accused in the case.
Industry players and observers that spoke to BT said the police bust – the largest AML operation in Singapore’s history – should be viewed in a positive light.
Banks file Suspicious Transaction Reports (STRs) when they detect a suspicious transaction or fund flow.

site_title: Chinese developer Sino-Ocean suspends offshore debt payments
summary: Chinese state-linked developer Sino-Ocean Group Holding has suspended payment on all its offshore borrowings due to tight liquidity, amid China's deepening property debt crisis. The firm, which owns over 290 property projects, has appointed financial advisers and legal counsel to formulate a restructuring plan. Trading on eight of its US dollar bonds will be suspended until further notice. Sino-Ocean's struggles highlight the ongoing liquidity constraints in China's debt-laden developer sector, following payment struggles at Country Garden Holdings and other firms.

images.alt_text: A logo of Chinese developer Country Garden is pictured in Tianjin, China August 18, 2023. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang

site_title: Judge temporarily halts New York fraud trial against Trump, pending appeal
summary: A New York state appeals court judge temporarily halted the October 2 trial of Donald Trump's fraud lawsuit, pending an appeal to a five-judge panel. The trial, which seeks to hold Trump's family business liable for $250 million and bar Trump and his sons from leading the business, was granted an interim stay by appeals court Justice David Friedman. The trial could still proceed on September 22, but the outcome is uncertain, with the appeals court expected to rule in the last week of September.

images.alt_text: The ruling by US Judge Tanya Chutkan means that former US president Donald Trump (above) will likely have to stand trial in at least three separate criminal cases during the thick of the Republican presidential nominating contest.

site_title: ‘Greatest driver’ talk bores Max Verstappen, who wants only race wins ahead of Singapore GP
summary: Max Verstappen, the two-time F1 world champion, remains focused on his current season's goals, prioritizing race wins over discussions about his legacy as one of the greatest drivers. Despite being 26 years old and holding multiple records, Verstappen is unmoved by talk of his achievements and instead focuses on his team's performances. He will attempt to break his Singapore GP drought, but the track changes due to redevelopment may pose a challenge. teammate Sergio Perez, who won the 2022 Singapore GP, hinted at potentially leaving Red Bull after his contract expires in 2024.

images.alt_text:
Formula One F1 - Singapore Grand Prix - Marina Bay Street Circuit, Singapore - September 14, 2023
Red Bull's Max Verstappen arrives ahead of the Singapore Grand Prix REUTERS/Edgar Su

site_title: UBS cuts about a dozen US bankers as part of its Credit Suisse integration
summary: UBS has cut about a dozen US bankers as part of its integration of Credit Suisse, affecting overlapping coverage areas. The move is part of the firm's larger plan to cut over half of Credit Suisse's 45,000-strong employee base, with 3,000 domestic job cuts and $10 billion in cost savings also planned. UBS's investment banking unit will soon relocate to 11 Madison Avenue in New York's Flatiron District.

site_title: UK says China is interfering by recruiting Britons in key roles
summary: The UK government has warned that China is interfering by recruiting Britons in key roles, with some actions crossing the line from influence to interference. A four-year inquiry by Parliament's Intelligence and Security Committee found China is targeting various sectors, including telecommunications, aerospace, and academia, using investment and espionage. The government acknowledged it must do more to counter China's espionage efforts, including in Parliament and Whitehall, and has taken action in some areas. Prime Minister Rishi Sunak has called the issue "unacceptable" and raised it with Chinese Premier Li Qiang at the G20 meeting.

site_title: Global diamond prices tumble as cheaper, lab-grown gems soar in popularity
summary: Global diamond prices have plummeted by 20-30% this year due to a surge in lab-grown diamonds and Russian imports despite sanctions. The price of mined diamonds has fallen to its lowest level since 2019, with the International Diamond Exchange's polished diamond price index dropping 28%. De Beers, the world's largest diamond producer, has ended its lab-grown diamond sales for engagement rings amid rising demand for lab-grown diamonds. Lab-grown diamonds now account for 11% of US diamond sales, up from 2% in 2019, with high profit margins and a growing market share.

images.alt_text: Diamonds have historically offered a steady return on investment, but this has recently given way to enormous volatility.
The difference between a natural diamond (right) and one grown in a lab. De Beers says selling lab-grown diamonds is not a sustainable market.
The stone found by Alrosa is of non-standard shape and bordered by a yellow-brown halo.
De Beers describes the first diamonds as “a key milestone”.

site_title: X unlikely to win back advertisers before holiday season
summary: Elon Musk's appointee Linda Yaccarino as CEO of X (formerly Twitter) has failed to win back major advertisers, with many planning to shift budgets to more stable platforms during the holiday season. Advertisers cite concerns over the platform's reputation for harmful posts and Musk's chaotic takeover. Despite efforts to improve control over ad placement and repair relationships with agencies, optimism has faded, and many advertisers are increasing spending on alternative platforms like Facebook, Instagram, and TikTok. X's ad revenue is down 60% from last year, and some executives overseeing paid social media at advertising agencies have not heard from Yaccarino since her appointment.

images.alt_text: This photo illustration shows the X logo (formerly Twitter) on a smartphone screen in Los Angeles, California, on July 31, 2023. San Francisco sent the company formerly known as Twitter a warning on July 31, 2023, that it needed proper permits for the giant, flashing new X sign atop its headquarters, after the tech firm twice refused to let building inspectors check it. (Photo by Chris Delmas / AFP)

site_title: US Fed is likely to shy away from calling interest-rate peak next week
summary: US Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell is likely to maintain a "hawkish hold" on interest rates at the Sep 19-20 meeting, despite inflation remaining above the 2% target and economic growth being solid. This stance is in contrast to the European Central Bank's decision to hold rates steady, with Powell leaving the door open to future rate hikes. The Fed is expected to retain a bias towards tighter policy, with policymakers signaling that they are attentive to signs that the economy may not be cooling as expected.

images.alt_text: Philip Jefferson is expected to align closely with chair Powell’s view that the Fed may need to act if inflation pressures remain uncomfortably high.
Consumers are growing more concerned about their ability to tap credit, with the share of households saying it is either much harder or somewhat harder to access credit now.
Federal Reserve Bank of New York President John Williams speaks during the Market Forum: FX in Focus event in New York, Sept 7, 2023.

site_title: Genesis, once among the largest, winds down remaining crypto trading operations
summary: Genesis, a major cryptocurrency trading firm, is winding down its remaining operations after halting spot and derivatives transactions to its affiliate GGCI. The decision, made for business reasons, comes after another related company, Genesis Global Holdco, filed for bankruptcy in January. Genesis will cease spot trading on September 21 and stop offering derivatives trading immediately, marking the end of its cryptocurrency trading services.

site_title: Princess Diana’s ‘Black Sheep’ sweater sells at auction for US$1.1 million
summary: Princess Diana's iconic "Black Sheep" sweater, designed by Sally Muir and Joanna Osborne, sold at an auction for US$1.1 million, surpassing initial estimates of between US$50,000 to US$80,000. The sweater, worn by Diana at a 1981 polo match, was re-released for sale in 2020 and appeared in the Netflix series "The Crown." The sale marks the highest price paid at auction for a garment belonging to Princess Diana and the most valuable sweater ever sold at auction.

images.alt_text: As King Charles III nears the milestone of his first year as monarch, he is said to have made a smooth transition following the seven-decade reign of Queen Elizabeth II.
Al Fayed controlled far-flung enterprises in oil, shipping, banking and real estate, including the palatial Ritz Hotel in Paris and, for 25 years, the storied London retail emporium Harrods.

site_title: Europe: Stocks have strongest day in 6 months as ECB signals end to rate hikes
summary: European stocks rose 1.5% to a one-week high, driven by the European Central Bank's signal that monetary tightening is nearing an end, and stronger commodity prices. The Stoxx 600 index climbed 1.3%, with miners and energy stocks leading sectoral gains. The ECB raised its key interest rate to 4% but may pause at the next meeting due to a weaker growth backdrop. The euro zone economy is in the doldrums, and Denmark's central bank also raised its key interest rate.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1.0 per cent to 34,907.11 on Thursday.

site_title: Stocks to watch: LHN, SGX, Tan Chong International
summary: LHN, a Catalist-listed real estate management services group, reported occupancy rates of 85-100% for three co-living locations in Singapore, with average rental rates ranging from S$2,200 to S$3,500. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) implemented a new organisational structure, with Michael Syn appointed as president and head of global markets division. Tan Chong International's 2023 interim report showed Nissan sales volume rose year on year, while Subaru's dropped 5%.

site_title: Salesforce to hire 3,300 people after layoffs earlier this year
summary: Salesforce is hiring 3,300 people across departments after eliminating 10% of its workforce earlier this year. The new hires aim to boost profit and revive revenue growth, with the pool split roughly equally among sales, engineering, and data cloud product teams. The company is betting on interest in artificial intelligence to fuel tech investment, particularly in its data cloud product. This move restores 40% of the headcount cut in January and follows a 65% increase in shares this year.

images.alt_text: Salesforce had 70,456 full-time employees at the end of the fiscal second quarter on Jul 31.
Salesforce’s plans for reducing headcount by about 8,000 people by the end of fiscal 2024 are the company’s largest ever.
AI Cloud will include Salesforce’s products from the Einstein service to workplace-messaging app Slack and data analysis software Tableau.

(FILES) In this file photo taken on December 1, 2020, The Salesforce logo at Salesforce Tower in San Francisco, California. - Cloud computing giant Salesforce on January 4, 2023, said it was shedding about 10 percent of its employees, or just under 8,000 jobs, and closing several offices. With the plan, Salesforce joins other US tech giants including Facebook-owner Meta, Twitter and Amazon that have also imposed job cuts as the world economy heads into a downturn. (Photo by Stephen Lam / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / AFP)
Consultant Bain & Co, which Salesforce is working with to review the business, has yet to provide final recommendations.

site_title: Apple tech support staff urged to stay mum on iPhone 12 radiation issue
summary: Apple has advised tech-support staff not to disclose information about the iPhone 12's radiation levels, following a French government claim that the device exceeds standards for electromagnetic radiation. The company has rejected the French government's request to stop sales and instead offered in-house and third-party lab testing to demonstrate compliance. Apple has already phased out the iPhone 12 and will not return or exchange the phone unless purchased in the past two weeks, according to company guidance. The issue has sparked concern among existing iPhone 12 users in Europe.

images.alt_text: Apple contests the French findings, saying the iPhone 12 – now a relatively old model launched in 2020 – was certified by multiple international bodies as compliant with radiation standards.
The ANFR said it “ordered Apple to remove the iPhone 12 from the French market from Sept 12 due to the model exceeding the limit” for electromagnetic absorption by the body.

site_title: Singapore’s first electric cargo vessel set to launch in Q4
summary: Singapore's first electric cargo vessel, the Hydromover, is set to start sea trials and launch in Q4, according to Yinson Green Technologies. Developed by the Goal Zero consortium, the vessel can carry 25 tons of cargo and has a battery that can be swapped in minutes. YGT will also introduce an electric vessel for transferring crew, called the Hydroglyder, by the end of the year. The move follows Singapore's requirement for all new harbour craft to be zero emission by 2030, and marks the latest effort by the city-state to transition to a cleaner maritime industry.

images.alt_text: Maersk, which operates a fleet of about 700 container ships, is alone responsible for about 0.1 per cent of all human-made CO2 emissions.
Singapore is among the more developed countries positive on its current progress in the infrastructure transition.
People are evacuated by an excavator from a flooded area in Larissa, central Greece. Climate change can disrupt business operations, evaporate demand, impose obsolescence and shrink market share.
Maersk is working to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions to net zero by 2040

site_title: Adobe offers tepid sales outlook despite growing AI optimism
summary: Adobe provided a sales outlook of $4.98-$5.03 billion for the period ending in November, meeting analysts' expectations but disappointing investors. The company is adding generative AI features, raising prices and charging additional fees, with analysts projecting a 10% sales increase in the first year of availability. Despite this, some analysts expressed caution about the impact of the price increase on demand, citing the competitive landscape and recent price hikes. Adobe's shares were little changed in extended trading after closing at $552.16.

images.alt_text: The original commitments, which are announced in July, aim at ensuring that AI's power is not used for destructive purposes.
UK CMA says Adobe will not offer any proposals to address its concerns.
“We’re worried this deal could stifle innovation and lead to higher costs for companies that rely on Figma and Adobe’s digital tools,” CMA says.

site_title: Worst could be over for semiconductor players after dismal H1
summary: Singapore-listed tech companies, primarily semiconductor manufacturers, saw their net profits decline 39.4% year-on-year and 36.3% half-on-half in the first half of the year. However, analysts see stabilization signs, with revenues increasing sequentially in the second quarter and expected to climb 12% in the third quarter. Some analysts, such as Maybank's Jarick Seet, remain bullish on companies like Frencken and UMS Holdings, citing improved inventory levels and potential for better quarters ahead.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
UMS chairman and chief executive Andy Luong said that while near term conditions for the semiconductor industry may remain cloudy, he expects the industry’s mid to longer-term prospects to brighten.
Shares of Frencken Group spiked on Tuesday (Aug 15) following the release of  half-year financial results for the semiconductor and machine manufacturer.
This came as Frencken books lower revenue and higher finance costs.
AEM Holdings' earnings plunged 76 per cent to S$19.7 million, on the back of an almost 50 per cent drop in revenue to S$275.2 million.

site_title: Oil rises to highest in 2023 on tight supply expectations
summary: Oil prices reached their highest point in 2023, with Brent crude rising 1.98% to $93.70, its highest since November 2022. US West Texas Intermediate crude also surged 1.85% to $90.16. Tight supply expectations outweighed concerns about weaker economic growth and rising US crude inventories. The price increase is attributed to OPEC's trimming of oil demand for the next four years.

images.alt_text: The Laura will help reduce its CO2 emissions by 100 tonnes a day, compared with the same vessel running on fuel oil.
International benchmark Brent futures dipped 18 cents to settle at US$91.88 a barrel on Wednesday.

site_title: LHN posts 85-100% occupancy rates for 3 co-living sites in Singapore
summary: LHN Limited, a Singapore-based real estate management services group, reported high occupancy rates of 85-100% for three co-living sites in Singapore as of September 7. The group manages 2,064 keys across its co-living projects in Singapore and overseas, with average rental rates ranging from S$2,200 to S$3,500. LHN has secured new contracts and launched car park projects, and has signed a 15-year power purchase agreement to install a solar photovoltaic system on a building's rooftop, expected to be operational by end-October.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
LHN executive chairman and group managing director Kelvin Lim is gunning for Coliwoo to have 10,000 rooms by 2030, which he says can be achieved through market consolidation or overseas acquisitions.
LHN believes the transfer of the company to the mainboard is "timely and appropriate", given its growth, relative stability and market position.

site_title: Belgium assessing Apple iPhone 12 after France halts sales over radiation
summary: Belgium is reviewing potential health risks linked to Apple's iPhone 12 after France halted sales due to radiation exposure limits. The European Commission will wait for feedback from other EU countries before deciding on any action. Apple contests the French findings, citing certification from multiple international bodies. Researchers have found no adverse health effects from mobile phone use. European standards are cautious, and experts say there are no immediate safety concerns.

images.alt_text: The ANFR said it “ordered Apple to remove the iPhone 12 from the French market from Sept 12 due to the model exceeding the limit” for electromagnetic absorption by the body.

site_title: Disney to cut target for Disney+ streaming subscribers
summary: Walt Disney Co. is expected to fall short of its 2024 target for Disney+ subscribers, with estimates ranging from 10-40 million subscribers short, according to people familiar with the matter. The decline is attributed to price increases and collapsing demand in India after failing to win cricket streaming rights. Despite this, Disney has narrowed its losses in its streaming division and raised prices to reach profitability. The company has also announced a deal with Charter Communications to package Disney+ with Spectrum TV, adding millions of new customers.

images.alt_text: Lucasfilm sold its Sandcrawler building in Singapore to US private equity giant Blackstone Group in 2021. It once served as its regional headquarters.
Walt Disney CEO Bob Iger sparks industry buzz about company's television business not being core.
Since the launch of Disney+ in November 2019, the world’s largest entertainment company had sought to attract streaming subscribers with unsustainably low prices.

site_title: A tale of two car brands for Tan Chong in Singapore
summary: Tan Chong International, a Hong Kong-listed car distributor, reported improved sales for Nissan in Singapore, with the brand becoming the fifth best-selling passenger car brand in the country. Nissan's e-Power range saw a 24% year-on-year rise in sales volume, driven by its expanding electrified line-up. In contrast, Subaru's sales volume in Singapore dropped 5% due to challenges from tight COE supply. Tan Chong expects total industry volume to increase in the second half of the year, driven by a larger COE supply.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Toyota topped overall passenger car registration figures for Singapore with 2,867 units in the first six months of 2023.
“Global markets are now flooded with cheaper Chinese electric cars. And their price is kept artificially low by huge state subsidies,” says EU Commission President Ursula von der Leyen.

site_title: Sustainable sojourns in Switzerland
summary: Switzerland is transforming into a beacon of sustainable tourism, with its nationwide "Swisstainable" strategy aiming to preserve natural landscapes. The country's iconic destinations, such as the Matterhorn, Lucerne, Zermatt, and Geneva, offer eco-friendly experiences, including car-free towns, electric transportation, and farm-to-table cuisine. Visitors can explore pristine wilderness, enjoy panoramic views, and experience world-class art and culture. As Switzerland works towards becoming climate-neutral by 2050, its sustainable tourism efforts make it a model for environmentally conscious travel, showcasing a harmonious coexistence between humans and nature.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: SoftBank’s Arm soars nearly 25% in market debut to US$65 billion valuation
summary: Arm Holdings, a British chip designer, made its market debut with a 24.68% gain, reaching a valuation of $65 billion. The IPO, priced at $51, saw the stock close at $63.59, exceeding expectations. The strong performance suggests a rebound in the IPO market, which has been hit by geopolitical tensions and higher interest rates. The debut is seen as a positive sign for the IPO pipeline, with several companies scheduled to go public in coming weeks, potentially triggering a wave of stock market launches in 2024.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Arm CEO Rene Haas rings the opening bell, as Softbank's Arm, chip design firm, holds an initial public offering (IPO) at Nasdaq Market site in New York, U.S., September 14, 2023. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo

site_title: Omega debuts new watches for the adventure traveller
summary: Omega has introduced three new watches in its Seamaster Aqua Terra line, designed for adventure travelers. The Worldtimer features a unique globe display and is available in three versions, including a sporty chronograph with a quick-change strap mechanism. The Ultra Light watch is ultra-light, weighing just 55 grams, and features a telescopic crown. The America's Cup chronograph is versatile and water-resistant to 300 meters, with a quick-change strap mechanism and a special box presentation.

site_title: Amazon ‘going big’ to fill delivery void left by Shopify
summary: Amazon is expanding its services to fill a logistics void left by Shopify's withdrawal from shipping services. The e-commerce giant's Buy With Prime offers fast delivery and other benefits to customers, attracting new shoppers to online brands. Since its introduction last year, Buy With Prime has boosted sales conversions by 25% and seen three-quarters of its purchases come from new customers familiar with the Amazon experience. Amazon aims to capitalize on this trend and increase its revenue.

images.alt_text: Amazon has provided some US$1.7 billion to create or preserve affordable rental units as part of a US$2 billion initiative launched two years ago.

site_title: Group behind casino hacks skilled at duping workers for access
summary: A hacking group known as Scattered Spider and UNC3944 has been linked to cyberattacks on MGM Resorts International and Caesars Entertainment Inc. The group uses social engineering tactics to trick workers into granting access to computer systems, and has been known to deploy ransomware. Members of the group, based in the US and UK, are estimated to be fewer than 10 people, mostly friends, and have been involved in hacking since they were 11 years old. The group's motive is to get rich quickly and avoid detection, and has been linked to the ALPHV ransomware group, which has been used in at least 60 attacks worldwide.

images.alt_text: MGM Resorts was the victim of a July 2019 data breach that exposed the personal information of as many as 10.6 million customers.

site_title: US: Stocks close higher as Arm shares surge on debut
summary: US stocks closed higher on Thursday as the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1.0% to 34,907.11, driven by strong retail sales figures and the successful debut of chip designer Arm, which surged 25% on its IPO. Retail sales exceeded expectations, with US wholesale prices also increasing as demand for energy surged. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also advanced 0.8% and 0.8% respectively, with Arm's IPO netting SoftBank around US$5 billion.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - AUGUST 25: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange during morning trading on August 25, 2023 in New York City. Stocks opened up higher as Wall Street awaits a speech from Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell’s at the Jackson Hole Economic Symposium.   Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Michael M. Santiago / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Mortgage rates in US increase for first time in three weeks
summary: US mortgage rates rose for the first time in three weeks, increasing to 7.18% for a 30-year, fixed loan, according to Freddie Mac. This uptick follows a five-week decline and further squeezes affordability, with potential buyers facing high rates and low inventory. The Federal Reserve's efforts to tame inflation may not be over, as underlying inflation data in August showed a faster-than-expected pace. Borrowers are now spending more on their mortgages, with a $600,000 loan costing $4,065 per month, a 56% increase from 2022.

site_title: G77+China summit in Cuba seeks ‘new economic world order’
summary: The G77+China summit in Cuba aims to promote a "new economic world order" amid growing global polarization. Representing 80% of the global population, the bloc seeks to address obstacles to development and promote collective economic interests. UN chief Antonio Guterres and over 30 heads of state will attend the two-day summit, concluding with a statement on the right to development in an increasingly exclusive international order. The meeting follows a series of multilateral summits, including the G20 and BRICS gatherings, and comes as Cuba faces its worst economic crisis in 30 years.

images.alt_text: Men walk near a sign of the G 77 + China Summit during the inauguration of the press room in Havana, on September 13, 2023. (Photo by YAMIL LAGE / AFP)

site_title: Mile & Apo: It takes two to triumph
summary: Thai actors Mile and Apo, stars of the hit series "KinnPorsche," have catapulted to global fame after their show became a global sensation, watched by millions worldwide. The mafia-themed series, which features a gay plot, has been a hit in Europe, North and South America, and Asia. The duo, who have risen from relative obscurity, have become the new ambassadors of Dior, and have released a new film, "Man Suang," which has received critical acclaim. They attribute their success to the changing global audience's willingness to embrace stories from different parts of the world and their own chemistry on-screen.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: US business inventories unchanged in July
summary: US business inventories remained unchanged in July, following a 0.1% dip in June, contrary to economists' expectations of a 0.1% increase. Inventories rose 1.4% year-over-year, but companies continued to manage their stock levels due to weak demand and higher interest rates. This cautious approach suggests a continued slowdown in the US economy.

site_title: President Tharman pledges to strengthen Singapore’s unity in a troubled world
summary: President Tharman Shanmugaratnam has pledged to strengthen Singapore's unity and inclusivity, vowing to promote multiracialism and build a strong culture of kinship and respect. He aims to foster greater interactions between communities, support disadvantaged groups, and lend active support to the arts and sports. Tharman also plans to be cautious with the country's reserves and balance meeting immediate needs with preserving them for future generations. As the country navigates a troubled world, he seeks to add depth and resilience to Singapore's multiracialism and promote its values and interests abroad.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Tessa Oh
Tharman swarmed by media and supporters at the Taman Jurong Hawker Centre ST PHOTO: SHINTARO TAY
President Tharman Shanmugaratnam has all the "vital prerequsites" for being president, said Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong during the former's swearing-in ceremony at the Istana on Thursday (Sep 14).
President Tharman Shanmugaratnam took 70.4 per cent of the votes in the presidential election, securing a landslide victory against two other hopefuls, Ng Kok Song and Tan Kin Lian.

site_title: Newly sworn-in President Tharman to play ‘important symbolic role’ in unifying Singapore: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's newly sworn-in President Tharman Shanmugaratnam is set to play a "symbolic role" in unifying the country, according to Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. Tharman received 70.41% of the vote, making him the most qualified candidate for the position, according to PM Lee. The election outcome is seen as a positive step for unity, with a decrease in racial bias and a greater understanding of the president's roles and duties. PM Lee pledged the government's support for Tharman's custodial duties and diplomatic role, and welcomed his wife to her new role.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
President Tharman Shanmugaratnam took 70.4 per cent of the votes in the presidential election, securing a landslide victory against two other hopefuls, Ng Kok Song and Tan Kin Lian.

Tharman Shanmugaratnam's resounding victory suggests that voters did indeed take a non-partisan view – which makes it hard to make any assumptions about sentiment ahead of the upcoming general elections.
Tharman Shanmugaratnam insisted he had always been independent-minded and never politically partisan, but he also highlighted the experience he had gained from his government roles
Tharman swarmed by media and supporters at the Taman Jurong Hawker Centre ST PHOTO: SHINTARO TAY

site_title: European Central Bank raises rates for a 10th time
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) raised interest rates for the 10th consecutive time, with the deposit rate increasing to 4%, the highest in the bank's two-decade history. The move aims to control inflation, which remains above the target of 2%. Despite slowing inflation, policymakers believe interest rates need to be maintained for a long period to achieve the target. The decision was seen as a cautious approach, with no clear indication of future rate cuts.

images.alt_text: Whether to raise borrowing costs for a 10th straight time in Thursday's ECB meeting is shaping up to be rate-setters’ trickiest decision.
Expectations for the next 12 months decline to 3.4 per cent from 3.9 per cent in May, the ECB says in its monthly survey.
The recent easing is mainly driven by non-energy industrial goods, the ECB writes in a pre-release of its economic bulletin.

site_title: Pakistan central bank leaves key rate unchanged in surprise move
summary: Pakistan's central bank kept its key interest rate unchanged at 22% in a surprise move, defying analyst expectations of a rate hike. The bank expects significant inflation spike in September, but a decline in October, with a continued downward trend. The decision comes as the country navigates a crisis-ridden economic situation, including rising inflation and dwindling foreign exchange reserves.

site_title: Lim Wenhui: Where globetrotting meets good design
summary: Lim Wenhui, founding director of Singapore-based Spark Architects, draws inspiration from her globetrotting experiences for her sustainable design projects. Her eclectic travel list includes notable sights in Japan, Europe, and New Zealand, which have influenced her work on projects such as the revitalized Starhill Gallery and GR.iD youth social hub. Lim's unique approach to design combines wide tastes and a passion for sustainability, resulting in innovative and visually striking structures that blend functionality with artistic expression. Her travels continue to inspire her work, pushing the boundaries of sustainable design.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: US wholesale prices rise more than expected in August
summary: US wholesale prices rose 0.7% in August, exceeding expectations, driven by a 2.0% surge in energy costs. The increase in energy prices is attributed to higher demand and contributes to the overall impact on consumers and producers. This rise in the producer price index (PPI) follows a revised 0.4% increase in July.

images.alt_text: Labor Department shows initial claims for state unemployment benefits rose to a seasonally adjusted 220,000 for the week ended Sep 9 from 217,000 the prior week.

site_title: Aluminium sector surging in India, but hampered by labour shortages
summary: India's aluminium sector is experiencing a surge in demand, driven by growing consumption and investment in infrastructure. The country is set to become the world's second-largest aluminium producer and third-largest consumer, with demand expected to double over the next decade. However, the sector faces challenges such as labour shortages, project approvals, and quality standards. Despite these issues, India's aluminium demand is expected to jump to 9 million metric tons by 2033, driven by a growing economy and increasing consumption. The private sector must step up efforts to train skilled workers to meet this growing demand.

images.alt_text: The departure, just two years into Liu’s tenure as chairman of Chalco.

site_title: Yusuke Shibata: Crafting connections through travel and tableware
summary: Yusuke Shibata, founder of Huls Gallery, was inspired by traditional Japanese craftsmanship during a 2014 visit to the Shussai pottery factory in Shimane Prefecture. Impressed by the potters' skill and dedication, he decided to open a gallery in Singapore to showcase handmade Japanese crafts, including pottery, ceramics, and lacquerware. Shibata's gallery aims to connect people with Japan's rich cultural heritage, transcending centuries and bridging the past and present. The gallery features a range of artisanal crafts, allowing customers to experience the essence of centuries-old Japanese culture.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: A seafaring journey through Japan
summary: A Silversea cruise aboard the Silver Muse circumnavigates Japan's island of Honshu, visiting prefectures and cities such as Osaka, Kagoshima, Niigata, Aomori, and Kanazawa. The 14-day journey showcases unique experiences, including flag performances, fireworks displays, and local festivals. The luxury cruise offers excursions, English-speaking guides, and a range of dining options. Silversea's newest ship, Silver Nova, is also introduced, featuring eco-friendly design and sustainable practices, including liquefied natural gas power and zero emissions.

images.alt_text: Berlin is linked by an extensive network of waterways. Museum Island buildings are at the far end, with Berlin Cathedral and the Berlin TV Tower on the right.

site_title: Hong Kong police investigating crypto exchange JPEX
summary: Hong Kong police are investigating cryptocurrency exchange JPEX after the city's securities regulator accused the platform of "suspicious" activities and promoting unlicensed products. The Securities and Futures Commission warned JPEX has not applied for or received a license, despite advertising itself as a "licensed and recognized platform." This comes after Hong Kong rolled out new rules requiring all crypto exchanges to acquire licenses and be subject to investor protection measures. The police are looking into whether criminal acts were involved.

images.alt_text: Retail investors are restricted to larger coins like Bitcoin and Ether that feature in at least two acceptable, investible indexes.
Hong Kong used to be a digital-asset center in earlier years before taking a more skeptical stance.
The remarks come after Circle received a licence as a major payments institution in Singapore.
Three Arrows Capital co-founders Kyle Livingston Davies (pictured) and Zhu Su have been issued nine-year prohibition orders by MAS.
The company and committees representing both US and foreign creditors have agreed that FTX should sell as much as US$100 million of crypto a week, depending on the market prices.
Tighter regulations generally have prompted many traditional financial institutions to hold back on offering cash to crypto services and vice versa, says Binance CEO Changpeng ‘CZ’ Zhao.
Binance Holdings has been shedding executives and other employees in recent months as well.
If approved, Franklin plans to use Coinbase Global as custodian for the fund’s Bitcoin holdings and Bank of New York Mellon for cash.
The yen has come under immense pressure against the US dollar as a result of growing interest rate differentials with the US.

site_title: China gold premium hits record as Beijing defends yuan
summary: China's gold premium on the Shanghai Gold Exchange reached a record high of over $120 an ounce, driven by a weak yuan and the central bank's efforts to defend the currency. The premium is the highest since the exchange's founding over two decades ago. Beijing has intervened by limiting gold shipments and squeezing import quotas to stem the slide in the currency, which has been driven by disappointing economic data and real estate turmoil. This move is part of the central bank's efforts to diverge monetary policy from the rest of the world.

images.alt_text: US gold futures were up 0.1 per cent at US$1,933.70.

site_title: Higher petrol prices lift US retail sales in August; weekly jobless claims rise slightly
summary: US retail sales rose 0.6% in August, boosted by higher petrol prices, despite underlying spending on goods slowing due to high inflation. Retail sales at petrol stations rebounded 5.2% after declining 10.3% in July. Excluding petrol stations, retail sales rose 0.2%. The data suggests solid growth in overall consumer spending this quarter, but dimming outlooks due to excess savings being run down and rising credit card balances. The Federal Reserve is expected to keep interest rates unchanged next week, and the economy's resilience is underscored by the tight labour market.

images.alt_text: The contract rate on an adjustable mortgage increases by more than a quarter of a percentage point to 6.59 per cent, the highest in Mortgage Bankers Association (MBA) data back to early 2011.

The White House has asked Congress to swiftly vote on a budget extension to avoid a government shutdown, which could paralyse nearly the entire federal government.

The National Association of Realtors (NAR) housing affordability index is unchanged at 87.8 in July, matching the lowest level in data back to 1989.
Initial claims for state unemployment benefits fall to 216,000 in the week ended Sep 2 from a revised 229,000 the week before, according to the Labor Department.
The US economy has shown signs of resiliency in recent months despite an aggressive campaign of interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve to tackle high inflation.

site_title: Detroit Three strike deadline nears as sides remain far apart
summary: US automakers and the United Auto Workers (UAW) union remain far apart on contract negotiations, with a strike deadline looming. The UAW plans a series of strikes targeting individual US plants if no deal is reached, potentially impacting US economic growth. The union is seeking 40% pay raises and major benefits improvements, while the automakers have offered up to 20% raises over 4.5 years. A full strike could hit earnings by $400-500 million per week and pose political problems for President Biden.

images.alt_text: United Auto Workers union members gather for a rally after marching in a parade on Sep 4, 2023. The union is in contract negotiations with Ford, General Motors, and Stellantis, and the current UAW contract expires on Sep 14.
A week long strike could shave off US$480 million from GM’s earnings

site_title: Maersk unveils world's first bio-methanol container ship
summary: Maersk, the world's largest container shipping company, has launched the world's first container ship running on bio-methanol, a key step in its effort to lower its massive carbon footprint. The ship, named Laura, is expected to reduce CO2 emissions by 100 tonnes a day, compared to fuel oil, and will begin operating in the Baltic Sea in October. Maersk aims to become carbon neutral by 2040 and has ordered 25 vessels that run on green methanol, with plans to produce the fuel in five or six sites worldwide.

images.alt_text: Maersk, which operates a fleet of about 700 container ships, is alone responsible for about 0.1 per cent of all human-made CO2 emissions.

site_title: Hong Kong launches glitzy nightlife campaign to boost spending
summary: Hong Kong launches "Night Vibes Hong Kong" campaign to boost nightlife spending, featuring evening bazaars and special events at waterfront locations and popular attractions. The move aims to revitalize the city's economy, which has been stagnant due to years of pandemic isolation and a surge in the Hong Kong US dollar against the yuan. However, experts say the campaign is a short-term fix for industry structural issues, and the city's tourism industry remains stalled. Retail spending remains low, with growth projected at 4% this year, down from an earlier median estimate.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong’s government has launched a slew of initiatives that fuel the demand for student housing and rental properties.
Hong Kong now accounts for about 10 per cent of Gaw’s portfolio, while mainland China assets have dropped to about 25 per cent of the total.
The economy is also facing challenges from China’s slowing momentum, soft global demand and the potential for local spending habits to taper off.

site_title: Thai central bank chief urges new government to focus on fiscal stability
summary: Thailand's central bank chief, Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput, urged the new government to prioritize fiscal stability, warning that policies aimed at easing the cost of living and boosting consumption could "overly affect stability" and cause unwanted side effects. The Bank of Thailand Governor emphasized the need for fiscal discipline and targeted debt suspension to preserve the budget. He also stated that the central bank will review its policy on September 27, with the current interest rate at 2.25% close to a neutral level that supports sustainable economic growth and inflation control.

images.alt_text: Thailand's Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin and his cabinet members pose for a group photo at the government house after a royal audience ceremony to swear the oath of allegiance in Bangkok, Thailand, September 5, 2023. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha

site_title: Tudor revives a classic chronograph
summary: Tudor has revived its classic Prince Chronograph One, a one-off production made for the Only Watch 2023 charity auction, featuring a new prototype chronograph movement developed from scratch. The watch boasts a 42mm yellow gold case and black lacquered dial, with a 70-hour power reserve and accuracy rate of minus two and plus four seconds per day. This marks a forward-looking execution of the vintage Big Block chronograph design, showcasing Tudor's capabilities in producing cutting-edge movements.

site_title: China cuts reserve requirement ratio for second time this year
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), lowered the reserve requirement ratio for most banks by 25 basis points, reducing the weighted average ratio to 7.4%. The move aims to bolster an economic recovery struggling to rebound. It is the second reserve requirement ratio cut this year, aimed at maintaining reasonably ample liquidity and supporting economic growth.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The headquarters of the People's Bank of China, the central bank, is pictured in Beijing, China, February 3, 2020. REUTERS/Jason Lee/File Photo

site_title: Euro down as ECB hikes interest rates to quash inflation
summary: The euro fell 0.7% to US$1.0656, its weakest since May, after the European Central Bank raised interest rates by 25 basis points to 4%, aiming to control inflation. The move comes amid steady US inflation data and a day after the Federal Reserve is expected to keep interest rates steady next week. The US dollar rose against the yuan, while the Australian dollar rose after a jobs report beat expectations.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Euro banknotes are seen in this illustration taken July 17, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Cedric Grolet: A pastry chef with a passion for fruit
summary: French pastry chef Cedric Grolet opened his Singapore store on September 14, 2023, as part of the COMO Group's new flagship, COMO Orchard. Grolet, 38, is known for his hyper-real fruit desserts and has eight million followers on Instagram. His reputation was built on reducing sugar in his creations while retaining natural fruit flavors. The Singapore store will feature unique pastries with tropical fruits and shapes like mooncake and dragon fruit, showcasing Grolet's artisanal approach to pastry-making. The store aims to offer a distinct experience, with a focus on sustainability and quality.

images.alt_text: Sonia Cheng is no flash in the pan, and has grown the Rosewood brand into a portfolio of 31 hotels and resorts globally.

site_title: China to avoid ‘Lehman moment’ despite property woes, Goldman says
summary: China's government is taking steps to avoid a financial crisis similar to the 2008 Lehman Brothers collapse, with Goldman Sachs' chief economist Jan Hatzius saying Beijing will provide financial support for banks and affected sectors. China's slowdown has rattled global markets, with developer Country Garden's debt crisis a major concern. However, Hatzius notes that China's economic growth will slow due to demographic factors, and the US economy is expected to avoid a recession this year. Goldman Sachs forecasts three rate cuts next year, citing improving consumer spending.

images.alt_text: Scaffolding surrounds an unfinished residential building at Evergrande Cultural Tourism City, a China Evergrande Group project whose construction has halted, in Suzhou's Taicang, Jiangsu province, China October 22, 2021. REUTERS/Aly Song

site_title: World needs US$2.7 trillion annually for net-zero emissions by 2050: Wood Mackenzie
summary: A report by Wood Mackenzie says the world needs an annual investment of $2.7 trillion by 2050 to achieve net-zero emissions and avoid a 1.5°C temperature rise. This is a 150% increase from the current $1.9 trillion needed to decarbonize the energy sector. To achieve this, renewables like wind and solar power must become the main source of power supply, and oil and gas must be managed as part of a transition to net-zero. Without this investment, global temperatures are likely to rise by 2.5°C by 2050.

images.alt_text: PT Indo Raya Tenaga, the developer of the Suralaya plants, has said it plans to power some of the new capacity with ammonia, along with coal, to reduce emissions.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's labour demand is set to ease further in the rest of 2023, according to the Ministry of Manpower's Labour Market Report. Employment growth and job vacancies moderated in Q2, leading to a fall in resident employment due to the end of seasonal hiring in food and beverage services and retail trade. This moderation is expected to continue, easing labour demand further this year.

site_title: Accused Su Haijin linked to £43 million purchase of London buildings
summary: A company linked to accused money launderer Su Haijin purchased two London buildings for £43.3 million (S$73.5m) in 2021. Su Haijin, a Singaporean national, faces charges of money laundering and resisting arrest. The company, New Yihao, is registered in a tax haven and lists Su Haijin as a beneficial owner. Authorities have seized over S$170 million in assets from Su Haijin and his wife, and have also linked another accused, Lin Baoying, to a luxury London apartment purchase.

images.alt_text: The 10 accused in the case.
Industry players and observers that spoke to BT said the police bust – the largest AML operation in Singapore’s history – should be viewed in a positive light.
The police seized cash and luxury items, and issued prohibition of disposal orders against ornaments and cars as part of an islandwide raid.
Su Haijin has been denied bail and will return to court on Oct 11.
Major authorised car dealers have anti-money laundering measures in place, but parallel imports and used cars offer more leeway for money laundering due to less scrutiny.
The 10 accused are citizens of seven different jurisdictions, including Cambodia. They are believed to have all originated from China.

In one of the biggest anti-money laundering operations in Singapore, the Singapore Police Force (SPF) rounded up a group of foreigners who had amassed about $1.8 billion worth of assets in the city-state.
DPM Heng Swee Keat speaking with moderator Justin Doebele at a dialogue session during the Forbes Global CEO Conference at Shangri-La Singapore on Sep 11.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as Fed pause bets remain unchanged after economic data
summary: Wall Street opened higher on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 111.97 points, or 0.32%, to 34,687.50. Despite hotter-than-expected economic data, investors remained optimistic about a possible pause in rate hikes in September. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher, with gains of 20.34 points, or 0.46%, and 76.17 points, or 0.55%, respectively. The market awaited the debut of Arm Holdings' stock market listing.

site_title: Beijing blasts EU probe as protectionist as China EV maker stocks slide
summary: China has blasted the European Commission's probe into its electric vehicle subsidies as "naked protectionist" and warned it will harm economic and trade relations. The probe, which could result in punitive tariffs, comes amid strained ties between the EU and China. Chinese EV maker stocks have slid, with Hong Kong-listed BYD falling over 3%, as analysts warn of retaliatory action from Beijing. The EU accuses China of flooding global markets with electric cars at artificially low prices due to huge state subsidies.

images.alt_text: Tackling China’s subsidies – even if proven – will also not change the view that Chinese vehicles are technologically advanced and Europe’s carmakers have been slow to adapt and innovate.

site_title: Building a dream home in Bali
summary: Architect Ian Chee, founder of VX Design, has built a dream home in Bali's Saba Beach, utilizing natural materials and traditional Balinese village designs. Chee, who has been drawn to the island since the early 2000s, purchased 4,750 square meters of freehold land and developed three modernist villas, caSabama, which function as holiday rentals. The villas, designed with open living spaces and generous areas, average 30-35% occupancy rates year-round, covering staff and maintenance costs. Chee plans to expand caSabama with a new "party house" venue, catering to larger gatherings and events.

site_title: Asia-Pacific family offices least likely to have investment committees, survey finds
summary: A survey by Citi Private Bank's Global Family Office Group found that family offices in the Asia-Pacific region are the least likely to have investment committees, with 45% of respondents not having one. In contrast, 65% of Latin American family offices and 57% of EMEA offices have such committees. Additionally, nearly a quarter (24%) of Asia-Pacific family offices have not separated from their family businesses, compared to 19% in North America. The survey also found that preserving asset value is the top concern for families in the region, with 74% citing it as a priority.

images.alt_text: Navene Elangovan
With multi-generational time horizons and associated long-term pools of capital, family offices are able to play the long game.
Family offices have traditionally been used by the business magnates behind major companies such as Walmart, Johnson & Johnson, Cargill and Kering.

The logo of Citigroup Inc. at the entrance to the bank's office in Paris, France, on Monday, Feb. 27, 2023. Citigroup is building a new trading floor in Paris as the Wall Street giant prepares to nearly double its staff in the French city. Photographer Benjamin Girette/Bloomberg

site_title: Luxury sector ratings cut at Barclays, Deutsche Bank on China woes
summary: Barclays and Deutsche Bank have cut their luxury sector ratings due to concerns over disappointing sales growth in China, which may weigh on stock prices. Barclays analyst Carole Madjo lowered her recommendation on LVMH to equal-weight from overweight, while Deutsche Bank downgraded consumer products due to luxury companies' exposure to China. The analysts attribute the sector's decline to deteriorating macro indicators from China and a return to normalised growth.

images.alt_text: LVMH says sales come to 21.2 billion euros (S$31.1 billion) for the three months to the end of June.
Kering last year saw sales rise nine per cent on a comparable basis, with Gucci’s sales edging up only one per cent.

site_title: Patek Philippe travels in style
summary: Patek Philippe has released several new travel watches, including the Calatrava 24-Hour Display Travel Time Reference 5224R-001, which features a 24-hour dial with two central hands tracking home and local time, and the Calatrava Pilot Travel Time Chronograph Ref 5924G, a pilot-style watch with a chronograph and dual time zone display. The watches are designed for jetsetters and are powered by in-house micro rotor automatic movements. With prices ranging from $76,400 to $100,800, the watches cater to various tastes and preferences, offering a unique blend of style and functionality.

site_title: Globetrotter appeal
summary: Rolex has unveiled two new versions of the Oyster Perpetual GMT-Master II and Oyster Perpetual Sky-Dweller watches, catering to globetrotters and travellers. The GMT-Master II features a two-colour, 24-hour graduated monobloc bezel insert in grey and black ceramic, while the Sky-Dweller boasts a new movement, calibre 9002, with a 72-hour power reserve. The new Sky-Dweller models also include a blue-green dial in 18 ct Everose gold and a black dial in 18 ct white gold. Prices range from S$21,850 to S$59,600.

images.alt_text:
pmluxerolex14b - Rolex's Sky-Dweller in Everose gold and a blue-green dial.



Credit: ROLEX
Oyster Perpetual GMT-Master II

site_title: South Korea’s central bank warns of overpriced housing market, excessive debt
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea, has warned of an overvalued housing market, citing a high house price-to-income ratio of 26, which is more than double the median ratio of other countries. Housing prices remain high despite income levels, and household debt has continued to increase, posing a risk to macroeconomic and financial stability. The bank's warning comes as housing prices rose in July after a year-long decline.

site_title: Rolex celebrates racing milestones
summary: Rolex is celebrating the 60th anniversary of its iconic Oyster Perpetual Cosmograph Daytona chronograph watch and the 100th year of the Le Mans 24-hour endurance race. To mark these milestones, Rolex has unveiled five new versions of the watch, including a platinum model, 18 ct Everose gold piece, and yellow Rolesor model. The new Cosmograph Daytona features a revised case design, improved movement, and new finishes. A special edition, the "Le Mans" Cosmograph Daytona, is also available, featuring a 72-hour power reserve and a unique movement inspired by the legendary race.

site_title: Iron ore futures near 6-month high on low stocks, pre-holiday restocking
summary: Iron ore futures rose for a fourth consecutive session, reaching a 6-month high of $120.35 a ton, driven by low inventories and pre-holiday restocking. Benchmark October iron ore on the Singapore Exchange gained 0.78% and January iron ore on China's Dalian Commodity Exchange rose 0.82%. Analysts attribute the price increase to solid demand from steelmakers and expected restocking. However, downside risks to prices remain due to concerns about lingering steel market weakness in peak construction season.

images.alt_text: Iron ore pellets in the yard at the Lebedinsky GOK iron ore mining and processing plant, operated by Metalloinvest Holding Co., in Gubkin, Russia, on Thursday, Nov. 25, 2021. Iron ore prices rebounded from last week’s pandemic-driven losses on bets the impact of a new coronavirus variant may not be as severe as initially feared. Photographer: Andrey Rudakov/Bloomberg

site_title: Singapore stocks rise as US inflation data stays within expectations; STI up 1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 1% to 3,249.51 points, driven by a regional rally, as major Asian markets also ended in the black. US inflation data, which rose 0.6% in August, was within expectations, supporting the market. The top gainers were DBS and UOB, with DBS rising 1.6% and UOB 1.3%, while Frasers Logistics and Commercial Trust was the only loser, shedding 0.9%.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
SGX logo in front of the SGX Centre building at Shenton Way.
The US dollar index, which tracks the currency against six peers including the yen, euro, and sterling, holds firm, though moves are subdued, up 0.13 percent to 104.73.

A nozzle is replaced on a fuel dispenser at a gas station in La Puente, California, on September 7, 2023. US gas prices this week hit the highest levels in a decade as the summer holiday season winds down, with rising crude-oil prices a likely contributing factor to higher gas prices. (Photo by Frederic J. BROWN / AFP)

site_title: Singapore’s 6-month T-bill yield bounces up to 3.73%
summary: Singapore's 6-month T-bill yield rose to 3.73% in its latest issue, rebounding from last month's low of 3.7%. Demand for the tranche was unchanged at S$11.2 billion, with a bid-to-cover ratio of 2.03. This is higher than the 2.99% posted in September last year. Senior rates strategist Eugene Leow expects the interest rate to remain at these levels for the immediate few months, with only modest upside risks if the Fed hikes again.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
FILE PHOTO: U.S. One dollar banknotes are seen in front of displayed stock graph in this illustration taken, February 8, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
The latest tranche of SSBs, which opened on Sep 4, offers a first-year interest rate of 3.05 per cent; the interest rate at the 10-year mark is 3.48 per cent.

site_title: Singapore adopts conservative crypto policy following FTX collapse, Binance CEO says
summary: Singapore has adopted a conservative approach to cryptocurrency following the collapse of FTX, according to Binance CEO Changpeng 'CZ' Zhao. The country's regulations, while not overly restrictive, have prompted traditional financial institutions to be cautious about offering crypto services. Despite this, Singapore remains crypto-friendly overall, with Zhao noting that new exchanges are emerging. Binance, the world's largest crypto exchange, has seen its share of digital-asset trading decline and is facing mounting legal and operational challenges, including job cuts.

site_title: Grand Seiko’s latest watches capture the beauty of Japan’s mountain ranges
summary: Grand Seiko has released a new line of watches inspired by Japan's natural landscapes, starting with the triple-time-zone Spring Drive GMT SBGE295, which is inspired by Mount Hotaka. The watch features a 44mm stainless steel case with a Zaratsu finish and a 24-hour chapter ring, GMT hand, and rotating bezel. The brand's Evolution 9 collection also includes the high-intensity titanium "Lake Suwa" SLGA019 and the mechanical Tentagraph SLGC001, both of which reflect Nagano's natural beauty.

site_title: China stocks end flat; auto shares pare losses after EU anti-subsidy probe
summary: China's blue-chip CSI 300 Index and the Shanghai Composite Index closed flat, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index edged up 0.2%. Auto stocks trimmed losses after the European Union's anti-subsidy probe into Chinese electric vehicles. The EU has vowed to maintain its competitive edge, with EU Commission chief Ursula von der Leyen declaring "whatever it takes". Investors await policy measures and signs of economic recovery.

images.alt_text: Tackling China’s subsidies – even if proven – will also not change the view that Chinese vehicles are technologically advanced and Europe’s carmakers have been slow to adapt and innovate.
