“Global markets are now flooded with cheaper Chinese electric cars. And their price is kept artificially low by huge state subsidies,” says EU Commission President Ursula von der Leyen.

site_title: SGX revamps organisation, names Michael Syn president and global markets head
summary: SGX revamps its organisation with Michael Syn as new president and global markets head, effective October 1. Syn, who has held roles since 2011, will oversee all business lines except indices, covering equities, fixed income, currencies, and commodities. The new structure aims to capitalise on Asia's growing capital flows and develop a multi-asset offering. Lee Beng Hong leads the newly formed wholesale markets and platforms division, while Ng Yao Loong oversees indices development and Tinku Gupta becomes chief information officer. The changes aim to enhance service delivery and create new solutions for customers.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
The fund — which was a collaboration between BlackRock, SGX and the MSCI –  has assets under management of US$426 million.
SGX derivatives daily average volume climbed up 7 per cent to 1 million contracts in August, with broad-base gains across foreign exchange (FX), commodities, and equities.
Profits of property developers and brokers were underwhelming due to a lack of divestment gains, slower monetisation activities and reduced market transaction volumes.

site_title: Singapore reaping rising investment from India, China, South-east Asia: EDB
summary: Singapore has seen increased investments from India, China, and South-east Asia, with the country's semiconductor sector being a major driver. Despite this, the Economic Development Board (EDB) expects a muted 2023 in terms of investments, following a record 2022. The EDB is focusing on green finance and renewable energy investments, with a goal of increasing green finance investments. Singapore currently accounts for 11% of the global semiconductor market and 20% of global semiconductor equipment manufactured in the country.

site_title: Vietnam’s top tech company FPT eyes AI, chips growth, no immediate plans for US IPO
summary: Vietnam's top tech company FPT is expanding its artificial intelligence and chip designing capabilities, with orders for nearly 70 million chips until 2025. Chairman Truong Gia Binh sees opportunities in the semiconductors sector, particularly with the US Chips Act, and is exploring partnerships with US companies like Nvidia. FPT has no immediate plans for a US IPO, but aims to multiply its US revenues to $1 billion by 2030. The company is also investing in education services, aiming to fill the training gap in Vietnam's chips engineering workforce.

images.alt_text: Vietnam's VinFast is the first in South-east Asia to sell its car brand in the US.

site_title: DBS chief says China pessimism not 'overdone' but upbeat about India prospects
summary: DBS Group CEO Piyush Gupta expressed cautious optimism about China's economy, stating that current pessimism is "not overdone" but acknowledges "real headwinds" in its debt-ridden property sector. However, he noted that sectors like electric vehicles in China have strong growth prospects. Gupta is upbeat about India, where DBS plans to triple its business in the next five years, and expects net inflows to be "pretty strong" in its wealth management business.

images.alt_text: Witnessing the MOU signing were Piyush Gupta (first from left), CEO of DBS and Loh Chin Hua, CEO of Keppel; signing the MOU were Tan Su Shan (first seated from left), Group Institutional Banking, DBS and Louis Lim, CEO, Real Estate Division, Keppel.

site_title: Huawei flags product event, details about closely watched smartphones expected
summary: Huawei is set to hold a media event on September 25 to discuss new products, fueling expectations that details about recently released smartphones, including the Mate 60 series, will be revealed. The series marks Huawei's first major attempt to return to the smartphone market after crippling US sanctions. The company started selling the Mate 60 and Mate 60 Pro at the end of last month, and presales for the Mate 60 Pro+ and foldable phone Mate X5 have begun. The event will also likely address how Huawei's phones will compete with Apple in a time of heightened US-Sino tensions.

images.alt_text: The new iPhone 15 goes on sale online in China on Alibaba’s Tmall marketplace on Sep 15, and in-stores on Sep 22.
Adding to the pressure on Apple, Huawei on Friday launched two new smartphones – foldable phone Mate X5 and Mate 60 Pro+ smartphone, a new addition to a series it unveiled last week.

Nearly a week after the release of Mate 60 Pro by Huawei Technologies, a Chinese telecommunications giant that has been the target of US sanctions and export controls for years-there are still more questions than answers about its development and what comes next.
Huawei announced on its official online store that it would start taking orders for the new Mate 60 Pro smartphone from 10.08 am (0208 GMT) with delivery by Oct 9.

site_title: Malaysia says Asean is a winner from shifting supply chains
summary: Malaysia and the Association of South-east Asian Nations (Asean) are emerging as the biggest beneficiaries of supply chain realignment due to rising US-China tensions. Trade Minister Zafrul Abdul Aziz stated that the realignment has benefited the region, with Malaysia securing RM71.4 billion in approved investments in the first three months of 2023. The country is positioning itself as a neutral supply chain base, attracting companies such as Microsoft and Google, and has a plan to grow its manufacturing sector to boost its economy.

images.alt_text: Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim tabled the Mid-Term Review of the 12th Malaysia Plan in the Parliament on Monday (Sep 11).

site_title: Volkswagen eyes job cuts at key EV factory over cratering demand
summary: Volkswagen is cutting nearly 300 temporary workers at its Zwickau electric vehicle factory in Germany due to declining orders for its ID fleet of EVs in Europe. The move comes as economic growth slows and energy, living, and borrowing costs rise. The company hired 2,700 temporary workers to meet expected demand but orders from corporate clients have plummeted since a federal subsidy for battery-powered company vehicles expired. Volkswagen plans to reduce production and export EVs from China to Europe, amid a competitive landscape that includes Tesla, BMW, and other manufacturers.

images.alt_text: VW is busy implementing improvements aimed at turning around a slide in sales in China.
The partnership could help lower Xpeng’s EV production costs by leveraging Volkswagen’s scale and bargaining power in supply.
Other issues also weigh on Volkswagen’s stock market performance, from high capital costs and risks in China to concerns over its ability to maintain market dominance in an electric age.

site_title: Australian jobs surge but not enough to dent rate hold expectations
summary: Australia's jobless rate held steady at 3.7% in August, matching forecasts, while the participation rate surged to 67.0%, the highest since 2013. Employment surged 64,900, mostly driven by part-time jobs, but did not disrupt interest rate expectations. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to keep rates steady next month, with a 40% chance of a final hike early next year. Economists warn that the labour market could slow from here due to high interest rates and global uncertainty.

images.alt_text: The move marks the latest blow for Hong Kong’s ambitions to keep growing as a primary Asian financial hub alongside places such as Singapore and Tokyo.
Qantas Airways now faces penalties and compensation payments to affected workers fired during the Covid-19 pandemic.
The RBA is currently in watch-and-wait mode after four percentage points of rate hikes since May last year as it tries to get control over inflation.

site_title: Yuan set to rebound, says ‘super bullish’ Citic Securities
summary: The yuan is expected to rebound by 5% against the dollar over the next year or two as China's economic data shows measures to boost consumption are working, according to Citic Securities. The currency has slumped 5.2% this year, but is seen as a good investment opportunity due to the possibility of a more stable US-China interest-rate differential. Citic Securities' Matthew Chan is "super bullish" on the renminbi, expecting it to have bottomed and recover, driven by signs of economic growth and potential interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve.

site_title: Ex-Goldman banker uses big data to beat biotech’s long odds
summary: Simone Song, a former Goldman Sachs banker, has used big data to successfully invest in biotech companies despite the industry's high failure rate. With only 10% of experimental drugs making it to market, Song's venture fund, ORI Capital, has beaten the odds by backing companies that have shown promising results. Through data analysis, Song has identified potential winners and avoided losers, allowing her fund to thrive in a challenging industry.

images.alt_text: From left: NTU president Ho Teck Hua, NUS president Tan Eng Chye, and Temasek head of emerging technologies Russell Tham at the MOU signing ceremony. Temasek, NUS and NTU will provide startups with access to their networks of businesses and mentors.
Kuldeep Singh Rajput founded Biofourmis in Singapore in 2015.

FILE PHOTO: A man wearing a face mask is seen inside the Shanghai Stock Exchange building, as the country is hit by a novel coronavirus outbreak, at the Pudong financial district in Shanghai, China February 28, 2020.  REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

site_title: Russia’s Putin accepts Kim’s invitation to visit North Korea: KCNA
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin has accepted an invitation from North Korean leader Kim Jong Un to visit North Korea, according to the state-run KCNA news agency. The invitation was extended during a meeting between the two leaders in Russia's Amur region. Putin expressed his willingness to strengthen cooperation and friendship with North Korea, and Kim reportedly assured Russia of a "great victory" over its enemies. The visit comes amid tensions over potential Russian arms agreements with North Korea, which Western allies have warned could violate UN Security Council resolutions.

images.alt_text: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un (third from left) signs the visitor's book during a visit along with Russian President Vladimir Putin (second right) to the Vostochny cosmodrome, outside the town of Tsiolkovsky, some 180km north of Blagoveschensk in Amur region, Russia, Sept 13, 2023.
Russia's President Vladimir Putin shakes hands with North Korea's leader Kim Jong Un during a meeting at the Vostochny Сosmodrome in the far eastern Amur region, Russia, Sept 13, 2023.
People watch a news segment detailing North Korean leader Kim Jong-un's visit to Russia at a train station in Seoul, South Korea, Sept 12, 2023.

site_title: Green groups slam World Bank for backing Indonesian coal plants
summary: Environmental groups have submitted a complaint to the World Bank for backing two coal-fired power plants in Indonesia, violating a pledge to stop supporting fossil fuels. The plants, developed by PT Indo Raya Tenaga, would emit 250 million tonnes of carbon dioxide, despite plans to power some capacity with ammonia to reduce emissions. The World Bank's International Financial Corporation (IFC) is an indirect backer of the project through its equity investment in Hana Bank Indonesia, a financier of the complex. The groups claim the World Bank's actions contradict its own commitment to reducing greenhouse gas emissions.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The TikTok logo is pictured outside the company's U.S. head office in Culver City, California, U.S.,  September 15, 2020.   REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo
Indonesian President Joko Widodo (right) points towards a display showing the speed during a trial of the new Bandung-Jakarta high-speed train on Sep 13, 2023.
Indonesia, with a population of more than 270 million, accounted for nearly US$52 billion worth of e-commerce transactions last year.

Indonesia's Communications and Information Minister Budi Arie Setiadi (left) shakes hands with President Joko Widodo at the Presidential Palace in Jakarta. His ministry blocks thousands of online gambling websites every week.

site_title: Japan’s weak machinery orders, other batch of soft data raise BOJ challenge
summary: Japan's core machinery orders fell 1.1% in July, the largest decline in eight months, due to weak demand from industries including electric machinery, auto, and chemicals. Orders from manufacturers dropped 5.3%, while core service-sector orders grew 1.3%. The decline raises concerns for the economy, with the Bank of Japan wary of speeding up an exit from its ultra-easy policy. Japan's exports fell for the first time in nearly 2.5 years, and industrial output contracted more than expected, highlighting a difficult period ahead for the world's third-largest economy.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: A worker checks machinery at a factory in Higashiosaka, Japan June 23, 2022.  REUTERS/Sakura Murakami/File Photo/File Photo
Rising wholesale prices have pushed up Japan’s broader consumer inflation by prodding many firms to charge households more for their goods.
Fumio Kishida is set to retain Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki as well as Economy, Trade and Industry Minister Yasutoshi Nishimura.

site_title: Less than half of companies expect to meet decarbonisation targets by 2030: Siemens
summary: A new study by Siemens found that less than half of global organizations believe they will meet their 2030 decarbonization targets, with only 44% of executives confident in their ability to hit these targets. The study also revealed that only 37% of executives use standardized methods to measure progress, and many businesses are lagging in improving energy efficiency and electrification. Respondents from developing countries and emerging markets cited poverty reduction and economic development as priorities, making it difficult to invest in clean energy.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
People are evacuated by an excavator from a flooded area in Larissa, central Greece. Climate change can disrupt business operations, evaporate demand, impose obsolescence and shrink market share.

UN Secretary General Antonio Guterres talks to the media during a press conference on sidelines of the 43rd Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) Summit in Jakarta, Indonesia, 07 September 2023. Indonesia hosts the 43rd ASEAN Summit and related summits from 05 to 07 September

The Cebu Cordova Link Expressway in Cebu City, the Philippines.  Asia Pacific will need sizable investments in industrials, utilities, waste management, renewables, data centres, education services, airports, highways and railways.

Cargo ships wait in the anchor zone to cross the Panama Canal from the Pacific entrance near Panama City, Panama, on Sept 1, 2023. Ships have been waiting for days as the congestion to cross from both sides  increase due to the intense droughts in the country.

site_title: Taiwan rejects China's integrated development plan as politicised cash grab
summary: Taiwan has rejected China's plan to boost economic integration across the Taiwan Strait, calling it a "politicised cash grab" to improve access for Taiwanese enterprises and win over the island's people. China aims to deepen integrated development of Xiamen and the Kinmen Islands, but Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council says the plan is an attempt to entice Taiwanese companies and people to integrate into China's systems and norms, and accept the Communist Party's leadership. The move comes as China faces economic problems and a "deteriorating business environment."

images.alt_text: Beijing will encourage Taiwanese firms in Fujian province to list on Chinese stock exchanges, citing a statement jointly issued by the Communist Party of China’s Central Committee and the State Council.

site_title: Japan’s new economy minister sees positive signs emerging for end of deflation
summary: Japan's new economy minister, Yoshitaka Shindo, says positive signs are emerging for the economy to escape deflation, citing output gaps and other areas. Shindo emphasized the need for private demand-led growth and fiscal reform to exit deflation, but declined to comment on monetary policy. The new economic package, set to be compiled by Shindo, aims to ease rising fuel and living costs, but may strain the public debt burden. Shindo aims to achieve growth and fiscal reform to meet the primary balance target by the fiscal year end in March 2026.

images.alt_text: Orders from manufacturers fell 5.3 per cent in July, the largest decline in eight months, due to weak demand for computers from industries including electric machinery, auto and chemicals.
Rising wholesale prices have pushed up Japan’s broader consumer inflation by prodding many firms to charge households more for their goods.
Fumio Kishida is set to retain Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki as well as Economy, Trade and Industry Minister Yasutoshi Nishimura.

site_title: Philippines signals rate pause on view supply shock may ease
summary: The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas, Philippines' central bank, is signaling a continued pause in its policy rate amid expectations that a supply-driven inflation shock will soon dissipate. Governor Eli Remolona stated that the central bank doesn't need to raise its key rate in its next policy meeting on September 21 if there are no further supply shocks. This pause comes as the central bank has stood pat on its policy rate for three straight meetings, but remains ready to resume tightening if needed to prevent inflation.

images.alt_text: The BSP has kept its policy steady at its last three meetings after a series of hikes totalling 425 basis points since last year to cool red-hot inflation.

site_title: National Australia Bank will shut its Hong Kong office
summary: National Australia Bank (NAB) plans to close its Hong Kong office and consolidate operations into mainland China, Singapore, and Japan over the next 18 months. The office, which houses about 50 staff, will be shut down in early 2025. This move marks a blow to Hong Kong's ambitions as a primary Asian financial hub, following Westpac Banking's recent closure of its Hong Kong branch. NAB will serve its customers and investors in Greater China from Shanghai and other Asian branches, as well as its head office in Australia.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The National Australia Bank Logo is seen on a branch in central Sydney, Australia, February 8, 2018. REUTERS/Daniel Munoz/File Photo

site_title: Saudi developer lines up US$2.7 billion for building spree
summary: Real estate developer Roshn has secured approximately US$2.67 billion in funding for its projects across Saudi Arabia. The company, owned by Saudi Arabia's sovereign wealth fund, has a revolving credit facility of 6 billion riyals (S$2.17 billion) from three local banks. Roshn plans to draw down the credit within the next three to nine months to support its large-scale projects, including around 400,000 homes, 1,000 schools, and commercial and entertainment districts.

site_title: Billionaire Maersk family forms green methanol firm for shipping
summary: The billionaire Maersk family is forming a new company, C2X, to produce green methanol for the shipping industry, aiming to cut emissions from the world's largest polluter. C2X will build and operate large-scale facilities, with an expected annual capacity of over 3 million tons by 2030. The company, backed by APMH and Maersk, will supply green methanol to the shipping industry and chemical companies, addressing a significant shortage of carbon-neutral fuel. This move is part of Maersk's goal to become carbon neutral by 2040 and follows a surge in demand for green methanol, with global demand expected to triple by 2050.

images.alt_text: Maersk is working to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions to net zero by 2040

FILE PHOTO: Containers are seen on the Maersk's Triple-E giant container ship Majestic Maersk, one of the world's largest container ships, next to cranes at the APM Terminals in the port of Algeciras, Spain January 20, 2023. REUTERS/Jon Nazca/File Photo

“We are pleased to have found a new owner of our two logistics sites in Russia and thereby execute on our decision to divest all our assets in the country,” Maersk's chief commercial officer Karsten Kildahl said in a statement.
Maersk – which boasts the world’s second-biggest container fleet, based on numbers from online database Alphaliner – seeks to become an integrated logistics provider that connects land, sea and air.

site_title: 🙋🏻‍♂️ When it’s time for a check-in with your boss
summary: Regular check-ins with managers can improve employee well-being and employer-employee relationships. These one-on-one sessions help managers understand employees' thought processes and work styles, while also addressing miscommunication and providing timely feedback. However, too many check-ins can be counterproductive, leaving everyone confused. To make the most of check-ins, employees should identify clear challenges, prepare key questions, and actively listen to feedback. They should also highlight accomplishments and articulate progress, and be specific about what they need from their boss. By being clear and proactive, employees can reap benefits from check-ins and improve their work performance.

images.alt_text: Chloe Lim

site_title: Country Garden’s Forest City is at only 1% of resident target
summary: Country Garden's Forest City development in Malaysia is struggling to meet its target of 700,000 residents, with only around 10,000 people living on the four reclaimed islands as of 2023. The US$100 billion project, which has cost RM20 billion, is facing financial stress due to weak cash flow and repayment obligations. Analysts say the project's prospects are increasingly challenging, and the Malaysian government's financial incentives may be crucial for its success. Country Garden may need to bring in external investors or parcel out assets to fast-track development.

images.alt_text: Holders of the securities voted in favour of the company’s plan to stretch principal repayments by three years.
The survey came as distressed Chinese property developers struggle to negotiate with creditors to extend repayments.
Onshore creditors voted on Monday for proposals by Country Garden to extend repayments on eight onshore bonds worth 10.8 billion yuan (S$2 billion) by three years.

Visitors at Country Garden’s sales office for the Ten Mile Bay project in Nantong, China. Country Garden's travails reflect the systemic nature of China's real estate problems, which are a threat to the broader economy.
Country Garden’s tumble into crisis has shocked China’s financial markets because it’s a household name, known for building homes in smaller cities.

site_title: Labour demand could ease further this year, after signs of cooling in Q2: MOM
summary: Singapore's demand for labour may ease further this year, with resident employment shrinking for the first time since Q2 2020 due to seasonal factors, according to the Ministry of Manpower. Non-resident employment rose by 25,500, with nearly half coming from construction. The contraction is unlikely to persist, suggesting a moderation in labour demand.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan

Despite a weaker economic outlook for the next 12 months, the employment outlook remains stable, with 89 per cent of companies expecting no change or an increase in manpower in the samd period, according to a survey by the Singapore Business Federation.

site_title: Manhattan rental market ‘topping out’ as prices hover at records
summary: Manhattan's rental market is nearing a plateau, with median rents remaining unchanged at a record $4,400 in August. The number of available apartments decreased 14% from a year earlier, suggesting renters are opting to renew leases over searching for new places. This trend is attributed to rising rents, which have increased 7.3% from last year and 35% from August 2021. The slower leasing season may indicate that consumers have reached a breaking point, limiting further price growth.

images.alt_text: The contract rate on an adjustable mortgage increases by more than a quarter of a percentage point to 6.59 per cent, the highest in Mortgage Bankers Association (MBA) data back to early 2011.

A nozzle is replaced on a fuel dispenser at a gas station in La Puente, California, on September 7, 2023. US gas prices this week hit the highest levels in a decade as the summer holiday season winds down, with rising crude-oil prices a likely contributing factor to higher gas prices. (Photo by Frederic J. BROWN / AFP)

site_title: MAS issues prohibition orders against Three Arrows founders
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has issued nine-year prohibition orders against Three Arrows Capital co-founders Kyle Livingston Davies and Zhu Su, citing contraventions of the Securities and Futures Act. The orders, effective September 13, prohibit them from performing regulated activities and managing any capital market services firm. Both were directors and co-founders of the defunct crypto hedge fund, which was ordered to liquidate in June last year. The prohibition orders follow the fund's collapse, which resulted in significant losses for investors.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
The 3AC founders have spent months battling liquidators looking to recover assets for creditors of their fallen fund after it failed last summer.
The blowup of Three Arrows shook the digital-asset industry last year and put the interconnected nature of the sector on display.
Crypto billionaire Zhu Su in early stage of buying S$49m GCB as trustee for 3-year-old
Three Arrows Capital office in Singapore.Photographer: Suvashree Ghosh/Bloomberg

site_title: EY Global’s revenue rises 9.3% to US$49.4 billion
summary: EY Global's revenue increased 9.3% to US$49.4 billion in FY2023, driven by investments in pivotal alliances, cutting-edge technologies, and staff upskilling. Consulting services saw the largest growth, up 16.7%, followed by tax and assurance. The company's revenue in the Americas grew 12.1%, while its investments in innovation and AI reached US$3.6 billion, with a record US$385 million invested in training. EY's global headcount grew 8.2% to 395,442, with the largest increase in consulting and strategy and transactions teams.

images.alt_text: Navene Elangovan
Besides consulting, the Big Four also help multinational corporations minimise tax while simultaneously acting as "gatekeepers" in auditing the same big companies.

site_title: Streetwear marketplace Novelship raises US$9.5 million in Series B funding
summary: Novelship, a Singapore-based streetwear marketplace, has raised US$9.5 million in Series B funding led by East Ventures. The funds will be used to improve logistics, authentication, and delivery processes, while growing in-house offerings and expanding brand presence in South-east Asia. Founded in 2018, Novelship aims to create a more inclusive space within the sneaker community by diversifying products and catering to a growing female market. CEO Richard Xia stated that the company believes in making products accessible to everyone and is committed to creating a more inclusive space.

images.alt_text: Daphne Yow

site_title: Did Europe just start a trade war with China over electric cars?
summary: The European Union has launched an investigation into China's financial support for its electric vehicle industry, which could lead to new EU tariffs on Chinese EV imports. The EU aims to protect domestic auto jobs, but the move may fuel a global subsidy war and draw in the US. The EU's investigation could result in tariffs close to 27.5% of the value of Chinese EV imports, potentially harming Chinese manufacturers and sparking a trade war. The EU's actions come as governments worldwide seek to secure supply chains and counter China's growing influence in strategic sectors.

images.alt_text: Tesla and India reopened dialogue in May following a year-long impasse.
“Global markets are now flooded with cheaper Chinese electric cars. And their price is kept artificially low by huge state subsidies,” says EU Commission President Ursula von der Leyen.
The Munich motor show was dominated by Chinese brands such as BYD, which were there in double the numbers seen in 2021.

site_title: Moody’s cuts China property sector’s outlook to negative
summary: Moody's downgraded China's property sector outlook to negative, citing economic growth challenges and debt defaults by cash-squeezed developers. The ratings agency expects contracted sales to fall by 5% over the next 6-12 months, despite government support. The downgrade comes as China Evergrande Group, the world's most indebted property developer, is at the center of the crisis. Moody's notes that the impact of government measures to boost property purchases is likely to be short-lived and uneven.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Prudential, Cordlife
summary: Prudential has shelved plans for a separate wealth management unit in Singapore, instead refocusing its wealth offerings in the Republic. The insurer cited a change in strategy following a media report. Cordlife Group's possible transaction with Cradle Investments has been put on hold. The Place Holdings has called for a trading halt pending an announcement.

site_title: Tesla plans to buy US$1.9 billion of auto parts from India
summary: Tesla plans to invest up to $1.9 billion in auto parts from India, according to the country's government. The electric carmaker previously sourced $1 billion worth of components from India last year. CEO Elon Musk announced significant investments in the country after meeting with Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi in the US. This move comes after a year-long dialogue between the two nations was reopened in May.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Tesla logo is seen in Los Angeles, California U.S. January 12, 2018. REUTERS/Lucy Nicholson/File Photo

site_title: A showdown between the US Department of Justice and Google begins
summary: The US Department of Justice, along with 38 state attorneys-general, has launched a courtroom battle against Google, accusing the company of abusing its online-search monopoly to extract profits, snuff out competition, and slow innovation. Google allegedly pays over $10 billion a year to smartphone makers to make its search engine the default on devices, perpetuating its dominance of search. The case aims to prove that Google is a monopoly and is abusing its position, with the outcome potentially having significant implications for the tech industry.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A logo is pictured at Google's European Engineering Center in Zurich, Switzerland July 19,  2018   REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo
In 2021, Google was hit with a 220 million euro (S$324.6 million) fine by France’s antitrust watchdog for favouring its AdX sales platform.

site_title: Gold crawls higher from three-week lows as US dollar, yields slip
summary: Gold prices rose on Thursday, with US gold futures up 0.1% at $1,933.70, and spot gold adding 0.3% to $1,912.09 per ounce. The US dollar and Treasury yields weakened after the latest US inflation data, which suggested a possible pause in Federal Reserve rate hikes next week. The European Central Bank is set to decide on interest rates, while traders now see a 96% chance of the Fed leaving rates unchanged on Wednesday.

images.alt_text: Spot gold was flat at US$1,912.59 per ounce, as at 0059 GMT, while US gold futures were unchanged at US$1,934.80.

site_title: South Korea rail workers launch first strike in four years
summary: South Korea's Korean Railway Workers' Union launched a four-day strike, the first in four years, on September 14, 2023, seeking improved pay and working conditions, as well as expansion of the KTX bullet train services to southern Seoul. The strike could cut passenger and cargo train operations by up to 60% amid soaring seasonal demand, affecting businesses such as cement, steel, and petrochemicals.

images.alt_text: epa10859688 Unionized railway workers stage a rally in downtown Seoul, South Korea, 14 September 2023, as they kicked off a four-day strike nationwide earlier in the day, calling for better working conditions.  EPA-EFE/YONHAP SOUTH KOREA OUT

site_title: SGX derivatives volume rises 16% on rising hedging by global investors
summary: SGX derivatives volume surged 16% in August, reaching 23.7 million contracts, driven by rising hedging by global investors amid China's stimulus efforts. Foreign exchange futures traded volume hit an all-time high, with commodity derivatives also seeing significant gains. The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 4.2% in August, despite broad-base gains in foreign exchange, commodities, and equities.

images.alt_text: Mia Pei
Mohamed Nasser Ismail, who has worked at the exchange for the past 18 years, will leave at the end of October for other opportunities, the exchange said.
The potential default of Chinese property developer debt has had a spillover effect on Singapore-listed property companies, according to analysts.
Commodity derivatives traded volume hits a record high of 4.3 million contracts.

site_title: Goldman Sachs fires transaction banking chief Hari Moorthy and other executives
summary: Goldman Sachs fired Hari Moorthy, head of its transaction banking unit, and several other executives over compliance lapses, including communicating on unauthorized channels and failing to comply with an internal review. The firm issued a statement saying it takes its communications policy seriously and expects personnel to comply, but declined to comment on individual disciplinary matters. Goldman Sachs remains committed to its transaction banking business.

images.alt_text: The move reduces Goldman Sachs' number of executive officers to eight, for now, and leaves just two women in the group.
UBS is set to eliminate a few hundred roles that include relationship managers in Hong Kong and Singapore, the majority within teams newly acquired from Credit Suisse.
Goldman Sachs reduced its headcount by about 3,200 in the first quarter in its biggest round of layoffs since the 2008 financial crisis. It also cut about 250 jobs in May.

site_title: There will be no stopping Vietnam – if it can avoid the mistakes of other Asian tigers
summary: Vietnam's economy is on track to converge with South Korea's in a decade, driven by productivity gains, a highly committed workforce, and favorable trade and investment partners. With a per capita income growth trend similar to South Korea's in the 1960s, Vietnam's external debt is less than 25% of GDP, and its annual economic expansion has averaged 6.2% since 2000. To achieve its full potential, policymakers must focus on increasing productivity, avoiding the mistakes of previous Asian Tigers, and addressing infrastructure bottlenecks, regulatory transparency, and education. With a clear policy focus, Vietnam is poised to become a highly competitive economy, driving greater investment, innovation, and lower prices for citizens.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden touts a "new stage" in the ties between the US and Vietnam to a meeting of officials and executives in Hanoi.
Vietnam's VinFast is the first in South-east Asia to sell its car brand in the US.

site_title: Asia: Markets rose as US inflation soothes rate fears for now
summary: Asian markets rose on Thursday as a mixed US inflation report alleviated concerns about a possible Federal Reserve interest rate hike next week. The data showed consumer prices picked up due to a surge in oil prices, but core inflation remained acceptable. Analysts expressed mixed views, with some supporting a pause in September and others indicating a possible rate hike in November and December. The European Central Bank's decision later in the day will also be closely watched for its impact on the region's cost pressures.

images.alt_text: Generic shots of SGX
Prudential shelves plans for a separate wealth management unit in Singapore.
The Stoxx 600 slid 0.3 per cent on Wednesday.

site_title: Alphabet lays off hundreds from global recruitment team
summary: Alphabet, the parent company of Google, is laying off hundreds of employees from its global recruitment team as part of its efforts to slow hiring. The move is not part of a wide-scale layoff, and the company will retain a significant majority of the team for critical roles. Alphabet previously cut 12,000 jobs in January, reducing its workforce by 6%. The company's decision comes amid a weak economy and a slowdown in hiring for tech giants, following peers such as Meta, Microsoft, and Amazon.

site_title: China’s Apple iPhone ban appears to be retaliation, US says
summary: The US believes China's ban on iPhones is retaliation for the US weighing in on the backlash against Apple, with the White House calling it "aggressive and inappropriate retaliation". China has expanded a ban on iPhones to state-backed companies and agencies, despite contradicting reports that it has not issued laws to ban the purchase of Apple phones. The move has left US investors unsure about Apple's status in China, with the company's shares falling 1.2% for the day, just ahead of the launch of the new iPhone 15.

images.alt_text: Apple iPhone 15 and Apple iPhone 15 Max on display during an event at Apple Park campus in Cupertino, California, US, Sept 12, 2023.
The iPhone 15 Pro is presented during the 'Wonderlust' event at the company's headquarters in Cupertino, California, U.S. September 12, 2023. REUTERS/Loren Elliott
“China has not issued laws, regulations or policy documents that prohibit the purchase and use of foreign brand phones such as Apple’s,” says foreign ministry spokesperson Mao Ning.
The new iPhone 15 goes on sale online in China on Alibaba’s Tmall marketplace on Sep 15, and in-stores on Sep 22.

site_title: New York City penthouse once listed for record US$250 million gets 22% price cut
summary: A New York City penthouse listed for US$250 million has seen a 22% price cut to US$195 million. The three-story condo, located on the 129th floor of Extell Development's Central Park Tower, features 23 rooms and outdoor space. The cut puts the property out of contention for the record-breaking sale price of US$238 million, which was achieved by billionaire Ken Griffin in 2019. The reduced price may be an attempt to stimulate sales after the condo failed to sell in its first year on the market.

site_title: Starbucks founder Howard Schultz steps down from board
summary: Starbucks founder Howard Schultz is stepping down from the company's board, effective September 13. Schultz, who built the company into a global coffee powerhouse, is handing over the reins to Laxman Narasimhan as the first outside CEO. The company also appointed Zhang Wei, a former Alibaba executive, as a director starting October 1. Schultz's departure comes as the company adapts to changing consumer habits, with 75% of drinks sold being cold beverages.

images.alt_text: The world’s largest coffeehouse chain has targeted its younger, wealthier US customer base by launching new drinks and promoting food options that have helped drive up average customer sales.
A Starbucks coffee shop in San Francisco, California, US, on Thursday, July 28, 2022. Starbucks Corp. is expected to release earnings figures August 2. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg
Starbucks said transactions grew 6 per cent in the US and also rose in China.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Thursday; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.3% at Thursday's open, with the Straits Times Index (STI) climbing 8.47 points to 3,227.4. Gainers outnumbered losers 63 to 31, driven by local banks opening higher, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC rising 0.7%, 0.5%, and 0.5% respectively. Other heavily traded counters, including Pollux Properties, Frencken Group, and Rex International, also gained ground.

images.alt_text: Prudential shelves plans for a separate wealth management unit in Singapore.

site_title: ECB considers lifting rates to record high even as economy slows
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is expected to raise interest rates to a record peak on Thursday, despite the economy slowing down. The decision comes as inflation remains above the 2% target, and the ECB is also expected to cut its growth projections for this year and next. Economists argue that the rate hike is necessary to combat inflation, but some believe it should be delayed due to the deteriorating economic outlook. A 25 basis point rate increase would bring the rate to 4.0%, the highest level since the euro's launch in 1999.

images.alt_text: A majority of economists, 39 of 69, in the Sept 5-7 poll predicted no change to the deposit rate on Thursday while 30 said the ECB’s Governing Council would hike it by a quarter-point to 4.00 per cent.
ECB chief economist Philip Lane says slowing in goods and services gauges are welcome and that underlying pressures will keep weakening.
Lagarde and her colleagues are still waiting to weigh the ECB’s in-house economic forecasts, which are a key piece to the puzzle of rate decisions.

site_title: The EU’s changed perspective on adding new members since Russia invaded Ukraine
summary: EU Commission President Ursula von der Leyen has signaled a shift in the union's perspective on adding new members since Russia's invasion of Ukraine. In her annual state of the union address, von der Leyen framed Ukraine as a genuine candidate for membership, marking a significant change in the EU's approach to enlargement. The EU is now positioning itself as a geopolitical union, with von der Leyen envisioning a "union complete with over 500 million people living in a free, democratic, and prosperous" EU. This marks a departure from the past focus on economic and legal roles, and von der Leyen has introduced a series of pre-enlargement policy reviews to facilitate the process.

images.alt_text: European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen speaks during a press conference as part of the 29th EU-Japan Summit at The European Union Building in Brussels on July 13, 2023. (Photo by JOHN THYS / AFP)

President of the European Council Charles Michel looks on during a press conference at the summit between European Union leaders and leaders of the CELAC group of Latin American and Caribbean states, in Brussels, Belgium July 18, 2023. REUTERS/Johanna Geron

site_title: Kim Jong Un says Russia will win ‘great victory’
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un has expressed confidence that Russia will win a "great victory" over its enemies, in comments made to Russian President Vladimir Putin during a visit to the Vostochny cosmodrome in Russia. Putin praised the strengthening of cooperation and friendship between their countries, and discussed possibilities for military cooperation, including helping North Korea build satellites. However, US officials have warned that any such cooperation would be "quite troubling" and potentially violate UN Security Council resolutions.

images.alt_text: Russia's President Vladimir Putin shakes hands with North Korea's leader Kim Jong Un during a meeting at the Vostochny Сosmodrome in the far eastern Amur region, Russia, Sept 13, 2023.
Putin’s public praise of Musk comes days after the US-based entrepreneur said he refused a Ukrainian request last year to activate his Starlink satellite network.
People watch a news segment detailing North Korean leader Kim Jong-un's visit to Russia at a train station in Seoul, South Korea, Sept 12, 2023.

site_title: US agency DFC invests US$15 million in Singapore-based VC fund Wavemaker Impact
summary: The US International Development Finance Corporation (DFC) has invested US$15 million in Singapore-based venture capital fund Wavemaker Impact, which focuses on climate tech and sustainable startups in South-east Asia. Wavemaker Impact aims to expand its portfolio to 10 companies by the end of 2023 and 16 by the end of 2024. The investment aligns with the DFC's focus on agriculture, food, and land use, and will support the growth of sustainability startups in the region.

images.alt_text: Daphne Yow
Rice cultivation is the second-largest source of greenhouse gas emissions in agrifood due to methane-emitting bacteria generated from flooded rice paddy fields.
L-R: Wavemaker Impact founding members Quentin Vaquette, Doug Parker, Marie Cheong, Paul Santos and Steve Melhuish.
Wavemaker Partners launches climate-tech venture builder, with US$25m target for fund

site_title: Investors scour Hong Kong hotels for student dorms, rentals
summary: Investors in Hong Kong are taking advantage of the city's property downturn by buying hotels and converting them into student housing or rental units. Since the COVID-19 pandemic, HK$14.5 billion worth of hotel transactions have occurred, with 61% of rooms converted into student living or rental properties. Firms like AEW Capital Management and PGIM Real Estate are acquiring hotels to capitalize on the trend, citing cheaper prices, suitable layouts, and existing communal facilities. The government's initiatives to attract foreign students and talent have fueled demand for student housing, with occupancy rates reaching 80% for some converted hotels.

images.alt_text: The landslide occurred after the city received record rainfall last week.
Hong Kong now accounts for about 10 per cent of Gaw’s portfolio, while mainland China assets have dropped to about 25 per cent of the total.
The economy is also facing challenges from China’s slowing momentum, soft global demand and the potential for local spending habits to taper off.

site_title: Despite energy ‘carrot’, EU’s worries about Israel grow
summary: The European Union's relations with Israel are threatened by domestic political troubles over controversial judicial reforms in Israel. Despite this, the EU sees an opportunity for renewed relations through energy diplomacy, particularly in light of the Ukrainian war and Europe's diversification of energy sources. Israel has become an energy exporter after major offshore finds, making it an attractive partner for the EU. A visit by European Commission president Ursula von der Leyen last year highlighted the potential for cooperation, but the current domestic situation in Israel may hinder progress.

images.alt_text: Solar panels atop a hops plantation in the Bavarian Holledau region in Au, Germany. EU successes in scaling up use of clean energy in the last year include reaching a record 41 GW of new solar energy capacity installed.
Proponents of the judicial changes say they would restore balance to the branches of government.

People demonstrate as a response to Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his nationalist coalition government's judicial overhaul, at Ben Gurion International Airport in Lod, Israel July 11, 2023. REUTERS/Amir Cohen

site_title: Indonesia’s US$7.3b high speed rail to begin service on Oct 1; no ticket subsidies for commuters
summary: Indonesia's US$7.3 billion high-speed rail project, the Kereta Cepat Jakarta Bandung, will begin commercial operations on October 1, reducing commuting time between Jakarta and Bandung to 40 minutes from three hours. The train, funded largely by China, features a top speed of 350 km/h. Indonesian President Joko Widodo took a test ride and expressed comfort during the journey. There will be no ticket subsidies for commuters, marking a departure from the project's original plan.

images.alt_text: Elisa Valenta

Indonesia’s President Joko Widodo (R) and Minister of Transportation Budi Karya Sumadi (L) point towards a display showing the speed during a trial of the new Bandung-Jakarta high-speed train in Jakarta on September 13, 2023. (Photo by AKBAR NUGROHO GUMAY / POOL / AFP)

site_title: Pine Grove taking another shot at collective sale with S$1.95 billion guide price
summary: Pine Grove, a 893,218 sq ft condominium in Singapore, is being put up for collective sale with a guide price of S$1.95 billion. The site has a maximum allowable gross plot ratio of 2.1 and can yield up to 2,050 new units. If successful, it will be the largest residential collective sale since Chuan Park was sold for S$890 million in 2022. Owners can expect to receive between S$2.39 million and S$3.2 million, depending on the size of their units.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
Singapore High Court grants sale order to Chuan Park’s S$890 million en bloc deal

site_title: FTX approved to start selling its US$3.4 billion crypto hoard
summary: FTX has received court approval to sell its US$3.4 billion crypto hoard, with the goal of raising funds for creditors who claim they are owed tens of billions of US dollars. The company will sell up to US$100 million of crypto per week, depending on market prices. A court-authorized sale plan aims to convert digital assets into US dollars for distribution to creditors once FTX wins final court approval of a payout plan.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo illustration taken on November 13, 2022, shows the logo of cryptocurrency FTX, reflected in its website on a laptop screen in Washington, DC. - Collapsed cryptocurrency exchange FTX suffered a "complete failure of corporate controls" under founder Sam Bankman-Fried, the company's new chief executive said on November 17, 2022, calling the situation "unprecedented." The scathing condemnation came in a filing in US bankruptcy court from John J. Ray -- an executive with 40 years of experience in corporate restructurings including the infamous implosion of Enron in 2001. (Photo by Stefani Reynolds / AFP)

site_title: UK house price gauge weakest in 14 years as interest rates weigh: RICS
summary: UK house prices have dropped by the largest margin in 14 years, according to a Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS) survey, due to elevated mortgage costs and economic uncertainty. The RICS house price balance slumped to -68 in August from -55 in July, marking the weakest reading since February 2009. Experts attribute the slowdown to sustained interest rate rises and a prolonged cost-of-living crisis. Mortgage lenders Halifax and Nationwide have also reported falling prices, with tenant demand outstripping landlord instructions in the rental market.

images.alt_text: British Chancellor of the Exchequer Jeremy Hunt holds a Ministerial Statement at the House of Commons in London, Britain, June 26, 2023. UK Parliament/Jessica Taylor/Handout via REUTERS THIS IMAGE HAS BEEN SUPPLIED BY A THIRD PARTY MANDATORY CREDIT. IMAGE MUST NOT BE ALTERED.
Grocery prices remain in the spotlight as Britons grapple with a cost-of-living crisis stretching into its second year.
The hiring of permanent staff fell by the most since June 2020, early in the Covid-19 pandemic, while spending on temporary workers dipped for the first time since July 2020.
The downturn gripping the UK housing market steepened in August as the cost-of-borrowing squeeze sapped demand, according to a major mortgage lender.

site_title: Socially awkward outsider is surprise contender to lead Taiwan
summary: Taiwan's presidential election is expected to be a surprise, with Ko Wen-je, a socially awkward outsider, leading in polls as a third-party candidate. Ko, a 64-year-old former trauma surgeon, has few aides and little money, yet has proven popular with 23% support in a recent poll. His stance on China is unique, separating himself from the ruling party's hardline approach, and he's considering dialogue with Beijing. A Ko victory would thrust a relative unknown into the US-China rivalry, with implications for Taiwan's defense and economy.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Taiwan's armed forces hold two days of routine drills to show combat readiness ahead of Lunar New Year holidays at a military base in Kaohsiung, Taiwan, January 11, 2023. REUTERS/Ann Wang/File Photo
Li Qiang will first attend the Association of South-east Asian Nations gathering in Jakarta, Indonesia, for wide-ranging talks on trade, climate change and global security.
FILE PHOTO: Terry Gou, Foxconn founder announces his bid for the Taiwan presidency during a press event in Taipei, Taiwan August 28, 2023. REUTERS/Ann Wang/File Photo

site_title: Coffee firms won’t be ready to comply with EU deforestation law: report
summary: Global coffee firms are unlikely to meet the EU's new law requiring importers of commodities linked to deforestation to produce a due diligence statement by end-2024. The law aims to reduce climate change by preventing imports of commodities contributing to deforestation. However, the lack of preparedness may prompt coffee firms to shift sourcing to more developed regions, leaving small, poverty-stricken farmers in developing countries to expand into forested areas, potentially negating the law's impact.

images.alt_text: Luckin Coffee employees preparing baijiu liquor-flavoured latte, the latest product in collaboration with Chinese liquor brand Kweichow Moutai, in a Luckin Coffee shop in Beijing on Monday (Sep 4).

site_title: Mexican Congress holds hearing on UFOs featuring purported ‘alien’ bodies
summary: Mexican lawmakers held a hearing on Unidentified Anomalous Phenomena (UAP), marking the country's first congressional event on UFOs. Journalist Jaime Maussan presented two tiny, 1,000-year-old artefacts with elongated heads and three fingers, claiming they were extraterrestrial remains. The specimens were carbon-dated by Mexico's National Autonomous University (UNAM) and underwent X-rays, 3-D reconstruction, and DNA analysis. Lawmakers expressed openness to investigating the evidence, with Congressman Sergio Gutierrez calling for further events on the topic, following a shift in the US government's stance on UAP.

images.alt_text: epa09043579 A handout photo made available by NASA shows an image of rocks and soil around NASA's Perseverance Mars rover acquired by using its onboard Left Navigation Camera (Navcam), on Sol 9, the ninth Martian day of the mission 28 February 2021. The camera is located high on the rover's mast and aids in driving. Perseverance's main mission on Mars is astrobiology and the search for signs of ancient microbial life, according to NASA.  EPA-EFE/NASA/JPL-Caltech HANDOUT  HANDOUT EDITORIAL USE ONLY/NO SALES##########mon##########
In September 2020, Sky Eye, which is located in China's southwestern Guizhou province and has a diameter of 500 metres, officially launched a search for extraterrestrial life.

site_title: Blackstone taps new credit boss in bid for US$1 trillion goal
summary: Blackstone, a private equity giant, has made sweeping changes to its credit unit as it seeks to become a bigger lending powerhouse. The firm promoted insurance chief Gilles Dellaert to lead the combined unit overseeing almost $300 billion of assets, with a goal to grow total credit assets to $1 trillion within a decade. Credit head Dwight Scott will become chairman, focusing on key clients, strategy, and initiatives. The changes aim to knit credit operations more tightly, providing insurers and investors with a variety of lending strategies and flexible financing.

images.alt_text: Blackstone's headquarters in New York. A consortium of investors, including Blackstone, has spent much of the year selling large chunks of shares in the exchange operator. In March, they announced the sale of about £2 billion of the shares; in May, they kicked off a process to sell about £2.7 billion.
Institutional investors around the globe have continued to add more capital into private credit funds.
Blackstone had bought Bellagio from MGM for US$4.3 billion in 2019.

site_title: New tech may boost tracking of potential money launderers, information exchange
summary: Singapore authorities have successfully busted a multi-billion-dollar anti-money laundering case, seizing S$1.8 billion in cash and assets from 10 individuals, including at least 105 properties and 50 vehicles. The bust was triggered by suspicious transaction reports (STRs) filed by financial institutions, which authorities used to investigate and identify potential red flags. The case highlights the effectiveness of Singapore's anti-money laundering regulations, but raises questions about the ability of authorities to keep pace with emerging threats and potential evasions by would-be money launderers.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
In a subsequent hearing in court, the prosecution revealed that the suspects include wives and relatives of the 10 accused people (above).

In one of the biggest anti-money laundering operations in Singapore, the Singapore Police Force (SPF) rounded up a group of foreigners who had amassed about $1.8 billion worth of assets in the city-state.
Su Haijin has been denied bail and will return to court on Oct 11.

site_title: SoftBank-backed Arm prices IPO at US$51 a share
summary: Arm Holdings, backed by SoftBank, priced its initial public offering (IPO) at $51 a share, raising $4.87 billion and valuing the company at $54.5 billion. The IPO is the largest in the US since Rivian Automotive's 2021 offering, and could provide a boost to the equity markets. SoftBank, which owns 90% of Arm, will control the company after the IPO, and is setting aside $700 million to be bought by major customers including Intel, Apple, and Nvidia. The offering is expected to begin trading on the Nasdaq Global Select Market on Thursday.

images.alt_text: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company's (TSMC) logo is seen while people attend the opening of the TSMC global R&D center in Hsinchu, Taiwan July 28, 2023. REUTERS/Ann Wang

Masayoshi Son's once-exalted reputation as an investor is badly tarnished, but the irrepressible founder of Japan's SoftBank is hoping that the mega-IPO of Arm this week might bring back the good times.
Arm is still considering raising the price range of its initial public offering as well.

site_title: Possible deal for Cordlife shares is off
summary: Cordlife Group, a Singapore-based cord blood banking company, announced that a possible transaction for its shares, previously announced as a confidential discussion between Cradle Investments and a third party, has ceased. The company's shares hit a three-year high of S$0.495 amid heavy trading on June 26. Following the update, Cordlife's counter rose 2.4% to S$0.425 at market close on September 13.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek

site_title: China’s data to show economy is trying to move past the worst
summary: China's economic activity likely improved in August, driven by a boom in spending on travel and hotels, and manufacturers reported expansion in new orders for the first time in five months. Industrial output is projected to have grown 3.9% year-over-year, while retail sales growth is expected to accelerate to 3% from 2.5% in July. However, the real estate sector's woes still loom, with property investment likely shrinking 8.9% in the first eight months of the year. The People's Bank of China is expected to keep policy rates unchanged, but policymakers may need to introduce more aggressive easing measures to ensure a real recovery.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The headquarters of the People's Bank of China, the central bank, is pictured in Beijing, China, February 3, 2020. REUTERS/Jason Lee/File Photo

site_title: Europe: Shares fall ahead of ECB decision, BP weighs
summary: European shares fell 0.3% on Wednesday, led by the industrials sector, as investors awaited the European Central Bank's monetary policy decision on Thursday. BP shares dropped 2.8% after CEO Bernard Looney's sudden exit, while US consumer prices rose 14 months, with underlying inflation at nearly two-year lows, potentially allowing the Federal Reserve to keep interest rates unchanged. The ECB is expected to raise rates by 25 basis points, with a 64% chance, according to market pricing.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average declined 0.2 per cent to 34,575.53 on Wednesday.

site_title: Oil dips as surprise US crude stockbuild faces supply cuts
summary: Oil prices dipped on Wednesday, with international benchmark Brent futures settling at $91.88 a barrel, down 18 cents. A surprise build in US crude inventories offset expectations of tight supply for the rest of the year, with Saudi Arabia and Russia extending production cuts of 1.3 million barrels per day. This could lead to a market deficit through the fourth quarter, potentially lifting Brent futures above $100 a barrel before the end year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A pump jack is seen at sunrise near Bakersfield, California October 14, 2014. Brent crude hit a new four-year low on Wednesday before recovering to just under $85 a barrel, as faltering global growth curbed demand for fuel at a time of heavy oversupply.  REUTERS/Lucy Nicholson/File Photo

site_title: BP begins search for new CEO with no clear front-runner
summary: BP begins searching for a new CEO after Bernard Looney's abrupt resignation, with no clear front-runner. The company has started both internal and external searches, with chairman Helge Lund taking over as interim CEO. Potential candidates include Murray Auchincloss, Gordon Birrell, and William Lin, as well as external candidates such as former BP executives Tufan Erginbilgic and Brian Gilvary. The board has not groomed a successor for Looney, who had planned to stay in the job for many more years, and Auchincloss's chances of staying on as a permanent CEO are slim.

images.alt_text: International benchmark Brent futures dipped 18 cents to settle at US$91.88 a barrel on Wednesday.

British energy giant BP said that its chief executive Bernard Looney had resigned "with immediate effect", after admitting that he had not been "fully transparent" about historical relationships with colleagues.

site_title: Shanghai exchange exploring potential LME nickel rival
summary: The Shanghai Futures Exchange (ShFE) is exploring the possibility of launching nickel futures for international use, potentially challenging the London Metal Exchange's (LME) contract. Industry participants have been studying the nickel market's structure and supply and demand to create an alternative benchmark. The move could impact the use of LME prices as a global benchmark for nickel trading, which is currently used by commodity traders, producers, and consumers for manufacturing stainless steel and electric vehicle batteries.

images.alt_text: Trading in the futures will start on Aug 18, the INE says.
Nanchu will not operate any delivery warehousing business for Shanghai Futures Exchange (SHFE )starting from Jul 1.

site_title: India’s Reliance Retail in talks with GIC, Gulf funds on US$1.5 billion injection: sources
summary: Reliance Retail, India's largest retailer, is in talks with sovereign wealth funds, including Singapore's GIC, Abu Dhabi's ADIA, and Saudi Arabia's PIF, to raise US$1.5 billion in new investments. This is part of an internal target to raise US$3.5 billion by the end of September. The funds aim to invest at a valuation of US$100 billion. Existing investors, including QIA and KKR, have already announced US$1 billion and US$250 million investments, respectively. The final investments or funding plans could still change.

images.alt_text: Reliance Retail is India’s biggest retailer whose operations stretch from selling groceries to electronics, and include foreign partnerships with brands.
FILE PHOTO: A signage of Singapore’s sovereign wealth fund GIC is pictured at their office in Singapore July 13, 2023. REUTERS/Edgar Su/File Photo
GIC this week reported its worst annualised five-year returns since 2016, citing the slowing global economy following Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, and rising inflation.

Football clubs in Saudi Arabia have signed a host of major stars beginning last year with Cristiano Ronaldo, pictured here playing for Al-Nassr in a pre-season club friendly against Paris Saint-Germain in July.
GIC group chief investment officer Jeffrey Jaensubhakij said it’s still early days, with a new AI company being set up every week and dozens attacking the same problem.

Major banks and public debt markets are growing wary about a real estate sector where higher rates are crunching property values just as home working and e-commerce challenge the long-term viability of some offices and malls.
Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates. Photographer: Christopher Pike/Bloomberg
China makes up 22 per cent of the portfolio of Temasek, which is ranked among the top 10 investors in the world with net portfolio value of S$382 billion.

site_title: BlackRock, SGX launch climate action ETF at local equity record of US$426 million
summary: BlackRock, the Singapore Exchange (SGX), and MSCI have launched a US$426 million climate action ETF, the largest equity amount for an ETF in Singapore. The fund tracks the MSCI Asia ex-Japan Climate Action Index, which tracks companies that meet certain environmental, social, and governance criteria. This is a collaboration among three major players in the financial and asset management sectors, highlighting the growing focus on sustainable investing in the region.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Singapore’s stock market is primed for gradual transformation with the right level of support and participation from public and private stakeholders.

site_title: Luxury cruise ship awaits rescue in Greenland’s Arctic
summary: A luxury cruise ship, the Ocean Explorer, carrying over 200 people, mostly Australians, became stuck in the Alpefjord in northeastern Greenland on September 11. Despite two failed attempts to free the ship from mud, rescue efforts are ongoing. The ship's captain initially waited for high tide, but the strong suction created by the mud held the vessel in place. Denmark's Arctic Special Forces and a naval ship are assisting in the rescue, with a vessel from Iceland on standby. All passengers are safe, according to the ship's operator, Aurora Expeditions.

site_title: Global boom in luxury property sales hit by higher interest rates
summary: Higher interest rates are slowing the luxury property boom, with residential sales above $10 million falling 13% in the second quarter compared to the previous year, according to Knight Frank. Total sales in 12 markets worldwide dropped to $30 billion, down from $40.7 billion in 2021. Despite this, Dubai remained the top city in terms of volume, driven by foreign wealth. Experts predict a lean 2024 for new developments, leading to rising competition for available stock and a floor under pricing. Supply remains a major constraint in the near term.

images.alt_text: Residential skyscraper buildings beyond motor yachts docked in a Dubai marina in late August.Photographer: Christopher Pike/Bloomberg

site_title: How Business Improvement Districts can help SMEs succeed
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority's (URA) Business Improvement District (BID) programme in Singapore aims to support small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) by providing a collective voice, marketing and promotion, networking and collaboration, data and research, and infrastructure enhancements. Since 2017, the programme has been piloted in areas such as the Singapore River, Marina Bay, and Tanjong Pagar, with local "place managers" helping to develop the area and support SME members. The programme provides seed funding, with the government matching every dollar of membership fees collected, and has resulted in initiatives such as free conversion of liquefied petroleum gas to piped gas for SMEs, increased revenue for merchants, and strategic partnerships among businesses.

images.alt_text: Lendlease, SingPost, Paya Lebar Square to form pilot Business Improvement District
The retail scene in post-pandemic Singapore

site_title: Singapore proptech company Simpple prices Nasdaq IPO at US$5.25 a share
summary: Simpple, a Singapore-based proptech company, priced its Nasdaq IPO at US$5.25 per share, raising US$8.4 million. The company, which serves over 60 clients in the Singapore facilities-management market, plans to use the proceeds for research and development, intellectual property, and expansion into Australia and the Middle East. Simpple will commence trading on the Nasdaq Capital Market under the ticker symbol "SPPL".

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek

site_title: US carriers cut margin outlook on fuel costs, Frontier flags lower bookings
summary: US airlines cut their third-quarter margin forecasts due to rising fuel costs, with American Airlines lowering its profit outlook from 85-95 cents to 20-30 cents per share. Shares fell 4-9% across carriers, including Frontier, which warned of lower bookings and operational cancellations. Fuel prices are expected to rise above $100 a barrel, and domestic travel demand is weakening due to inflation and staffing costs. The decline in demand and increased expenses are expected to impact airline revenue and pricing power.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: American Airlines aircraft sit on the tarmac at LaGuardia airport following a reservation system outage in New York, April 16, 2013. REUTERS/Carlo Allegri/File Photo

site_title: US: Muted day on Wall Street after mixed inflation data
summary: US stocks experienced a muted day on Wall Street, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average declining 0.2% to 34,575.53. The mixed inflation report, which showed a 3.7% increase in consumer inflation, did not alter expectations for the Federal Reserve to keep interest rates unchanged this month. However, the report did raise concerns about demand, particularly in the airline sector, with American Airlines shares falling 5.7% due to higher jet fuel costs and lowered forecasts. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.1% and 0.3%, respectively.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., September 11, 2023.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Insurer FM Global allocates US$350 million to support client investment in climate resilience
summary: FM Global, a commercial property insurer, has allocated US$350 million to support client investment in climate resilience, a 15% increase from its inaugural year in 2022. The allocation provides a 5% premium offset against certain policies, enabling policyholders to invest in flood protection projects, reinforced roofs, and other risk mitigation efforts. The move aims to help clients protect against climate-related perils and drive business continuity.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting

Cargo ships wait in the anchor zone to cross the Panama Canal from the Pacific entrance near Panama City, Panama, on Sept 1, 2023. Ships have been waiting for days as the congestion to cross from both sides  increase due to the intense droughts in the country.
People are evacuated by an excavator from a flooded area in Larissa, central Greece. Climate change can disrupt business operations, evaporate demand, impose obsolescence and shrink market share.
The Investor Agenda says governments continue to see climate change as separate to, and less important than, other aspects of economic and fiscal policy.

site_title: How do financial institutions spot and flag suspicious transactions?
summary: Financial institutions in Singapore use various methods to identify and flag suspicious transactions, including checking customers' Singpass accounts and verifying their sources of wealth. Banks also consider factors such as a customer's country of origin, occupation, and employment status. When a suspicious transaction is detected, the bank files a Suspicious Transaction Report (STR) with the Suspicious Transaction Reporting Office (STRO) and accepts the transaction to avoid alerting the customer. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is developing a new digital platform, Cosmic, to enable secure sharing of information on potentially suspicious customers among financial institutions, aiming to strengthen anti-money laundering measures by the second half of 2024.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting

In one of the biggest anti-money laundering operations in Singapore, the Singapore Police Force (SPF) rounded up a group of foreigners who had amassed about $1.8 billion worth of assets in the city-state.

site_title: Wealthy here should contribute to society, adhere to Singapore’s norms: DPM Wong
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the importance of the wealthy in Singapore contributing to society through taxes and philanthropy, while adhering to the country's norms against ostentatious displays of wealth. The government aims to maintain the social compact and keep society strong and united, ensuring real income growth and improvements in the standard of living for the broad middle of society. Wong also highlighted efforts to address inequality and social mobility, including the Forward Singapore exercise, which includes reskilling workers and supporting the unemployed.

site_title: Energy transition could rock Singapore’s star energy & chemicals sector
summary: Singapore's energy and chemicals sector, a key contributor to the nation's economy, is undergoing a transformation to adapt to the energy transition. Despite predictions that oil and gas will remain prominent in the global energy mix until 2050, companies are shifting their focus to sustainable products and low-carbon technologies. Multinationals, including ExxonMobil, Shell, and Chevron, are investing in emerging low-carbon technologies and carbon capture, utilization, and storage. Singapore aims to become a global hub for advanced low-carbon technologies, leveraging its existing expertise in the fossil fuel industry to drive innovation and growth in the hydrogen and renewable fuel sectors.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
Plans are underway to transform Jurong Island - the pulse of Singapore's energy and chemicals sector - into a space that operates sustainably and exports sustainable products globally

site_title: India calls X a 'habitual non-compliant platform' in latest court tussle
summary: India's IT ministry has called Elon Musk's X, formerly Twitter, a "habitual non-compliant platform" and accused it of undermining the government's role in a democratic setup. The ministry's filing, reviewed by Reuters, alleges X has failed to comply with many content removal orders, including blocking accounts deemed supportive of an independent Sikh state and spreading misinformation about protests. The remarks come as X is set to challenge a June fine of $60,291 imposed by a Karnataka court, which also found X non-compliant with blocking orders.

images.alt_text: Owner of X, Elon Musk, wants X to become more like Tencent Holdings’ WeChat, a messaging service turned super-app that offers everything from social media and video games to fintech. X chief executive Linda Yaccarino has said X will include features such as payments and banking.

site_title: The ‘misery effect’ is back with a vengeance as US labour strikes take a toll
summary: A wave of strikes and contract disputes is spreading across the US and elsewhere, mirroring the "misery effect" of the late 1970s and early 1980s. The US labor market is experiencing a resurgence of strikes, with major industrial sectors, including the automotive and entertainment industries, affected. The United Auto Workers union is in contract negotiations with Ford, General Motors, and Stellantis, while Hollywood actors and writers are on strike. Economists warn that a prolonged strike could lead to shortages, higher prices, and inflation, echoing the stagflation of the 1970s and 1980s.

images.alt_text: A week long strike could shave off US$480 million from GM’s earnings
The raises, negotiated in the 2019 contract with the UAW, lift the pay of the workers by US$4.33 an hour, or US$9,000 a year, according to Ford.

A poster for the film "Maestro" at the 80th Venice Film Festival. The biopic stars Hollywood actor Bradley Cooper, who plays legendary conductor and composer Leonard Bernstein. He will not attend the festival because of the ongoing Hollywood strike by actors and writers.
Members of the Writers Guild of America (WGA) and the Screen Actors Guild walk the picket line outside of Netflix in Hollywood, California, on Aug 9, 2023.

site_title: Fed’s vice-chair, newest governor sworn in
summary: Philip Jefferson, the new US Federal Reserve vice-chair, took the oath of office alongside governors Lisa Cook and Adriana Kugler. The swearing-in follows Senate confirmations last week. The Fed is set to maintain its current interest-rate range of 5.25%-5.50% at its upcoming meeting. Jefferson is expected to align closely with Chair Powell's view that the Fed may need to act if inflation pressures remain high. The decision is not expected to change the outcome of the Sep 19-20 meeting.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Fed Governor Philip Jefferson testifies before a Senate Banking Committee hearing on his nomination to be the Federal Reserve's next vice chair, on Capitol Hill in Washington, U.S., June 21, 2023. REUTERS/Jonathan Ernst/File Photo

site_title: Amazon unveils US$40 million fund for homeownership in new push
summary: Amazon has launched a $40 million fund to support homeownership, partnering with the National Housing Trust to create or preserve affordable homes near its headquarters sites in Seattle and Arlington, Virginia, and Nashville. This initiative builds on the company's $1.7 billion investment in affordable rental units, aiming to expand access to homeownership for those who may be shut out due to rising housing costs. The program focuses on individuals making too much to qualify for government assistance but struggling to keep up with mortgage payments.

images.alt_text: Amazon may not dominate the Emmys, or Nielsen’s top ten. But, says a former executive, its chief aims in video are for people to watch TV through its hardware, to buy content through its store, and to watch commercials served by Amazon advertising.

site_title: Softer housing market, higher incomes help Canadians trim debts
summary: Canada's households modestly repaired their balance sheets in the second quarter, driven by rising incomes and slower debt accumulation. Disposable incomes rose 2.6% and households pared their growth in credit market debt, which increased just 0.6%. The debt-service ratio, or proportion of income dedicated to debt and interest obligations, edged down to 14.8%, the first decrease since 2022. This points to Canadians' strong financial positions ahead of projected slower economic growth and higher unemployment.

images.alt_text: Policymakers led by Bank of Canada governor Tiff Macklem keep the benchmark overnight lending rate at 5 per cent, the highest level in 22 years.
Exports and imports in July were impacted by a 13-day dock workers strike in British Columbia that disrupted operations at two of Canada’s three busiest ports.
FILE PHOTO: A view shows condo buildings in Liberty Village neighbourhood in Toronto, Ontario, Canada July 13, 2022.  REUTERS/Carlos Osorio
None of the 222 wineries in the region report any direct fire damage. But they suffer a big drop in revenues as tourists stay away during the peak month of August.
Statistics Canada reports that the modest increase in June retail is driven by rises at motor vehicle and parts dealers, along with petrol stations and fuel vendors.

Residential buildings stand in the Liberty Village neighborhood of Toronto, Ontario, Canada, on Saturday, Feb. 15, 2020. A shrinking supply of available homes for sale in Canada's largest city continued to drive prices higher last month, bringing annual increases to the strongest in more than two years.
