The island’s Indigenous community of fewer than 2,000 souls scrapes by without potable water or sanitation.

site_title: RBNZ and New Zealand treasury at odds over double-dip recession
summary: New Zealand's central bank and Treasury are at odds over the need for another recession to control inflation. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) projects a double-dip recession to bring inflation to 2.7% by 2024, while the Treasury predicts steady growth with inflation below 3% by year-end. Economists agree the economy needs to slow sharply, and a sharp contraction may be necessary to bring inflation down, potentially leading to another interest rate hike.

images.alt_text: The New Zealand government forecast a budget deficit of NZ$11.38 billion (S$9.14 billion) for the fiscal year ending June 30, 2024, larger than a deficit of NZ$7.56 billion forecast at the budget in May.
The increase in volumes offset a third straight quarter of weaker export prices as slower economic growth in China hurts global commodity prices.
Homes remain unaffordable for many and mortgage rates are set to be higher for longer, Kelvin Davidson says.
New Zealand’s general election on Oct 14 may also produce a result that fuels house-price gains.

site_title: Biden’s new ‘New Deal’ falls short in two critical areas
summary: President Joe Biden's new economic plans, dubbed the "New Deal," share similarities with Franklin D. Roosevelt's policies, but fall short in two critical areas: financial regulations and advocacy for workers' rights. The Inflation Reduction Act includes public infrastructure and climate change initiatives, echoing Roosevelt's priorities. However, Biden's plans lack robust financial regulations and effective advocacy for workers' rights, raising concerns about their impact on the economy and society.

images.alt_text: PHILADELPHIA, PENNSYLVANIA - SEPTEMBER 4: U.S. President Joe Biden addresses union workers at Sheet Metal Workers Local 19 on September 4, 2023 in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. During his speech, President Biden talked about his record on job creation and support for labor unions.   Mark Makela/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Mark Makela / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Hatten Land to resume Harbour City project after unit restructuring gets nod
summary: Hatten Land's subsidiary, Gold Mart, has secured majority approval from unsecured creditors to waive 60% of liquidated damages in its scheme of arrangement. This move will allow the company to resume construction activities and marketing for its Harbour City project in Melaka, which was stalled due to a legal dispute and the Covid-19 pandemic. The company plans to complete the project within three years and has preserved its cash reserves.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
An artist impression of the Harbour City project in Melaka.
Hatten Land to pay China Construction Yangtze River RM1.5m
Hatten Land Q3 net loss widens to RM37.2 million

site_title: Japan PM reshuffles Cabinet, promises ‘drastic’ measures
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida has reshuffled his Cabinet, promising "drastic" economic measures to address the country's high inflation rates. The reshuffle, which saw five women appointed to key positions, aims to boost Kishida's flagging popularity ahead of next year's re-election. Despite minor changes, analysts say the reshuffle may not significantly improve public support for Kishida, who faces criticism over issues including the new identification system and a scandal involving his son.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida speaks during the leaders talk of the ASEAN-Indo Pacific Forum (AIPF) in Jakarta, Indonesia September 6, 2023. Adek Berry/Pool via REUTERS/File Photo

Japan Prime Minister Fumio Kishida says: “On economic measures, I want them to protect the people’s lives from price hikes and to reinforce the trend of wage increases and investment expansion. I want to carry out drastic steps, supported firmly by a necessary budget,”

site_title: Turning disputes into deals, one mediation at a time
summary: Mediation can be a catalyst for resolving disputes and fostering new business opportunities. By proposing mediation, parties demonstrate their value for the business relationship and encourage open dialogue. A professional mediator helps disputing parties articulate their interests and find common ground, potentially leading to settlement and new deals. This approach avoids the consequences of legal action, such as confidentiality and reputational damage, and can repair relationships. Mediation can be a collaborative process that goes beyond dispute resolution, creating new opportunities post-dispute.

images.alt_text: International businesses should proactively put in place policies and plans on resolving disputes.

site_title: US: Markets slump as tech stocks face pressure
summary: US stocks fell on Tuesday as the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite Index slid 1.0% to 13,773.61, while the S&P 500 lost 0.6% to 4,461.90. Disappointing revenue and guidance from Oracle, combined with Apple's iPhone release, contributed to the decline. Other major tech names, including Amazon and Alphabet, also saw their shares drop. Investors are awaiting key consumer inflation data due on Wednesday, which may influence the Federal Reserve's upcoming rate decision.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., August 29, 2023.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Deutsche Bank scraps 60% of trading apps with costs in focus
summary: Deutsche Bank has decommissioned 60% of its trading apps to reduce costs, part of a broader effort to increase cost efficiency. The move aims to improve the bank's cost-to-income ratio and follows recent cost-cutting measures, including job cuts. CEO Christian Sewing has set a medium-term profitability target of over 10% in return on tangible equity. Investment banking activity is expected to increase, driven by private equity investments, which may boost advisory services and equity capital markets. The bank is starting to see early signs of a turnaround in investment banking activity.

site_title: Companies may be only as ‘good’ as their controlling shareholders allow them to be
summary: Companies in Singapore may only be as "good" as their controlling shareholders allow them to be, according to a recent Singapore Corporate Awards 2023. The awards recognized companies with strong corporate governance practices, but also highlighted the influence of controlling shareholders on a company's performance. Directors who don't align with the views of controlling shareholders are unlikely to last long, suggesting that the power of controlling shareholders plays a significant role in determining a company's success.

images.alt_text: Ben Paul
CDL's Yiong Yim Ming says disruptions to the financial landscape are changing how companies and investors look at numbers and financial stewardship.
It is vital for companies to provide transparent information that offers perspective in their annual reports, says Dr Hanny Kusnadi.
Financial materiality and impact materiality have to be effectively harmonised to attain corporate excellence.
In the years ahead, a focus on corporate governance will be critical in an increasingly uncertain world, says Standard Chartered's Patrick Lee.
Black swan events – or unknown unknowns – are potentially catastrophic events that are rare, impossible to predict and outside our control.
Recent court and enforcement cases highlight the importance for directors to be vigilant and diligent.
From left: Wong Kan Seng, chairman, UOB; Danny Teoh, chairman, Keppel Corporation; Rolando C Gapud, executive chairman, Del Monte Pacific; and Michael Lau, chairman, Sing Investments & Finance

The Business Times speaks to the boards of the nine companies that have garnered the awards for Best Risk Management at the Singapore Corporate Awards 2023 about how they successfully guided their respective companies through the challenges.

Recipients of the Best Chief Executive award at the 18th Singapore Corporate Awards. From left: Seah Kiin Peng, CEO of BRC Asia; Jeffery Tan, group general counsel of Jardine Cycle & Carriage, representing CEO Benjamin Birks; and Jeanette Chang, CEO of Baker Technology.
Investors today are more aware that better-governed companies, on balance, tend to make better investments.

site_title: Japan’s Aug wholesale inflation slows for 8th straight month, stays above BOJ target
summary: Japan's wholesale inflation slowed to 3.2% in August for the 8th straight month, matching market forecasts. This is a decrease from a revised 3.4% rise in July and a peak of 10.6% in December last year. The slowdown is attributed to a decrease in global commodity costs and the weak yen. Despite this, Japan's broader consumer inflation remains above the Bank of Japan's 2% target, prompting the central bank to maintain ultra-loose monetary policy until domestic demand-driven price increases replace supply-driven rises.

site_title: Citi’s family office clients are hunting for direct investments
summary: Citi's family office clients are actively seeking direct investments in private markets due to volatility from inflation and interest rates. Over half of the 268 surveyed family offices, representing $565 billion in net worth, are looking for opportunistic direct deals in sectors like technology, real estate, and healthcare. These investments involve buying directly into companies or assets, with allocations to private equity and real estate making up about a quarter of their portfolios. Family offices are focusing on less risky investments in developed markets, targeting companies generating cash, amid macroeconomic uncertainty.

images.alt_text: 0816CKS TEN FOREIGN NATIONALS TO BE CHARGED FOR OFFENCES INCLUDING FORGERY AND MONEY LAUNDERING WITH AN ESTIMATED VALUE OF ABOUT ONE BILLION IN CASH AND VARIOUS ASSETS SEIZED, FROZEN OR ISSUED WITH PROHIBITION OF DISPOSAL ORDERS

(FILES) In this file photo taken on July 14, 2014, the Citigroup Center is viewed in midtown Manhattan. - Citigroup announced on August 25, 2022, it will shutter its retail banking business in Russia after failing to find a local buyer. The wind-down will begin in the current quarter and will affect around 2,300 employees in 15 branches across the country. The global banking giant had indicated as early as April 2021 that it intended to stop offering services to individuals in Russia as part of a global reorganization leading to the withdrawal of 14 markets in Asia, Europe, the Middle East, Africa and Mexico. (Photo by Timothy A. CLARY / AFP)
Citi plans to complete the sale of the ninth consumer unit in Indonesia later this year.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall as SAP drags, investors await US data, ECB
summary: European stocks fell 0.2% on Tuesday, with SAP dragging down the Stoxx 600 index, as prices of base metals fell on a stronger dollar. Basic resources lost 0.5% and Germany's DAX dropped 0.5% due to SAP's weak forecast from US tech firm Oracle. Investors remain cautious ahead of US inflation data and the European Central Bank's rate decision later this week.

images.alt_text: The Nasdaq slid 1.0 per cent to end at 13,773.61, while the broad-based S&P 500 also lost 0.6 per cent at 4,461.90 on Tuesday.

site_title: Australia’s biggest bank says fierce mortgage fight isn’t over
summary: Australia's largest bank, Commonwealth Bank, expects fierce competition for home loans to continue into next year, putting pressure on its largest business. The bank's decline in total housing loans in July is likely to extend into August, according to executive general manager Michael Baumann. With about 25% of the mortgage market, Commonwealth Bank is grappling with challenges to profitability amid rebounding property prices and higher borrowing costs. The bank's decision to prioritize shareholder returns has led to a share loss, with Baumann indicating a limit to further share giveaways.

images.alt_text: CBA’s smaller rivals National Australia Bank, Westpac and ANZ Group are expected give third-quarter updates over the course of the month.

site_title: Oil jumps 2% to near 10-month high as Opec predicts tight supplies
summary: Oil prices surged 2% to a near 10-month high, reaching $92.06 a barrel, driven by OPEC's tighter supply outlook and optimism over resilient energy demand in major economies. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) forecast robust growth in global oil demand, citing stronger-than-expected major economies. Saudi Arabia and Russia extended voluntary supply cuts, further contributing to the tight supply. Oil prices remain technically overbought for the eighth consecutive day, with Brent futures reaching their highest levels since November 2022.

images.alt_text: With European economies strained by higher interest rates, there are fears that some gas demand might never come back.
Brent crude settled down 1 cent to US$90.64 a barrel while US West Texas Intermediate crude settled down 22 cents to US$87.29 on Monday.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Thomson Medical, ValueMax, Hatten Land, CDL, GuocoLand
summary: Thomson Medical Group plans to apply to the Singapore Exchange to restore its public float to 10% after dipping to 9.98%. ValueMax has launched its eighth series of commercial paper in digital securities, expecting to raise S$20-50 million. Hatten Land's proposed scheme of arrangement for its Malaysian subsidiary Gold Mart was approved, and the company will restart construction activities and marketing campaigns. CDL won a tendered plot along Champions Way in Woodlands at S$904 per square foot, while GuocoLand won a plot at Lentor Central at S$982 per square foot.

site_title: Tencent scores biggest anime game with ‘Blue Protocol’ deal
summary: Tencent Holdings has secured the rights to develop and publish the mobile edition of Bandai Namco's 'Blue Protocol', a multiplayer online role-playing game. The deal, which includes global distribution rights, is part of Tencent's strategy to expand its presence in Japan's entertainment industry and leverage the game's popularity to boost its international growth. The PC edition of the game launched in Japan in June and attracted 600,000 players in its first week, with a mobile release expected in the coming year.

images.alt_text: Signage for Tencent Holdings Ltd. atop an entrance to an office building in Shanghai, China, on Tuesday, March 22, 2022. Tencent is scheduled to release earnings results on March 23. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: Bank of England bond sell-off likened to Brown’s notorious gold losses
summary: The Bank of England's bond sell-off, part of its quantitative tightening (QT) program, is being likened to former Chancellor Gordon Brown's infamous decision to "sell gold at the bottom of the market" in 1999-2002. The BOE's aggressive asset sales are resulting in significant losses for the taxpayer, with estimates suggesting annual losses of around £3 billion. Critics argue that the BOE is selling assets too quickly, pushing down prices and deepening losses, and that its estimates of the program's impact on financial markets are too low.

images.alt_text: Businesses expect wages will rise by 5.0 per cent over the coming year, unchanged from their expectations in July.
Britain’s annual consumer price inflation rate cooled to 6.8 per cent in July- still the highest rate among the Group of Seven economies.
Excluding bonuses, the average earnings of British workers went up 7.8 per cent in the three months to June 2023 compared with a year ago.
British inflation has been slow to fall since it hit a 41-year high of 11.1per cent last year, and at 6.8 per cent in July was the highest of any major economy.

site_title: Creating value through social sustainability
summary: Companies can create value through social sustainability by integrating social objectives into their core strategy, driven by the board and senior management. The social aspect of ESG (environmental, social, and governance) covers talent management and societal contributions, shaping organizational culture and stakeholder relationships. Investing in social sustainability can provide long-term benefits, but requires a value-driven approach, overcoming challenges such as budget constraints and cultural impediments. Experts emphasize the importance of aligning organizational purpose with community values, fostering a more equitable and inclusive world.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Wednesday; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) up 0.1% at 3,217.57. Gainers outnumbered losers 55 to 50, and major local banks such as UOB, DBS, and OCBC rose. The rally follows a decline in global markets, with the Nasdaq and S&P 500 falling 1% and 0.6% respectively. The STI is expected to track regional decline.

images.alt_text: Generic pictures of SGX

site_title: Thomson Medical’s public float dips under 10%
summary: Thomson Medical Group's public float has dropped to 9.98% due to a large sale of shares by public shareholders. The company plans to apply to the Singapore Exchange (SGX) for a three-month extension to restore the float to 10%. If the SGX denies the request, Thomson Medical Group may be directed to delist and offer a fair and reasonable exit to public shareholders. The company's counter closed at S$0.06, a 1.7% increase from the previous day.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek

site_title: What should be on the board agenda for climate risks
summary: Corporate boards must address climate risks by setting the right tone and overseeing effective management. They should ask pertinent questions, consider key issues, and acquire relevant expertise. Boards should conduct a robust materiality assessment, install a governance structure, and steer the company towards an integrated strategic approach. Climate risks can disrupt operations, evaporate demand, and impose obsolescence, but also bring business opportunities. Boards must determine their company's climate-risk appetite, set objectives and strategies, and adopt a framework for managing climate risks. Effective disclosure of climate-related information is crucial for the transition to a low-carbon economy.

images.alt_text: Black swan events – or unknown unknowns – are potentially catastrophic events that are rare, impossible to predict and outside our control.
Recent court and enforcement cases highlight the importance for directors to be vigilant and diligent.
All businesses must be onboard the sustainability impact ship and set the directions into the horizon
Generic shots of SGX

site_title: At least 2,300 dead in 'epic' Libya floods, thousands more missing
summary: At least 2,300 people have been killed and thousands more are missing in Libya after catastrophic flash floods devastated the eastern coastal city of Derna, leaving over 7,000 injured. The floods, caused by torrential rains from Storm Daniel, have also destroyed entire neighborhoods and shattered the Mediterranean coastal city, with multiple nations offering to send aid and rescue teams to help the war-scarred country. The death toll is expected to rise further, with some estimates suggesting it may reach thousands.

images.alt_text: A flooded area after heavy rains in Hong Kong, Sept 8, 2023.

site_title: Google’s search domination began with plan to combat rivals
summary: Google's dominance in the search market began with a plan to combat rivals by making its search engine the default tool for as many browsers as possible. In 2003, Google chief economist Hal Varian warned executives to consider ways to retain users and recommended evaluating product ideas based on technological merit, value to users, and revenue potential. Google now maintains a monopoly in online search by paying over $10 billion annually to tech rivals and phone manufacturers to be set as the preselected option. The US Justice Department is seeking remedies to break off Alphabet's search business, citing Google's dominance and lack of competition.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A logo is pictured at Google's European Engineering Center in Zurich, Switzerland July 19,  2018   REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo
Google and other US tech giants have also faced investigations from US, British and EU regulators in recent years as authorities crack down on their business practices.
Google’s ad policies already ban manipulating digital media to deceive or mislead people about politics, social issues, or matters of public concern.
Consumers express frustration over app spending and alleged monopoly while Google remains silent on proposed settlement.

site_title: Foreign direct investment in Germany dives to 3.5 billion euros in H1
summary: Foreign direct investment (FDI) in Germany dropped to 3.5 billion euros in the first half of 2023, its lowest level in nearly 20 years. This decline indicates a loss of attractiveness for Germany as a business location, according to the Germany Economic Institute. Despite Chancellor Olaf Scholz's optimism about Germany's industrial prospects, experts attribute the decline to "exorbitant subsidies" and doubt about the quality of the location, rather than genuine investment interest.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTOl The skyline of the banking district is pictured in Frankfurt, October 21, 2014. REUTERS/Ralph Orlowski

site_title: Escaped murderer steals rifle, outwits huge US manhunt
summary: Escaped Brazilian murderer Danelo Souza Cavalcante dodged police efforts to capture him after making a daring escape from Chester County Prison nearly two weeks ago. He stole a rifle from a home in rural Pennsylvania, prompting authorities to close schools and lock down residents. Authorities have deployed elite SWAT teams, roadblocks, and armored vehicles to track him down, but Cavalcante remains "extremely dangerous" and has outwitted multiple law enforcement efforts.

images.alt_text: Paul Landis, one of the Secret Service agents just feet away from John F. Kennedy when he was assassinated, shows where he was on the day of the slain president's funeral, at his home in Cleveland on Aug 7, 2023. 60 years later, Landis is telling his story in full for the first time.
US actor Danny Masterson was sentenced to 30 years in prison for raping two women at his home two decades ago.
Peter Navarro, an advisor to former US President Donald Trump, leaves after being found guilty of contempt of Congress at the E. Barrett Prettyman Courthouse in Washington, DC, Sept 7, 2023

site_title: Apple’s iPhone 15 debut includes higher price on top model
summary: Apple unveiled four new iPhone models, the iPhone 15, 15 Plus, 15 Pro, and 15 Pro Max, with upgraded camera systems, improved performance, and a USB-C connector. The Pro models start at $999, with the Pro Max at $1,199, a $100 increase from last year. The new iPhones also feature a programmable "action button" and improved graphics capabilities. The company is looking to pull out of a sales slump and compete with the sluggish smartphone market, particularly in China, where government workers are banned from using its products.

site_title: Adobe, others join voluntary US scheme to manage AI risks
summary: Adobe and five other companies, including IBM, Nvidia, and Google, have joined a voluntary US scheme to manage AI risks. The commitments, announced in July, require steps such as watermarking AI-generated content to prevent its use for destructive purposes. The White House is working on an executive order on AI and has partnered with the private sector to address the issue. The move is seen as a stopgap measure, as Congress has yet to introduce significant AI legislation. The partnerships aim to harness AI's benefits while managing its risks.

site_title: Inflation dragged real US household incomes down 2.3% in 2022
summary: US household incomes decreased 2.3% in 2022, driven by inflation, with median income falling to $74,580. The poverty rate edged down to 11.5%, but a post-tax measure rose to 12.4%. Income inequality narrowed, with median incomes at the 90th percentile decreasing to $216,000 and those at the bottom 10th percentile increasing to $17,100.

images.alt_text: The net share of owners reporting higher nominal sales in the past three months falls to a three-year low of minus 14 per cent.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as investors await key inflation data
summary: US stocks opened lower on Tuesday, September 12, as investors awaited key inflation data, which may influence the Federal Reserve's interest-rate path. The Dow Jones fell 43.70 points, the S&P 500 dropped 14.19 points, and the Nasdaq Composite declined 58.96 points. The market began the week on a strong footing, but investors' focus shifted to inflation data, leading to a decline in opening prices.

site_title: G20 divisions diminish its potential
summary: The G20 summit in India, marked by over 200 hours of negotiations and 300 bilateral meetings, resulted in a modest success, with the body failing to fully realize its potential amidst growing geopolitical divisions. Key outcomes include the African Union's permanent membership, a proposed India-Middle East-Europe Economic Corridor, and a pledge to pursue and encourage efforts to triple renewable energy capacity globally. However, environmental NGOs criticized the lack of a deadline for phasing out fossil fuels, and the summit failed to address the ongoing conflict in Ukraine.

images.alt_text: Fellow G20 nations hailed India’s success in reaching agreement on a joint communique that remained in doubt just days before world leaders gathered in New Delhi for their most significant annual diplomatic event.
PM Lee notes that more private funds are needed to combat the “existential” threat of climate change.

Washington, Saudi Arabia, the European Union, the United Arab Emirates and others will sign an agreement on the sidelines of the G20 summit to explore a railway and port project to augment trade flows between Europe and India, say officials.
India plays host to the G20 Summit this year, taking up the mantle from Indonesia.
Two leaders – China's Xi Jinping and Russia's Vladimir Putin – will not be in attendance when the G20 summit convenes this weekend in New Delhi.

site_title: Boeing deliveries decrease in August as it wrestles with manufacturing defect
summary: Boeing delivered 35 planes in August, its lowest number since April, due to a manufacturing defect on the 737 MAX. The company has handed over 344 planes to customers in the first eight months of 2023, a jump from the same period last year. Despite booking new orders for 43 planes, Boeing's 737 deliveries are expected to be on the "low end" of its target, with 22 narrowbody 737s delivered in August. Airbus delivered 433 aircraft over the same period, including 117 planes in August.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Boeing logo is seen at the 54th International Paris Airshow at Le Bourget Airport near Paris, France, June 18, 2023. REUTERS/Benoit Tessier/File Photo

site_title: Two more Chinese firms cease public project funding amid deepening debt woes
summary: Two Chinese transport and infrastructure companies in Jiangsu province have ceased participating in public project funding, joining a growing number of local government financial vehicles (LGFVs) going independent amid China's slowing economy. LGFVs, set up to fund infrastructure investment, now represent a major risk with combined debt of around $9 trillion. Beijing is putting LGFVs under tighter scrutiny and barring new ones from selling bonds publicly, with some nudged to operate on a commercial basis and pay off debts with implicit government guarantees.

site_title:
HSBC, Morgan Stanley among creditors as 
money-laundering probe expands to associates
summary: HSBC and Morgan Stanley are among potential creditors of companies linked to individuals charged in a Singapore anti-money laundering operation. The investigation has expanded to associates of 10 individuals, with assets totaling S$1.8 billion. Business filings show at least six banks, including HSBC and Morgan Stanley, as creditors to eight entities linked to 24 associates of the charged individuals.

images.alt_text: TEN FOREIGN NATIONALS TO BE CHARGED FOR OFFENCES INCLUDING FORGERY AND MONEY LAUNDERING WITH AN ESTIMATED VALUE OF ABOUT ONE BILLION IN CASH AND VARIOUS ASSETS SEIZED, FROZEN OR ISSUED WITH PROHIBITION OF DISPOSAL ORDERSThe total value of the properties and other goods seized in the recent raid amounts to over S$1 billion.

Quashing speculation among some that the arrests were linked to a visit by China’s Foreign Minister Wang Yi on Aug 10, Shanmugam (above) said there was absolutely no connection between the two events.

site_title: US takes on Google in landmark antitrust trial
summary: The US government has launched a landmark antitrust trial against Google, alleging the tech giant unfairly dominated online search by forging exclusivity contracts with device makers and mobile operators. The 10-week trial, the biggest US antitrust case against a big tech company since Microsoft in 2001, centers on Google's payments of billions of dollars to secure its search engine default status on phones and web browsers. The US Department of Justice claims this created a "feedback loop" that stifled competition, with Google's dominance making it nearly impossible for rivals to compete.

images.alt_text: Google and other US tech giants have also faced investigations from US, British and EU regulators in recent years as authorities crack down on their business practices.

site_title: TikTok launches online shopping in the US
summary: TikTok has launched its online shopping feature in the US, allowing its over 150 million users to purchase items directly from videos and live streams on the app. The platform offers tools for content creators, brands, and merchants to create shoppable content, and has integrated its shopping service with third-party platforms like Shopify and Salesforce. This move aims to replicate the success of Asian e-commerce platforms like Shein and Temu. The online marketplace is available in several countries, including Thailand, Vietnam, and the UK, in addition to the US.

site_title: US bank lobby argues regulators must repropose sweeping capital plan
summary: A group of six major US banking trade organizations has argued that a recent proposal to hike bank capital requirements violates federal law due to insufficient analysis and must be redone. The proposal, which aims to raise capital by 16% overall, lacks sufficient public data and analysis, according to the group. They claim the Federal Reserve, FDIC, and Office of the Comptroller of the Currency should freeze work on the new rules until all necessary data is collected and issue a new proposal.

images.alt_text: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corp (FDIC) says industry profits dip 11.3 per cent to US$70.8 billion in the second quarter.
Under the new rules, banks with US$100 billion of assets or more will need to issue enough long-term debt to cover capital losses in times of severe stress.
A bank run on the midsized Californian lender Silicon Valley Bank (SVB) in March over interest-rate concerns quickly spiraled into one of the most acute banking crises in years.

site_title: Aung San Suu Kyi's son 'extremely worried' about his mother's health
summary: Aung San Suu Kyi, the 78-year-old Nobel laureate, is "extremely worried" about her health due to bouts of dizziness, vomiting, and a serious gum disease. Detained for over two years, she is being refused permission to see an outside doctor and is subjected to solitary confinement. Her son, Kim Aris, claims she is struggling to eat and is not robust as she once was, sparking concerns about her well-being. The international community has called for her unconditional release, with many governments imposing sanctions on Myanmar.

images.alt_text: (FILES) in this file photo taken on January 17, 2020, Myanmar's State Counsellor Aung San Suu Kyi poses for pictures during a welcoming ceremony for China's President Xi Jinping at the Presidential Palace in Naypyidaw. - Myanmar junta court jails Suu Kyi for six years on August 15, 2022, for corruption. (Photo by AFP)

site_title: Global economy to ‘catch its breath’ in Q4 as monetary policy weighs on demand: BNP Paribas
summary: The global economy is expected to slow down in the fourth quarter of 2023 and beyond due to monetary policy weighing on demand. Central banks' efforts to curb inflation are taking time, but inflation remains anchored. The report from BNP Paribas notes a slowdown in US growth, stagnation in the eurozone, a shallow recovery in China, and tepid growth in emerging markets. This suggests a global economic slowdown, with recession in the US and stagnation in the eurozone.

images.alt_text: Zhao Yifan
The White House has asked Congress to swiftly vote on a budget extension to avoid a government shutdown, which could paralyse nearly the entire federal government.
Pricing in derivatives markets indicated that traders see a 62 per cent chance that the ECB will leave interest rates at 3.75 per cent; and a 38 per cent chance of a 25 bp increase.
Inflation concerns and hawkish remarks from the European Central Bank policymakers have led money markets to increase their bets on a further rate hike in next week’s policy decision.
Tokyo, Taipei and Manila financial markets edged up but Hong Kong, Shanghai, Seoul, Sydney, Singapore, Wellington and Jakarta were all down at midday on Tuesday.

site_title: Keppel power plant to be built on former chemical plant site; nature groups say further study needed
summary: Singapore's first hydrogen-ready power plant will be built on a "largely brownfield site" previously occupied by a chemical plant. The Keppel Sakra Cogen Plant, set to be completed by 2026, will be located on Jurong Island. Environmental groups criticized the power plant's environmental impact assessment (EIA) report, citing inadequate attention to land-based biodiversity and the potential impact of hot water discharge on marine life. The URA clarified that the site is a brownfield, but nature groups argue that a further study is needed to mitigate potential impacts on terrestrial habitats.

site_title: TSMC to invest up to US$100 million in Arm Holdings' IPO
summary: TSMC, the world's largest contract chipmaker, plans to invest up to $100 million in Arm Holdings' initial public share offering (IPO), valued at up to $4.87 billion. This investment is part of TSMC's commitment to Arm's success and health. Other major clients, including Apple and Nvidia, have also signed up as cornerstone investors. TSMC also agreed to purchase a 10% equity interest in IMS Nanofabrication Global from Intel for up to $432.8 million.

site_title: India’s industrial output up more than expected in July
summary: India's industrial output rose 5.7% year-on-year in July, exceeding expectations of a 4.8% expansion, according to data from the Ministry of Statistics. This followed a 3.1% increase in June. Manufacturing output rose 4.6% year-on-year, while electricity generation increased 8% and mining activities rose 10.7% compared to the same period last year.

site_title: UK mortgage arrears jump 28% as high rates squeeze borrowers
summary: UK mortgage arrears have surged 28% in the year through June, with loans in arrears climbing 13% in the second quarter, according to Bank of England data. The total value of home loans with late payments now accounts for 1.02% of all outstanding mortgages, or £16.9 billion. Higher interest rates are compounding the impact of soaring inflation and squeezed household finances, leaving borrowers struggling to keep up with repayments. Despite low overall volumes of arrears, the situation is becoming increasingly painful for borrowers.

site_title: Scoot among airlines, suppliers warn of hit from RTX engine snag
summary: RTX, a US firm, has disclosed a rare manufacturing flaw in its Pratt & Whitney Geared Turbofan (GTF) engines, which could lead to the cracking of engine components and ground hundreds of Airbus jets. The issue will require 600-700 engines to be pulled for quality inspections between 2023 and 2026, affecting an average of 350 jets per year. This adds to the troubles of the airline industry, which is already grappling with staff shortages and new plane deliveries. Industry suppliers and airlines, including Scoot and Air New Zealand, are warning of potential hits to their operations and profits.

images.alt_text: Scoot itself flew over 1 million passengers in May, more than double from 418,700 passenger count in the same month last year.
Airbus plans to introduce a hydrogen-powered commercial aircraft by 2035.

site_title: Buying a good stock is easy, but can you hold?
summary: A savvy investor can hold a winning stock, but it's challenging. A case study of Netflix's stock shows how a $3.30 share in 2007 increased to over $442, but the journey was volatile. To overcome doubts and make informed decisions, three key principles can be applied: 1) don't fall into hate with your stock, focusing on the positives despite declines; 2) beware of false narratives created by the financial media; and 3) it's often better to hold a losing stock longer than sell a winning one, as the latter can lead to missed gains.

images.alt_text:
(FILES) The Netflix logo is seen on top of their office building in Hollywood, California, March 2, 2022. - April 19, 2023, after shipping out more than five billion DVDs in trademark red envelopes, Netflix has finally called time on the movie mail-out subscription business that launched today's Hollywood streaming colossus.
The announcement, made in a letter to shareholders before this week's earnings call, was greeted with bafflement by some broadband binge-watchers who did not know Netflix's DVD business was still running -- or that it existed in the first place. (Photo by Chris DELMAS / AFP)
Since the launch of Disney+ in November 2019, the world’s largest entertainment company had sought to attract streaming subscribers with unsustainably low prices.
Netflix has been looking for new ways to make money as streaming competition intensifies and it nears market saturation in the United States.

site_title: EU Parliament passes Bill hiking renewable energy targets
summary: The European Union Parliament has passed a bill increasing renewable energy targets to 42.5% of EU energy by 2030, up from the current 32% target. The law, which requires EU countries to greenlight the final bill, aims to spur investments in wind and solar energy, with a focus on local manufacturing. France secured carve-outs for nuclear energy, a low-carbon but non-renewable source, to secure support. The law is seen as a key step in the EU's efforts to curb climate change and shift away from fossil fuels.

images.alt_text: Solar panels atop a hops plantation in the Bavarian Holledau region in Au, Germany. EU successes in scaling up use of clean energy in the last year include reaching a record 41 GW of new solar energy capacity installed.
Across the EU’s 27 member countries, fossil fuel-based power generation fell by 17 per cent in the first half of the year, compared with the first half of 2022.
German farmers supporting the EU's Green Deal bill demonstrate in front of the European Parliament, in Strasbourg, eastern France, on July 11, 2023.

site_title: Yen gives back some gains, US dollar rebounds before inflation data
summary: The yen slipped 0.2% against the US dollar on Tuesday after its largest daily gain since mid-July, as interest rate differentials with the US continued to pressure the currency. The US dollar rebounded, regaining lost ground after its biggest daily fall since July 13. The Bank of Japan's governor, Kazuo Ueda, hinted at the possibility of ending negative interest rates, but did not provide a clear timeline. The US dollar index rose 0.2% to 104.80, ahead of Wednesday's inflation data, which is expected to influence the Federal Reserve's rate decisions.

site_title: Digital literacy workshop with getai twist entertains and educates seniors
summary: DBS Foundation and POSB organised five getai edutainment roadshows to promote digital literacy among senior citizens in Singapore. The events, held at hawker centres, concluded with a digital literacy workshop at Mei Ling Market & Food Centre, attracting around 350 participants. The initiative aims to engage seniors with digital literacy education, encouraging them to use mobile wallet apps like DBS PayLah!. The events are part of DBS' broader efforts to bolster digital-inclusion efforts in Singapore, with a goal of committing up to S$1 billion and 1.5 million volunteer hours over the next 10 years to support underprivileged communities.

images.alt_text: RWS staff volunteers (second from left and second from right) with homemaker Siti Rosninah (far left) and her family.
Soon Li Coffee Stall in Tiong Bahru market displaying the SGQR code for quick, cashless payments. Stalls like this are on board the subsidised meals programme by DBS/POSB.

site_title: Julius Baer can grow to US$1 trillion wealth manager: CEO
summary: Julius Baer CEO Philipp Rickenbacher stated that the Swiss bank can reach a US$1 trillion wealth manager by the 2030s through organic growth, with no specific timeline or commitment to the goal. Despite current market uncertainties, Rickenbacher expressed cautious optimism about the resilience of the global economy. The bank has no plans for significant expansion in the US or mainland China, and instead focuses on its current international network to generate growth.

images.alt_text: The cruise industry could enjoy a boost from older adults with money to spend on travel.

Under chief executive officer Philipp Rickenbacher, Julius Baer has been moving past a difficult period that saw an investigation into its Latin American business and impairments at its Italian fund unit Kairos.
Julius Baer manages about 424.1 billion Swiss francs at year-end, making it the third-largest Swiss bank after Credit Suisse and UBS.

site_title: Deutsche Bank launches new private credit business
summary: Deutsche Bank has launched a new private credit business, DB Investment Partners (DBIP), to raise outside money for private credit opportunities. DBIP will invest in various private debt strategies, targeting institutional clients and high-net-worth investors. The new venture will operate independently of Deutsche Bank's existing private debt business and is expected to benefit from dealflow generated through the bank's lending arms. DBIP's CEO is Raheman Meghji, while Jon Aisbitt will serve as chair. This move follows other banks, such as JPMorgan Chase and Societe Generale, entering the private credit market, which has grown to $1.5 trillion.

images.alt_text: The move comes as private equity firms and their deals become an important source of business for banks.

site_title: Positioning for income in a high-rate environment
summary: High interest rates have led to a surge in bank deposit rates, but whether these returns can keep pace with inflation remains uncertain. Yield-focused investors can enhance their returns by capturing both dividends and bond yields, and maintaining a diversified asset allocation across multiple asset classes can help. Historically, the Federal Reserve typically lowers interest rates six to nine months after halting rate hikes, suggesting a potential end to the tightening cycle, and remaining invested could be a sensible approach to avoid missing out on a rebound in risk assets.

images.alt_text: Pricing in derivatives markets indicated that traders see a 62 per cent chance that the ECB will leave interest rates at 3.75 per cent; and a 38 per cent chance of a 25 bp increase.

Recent auctions have been weak as even long-term buyers wait for an eventual rise in yields after the BOJ, so far an outlier among hawkish global central banks, tweaked its yield curve control policy late in July.

site_title: Dutch art detective recovers stolen Van Gogh
summary: Dutch art detective Arthur Brand recovered the 1884 Vincent van Gogh painting "Parsonage Garden at Nuenen in Spring" after a three-and-a-half-year investigation. The painting, worth between $4.4 million and $8.8 million, was stolen from a museum during the coronavirus lockdown. Brand, known for tracing high-profile lost artworks, confirmed the painting's authenticity and said it was "one of the greatest moments of my life." The painting was recovered at Brand's Amsterdam home, stuffed in a blue Ikea bag.

images.alt_text: "Sermon on the Mount" by Frans Francken the Younger. Some experts believe this 17th-century work, now up for sale, was originally stolen by the Nazis, but no clues to its pre-war owner have turned up after years of searching.

From left: The curatorial team of Julia McHugh, Marshall Price, Mark Olson and Julianne Miao, who oversaw the exhibition ÒAct as if You Are a Curator,Ó that was put together by asking ChatGPT to organize it, at Duke UniversityÕs Nasher Museum of Art, in Durham, N.C., Sept. 1, 2023. The AI chatbot program selected 21 artworks from the museumÕs collection of nearly 14,000 objects, a very small show that included questionable inclusions, mistitled objects and errant informational texts. (Eamon Queeney/The New York Times)

site_title: Japan PM to replace foreign and defence ministers
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida is set to replace his foreign and defense ministers in a cabinet reshuffle aimed at boosting his sagging popularity. Yoshimasa Hayashi will be succeeded by Yoko Kamikawa, a former justice minister, while Minoru Kihara will replace Yasukazu Hamada as defense minister, currently heading a Japan-Taiwan interparliamentary group. The move comes as Kishida faces declining approval ratings, with recent polls showing lower approval than disapproval ratings.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida speaks during the leaders talk of the ASEAN-Indo Pacific Forum (AIPF) in Jakarta, Indonesia September 6, 2023. Adek Berry/Pool via REUTERS/File Photo

site_title: China, HK stocks slip as traders await stabilisation signs, policy measures
summary: China's blue-chip CSI 300 Index and the Shanghai Composite Index ended the session down 0.2% on Tuesday, despite recent data showing signs of economic stabilisation. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index dropped 0.4%, with shares in consumer discretionary and automobiles rising, while real estate developers and semiconductor makers fell. Analysts expect China's economy to face new headwinds and may need more aggressive easing measures to ensure a real recovery.

images.alt_text: The Hang Seng Index sank 1.43 per cent, or 260.42 points, to 17,941.65 on Monday morning.
Beijing has taken a number of steps in recent weeks to restore investor confidence, from lowering transaction costs to restricting some top shareholders from selling stakes.
Investors monitor stock prices at a securities exchange house in Shanghai, China on Friday, 31 December 2010.
The Hang Seng China Enterprises Index gained as much as 2.4 per cent, with property names China Resources Land and China Overseas Land & Investment leading the advance.

epa10811381 People walk on a pedestrian bridge with a screen showing stock exchange data, in Shanghai, China, 21 August 2023. Asian markets faced a setback on 21 August as China's reduction in lending rates proved to be smaller than anticipated. This extends Beijing's trend of providing stimulus measures that are more conservative than expected. The one-year loan prime rate (LPR) experienced a ten basis points reduction by the People's Bank of China, whereas the unchanged five-year rate, employed in calculating mortgage expenses, remained steady.  EPA-EFE/ALEX PLAVEVSKI

site_title: Japan elevates Taiwan security ties in move likely to rile China
summary: Japan has appointed a serving government official as its de facto defence attaché in Taiwan, elevating security ties and likely to anger China, which claims the island as its own. The move follows Japan's biggest military buildup since World War Two and comes amid growing concerns about Beijing's military presence around the island. Japan's defence ministry has stated that the move is within the bounds of a 1972 joint statement recognizing Beijing as China's sole legitimate government, but Beijing could see the upgrade as an attempt to interfere in its internal affairs.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Taiwan's armed forces hold two days of routine drills to show combat readiness ahead of Lunar New Year holidays at a military base in Kaohsiung, Taiwan, January 11, 2023. REUTERS/Ann Wang/File Photo

site_title: Singapore among countries most at risk from rising geopolitical tensions: WTO
summary: Singapore is one of the countries most at risk from rising geopolitical tensions due to its high reliance on trade, according to the World Trade Organization (WTO). The WTO report highlights the increasing skepticism over the benefits of international trade and multilateral cooperation, fueled by economic shocks from Covid-19 and the war in Ukraine. Trade tensions and restrictions have led to a reorientation of trade patterns along geopolitical lines, potentially reducing production costs and consumer prices, but increasing vulnerability in the global economy.

images.alt_text: The director-general of the World Trade Organization Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala in Berlin on Monday (Sep 4).  She encouraged western economies to shift production facilities into nations from the global south as a way of building resilience in global supply chains after three years of historic disruptions.

site_title: Are stocks priced for perfection?
summary: Investors are prone to extrapolating a stock's rosy outlook into the future, leading to vulnerable valuations when fundamentals disappoint. This phenomenon is reminiscent of the 1990s Internet craze, where companies like Cisco Systems experienced extraordinary growth before taking a significant downturn. Today, Nvidia's price-to-earnings ratio is over 220 times, similar to Cisco's peak in 2000. To mitigate this risk, investors should right-size their investments, particularly in stocks with significant volatility, and consider limiting exposure to minimize potential losses.

images.alt_text: ChatGPT is able to generate responses in split seconds due to Microsoft Azure datacentres powered by tens of thousands of Nvidia GPUs. As more AIUs.
There are no signs in market prices that AI heralds the end of the world, as some critics have alleged.

site_title: China outlines plan to make Fujian a zone for cross-strait development with Taiwan
summary: China has outlined a plan to develop Fujian province as a zone for cross-strait development with Taiwan, including financial market initiatives. The plan aims to encourage Taiwanese firms to list on Chinese stock exchanges, support innovative capital cooperation, and set up an integration development fund. This move is seen as part of China's efforts to strengthen economic ties with Taiwan, which it claims as its own territory, despite Taiwan's sovereignty. The plan is part of China's long-term economic and social plans for Taiwan, which envisions reunification with China.

images.alt_text: Investors monitor stock prices at a securities exchange house in Shanghai, China on Friday, 31 December 2010.

site_title: While Reits are struggling, they can still be sound investments for retirees
summary: Reits, despite struggling, can still be a sound investment for retirees due to diversification, liquidity benefits, and professional management. Unlike buying physical properties, Reits offer a steady stream of income, with many paying stable distributions per unit. Fluctuations in unit prices can be minimized through a buy-and-hold strategy, and Reits' safety margin, diversification, and professional management also make them an attractive option. However, retirees should consider factors such as borrowing costs and market volatility when deciding between Reits and physical properties.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
Far East Hospitality Trust was one of the best S-Reit performers in H1, as post-pandemic travel lifted the hospitality sector.
For the first half of FY2023, CICT reported higher gross revenue and net property income of 19.6 per cent and 14.8 per cent year on year respectively for its office portfolio.

site_title: Thailand’s economic policy commits to growth but remains sketchy on details
summary: Thailand's new Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin has announced an economic growth target of 2.8% in 2023, but critics have described his policy agenda as vague and lacking in details. Thavisin's administration plans to address the cost of living, suspend farmers' debts, boost tourism, and raise the daily minimum wage. The opposition has panned the agenda, calling it "lacking in direction" and "not specific enough." A Cabinet meeting is scheduled for Wednesday to confirm the details of the agenda.

images.alt_text: The opposition parties say the policy agenda of Thai Prime Minster Srettha’s Pheu Thai party lacked specifics.
Srettha Thavisin faces the challenge of boosting growth amid declining demand for its goods from its top trading partner China, and less-than-expected earnings from foreign tourists.

Softer global demand has crimped Thai exports, while its economy has been slow to recover, with household debt staying high.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore F1 attendance is down, but hotel takings may still exceed 2022 levels due to increased tourism. HSBC and Morgan Stanley are among potential creditors in a money laundering probe. Most companies plan to maintain employment despite an economic downturn. GlobalFoundries has opened a US$4 billion expanded fabrication plant in Singapore, citing long-term demand for chips. Ryde, a Singapore-based ride-hailing company, has filed for a US$17 million IPO on the NYSE. Singapore stocks fell 0.1% on Tuesday, tracking regional declines.

site_title: Fidelity incorporates ‘just transition’ metrics in its investment decisions
summary: Fidelity International, a global asset manager, has incorporated "just transition" metrics into its investment decisions. Just transition considers a company's approach to employee management, community impact, and affordability of basic goods like electricity. Fidelity aims to phase out thermal coal from its portfolio by 2030 for OECD countries and 2040 globally. The company engages with investee companies through regular dialogue, supports climate-related shareholder proposals, and considers divestment as a tool to nudge companies into taking action. A just transition is crucial for a fair and inclusive low-carbon economy, according to Fidelity's chief sustainability officer.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
As their business becomes cleaner, utilities will be able to profit from higher growth and reduce transition risks, which can lead to outperformance.

In the Asia-Pacific, financing the managed phase-out of coal-fired power plants is one of the most pressing issues within the global energy transition, says Fang Eu-Lin, PwC Singapore’s sustainability and climate change leader.
The Investor Agenda says governments continue to see climate change as separate to, and less important than, other aspects of economic and fiscal policy.

UN Secretary General Antonio Guterres talks to the media during a press conference on sidelines of the 43rd Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) Summit in Jakarta, Indonesia, 07 September 2023. Indonesia hosts the 43rd ASEAN Summit and related summits from 05 to 07 September

site_title: Malaysian court upholds ex-leader Najib's audit tampering acquittal
summary: A Malaysian court upheld the acquittal of former prime minister Najib Razak on an audit tampering charge related to the 1MDB scandal. Najib, serving a 12-year prison term, was acquitted in March after prosecutors failed to provide sufficient evidence. The decision does not affect his current sentence, as he faces dozens more charges. Najib's co-accused, former 1MDB chief Arul Kanda Kandasamy, was also acquitted. The acquittal is a setback for prosecutors, who did not submit documents in time to appeal the decision.

images.alt_text: Analysts said the upcoming state elections in six states in Malaysia will be a real test on Umno president Ahmad Zahid Hamidi’s influence within the party.
Zeti Akhtar Aziz, who is credited by investors with strengthening the credibility and independence of Bank Negara Malaysia, makes her first appearance at the 1MDB trial.

site_title: US small-business optimism edges lower, selling prices rise
summary: US small business optimism declined in August, falling to a three-year low of 91.3 due to weaker sales and economic concerns. The National Federation of Independent Business (NFIB) index decreased 0.6 points, while the net share of owners reporting higher nominal sales dropped to minus 14%. A net 27% of owners raised selling prices, and 23% cited inflation as their top problem. The share of unfilled positions fell to the lowest level since February 2021, but 26% planned to raise compensation.

images.alt_text: Consumers are growing more concerned about their ability to tap credit, with the share of households saying it is either much harder or somewhat harder to access credit now.
Initial claims for state unemployment benefits fall to 216,000 in the week ended Sep 2 from a revised 229,000 the week before, according to the Labor Department.
The US economy has shown signs of resiliency in recent months despite an aggressive campaign of interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve to tackle high inflation.
A reading above 50 indicates growth in the services industry, which accounts for more than two-thirds of the economy.
The shortfall in goods and services trade grows to US$65 billion from a revised US$63.7 billion in the prior month, Commerce Department data shows.

site_title: In a former Berlin Squat, slick photo shows and Martinis
summary: A former Berlin art squat, Tacheles, is reopening as the Berlin branch of Fotografiska, a photography exhibition center. The squat, which operated from 1990 to 2012, was a hub for post-reunification Berlin's underground culture, featuring artist studios, a movie theater, and live music venues. The site, which was occupied by young artists and anarchists after the wall came down, has undergone redevelopment and will now showcase photography exhibitions. The museum will be located in the same building where the squat once stood, offering a unique blend of art and history.

images.alt_text: In the first half of the 20th century, Grock’s success rivalled that of Charlie Chaplin. But while Chaplin satirised Hitler, Grock seems to have welcomed him into his dressing room.

site_title: Temasek, NUS, NTU to invest S$75 million in supporting deep-tech ventures
summary: Temasek, the National University of Singapore (NUS), and Nanyang Technological University (NTU) have partnered to invest S$75 million in supporting deep-tech ventures. The investment will focus on areas like energy transition, biotechnology, and future computing. The partnership will provide startups with access to networks of businesses and mentors, and will also develop a common intellectual property (IP) licensing framework to speed up the licensing and translation of university technologies. At least two startups are expected to be launched annually.

site_title: Dubai apartment prices jump most in a decade as housing boom widens
summary: Dubai's apartment prices surged 20% on average in the year through August, marking the best performance since 2014, according to real estate adviser CBRE Group. The city's housing boom, driven by a large influx of newcomers, has pushed up prices for apartments, which make up 85% of the housing supply. This outpaced price increases for single-family homes, known as villas, and brings Dubai's real estate market back to life after a seven-year slump.

images.alt_text: “Affordability is the main driver as everything is becoming more expensive,” said Haider Tuaima, director and head of real estate research at the Dubai-based firm. “Investors are now paying more for less space than they would have three years ago.”

site_title: Central banks set for higher-for-longer era to fight inflation
summary: Central banks are poised for a "higher-for-longer" era to combat inflation, with key decisions expected in the coming week. The European Central Bank (ECB) is set to decide on Thursday whether to keep raising interest rates or pause, with economists split on the outcome. The Federal Reserve is also expected to maintain steady rates, with a focus on keeping inflation near its 2% target. The Bank of England is likely to raise rates a quarter point, while the Swiss National Bank and Norges Bank are expected to end rate hikes.

images.alt_text: Whether to raise borrowing costs for a 10th straight time in Thursday's ECB meeting is shaping up to be rate-setters’ trickiest decision.

site_title: Australian cotton piles up in China warehouses on bets ban will lift soon
summary: Australian cotton is piling up in Chinese warehouses, with 43,364 metric tons entering bonded warehouses in the first seven months of this year, more than double 2022's total. Buyers, including state-owned China National Cotton Group Corp, are stockpiling cotton, betting that a three-year ban on imports will soon be lifted as diplomatic and trade ties between Australia and China ease. The ban was imposed in 2020 following Canberra's call for an international inquiry into the origins of Covid-19, but has been gradually eased since the Labor government took office in May 2022.

images.alt_text: The crop in Xinjiang, which accounts for about 90 per cent of China’s cotton, is currently at risk from high temperatures and hailstorms, just a few months after cold weather disrupted sowing.

site_title: EC World Reit fails to top up interest reserve, at risk of immediate loan repayment demands
summary: EC World Reit, a China-focused real estate investment trust, failed to top up its offshore interest reserve within the required five business days, putting it at risk of immediate loan repayment demands. The company used $3.4 million of the reserve to repay interest expenses, and lenders are reviewing the manager's requests for an extension. If the reserve is not topped up within 10 business days, an event of default will trigger cross-defaults under existing onshore facilities, and units have been suspended from trading for over five consecutive days.

site_title: GlobalFoundries opens US$4 billion expanded fabrication plant in Singapore
summary: GlobalFoundries has opened a US$4 billion expanded fabrication plant in Singapore, creating 1,000 jobs and increasing its annual wafer production capacity to approximately 1.5 million. The new facility will enable the company to capture the growing demand for chips driven by artificial intelligence and 5G technology. Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong noted that Singapore's niche in specialty chips and stable business conditions make it an attractive location for the company, despite intense competition from larger countries.

site_title: China says its economy is ‘resilient’, rejects Western concerns
summary: China's foreign ministry spokesperson Mao Ning has rejected Western concerns that the country's economy is faltering, calling it "resilient" and capable of promoting sustained development. The claims come as US President Joe Biden and Australian Treasurer Jim Chalmers have publicly raised concerns about the world's second-largest economy. Despite a slowdown in China's economic recovery following COVID-19 restrictions, analysts predict the economy will grow 5.0% this year, lower than initial forecasts. Mao Ning stated that China's fundamentals of long-term improvement remain unchanged, despite some economic challenges.

site_title: Apple to sell made-in-India iPhones on launch day for first time
summary: Apple plans to sell made-in-India iPhones on the launch day for the first time, with the majority of iPhone 15s coming from China. The move marks a significant departure from Apple's previous strategy of selling mostly Chinese-made devices, reflecting India's growing production prowess. Apple has increased its India assembly to 7% of global output, with slight delays possible due to logistics bottlenecks. The India-built iPhone 15 is expected to include upgrades to the camera system and improved processor, aiming to revive flagging sales.

site_title: Battery maker LG eyes US market to lift energy storage sales
summary: LG Energy Solution, a South Korean battery maker, plans to expand its production in the US to triple energy storage system (ESS) sales, aiming for 70% of North American sales by 2030. The company will focus on higher-end storage systems, leveraging tax credits from the US Inflation Reduction Act, and will prioritize safety, having learned from safety concerns in South Korea that led to stricter regulations. LG aims to differentiate itself by offering integrated software solutions, competing with Chinese suppliers who have gained market share.

site_title: Country Garden wins approval to extend six onshore bond repayments by 3 years: sources
summary: Country Garden, a distressed developer, has won approval from its creditors to extend repayments on six onshore bonds worth 10.8 billion yuan (S$2 billion) by three years. Onshore creditors voted to approve the proposals, which concluded on Monday. This decision comes after a voting process, with creditors approving the extension for six out of the eight bonds. The extension will provide Country Garden with more time to repay the bonds, alleviating some pressure on the struggling developer.

site_title: Accor sees record China hotel deals as travel beats slowdown
summary: Accor is on track to sign a record 125 hotel partnership projects in China this year, doubling down on expansion in a country where tourism has become a bright spot amid an economic downturn. The French hospitality giant currently has over 640 hotels across Greater China, with revenue from the region accounting for one-fifth of its Asia-Pacific and Middle East revenue. Accor's accelerated expansion in China comes as domestic travel has seen a strong rebound, driven by consumers seeking leisure and entertainment activities amid economic uncertainties.

site_title: Europe’s weak gas demand signals industrial malaise taking hold
summary: Europe's industrial sector is experiencing a deep-rooted malaise, with gas demand projected to remain 20% below 2021 levels due to worsening economic conditions and record-high interest rates. The downturn is evident in Germany, where the energy-intensive industry is struggling despite an 80% decline in gas prices. Production in the chemicals sector is expected to fall by 11% in 2023, and the European Chemical Industry Council anticipates an 8% drop. The crisis is attributed to companies' hesitation to ramp up production again, with some switching to renewable power or relocating to other countries.

site_title: Alibaba CEO elevates AI to key priority in group revamp plan
summary: Alibaba Group Holding has elevated artificial intelligence (AI) to a top priority, following a global trend to stake a spot in the emergent field of AI. CEO Eddie Wu has emphasized the need for the company to adjust its approach to go AI-first, while maintaining its focus on user experience. This shift aims to reclaim customers and market share in a competitive arena, as Wu seeks to reclaim the company's position in the tech industry.

images.alt_text: The cloud business is a major part of a restructuring the Chinese e-commerce giant announced in March that breaks the company up into six units, each with its own boards and CEOs.

site_title: How Goldilocks came to the US economy
summary: The US economy experienced a "minor miracle" in reducing inflation without a major economic slowdown or rise in unemployment. Despite initial expectations of an inflation rate of 4-5%, the underlying inflation rate has fallen to under 3% and is continuing to decline, according to statistical models. Two economists, Paul Krugman and Mike Konczal, argue that either the "nonlinear Phillips curve" or the "long transitory" theory could explain the sudden drop in inflation. While both theories have merit, the latter seems to better fit the data, with falling inflation rates in goods and services whose consumption has increased.

site_title: China’s housing rebound fades fast in big cities after stimulus
summary: China's housing market is experiencing a fast-fading recovery in big cities after the government loosened mortgage restrictions, raising doubts about the effectiveness of the stimulus. Home sales in Beijing, Shenzhen, and Shanghai declined, with existing home sales plummeting 35% in Beijing and new home sales sliding in Shanghai and Guangzhou. The rebound is seen as insufficient to revive the market before a crucial holiday season, with some analysts calling for more aggressive easing measures to ensure a real recovery.

site_title: German housing construction sector cancellations hit new high: survey
summary: Germany's housing construction sector saw a new high in cancelled projects in August, with 20.7% of companies reporting cancellations, up from 18.9% in the previous month. The crisis is driven by high credit and material costs, as well as tightening energy regulations. Many profitable projects from 2022 are now unviable due to rising construction costs and interest rates. 44.2% of companies reported a lack of orders, and nearly 12% face financing difficulties, with a majority fearing further declines in business over the next six months.

images.alt_text: The site in central Munich of a project planned by Euroboden, a property developer that has filed for insolvency.

It is the latest sign of strain in Germany’s property sector, which long benefited from an era of cheap money that fuelled a boom in real estate, but is now grappling with a major turn of fortune.

site_title: Sri Lanka gets closer to IMF funds with local bond swap deal
summary: Sri Lanka accepted almost all offers to exchange defaulted local debt for new bonds, receiving 3.2 trillion rupees (S$13.5 billion) from superannuation funds. This move puts the nation closer to completing its debt restructuring this year, paving the way for a potential disbursement of US$330 million by November. The government must still reach an agreement with foreign debt holders, including China and India, to complete the IMF review. This milestone is seen as an important step towards completing the IMF bailout and addressing the country's debt crisis.

site_title: Neste raises Q3 refining margin outlook, says Singapore ramp-up slowed
summary: Neste, a Finnish oil refiner and biofuels producer, has raised its third-quarter margin outlook despite a slower-than-expected ramp-up at its Singapore refinery due to ongoing repairs. The company estimates a 100,000-ton sales volume impact in the second half of 2023, mainly affecting fourth-quarter sales. Meanwhile, North European diesel and petrol margins have risen to a high level in the third quarter, driven by volatile oil markets. Neste expects its margin to be "significantly higher than in the second quarter."

images.alt_text: Neste produces renewable fuels, mainly from waste and residues such as used cooking oil and animal fat from food industry waste.

site_title: Tokyo: The big city where housing is still affordable
summary: Tokyo remains an affordable city, where two full-time workers earning the minimum wage can comfortably afford a two-bedroom apartment in six of its 23 wards. Unlike major US cities, Tokyo's affordable housing is due to its investment in transit and development, adding more housing units than the total in New York City. The city's zoning law allows for easy development, and new construction is not always luxury housing, preserving economic diversity and small businesses. This model offers a template for other cities to revive their economies post-pandemic.

images.alt_text: Greater Tokyo area apartment demand raises average sale price by 55.8 per cent to 99.4 million yen.

site_title: Singapore stocks track regional decline, STI falls 0.1%
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.1% to 3,214.46 on Tuesday, tracking regional declines. The index saw 921.6 million securities worth S$655.8 million change hands, with gainers outnumbering losers 279 to 253. Regional indices also fell, with the Hang Seng Index losing 0.4% and the Kospi Composite Index falling 0.8%.

site_title: China sows disinformation about Hawaii fires using new techniques
summary: China has been using new disinformation techniques to sow discord in the US, including falsely attributing Hawaii wildfires to a US "weather weapon." Researchers from Microsoft and other organizations found that China used AI-generated photos to bolster the plausibility of the claims. This marks a shift in China's tactics, as they previously focused on amplifying propaganda on Taiwan and other subjects. The effort is part of a broader disinformation campaign by China and Russia, which often echo each other's messages, particularly when criticizing US policies.

images.alt_text: The new risks presented by AI are driven by an emerging breed of bad actors who use sophisticated tradecraft and technologies to drive harmful narratives.

site_title: ValueMax to raise up to S$50 million through digital commercial paper
summary: ValueMax, a pawnbroking chain, plans to raise up to S$50 million through its eighth series of three-month digital commercial paper. The paper, priced at 5.1% per annum, is due to mature in three months and will be issued through the ADDX private market exchange. This follows a successful previous issuance in August that raised S$14.9 million. The funds will be used for the company's operations and investments.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
ValueMax said it will continue to explore acquisition opportunities  and suitable locations to grow its network of pawnshops and retail outlets, as well as its moneylending business.
ValueMax expects to  raise S$10 million to S$20 million from accredited and institutional investors from its inaugural digital commercial paper to be listed on the SDAX digital platform.

In its outlook statement, ValueMax noted that gold prices may continue to remain volatile amid the likes of rising interest rates, the war between Russia and Ukraine, as well as geopolitical tensions.

site_title: Developers take cautious stance in land tenders for Woodlands, Lentor housing sites
summary: Singapore's developers have shown cautious sentiment in land tenders for Woodlands and Lentor housing sites, with bids coming in below expectations. City Developments Limited (CDL) secured the top bid of S$904 psf ppr for the Woodlands plot, while a joint venture between Hong Leong Holdings, GuocoLand, and China Communications Construction Company submitted the top bid of S$982 psf ppr for the Lentor Central plot. The bids reflect the current uncertain economic conditions, inflation, and rising borrowing costs. The projects are expected to be launched at prices ranging from S$1,750 to S$1,950 psf for the Woodlands site and S$1,950 to S$2,200 psf for the Lentor Central site.

site_title: Hong Kong to take action against illegal works at luxury estate
summary: Hong Kong's leader John Lee announced plans to investigate and prosecute owners of a luxury residential estate in Tai Tam who built unauthorised structures, putting some houses at risk. The investigation follows a landslide that occurred after record rainfall last week, with evidence suggesting breaches of leases and unlawful occupation. Lee vowed to take action against those breaking the law, amid concerns over illegal building works in the wealthy community.

site_title: Europe’s energy security expedited post-Ukraine
summary: The European Union has expedited energy security post-Ukraine by scaling up clean energy and diversifying away from Russian energy sources. In the last year, the EU reached a record 41 GW of new solar energy capacity installed and increased wind capacity by 16 GW, generating more electricity from wind and solar sources than from gas. The EU has secured new gas supplies from countries like the US, UAE, and Azerbaijan, but the new gas infrastructure will require a medium- to longer-term horizon, complicating the EU's energy transition pathway. The EU is seeking to enhance its climate commitments ahead of COP28, potentially raising its 2030 greenhouse-gas-reduction target.

site_title: Ride-hailing platform Ryde files for NYSE IPO to raise US$17 million
summary: Singapore-based ride-hailing platform Ryde files for a US$17 million initial public offering (IPO) on the New York Stock Exchange, with no pricing terms disclosed. The company aims to raise funds to address recurring losses and negative working capital. Founded in 2014, Ryde focuses on carpooling and plans to expand into multiple mobility tools. Despite registered losses, the startup has secured S$5.8 million in funding from venture capital companies and is expanding into the quick commerce industry through its recent acquisition of Meili Technology.

site_title: SoftBank supremo eyes rare success with Arm IPO
summary: SoftBank founder Masayoshi Son is hoping the mega-IPO of chip designer Arm this week will bring back his investor reputation. The IPO values Arm at up to $52 billion, a significant gain on SoftBank's $32 billion investment in 2016. However, analysts expect the valuation to be lower than SoftBank's rumored $60-70 billion target. The IPO has already received 10 times oversubscription, with SoftBank considering raising the price. A successful IPO could help SoftBank deliver positive returns and leverage Arm's remaining 90% to borrow money for future investments.

images.alt_text: Following strong demand from investors, Arm will likely be able to price the IPO at the top or above its US$47-to-US$51-per-share range.
Arm is seeking a valuation on a fully diluted basis of US$50 billion to US$54.5 billion.
Arm is still considering raising the price range of its initial public offering as well.

site_title: Singapore F1 attendance down, but hotel takings may still exceed 2022 levels
summary: Singapore's Formula 1 (F1) Grand Prix is expected to see hotel takings exceed pre-Covid levels, possibly even surpassing those of 2022. Despite a 17% decrease in attendance to 250,000 spectators, tourism players anticipate strong revenue due to the resumption of travel and higher room rates, which are 10% higher than 2022. Industry observers attribute the boost to the event's earlier dates, which may be more convenient for Western travelers, and the spread of F1-related activities across a longer timeframe.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim

The 2023 Singapore Grand Prix is not expected to match last year's record turnout of 302,000 spectators, but it is taking place amid a recovery in international travel that has boosted the profitability of many hotel owners.
