site_title: This museum has 300 tanks and over 100 million YouTube views
summary: The Tank Museum in Bovington, England, has gained massive success on YouTube, surpassing the world's largest museums in subscribers and views. The channel has over 550,000 subscribers and recently hit 100 million views, with weekly clips featuring detailed discussions on tank history and newsier items on armoured vehicles in Ukraine. The museum's success has led to increased revenue, with online income generating one-third of its revenue last year, and has also allowed the museum to hire full-time presenters and expand its online presence.

images.alt_text: The Nisga’a believe that the pole has a spirit embedded in it and do not consider it an object but a living being.

site_title: Malaysia's Carsome open to new funding from strategic investors
summary: Malaysia's Carsome, a leading car e-commerce platform, is open to new funding from strategic investors, according to co-founder and group CEO Eric Cheng. The company, valued at $1.7 billion, is ready for an initial public offering (IPO) but is in no rush to list. Cheng emphasized the need for exchanges to provide liquidity and added that the company is also open to a dual listing. Carsome has hit operational profitability and is expected to achieve its first group-wide profit or break-even before year-end, with a cash position of $200 million.

images.alt_text: Eric Cheng, co-founder and chief executive officer of Carsome, says the group's liquidity position and strong investor backing place it on solid footing to deliver the world’s first integrated car ownership ecosystem.

site_title: Train carrying North Korea’s Kim entered Russia, Ria Novosti agency confirms
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un's train has entered Russia, according to Russian state news agency Ria Novosti. The train, carrying Kim, crossed into the Primorsky region from North Korea, ahead of a meeting with President Vladimir Putin later this week. Experts believe Moscow will seek artillery shells and antitank missiles from North Korea in exchange for advanced satellite and nuclear-powered submarine technology. The visit marks Kim's first trip abroad in four years, and the US has warned North Korea that supplying Moscow with weapons for the Ukraine conflict would "pay a price."

images.alt_text: North Korea launched a new tactical nuclear attack submarine on Sept 8, 2023.
“At present, it is very important to oppose taking sides, bloc confrontation and a new Cold War,” says China's Premier Li Qiang.

North Korean leader Kim Jong Un visits a key military factory in this undated photo released by North Korea's Korean Central News Agency on Aug 14, 2023.

site_title: GlobalFoundries opens US$4 billion Singapore fabrication plant
summary: GlobalFoundries has launched a $4 billion fabrication plant in Singapore, producing an additional 450,000 300mm wafers per year and creating 1,000 jobs. The 23,000 sqm facility is part of the company's major global manufacturing expansion. This move is expected to boost Singapore's semiconductor output, which accounts for 11% of the global market, and follows a trend of chipmakers expanding operations in the city-state.

site_title: Tackling the scourge of fires on board ships
summary: A fire broke out on the Fremantle Highway on July 25, killing one crew member, prompting a massive effort to extinguish the flames. The global container shipping industry is backing a program focused on reducing cargo fires and loss. Non-profit organization Safetytech Accelerator has launched a multi-year collaborative program to expedite the adoption of technology and best practices to prevent fires from starting or spreading to cargo holds, with a focus on early fire detection in cargo holds.

Towing of the cargo ship on fire off the coast of the Netherlands, with thousands of cars on board, is expected to begin on July 29, 2023, even though the fire has diminished in intensity, according to the authorities, who have been trying for several days to prevent an environmental disaster. site_title: Gold flat as investors look to US inflation data for Fed clues
summary: Gold prices remained steady at $1,921.04 per ounce, awaiting US inflation data that could influence interest rates. Investors also watched the US dollar index, which steadied after a two-week intraday loss. The European Commission forecast a slower-than-expected eurozone economy growth, while the Bank of England's Catherine Mann said it's too soon to stop raising interest rates. Gold holdings fell 0.20% at the SPDR Gold Trust, and other precious metals prices were also unchanged.

images.alt_text: US gold futures steadied at US$1,943.

site_title: UK posts record wage growth even as job market cools
summary: The UK posted a record wage growth of 7.8% in the three months through July, driven by high inflation, despite signs of a cooling job market. Average earnings excluding bonuses rose to 8.5%, a record, while unemployment ticked higher to 4.3%. The Bank of England is expected to raise interest rates again, with money markets pricing in a quarter-point hike to 5.5% and a 50% chance of further rate increases by the end of the year. Chancellor Jeremy Hunt emphasized the need to halve inflation to sustainably grow real wages.

images.alt_text: The hiring of permanent staff fell by the most since June 2020, early in the Covid-19 pandemic, while spending on temporary workers dipped for the first time since July 2020.

site_title: Asia: Most markets drop as uneasy traders await key data
summary: Asian markets declined on Tuesday as traders await US inflation data, which is expected to influence the Federal Reserve's policy decisions. Despite some gains in Tokyo, Taipei, and Manila, Hong Kong, Shanghai, Seoul, Sydney, Singapore, Wellington, and Jakarta markets fell. Lingering concerns about China's economy and the potential for interest rate hikes also weighed on the markets. The consumer price index report is set to be released next week, with traders expecting the Federal Reserve to hold interest rates.

site_title: Thai industrial sentiment at one-year low despite end of political deadlock
summary: Thailand's industrial sentiment index dropped to a one-year low of 91.3 in August due to concerns over weak exports, slow economic recovery, and high household debt. Softer global demand has crimped Thai exports, while the economy has been slow to recover. The new government's policy plans were deemed too vague, and its plan to boost year-end tourism was seen as helpful. The Federation of Thai Industries (FTI) urged the government to prioritize its policies and provide an execution plan to help the economy, which is "actually worse than thought".

images.alt_text: The opposition parties say the policy agenda of Thai Prime Minster Srettha’s Pheu Thai party lacked specifics.

site_title: Japan 10-year yield retreats from near-decade high after smooth auction
summary: Japan's 10-year government bond yield retreated to 0.705% after a smooth auction of five-year notes, snapping a string of weak sales. The benchmark yield had reached 0.72% earlier, its highest since January 2014. The five-year yield fell one basis point to 0.27%, reversing from an eight-month high. This follows the Bank of Japan's yield curve control policy tweak in July, which has led long-term buyers to wait for an eventual rise in yields.

site_title: Vertex closes fifth fund at US$541 million for South-east Asia and India
summary: Vertex Ventures Southeast Asia and India has closed its fifth fund at US$541 million, exceeding its initial target of US$450 million. The fund, backed by existing and new limited partners, will invest US$2 million to US$8 million in startups, with a focus on supporting women entrepreneurs. The fund's parallel co-investment envelope will prioritize startups led by women founders. This marks the firm's continued bullish outlook on the tech startup ecosystem in South-east Asia and India.

site_title: Most companies plan to keep employment stable despite pessimistic economic outlook: SBF survey
summary: A survey by the Singapore Business Federation found that 89% of companies expect no change or an increase in manpower despite a pessimistic economic outlook for the next 12 months. Slightly over a third of companies polled (33%) believe the economic climate will worsen, while 28% expect it to improve. The most optimistic companies are in "other services," wholesale trade, and manufacturing.

site_title: Indonesia faces uphill battle to curb surge in online gambling websites
summary: Indonesia's government faces a significant challenge in curbing the surge in online gambling websites, with nearly 939,000 sites shut down since 2018. The country's Communications and Information Minister, Budi Arie Setiadi, has blocked 42,622 online gambling sites in his first three weeks on the job. Online gambling is prohibited in Indonesia, with players and organizers facing fines and jail time. Authorities have also targeted social media influencers and celebrities promoting illegal investment platforms, with an estimated $5.2 billion wagered illegally online in 2022.

site_title: Japan considers building a train up Mount Fuji to curb traffic, tourists
summary: Japan is considering building a train up Mount Fuji to curb traffic and prevent overcrowding, aiming to preserve the iconic mountain's natural beauty and boost the local economy. The light rail project would allow tourists to access the 2,300-meter Fuji Subaru 5th Station, currently overwhelmed by buses and cars, for a round-trip fee of 10,000 yen. Officials hope to reduce carbon emissions and create a more exclusive tourist experience, with plans to build a hotel and increase ticket prices to attract higher-paying visitors.

site_title: US FDA authorises Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna’s updated Covid shots
summary: The US FDA has authorised updated Covid-19 vaccines from Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna, targeting the XBB.1.5 subvariant of the virus. The shots are expected to be available for most people in the US in the coming days, with a third shot from Novavax still under review. The FDA's approval follows a rise in cases, with the new EG.5 subvariant of Omicron spreading rapidly in the US and other countries. The updated vaccines have met the agency's rigorous scientific standards, and a CDC endorsement is expected to clear the way for their rollout.

images.alt_text: Moderna says it had shared the new finding on its vaccine with regulators and submitted it for peer review publication.

site_title: EM Asia’s worst stock sell-off may extend as foreigners flee
summary: Global investors have been selling Philippine stocks aggressively, offloading about $164 million so far in September, as concerns about a hawkish central bank keep foreign investors on the sidelines. The Philippine Stock Exchange Index has slid 3.6% this quarter, wiping out over $11 billion in market value. Experts say the market's attractiveness is reduced due to interest rates staying higher for longer, and a rebound will depend on the US interest-rate outlook. The government needs to implement measures to revive economic growth and a drop in interest rates is crucial to reviving consumer confidence.

site_title: More insurance plans for EVs, but charging-specific coverage remains rare
summary: Singapore's car insurers are expanding coverage for electric vehicles (EVs), with two insurers now offering EV-specific plans. Great Eastern's EV Protect and Singlife's EV-specific insurance policy cover medical claims, damage, and loss arising from EV chargers. However, complexities surrounding EV charging risks persist, and industry experts say that potential buyers may be deterred by the additional cost. Despite this, EV charging is considered "very safe" due to Singapore's stringent certification requirements, and more insurance coverage aims to raise awareness of EVs.

site_title: Australia consumer sentiment languishes in pessimistic territory
summary: Australia's consumer sentiment has slipped further into "deeply pessimistic" territory, with a 1.5% decline to 79.7 points, according to a Westpac Banking survey. This marks the lowest level in the current cycle, with assessments of "family finances" down 4.4% and a gauge of household spending down 3%. The Reserve Bank of Australia is in watch-and-wait mode after four rate hikes since May, and policymakers are ready to move again if needed to control inflation.

images.alt_text: Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said he would visit China later this year.
Markets see a good chance that the RBA is done, but a majority of economists expect one more hike by the end of the year to bring inflation to heel.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Olam
summary: Olam Group denied allegations of involvement in a multibillion-dollar fraud at its Nigerian unit, following recent media reports. The company's board directed an audit committee review of the matter. As a result, Olam Group's shares fell 8.6% to close at S$1.17.

site_title: New Zealand forecasts larger budget deficit but improved economy
summary: New Zealand's government forecasts a larger budget deficit of NZ$11.38 billion (S$9.14 billion) for the fiscal year ending June 30, 2024, due to a deteriorating global economy and falling tax revenue. Despite this, the economy is expected to remain in positive territory over the next year, with inflation forecast to peak at three-decade highs in late 2024. The government aims to return to surplus by 2026/27 and expects net debt to peak at 43.6% of GDP in 2023/24.

images.alt_text: The increase in volumes offset a third straight quarter of weaker export prices as slower economic growth in China hurts global commodity prices.

site_title: Japan tests demand in another debt sale after Ueda rate remarks
summary: Japan will conduct a five-year bond auction on Tuesday, selling 2.5 trillion yen, amid weak demand in auctions over the past month. The move comes after central bank governor Kazuo Ueda stated the BOJ is "some distance away" from achieving its price stability target, indicating it will continue patient monetary easing. The auction follows a 20-year auction in August with a record-wide "tail" and yields on the nation's benchmark five-year debt reaching their highest level since January.

images.alt_text: Since the yen weakens past the 145 per US dollar threshold this month, traders are on alert for any signs of intervention from Japan to shore up the currency.

The sharp rise in the yield came as investors reacted to BOJ governor Kazuo Ueda’s interview with the Yomiuri newspaper, published on Saturday, in which he said the central bank could end its negative interest rate policy when its 2 per cent inflation goal is in sight, indicating possible rate hikes by year-end.

site_title: China firms will drive Hong Kong office market rebound, Gaw says
summary: Hong Kong's office market is expected to rebound over the next two to four years, driven by an influx of Chinese firms seeking to list in the city, according to Goodwin Gaw, chairman of Gaw Capital Partners. Chinese investment banks and securities firms will replace multinational companies reducing their footprint, and Gaw's firm is seeking to increase its presence in South-east Asian markets. Hong Kong's occupancy rates are still "pretty good," ranging from mid-80s to 90s, and Gaw favors office space in the US, where valuations have become attractive.

images.alt_text: The stamp duty has been heavily debated in Hong Kong over the past weeks and China’s cut gave backing to those calling for a reduction.
Hong Kong’s rates have surged because its monetary policy is tied to the US, weighing on the economy.

site_title: Beware of Trump 2.0’s trade policies
summary: US President Donald Trump is planning to implement a "universal reciprocal tariff" in his second term, imposing tariff rates on foreign goods equivalent to what the exporting country charges on US goods. This would lead to higher prices for American consumers, devastate American exporters, and collapse the liberal international trade order. Critics argue that such a policy would be disastrous for American workers, trigger global retaliation, and erode the US's global position. The proposal has been met with widespread criticism from free traders and economists, who warn of the devastating consequences for the global economy.

site_title: Singapore’s shares open lower on Tuesday; STI down by 0.2%
summary: Singapore's shares dropped 0.2% to 3,213.10 at the open on Tuesday, with Seatrium rising 0.7% and Genting Singapore falling 1.1%. Olam Group shares slid 2.6% after denying allegations of a multibillion-dollar fraud. Banking stocks were mixed, with DBS and UOB falling, while OCBC gained 0.1%. The Straits Times Index closed higher on Monday, following a 1.1% rise in the Nasdaq Composite Index and a 0.3% gain in the pan-European Stoxx 600 index.

images.alt_text: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) centre taken on January 8, 2020.

site_title: This startup is using billions of dollars to build Japan’s own TSMC
summary: Japan's government-backed startup, Rapidus, aims to build a Silicon Valley-like ecosystem on the island of Hokkaido by 2033. The 13-month-old company plans to mass-produce 2-nanometre logic chips by 2027 and envisions a chipmaking cluster spanning coast to coast. Rapidus CEO Atsuyoshi Koike aims to create a 'Hokkaido Valley' that competes with Silicon Valley, with a goal to set the trend in the global chip industry. The project is backed by billions of dollars and seeks to establish Hokkaido as a center of semiconductor innovation.

images.alt_text: Rapidus will work with IBM with the aim of starting mass production of two-nanometre node chips from 2027.

site_title: Everton Football Club close to sale to 777 Partners
summary: Everton Football Club is close to a sale to 777 Partners LLC, following months of talks. Club owner Farhad Moshiri is expected to exit with a fraction of the hundreds of millions of pounds he invested. The deal, if completed, would bring the number of American-owned Premier League teams to 10 out of 20. 777 Partners, which has previously acquired historic football teams in Brazil, Italy, and Germany, is advising on the deal and may consider a capital raise. A deal could be announced as soon as Tuesday.

site_title: Money laundering crackdown testament to integrity of Singapore as a financial centre: DPM Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat said Singapore's recent crackdown on money laundering, involving over S$1.8 billion in assets, is a testament to the country's integrity as a financial center. The probe targeted 10 foreigners, believed to originate from China, and highlighted the importance of staying vigilant against money laundering and terror financing. Heng also praised the outcome of Singapore's presidential election, where Tharman Shanmugaratnam won with 70.4% of the vote, seen as a positive sign for the country's multiracial society.

site_title: US government shutdown threatens economic risk: Treasury official
summary: The US government is at risk of a shutdown, which could paralyze nearly the entire federal government, if Congress fails to vote on a budget extension by the end of the month. A Treasury official warned that a shutdown would bring challenges to the world's biggest economy, dampening demand and limiting resources for people. The White House has urged Congress to act swiftly to avoid the shutdown, which could have significant economic implications.

site_title: JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon blasts draft US bank capital rules
summary: JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon criticized US bank capital rules, calling them "hugely disappointing" and lacking transparency. He expressed concerns that stricter capital requirements could lead to lenders pulling back and stymieing economic growth. Dimon questioned the regulators' rationale behind the rules, advocating for fairness, transparency, and openness instead. The proposal comes as the Chinese market is seen as less lucrative, with Dimon describing the risk-reward as "okay" but the risk as "bad".

site_title: JFK assassination witness breaks his silence and raises new questions
summary: Paul Landis, a Secret Service agent who was just feet away from John F. Kennedy when he was assassinated, is breaking his 60-year silence and raising new questions about the event. Landis' account differs from the official Warren Commission version, suggesting that one bullet may not have struck Kennedy and Texas Gov. John Connally in multiple places, but instead may have been a separate bullet that hit Connally. Landis' testimony, included in a forthcoming memoir, challenges the "magic bullet" theory and raises the possibility of a second shooter. The agent's account, corroborated by experts, could potentially reopen the question of a second shooter and contradict the central thesis of the Warren Report.

site_title: Nike faces calls to pay garment workers ahead of annual shareholder meeting
summary: Nike faces calls to pay garment workers in Cambodia and Thailand, totaling $2.2 million in allegedly unpaid wages to over 4,000 workers. The request comes from more than a dozen investors ahead of the company's annual shareholder meeting. This comes as Nike already faces growing scrutiny of its supply chain, including investigations by Canadian and US government agencies. The allegations were made by a labor rights group, but Reuters could not independently verify the claims.

images.alt_text: PouYuen Vietnam, a unit of Taiwan-based Pou Chen Group, will lay off around 1,200 workers with permanent contracts from the end of August.

Nike has already seen “incredibly strong” demand for England’s uniforms and for now it continues to have supplies available.

site_title: MGM Resorts says it shut down some systems following hack
summary: MGM Resorts International reported a cyberattack affecting some of its systems, disrupting slot machines and guest check-in. The company has notified law enforcement and begun an investigation with external cybersecurity experts. MGM Resorts shut down certain systems to protect data and notified customers about the incident. The extent of the hack is unknown, and some guests experienced issues with checking in and using slot machines.

images.alt_text: The post-pandemic travel rebound in China and Macau has been a tailwind for casino operators such as MGM Resorts and Las Vegas Sands.

site_title: Bank of America keeps guidance on expenses, net interest income unchanged
summary: Bank of America is maintaining its guidance for expenses and net interest income for the second half of the year, citing a focus on driving organic growth and maintaining expense discipline. CFO Alastair Borthwick reiterated forecasts of $14.2-14.3 billion for the third quarter and $14 billion for the fourth quarter. The bank's deposits are flat to higher compared to a year ago, while loan growth has slowed due to decreased commercial borrowing and card spending.

images.alt_text: Bank of America has reported a 7 per cent rise in investment banking fees to US$1.2 billion. That contrasts with peers whose earnings suffered from a dealmaking drought that has persisted for months.
