site_title: Oil prices settle mostly flat ahead of monthly oil forecasts
summary: Oil prices settled mostly flat ahead of monthly forecasts, holding above $90 a barrel for the first time in 10 months. Saudi Arabia and Russia announced a combined 1.3 million barrel-per-day supply cut extension until the end of the year, overshadowing concerns over Chinese economic activity. US crude inventories are expected to fall for the fifth week in a row. Fresh disruptions from powerful storms in eastern Libya and a light refinery maintenance season in Europe could impact crude supply. Monthly reports from the IEA and Opec are due later this week.

images.alt_text: Saudi Aramco raises the October official selling price for its Arab Light crude by a less than expected 10 cents from the previous month.
Brent crude fell 49 cents, or 0.5 per cent, to US$90.16 a barrel by 0022 GMT on Monday.

site_title: Musk biography describes troubled tycoon driven by demons
summary: Elon Musk's biography, written by Walter Isaacson, portrays the billionaire as a troubled tycoon driven by childhood demons and a desire to bring human life to Mars. The book details Musk's chaotic and impulse-driven takeover of Twitter, his vindictive tendencies toward doubters and critics, and his personal life, including his large family and strained relationships. The biography also highlights Musk's obsessive personality, citing his "demon mode" as a key factor in his productivity.

images.alt_text: Tesla has been mentioning how Dojo gives it an edge in AI and self-driving technology since at least 2021.
Tesla has rolled out another round of price cuts and unveiled its refreshed Model 3 in an all-out push to boost sales.
Musk paid back the US$1 billion with interest to SpaceX in November.

Owner of X, Elon Musk, wants X to become more like Tencent Holdings’ WeChat, a messaging service turned super-app that offers everything from social media and video games to fintech. X chief executive Linda Yaccarino has said X will include features such as payments and banking.

site_title: FTX 2.0: Bankman-Fried’s former crypto exchange outlines plan for potential reboot
summary: FTX Group, the bankrupt crypto exchange, is considering a plan to reboot a new version, dubbed "FTX 2.0", with over 75 bidders contacted since May to gauge industry interest. The FTX estate is evaluating potential structures, including acquisitions, mergers, or recapitalizations, and aims to select a stalking-horse bid by October 16. The estate has recovered around $7 billion in assets and has $16 billion in customer claims, with a deadline for new bids set for September 24. A potential relaunch could inject activity back into the market, which has been subdued since the platform's collapse.

images.alt_text: An FTX affiliate has said it paid tennis star Naomi Osaka (centre) US$2 million on Nov 9, 2022, two days before Sam Bankman-Fried resigned as CEO and his company filed for bankruptcy.
Ryan Salame’s plea agreement did not include a promise to testify against Sam Bankman-Fried.

A courtroom sketch from Aug 23 showing FTX cryptocurrency exchange founder Sam Bankman-Fried in prison clothing, with his attorney Christian Everdell in a Manhattan federal court, where he pleaded not guilty to seven criminal charges.
Lawyers filed a motion for Sam Bankman-Fried (above) to be released from jail late on Friday night (Aug 25) with the US 2nd Circuit Court of Appeals.
Galaxy will help “stake” FTX’s crypto, a process where crypto is lent to validate blockchain transactions, earning interest in the process.

site_title: Europe: Miners lift shares ahead of US CPI, ECB meet
summary: European stocks rose 0.3% on Monday, led by miners as base metal prices increased ahead of US inflation data and the European Central Bank's monetary policy decision. Miners jumped 2.4% on prospects of better demand from top consumer China, while positive inflation data and stimulus measures added to signs of China's economy stabilizing. The Stoxx 600 index closed at a near one-week high, with Italy's banks-heavy index leading gains.

site_title: Biden urges ‘national unity’ 22 years after 9/11
summary: US President Joe Biden called for national unity on the 22nd anniversary of the 9/11 attacks, urging Americans to put aside partisan differences. Biden spoke at a US military base in Anchorage, Alaska, where nearly 3,000 people were killed in the attacks. He emphasized that terrorism is the opposite of what the US stands for and that the country must remain united against such threats. Biden's speech comes as the US is increasingly polarized, with his potential election rematch against Republican former president Donald Trump looming.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden touts a "new stage" in the ties between the US and Vietnam to a meeting of officials and executives in Hanoi.

US President Joe Biden with Vietnam's Communist Party General Secretary Nguyen Phu Trong (right) after a meeting in Hanoi; Biden’s visit comes as bilateral trade and investment ties are growing and a long-simmering territorial dispute between Vietnam and China heats up in the South China Sea.
Donald Trump is also promoting a universal reciprocal tariff that would see the United States imposing tariff rates on foreign goods equivalent to what the exporting country charges on US goods.

site_title: NRICs, home addresses of doctors among data leaked from Academy of Medicine, Singapore
summary: A data breach at the Academy of Medicine, Singapore, has exposed the personal information of around 50 doctors, including NRIC numbers and home addresses, on the dark web. The breach, attributed to a Russian-based ransomware gang, also included log-in credentials for social media accounts and a staff contact list. The incident prompted the academy to take immediate action, including appointing cybersecurity experts and strengthening its infrastructure. The Personal Data Protection Commission and police have been informed, and the academy has urged affected individuals to take precautions.

images.alt_text: Cortina Holdings has deployed managed detection and response services across all workstations and servers after it was hacked in June.

site_title: Oracle sees revenue below estimates as cloud spending sputters
summary: Oracle reported revenue below estimates for the current quarter, with cloud spending by businesses pressured by a tough economy. The company narrowly missed first-quarter expectations, with shares falling 9% in extended trading. Despite this, Oracle's cloud infrastructure business is expected to benefit from the growing adoption of artificial intelligence (AI) applications, with over $4 billion in contracts signed so far. Oracle chairman Larry Ellison announced deals with AI startups and utility companies to replace existing systems with its Fusion Cloud applications.

images.alt_text: The Oracle Corp. logo outside the company's offices in Hyderabad, India. Photographer: Dhiraj Singh/Bloomberg

site_title: Germany implemented 45% of its startup strategy measures: ministry
summary: Germany has implemented 45% of its planned measures to promote startups, according to the economics ministry. The country's startup ecosystem is valued at $168 billion, ranking fourth internationally. The government aims to attract top talent and simplify financing options through the Future of Financing Act and Skilled Immigration Act. However, digitalizing visa processes remains a challenge, with 4% of measures not yet addressed. Startups play a crucial role in the country's economic renewal, with 31 unicorns in Germany.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.3 per cent on Monday to close at a near one-week high.

Solar panels atop a hops plantation in the Bavarian Holledau region in Au, Germany. EU successes in scaling up use of clean energy in the last year include reaching a record 41 GW of new solar energy capacity installed.
The European Commission predicts that the German economy will contract by 0.4 per cent, compared to a previous forecast of 0.2 per cent growth.

site_title: Asean and Africa: Building stronger communities through trade and investment
summary: Standard Chartered forecasts that trade expansion between ASEAN and Africa will outpace the average global annual growth rate by 2030, driven by the African Continental Free Trade Agreement (AfCFTA) and the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP). ASEAN firms have opportunities in Africa, particularly in digitization, innovation, and sustainable investment, with companies like Tolaram blazed a path in the continent. Collaboration on climate policies and infrastructure development can also bridge gaps and boost access to innovative financing solutions, with Standard Chartered well-positioned to support capital inflows and ensure clients gain from its international balance sheet.

images.alt_text: UN Secretary General Antonio Guterres talks to the media during a press conference on sidelines of the 43rd Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) Summit in Jakarta, Indonesia, 07 September 2023. Indonesia hosts the 43rd ASEAN Summit and related summits from 05 to 07 September

site_title: New HDB Plus flat segment could be a boon for young seniors
summary: Singapore's new HDB framework, emphasizing homes as for living, may benefit young seniors in their 50s and early 60s, who care for both young and old in their families. The Majulah Package, a retirement support scheme for those born in 1973 or earlier, includes an "Earn and Save" Bonus, Retirement Savings Bonus, and MediSave Bonus. The package costs the government approximately S$7 billion and aims to support young seniors in meeting their retirement needs.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
Under the new framework, Plus flats will come with more subsidies but with stricter resale conditions.
Under a new framework, HDB flats will classify BTO projects as Standard, Plus or Prime.
Potential flat buyers will have to think long and hard about how much they prize these locations versus any investment returns that they could make.

site_title: Arm’s IPO orders are already oversubscribed by 10 times
summary: Arm Holdings' initial public offering (IPO) is already oversubscribed by 10 times, with bankers planning to close the order book early. The IPO could end up as much as 15 times oversubscribed by Wednesday. Arm filed for the IPO at $47 to $51 a share, valuing the company at $54.5 billion. The company is still considering raising the price range, and the IPO is expected to price on Wednesday.

images.alt_text: Following strong demand from investors, Arm will likely be able to price the IPO at the top or above its US$47-to-US$51-per-share range.

site_title: Bringing our global strengths to the fore
summary: Singapore's stock market is poised for gradual transformation with the right level of support and participation from public and private stakeholders. The SGX Group, a trusted international venue for capital flows and risk management, has performed well despite a challenging macroeconomic environment. Asia, particularly South-east Asia, is expected to remain a bright spot in global growth, with the region accounting for 70% of global growth. The SGX Group is at the heart of international capital flows to Asia, facilitating transactions in Asian benchmark equity derivatives and other assets.

images.alt_text: Koh begins his duties as chairman on Jan 1, 2023.
Issuers whose financial indicators are at concerning thresholds should consider substantive disclosures on a proactive basis.
Mohamed Nasser Ismail, who has worked at the exchange for the past 18 years, will leave at the end of October for other opportunities, the exchange said.

site_title: A lot of Brics but no mortar
summary: BRICS, an alliance of Brazil, Russia, India, China, and South Africa, aims to represent the Global South, but its effectiveness as a collective action is uncertain. Despite predictions of rivaling the industrialized West, the bloc lacks a coherent agenda and has yet to replace the Washington Consensus. Anti-American rhetoric won't drive collective action, and internal issues, such as tensions between China and India, and disagreements over trade and investment policies, hinder its ability to pursue collective action. The US could counter the Brics' designs by offering access to its markets and reforming international economic organizations.

images.alt_text: The latest phase of Great Power competition is much more about technology than it is about trade.
Brics leaders and delegates on the closing day of the Brics summit in Johannesburg, South Africa, Aug 24, 2023. The grouping announced that they would welcome six new members in January 2024.

Amid global discontent with the current world order, the commitment of Brics nations (Brazil, Russia, India, China, and South Africa) to elevate the group as a prominent advocate for the "Global South" resonates, even with limited tangible outcomes.
The national flags of the BRICS (Brazil, Russia, India, China, South Africa) behind a window, at a BRICS foreign

site_title: Apple renews Qualcomm deal in sign its own modem chip isn’t ready
summary: Apple has renewed its agreement with Qualcomm to use the chipmaker's modem semiconductors for three more years, covering smartphone launches in 2024, 2025, and 2026. The deal, which was set to expire this year, suggests that Apple's efforts to design its own modem chip are taking longer than expected. Qualcomm's shares surged over 8% on the news, while Apple's stock rose less than 1%. The move validates Qualcomm's claim to having the best smartphone modem and maintains its lucrative position within Apple's supply chain.

images.alt_text: Adding to the pressure on Apple, Huawei on Friday launched two new smartphones – foldable phone Mate X5 and Mate 60 Pro+ smartphone, a new addition to a series it unveiled last week.

site_title: Red Cross cuts 2024 budget as donations fall
summary: The International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) will cut its 2024 budget by 13% due to reduced funding from major donors, including the US. This decision comes amid a surge in global humanitarian needs, particularly in Ukraine and Sudan. Director-General Robert Mardini expressed concern about the impact of the cuts, stating that global humanitarian needs have never been higher. The reduction in aid budgets globally is also affecting other humanitarian organizations.

site_title: Dangerous link between China’s real estate, economy and financial system
summary: China's real estate sector is facing a painful adjustment, with excess capacity and decelerating prices contributing to a slowdown. The sector's failure could have a significant impact on China's financial system, with spillover effects from real estate developers into the financial sector being a major concern. The risk of a "sudden stop" in a risk-off environment is low due to China's external creditor status and capital controls. Policymakers must focus on limiting the potential spillovers into the financial sector to avoid systemic risks, with measures to ensure financial stability being crucial.

images.alt_text: Country Garden’s tumble into crisis has shocked China’s financial markets because it’s a household name, known for building homes in smaller cities.
China’s property sector has been on a downward spiral since 2021 when the government took steps to stop developers from accumulating debt.
Central bank officials have pledged to use policy tools such as reserve requirement ratio cuts to ensure reasonably ample liquidity.

site_title: India’s Byju’s looks to raise US$1 billion with sale of Great Learning, Epic
summary: Byju's, an Indian education giant valued at $22 billion, is planning to sell two companies, Great Learning and Epic, to raise up to $1 billion. The sale is part of a business turnaround strategy to focus on its K-12 education area. Byju's acquired Great Learning for $600 million and Epic for $500 million in 2021. The company is also negotiating the repayment of a $1.2 billion loan and has received term sheets to sell Epic.

images.alt_text: Byju’s officials are in ongoing talks with lenders to amend terms of the US$1.2 billion in loans.

FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: People walk past an advertising hoarding of Byju's, an education technology company and one of India's biggest startup, outside one of its branches in New Delhi, India, June 23, 2023. REUTERS/Adnan Abidi/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: US: Stocks jump on rebound in tech optimism
summary: US stocks rebounded on Monday, with the Nasdaq Composite Index rising 1.1% to 13,917.89, while the S&P 500 gained 0.7% to 4,487.46. Tech stocks led the recovery, with Tesla's shares surging over 10% after a positive report from Morgan Stanley. Chipmaker Qualcomm also saw its shares rise after announcing a deal to supply Apple with 5G modems. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.3% to 34,663.72, driven by risk-on sentiment and optimism about the tech sector.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average has risen 73.42 points, or 0.21 per cent, at Monday's open to 34,650.01.

site_title: Goldman shrinks executive committee in reshuffle, moves admin officer to banking, markets: memo
summary: Goldman Sachs has reduced its executive committee to eight members, the fewest since 2010, and has promoted Ericka Leslie to head global banking and markets operations. Leslie, the current chief administrative officer, will oversee the bank's largest division, replacing a previous executive. The move leaves only two women in the executive committee, highlighting the lack of diversity in the bank's leadership. Leslie's previous duties will be reassigned to other executives, according to people familiar with the matter.

images.alt_text: Goldman Sachs reduced its headcount by about 3,200 in the first quarter in its biggest round of layoffs since the 2008 financial crisis. It also cut about 250 jobs in May.
CEO David Solomon's reorganization into three units last year and scaling down of loss-making consumer business lead to potential divestment of Goldman Sachs.
Goldman’s new hiring push is the first tangible fallout to emerge from regulators’ heightened interest in the firm.
Goldman Sachs reports a profit of US$1.07 billion, or US$3.08 per share, for the quarter ended Jun 30.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher on Tesla boost, inflation data in focus
summary: US stocks rose at Monday's open, driven by Tesla's rally, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average increasing 73.42 points, or 0.21%, to 34,650.01. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher, with gains of 23.49 points, or 0.53%, and 122.51 points, or 0.89%, respectively. Investors await inflation data later this week for clues on the US Federal Reserve's interest-rate path.

site_title: Crypto exchange Coinbase to disable some accounts of Indian users
summary: US-based crypto exchange Coinbase will disable some Indian accounts on September 25 due to not meeting updated standards. The move comes after India imposed stricter tax rules on cryptocurrencies in 2022, leading to a significant decline in trading volumes. Despite this, Coinbase remains committed to its long-term presence in the Indian market and continues to explore ways to strengthen its presence. The company had previously halted new user sign-ups and scrapped a payments initiative under regulatory pressure.

site_title: Franklin Templeton joins race to offer US spot Bitcoin ETF
summary: Franklin Templeton, a San Mateo, California-based asset manager with over $1.4 trillion in assets, has filed an application with the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) to offer the first US exchange-traded fund (ETF) that invests directly in Bitcoin. If approved, Franklin plans to use Coinbase Global as custodian for the fund's Bitcoin holdings and Bank of New York Mellon for cash. This move follows years of rejections and optimism that large asset managers' interest in Bitcoin investing could lead to a more receptive SEC.

site_title: How startups can tackle The Intangible Hulk
summary: Singapore is developing a framework to guide companies in disclosing intangible assets, which are crucial to the region's digitalized economy. Intangible assets, such as intellectual property and code, cannot be physically held, making it difficult to assess their value. The framework aims to increase transparency, potentially leading to better valuations and easier access to loans. This move addresses the need for clearer disclosure, as companies may inflate valuations, and whistleblowing becomes increasingly important to prevent corporate shenanigans.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai

site_title: US inflation outlook stable, credit pessimism rises in Fed study
summary: US inflation expectations remained stable in August, with median one-year-ahead inflation expectations at 3.6% and expectations for the three-year horizon at 2.8%. However, consumers grew more pessimistic about their finances and job market, with perceptions about current credit conditions and expectations about future conditions deteriorating. The share of households saying it's harder to access credit increased, reflecting growing concern about credit access.

images.alt_text: Growth is forecast to accelerate in the third quarter on the back of a recent pickup in household spending, which jumped in July by the most in six months.
Initial claims for state unemployment benefits fall to 216,000 in the week ended Sep 2 from a revised 229,000 the week before, according to the Labor Department.
The US economy has shown signs of resiliency in recent months despite an aggressive campaign of interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve to tackle high inflation.
A reading above 50 indicates growth in the services industry, which accounts for more than two-thirds of the economy.
The shortfall in goods and services trade grows to US$65 billion from a revised US$63.7 billion in the prior month, Commerce Department data shows.

site_title: AI and reputational risks
summary: Organisations using AI for customer-facing purposes face growing reputational risks due to potential biases and missteps. AI can lead to discriminatory outcomes, such as Amazon's hiring system favouring male candidates, and generate unhelpful product recommendations. To address these risks, organisations must adopt a "human-in-the-loop" approach, prioritise ethical AI practices, and cultivate a reputation-sensitive culture. This includes involving cross-functional teams to establish a comprehensive AI framework, prioritising fairness, transparency, and detection for bias, and taking responsibility for any issues that may occur. By doing so, organisations can build trust with customers and stakeholders, and fully exploit AI for business success.

images.alt_text: In this millennium, technology has been a massive deflationary force for anything that computers, programmable machinery and automation can do.

In today’s digital world, a company’s reputation does not solely exist in the real world, but is indented forever online. Digital platforms are often  very first touchpoint any stakeholder will engage with the brand.

site_title: Cultural differences have slowed European expansion, says LG Energy
summary: LG Energy Solution, a Korean battery maker, has faced challenges in ramping up production at its Polish plant due to cultural differences with local workers. The company's chief technology officer, Shin Youngjoon, acknowledged that LG Energy didn't initially understand Polish culture, leading to issues with instruction delivery and high staff turnover. To resolve the issue, the company has implemented changes and increased the role of automation. Despite the struggles, LG Energy plans to increase output to 100 GWh by 2025 and employs over 7,000 workers at the plant.

images.alt_text: The company, which supplies General Motors, Tesla and others, reported an operating profit of 461 billion won for the April-June period, versus 196 billion won a year earlier.

site_title: MoneyOwl client absorption is latest feather in iFast’s cap
summary: iFast Corporation is taking over the investment and insurance business of MoneyOwl, a social enterprise that had decided to wind down its operations due to high costs and low revenue. The transfer will see MoneyOwl's clients transacting on iFast's portal starting next month. iFast aims to grow its assets under administration to S$100 billion by 2028, with a focus on its ePension division in Hong Kong, which is expected to achieve over HK$500 million in profit before taxes by 2025. The company's digital banking business is also expected to contribute significantly to its growth, with a target of breaking even by 2024.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Chuin Ting Weber, chief executive and chief investment officer of fund manager MoneyOwl.
MoneyOwl is winding down operations, as low revenues and high operating costs made financial viability a stiff challenge.

Lim Chung Chun, chief executive of iFast was named Outstanding CEO of the year, for his leadership in growing the company into a regional fintech network with over S$18 billion in assets under administration (AUA).

Going into 2024, chief executive Lim Chung Chun said iFast will also be in a position to boost its dividend payouts to shareholders, as the group’s overall cash flow starts to improve “quite significantly”.

site_title: SGX listcos post 16.7% higher quarterly profits in April-June quarter
summary: SGX-listed companies reported a 16.7% increase in quarterly profits to S$7.1 billion, driven by a 57% of companies posting profits, while 25 were in the red. Of the profitable companies, 23 improved earnings and eight swung back into profitability. The lacklustre results were attributed to a lack of divestment gains, slower monetisation activities, and reduced market transaction volumes.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek

Generic pictures of property construction in Singapore. Demand for construction across Singapore in 2023 is expected to be stable. This is due to a steady level of construction demand and some backlog of remaining workloads impacted by the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: KKR raises stake in Indian billionaire Ambani’s Reliance Retail with US$250 million
summary: KKR has invested an additional $250 million in Indian billionaire Mukesh Ambani's Reliance Retail Ventures, increasing its stake to 1.42% at a valuation of $100 billion. The investment adds to KKR's bet on the country's largest retailer, which operates over 18,000 stores and competes with Amazon and Walmart's Flipkart. This marks growing interest in Ambani's retail operations, with the valuation of the business nearly doubling in less than three years. The investment is subject to regulatory approvals and comes after Reliance Retail reported a consolidated net profit of $1.5 billion for the financial year ended in March 2023.

images.alt_text: The target fund raise of US$2.5 billion is part of a combined US$3.5 billion target the firm has set for itself, a part of which US$1 billion came from Qatar Investment Authority (QIA) and was announced last month.
FILE PHOTO: Trading information for KKR & Co is displayed on a screen on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, U.S., August 23, 2018. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo
KKR plans to launch its private equity fund for US retail investors in the current quarter.

site_title: Hoi Hup, Sunway clinch keenly contested Tengah EC site for S$348.5 million
summary: Hoi Hup Realty and Sunway Developments have secured an executive condominium (EC) site in Tengah for S$348.5 million, with the S$703 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr) rate marking a record high for EC land. The 99-year leasehold site, which can yield 495 EC units, attracted nine bids from heavyweight developers. The top bid reflects confidence in the EC market and Tengah, with the estimated launch price potentially falling between S$1,450 and S$1,550 psf.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
The 99-year leasehold Plantation Close EC site, which can yield an estimated 495 units, is located between the future Tengah Park MRT station and Bukit Batok West MRT station.

site_title: Shipping giant Maersk taps investors for first green- bond sale
summary: Shipping giant Maersk is selling its first green bonds, denominated in US dollars, to finance or refinance green assets and help achieve its goal of reducing greenhouse gas emissions to net zero by 2040. The 10-year bonds may yield 1.9 percentage points above Treasuries and are being managed by Barclays, Citigroup, HSBC, JPMorgan Chase, and Morgan Stanley. The sale comes as the shipping sector seeks to decarbonize, with Maersk ordering more methanol-fuelled ships. This is the company's first green bond sale in the US market, which has seen a slump in sustainable bond sales amid political pressure.

images.alt_text: ARA Asset Management Limited announced on Monday the acquisition of a portfolio of 38 select-service hotels, branded as Hyatt Place and Hyatt House, across 21 states in the US.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Protege Ventures launched a S$500,000 fund to develop student entrepreneurship, while Olam Group denied US$50 billion Nigerian forex fraud allegations. Malaysia committed to allocating RM90 million yearly to boost the economy, and Standard Chartered appointed a new global head of wealth planning. Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.3% despite weak Asian sentiment, and Prime Minister Lee acknowledged "young seniors" in their 50s and early 60s as a sandwiched phase of life.

site_title: Impact of possible strikes on Detroit Three automakers
summary: A US labor union, the United Auto Workers (UAW), has threatened a strike against General Motors, Ford, and Stellantis if a contract deal isn't reached by September 14. A strike could cost billions of dollars in losses for automakers and their suppliers, with estimates suggesting a week-long strike could shave off $480 million from GM's earnings. The strike could also impact US new light vehicle sales, with a month-long stoppage potentially cutting output by 500,000 vehicles.

images.alt_text: The raises, negotiated in the 2019 contract with the UAW, lift the pay of the workers by US$4.33 an hour, or US$9,000 a year, according to Ford.
Another key issue in the talks involves pay and treatment of workers at GM’s joint venture battery plants.

site_title: As interest rates stay elevated, investors must consider impact on bottom lines
summary: Singapore-listed companies are feeling the impact of rising interest rates, with non-bank counters on the Straits Times Index experiencing a 70% increase in net finance costs in their latest semi-annual financial statements. Around half of these companies have reported a net increase in finance costs or interest expenses. Investors entering the market must consider how long the impact of higher interest rates will continue to weigh on locally-listed companies' bottom lines.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim

Investors across assets are rethinking bets on a downturn. Equity, credit and rate markets together are assigning 16 per cent probability to a US recession over the next six to 12 months, down from more than 50 per cent in October, a JPMorgan trading model reveals.
FILE PHOTO: The Nasdaq logo is displayed at the Nasdaq Market site in Times Square in New York City, U.S., December 3, 2021. REUTERS/Jeenah Moon/File Photo

site_title: Olam shares slump
summary: Olam Group's shares plummeted 7.8% by 3:06 pm, marking the largest daily decline since March 2020, after the company denied allegations of a multibillion-dollar fraud in Nigeria. The allegations, made by external parties, claim Olam Nigeria's subsidiaries engaged in illicit activities, but the company categorically denies them. The board has directed an audit review into the matter, with Olam's business in Nigeria generating over $3 billion in annual revenue. The company's shares slid for four straight months until August before the latest decline.

site_title: EU forecasts German economy in recession in 2023
summary: The European Commission has downgraded its forecast for the euro area economy, predicting a 0.8% growth in 2023, down from 1.1% previously. Germany, the region's largest economy, is expected to contract by 0.4% this year, while the Netherlands is forecast to shrink by 0.5%. Inflation is expected to remain elevated, at 5.6% this year and 2.9% in 2024. The downgrade may lead to concerns about a prolonged period of subdued growth and above-target inflation, and could influence the European Central Bank's interest rate decisions.

images.alt_text: After a winter recession sparked by the Ukraine war, German output remains stagnant in Q2, and this is likely to persist in Q3.

site_title: China tightens scrutiny of municipal debt
summary: China is tightening scrutiny of municipal debt by putting thousands of local government financial vehicles (LGFVs) under closer inspection, aiming to prevent them from raising funds through new entities or shell companies. This move is part of a broader effort to address China's slowing economy and the growing debt problem, which has ballooned to around $9 trillion. The new measures are expected to include special bond issuance, debt swaps, and loan rollovers to prevent LGFV debt from growing further.

images.alt_text: The Chinese central bank may set up a special purpose vehicle with banks to provide low-cost and long-term liquidity to local government financing vehicles (LGFVs), the report says.
LGFVs have been central to government efforts to ensure China’s infrastructure and public services expand fast enough to sustain outsize economic growth.

site_title: UBS to cut wealth jobs in Asia as activity slows
summary: UBS is cutting Asia wealth-management jobs in the low hundreds, mainly from teams acquired from Credit Suisse, due to muted client activity and China's slowing economy. At least 100 positions are expected to go, with relationship managers in Hong Kong and Singapore among those affected. The bank aims to keep private bankers in Australia and India for now. This move follows a 9% decline in the region's profit before tax in the second quarter.

images.alt_text: Logos of Swiss banks Credit Suisse and UBS are seen before a news conference in Zurich Switzerland, August 30, 2023.  REUTERS/Denis Balibouse

site_title: Thailand’s new PM draws flak in parliament for ‘aimless’ economic agenda
summary: Thailand's Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin faced criticism in parliament for his party's vague economic agenda, with opposition lawmakers calling it "aimless" and lacking specifics. The agenda, which includes digital cash handouts, lower energy prices, and tourism relaxation, was met with skepticism, with some questioning its sources of funds and feasibility. The government aims for annual growth of at least 5% and plans to boost tourism to support the economy. The opposition Move Forward party called for more details and a market-led approach to increase income for farmers.

images.alt_text: Srettha Thavisin faces the challenge of boosting growth amid declining demand for its goods from its top trading partner China, and less-than-expected earnings from foreign tourists.

site_title: Singapore banking veteran Elizabeth Sam dies at 84
summary: Elizabeth Sam, a renowned Singaporean banker and former chairman of the Singapore International Monetary Exchange, passed away at 84. With over four decades of experience in the financial sector, Sam played a key role in developing Singapore's financial markets, particularly the Asian dollar market and foreign exchange market. She held various high-profile positions, including chief manager at the Monetary Authority of Singapore and executive vice-president at OCBC. Sam was remembered for her feminine flair in a male-dominated industry and her contributions to Singapore's financial sector, earning her the Public Service Star award.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
MAS' approach of 'caution with creativity', industry cooperation key to 50 years of success: PM Lee
A private funeral for Dr Richard Hu is scheduled to be held on Sunday at the Mandai Crematorium.

site_title: Yen surges on BOJ’s remarks; US dollar eases ahead of US inflation
summary: The yen surged 0.67% to 146.85 against the US dollar on Monday after Bank of Japan governor Kazuo Ueda hinted at ending negative interest rates, boosting hopes for a "soft landing". The US dollar eased ahead of the week's key US inflation reading, with traders seeking signs of a slowdown in rate hikes. The yen's gain was also seen as a stopgap measure, similar to government intervention, following its weakness past the 145 per US dollar threshold.

site_title: Biden showcases Boeing, chip deals as US and Vietnam draw closer
summary: US President Joe Biden announced a series of deals with top US companies and Vietnam, solidifying their "comprehensive strategic partnership" and increasing economic integration in the Indo-Pacific region. Deals include a Boeing aircraft purchase, semiconductor design centers, and infrastructure projects, aiming to boost US influence in the region and counter China's assertiveness. The agreements also include technology companies and initiatives to make emerging AI technology more accessible to Vietnamese businesses, further deepening ties between the two countries.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden with Vietnam's Communist Party General Secretary Nguyen Phu Trong (right) after a meeting in Hanoi; Biden’s visit comes as bilateral trade and investment ties are growing and a long-simmering territorial dispute between Vietnam and China heats up in the South China Sea.
Vietnam was the world’s fifth fastest-growing aviation market in 2022 when it lifted Covid-19 travel restrictions.
The individual Asean governments must undertake reform and adjust to the new, harsher conditions. The group must also renew efforts to work together, to enhance the role of the region.

During his state visit to Vietnam on Sunday (Sep 10), US President Joe Biden is expected to oversee the signing of a “comprehensive strategic partnership” with Hanoi, a symbolic but significant status long coveted by the US.

site_title: The danger of building strong narratives on weak data
summary: Britain's economic growth data was initially reported as a recession in 2012, but subsequent revisions showed the economy had actually grown 0.8% in Q1 2012. This highlights the challenges of measuring GDP, with some countries experiencing large revisions of up to 10 times the original value. This issue is not unique to Britain, with Ireland experiencing revisions of up to 21.4% in 2015. The article concludes that people often build strong narratives on weak data, and a more nuanced approach to data analysis is needed to avoid misinterpreting economic trends.

images.alt_text: Shoppers in Union Square in San Francisco, California, US, on Monday, June 26, 2023. California led a nationwide jump in job vacancies in April that reversed recent declines and keeps pressure on the Federal Reserve to consider more interest-rate hikes. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

The Bank of England in its latest monetary policy report said the UK should avoid a recession – a reversal of its position last November when it forecast the longest period of contraction in modern history.

site_title: BMW to invest £600 million in UK plants to take Mini fully electric
summary: BMW plans to invest £600 million in its UK plants, taking the Mini brand fully electric by 2030. The company will produce two electric models, the Mini Cooper 3-door and Mini Aceman, at its Oxford plant starting in 2026. The plant will also make electric models for China, with exports beginning in 2024. The move aims to boost Britain's car industry and secure its position as a major manufacturer.

images.alt_text: The i4 eDrive35's exemplary fluidity is paired with supple ride quality.
BMW is close to hitting its target of 15 per cent battery-electric sales this year, beating Mercedes-Benz and Porsche, for whom battery-electric cars have so far made up around 11 per cent of sales.
The logo of German automaker BMW is seen in Brussels, Belgium February 28, 2023. REUTERS/Yves Herman

site_title: China’s central bank to scrutinise bulk dollar purchases: sources
summary: China's central bank is tightening scrutiny of large US dollar purchases by domestic firms, requiring approval for transactions over $50 million. This move comes as the yuan faces mounting depreciation pressure, with a 6% decline against the US dollar this year. The People's Bank of China has convened meetings with commercial banks to discuss the matter and extend the approval process. The yuan's recent decline has raised concerns of further weakening, with some predicting a decline beyond 7.5 US dollars.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The headquarters of the People's Bank of China, the central bank, is pictured in Beijing, China, February 3, 2020. REUTERS/Jason Lee/File Photo
The PBOC has set firmer-than-expected daily guidance rates to stem the yuan’s decline.

Beijing is trying to revive confidence in the world’s second-largest economy as latest signs show further weakening in the property market, deflation pressure, a slump in exports and subdued consumer spending.
China’s central bank kept a key interest rate that guides mortgages on hold and made a smaller-than-expected cut to another rate in August.
The directive is the latest in a volley of measures China has taken to defend a currency that’s been beaten down by a weak economy and capital outflows.

site_title: Denzel hangs in, but ‘Nun’ better in North American theatres
summary: The Nun II, directed by Michael Chaves, took the top spot at the North American box office with an estimated US$32.6 million, following the Conjuring series trend of resilient horror movies. The film, starring Taissa Farmiga, Jonas Bloquet, and Storm Reid, fell short of the original US$53.8 million take of 2018's The Nun. Denzel Washington's The Equalizer 3 took second place, while My Big Fat Greek Wedding 3 and Jawan rounded out the top five.

images.alt_text: Netflix held the fan screening of “One Piece,”  at the Santa Monica Pier in Santa Monica, Calif., on Aug. 24, 2023. The “One Piece” franchise is enormously popular, with more than 516 million books sold and numerous anime series and movies released. (Yuri Hasegawa/The New York Times)
From left: Liu Haoran, Zhou Dongyu and Qu Chuxiao star in Anthony Chen's The Breaking Ice.

American director Woody Allen with French actresses Valérie Lemercier (left) and Lou De Laage at the photocall for the movie "Coup de Chance", presented out of competition at the 80th Venice Film Festival on Monday (Sep 4).

site_title: Thousands of UK jobs lost as retailer Wilko rescue deal collapses
summary: Wilko, a UK discount retailer, has collapsed after a rescue deal attempt by Canadian tycoon Doug Putman fell through, resulting in thousands of job losses. Wilko, which employed 12,500 staff, ran out of cash due to weak footfall. The company had received a £40 million lifeline earlier this year, but it was not enough to save it. The collapse is attributed to management's decision to take out cash from the business, according to the GMB labour group.

site_title: Nvidia’s dominance in AI chips deters funding for startups
summary: Nvidia's dominance in AI chips has chilled venture funding for startups, with US deals falling 80% from a year ago. The company's strong market position has made it harder for competitors to raise funding, with some startups, like Mythic, running out of cash. Investors now require companies to have a product ready for launch or generating sales, with funding amounts dropping to around $100 million. However, AMD and Intel's planned chip launches and emerging niches in data-intensive computing offer potential alternatives to Nvidia's chip, and some startups are still managing to raise funds with high-profile backing.

images.alt_text: The deals with two of India’s largest business houses will help the Nvidia deepen inroads to the emerging AI ecosystem of the South Asian nation.

Cutting out intermediaries like Nvidia, AMD, and Intel allows companies to optimise chips specifically for their unique tasks whether it’s streaming videos, serving up search queries, or managing massive databases.
Nvidia this week did not specify which countries in the Middle East were affected.
QCT generates billions of dollars in revenue annually, with AI servers accounting for 65 per cent of its total sales, Mike Yang says.
Despite the staggering dollar amount, Nvidia’s buyback amounted to only 2.1 per cent of its nearly US$1.2 trillion market value, or buyback yield, as at Wednesday.
From AI startups to major cloud services providers such as Microsoft, all are looking to get their hands on more Nvidia chips.

site_title: Apac consumers willing to pay more for sustainable products, but large-scale solutions still lacking: Deloitte
summary: Deloitte's survey of 23 geographies found Asian-Pacific (Apac) consumers are more willing to pay for sustainable products and system-level solutions, with 52% changing purchasing behaviors due to climate concerns and 49% supporting new regulations. However, the region lags global averages in driving large-scale solutions through financial markets and reducing structural barriers to greener choices. To address this, Deloitte recommends collaboration between governments, private sector, and consumers to normalize affordable green products, provide low-emission energy options, and make recycling easier.

images.alt_text: Mia Pei
Deloitte, with a workforce of over 100,000 in India, says it will hire 50,000 more staff over three years, and expand its footprint in new towns.
Most current workers will likely need to upskill, rather than completely retrain, to find a new job or remain in their current one.
Invest and grow charts concept Credit: PIXABAY

site_title: Eurozone bond yields rise after Japanese yields hit 9-year high
summary: Eurozone bond yields rose on Monday after Japan's 10-year bond yield hit a 9-year high. Germany's 10-year bond yield rose 4 basis points to 2.633%, while Italy's 10-year bond yield increased 5 basis points to 4.386%. Traders expect the European Central Bank to keep interest rates at 3.75% with a 62% chance of no change and a 38% chance of a 25bp increase. The rise in Japanese yields is seen as a driver of the increase in eurozone bond yields, with investors concerned that a rise in Japanese rates could draw money back to Japan and out of European bond markets.

images.alt_text: The sharp rise in the yield came as investors reacted to BOJ governor Kazuo Ueda’s interview with the Yomiuri newspaper, published on Saturday, in which he said the central bank could end its negative interest rate policy when its 2 per cent inflation goal is in sight, indicating possible rate hikes by year-end.

site_title: Saudi Aramco to supply full oil volumes to North Asia refiners: sources
summary: Saudi Aramco will supply full contractual volumes of crude oil to North Asian buyers in October, despite pledging extended output cuts, according to sources. The company raised its October official selling price for Arab Light crude by less than expected 10 cents. This decision comes after Saudi Aramco prolonged its 1 million barrels per day output cut to the end of the year, driving up benchmark Brent crude above $90 a barrel. Despite the price hike, Saudi crude remains more expensive than other options, and refiners are bound by term contracts.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: An Aramco employee walks near an oil tank at Saudi Aramco's Ras Tanura oil refinery and oil terminal in Saudi Arabia May 21, 2018. REUTERS/Ahmed Jadallah/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Olam denies media reports of US$50 billion Nigerian forex fraud, sets up review
summary: Olam Group has denied allegations of a multi-billion dollar forex fraud in Nigeria, stating that references to $50 billion and $34 billion are "manifestly inaccurate and designed to be misleading". The company has set up a review of the matter, despite a lack of evidence, and emphasized that its Nigerian unit's cumulative turnover was $14 billion from 2015 to 2022, with capital importations totaling $2.4 billion. Olam will cooperate with legitimate requests from Nigerian authorities and has settled rule violations with the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Olam Group's food ingredient unit, ofi, has secured a sustainability-linked facility worth US$1.75 billion to refinance its existing loans.
Olam falls as much as 7.6 per cent in early trading.
Suresh Sundararajan, the CEO of Olam's incubation and venture building arm Nupo Ventures.
The group said it expects to continue to incur expenses associated with the execution of its reorganisation plan in H2.

site_title: China’s central bank yanks yuan off 16-year low with strongest fixing bias
summary: China's central bank set a firmer-than-expected daily midpoint guidance rate for the yuan, yanking it off a 16-year low against the US dollar. The rate, set at 7.2148 per dollar, is the largest deviation from market projections on record and aims to stem the yuan's decline. The move limits the downside room for the yuan to sink and suggests the authorities are determined to prevent further weakening. However, analysts warn that the yuan may face more challenges ahead due to global economic uncertainties and the Federal Reserve's monetary tightening pace.

images.alt_text: The consumer price index remains well below the government’s official target of around 3 per cent for the year.
The stamp duty has been heavily debated in Hong Kong over the past weeks and China’s cut gave backing to those calling for a reduction.

site_title: Private credit and the illiquidity premium
summary: Private credit has stepped in to fill the gap in the commercial real estate market, offering equity-like returns with lower risk, as banks struggle to lend to small and medium-sized companies and those looking to refinance commercial properties due to weakness in the market. Manager skill is critical in this sector, as illiquidity can be a significant issue, with investors holding less than 20% of their total net worth in liquid investments. This shift towards private credit may provide a more stable investment option, but its potential impact on traditional asset classes remains to be seen.

images.alt_text: Institutional investors around the globe have continued to add more capital into private credit funds.

site_title: Tropical storm rains batter China for seventh day
summary: A tropical storm, formerly Typhoon Haikui, continues to batter southern China for the seventh day, causing widespread flooding and damage. Heavy rains in the Guangxi region have reached 511.2 mm, shattering local records, and have stranded residents in low-lying areas. The storm has weakened but its residual vortex has continued to wreak havoc, with the city of Shenzhen experiencing its heaviest rain since records began in 1952. Scientists warn that typhoons are becoming more intense and complex, escalating the risk of disaster in coastal cities.

images.alt_text: A flooded area after heavy rains in Hong Kong, Sept 8, 2023.

Cargo ships wait in the anchor zone to cross the Panama Canal from the Pacific entrance near Panama City, Panama, on Sept 1, 2023. Ships have been waiting for days as the congestion to cross from both sides  increase due to the intense droughts in the country.
The city was shut down on Friday and Saturday last week due to Super Typhoon Saola.

A woman being evacuated from a flooded area following heavy rains caused by Typhoon Haikui in Xiamen, in China's southern Fujian province. Economic losses have reached 5.05 billion yuan (S$942.7 million).

site_title: More Chinese cities lift home-buying curbs to revive demand
summary: Two major Chinese cities, Jinan and Qingdao, lifted home-buying curbs, allowing homes in all areas to be put on the market, as part of broader support measures to revive the sluggish property market. This move joins several other cities in dropping restrictions, including Nanjing, Dalian, and Shenyang. The measures aim to attract buyers and boost the economy, which accounts for a quarter of China's economy, following a sector-wide liquidity crunch since 2021.

images.alt_text: Shenyang is one of three cities that have announced they will no longer restrict the number of properties residents can buy in most parts of the city.
China’s property sector has been on a downward spiral since 2021 when the government took steps to stop developers from accumulating debt.

site_title: Brokers’ take: RHB raises target on Frencken Group ahead of industry recovery, but risks remain
summary: RHB Research raised its target price on Frencken Group to S$0.97, citing the semiconductor industry's expected recovery for next year. The new target price incorporates rolled-over FY2024 estimates, but risks remain due to lower margins and higher-than-expected costs. Frencken's H1 earnings fell short of RHB's estimates, but overall earnings projections for FY2024-2025 have been raised. The brokerage maintains a "neutral" call, citing a mixed near-term outlook and a "slightly lofty" valuation. A firmer recovery of electronics demand is expected, but the pace of inventory drawdown and electronics demand recovery remain uncertain.

images.alt_text: This came as Frencken books lower revenue and higher finance costs.
Semiconductor companies could ride the AI boom, even if they do not directly produce chips that are used in AI applications.
Shares of Frencken Group spiked on Tuesday (Aug 15) following the release of  half-year financial results for the semiconductor and machine manufacturer.
Frencken Group expects stable revenue in the second half despite a cautious full-year outlook.

site_title: Oil prices ease but supply cuts keep Brent above US$90/barrel
summary: Oil prices eased on Monday, with Brent crude falling 49 cents to $90.16 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude declined 74 cents to $86.77 a barrel. Despite the drop, Brent remained above $90 due to ongoing supply cuts by Saudi Arabia and Russia, which will continue until the end of the year. Economic concerns in China, fueled by a stronger US dollar, also weighed on fuel demand. The International Energy Agency and OPEC are set to release their monthly reports this week, which may impact oil prices further.

images.alt_text: Russia’s extra cut is less than a third of the size of Riyadh’s and applies to exports rather than production, but their combined effect is forcing consumers to run down their inventories to satisfy demand, driving up prices in the process.
Interest rate hikes can slow economic growth and reduce oil demand.

site_title: AirAsia’s operations to return to pre-pandemic level by Dec: Fernandes
summary: AirAsia's parent company, Capital A, expects the airline's operations to return to pre-pandemic levels by December, with 190 planes operational, a slight delay from the earlier target of August. The carrier's operating level stood at 50-60% in the first half, driven by improving demand from migrating workers, tourism, students, and connecting travelers. CEO Tony Fernandes attributed the delay to ongoing maintenance.

site_title: Tesla to surge thanks to Dojo supercomputer, Morgan Stanley says
summary: Morgan Stanley predicts Tesla's Dojo supercomputer could add up to $500 billion to the company's market value through faster adoption of robotaxis and network services. The supercomputer, designed for training driving systems, may put Tesla at an "asymmetric advantage" in a $10 trillion market, making software and services the biggest value driver. Analysts upgraded the stock to "overweight" and raised the 12-month price target to $400 per share.

site_title: Temasek’s Advanced MedTech chooses Singapore IPO over US: sources
summary: Advanced MedTech, a medical device maker backed by Temasek, has chosen to list in Singapore instead of the US, according to sources. The company, which could value at about $1 billion, has picked Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, and OCBC to work on its planned initial public offering (IPO), which could raise $200-300 million. A listing in Singapore may take place as early as the end of this year, which could help catalyze the country's dormant IPO market.

images.alt_text: South-east Asia generally should attract a lot of capital inflow and attention over the next five to 10 years, says SGX's Pol de Win.

site_title: China’s August new bank loans jump more than expected; credit growth quickens
summary: China's new bank loans jumped 3.9 times in August to 1.36 trillion yuan, beating expectations, as the central bank sought to boost economic growth. Credit growth improved modestly, with mortgage loans rebounding and corporate loans rising. The government has rolled out policy measures to spur housing demand, and central bank officials pledged to use reserve requirement ratio cuts to ensure liquidity. The M2 money supply grew 10.6% from a year earlier, and outstanding yuan loans grew 11.1% in August.

images.alt_text: The PBOC has set firmer-than-expected daily guidance rates to stem the yuan’s decline.
The consumer price index remains well below the government’s official target of around 3 per cent for the year.

site_title:
Singapore stocks up despite weak 
Asian sentiment; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.3% to 3,218.28, defying weak Asian market sentiment. Despite Japan's Nikkei 225 index shedding 0.4% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index falling 0.6%, Singapore's gains were driven by a 9.8 times oversubscription of NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer. IG market analyst Yeap Jun Rong attributed the positive sentiment to Asian markets digesting Bank of Japan governor Kazuo Ueda's comments on ending ultra-loose monetary policies, with the BOJ potentially having enough data by year-end to make a decision.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan

The sharp rise in the yield came as investors reacted to BOJ governor Kazuo Ueda’s interview with the Yomiuri newspaper, published on Saturday, in which he said the central bank could end its negative interest rate policy when its 2 per cent inflation goal is in sight, indicating possible rate hikes by year-end.

site_title: Employers to provide proof of acceptable lodging for new non-Malaysian work permit holders
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Manpower (MOM) will require employers in the construction, marine shipyard, and process sectors to provide proof of acceptable accommodation for new non-Malaysian work permit holders, starting September 19. This requirement aims to ensure workers have a safe and suitable place to stay, following a 19% increase in work permit holders in these sectors since pre-Covid levels. Employers must provide tenancy or rental agreements, or contracts with accommodation providers, and may face suspension of work pass privileges if they fail to comply.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
While they recognise ferrying workers on lorries is not ideal, the authorities say banning transporting workers on lorries will pose operational challenges to businesses.
Construction workers working on the roof of a walkway at Blk 4 Queen's Road, on Nov 05, 2020.
Including housekeepers and porters, there are now a total of nine roles where firms can hire "non-traditional source" workers.

site_title: Malaysia to spend RM90 billion yearly to speed up economic transformation
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim announced a revised economic plan, allocating RM415 billion from 2023 to 2025 to boost the economy and turn the country into a high-income nation by 2025. The plan includes measures to accelerate economic structure reform, strengthen competitiveness, and promote high-value industries. New initiatives include increasing low-income earners' salaries, embracing advanced technology, and accelerating the transition to high-value industries. The government aims to create 7,000 job opportunities and contribute RM9.5 billion to GDP by 2025.

images.alt_text: Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim (sixth from left) unveiled the New Industrial Master Plan with other ministers on Sep 1, 2023.
Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim said there is a strong interest  for international collaboration that will provide additional avenues to decarbonise.

site_title: China economy shows tentative signs of stability as CPI ticks up
summary: China's economy shows tentative signs of stability, with the consumer price index (CPI) ticking up in August, albeit by a slim margin, and factory-gate prices narrowing. Data expected this week may show a pickup in credit demand, adding to recent signs of stabilization. Analysts expect the economy's slump to slow in the coming months, with the government's annual growth target of about 5% at risk due to ongoing property crisis and weak confidence.

images.alt_text: China’s youth are seen as key to growth in the country’s huge consumer market.
The producer price index has fallen 3.0 per cent from a year earlier – in line with expectations – after a drop of 4.4 per cent in July.

site_title: Global companies to hike security spending as threats rise: survey
summary: A survey of 1,775 chief security officers in 30 countries found that global companies are expected to increase their security budgets significantly due to rising economic and social unrest. Non-cybersecurity incidents, such as theft and intellectual property loss, cost companies over US$1 trillion in revenue in 2022. The survey found that 46% of companies plan to increase their security budgets, with 42% investing in artificial intelligence to spot threats more quickly. Economic unrest, climate change, and social causes are driving security breaches, with North America being particularly affected.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Miniatures of people with computers are seen in front of binary codes and words 'Cyber attack' in this illustration taken July 19, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: If Asean means business
summary: Asean nations must undertake reform and work together to enhance the region's role, as high politics and post-pandemic uncertainties pose challenges to business and economy. The group's centrality is crucial, with individual governments needing to cooperate and integrate to achieve deeper trade flow and linkages to global supply chains. Asean must also address emerging opportunities from digital and green trends, leveraging comparative advantages and setting regional standards. With the recent Asean Business and Investment Summit emphasizing "Asean matters," the region must develop a forward-looking agenda to be resilient against future shocks and leverage new drivers for growth.

images.alt_text: UN Secretary General Antonio Guterres talks to the media during a press conference on sidelines of the 43rd Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) Summit in Jakarta, Indonesia, 07 September 2023. Indonesia hosts the 43rd ASEAN Summit and related summits from 05 to 07 September
According to Boston Consulting Group, Asean’s digital economy is projected to triple by 2030, reaching almost US$1 trillion, up from the current US$300 billion.
A masked traveller at Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport in Arlington, Virginia, April 28, 2023. While Covid-19 mandates and lockdowns are long gone, the virus isn't.
Move Forward Party leader and prime ministerial candidate Pita Limjaroenrat  waves to his supporters during a victory parade in Bangkok on May 15, 2023.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks tumble 1.43% at Monday’s open
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index dropped 1.43% to 17,941.65 on Monday, following a sell-off last week fueled by US interest rate worries. The Shanghai Composite Index edged up 0.09% and the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 0.05%. The losses were attributed to investors catching up on market movements over the weekend.

site_title: Philippines resupplies sea outpost despite China manoeuvres
summary: The Philippines successfully resupplied a stranded ship in the South China Sea, despite "dangerous manoeuvres" by China's Coast Guard vessels and militia. This is the Philippines' second successful resupply mission since China thwarted a similar operation in August. The move comes amid a territorial dispute between the two nations over the disputed sea. China has warned against entering the area without approval, but the Philippines has continued to pressure Beijing to change its ways.

images.alt_text: “At present, it is very important to oppose taking sides, bloc confrontation and a new Cold War,” says China's Premier Li Qiang.

US President Joe Biden with Vietnam's Communist Party General Secretary Nguyen Phu Trong (right) after a meeting in Hanoi; Biden’s visit comes as bilateral trade and investment ties are growing and a long-simmering territorial dispute between Vietnam and China heats up in the South China Sea.

During his state visit to Vietnam on Sunday (Sep 10), US President Joe Biden is expected to oversee the signing of a “comprehensive strategic partnership” with Hanoi, a symbolic but significant status long coveted by the US.

site_title: Protege Ventures launches new S$500,000 fund to develop student entrepreneurship
summary: Protege Ventures, a student-run venture fund programme in Singapore, has launched a new S$500,000 fund to invest in early-stage technology startups founded by students or recent graduates. The fund, contributed by Matrix Partners China, aims to support the growth of student-led startups. This is the 11th edition of the Lee Kuan Yew Global Business Plan competition, which has trained 251 students and invested S$265,000 in 10 startups, with collective funding of over S$35 million.

images.alt_text: Goh Ruoxue

The Marina & David Su Protege Ventures Fund II will allow for more investment in early-stage technology startups founded by students or recent graduates of Singapore’s polytechnics and universities seeking pre-seed to seed funding. 

(From left) Sherwin Ng, Managing Partner of Protege Ventures; Anaanya Bijay, Managing Partner of Protege Ventures; Prof Lim Sun Sun, SMU’s Vice President of Partnerships and Engagement; Deputy Prime Minister and Coordinating Minister for Economic Policies Heng Swee Keat; and David Su, Founding Managing Partner of Matrix Partners China

site_title: Asia: Most markets in retreat as US inflation data looms
summary: Asia markets retreated on Monday, with Hong Kong leading losses over 1% after playing catch-up with regional declines on Friday due to a heavy storm. Investors focus on the upcoming US inflation report, which may ease concerns about the Federal Reserve's interest rate plans. The region's weak run is attributed to China's economic struggles, with few catalysts driving activity. The US consumer price index figures are expected to be a key focus, particularly as the Fed emphasizes data-driven decisions.

images.alt_text: People walk past a screen displaying the Hang Seng Index at Central district, in Hong Kong, China March 17, 2023. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu
Generic shots of SGX

site_title: Russian diamond giant Alrosa finds biggest jewellery gem in decade
summary: Russian diamond giant Alrosa has discovered a 390.7-carat diamond of jewelry quality, the largest to be recovered in Russia in a decade. Found at the Mayat mine in Yakutia, the stone is of non-standard shape and has a yellow-brown halo. Sanctions imposed by countries such as the US and UK may hinder the sale of the diamond due to restrictions on importing Russian gem-quality diamonds. Alrosa's sales have recovered from initial sanctions by shifting volumes to Asia, mainly India.

images.alt_text: Pandora now anticipates organic sales to grow between 2 per cent and 5 per cent, compared to the previous range of -2 per cent to 3 per cent.

site_title: SoftBank’s Arm eyes pricing IPO at top of range or above: sources
summary: SoftBank's chip design arm, Arm, is likely to price its initial public offering (IPO) at the top or above its initial range of $47-$51 per share, following strong investor demand. The IPO aims to raise $54.5 billion, surpassing SoftBank's original valuation of $64 billion. Arm is considering raising the price range or seeking a valuation above $54.5 billion. The company has signed up major clients, including Apple and Nvidia, as cornerstone investors.

images.alt_text: Arm is seeking a valuation on a fully diluted basis of US$50 billion to US$54.5 billion.
SoftBank is offering 95.5 million American depository shares of Arm for a price of between US$47 and US$51 apiece.
Arm has lined up some of its biggest customers – Apple, Nvidia, Intel and Samsung Electronics – as strategic investors for the initial public offering.
The show of support from some of the tech industry’s biggest names will help bolster the offering, which is expected to raise US$5 billion to US$7 billion.

site_title: Alibaba stock slides after ex-CEO abruptly quits cloud unit ahead of IPO
summary: Alibaba's share price has fallen 4.4% to HK$86.85, its lowest since August 23, after ex-group CEO Daniel Zhang abruptly quit two months before the planned spin-off of its cloud computing unit. Zhang's departure raises concerns over the unit's IPO plan and potential discord at the top. New CEO Eddie Wu will take over and act as chairman of the cloud unit, which is expected to go public next year. Analysts have mixed thoughts on the news, citing concerns of disagreements among Alibaba's partners.

site_title: India’s G20 win shows US learning how to counter China rise
summary: India successfully negotiated a joint G20 communique during the summit in New Delhi, with the US and Europe supporting the agreement. The communique, which included consensus on Russia's war in Ukraine and climate change, was seen as a win for India and a setback for China, which stayed away from the summit. The US, under President Joe Biden, saw India as a key ally in countering China's growing influence and bolstering the US-led world order. The agreement also marked a shift in China's behavior, with Beijing appearing to take a more confrontational stance during the summit.

site_title: SK Hynix’s US$24 billion rally unravelling on US-China tech war
summary: SK Hynix's US$24 billion rally is unraveling due to an intensifying US-China tech war. The chipmaker reported dismal quarterly loss and operating losses for the third straight quarter. A recent discovery that its products were used in Huawei's Mate 60 Pro, prompting a suspension of business with the Chinese phone maker, has raised concerns about geopolitical risks. The stock slid 6% after the news, as traders reassess the risks facing Korean companies with significant business operations in China.

images.alt_text: It’s unclear how Huawei may have procured the memory chips from Hynix, which makes most of its semiconductors at plants in China.

site_title: Japanese government bond 10-year yield hits near-decade high, BOJ steps in
summary: The Japanese government bond 10-year yield reached a near-decade high of 0.705% amid concerns about the Bank of Japan's (BOJ) potential end to negative interest rate policy. BOJ governor Kazuo Ueda's interview hinted at possible rate hikes by year-end, sparking market reaction. The BOJ responded by offering five-year loans against collateral to encourage investors to buy five-year bonds, but yields remained high. The BOJ's yield curve control policy has allowed the 10-year yield to move up to 1%, and the central bank is set to announce details of the loan terms later.

images.alt_text: At the centre of the picture is the BOJ, which is starting to relent in its years-long campaign to suppress yields.

site_title: More Chinese seek bargains at Beijing market as confidence in economy wanes
summary: Chinese consumers are increasingly seeking bargains at wholesale markets like Daliushu Guanxin in Beijing amid economic uncertainty, with many middle-class shoppers opting for cheaper goods due to low household demand and job insecurity. Consumer prices rose just 0.1% year-on-year in August, contrasting with surging inflation in other major economies. The shift in spending habits poses a challenge for luxury brands and retailers, who have long targeted the Chinese middle class. Experts say the issue is a confidence problem, with no clear solution to restore household confidence and spending power.

images.alt_text: The consumer price index remains well below the government’s official target of around 3 per cent for the year.
China’s youth are seen as key to growth in the country’s huge consumer market.

site_title: India central bank, banks plan new features to boost digital currency transactions: sources
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) is working with banks to introduce new features to boost digital currency transactions, specifically for its central bank digital currency (CBDC), the e-rupee. Despite averaging around 18,000 transactions daily, the RBI's goal of reaching 1 million daily transactions by 2023 is not met. New features will include allowing digital rupee transactions when offline and linking the e-rupee to the popular Unified Payments Interface (UPI). This aims to increase adoption and popularity of the digital currency.

images.alt_text: Fellow G20 nations hailed India’s success in reaching agreement on a joint communique that remained in doubt just days before world leaders gathered in New Delhi for their most significant annual diplomatic event.

site_title: HSBC to raise Hong Kong mortgage rates in added pressure on economy
summary: HSBC Holdings is raising mortgage rates in Hong Kong by 0.5 percentage points, effective September 18, to 4.125% for new loans. This move adds pressure to the city's struggling property market, where homebuyers are deterred by rising rates. The decision follows a 25 basis point increase in 2022 and reflects Hong Kong's monetary policy being tied to the US, weighing on the economy. The city's property market has seen its lowest sales since 2019, with developers reporting the fewest sales of new residential units in six months of 2023.

images.alt_text: HSBC is stepping up in the market when venture capital activity has slowed due to global market uncertainty in the wake of the Federal Reserve-led monetary tightening and stress in the banking sector.

site_title: The mighty American consumer is about to hit a wall, investors say
summary: US consumer spending, a key driver of economic growth, is forecast to decline in early 2024, according to a Bloomberg survey of 526 investors. Over half predicted a quarterly decline, with 21% expecting a reversal by the end of this year. This could lead to a recession and downside for stocks, which have already slipped from July highs. Analysts say the decline is unsustainable, driven by one-off factors, and that the economy's fate hinges on US consumer behavior.

summary: Ten individuals, including wives and relatives, have been arrested in a money laundering probe. The suspects, linked to the probe, are being investigated for suspicious transactions and assets. The Ministry of Law has been monitoring their activities, and a notice was sent to dealers of precious metals and stones on August 27. The investigation is ongoing, with authorities examining the individuals' assets and businesses.

site_title: StanChart appoints new global head of wealth planning and family advisory
summary: Standard Chartered appoints Mike Tan as its new global head of wealth planning and family advisory, effective September 25. Tan, a former JPMorgan executive, brings 20 years of experience in wealth advisory roles to the bank. In this role, he will lead a team offering competitive and integrated wealth planning, family office, and family governance advice to ultra-high-net-worth individuals and families. The appointment reflects Standard Chartered's commitment to delivering a holistic wealth advisory experience, solidifying its position as a leading international wealth manager.

site_title: Thai premier pitches 560 billion baht cash handout to revive economy
summary: Thailand's new Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin has proposed a 560 billion baht (S$21.5 billion) cash handout to boost the economy, targeting 55 million adults. The program, set to be rolled out within the first quarter, will provide 10,000 baht to each recipient, aiming to stimulate domestic demand and investment. The government also plans to cut energy prices, offer debt moratoriums, and implement other measures to revive the economy, with potential growth of up to 5% next year.

site_title: Gold edges higher on dollar dip; investors eye US inflation data
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $1,919.52 per ounce, supported by a decline in the US dollar and anticipation of US inflation data this week, which may influence the Federal Reserve's interest rate move. The US dollar and 10-year bond yields dropped 0.2%, making non-yielding bullion more attractive for overseas buyers. Spot silver rose 0.2% and platinum 0.1% as investors awaited inflation data, while China's consumer prices returned to positive territory in August.

images.alt_text: US gold futures rose 0.2 per cent to US$1,946.90.

site_title: Djokovic wins US Open for record equalling 24th Grand Slam
summary: Novak Djokovic won the US Open men's title, equaling Margaret Court's record of 24 Grand Slams, defeating Daniil Medvedev 6-3, 7-6(5), 6-3. The 36-year-old Serb becomes the oldest US Open men's winner in the Open Era and the first to win three Grand Slam events in a season for the fourth time. Djokovic's victory caps a remarkable Grand Slam campaign, with wins at the Australian, French, and US Opens.

images.alt_text: The 36-year-old Novak Djokovic is attempting to become the oldest men’s champion in New York in the Open era.

site_title: US judge says 2008 bank fraudsters got off easy
summary: A US judge, Jed Rakoff, criticized the $36 billion in fines imposed on banks following the 2008 financial crisis, calling it an "easy cop-out" that fails to achieve justice or deter future wrongdoing. Rakoff believes the fines have little deterrent effect, as senior bankers are not being criminally prosecuted. This stance contrasts with the government's response to the crisis, which has been praised for its enforcement record. Rakoff's comments highlight ongoing concerns about accountability and justice in the financial sector.

site_title: Singapore’s stocks open higher on Monday; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore's stocks rose 0.2% at Monday's open, with the Straits Times Index (STI) increasing 4.7 points to 3,212.45. Gainers outnumbered losers 52 to 34, driven by gains in Seatrium and DBS. The market followed global gains, with Wall Street stocks finishing modestly higher last Friday.

site_title: UK rents to rise 25% by 2026 as landlords pass on mortgage costs
summary: UK rents are projected to rise 25% by 2026 due to landlords passing on increased mortgage costs and stricter regulation. This increase is attributed to the Bank of England's efforts to combat inflation, which have disproportionately affected the rental sector. House prices are expected to decline 5% over the same period, adjusted for inflation. Experts believe these pressures will continue, leading to sustained rent growth over the next few years.
