site_title: Malaysian MP retracts support for Anwar over graft case handling
summary: Malaysian MP Syed Saddiq Syed Abdul Rahman, a junior partner in the ruling alliance, has exited the government after a court discharged Deputy Prime Minister Ahmad Zahid Hamidi from graft charges. Syed Saddiq cited the move as a sign of "normalising corruption." Despite this, Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim's majority in parliament remains intact, and his Cabinet remains unchanged. The move highlights Anwar's dilemma in balancing his decision to welcome Zahid as an ally while maintaining the support of other key parties.

summary: Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau was forced to extend his stay in New Delhi after his aircraft broke down, delaying his return home. Trudeau was due to return on Sunday after laying a wreath at a memorial to Indian independence leader Mahatma Gandhi, but a mechanical fault kept him in India overnight. The Canadian delegation will stay in India until alternative arrangements are made, according to Trudeau's office.

site_title: Meta is developing a new, more powerful AI system: WSJ
summary: Meta is developing a new, more powerful AI system, aiming for a 2024 launch, reportedly several times more powerful than its commercial version Llama 2. The system, intended to be as powerful as OpenAI's ChatGPT, will help other companies build services producing sophisticated text and analysis. Meta expects to start training the new AI system in early 2024.

site_title: Country Garden’s plan to extend 10.8 billion yuan of bonds faces vote
summary: Country Garden Holdings, a Chinese developer, is seeking to extend a group of local bonds worth 10.8 billion yuan (S$2 billion) by three years, with voting ending on Monday. The company must secure approval to avoid a potential repayment demand as early as Thursday. Country Garden has dodged a default on dollar securities and has recently navigated other deadlines, but still faces nearly $2 billion of bond payments due this year. The outcome of the vote could impact China's housing market, which has been affected by the company's tumble into crisis.

site_title: Waitrose cuts more prices as Britain’s food inflation picture improves
summary: Waitrose, a UK supermarket, has cut prices on 250 products by an average of 10% as Britain's food inflation slows to 14.9% in July, down from 19% in March. This is the third price reduction this year, with the company aiming to improve its market share. Despite this, UK food price inflation is still expected to be around 9% in December, with potential supply chain challenges adding to input costs. Waitrose's market share remains low, at 4.4%, behind rivals such as Tesco and Sainsbury's.

site_title: Three Chinese cities lift house-buying curbs
summary: China's debt-ridden property sector, accounting for one-quarter of the state's economic activity, is gradually being revived as three major cities lift house-buying curbs. Dalian, Shenyang, and Nanjing have removed restrictions on home buying, offering subsidies and tax relief to stimulate the economy. This move follows a nationwide crackdown on the property sector, which aims to address China's economic woes and stabilize the industry.

site_title: China’s abrupt trading tax cut forces Hong Kong into hard choice
summary: Hong Kong is under pressure to cut its stock trading tax following China's surprise move to slash its trading tax. The city's finance chief, Paul Chan, has accelerated plans to revive trading and initial public offerings (IPOs), with a task force led by a former regulator and executives from top banks. The move aims to enhance the stock market's competitiveness and comes amid concerns over market sentiment and liquidity. The potential cut in stamp duty could cost the government HK$12.3 billion to HK$53.1 billion, but is seen as necessary to stimulate long-term trading.

images.alt_text: The economy is also facing challenges from China’s slowing momentum, soft global demand and the potential for local spending habits to taper off.

site_title: Global Stocktake’s ‘shift the trillions’ call turns climate spotlight on private sector
summary: The Global Stocktake report emphasizes the private sector's crucial role in achieving the Paris Agreement's climate goals. The report highlights the need for consistent financial flows towards low greenhouse-gas emissions and climate-resilient development, requiring increased private sector engagement. Developing countries need at least $5.8 trillion to achieve their climate commitments, with $502 billion requiring international finance and $112 billion domestic finance. The report calls for policymakers to support the phase-out of coal-fired power plants, grid infrastructure, and renewable energy investments to scale up climate action.

site_title: Alibaba’s outgoing CEO Daniel Zhang quits cloud business in surprise move
summary: Alibaba Group announced that outgoing CEO Daniel Zhang is quitting the cloud business, a major part of the company's restructuring plan announced in March. Zhang, who was set to hand over the group CEO role to Eddie Wu, will instead leave the cloud unit, which is China's largest cloud provider, effective immediately. The company will continue to execute the spinoff plan under a separate management team, with Zhang to establish a $1 billion technology fund and contribute to Alibaba in a different capacity.

site_title: Yellen ‘feeling very good’ about soft landing for US economy
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen expressed confidence that the US economy will avoid major damage from inflation, citing a steady slowdown in inflation and a fresh influx of job seekers. Yellen said she's "feeling very good" about the prospects for a soft landing, similar to her previous hopes that the US would avoid a recession while reining in consumer-price gains.

site_title: Hong Kong’s economic growth forecast at risk: survey
summary: Hong Kong's economic growth forecast has been downgraded, with economists predicting a 4% expansion in 2023, lower than the previous median estimate of 4.6%. The city's economy is facing challenges from China's slowing momentum, soft global demand, and tapering local spending habits. The government's growth goal for the year may be at risk, with 10 economists expecting GDP to expand less than 4%. This downward revision reflects the post-pandemic recovery running out of steam, with high global interest rates expected to hinder growth in 2024.

summary: Four people were killed and three others injured in Spain when a commuter train hit a group of seven people attempting to cross the railway line in Montmelo, near Barcelona, in an unauthorized area. This incident is the latest in a series of such incidents blamed on central government underfunding by regional officials in Catalonia.

summary: Mak Swee Wah, a former Singapore Airlines COO, has joined the board of directors at Sats as an independent, non-executive director and member of the audit committee. summary: Vietnam's VinFast, an electric vehicle maker, has seen its share price soar after its Nasdaq listing, valuing the company at over $200 billion, making it the third most valuable automaker globally. Despite a net loss in 2022 and an EV business yet to turn a profit, investors are optimistic about VinFast's long-term prospects, citing Vietnam's strategic position, low-cost workforce, and government incentives. With 80% of HR leaders in Singapore believing that improving employee experience management will significantly improve business results, CHROs are taking center stage in leadership teams. site_title: China’s Gen Z is trying to leisure-shop way out of jobless blues
summary: China's Gen Z is bucking the trend of economic woes by increasing spending on leisure activities such as movie tickets, beauty services, and sporting events. According to a Mintel Group survey, 40% of respondents spent more on leisure in August than in the previous month, with experience-led spending becoming the mainstream way for Gen Z to resume their lives post-Covid. This shift is seen as a key factor in China's huge consumer market, where youth are expected to drive growth.

images.alt_text: Beijing has taken a number of steps in recent weeks to restore investor confidence, from lowering transaction costs to restricting some top shareholders from selling stakes.

The US and China also agreed to convene subject matter experts from both sides for technical discussions “regarding strengthening the protection of trade secrets and confidential business information”, Raimondo says.

site_title: Money laundering probe sparked by suspicious transaction reports, not external pressure: Shanmugam
summary: Singapore's money laundering probe, which led to the arrest of 10 foreigners, was triggered by suspicious transaction reports filed by financial institutions, not external pressure, said Home Affairs and Law Minister K Shanmugam. The probe had been ongoing for months and was based on intelligence and other pieces of information. The 10 suspects are believed to be involved in organised crime overseas and are suspected of trying to launder the proceeds of those crimes in Singapore. The government will seize assets, and courts will decide how they are dealt with. Shanmugam emphasized that Singapore is a reputable financial centre that will act against money laundering.

images.alt_text: The recent money laundering probe has thrown the purchase of uncompleted residential units at Canninghill Piers into a limbo.

site_title: Utility companies a key source of transition alpha
summary: Utilities are poised to become a key source of "transition alpha" as they transition to cleaner energy sources, reducing transition risks and potentially outperforming peers. Companies like those in Europe and the US are ramping up investments in renewables and reducing emissions, benefiting both the environment and their bottom lines. As their business becomes "cleaner," utilities can profit from higher growth and reduce transition risks, making them an attractive investment opportunity for investors.

images.alt_text: Nature is itself a carbon sink, absorbing carbon dioxide from the atmosphere. It is beginning to emerge as an asset class in the form of natural climate solutions.
The Apac region has more than 680 companies that draw more than half their revenue from clean energy.
The Manah Solar II Independent Power Project is backed by a 20-year power purchase agreement, and awarded by the Oman Power and Water Procurement Company.

site_title: Directors building stakes in XMH, Huationg, Green Build Tech, Union Steel
summary: Singaporean directors have increased their stakes in various companies, including XMH Holdings, Green Build Technology, Union Steel Holdings, and Huationg Global. Net institutional buyers accumulated S$6.3 million in Singapore stocks, while 26 primary-listed companies conducted share buybacks totaling S$37.8 million. Notable acquisitions include XMH Holdings chairman Tan Tin Yeow's 49.56% stake, Green Build Technology executive director Chan Mang Ghoon's 10.52% stake, and Union Steel Holdings executive director Ang Yew Chye's 10.92% stake.

images.alt_text: Singapore Exchange Centre at 2 Shenton Way, taken on 15 Feb 2019.

site_title: Rice prices surge, but restaurant operators see limited impact for now
summary: Rice prices have surged to nearly 15-year highs due to factors such as Thailand's drought and India's export ban. However, restaurant operators in Singapore report limited impact on their supply costs, with most using short-grain or other sources of rice. Analysts warn that rising rice prices could have a wider impact on food costs, particularly in Southeast Asia, where El Nino weather conditions are expected to worsen crop yields.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah
The Philippines is one of the world’s biggest importers of the grain.
Bank Indonesia’s inflation target range for 2023 is 2 per cent to 4 per cent.
Workers unload sacks of rice imported from Thailand from a cargo ship at Malahayati Port in Krueng Raya, Indonesia's Aceh province, on June 22, 2023. (Photo by CHAIDEER MAHYUDDIN / AFP)

site_title: Asia’s aviation recovery lags rest of world, but return to pre-Covid levels expected by 2024
summary: Asia's aviation recovery is expected to return to pre-Covid levels by 2024, driven by China and India's growth. The region's RPK rose 125.6% in the first half of 2023, but still lags the global average due to delayed border reopenings. Supply chain disruptions and labour shortages have exacerbated the delay. China's domestic aviation has recovered, while India's international air traffic is at 8% above 2019 levels. Industry observers predict Asia's recovery will gain momentum, with China and India expected to eclipse pre-Covid levels by 2024, driven by increased demand.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong
Delvag is Lufthansa’s in-house insurer and offers, for instance, coverage for air cargo, sea freight and transport.
A Greater Bay Airlines Co. aircraft at Hong Kong International Airport in Hong Kong, China, on Friday, Feb. 17, 2023.
The national carrier will restore certain flight frequencies to pre-pandemic levels or exceed them, it said in a press statement on Monday (Aug 7).
Singapore Airlines carried 2.8 million passengers in May, hitting 88 per cent of its pre-Covid capacity and advancing towards the 3.4 million high set in January 2020.

site_title: US dollar flat, but on track for eight straight weeks of gains; yuan sinks
summary: The US dollar remained stable on Friday, despite better-than-expected economic data, and is on track for its eighth straight week of gains. The euro fell 0.7% on the week, while the yuan reached its weakest level since 2007 due to capital outflow pressures and a widening yield gap with major economies. The Canadian dollar firmed against the greenback after a job report showing a gain of 39,900 jobs, while the yen declined 0.3% due to rapid currency moves deemed undesirable by Japanese authorities.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index is last 0.05 per cent lower at 105 but remains not far from the previous session’s six-month high of 105.15.

site_title: US, Vietnam upgrade ties as Biden visits in hedge against China
summary: US President Joe Biden secured deals with Vietnam on semiconductors and minerals during his visit, elevating the strategic South-east Asian nation to the US's highest diplomatic status alongside China and Russia. The upgraded ties come as Vietnam navigates frosty relations between Washington and Beijing, and amid a long-simmering territorial dispute in the South China Sea. The agreements are expected to include support for Vietnam's growing tech sector and diversifying its military supplies, with the US offering help to reduce reliance on Russia.

images.alt_text: During his state visit to Vietnam on Sunday (Sep 10), US President Joe Biden is expected to oversee the signing of a “comprehensive strategic partnership” with Hanoi, a symbolic but significant status long coveted by the US.

site_title: US10Y treasury yield’s bullish outlook remains strong
summary: The US10Y Treasury yield remains strong, poised to continue its ascent towards a retest of the 4.3% level. Following Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's comments at the Jackson Hole Symposium, markets anticipate a "higher for longer" scenario, driven by resilient economic data and the Fed's reluctance to cut rates. The yield has broken out of a downtrend channel and traded above the 4% level, supported by a golden cross and upward sloping dynamic moving averages, indicating a strong uptrend. A retest of the 4.3% level is expected.

site_title: Instacart seeks US$10 billion valuation amid industry woes: WSJ
summary: Instacart, a US grocery delivery startup, is seeking a valuation of under $10 billion ahead of its upcoming IPO. The company, founded in 2012, is targeting a valuation of $8.6 billion to $9.2 billion, significantly lower than its 2021 valuation of $39 billion. The lower valuation reflects diminished investor enthusiasm for tech IPOs amid challenging economic conditions. Instacart's business has cooled since the pandemic, leading to a workforce cut and a shift towards grocery store pickup. The company's IPO is expected to debut on the Nasdaq next week.

images.alt_text: Instacart’s listing could further energise an IPO market that has been warming in fits and starts.
Instacart sees itself clearly as a grocery technology company and suggests there is plenty of room for growth.

site_title: Japan PM says he plans Cabinet reshuffle, 'drastic' economic measures
summary: Japan Prime Minister Fumio Kishida plans to reshuffle his Cabinet as early as Wednesday, amid a fragile economic recovery. He aims to implement "drastic" economic measures to protect people's lives from price hikes and reinforce wage increases and investment expansion, supported by a necessary budget. Kishida's approval ratings have plummeted due to government mishaps, including a policy to integrate people's tax and social security data. Japan's economy grew less than expected in the second quarter, and wages slumped in July, casting doubt over the country's recovery.

images.alt_text: Managing Director of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) Kristalina Georgieva says: “Countries also need to mobilise domestic resources to finance and manage the green transition through tax reforms, effective and efficient public spending, strong fiscal institutions, and deep local debt markets.”

site_title: IMF urges pact to boost its resource quota,  strengthen world economy
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is urging G20 nations to increase its quota resources by the end of the year to boost the world economy. Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva also emphasized the need for countries to mobilize domestic resources to finance the green transition through tax reforms, public spending, and strong fiscal institutions. Additionally, the IMF is pushing for G20 members to deliver on their promise of $100 billion in climate funds per year, with strengthened multilateral development banks.

images.alt_text: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi , US President Joe Biden, German Chancellor Olaf Scholz and Australia's Prime Minister Anthony Albanese along with world leaders paying respect at the Mahatma Gandhi memorial on the sidelines of the G20 summit on Sunday.

site_title: Wall Street fears a too-hot economy as recession bets plunge
summary: Wall Street is reassessing recession bets as the probability of a US recession over the next six to 12 months has fallen to 16% from over 50% in October, according to a JPMorgan trading model. The odds of a recession are now lower than since April 2022, making markets vulnerable to signs of a hot economy. Positive economic data, such as solid jobless claims and service-sector activity, is fueling rate hikes and inflation concerns, making it difficult for investors to predict a soft landing.

images.alt_text: VinFast, an unprofitable electric-vehicle maker that at the zenith of a four-week trading frenzy had a market value greater than McDonald’s and four times that of General Motors, has sunk roughly 80 per cent in the eight days since.

site_title: SGX, SP Group charity golf events raise more than S$900,000
summary: SGX's charity golf events, part of SGX Cares Bull Charge, raised over S$900,000 for charities, including non-profit organisations Awwa and Autism Association (Singapore) and seniors from lower-income backgrounds. The events, which included a 20th anniversary tournament, drew over 150 golfers and guests, surpassing previous totals. The funds support SGX's SP Heartware Fund, which has raised over S$20 million since its establishment in 2005.

images.alt_text: Vivien Ang
SingLand volunteers helping to clean a senior's home in Bendemeer. This year, the group clocked 64 per cent more volunteer hours than in 2022.

site_title: Vietnam and US forge deeper ties as worries rise about China
summary: US President Joe Biden is set to sign a "comprehensive strategic partnership" with Vietnam during his state visit, marking a significant milestone in the two countries' relationship. This move is seen as a response to China's growing ambitions, with Vietnam having previously reserved this status for only four countries: China, Russia, India, and South Korea. The partnership is expected to strengthen ties between the US and Vietnam, bringing the two historical foes closer together.

images.alt_text: epa10845089 US President Joe Biden speaks to leaders of the International Longshore and Warehouse Union (ILWU) and the Pacific Maritime Association (PMA) on finalizing a new labor contract covering West Coast ports in the State Dining Room at the White House in Washington, DC, USA, 06 September 2023.  EPA-EFE/BONNIE CASH / POOL

site_title: F1 weekend a bonanza for hospitality plays
summary: Hospitality trusts in Singapore are benefiting from the recovery in international travel, with some outperforming their peers. Frasers Hospitality Trust (FHT) and Far East Hospitality Trust (FEHT) reported strong revenue and net property income growth, driven by a 96.9% increase in RevPAR at FEHT's hotels. In contrast, CapitaLand Ascott Trust (Clas) delivered a weak total return of minus 5.2% due to a failed equity-raising exercise. CDL Hospitality Trusts (CDLHT) also reported a 20.9% rise in revenue, but its total return was minus 16% due to a sell-off. These trusts are expected to benefit from marquee events like the F1 Grand Prix and the recovery in international tourism.

images.alt_text: Ben Paul
The ongoing recovery in international travel has boosted CDLHT's financial performance for the first half ended Jun 30.
Keppel DC Reit says stable distributable income is mainly due to new acquisitions of data centres in Guangdong, renewals and income escalations as well as tax savings.

One of the three lodging assets is The Cavendish London in the UK.
FHT says that RevPar for its Singapore portfolio has risen to S$283, from S$225 in Q3 2022.
Singapore's 2022 Formula 1 Grand Prix is estimated to have produced 2,372 tCO2e.

site_title: CapitaLand Ascott Trust shoots for lower carbon footprint, higher portfolio yield
summary: CapitaLand Ascott Trust, Asia-Pacific's largest lodging trust, aims to lower its carbon footprint and increase its portfolio yield under its new sustainability strategy. CEO Serena Teo has implemented measures such as increasing renewable energy sources and installing sensors to reduce electricity consumption. The trust has also partnered with the International Finance Corporation to launch a sustainability-linked bond. As of June 30, Clas' portfolio comprises 107 properties across 15 countries, with a total asset value of S$8.1 billion. The trust expects to increase its distribution by S$13.5 million following the acquisition of three new assets, with a potential yield increase of 6.8%.

Serena Teo, chief executive officer of the managers of CapitaLand Ascott Trust
One of CLAS’ student accommodation properties in the US, Standard at Columbia, recently received its temporary certificate of occupancy on Jun 30.

site_title: Museum curators evaluate AI threat by giving it the reins
summary: Art museum curators at Duke University's Nasher Museum of Art tested AI's ability to organize an art exhibition by teaching ChatGPT how to curate the "Act as if You Are a Curator" show. The AI successfully identified themes and selected artworks, but produced a disjointed and eclectic show with errors, including mistitled objects and incorrect information. The experiment highlights the challenges and limitations of automating the curatorial process, but also suggests that AI can support human curators in rethinking their approaches. The exhibition, running through January, showcases the potential and pitfalls of AI-assisted curation.

images.alt_text: "Sermon on the Mount" by Frans Francken the Younger. Some experts believe this 17th-century work, now up for sale, was originally stolen by the Nazis, but no clues to its pre-war owner have turned up after years of searching.
“The museum has a mission that lasts across generations. We will learn, restore confidence and deserve to be admired once again.” says George Osborne, chair of British Museum's board of trustees.
Belgian Beer World will open on Saturday (Sep 9) in the neoclassical former Brussels Stock Exchange.

site_title: Straits Trading launches investment product offering fractionalised exposure to Chatsworth Park GCB
summary: Straits Trading has launched two new fractionalised property investment products under its FIR-ST programme, offering investors exposure to a freehold Good Class Bungalow and a 999-year leasehold condominium unit in Singapore. The minimum investment amounts are S$200,000 for the condominium and S$500,000 for the GCB. Preference shareholders may receive dividends and a special payout at the end of the five-year investment period, which are non-guaranteed and subject to performance. The products are available to Straits Trading Shareholders' Club registrants only.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Gains in Straits Trading's property revenue was offset by a decline in tin mining and smelting revenue.

site_title: Changi Airport reopens runway nearly 3 hours after Air China emergency landing
summary: Air China flight CA403 made an emergency landing at Changi Airport due to smoke in its forward cargo hold and lavatory on its way to Singapore. The flight landed at 4:15 pm and the runway was temporarily closed. The runway reopened nearly three hours later at 7:02 pm after checks were completed. One aircraft, Scoot flight TR635, was diverted to Batam, Indonesia, during the closure period. The incident was declared an emergency and the flight received priority.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Air China flight CA403 encountered smoke in its forward cargo hold and lavatory on its way to Changi Airport and had to make an emergency landing.

site_title: China eases rules for insurers buying stocks in support measure
summary: China has relaxed rules for insurance companies to invest in domestic stocks, aiming to boost market sentiment and support capital market development. The new rules lower risk weighting for investments in the CSI 300 Index and stocks listed on the Star market, reducing minimum capital requirements for insurers. This move is part of a series of measures to restore investor confidence, including lowering transaction costs and restricting top shareholders from selling stakes. Insurers may accelerate the flow of funds into the capital market, potentially stabilizing shares and boosting economic development.

images.alt_text: The producer price index has fallen 3.0 per cent from a year earlier – in line with expectations – after a drop of 4.4 per cent in July.

site_title: Vietnam Air, Boeing near US$7.5 billion deal for 50 737 max planes
summary: Vietnam Airlines is expected to sign an agreement to buy about 50 Boeing 737 Max jets in a deal valued at around $7.5 billion, following US President Joe Biden's visit to Hanoi. The deal comes as Vietnam's aviation market continues to grow, with the country predicted to serve 150 million air transport passengers by 2035. This is Boeing's second deal with Vietnam Airlines, following a separate agreement with rival VietJet for 200 737 Max planes. The 737 Max was grounded worldwide after fatal crashes in 2018 and 2019 but returned to service in 2020.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO-An aircraft of the national flag carrier Vietnam Airlines taxis at Noi Bai airport in Hanoi, Vietnam December 23, 2020. Picture taken December 23, 2020. REUTERS/Kham/File Photo

site_title: Europe: Shares end week lower due to rate hike worries
summary: European stocks ended the week lower due to concerns over inflation and interest rates, with investors worried about a potential rate hike by the European Central Bank next week. Despite a slight gain on Friday, the Stoxx 600 index declined 0.8% for the week, with luxury heavyweight LVMH and travel and leisure sectors showing gains. Traders have increased their bets on a rate hike, with a 40% chance of a 25 basis point hike, amid hawkish remarks from ECB policymakers.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 index eased 0.1 per cent on Thursday, down for the seventh straight day, its worst string of losses since February 2018.

site_title: Air China plane lands safely at Changi Airport after engine catches fire; one runway closed
summary: Air China flight CA403, en route from Chengdu to Changi Airport, made an emergency landing after its left engine caught fire. The plane encountered smoke in its forward cargo hold and lavatory, prompting an evacuation of all passengers and crew members. The aircraft landed safely at Changi's Runway 3 at 4:15 pm. One runway remains closed following the incident.

images.alt_text: The warplanes were scrambled at 12.40pm on Aug 9.

site_title: ‘Govts alone cannot do all this’: PM Lee at G20 summit calls for partners to fund climate efforts
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong called for global cooperation to combat climate change, stating that governments alone cannot fund efforts to achieve net-zero emissions by 2050. Lee emphasized the need for a blended finance platform combining public, private, and philanthropic funds to support green investments and high-carbon companies reducing emissions. The G20 summit's declaration on climate change, which includes a pledge to triple renewable energy sources by 2030, has increased the odds of agreeing a global goal at COP28 in December.

images.alt_text: PM Lee attending the wreath laying ceremony along with other G20 leaders at the Rajghat memorial complex in Delhi, India, on Sept 10.

site_title:
Retail and institutions net buy industrial
and retail S-Reits in August
summary: Retail investors net bought S-Reits in August, with $187 million in net fund flows, while institutions net sold $94 million. Top sectors by retail buyers were diversified Reits, hospitality Reits, and industrial Reits. Institutions only bought industrial Reits and retail Reits, with CapitaLand Ascendas Reit, E-Logos Reit, and Mapletree Logistics Trust seeing inflows from both retail and institutional investors.

images.alt_text: DC Reit has a portfolio of 11 data centres located in key metros in the US, Canada and Germany with an AUM of S$1.6 billion as at Jun 30, 2023.

site_title: VinFast’s 504% rally burns traders playing greater fool theory
summary: VinFast, a Vietnam-based electric-vehicle maker, experienced a 504% rally in August before plummeting 80% in the following eight days. The company's market value surpassed McDonald's and General Motors at its peak, and its chairman controls 99% of the stock. This phenomenon is linked to the "greater fool theory," where investors bid up obscure stocks in hopes of selling to others at an even higher price. Similar episodes have occurred in the US stock market, driven by social media and online communities.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Nasdaq logo is displayed at the Nasdaq Market site in Times Square in New York City, U.S., December 3, 2021. REUTERS/Jeenah Moon/File Photo

site_title: Hedge funds ditch bets on euro ahead of ECB decision
summary: Hedge funds are significantly reducing their bets on the euro, dumping nearly 90% of their net long euro positions in one month ahead of the European Central Bank's interest-rate decision. This follows growing speculation that policymakers will pause an aggressive hiking cycle due to deteriorating growth signs and sticky inflation above 2%. Economists and markets are split on the decision, with a 40% chance of one more quarter-point hike on Thursday. The euro has dropped nearly 5% since mid-July, its longest streak of weekly losses since 2014.

images.alt_text: A majority of economists, 39 of 69, in the Sept 5-7 poll predicted no change to the deposit rate on Thursday while 30 said the ECB’s Governing Council would hike it by a quarter-point to 4.00 per cent.

site_title: 'Historic' EU-Middle East-India trade plan launched
summary: A historic trade plan linking Europe, the Middle East, and India was unveiled by the US, Saudi Arabia, the European Union, and the UAE on the sidelines of the Group of 20 summit in New Delhi. The initiative aims to boost trade ties by connecting railways, ports, electricity, and data networks, as well as hydrogen pipelines. The plan, dubbed the "Spice Route," could have wide-ranging geopolitical implications, including developing contacts between long-time foes Israel and Saudi Arabia. The project is seen as a major development in global trade and commerce.

images.alt_text: Washington, Saudi Arabia, the European Union, the United Arab Emirates and others will sign an agreement on the sidelines of the G20 summit to explore a railway and port project to augment trade flows between Europe and India, say officials.

site_title: Munich motor show: movie-projecting cars and a bike wash
summary: The Munich auto fair IAA featured Chinese electric vehicle manufacturer BYD setting up a prominent stand opposite Volkswagen. The fair showcased innovative technologies, including movie-projecting cars and a bike wash. Key takeaways include the growing focus on electric vehicles and the push towards a zero-waste future. The event highlighted the rapid advancements in Chinese car technology and the industry's shift towards sustainability.

images.alt_text: China has granted just a handful – including to industry newcomer Hozon New Energy Automobile – since July 2017, when it tightened rules to contain overcapacity.

site_title: Reality is creeping in on Nasdaq’s year-long dream rally
summary: The Nasdaq, a year-long dream rally, has started to show signs of slowing down. The index slumped this week, with Apple and Nvidia experiencing their second-worst falls of the year. The rally's momentum has been fueled by optimistic views on artificial intelligence, but analysts warn that valuations are stretched and interest rates are due for a correction. The Nasdaq 100's valuation is 27 times annual earnings, significantly higher than the S&P 500. Regulators are also set to break up tech monopolies, adding to the bearish sentiment.

images.alt_text: If Beijing goes ahead, the unprecedented iPhone blockade might also affect several other US technology companies that rely on sales and production in China.

site_title: Football: Neymar beats Pele’s record to become Brazil’s all-time top scorer
summary: Neymar scored his 78th goal for Brazil, surpassing Pele's record as the country's all-time top scorer, in a 4-0 win over Bolivia on September 8. The 31-year-old forward, making his 125th appearance for Brazil, converted a loose ball into the net in the 61st minute. This milestone marks a significant achievement for Neymar, who recently moved to Saudi Arabian club Al Hilal from Paris Saint-Germain.

site_title: Over 5,000 new homes could rise from 3 new Tanjong Rhu plots on city fringe
summary: Three plots of land in Tanjong Rhu, Singapore, could support over 5,000 new homes, according to the Urban Redevelopment Authority's (URA) amended masterplan. The plots, which are near the Greater Southern Waterfront and MRT stations, have been re-parcelled and their plot ratios increased, allowing for high-density residential developments. Analysts estimate that the plots could yield 600-900 public housing units or 800-900 condominium units, with the possibility of private or public projects. The developments are expected to support housing demand and provide residents with access to amenities, despite being located on the city fringe.

site_title: Where in the world are people back in the office?
summary: Remote work levels vary globally, with countries in Europe and North America having higher levels than those in Asia. According to a study, workers in the US and UK spent 5-6 paid days a month working from home, while Germans worked 4 days a month. Housing density, Covid lockdowns, and cultural norms influence remote work patterns. Asian countries with densely populated cities and limited housing options tend to have lower remote work levels, while areas with longer lockdowns and more comfortable home setups have higher remote work adoption.

site_title:
Oil price resurgence has further 
to run after Saudis turn the screw
summary: Oil prices surge above $90 a barrel as Saudi Arabia and Russia agree to a combined output cut of 1 million barrels a day, effective until year-end. The reduction aims to balance supply and demand, resulting in a 2.7 million barrel-per-day deficit in the fourth quarter. This move is seen as a significant step in driving up prices, with the two major oil producers now working together to control supply. The price surge is expected to have a significant impact on consumers, who may be forced to reduce their inventories to meet demand.

images.alt_text: Interest rate hikes can slow economic growth and reduce oil demand.

site_title: Three Chinese cities lift house-buying curbs
summary: Three Chinese cities, Dalian, Shenyang, and Nanjing, have lifted house-buying curbs as part of a nationwide effort to revive the economy. The cities will no longer restrict property purchases in most areas, offering subsidies for buyers and tax relief for sellers. The move comes after a series of support measures for the property sector, including lower mortgage rates for first-time homebuyers. The property sector accounts for one-quarter of China's economic activity, which has been struggling since 2021 due to government restrictions.

site_title: China’s August consumer prices edge higher, factory prices fall
summary: China's consumer prices rose 0.1% in August, returning to positive territory, while factory-gate prices declined 3.0% from a year earlier, easing deflationary pressures. This follows a 0.3% year-on-year decline in July. The data suggests stabilization in the economy, but policymakers may face pressure as China's GDP growth is expected to slow.

images.alt_text: The heightened sensitivity surrounding the struggling property sector, in particular, makes households more cautious on spending, further diminishing a growth driver.

site_title: Google's former CEO is leveraging his US$27 billion fortune to shape AI policy
summary: Eric Schmidt, former Google CEO, is using his $27 billion fortune to shape AI policy in the US. He has built a powerful influence machine in Washington, leveraging his connections to tech executives and experts to inform public policy. Schmidt's initiatives, such as the Special Competitive Studies Project and Schmidt Futures, have been influential in shaping AI policy, and he has profited from his investments in AI startups and companies. Critics argue that Schmidt's influence is driven by his personal financial interests, and that his philanthropic efforts in China, where he has invested in state-owned enterprises, create conflicts of interest.

images.alt_text: The agency’s new funding is supposed to help the IRS raise more federal revenue by cracking down on tax cheats and others who use sophisticated accounting manoeuvres to avoid paying what they owe.

site_title: Everything Apple plans to show on Sep 12: iPhone 15, watches, AirPods
summary: Apple is set to unveil its iPhone 15, new smartwatches, and AirPods on September 12. The most significant new product will be the iPhone 15 Pro line, featuring a new titanium design, faster A17 chip, and improved camera capabilities. The iPhone 15 Pro Max will also have enhanced telephoto and ultrawide lenses. The Apple Watch Series 9 and second-generation Ultra will focus on performance, with new chips and sensor upgrades. The AirPods will switch to USB-C charging and gain new health features. The event aims to boost sales after a sales slump and amid challenges in China.

images.alt_text: Adding to the pressure on Apple, Huawei on Friday launched two new smartphones – foldable phone Mate X5 and Mate 60 Pro+ smartphone, a new addition to a series it unveiled last week.
If consumers in China are looking to dump Apple, the new Huawei phone could provide an alternative.
Apple issued new updates on its devices after investigating the flaws reported by Citizen Lab.

site_title: Of extraordinary attorneys and rain men
summary: Neurodiverse individuals, such as those with autism and ADHD, hold immense potential for businesses due to their unique skills and perspectives. Despite challenges, only about 20% of people with autism are employed, and many neurodivergent individuals are underrepresented in the workplace. To succeed, society must be mobilized for neurodiversity in the workplace, and businesses must adjust their recruitment and career management processes to support neurodivergent employees. This includes designing tasks and functions tailored to their strengths and providing non-interview assessments to identify their capabilities. By doing so, organizations can tap into the value of neurodiverse individuals and avoid the dangers of groupthink.

Workers and employers need to agree on the ground rules of the new workplace and foster a culture and environment that promotes employee retention and engagement, as well as organisational performance.
OpenAI CEO Sam Altman is the first recipient of Indonesia's golden visa, which has numerous perks such as priority security screening at airports and longer stay periods.

site_title: Bridging the Stem gender gap: Perspectives from a female Apac head economist
summary: A female economist in Singapore shares her experiences with gender bias in the male-dominated STEM field, citing low representation of women in leadership roles and biases in hiring and promotion processes. Despite efforts to address these issues, unconscious bias persists, limiting women's participation and empowerment. To bridge the gap, organizations must create equal opportunities for women to take on leadership roles, highlight and celebrate their achievements, and provide support and allyship. By addressing these challenges, women can overcome self-doubt and build confidence to step into leadership positions.

images.alt_text: A renewed focus on employee experience is becoming a new business priority.
Can fathers stop feeling emasculated or like they will be penalised at work for taking all of their paternity leave, or for wanting to be present in the home?
A video thumbnail from Feon Ang's new video series called "At The Table", with its first episode featuring Georgette Tan, Roshni Cheung, and Minister for Communications and Information Josephine Teo.

Celia Chen, who at first misattributed symptoms in her late 40s with stress from her job as a startup marketing executive, at home in Venice, Calif. on Dec. 6, 2022. After switching to a new gynecologist, she learned that these changes were related to her transition to menopause, known as perimenopause.
Women need to constantly prove and reinvent themselves throughout their working lives.
If you're struggling to get your employees on board with transformation, you might need to relook at how you lead.
Time and again, predictions about ways in which the labour market had been permanently changed have proved temporary or even illusory.
Graduates attend a ceremony at Central China Normal University in Wuhan, Hubei province, China June 13, 2021.
Gender inequality begins at the internship stage, where more women than men seem to get unpaid stints. This begins years ahead of the so-called “motherhood penalty”.
One potential explanation for the gender disparity: Women continue to shoulder the burden of housework and childcare.

site_title: African Union formally joins G20 at Delhi summit
summary: The African Union formally joined the G20 at the Delhi summit, a diplomatic victory for Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi. The expansion was announced by Modi, who invited the African Union chair, Comoros President Azali Assoumani, to take a seat as a permanent member. The move comes amid a growing crisis of trust in the world, with deep divisions on the Ukraine war. The inclusion of the African Union is seen as a significant development, with Modi using hosting rights to burnish his image as an international statesman ahead of national elections next year.

images.alt_text: Washington, Saudi Arabia, the European Union, the United Arab Emirates and others will sign an agreement on the sidelines of the G20 summit to explore a railway and port project to augment trade flows between Europe and India, say officials.

site_title: Japan’s resurgent real estate market: A haven for Singapore investors
summary: Japan's commercial real estate (CRE) market has seen a surge in investment from Singapore investors, with an estimated $16.2 billion poured into the sector between 2013 and 2023. The Japanese government's monetary policies have contributed to the growth, with the yen hitting multi-year lows against major currencies. The market is shifting towards growth-oriented asset classes like logistics and hospitality, driven by e-commerce and tourism demand. Singapore-based investors, including GIC, have invested heavily in these sectors, with $1.68 billion invested in logistics assets in the first half of 2023.

images.alt_text: Spending on hotels by overseas investors recorded its fastest pace in nearly a decade, making up the largest proportion of hotel deals in Japan since 2014.
Globally, investors are also shying away from offices due to historically high vacancy rates in major cities.
Blackstone has used that interest to turn over many of its assets – Japan has been one of its most active markets in Asia-Pacific in terms of buying and selling.

site_title: China’s Didi Q2 revenue grows as regulatory curbs ease
summary: China's Didi Chuxing reported a 52.6% increase in Q2 revenue to 48.8 billion yuan, driven by a rebound in demand after the end of strict Covid-19 restrictions. The company, which faced regulatory curbs and a delisting from the New York Stock Exchange, emerged from its troubles earlier this year. Despite a net loss of 300 million yuan, Didi plans to engage with consumers and drivers more actively through promotions and diversified product offerings for the rest of 2023.

site_title: India hands over G20 presidency to Brazil
summary: India handed over the G20 presidency to Brazil at the end of the G20 summit in New Delhi, marking a consensus on a Leaders' Declaration that avoided condemning Russia for the war in Ukraine but called for peaceful resolution. The declaration also acknowledged human suffering caused by the conflict. Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi praised the consensus, while Brazilian President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva emphasized the need for cooperation and peace. The summit also admitted the African Union as a permanent member, and leaders paid respects to Mahatma Gandhi at a memorial site.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi (R), US President Joe Biden (C), German Chancellor Olaf Scholz (3R) and Australia's Prime Minister Anthony Albanese (3L) along with world leaders arrive to pay respect at the Mahatma Gandhi memorial at Raj Ghat on the sidelines of the G20 summit in New Delhi on September 10, 2023. (Photo by Ludovic MARIN / POOL / AFP)

site_title: Helmut Lang and Ralph Lauren kick off New York Fashion Week
summary: New York Fashion Week kicked off with Helmut Lang and Ralph Lauren showcasing diverse collections. Helmut Lang's designs, led by 32-year-old Vietnamese-born Peter Do, featured black jacket-trouser ensembles with neon stripes, while Ralph Lauren's show featured rustic, preppy attire with denim, beads, and embroidered feathers. The event marked a return to the calendar for Helmut Lang, which was once a staple of 90s and 2000s fashion. With a dozen shows per day until September 13, the event aims to remain a cornerstone of fashion, despite the impact of the Hollywood writers' strike on red-carpet appearances.

images.alt_text: French designer for Christian Dior Marc Bohan was a master of the trade who managed to keep the spirit of the label alive after its mid-twentieth century heyday.

site_title: Rice crisis in the Philippines sounds global inflation alarm
summary: The Philippines is experiencing the fastest rate of rice inflation in almost five years, prompting global concerns about the impact on other major rice importers. India's export restrictions have driven up prices, prompting nations to secure supplies and implement price controls. The Philippines has capped retail prices, and other countries, including Vietnam and Senegal, are negotiating deals to ensure supply. The crisis has also led to the resignation of a finance official and has raised concerns about the global food market.

images.alt_text: Rice export restrictions by India have sent shock-waves across Asia, prompting worried consumers to implement measures to secure supply and contain rising food costs.
The Philippines will be the hardest hit by the recent rise in rice prices, according to a research note by OCBC Bank.

site_title: US deploys artificial intelligence to catch tax evasion
summary: The US Internal Revenue Service (IRS) has started using artificial intelligence to investigate tax evasion at multibillion-dollar partnerships, targeting wealthy individuals and large corporations that use sophisticated accounting manoeuvres to avoid paying taxes. The new funding, part of the US$80 billion allocated through the Inflation Reduction Act, aims to raise federal revenue and crack down on tax cheats. However, the allocation has been contentious, with Republicans claiming it will target small businesses and middle-class taxpayers. The IRS will use AI to analyze complex tax cases and identify tax evasion.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A street sign stands near the Morgan Stanley worldwide headquarters building in New York May 8, 2009. REUTERS/Lucas Jackson/File Photo

site_title: PM Lee urges G20 nations to reform WTO, development banks
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong urged G20 nations to reform the World Trade Organisation (WTO) and development banks to address global development challenges. He emphasized the need for WTO reforms to keep pace with digital transformation and restore a functioning dispute settlement system. Lee also called for a strong G20 push to advance WTO reform negotiations. The call comes as the G20 summit concluded in New Delhi, India, with the theme "One Future."

images.alt_text: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi , US President Joe Biden, German Chancellor Olaf Scholz and Australia's Prime Minister Anthony Albanese along with world leaders paying respect at the Mahatma Gandhi memorial on the sidelines of the G20 summit on Sunday.

site_title: Supporting people with dementia
summary: The number of people with dementia in Singapore is projected to reach 152,000 by 2030, highlighting the need for continued support for those affected and their caregivers. Personal experiences of caring for a loved one with dementia emphasize the importance of early intervention, social interaction, and a supportive environment. Despite a lack of stigma felt by the writer, a recent survey found that 60% of people with dementia feel treated as being less able, underscoring the need for education and inclusivity. A dementia-inclusive society requires acceptance, support, and infrastructure to ensure those with dementia can live as normal a life as possible.

images.alt_text: Lilly’s drug, donanemab, like Eisai and Biogen’s recently approved Leqembi, is an intravenous antibody designed to remove deposits of a protein called beta amyloid from the brains of Alzheimer’s patients.
The drug lecanemab, developed by Biogen and Eisai, slowed cognitive decline by 27 per cent across an 18-month period.
Shedding new light on dementia
Preventing memory loss

site_title: US dollar set for longest weekly winning streak since 2014, yuan plumbs 2007 low
summary: The US dollar is poised for its longest weekly winning streak since 2014, driven by robust US economic data, including a strong services sector and low jobless claims. The US dollar index is near a six-month high, while the euro faces its eighth consecutive week of losses. Meanwhile, China's onshore yuan has plummeted to its lowest level since 2007, struggling with capital outflow pressures and a widening yield gap with major economies.

images.alt_text: The offshore yuan follows the weakening trend despite state banks’ recent actions to tighten offshore yuan liquidity to raise the cost of shorting the Chinese currency.
The yuan, one of the region’s worst performing currencies, is on track to log its biggest weekly loss since February and has shed roughly 6.1 per cent against the dollar so far this year.
Against a basket of currencies including the euro and sterling, the US dollar rises 0.1 per cent to 104.98.
Backed by a strong economy and rising US Treasury yields, the US dollar, despite bouts of weakness, has stayed resilient against most major currencies.

site_title: G20 members to back EU, Mid-East and India trade plan
summary: G20 members, including the European Union, Saudi Arabia, and the United Arab Emirates, will sign an agreement to explore a railway and port project to boost trade between Europe, India, and the Middle East. The project aims to create a modern-day Spice Route, which could significantly impact the global economy. The deal comes as the US engages with Saudi Arabia to normalize ties with Israel. The project's details and timeline have not been disclosed, but it is expected to have a significant impact on trade flows between the three regions.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden will also travel to Vietnam on Sunday where he is expected to upgrade relations with the former foe, in a further bid to push back an increasingly assertive China.
Police barricades outside the Red Fort, ahead of the G20 Summit in New Delhi, on Thursday (Sep 7).
Two leaders – China's Xi Jinping and Russia's Vladimir Putin – will not be in attendance when the G20 summit convenes this weekend in New Delhi.

site_title: US: Wall St opens subdued in cautious trading ahead of inflation data
summary: US stocks opened subdued on Friday, September 8, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 13.32 points, or 0.04%, to 34,487.41. Investors await upcoming inflation data, which may indicate interest rates will remain higher for longer. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite opened higher, with gains of 0.16% and 0.04%, respectively. The cautious trading is attributed to concerns about the economy and interest rates.

site_title: Oil prices rise to 9-month high on worries about tight supply
summary: Oil prices rose to a nine-month high, reaching $90.65 a barrel for Brent and $87.51 a barrel for US West Texas Intermediate, due to concerns over tight oil supplies after Saudi Arabia and Russia extended supply cuts. The price increase, driven by rising US diesel futures, is attributed to supply-side drivers, with analysts predicting that Opec+ will maintain a tight market going into the winter. Energy companies also added one oil rig, the first weekly increase since June, according to energy services firm Baker Hughes.

images.alt_text: A nozzle is replaced on a fuel dispenser at a gas station in La Puente, California, on September 7, 2023. US gas prices this week hit the highest levels in a decade as the summer holiday season winds down, with rising crude-oil prices a likely contributing factor to higher gas prices. (Photo by Frederic J. BROWN / AFP)

site_title: Million-dollar HDB flat sales in 2023
summary: In 2023, a record 301 million-dollar HDB flats were sold as of September 6, surpassing previous years. August saw an all-time record of million-dollar flat sales. Many of these sales occurred at the Pinnacle @ Duxton, with a significant number not being on high floors. The trend highlights the growing demand for luxury HDB flats, with various regions across Singapore experiencing million-dollar sales.

images.alt_text: Jeanette Tan

site_title: Pinault’s Hollywood deal caps buying spree worth billions
summary: Francois-Henri Pinault, CEO of Kering, has agreed to buy a majority stake in talent-management giant Creative Artists Agency (CAA) for US$7 billion. This deal marks the third multibillion-dollar acquisition in as many months for Pinault, who is also the husband of actress Salma Hayek. The purchase comes as Gucci, a key contributor to Pinault's family fortune, struggles with management and design issues. The acquisition caps Pinault's buying spree, which has been worth billions.

images.alt_text: Francois-Henry Bennahmias plans to step down at the end of this year, to be replaced by former Procter & Gamble executive Ilaria Resta.

site_title: Los Angeles City Council acts to spare Marilyn Monroe house from demolition
summary: The Los Angeles City Council has unanimously voted to launch a process to designate Marilyn Monroe's former home, where she died in 1962, as a historic and cultural monument, blocking plans to demolish the property. The Spanish Colonial-style house, where Monroe purchased the home in the early 1960s, will undergo review to determine its potential status as a landmark, with a demolition permit revoked and major alterations barred. The home, currently owned by a little-known entity, had been slated for demolition but sparked outrage on social media, prompting Councilwoman Traci Park to take action.

images.alt_text: Cuban-born Spanish actress Ana de Armas at the 79th annual Venice International Film Festival on Sep 8 2022. “I truly believe that she was very close to us. She was with us,” she said referring to her role as Marilyn Monroe.
Christie's to auction Warhol portrait of Marilyn Monroe estimated at US$200m

site_title: Rich Norwegians flee fjords for Swiss exile in rage about taxes
summary: Norway's richest citizens are fleeing the country, with dozens moving to Switzerland, amid a tax regime that has driven them into exile. The tax-the-rich push by Prime Minister Jonas Gahr Store has pitted traditional Nordic concepts of equality and social justice against claims that it penalizes success and hurts the economy. The government's measures include stricter exit levies and plans to capture personal consumption through companies, sparking a backlash from the wealthy elite.

images.alt_text: This handout photograph taken and released by the Ukrainian Presidential Press Service on August 24, 2023, shows Norway's Prime Minister Jonas Gahr Store gesturing as he attends a meeting with Ukraine's President in Kyiv. site_title: US: Stocks post modest gains to conclude lacklustre week
summary: US stocks ended the week modestly higher, closing 0.1% higher on Friday. Despite a lacklustre week, investors held onto hopes that the Fed can navigate a soft landing, driving gains. The S&P 500 fell 1.3% for the week, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.2%. Individual companies saw mixed results, with Apple up 0.4% and Kroger gaining 3.1% on better-than-expected profits, while Restoration Hardware sank 15.6% after reporting a decline in quarterly profits.

images.alt_text: Apple fell 2.9 per cent on Thursday, its second straight decline, following reports that China has barred the use of iPhones in government offices.

site_title: Netflix finally finds a manga hit with One Piece
summary: Netflix's live-action adaptation of the popular manga series "One Piece" has been a success, with over 18 million viewers in its first four days. The show, based on the story of Monkey D Luffy's quest to become the king of all pirates, has received positive reviews, with critics praising its faithful adaptation of the comic's vision. The series' success marks a rare hit for Netflix, which has struggled with other Japanese manga and anime adaptations, including "Fullmetal Alchemist" and "Death Note". The show's author, Eiichiro Oda, was involved in the production and gave final approval, ensuring the material was adapted correctly.

images.alt_text: The eight-episode adventure series is a live-action retelling of one of Japan’s biggest manga comic-book franchises.

site_title: John Lennon’s missing Patek Philippe wristwatch found in Geneva
summary: A Patek Philippe 2499 perpetual calendar chronograph watch, given to John Lennon by his wife Yoko Ono before his 1980 assassination, has been found in Geneva after being missing for years. A Geneva court ruled that Ono is the rightful owner, and the collector is appealing. The watch, considered a holy grail for collectors, could be worth between $5 million and $10 million. The court's decision was made despite the collector's argument that Ono failed to report the watch stolen within three years of the theft.

images.alt_text: Swiss watch exports to Singapore suffer a 7.9 per cent drop compared to a strong rise a year ago.
Around 80,000 watches have been registered as stolen or missing with The Watch Register, a company that helps owners, auction houses and dealers identify stolen timepieces for a fee.
Omega has alleged former employees conspired with others to produce a so-called “Frankenstein” version of a vintage Speedmaster.

site_title: Lessons from F1 in information security
summary: The article draws parallels between Formula 1 (F1) and information security, highlighting the need for a balance between regulation and innovation. F1's governing body, the FIA, has introduced new regulations to mitigate safety and environmental concerns while fostering competition. Similarly, information security regulations aim to protect organizations and individuals, but may hinder innovation. However, the article concludes that regulations can be a blueprint for innovation, and success lies in striking a fine balance between the two. By adopting a proactive approach to regulations, organizations can ensure they remain competitive while maintaining societal values and consumer trust.

images.alt_text: Lewis Hamilton, Formula 1 racing's most successful driver, joined Mercedes from McLaren in 2013 and has taken six titles and 82 of his 103 career victories with the team.
The hot areas in AI use crypto technology to build decentralised controls. At the same time, many crypto projects are exploiting AI to build complex structures out of decentralised parts.
The challenges of good governance are no less acute in the digital age. There are very few tried and tested formulas of good digital governance; no ready playbooks to adapt.

site_title: Global sovereign debt roundtable to meet on local debt restructuring: sources
summary: Global creditors will discuss domestic debt inclusion in restructuring plans for countries in default at a September 15 technical meeting of the Global Sovereign Debt Roundtable. The meeting will cover risks of local debt restructuring and prepare for a high-level reunion during October's IMF-World Bank meetings in Morocco. Countries such as Sri Lanka and Ghana have included domestic debt in their restructurings, but no common template exists. The meeting aims to address concerns over burden sharing and stability in domestic financial sectors.

images.alt_text: The paper sets out timelines for members of the IMF and G20 to implement recent recommendations to regulate crypto from the Financial Stability Board and IOSCO.
FILE PHOTO: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) logo in Washington, United States, September 4, 2018. REUTERS/Yuri Gripas//File Photo

site_title: US housing affordability remains at a record low, NAR says
summary: US housing affordability remains at a record low, with the National Association of Realtors (NAR) housing affordability index unchanged at 87.8 in July, matching the lowest level since 1989. High mortgage rates and prices continue to keep home ownership out of reach for many Americans. The typical family spends 28.5% of their income on mortgage payments, and qualifying income for a mortgage is a record US$104,496. Experts warn that the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes are widening the social divide and preventing middle-income renters from ownership opportunities.

images.alt_text: High mortgage rates have pushed homeownership further out of reach for many Americans.
Houses in Meridian, Idaho. US house housing Photographer: Jeremy Erickson/Bloomberg
Public homebuilders on average have raised prices in about two-thirds of their communities, says analyst.
US Commerce Department says a surge in new home sales, rising by 4.4 per cent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 714,000 units in July.

site_title: Tennis: Djokovic schools Shelton to reach 10th US Open final
summary: Novak Djokovic advanced to his 10th US Open final with a straight-set win over unseeded American Ben Shelton, winning 6-3, 6-2, 7-6 (7/4). Djokovic, 36, will face either Carlos Alcaraz or Daniil Medvedev in the final, aiming to become the oldest men's champion in New York in the Open era and match Margaret Court's record for most major singles titles. Djokovic has now won 22 of his last 23 Grand Slam semi-finals and will return to world No 1 after the US Open.

images.alt_text: Sep 7, 2023; Flushing, NY, USA; Coco Gauff of the United States celebrates after her match against Karolina Muchova of Czech Republic (not pictured) in a women's singles semifinal on day eleven of the 2023 U.S. Open tennis tournament at USTA Billie Jean King National Tennis Center. Mandatory Credit: Geoff Burke-USA TODAY Sports

site_title: Who says I need to do more?
summary: A debate arose among staff members about who is the better employee: those who take on extra work outside their job scope or those who stick to their core duties. While some argue that the former is more desirable, others believe that the latter's reliability and dependability should not be overlooked. Experts suggest that managers should consider each employee's strengths and provide learning pathways to help them grow professionally, regardless of their willingness to take on extra work. A toxic culture should be avoided, and employees should be given flexibility to choose how they approach their work.

images.alt_text: Vivien Ang
A Bloomberg article last year stated that meetings “wasted” up to US$100 million for big companies.

site_title: Richard Hu, Singapore’s longest-serving finance minister, dies aged 96
summary: Singapore's longest-serving finance minister, Richard Hu Tsu Tau, died at 96. He served as finance minister from 1985 to 2001. A private funeral is scheduled for Sunday at the Mandai Crematorium. Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong announced his passing in a Facebook post, noting Dr Hu's significant contribution to Singapore's economic development.

site_title: FTX probing if millions in payments to Shaq, Naomi Osaka can be returned
summary: FTX Group advisers are scrutinizing whether they can recover millions of dollars paid to Shaquille O'Neal, Naomi Osaka, and other professional athletes and teams that promoted Sam Bankman-Fried's crypto platform before its collapse. The firm has disclosed payments of at least $12.2 million to Formula 1's Mercedes-AMG Petronas and $3.4 million to the NBA's Golden State Warriors. FTX's new management has also sued a venture capital firm that allegedly connected Bankman-Fried to NBA stars and other celebrities, amid allegations of wrongdoing by athletes and teams.

images.alt_text: Ryan Salame’s plea agreement did not include a promise to testify against Sam Bankman-Fried.

A courtroom sketch from Aug 23 showing FTX cryptocurrency exchange founder Sam Bankman-Fried in prison clothing, with his attorney Christian Everdell in a Manhattan federal court, where he pleaded not guilty to seven criminal charges.

site_title: UN says more needed ‘on all fronts’ to meet climate goals
summary: The UN's first comprehensive progress review of the 2015 Paris Agreement found that the world is not on track to curb global warming. The Global Stocktake report, released ahead of COP28 climate talks in Dubai, warns that more action is needed on all fronts to meet climate goals. The report, based on 2 years of submissions from experts, governments, and campaigners, highlights the need for increased efforts to address the growing climate crisis, which is characterized by terrifying wildfires and soaring temperatures.

images.alt_text: An aerial view shows a vehicle driving along a flooded street in New Port Richey, Florida, on August 30, 2023, after Hurricane Idalia made landfall.
The Investor Agenda says governments continue to see climate change as separate to, and less important than, other aspects of economic and fiscal policy.

Sultan al-Jaber, chief executive of the UAE's Abu Dhabi National Oil Company (ADNOC) and president of this year's COP28 climate gestures during the 7th Ministerial on Climate Action (MoCA) in Brussels on July 13, 2023. The Ministerial on Climate Action (MoCA) is an annual meeting attended by ministers and high-level representatives from over 30 countries, including ministers from the G20 and chairs of key party groupings in the UN climate negotiations. (Photo by François WALSCHAERTS / AFP)

site_title: China Evergrande delays decision on offshore debt restructuring to October
summary: China Evergrande Group has delayed its decision on offshore debt restructuring until October, giving Hong Kong CEG class holders more time to consider its fresh restructuring plan. The meetings for CEG class A and class C debt holders, initially scheduled for September 26, are now set for October 16 and 17. Evergrande needs approval from over 75% of debt class holders to approve the plan, which offers creditors options to swap debt for new bonds and equity-linked instruments. This decision is part of the company's efforts to address a crisis in China's property sector.

site_title: Japan PM Kishida set to reshuffle cabinet on Sep 13: NHK
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida plans to reshuffle his cabinet on September 13, amid plunging approval ratings and government mishaps. Kishida's approval ratings have dropped to 35% in a recent poll, with 50% opposing his leadership. The decision to reshuffle comes after a series of controversies, including the arrest of former Liberal Democratic Party member Masatoshi Akimoto on bribery charges. Kishida has vowed to focus on his job despite the setbacks, but a poll suggests that 56% of people think he should renew his cabinet and shake up the ruling party's senior executives.

site_title: US food firms go deal hunting as pandemic growth fades
summary: US food firms are making deals to revamp their brand portfolios as pandemic-era growth fades. Campbell Soup Co acquired Rao's sauce maker Sovos Brands for $2.7 billion, while Unilever bought premium frozen yogurt brand Yasso and Mars acquired healthy foods maker Kevin's Natural Foods. Despite higher borrowing costs, the US food and beverage industry saw a 17.5% increase in deal volumes to $10.39 billion this year, with large food companies seeking to add new concepts and items to their portfolios. Experts predict continued deal-making in the industry, citing the need for companies to stay relevant through strategic acquisitions.

images.alt_text: PepsiCo’s revenue rose 16 per cent in Russia and profits quadrupled, and the soda maker said operations in Russia accounted for 5 per cent of consolidated net revenue for 2022, up from 4 per cent a year earlier.
The British company has reported a 7.9 per cent rise in underlying second-quarter sales, beating analysts’ average forecast of 6.4 per cent.

site_title: China slows fertiliser exports, raising industry concerns in India
summary: China has slowed down fertilizer exports, including urea, to India due to a surge in demand and a subsequent price surge. Around half a million tonnes of urea are held up at Chinese ports, affecting Indian companies such as Indian Potash Limited and Rashtriya Chemicals and Fertilizers Limited. This move is expected to raise global prices and spending on fertilizers in India, with supplies from other countries such as Oman, Saudi Arabia, and Russia potentially filling the gap.

images.alt_text: As in several parts of the world, the use of “night soil” to fertilise crops was once common in Japan.

site_title: Indonesia, China discuss boost to investment and trade
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo and Chinese Premier Li Qiang discussed ways to boost bilateral investment and trade, including expanding Indonesian export products and improving flight connectivity. China agreed to import more Indonesian bulk commodities and premium agricultural products, while Indonesia invited Chinese firms to participate in its $32 billion new capital project. An agreement was also signed between the two countries' commerce ministries to expand e-commerce cooperation. The meeting aimed to strengthen ties between the two nations, with a focus on increasing economic cooperation and trade.

site_title: AI’s potential damage to economies
summary: Artificial intelligence (AI) is increasingly removing goods and products from GDP calculations, posing a significant threat to the global economic system. As AI dematerializes goods and services, it introduces massive productivity gains into human-centred industries, but also raises concerns about debt and inflation. If AI continues to increase exponentially, it may destabilize the system, leading to social unrest and inflation. Governments and central banks face a challenge in adjusting to this new reality, as AI's impact on GDP calculations could lead to a "ratio explodes higher" and massive debt becoming a serious problem.

images.alt_text: Launched by Microsoft-backed OpenAI in November, GenAI chatbot ChatGPT has become the world’s fastest growing app to date, and its emergence has prompted the release of rivals, such as Google’s Bard.
Companies relying on externally developed AI systems should conduct thorough due diligence to ensure system accuracy and robustness.

site_title: Huawei’s surprise phone gives ammo to Biden doubters on China
summary: The US is investigating Huawei's latest smartphone, the Mate 60 Pro, released with a 7-nanometre processor, which could be a breach of US export controls. The development has raised concerns about China's potential military advantage in the semiconductor market, prompting calls for stricter restrictions on Huawei and its supplier, SMIC. The Biden administration is considering updating export controls and revoking existing licenses for Huawei, but more information is needed to determine the extent of the breach. The incident highlights the ongoing tensions between the US and China over technology exports and national security.

images.alt_text: Adding to the pressure on Apple, Huawei on Friday launched two new smartphones – foldable phone Mate X5 and Mate 60 Pro+ smartphone, a new addition to a series it unveiled last week.
Huawei announced on its official online store that it would start taking orders for the new Mate 60 Pro smartphone from 10.08 am (0208 GMT) with delivery by Oct 9.

The Apple Store in Beijing. Apple enjoys widespread popularity in China, despite rising resentment of American efforts to contain the Asian country’s technology industry. The company’s iPhones are among the nation’s bestsellers and are common in both the government and private sector.
Huawei's latest Mate 60 Pro is powered by a new advanced chip made by China's SMIC using 7nm technology, a breakthrough for the duo despite US sanctions.
Huawei was placed on a trade blacklist in May 2019 over national security concerns.
It’s unclear how Huawei may have procured the memory chips from Hynix, which makes most of its semiconductors at plants in China.
Some analysts suggest the possibility that Huawei may have acquired the technology and equipment from SMIC to produce the chip, rather than collaborating on its development.
The Mate 60 Pro, which went on sale this week, fanned patriotic fervour as it was seen to represent China’s ability to get around US sanctions.

site_title: Dior’s longest-running designer Marc Bohan dies at 97
summary: Fashion designer Marc Bohan, who was artistic director of Dior for 30 years, has died at 97. Born in Paris in 1926, Bohan joined Dior in 1957 and created iconic collections, including the "Slim Look" in 1961. He successfully revived the brand's spirit after its mid-20th-century heyday, introducing ready-to-wear lines and collaborating with icons like Francoise Sagan and Empress Farah of Iran. Bohan won two "De d'Or" awards for his designs before retiring from Dior in 1989.

images.alt_text: (FILES) French designer for Christian Dior Marc Bohan poses with sewing scissors, on March 1, 1987 in his fashion workshop in Paris. Fashion designer Marc Bohan, who was artistic director of Dior for nearly thirty years (1961-1989), an unequaled longevity in this house, has died, the luxury brand announced on September 8, 2023.
