site_title: Swiss post mortem of Credit Suisse crisis to go back to 2015
summary: Switzerland has begun a post-mortem inquiry into the 2023 collapse of Credit Suisse, examining actions by state bodies from 2015 to March 2023. The inquiry, led by a cross-party parliamentary committee, will focus on the government, financial markets watchdog Finma, and the Swiss National Bank's responses to Credit Suisse's worsening situation. The investigation is expected to last until February 2024 and will not assess the bank's management, but instead focus on the implementation of financial market supervision legislation and international comparisons.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse and UBS, two of the most systemically relevant in global finance, hold combined assets of up to 140 per cent of Swiss gross domestic product.

site_title: India central bank to wind down incremental cash reserve ratio in phases
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) plans to unwind its incremental cash reserve ratio (I-CRR) requirement in phases, releasing 25% on September 9, another 25% on September 23, and the remaining amount on October 7. The I-CRR, introduced in August, aimed to withdraw over $16.4 billion in banking system liquidity. Market participants had expected the ratio to be lowered to 5-8% ahead of twin tax outflows, but the RBI will maintain the current level. The move aims to prevent sudden shocks to system liquidity and ensure orderly money market functioning.

site_title: Alibaba puts grocery IPO on backburner due to disappointing valuations
summary: Alibaba Group Holding has put its planned Hong Kong initial public offering (IPO) of Freshippo grocery chain on hold due to disappointing valuations. The company had initially expected a valuation of $6 billion to $10 billion but now believes it can achieve a valuation of around $4 billion. This decision comes amid weak sentiment for consumer stocks and a delay in a more favorable market. The IPO was initially set to float by May 2024, but Freshippo may proceed with its listing plan once the Chinese retail environment improves.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: 3D printed clouds and figurines are seen in front of the Alibaba Cloud service logo in this illustration taken February 8, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
DingTalk will operate as a wholly-owned subsidiary of Alibaba Holding Group and there would be no impact on its services.
FILE PHOTO: The logo of Alibaba Group is seen lit up at its office building in Beijing, China August 9, 2021. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo
Alibaba has in the past explored splitting off Lazada.

site_title: UK experiencing longest September heatwave
summary: The UK is experiencing its longest September heatwave, with temperatures topping 30°C for five consecutive days. This breaks the previous record of three consecutive days. The heat is expected to persist until at least Saturday, with temperatures reaching 32°C in some areas. An amber health alert has been issued due to increased risks to vulnerable individuals. The Met Office attributes the heatwave to climate change, stating that hot spells like this are becoming more frequent and severe.

images.alt_text: Over the second quarter as a whole, food spending was up 9.8 per cent while non-food spending grew just 0.3 per cent.

site_title: Saudi football clubs’ spending in transfer window second only to England
summary: Saudi Arabian football clubs spent US$875.4 million in the transfer window, second only to the English Premier League's US$1.98 billion, according to FIFA and Deloitte reports. The Saudi Pro League signed 37 players from top European leagues, including Neymar, Karim Benzema, and Cristiano Ronaldo. The league's net spend of US$907 million was behind the Premier League's US$1.39 billion, but marked the first time a non-UEFA confederation surpassed 10% of global transfer spending.

images.alt_text: Read about a Brazilian player being greeted by thousands of fans and whisked off in a Rolls-Royce to banquet with royalty, and Neymar springs to mind.
Al-Hilal also tried to sign Neymar’s former teammates France striker Kylian Mbappe and Lionel Messi, but the Argentine eventually opted for Major League Soccer’s Inter Miami.

site_title: MCI warns The Economist’s Singapore bureau chief against interference in domestic politics
summary: The Ministry of Communications and Information (MCI) has issued a warning to Dominic Ziegler, The Economist's Singapore bureau chief, over publicly endorsing a local online publication, Jom, on August 25, which MCI deemed as interference in Singapore's domestic politics. Ziegler compared Singapore to an illiberal state and encouraged Singaporeans to adopt an alternative vision. MCI stated that foreign correspondents are allowed to report on Singapore, but not to participate in domestic politics. The warning aims to clarify the distinction between reporting and interference.

site_title: German finance minister announces additional tax cuts of two billion euros
summary: German Finance Minister Christian Lindner announced additional tax cuts of nearly 2 billion euros for 2024, not included in the draft budget. The tax-free basic allowance will rise by 180 euros to 11,784 euros, and the child basic allowance will increase by 228 euros to 6,612 euros.

images.alt_text: German Finance Minister Christian Lindner addresses delegates during a debate on the 2024 state budget at the Bundestag, the lower house of parliament, on September 5, 2023 in Berlin. (Photo by John MACDOUGALL / AFP)

site_title: PetroChina buys EV charging firm Potevio New Energy
summary: PetroChina has acquired 100% of electric vehicle (EV) charging firm Potevio New Energy Co, further expanding its investment in low-carbon businesses. Potevio, set up in 2010, operated 50,000 charging points in over 50 Chinese cities. This acquisition is part of China's goal to be carbon neutral by 2060. PetroChina has also set up a new entity to focus on EV charging facilities and previously joined a joint venture to supply swappable batteries for EVs. The cost of the acquisition was not disclosed.

images.alt_text: PetroChina says it is establishing and gradually expanding its global liquefied natural gas (LNG) portfolio through long-term investments.

site_title: Stellantis plans to expand battery capacity to 400 GWh
summary: Stellantis plans to expand its battery capacity to 400 gigawatt hours (GWh) to support growing electric vehicle production, according to Micky Bly, head of global propulsion systems. The company has already announced 250 GWh of capacity and is working to secure key material supplies. Stellantis aims to deliver six gigafactories worldwide, with three planned in the US and Canada. The company has invested 40 million euros in its Turin Battery Technology Center, which will focus on in-house testing and development of EV battery packs.

images.alt_text: Stellantis plans to start selling an EV city car from its French brand Citroen priced below 25,000 euros early next year.

site_title: Volvo's Russian assets transferred to Russian investor, says industry ministry
summary: Volvo's Russian assets, including the Kaluga plant, have been transferred to an undisclosed Russian investor, according to the Ministry of Industry and Trade. The assets, which include production capacity for 15,000 trucks per year, were previously suspended due to Russia's invasion of Ukraine in 2022. The new owner, identified as businessman Igor Kim, has partnered with Alexei Sannikov to restart production at the site. This move follows other Western firms, such as Volkswagen and Mercedes-Benz, pulling out of manufacturing in Russia due to economic sanctions and threats.

images.alt_text: (L-R) Joseph Heng general manager UD Trucks Singapore; Anna Engblom, managing director Volvo Trucks - South-East Asia & Japan; Gino Marzola, managing director DSV Air & Sea Singapore & Malaysia.

site_title: Enviro-Hub Holdings responds to SGX queries on details about CPIB probe of unit’s ex-GM
summary: Enviro-Hub Holdings responded to Singapore Exchange Securities Trading (SGX-ST) queries about a CPIB probe of its unit's former general manager. The company confirmed the former executive resigned on Sep 4, citing personal matters, and stated that the CPIB investigation primarily pertains to her personal matters. Enviro-Hub also clarified that no other employees are being investigated by CPIB and that the former executive has presented a bond and bail bond to the investigation committee. The company acted swiftly in response to the developments.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Enviro-Hub says it was informed of the CPIB probe by the general manager, and that it was not involved in the interview process.
Enviro-Hub noted that the group was informed of the investigation and not involved in the CPIB interview process.

site_title: Indonesia’s new golden visa will attract top talent, boost sluggish property market
summary: Indonesia has launched its new golden visa scheme, offering perks such as priority security screening and longer stay periods to attract top foreign talent and boost its sluggish real estate market. The first recipient, OpenAI CEO Sam Altman, received a five-year visa after investing at least US$2.5 million in an Indonesian company. Analysts expect the scheme to stimulate economic development and attract quality foreign talent, with potential benefits for Indonesia's digital economy and real estate sector.

images.alt_text: CEO of OpenAI Sam Altman (R) arrives for an official State Dinner in honor of India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi, at the White House in Washington, DC, on June 22, 2023. (Photo by Stefani Reynolds / AFP)

site_title: US Treasury to issue more clean energy tax credit guidance by end-2023
summary: The US Treasury plans to release guidance on clean energy tax incentives before the end of 2023, including a provision to deter companies relying on Chinese supply chains. The guidance will cover the "45X" manufacturing production tax for clean energy products and foreign entity of concern rules for batteries and critical minerals. The auto industry is watching the rules as they make investment decisions on electric vehicles. The guidance is expected to address concerns raised by Ford Motor Co's deal with Chinese battery manufacturer CATL.

images.alt_text: The IRA includes a 30 per cent credit for renewable energy facilities like solar and wind farms, as well as credits for clean vehicles and fuels, hydrogen, carbon capture and storage and clean energy equipment manufacturing.

site_title: Issue 65: Hot and bothered with the Global Stocktake; Singapore gives palm oil thumbs up for jet fuel
summary: The world is far behind on its climate goals, with current policies falling short of mitigating greenhouse gas emissions to avoid crossing critical global warming temperature thresholds. The first progress review of the Paris Agreement, known as the Global Stocktake, will be held at COP28 in Dubai, where world leaders will face the reality of inadequate climate action. Singapore has given its approval for the use of palm oil as a feedstock for sustainable aviation fuel, potentially splitting the market and raising compliance issues. Urgent action is needed to address the issue, with rapid decarbonization and higher risk of "hot house" and "disorderly" scenarios.

site_title: Taiwan August exports fall less than expected, growth seen resuming
summary: Taiwan's exports declined 7.3% in August, the smallest drop in 12 months and first single-digit percentage fall since October, exceeding a Reuters poll's 8.05% contraction. However, the island's GDP returned to growth in the second quarter due to resilient domestic consumption. This indicates that Taiwan's economy may resume growth ahead of the year-end holiday shopping season.

images.alt_text: In July, Taiwan's exports drop for the 11th consecutive month due to sluggish demand from the US and China.
Taiwan's overseas shipments fall 10.4 per cent to US$38.7 billion last month compared to a year earlier, the Ministry of Finance says.
Taiwan's GDP expands by a preliminary 1.45 per cent in the April-June period versus a year earlier.

site_title: German economy expected to contract 0.4% in 2023
summary: Germany's economy is expected to contract 0.4% in 2023 due to sluggish consumption by private households and weak exports, largely influenced by faltering demand from China. The DIW economic research institute lowered its forecast from 0.2% contraction. This marks Germany as the only major global economy expected to shrink this year, with households' spending mood benefiting from lower inflation, but the export-oriented economy slow to recover.

site_title: Virgin Voyages raises US$550 million in Ares-led round
summary: Virgin Voyages, a cruise brand from Richard Branson's Virgin Group, has raised $550 million in fresh capital led by Ares Management. Existing investors, including Virgin Group and Bain Capital, also participated. The funding will aid expansion into new international markets, with plans to operate in Australia and New Zealand by the end of the year. Founding CEO Tom McAlpin will become chairman, while President Nirmal Saverimuttu will take over as CEO.

site_title: It’s no longer a given that China will become the world’s largest economy
summary: China's economic performance is expected to remain lacklustre for the remainder of 2023 and the first half of 2024, with the country's return as a powerful driver of global economic growth unlikely in the near future. The Chinese government's reliance on traditional stimulus measures is being questioned, with economists warning of significant financial issues, including high indebtedness that could transform into systemic risks. The country's economic strategy, which has historically over-relied on real estate and domestic consumer Internet platforms, is being re-evaluated, with a focus on new growth sectors such as higher-value manufacturing and green energy.

images.alt_text: China's development story has been one of the world’s greatest economic miracles. Success comes with responsibilities, however.

site_title: China's Ant Group unveils finance AI model as race heats up
summary: China's Ant Group has unveiled a finance-specific artificial intelligence (AI) model, joining a crowded race to deploy AI in heavily-regulated China. The model, called Zhixiaobao 2.0, can match the average financial professional in market analysis and reasoning capability, and will be available once it receives regulatory approval. This is the latest move by Ant, China's biggest fintech firm, to deploy AI, following similar announcements by tech giants Tencent and Xiaomi, and its affiliate Alibaba. The model will be tested on Ant's wealth management and insurance platforms, with closed tests already underway.

images.alt_text: Global investors including Warburg, GIC and Carlyle had invested in Ant in its 2018 fundraising at a valuation of US$150 billion.

site_title: Platform workers have lower insurance coverage for critical illness, mortality: study
summary: A study found platform workers in Singapore have a 59% mortality protection gap compared to 21% for economically active citizens, and a 91% critical illness protection gap compared to 74% for all economically active workers.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Canninghill Piers luxury property sales are linked to a money laundering suspect, with partially paid transactions for 10 properties causing a probe to stall. The Singapore GP has pledged to halve F1 energy emissions by 2028. A new energy cooperation MOU has been signed between Singapore and Indonesia. Pet owners are splurging on pet products, but the industry faces challenges due to high costs and space limitations. The G20 Summit is set to take place in New Delhi, with leaders gathering for the event. Singapore shares closed lower on Friday, down 0.6%.

site_title: World food price index back at two-year low despite rice surge
summary: The Food and Agriculture Organization's (FAO) world price index fell to a two-year low in August, averaging 121.4 points, down from a revised 124.0 in the previous month. The decline in most food commodities offset increases for rice and sugar, reversing a rebound seen in the previous month. This marks a new low for the index since June 2022.

Maize prices fell on the prospect harvesting in South America and US production will replenish stocks.

site_title: Swedish housing prices near inflection point as rates trek up
summary: Sweden's housing prices remained stable in August, with apartment prices falling 1% and detached house prices unchanged. This marks a stabilization after a decline that started last year due to inflation and rising borrowing costs. Current prices are 10-11% below the peak in March-April 2022. Analysts are split on whether prices will resume their decline, with some predicting a trough and others expecting moderate declines. The Riksbank is expected to raise its benchmark rate to 4% in the coming months, further tightening mortgage lenders and adding pressure on the housing market.

site_title: Nvidia strikes deals with Reliance, Tata in deepening India AI bet
summary: Nvidia has announced partnerships with Indian conglomerates Reliance Industries and Tata Group to develop cloud infrastructure, language models, and generative applications. The deals will help Nvidia deepen its inroads to India's emerging AI ecosystem, a move seen as a strategic response to US restrictions on chip exports to China. Reliance will create AI applications for its 450 million Jio customers, while Tata Consultancy Services will build and process generative AI apps using Nvidia's technology, aiming to upskill its 600,000-strong workforce.

site_title: MAS directs banks to probe ties with money laundering suspects
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has directed banks to investigate any relationships with individuals tied to a money laundering scandal involving over S$1.8 billion of assets. The 34 individuals, including 10 suspects arrested last month, "could be involved in illicit activities." MAS instructed banks to review suspicious transactions from 2020, and the move underscores efforts to plug gaps exposed by a previous crackdown.

site_title: Oil cut extension raises risk of Saudi economic contraction this year
summary: Saudi Arabia's decision to extend crude production cuts until the end of 2023 raises the risk of an economic contraction this year, with a 9% drop in production expected. The move is expected to reduce oil prices, but may still impact the economy due to its heavy reliance on oil. Analysts forecast a 0.5% contraction in GDP, with non-oil growth needing to average 5% to maintain growth. The government's reliance on oil revenue and the impact of the extended cuts on state-owned Saudi Aramco's dividend payouts are also concerns.

images.alt_text: Customers of the kingdom’s crude in Europe have had to scramble for alternatives with many now switching to sweet, or low-sulphur, oil.

site_title: French wine output falls with sharp contrasts between vineyards
summary: French wine production is expected to reach nearly 45 million hectolitres this year, a 2% decline from previous years, due to contrasting conditions in different regions. Severe fungal diseases in Bordeaux and southwest, as well as drought in Languedoc and Roussillon, have reduced harvest potential. Despite these challenges, the output is still above the average of the past five harvests.

site_title: BMW i4 eDrive35 review: Sweet and low-down
summary: The BMW i4 eDrive35 is a sweet and balanced electric sedan that offers a unique driving experience, despite its less powerful motor. With 286 horsepower and instant torque, it accelerates from 0-100 km/h in 6 seconds, making it a quick car. The i4 eDrive35 features a supple ride quality, exemplary fluidity, and a conventional interior with a familiar BMW feel. Although it's more expensive than the iX3, the i4 eDrive35 is now BMW's cheapest electric vehicle, priced at S$345,888.

site_title: Singapore stocks end lower on Friday, tracking regional losses; STI down 0.6%
summary: Singapore stocks closed lower on Friday, down 0.6% or 18.84 points to 3,207.75, as regional markets finished mostly red. The largest decliners included Jardine Cycle & Carriage, UOB, and Jardine Matheson. Local banks UOB, OCBC, and DBS also fell, with DBS down 0.5% or S$0.18 to S$33.23. Regionally, major indices in Australia, South Korea, Shanghai, and Malaysia ended lower, while Japan reported weaker-than-expected economic growth.

site_title: Berkeley freezes investment in UK housing market as rates weigh
summary: Berkeley Group Holdings, the UK's largest developer, has halted investment in new projects due to high interest rates and inflation in the housing market. The company reported a 35% drop in new home reservations in the summer period, citing ongoing planning issues and high interest rates. Despite this, Berkeley's pricing remains resilient, and it reaffirmed its earnings guidance of £1 billion in pre-tax profits. The company's decision reflects the challenges faced by the UK's largest homebuilders, which have seen their market capitalisations tumble this year.

site_title: Thai economy may grow 2.8% this year after formation of new government, says minister
summary: Thailand's economy is expected to grow 2.8% this year, driven by public investment and spending that will attract more private investment, as well as continued growth in private consumption and tourism. The growth outlook is lower than the ministry's earlier forecast of 3.5% due to weak exports amid slowing global demand.

site_title: China car sales return to growth in Aug, Tesla nearly doubles EV share
summary: China's passenger vehicle sales returned to growth in August, increasing 2.2% year-on-year to 1.94 million units, according to the China Passenger Car Association. Electric vehicles drove the growth, with sales rising 8.5% from July and accounting for 36.9% of total car sales. Tesla nearly doubled its share of the electric vehicle market, selling 64,694 cars in China in August, while Chinese automakers continued to focus on overseas markets, with exports surging 31% in August.

site_title: Malaysian PM Anwar faces backlash as allies’ graft charges dropped
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim faces criticism after Deputy Prime Minister Ahmad Zahid Hamidi's 47 criminal charges were dropped due to ongoing investigations. Anwar denies interfering in the decision, citing the ongoing investigations, but critics argue this undermines his anti-corruption commitment. The move is seen as a "significant step backward" for Anwar's reform agenda, and Zahid's discharge erodes the government's credibility on rule of law and justice. Anwar's closest allies have distanced themselves from the case, and critics wonder if former Prime Minister Najib Razak may also be spared similar treatment.

site_title: Singapore GP pledges to halve F1 energy emissions by 2028
summary: Singapore Grand Prix has pledged to halve its energy emissions from the annual Formula 1 event by 2028 through reducing energy usage, increasing renewable energy resources, and using Renewable Energy Certificates to offset unavoidable emissions. The event expects to reduce carbon dioxide emissions by up to 52% when fully implemented, primarily through the use of hydro-treated vegetable oil in power generators.

site_title: Seatrium left with S$300 million net proceeds from S$1.5 billion rights issue in 2021
summary: Seatrium, an offshore and marine group, has a remaining balance of S$300 million in net proceeds from its 2021 rights issue, which raised S$1.5 billion. The latest S$100 million repayment of a loan facility has been utilized, in accordance with the intended use of net proceeds. The company will continue to make periodic announcements on the use of the remaining net proceeds as they are materially disbursed.

site_title: Parkson Retail Asia warns of ‘adverse impact’ on full-year financials in light of unit’s legal woes
summary: Parkson Retail Asia has warned that its full-year financials may be negatively impacted if the outcome of ongoing legal proceedings does not favor its unit, Parkson Corporation. The unit is involved in a dispute with PKNS Andaman Development over premises leased within Evo shopping mall. If the amended claims are settled in full, Parkson Retail's financial position for the year ending December 31 is expected to be adversely affected. The outcome of the legal proceedings is uncertain and could have a significant impact on the company's financials.

site_title: Latest UK renewables auction fails to attract offshore wind bids
summary: The UK's latest renewable energy auction failed to attract bids for offshore wind projects, resulting in no contracts awarded. The auction was impacted by global inflation and supply chain challenges, with the government maintaining a price cap of £44 per megawatt hour, which critics say was too low. The lack of new offshore wind capacity is expected to cost consumers £1 billion annually. The government aims to reach 50 GW of offshore wind in operation by 2030, but the failure to secure bids has raised concerns about meeting this goal.

images.alt_text: Newer entrants to the US offshore wind industry include divisions of South Korea’s Hanwha, US renewable energy developer Hecate Energy, and Houston private equity firm Quantum Capital.

site_title: China’s Huawei launches Mate 60 Pro+ smartphone for presale
summary: Huawei launched the Mate 60 Pro+ smartphone for presale on its official online store, starting orders at 10.08 am GMT on September 8, with delivery by October 9. The new version offers capabilities to link to two satellites concurrently and larger internal storage compared to the Mate 60 Pro, but its price remains undisclosed. This move comes after the company's success in beating back US sanctions and capturing global attention.

site_title: Chevron workers on strike at gas plants in Western Australia
summary: Chevron workers launched rolling strikes on Friday at the company's gas plants in Western Australia, threatening a major production pipeline that pumps out 5% of global LNG stocks. The strike, which began after Australia's industrial umpire brokered last-minute talks, is expected to slowly escalate in coming weeks, covering 500 staff and including stoppages, bans, and limitations. Chevron has warned of safe and reliable operations, but union officials claim the company will "finally be facing their day of reckoning."

images.alt_text: Employees last week almost unanimously rejected a pay and conditions deal put to them directly by Chevron, bypassing unions.

site_title: Japanese investors turn buyers of foreign bonds in August on higher yields
summary: Japanese investors turned to foreign bonds in August, purchasing 2.32 trillion yen worth of long-term bonds, marking their first net buying in four months. This comes as yields surged and global stocks declined due to fears of prolonged interest rate hikes. In contrast, they sold 1.76 trillion yen worth of foreign bonds in July. The purchases were driven by concerns over high interest rates, with US Treasury yields reaching a 16-year high. This is part of a larger trend, with Japanese investors pouring 14.01 trillion yen into US bonds this year.

site_title: Pet owners are splurging, but competition is ruff for the industry
summary: Pet owners in Singapore are splurging on pet products and services, driving growing demand, but the industry faces challenges. High costs, price wars, and limited space are affecting some parts of the industry. Despite new pet licensing conditions having little impact on demand, the industry is experiencing disruption. The rise of digital pet influencers is also notable, with pet owners seeking online content and experiences. Overall, the industry is adapting to changing consumer behaviors and market trends, but faces ongoing challenges in maintaining profitability and growth.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Tessa Oh

site_title: Leaders, limousines, and langur monkey impersonators: New Delhi primed for G20 pow-wow
summary: World leaders, including US President Joe Biden and Chinese Premier Li Qiang, are gathering in New Delhi for the G20 Summit, hosted by Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi. The summit, which takes place on Saturday and Sunday, aims to address global issues such as climate change, economic growth, and trade. India has adopted the theme "Vasudhaiva Kutumbakam" (one earth, one family, one future) and seeks to promote inclusive growth and accelerate the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals. However, China's President Xi Jinping will not attend, and Russia's President Vladimir Putin has also skipped the summit.

images.alt_text: Goh Ruoxue

China's President Xi Jinping (right) is likely to skip the G20 summit and Chinese Premier Li Qiang is expected to represent Beijing at the meeting in New Delhi, sources familiar with the matter have told Reuters.

President Xi Jinping skipping the G20 meeting, sending instead Prime Minister Li Qiang (above) in his place, would be a blow for the host, India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi. Xi has attended every G20 meeting since taking power about a decade ago.
US President Joe Biden's stop in Hanoi, which will follow on the heels of a multi-day visit to India for the G20 summit, comes as Washington seeks to counter China’s influence in the region.
Russian President Vladimir Putin (above) on Monday (Aug 28) told his Indian counterpart Narendra Modi that Russia would be represented by Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov.

site_title: Apple suppliers slide on China anxiety, rising competition from Huawei
summary: Apple suppliers, including Qualcomm and Broadcom, fell after China intensified curbs on iPhone use by government staff, fueling fears of rising Sino-US tensions and competition from Huawei. The ban, which may affect up to 5-10 million iPhone units annually, coincides with Huawei's launch of new smartphones, including a foldable phone. Analysts say Huawei's moves may mark a comeback effort, while analysts and investors express concern about the impact on Apple's sales prospects in China.

images.alt_text: If consumers in China are looking to dump Apple, the new Huawei phone could provide an alternative.

site_title: First phase of Fukushima water release to end Monday
summary: Japan's first phase of releasing treated Fukushima water into the Pacific is set to end on Monday, with 7,800 tonnes of water released since August 24. The water, equivalent to 540 Olympic pools, has been used to cool the reactors since the 2011 tsunami. Levels of radioactive tritium in seawater samples are within safe limits, according to Tepco. The release is expected to take decades to complete, aimed at making space for removing highly radioactive fuel and rubble from the wrecked reactors.

images.alt_text: Fishery workers sorting out seafood at Matsukawaura port in Fukushima prefecture over the weekend. “The government failed to keep to its promise of gaining agreement from fishermen before taking such a decision to release (the water),” said a spokeperson for the group of more than 100 plaintiffs.
Beijing has been the most vocal opponent to Japan’s move to discharge treated radioactive water into the ocean.

Protestors shout slogans during a rally in front of the Japanese Embassy in Seoul to call on the Japanese government; the government has launched a voucher programme offering up to 20,000 won to shoppers who buy seafood.

site_title: Singapore, Indonesia to further strengthen cross-border electricity trade
summary: Singapore and Indonesia signed a new memorandum of understanding (MOU) on September 8, 2023, to support commercial projects for cross-border trading of low-carbon electricity. The agreement aims to import up to 4 GW of low-carbon electricity by 2035, with five projects already granted conditional approval by Singapore's Energy Market Authority. The projects involve importing 2 GW of low-carbon electricity from Indonesia and will support the development of solar photovoltaics and battery-energy storage systems in the country.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
A Keppel employee poses for photos during a tour of their rooftop solar panels at their Keppel Bay Tower office building in Singapore July 6, 2023. REUTERS/Edgar Su
EMA is looking for proposals that develop more land-efficient, cost-effective and safer ESS solutions suited for the Republic’s tropical and urbanised climate.
The Energy Market Authority said it will progressively roll out enhancements to its regulatory framework for electricity retailers from August 2023.
EMA issues request for proposal to study Singapore's potential for geothermal energy to generate power.

site_title: Pentagreen signs deal to bridge US$30 million funding gap for Philippine solar projects
summary: Pentagreen Capital, a sustainable infrastructure debt financing platform backed by Temasek, has signed a deal with Citicore Renewable Energy Corporation to bridge a $30 million funding gap for 490 MW of solar power projects in the Philippines. The deal, which carries a greenshoe option to raise the committed amount to $100 million, aims to support the Philippine government's goal of generating 35% of the country's energy needs from renewable sources by 2030 and 50% by 2040. The partnership is seen as a vote of confidence in Citicore's ability to scale up its project development and is expected to catalyze sustainable infrastructure development in ASEAN.

images.alt_text: The Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone will create jobs and open up investment opportunities in the flourishing Malaysia-Singapore corridor.

Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam said financial supervision is required if carbon taxes – the “most logical and rational” option – don’t rise to adequate levels globally without lots of free riders.

site_title: Quarz announces committee for Sabana’s internalisation, invites unitholders to join
summary: Sabana Real Estate Investment Trust (Sabana Reit) has established a committee, the Sabana Growth Internalisation Committee (SGIC), to support the internalisation process of the manager, following its removal at an extraordinary general meeting. The committee, led by activist investor Quarz, aims to ensure the internalisation process is completed within a target budget of S$3 million to S$5 million by April 2024. Unitholders can join the committee as actively involved, partially involved, or passive members, and will have the right to vote in, remove, and re-elect directors once the internalisation is completed.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
The profit number for Sabana Reit's manager in ESR Goup's letter on Friday night is "factually wrong" , said Quarz.
Sabana Industrial Reit's NTP+ at 151 Lorong Chuan
151 Lorong Chuan, New Tech Park, from Sabana Reit's portfolio. Sabana Reit unitholders will be voting on two resolutions in an EGM requisitioned by Quarz Capital on Aug 4.
Why has Quarz decided to push Sabana Reit down this path despite all the risks?

site_title: Hong Kong flooded by heaviest rainfall in 140 years
summary: Heavy rainfall in Hong Kong on September 8, 2023, brought the city to a standstill, with a record 158.1 mm of rain recorded in just one hour. The floodwaters submerged streets, subway stations, and homes, forcing schools to close and leaving at least 110 people hospitalized. Four people were declared dead, and authorities warned of potential landslips and coastal damage. Climate experts attribute the extreme weather to climate change, which has increased the intensity of tropical storms. The flooding is estimated to cost at least US$100 million.

images.alt_text: A woman being evacuated from a flooded area following heavy rains caused by Typhoon Haikui in Xiamen, in China's southern Fujian province. Economic losses have reached 5.05 billion yuan (S$942.7 million).

Sultan al-Jaber, chief executive of the UAE's Abu Dhabi National Oil Company (ADNOC) and president of this year's COP28 climate gestures during the 7th Ministerial on Climate Action (MoCA) in Brussels on July 13, 2023. The Ministerial on Climate Action (MoCA) is an annual meeting attended by ministers and high-level representatives from over 30 countries, including ministers from the G20 and chairs of key party groupings in the UN climate negotiations. (Photo by François WALSCHAERTS / AFP)
The damage wrought by Hurricane Idalia in Horseshoe Beach in Florida on Aug 31.
Typhoon Haikui makes landfall in Yilan in eastern Taiwan on Sept 3, 2023.

site_title: Tennis teen Gauff seeks home comforts once more in pursuit of US Open crown
summary: Tennis teenager Coco Gauff has reached the US Open final, where she will face second-seed Aryna Sabalenka from Belarus. Gauff, 19, beat Karolina Muchova in straight sets to advance to the final, overcoming a nearly 50-minute delay caused by a climate protest during the match. Gauff's victory marks a significant milestone in her career, with many considering her the new face of American tennis. The match will be played on Sunday, with Sabalenka seeking to become the world No. 1.

images.alt_text: Manchester United’s market capitalisation is now at US$3.15 billion, less than half the US$7.5 billion asking price the Glazers put on the club.

Diane and Phil Schiavo play pickleball against Lori Vickery and Frank Laratonda during the 2023 Ballpark Series at Fenway Park, home of Major League Baseball’s Boston Red Sox, in Boston, Massachusetts, US, July 14, 2023.

Formula One governing body FIA has introduced new regulations in recent years designed to mitigate safety and environmental concerns, but also level the playing field and foster competition in a sport that sometimes sees too much domination from a specific team or driver.

site_title: Canninghill Piers sales linked to money laundering suspect stuck in limbo as probe continues
summary: A money laundering probe linked to partially paid transactions for 10 luxury properties at Canninghill Piers in Singapore has thrown the project into limbo. The properties, valued at between S$30 million and S$50 million, were financed by Vang Shuiming, one of 10 suspects caught in the massive police dragnet. With the police probe ongoing, the status of uncompleted transactions and payments made to developers is uncertain. The developers, City Developments and CapitaLand Development, may be unable to keep funds collected so far, and the units now frozen by court order may be resold by the developers if a court order is made.

images.alt_text: Wang Baosen and Su Baolin have been denied bail and will return to court on Oct 4.
Gramercy Park, where two of the 10 arrested in the billion-dollar money-laundering case own condominium units.
$1b in cash and assets were seized and frozen.
Cash seized by the police in the S$1 billion money laundering case

site_title: Nanjing scraps home-buying curbs in China’s latest property boost
summary: Nanjing, a major Chinese city, has lifted home-buying curbs, allowing individuals to purchase flats without proof of eligibility in four districts. This move is part of China's efforts to support its struggling property sector, which accounts for one-quarter of the country's economic activity. Analysts predict that other cities may follow Nanjing's lead, easing restrictions on home purchases. The easing of curbs is seen as a potential boost to the sector, which has been on a downward spiral since 2021 due to government measures to curb debt accumulation.

images.alt_text: Mortgage rates for first homes are around 4 per cent, while one-year fixed deposit rates are roughly 1.5 per cent.
China has granted just a handful – including to industry newcomer Hozon New Energy Automobile – since July 2017, when it tightened rules to contain overcapacity.

site_title: Heathrow charges provisionally backed by UK competition regulator
summary: The UK's competition regulator, the Competitions and Markets Authority (CMA), has provisionally backed most of the Civil Aviation Authority's (CAA) decisions on Heathrow's airline charges for the 2024 to 2026 period. The CAA proposed a cut in fees, but airlines and Heathrow disagreed, with airlines saying the cuts did not go far enough. The CMA will review the CAA's decision until October 17 and consider comments before making a final decision. The regulator provisionally considers that the CAA was not wrong in most of its decisions.

images.alt_text: Woldbye will step down as CEO of Copenhagen Airports by Sept 30 after 12 years in the role.

site_title: Asia-Pacific’s infrastructure opportunity is not just a private affair
summary: Asia-Pacific will require significant investments in various infrastructure sectors, including industrials, utilities, waste management, renewables, data centers, and transportation networks, to sustain economic development and mitigate climate change. The region's growing middle class and demographics are driving demand for these assets, with an estimated $1.7 trillion of annual infrastructure investment needed in developing Asia alone. This investment will support the region's economic growth and enhance climate adaptation and mitigation efforts.

images.alt_text: To prepare for the energy transition, GIC has made early investments in renewable energy companies, future fuels such as green hydrogen, long-term energy storage, and carbon capture and sequestration.

site_title: Will India be the breakout emerging market this decade?
summary: India is poised for a period of long-term growth, driven by significant expansion in direct and fixed-asset investment. The country's digital transformation and infrastructure boom are helping unlock growth in its equity market. Key factors include corporate confidence, economic expansion, and technological innovation. With relative political stability over the past decade, India is an attractive emerging market compared to others, with a favorable business environment and potential for sustained growth. This could make India the breakout emerging market of the decade.

images.alt_text: The neighbourhood around the Gateway – including the boutique-filled The Taj Mahal Palace hotel – has always been home to affluent, old school business families.
The Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) building in Mumbai, India. Aggregate Indian equity market capitalisation has risen two-fold in the past 20 years.

site_title: Norway’s US$1.4 trillion wealth fund shutters Shanghai office as Singapore takes over as its Asia hub
summary: Norway's $1.4 trillion sovereign wealth fund is closing its Shanghai office, shifting its Asian hub to Singapore. The move is due to "operational considerations" and does not affect investment strategy in China. This shift follows other international investors scaling back plans in China amid a deteriorating geopolitical climate. The fund, which owns about 850 companies in its Chinese portfolio, will ensure an orderly closure of its Shanghai office.

images.alt_text: Caves in South Sulawesi are home to paintings that are believed to be about 44,000 years old and the earliest known pictorial record of story-telling.
FILE PHOTO: A view shows the building of Norway’s central bank (Norges Bank) in Oslo, Norway, June 23, 2022.  REUTERS/Victoria Klesty/File Photo

site_title: Lilly's diabetes drug gets green light from UK watchdog
summary: The UK's National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (Nice) has approved Lilly's diabetes drug Mounjaro (tirzepatide) as a treatment for patients with poorly controlled Type 2 diabetes. The drug is estimated to benefit around 180,000 people in the UK and is expected to be made available in the National Health Service within 90 days. The approval follows a request for more data on the drug's benefits, and investors have seen Lilly's shares surge in anticipation of a potential blockbuster drug.

images.alt_text: Ozempic (above) is used to treat Type 2 diabetes and obesity. It shares the same active ingredient as Wegovy, namely, semaglutide. The results of the study make Wegovy the first drug to combine effective weight loss with reduced heart disease risk, said a senior executive of Novo Nordisk.

site_title: Nomura crypto chief warns market rout may delay unit’s profit
summary: Nomura's digital assets arm, Laser Digital, may take longer to break even than initially forecast due to a decline in trading volumes and regulatory changes. The unit, which launched in September 2022, had aimed to turn a profit by 2024, but CEO Jez Mohideen attributed the delay to a "deep rout" in crypto markets and regulatory changes. This is the second time the unit has faced challenges, following the bankruptcy of FTX in November 2022.

images.alt_text: Nomura will also pay almost US$808,000 in restitution to victims of the scheme.
The bank aims to boost assets under its international wealth management business to US$35 billion from US$15 billion by March 2025.

A pedestrian wearing a protective face mask walks past the Nomura Holdings Inc. signage outside its headquarters in Tokyo, Japan, on Monday, March 29, 2021. Nomura's warning of a "significant" potential loss from an unnamed U.S. client is related to the unwinding of trades by Bill Hwangs Archegos Capital Management, according to people familiar with the matter. Photographer: Kiyoshi Ota/Bloomberg

A sign is lit up outside a Nomura Securities Co. branch in the Shinjuku district of Tokyo, Japan, on Thursday, April 23, 2009.  Nomura Holdings Inc., Japan's largest brokerage, is expected to announce earnings today. Photographer: Kimimasa Mayama/Bloomberg News

site_title: London room rental costs top £1,000 a month for the first time
summary: London's average rent for a single room has surpassed £1,013 (S$1,704) a month, a 15% increase from the previous year, marking the first time it has exceeded £1,000. The shortage of available rentals is attributed to higher mortgage rates and house prices, prompting landlords to sell their properties, and some converting to short-term rentals. The rental market is becoming a pinch point in the UK economy, particularly affecting first-time buyers who struggle to afford mortgage repayments, now accounting for over 40% of take-home pay.

images.alt_text: united kingdom london housing  Photographer: Jose Sarmento Matos/Bloomberg
The hiring of permanent staff fell by the most since June 2020, early in the Covid-19 pandemic, while spending on temporary workers dipped for the first time since July 2020.
he proposal comes days after Russian President Vladimir Putin said he wouldn’t revive a deal that had safeguarded the passage of Ukrainian grain through the Black Sea.

site_title: Apple grapples with turmoil in China days before iPhone 15 launch
summary: Apple faces a crisis in China, its largest international market, just days before the launch of its iPhone 15. Controversies include a growing ban on iPhone use among government workers and a new Huawei phone providing homegrown competition. Additionally, a resurgence in Chinese nationalism may lead to everyday consumers shunning foreign-branded devices, including iPhones. This could overshadow the iPhone 15 launch and test the smartphone industry's ability to innovate. Apple must address these challenges to mitigate potential losses and maintain its market share in China.

images.alt_text: Apple issued new updates on its devices after investigating the flaws reported by Citizen Lab.
If Beijing goes ahead, the unprecedented iPhone blockade might also affect several other US technology companies that rely on sales and production in China.

The Apple Store in Beijing. Apple enjoys widespread popularity in China, despite rising resentment of American efforts to contain the Asian country’s technology industry. The company’s iPhones are among the nation’s bestsellers and are common in both the government and private sector.
Prime Minister Narendra Modi has rolled out a mix of tariffs and incentives to lure companies to make in India.

site_title: Scientists grow human-like kidneys in pigs
summary: Chinese scientists have successfully grown human-like kidneys in pig embryos using CRISPR gene editing to delete pig cells' formation genes, allowing human pluripotent stem cells to fill the niche. The kidneys, containing 50-60% human cells, functionally normal and start growing ureters, but the presence of human cells in the pig brains raises concerns. The breakthrough, a world first, could help address organ donation shortages, but significant challenges remain before it can be used in human transplantation.

images.alt_text: pig, snout, nose

While previous such transplants have involved up to 10 modifications, the latest experiment involved just one: the gene involved in the so-called “hyperacute rejection,” which would otherwise occur within minutes of an animal organ being connected to a human circulatory system.

site_title: BT Market Focus: Cautious trading driven by weak China data and rate hike fears (Ep 58)
summary: Markets experienced cautious trading this week driven by weak China trade data and fears of US rate hikes. China's data showed a decline in exports and imports, while US inflationary pressures raised concerns about interest rate increases. As a result, markets remained volatile, with investors taking a cautious stance. The impact of these factors will be closely watched by traders and investors in the coming weeks.

images.alt_text: What propelled a rally among global tech stocks?
How much were Singapore stocks impacted by China's economic woes?

site_title: Indosat considers stake sale in US$1 billion fibre assets
summary: Indosat Ooredoo Hutchison is reviewing its fibre assets amid interest from global investors, considering a stake sale valued at over $1 billion. The move follows similar deals by other companies in the industry, such as the $6 billion merger of CK Hutchison Holdings and Qatar's Ooredoo QPSC last year. Indosat has previously sold a portfolio of towers to Mitratel and agreed to form a $300 million joint venture with Big Data Exchange. A transaction could be announced soon, although preliminary and subject to change.

site_title: Brokers’ take: UOBKH upgrades CP Foods to ‘buy’ in view of improved earnings in Q4
summary: UOB Kay Hian (UOBKH) upgraded its call on Thailand-listed CP Foods to "buy" from "hold", expecting the company to turn around in the fourth quarter of FY2023. The brokerage raised its target price to 26 baht, up from 20 previously, citing a strong recovery in FY2024 with a forward price-to-earnings multiple of 18.3 times. This upgrade reflects improved earnings expectations for CP Foods.

images.alt_text: The two listings would give a lift to Thailand’s IPO activity, which has raised US$454 million this year, according to Dealogic data.
CGS-CIMB is expecting Thailand’s national wage committee to increase its daily minimum wage sometime in August to September this year.
CP Foods' processing plant in Chok Chai, Nakhon Ratchasima province, Thailand.

site_title: Asia: Markets extend losses as US rate hike fears build
summary: Asia markets continued their losses on Friday, with stocks sinking after a resilient US jobs market report fueled fears of the Federal Reserve's monetary tightening campaign. The yen strengthened against the US dollar, hitting a 10-month low. Despite some positive GDP data from Singapore, overall indicators suggested the global economy is in good health, making it difficult for investors to recover from the losses. The sell-off extends a sell-off from the previous week, with Chinese data showing continued weakness.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Japanese yen and U.S. dollar banknotes are seen with a currency exchange rate graph in this illustration picture taken June 16, 2022. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Philippine central bank has room to further raise rates: report
summary: The Philippine central bank, Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas, has room to further raise interest rates to combat inflation, now expected to return to its 2-4% target in the first quarter of next year, earlier than initially expected. Annual inflation quickened to 5.3% in August, exceeding the central bank's comfort range. Governor Eli Remolona stated that if inflation continues, the central bank may raise the policy rate from 6.25% to a higher rate. The central bank has kept its policy steady at its last three meetings after a series of 425 basis point hikes since last year.

images.alt_text: Ranked among the world’s worst international gateways, Ninoy Aquino International Airport badly needs an upgrade to end chronic flight delays, address congestion, and improve facilities.

site_title: US CFTC focuses on DeFi platforms in latest crypto crackdown
summary: The US Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) has brought enforcement actions against three DeFi firms, Opyn, ZeroEx, and Deridex, for allegedly allowing US customers to trade digital-asset derivatives without registering. The firms have been ordered to cease and desist from violating CFTC rules and pay civil penalties totaling $750,000. The CFTC's actions signal a continued crackdown on DeFi platforms, with enforcement director Ian McGinley stating that "unlawful transactions become lawful when facilitated by smart contracts" do not.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Representations of cryptocurrencies are seen in this illustration, August 10, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Yuan falls to weakest since Dec 2007 as outflow pressure builds
summary: The yuan, China's currency, has fallen to its weakest level since December 2007, losing 6.1% against the dollar this year. Capital outflow pressures and a yield gap with major economies, particularly the US, are contributing to the decline. Analysts expect further selling pressure in the near term, but the pace of depreciation is likely to be measured. The yuan's biggest weekly loss since February is expected, with China's economy showing signs of slowing down, raising pressure on policymakers.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. Dollar and Chinese Yuan banknotes are seen in this illustration taken January 30, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration//File Photo
If consumers in China are looking to dump Apple, the new Huawei phone could provide an alternative.
Against a basket of currencies including the euro and sterling, the US dollar rises 0.1 per cent to 104.98.

site_title: Arm touts cloud computing expansion, royalty revenue
summary: Arm Holdings, a chip designer, is seeking a valuation of $50 billion to $54.5 billion in its initial public offering (IPO). The company expects significant growth in cloud computing and royalty revenue, driven by its 10% market share in cloud computing and 41% market share in the automotive industry. Arm's revenue stagnated due to weak mobile demand, but the company is optimistic about its prospects beyond the mobile phone market. Several major customers, including Apple and Nvidia, have invested in the IPO.

images.alt_text: SoftBank is offering 95.5 million American depository shares of Arm for a price of between US$47 and US$51 apiece.
Arm, the chip designer owned by SoftBank Group, is expected to set a price range for its offering next week, sources say.
SoftBank plans to sell about 10 per cent of Arm’s shares in the IPO at a valuation of US$60 billion to US$70 billion.
The IPO, expected to value Arm at between US$60 billion and US$70 billion, is likely to draw in some of its biggest customers as anchor shareholders, and even some competitors.
Arm has been seen as a potentially significant player in artificial intelligence (AI), highlighting the hot technology in its prospectus.

site_title: China needs more than cheaper mortgages to revive spending
summary: China's latest measures to support the ailing property sector, including mortgage rate cuts and eased rules for first-time buyers, are expected to have limited impact on consumer spending. Analysts estimate that the mortgage rate cuts could save borrowers 200-300 billion yuan per year, but also reduce interest income for depositors by 197 billion per year. Experts say the main constraint on consumer spending is people's income, and that the government should focus on transferring resources to consumers from other sectors of the economy rather than from household savings.

images.alt_text: China has granted just a handful – including to industry newcomer Hozon New Energy Automobile – since July 2017, when it tightened rules to contain overcapacity.
China’s imports have increased from last year since domestic fuel demand is no longer being suppressed by widespread curbs to tackle the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Ex-FTX executive Salame pleads guilty to criminal charges
summary: Former FTX executive Ryan Salame pleaded guilty to one campaign finance violation and one charge of operating an illegal money-transmitting business. Salame, who was the co-CEO of FTX's Bahamas subsidiary, agreed to a $1.55 billion forfeiture order and will likely face a maximum 5-year prison sentence. Salame's plea deal does not include a promise to testify against Sam Bankman-Fried, who goes on trial for fraud next month, increasing pressure on the FTX co-founder.

images.alt_text: A courtroom sketch from Aug 23 showing FTX cryptocurrency exchange founder Sam Bankman-Fried in prison clothing, with his attorney Christian Everdell in a Manhattan federal court, where he pleaded not guilty to seven criminal charges.
Lawyers filed a motion for Sam Bankman-Fried (above) to be released from jail late on Friday night (Aug 25) with the US 2nd Circuit Court of Appeals.
Galaxy will help “stake” FTX’s crypto, a process where crypto is lent to validate blockchain transactions, earning interest in the process.
BlockFi, which is liquidating, has said litigation with FTX, Three Arrows and a few other crypto firms could affect the amount its customers are repaid by US$1 billion.
Prosecutors have accused Bankman-Fried of stealing billions of dollars from FTX customers to prop up a separate hedge fund, conduct risky trades, buy property and make political donations.

site_title: Singapore’s shares open lower on Friday; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 3.86 points or 0.1% to 3,222.73 on Friday, September 8, after global markets mostly finished lower overnight. Losers outnumbered gainers 60 to 42, with 54 million securities worth S$30.54 million changing hands. The most actively traded stocks were Seatrium and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, with Seatrium dropping 0.7% and Yangzijiang gaining 0.6%. This follows similar trends on Wall Street, where stocks finished mostly lower due to worries about higher interest rate policy.

images.alt_text: Singapore stocks close higher despite regional losses, STI gains 0.1%

site_title: New flaw in Apple devices led to spyware infection, researchers say
summary: Researchers at Citizen Lab found a newly discovered flaw in Apple devices that exploited to infect with NSO's Pegasus spyware, linked to an Israeli firm. The flaw allowed iPhones running the latest iOS version to be compromised without interaction from the victim. Apple issued new updates after investigating the flaws reported by Citizen Lab, urging consumers to update their devices. The Israeli firm NSO has been blacklisted by the US government for alleged abuses, including surveillance of government officials and journalists.

images.alt_text: If Beijing goes ahead, the unprecedented iPhone blockade might also affect several other US technology companies that rely on sales and production in China.

The Apple Store in Beijing. Apple enjoys widespread popularity in China, despite rising resentment of American efforts to contain the Asian country’s technology industry. The company’s iPhones are among the nation’s bestsellers and are common in both the government and private sector.
Google and other US tech giants have also faced investigations from US, British and EU regulators in recent years as authorities crack down on their business practices.
Prime Minister Narendra Modi has rolled out a mix of tariffs and incentives to lure companies to make in India.

site_title: ECB to pause hiking rates on Sept 14; economists split on one more: poll
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is expected to hold interest rates steady on September 14, according to a majority of economists polled by Reuters. However, nearly half of the economists predict one more rate hike this year to combat inflation, which remains above the ECB's 2% target at 5.3% in August. The decision hinges on incoming economic data and comes as the euro zone's economic activity slows, with a growing threat of recession.

images.alt_text: The ECB is due to decide in October whether to push ahead with a digital euro, which aims to tackle a shortage of European payment service providers.
ECB Governing Council member Francois Villeroy de Galhau is "convinced we are close or very close to the high point of interest rate".
ECB chief economist Philip Lane says slowing in goods and services gauges are welcome and that underlying pressures will keep weakening.
Lagarde and her colleagues are still waiting to weigh the ECB’s in-house economic forecasts, which are a key piece to the puzzle of rate decisions.

site_title: Federal Reserve’s Williams says monetary policy in good place, must be data dependent
summary: Federal Reserve Bank of New York President John Williams stated that US monetary policy is "in a good place" but will need to be data-dependent to decide on future interest rate actions. Williams noted that current policy is restrictive, having brought demand and supply into balance and eased inflation. He emphasized the need to continue monitoring data to ensure the policy is sufficient in shrinking labor market imbalances and bringing inflation back down.

site_title: Top global ports may be unusable by 2050 without more climate action: report
summary: Top global ports may become unusable by 2050 due to rising sea levels, with the world's 3,800 ports vulnerable to climate change. A report by Economist Impact found that ports like Shanghai, Houston, and Lazaro Cardenas could be inoperable with a 40cm rise in sea levels. To mitigate this, ports may need to invest in flood defense systems, and the shipping industry is actively cutting emissions by reducing fossil fuel consumption.

images.alt_text: The island’s Indigenous community of fewer than 2,000 souls scrapes by without potable water or sanitation.
The black-market shark fin trade is estimated to be worth US$500 million annually, and Panama has spearheaded international efforts to protect many endangered shark species.
The Iranian flagged vessel MT Arman 114 (left) is captured after being spotted in Indonesia’s North Natuna Sea, carrying out a ship-to-ship oil transfer with the Cameroon-flagged MT S Tinos.

site_title: Goldman Sachs plans fresh round of job cuts for underperformers: FT
summary: Goldman Sachs is planning another round of job cuts, targeting underperforming employees, with estimates suggesting 1-5% of company-wide employees could lose their jobs. This round is expected to occur by late October and will primarily affect core investment banking and trading divisions. The move is part of Goldman's annual performance review process, which was reinstated after being halted during the pandemic. The bank reduced its headcount by 3,200 in the first quarter and 250 in May, its largest layoffs since the 2008 financial crisis.

images.alt_text: Ng, 51, was convicted in March 2022 on bribery and money laundering conspiracy charges.

Roger Ng, a former banker for Goldman Sachs, permanently prohibited from performing any regulated activity under the Securities and Futures Act, and from providing any financial advisory services under the Financial Advisers Act.

site_title: Biden heads for G20 to seize on absence of Xi, Putin
summary: US President Joe Biden is attending the G20 summit in India, aiming to bolster US influence in the bloc despite China and Russia's absence. He will also visit Vietnam on Sunday to upgrade relations with the former foe, amid a push to counter China's growing assertiveness. The G20 meeting is expected to focus on key issues like the Russia-Ukraine conflict and climate change, but deep splits may hinder agreements. Biden seeks to demonstrate Washington's capabilities as a partner on major global issues.

images.alt_text: Peter Navarro, an advisor to former US President Donald Trump, leaves after being found guilty of contempt of Congress at the E. Barrett Prettyman Courthouse in Washington, DC, Sept 7, 2023
China President Xi Jinping misses Asean summit and will also skip the G20 meeting over the weekend.
