site_title: Instacart prepares to set IPO price range as early as Monday
summary: Instacart is preparing to set an IPO price range as early as Monday, with plans to list on September 19 and start trading the following day. The company, founded in 2012, has been preparing for a public listing for years and has raised $2.74 billion as a startup. Instacart's growth has slowed since the pandemic, forcing the company to slash its internal valuation three times last year. The IPO could further energize the market, following Arm Holdings' upcoming listing.

images.alt_text: Instacart sees itself clearly as a grocery technology company and suggests there is plenty of room for growth.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Del Monte, mm2 Asia, USP Group, Enviro-Hub
summary: Del Monte Pacific narrowed its net loss to $13.1 million for the first fiscal quarter, and expects to achieve a net profit for the remainder of FY2024. mm2 Asia subscribed to HK$19 million worth of bonds, increasing its shares by 2.6%. USP Group faces pressure from minority shareholders to overhaul its board of directors. Enviro-Hub's former general manager resigned after being interviewed by the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Del Monte Gold pineapples rest in crates at Specialty Produce's warehouse in San Diego, California, U.S. on Friday, Nov. 1, 2013

site_title: mm2 Asia invests HK$19 million in Unipact to expand concert business in Asia
summary: mm2 Asia, a Singapore-based entertainment group, has invested HK$19 million (S$3.3 million) in Unipact, a Hong Kong concert organiser, to expand its live entertainment presence in Asia. The investment allows mm2 Asia's wholly owned subsidiary mmLive to acquire 5% of Unipact shares, with the bonds bearing a 3% annual interest rate. The move aims to integrate resources and grow the group's market presence in the region.

images.alt_text: Mia Pei
Customers at Parkway Parade shopping centre on 15 March 2022.
mm2 Asia proposes rights issue at 4.7 Singapore cents a share to raise S$52.2m
mm2 Asia's bet on cinemas may be a long shot

site_title: Europe: Shares fall for sixth day as economic slowdown, rate concerns bite
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index fell 0.6% on Wednesday, marking its sixth consecutive loss, amid concerns over slowing global growth and rising bond yields. German industrial orders declined more than expected in July, further fueling economic slowdown worries. The decline in European stocks follows a similar trend in the US, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.6 per cent lower at 34,443.19 on Wednesday.

site_title: Digital euro package should be focus of next EU Commission: McGuinness
summary: European Union's financial services chief Mairead McGuinness advises against rushing a digital euro draft law ahead of European elections in June, suggesting a "quiet and slow" examination. The European Central Bank (ECB) will decide on issuing a digital euro, which aims to address a shortage of European payment service providers. The draft law's proposal was made in June, but McGuinness emphasizes the need for a cautious approach to avoid disrupting the legislative process.

images.alt_text: Digital euro enthusiasts say it will complement cash and ensure the ECB does not leave a gap that could be filled by private, usually non-European, players and other central banks.

site_title: James Kuffner exits as CEO of Toyota’s technology unit
summary: James Kuffner, 52, is leaving his post as CEO of Toyota's automotive-technology unit Woven by Toyota, effective immediately. He will be replaced by Hajime Kumabe, who previously served as CEO of J-QuAD Dynamics Inc. The move comes as Toyota aims to rapidly expand electric vehicle production in the coming years, a goal announced by new CEO Koji Sato in May. Kuffner's departure follows a broader management shake-up at Toyota, with Sato appointing Hiroki Nakajima as chief technology officer.

site_title: Japan launches ‘Moon Sniper’ mission
summary: Japan successfully launched its "Moon Sniper" mission, a rocket carrying a moon lander, on September 7, 2023, from Tanegashima Space Centre. The mission aims to land within 100m of a specific target on the lunar surface, a feat previously unaccomplished. The Smart Lander for Investigating Moon (SLIM) is designed to achieve precise landing, paving the way for future lunar missions. The launch follows India's recent lunar triumph and marks Japan's efforts to bounce back from past failures.

images.alt_text: Musk paid back the US$1 billion with interest to SpaceX in November.

site_title: Developing policies to upkeep good corporate governance, Singapore Corporate Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: The 19th Singapore Corporate Awards honored outstanding companies and leaders in the country. Winners included DBS Vickers, OCBC Bank, and Singtel. DBS Vickers took home the top award for Company of the Year. The awards recognized excellence in various categories such as leadership, innovation, and sustainability. The event showcased the achievements of Singaporean businesses and their leaders. The awards ceremony highlighted the country's thriving corporate landscape and the impact of its companies on the global economy. Winners were selected through a rigorous evaluation process by a panel of industry experts and judges.

site_title: Blackstone’s flagship private credit fund lands US$2.4 billion
summary: Blackstone's flagship private credit fund, BCRED, has attracted US$2.4 billion in capital, a 30% increase from the prior quarter, marking a rebound in fundraising for private credit strategies. The fund's annualized distribution yield is 10.6% based on net asset value. This surge in capital inflows, coupled with 34 new funds raising US$71.2 billion in the second quarter, highlights a broad rebound for private credit strategies, with 45% of investors expecting to boost their allocation to private credit next year.

images.alt_text: This follows a sale in May of about US$3.4 billion shares in the bourse operator as the investor group seeks to offload its stake in LSEG.
Shares of Blackstone, the world’s largest alternative asset manager, were up 4.1 per cent in after hours trading while Airbnb’s rallied about 4 per cent.
Blackstone had bought Bellagio from MGM for US$4.3 billion in 2019.

site_title: The world’s safest airline is crashing its brand
summary: Qantas, the world's safest airline, is embroiled in a scandal after its CEO, Alan Joyce, departed amid allegations of selling seats on cancelled flights. The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission found Qantas continued to advertise over 8,000 cancelled flights for an average of two weeks, despite service being scrapped. Joyce's departure comes as Qantas faces a duopoly with Virgin Australia, and anti-monopoly allegations will likely intensify. New CEO Vanessa Hudson will face inquiries, lawsuits, and a damaged brand, making it challenging for her to restore customer trust.

images.alt_text: Plagued by a series of controversies, Qantas Airways CEO Alan Joyce has brought forward his retirement by two months.
The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission alleged that Qantas kept selling tickets for an average of 16 days after it had cancelled flights for reasons often within its control.

The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission said in a court filing that Qantas broke consumer law when it sold tickets to more than 8,000 flights between May and July 2022 without disclosing they had been cancelled.
Global airline companies have been struggling hard to cut down on emissions and are looking for alternatives to traditional jet kerosene fuels.

site_title: Brazil judge throws out evidence in Odebrecht scandal
summary: A Brazilian Supreme Court judge has excluded all evidence obtained through plea deals with Odebrecht executives in the "Car Wash" corruption probe, a major blow to the investigation. The probe, which began in 2014, led to the downfall of powerful politicians and executives, including former President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, who was jailed in 2018 but released after his convictions were annulled. The ruling marks the latest unraveling of the investigation, which remains ongoing.

images.alt_text: South African President Cyril Ramaphosa, currently hosting a summit of Brics leaders, announces on Thursday (Aug 24) that new candidates will be admitted as members on Jan 1, 2024.
Lula has enjoyed much international goodwill since returning to the presidency, but only because his predecessor was so thuggish and anti-democratic.
Petrobras adjusts kerosene prices on a monthly basis.

site_title: Ministers Shanmugam, Vivian seek to serve defamation papers on Lee Hsien Yang via Facebook
summary: Singapore Cabinet ministers K Shanmugam and Vivian Balakrishnan have applied to serve defamation papers on Lee Hsien Yang via Facebook Messenger, as they cannot be reached in person in Britain. The ministers are suing Lee over comments made on his Facebook page regarding the rental of state-owned bungalows in Ridout Road, claiming the allegations are false and defamatory. They are seeking damages and an injunction, with the court documents stating that substituted service through Facebook Messenger is a practical method.

images.alt_text: After the two ministers sent him lawyers’ letters, Lee said on Facebook on July 29 that he was simply stating the facts.
While the potential defamation suit can be commenced in Britain, this is unlikely to happen as Singapore may be regarded as the just and convenient forum, say lawyers.
Mr Lee Hsien Yang said in a Facebook post on July 29 that he was simply stating the facts.
Lee Hsien Yang (left) has been sent lawyers' letters by ministers K Shanmugam and Vivian Balakrishnan over allegations made regarding the Ridout Road properties.

site_title: Honorary Oscars gala postponed until January amid strikes
summary: The Governors Awards gala, which honors lifetime achievements with honorary Oscars, has been postponed from November to January due to the ongoing actors' and writers' strikes in Hollywood. The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences made the decision without explanation, and the event may be affected as honorees, including US comic Mel Brooks and actress Angela Bassett, are unlikely to attend. The strikes, which began in May, are seeking better pay and guarantees that artificial intelligence won't replace jobs.

images.alt_text: Japanese director Ryusuke Hamaguchi arrives for the screening of 'Aku wa sonzai shinai (Evil Does Not Exist)' during the 80th annual Venice International Film Festival, in Venice, Italy, on Sep 4.

(FILES) An Emmy statue is seen ahead of the 74th Emmy Awards at the Microsoft Theater in Los Angeles, California, on September 12, 2022. Can any TV show topple "Succession" at the Emmys? Will Amazon's lavish "Lord of the Rings" rule them all? And, with ongoing Hollywood strikes, will television's finest even be honored this year?
Nominations for television's equivalent of the Oscars will be announced in a live-streamed ceremony Wednesday July 12, starting at 8:30 am Pacific time (1530 GMT), after which final-round voting begins for the 75th Emmy Awards, tentatively set for September 18. (Photo by Robyn BECK / AFP)
If Hollywood actors join the ongoing writers' strike, A-list stars will not be able to promote big releases such as Oppenheimer, due to have its US premiere in New York next week.

site_title: Gold hovers near one-week low as dollar firms after US data
summary: Gold prices hovered near a one-week low, falling 0.1% to US$1,942.20, after the US dollar strengthened following data showing the US services sector unexpectedly gained steam in August. This data led to a rise in the benchmark US Treasury yield and a six-month high for the dollar.

images.alt_text: US gold futures fell 0.1 per cent to US$1,949.80.

site_title: Saudi Arabia raises oil prices to Asia for fourth month in a row
summary: Saudi Arabia raised oil prices for Asia and the US for the fourth consecutive month, with prices increasing by 10 US cents to $3.60 a barrel and 20 US cents to a record high for US-bound supplies. This move follows the kingdom and Russia's efforts to tighten the oil market. Customers in Europe have had to scramble for alternative sweet or low-sulphur oil. The price hike is the highest since December, but lower than expected.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Saudi Aramco sign is pictured at an oil facility in Abqaiq, Saudi Arabia, October 12, 2019. REUTERS/Maxim Shemetov//File Photo
FILE PHOTO: A Saudi Aramco sign is pictured at an oil facility in Abqaiq, Saudi Arabia, October 12, 2019. REUTERS/Maxim Shemetov//File Photo

site_title: Bankrupt Genesis sues DCG over US$620 million of unpaid loans
summary: Genesis Global Holdco, a bankrupt cryptocurrency lender, sued its parent Digital Currency Group (DCG) for $620 million in unpaid loans. Despite ongoing settlement talks, Genesis claims the loans matured in May and includes accrued interest and late fees. A proposed restructuring deal could result in unsecured creditors recovering up to 90% of their debt. Genesis has agreed to stay the lawsuit to document the deal in principle with DCG and the UCC. DCG will begin repaying the loans after a standstill agreement is filed with the bankruptcy court.

images.alt_text: Kroll warns customers of Genesis, FTX and BlockFi about potential phishing scams that could seek unauthorised access to their crypto wallets.

Genesis lawyer Sean O’Neal said on Friday (Apr 28) that the crypto lender has agreed to a 30-day mediation period including its committee of unsecured creditors, which has opposed the proposed restructuring deal.

site_title: WeWork to renegotiate nearly all leases, exit ‘unfit’ sites
summary: WeWork is renegotiating nearly all of its leases with landlords, planning to exit "unfit and underperforming" locations, and will remain in the majority of its buildings and markets. The company's business has struggled due to the shift to remote work, and a substantial doubt about its ability to stay in business was recently disclosed. WeWork aims to cut rental costs, negotiate more favorable leases, boost revenue, and raise money over the next year to stabilize its financial situation.

site_title: Biden’s son to be charged in gun case this month: prosecutor
summary: Hunter Biden, the son of US President Joe Biden, will be charged with a federal firearm offense before September 29, according to Special Counsel David Weiss. The charges stem from Biden's failure to file tax returns and keeping a handgun despite a serious drug problem. A plea deal that had been reached in July collapsed, leading to the new charges. If convicted, Biden could face up to 10 years in prison.

images.alt_text: The appeal of ‘Trumpism’ remains strong with key US groups, evidenced by polls of Republican party identifiers in 2023.
Hunter Biden did not pay taxes on more than US$1.5 million in income in 2017 and 2018 despite owing more than US$100,000, prosecutors allege.
Hunter Biden, 53, for years has been the focus of unrelenting attacks by Trump and his Republican allies who have accused him of wrongdoing relating to Ukraine and China, among other matters.

Oversight Committee Chair James Comer said Romanian funds were part of more than US$10 million that Hunter Biden (pictured), his family and business associates had received from deals with foreigners in China, Ukraine, and elsewhere while Joe Biden was vice-president from 2009 to 2017.

site_title: US lawmaker calls for ban on all tech exports to Huawei, SMIC after chip breakthrough
summary: US Representative Mike Gallagher calls for a ban on all tech exports to Huawei and SMIC following the discovery of new chips in Huawei phones that may violate trade restrictions. The chips, found in the Mate 60 Pro, likely require US technology and could have been produced with a US technology breakthrough, violating the Foreign Direct Product Rule. Gallagher urges the Commerce Department to cut off US technology exports to both companies to protect national security.

images.alt_text: Some analysts suggest the possibility that Huawei may have acquired the technology and equipment from SMIC to produce the chip, rather than collaborating on its development.
The Mate 60 Pro, which went on sale this week, fanned patriotic fervour as it was seen to represent China’s ability to get around US sanctions.

site_title: China's 'father of EVs' urges cooperation to scale up
summary: China's 'father of EVs,' Wan Gang, emphasizes the need for international cooperation and standardization to scale up electric vehicles. He highlights the importance of efficient batteries, EV architectures, and intelligent driving systems. Wan also praises the role of hybrid and fuel cell vehicles powered by hydrogen in reducing emissions, particularly for commercial vehicles. The chairman of China's World New Energy Vehicle Congress called for a collaborative approach to promote the entire supply chain of low-carbon development.

images.alt_text: Wan Gang, chairman of the World New Energy Vehicle Congress (WNEVC), speaks during the New World Energy Vehicle Congress (WNEVC) on day two of the Munich Motor Show (IAA) in Munich, Germany, on Wednesday, Sept. 6, 2023. Europe's automakers are showing off their latest battery-powered vehicles at the IAA Mobility car show this week as they try to challenge Tesla Inc. and fend off growing competition from China. Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg

German Chancellor Olaf Scholz announces plans for Germany to lead Europe by implementing a law mandating 80 per cent of service stations to offer fast-charging options of at least 150 kilowatts for electric cars.
Led by BYD, Chinese carmakers will almost double their share of the auto market to 33 per cent by the end of the decade, according to UBS analysts.

The OJK would consider to expand the green label to loans for coal-fired power plants used by industries that make products considered sustainable, such as batteries for electric vehicles, says OJK chief Mahendra.

“For us, to survive, we have to achieve at least 500,000 to 1 million units of annual sales globally. It would take at least two to three years for us to achieve that,”  says .Leapmotor's CEO Zhu Jiangming.
Mercedes-Benz's Vision One-Eleven electric car at the International Motor Show (IAA) in Munich on Monday (Sep 4).

Opel's president for design Mark Adams next to an Opel experimental car at the International Motor Show (IAA) in Munich. China's offerings are biting on the heels of European carmakers: 8 per cent of new EVs sold in Europe so far this year were Chinese brands, up from 6 per cent last year and 4 per cent in 2021.

site_title: LSEG investors Thomson Reuters, Blackstone to sell £2.3 billion shares in bourse operator
summary: Investors including Blackstone and Thomson Reuters plan to sell approximately 28.3 million shares worth £2.3 billion in the London Stock Exchange Group (LSEG). The sale is part of a larger effort to offload the group's stake, with the consortium aiming to sell a total of 43.1 million shares. LSEG also plans to buy back £750 million worth of limited-voting ordinary shares. The consortium holds an 18.7% economic interest and 11.3% voting interest in the company, with remaining shares locked up for 180 days.

images.alt_text: Blockchain is a digital ledger which records and verifies transactions.

A logo outside the London Stock Exchange Group Plc's offices in London, UK, on Friday, Aug. 12, 2022. London Stock Exchange Plc Chief Executive Officer Julia Hoggett said the IPO pipeline in London remains robust, despite a slowdown this year that’s been felt at many exchanges globally. Photographer: Jose Sarmento Matos/Bloomberg

site_title: IPO for Vietnam’s VNG may be tough sell in US
summary: Vietnam's VNG Corporation has filed for a Nasdaq listing, but its IPO may be a tough sell due to a unique corporate structure, sluggish growth, and fintech losses. The company's gaming business is not as efficient as Sea's Garena, and its fintech unit, ZaloPay, has not achieved widespread adoption in Vietnam. Revenue growth has slowed, with a 23% decline in communications and media revenue in the first half of 2023. VNG's cash position appears strong, but its liabilities bear watching. The company's unusual listing structure, designed to comply with Vietnamese laws, has raised concerns about its compliance with US regulations.

images.alt_text: While the IPO market could recover, there is a hitch: the public markets may not be able to match the valuations that these companies are seeking, writes Garage correspondent Sharanya Pillai.
VNG, which plans to offer almost 22 million shares in the IPO, will set a proposed price range in a later filing with the US Securities and Exchange Commission.

site_title: Chinese auto chipmaker raises over US$1.8 billion as Beijing prepares new chip fund
summary: Chinese auto chipmaker GTA Semiconductor raised over $1.8 billion in funding, mostly from state funds, as Beijing prepares to launch a new $40 billion state-backed investment fund for the semiconductor sector. This move signals Beijing's continued investment in domestic chip manufacturing. GTA Semiconductor has received over $2.7 billion in state funds in less than two years, highlighting the government's commitment to supporting the industry.

images.alt_text: China has in recent years grown more concerned over data security and has rolled out new laws and compliance requirements for companies.
The property sector accounts for roughly a quarter of the world’s second-largest economy

site_title: China's Xpeng says German carmakers ready to tackle crisis as EV race hots up
summary: Chinese electric vehicle (EV) maker Xpeng's president, Brian Gu, stated that German carmakers are determined to address their crisis by adopting new technologies and strategies. As Chinese companies like Xpeng, BYD, and Leapmotor expand into European markets, they are putting pressure on European carmakers to increase production of EVs. Despite European carmakers' efforts, Chinese companies still face challenges such as stereotypes and high import costs. Gu plans for Xpeng to expand into more European markets, including Germany, Britain, and France in 2024.

images.alt_text: China has made pledges recently to stoke auto demand as part of a broader push to boost the economy, including a 10-step plan to increase car purchases, particularly NEVs.

site_title: Canada posts smaller-than-expected trade deficit in July
summary: Canada's trade deficit narrowed to C$987 million in July, beating forecasts, as a 13-day dock workers strike in British Columbia disrupted port operations. Imports declined 5.4% due to lower gold prices and port-related declines, while exports rose 0.7% due to increased exports of canola and transportation equipment. The smaller-than-expected deficit is a relief for policymakers, but trade disruptions may continue to impact trade in the coming months as freight backlogs remain.

images.alt_text: Street scene in Montreal. Canada booked broad declines in exports in June, with metal and non-metallic mineral products being the largest drag.

site_title: Australian billionaire Cannon-Brookes takes a fresh swing to sell solar to Singapore
summary: Australian billionaire Mike Cannon-Brookes has completed the purchase of Sun Cable and is renewing his bid to sell solar power to Singapore. The flagship project, Australia-Asia Power Link (AAPowerLink), aims to deliver 6 GW of renewable energy in multiple stages, with the first stage generating 900 MW in Australia and over 1.75 GW in Singapore. Cannon-Brookes is submitting a plan to Singapore's Energy Market Authority (EMA) to obtain an energy import conditional licence, with the project's viability being assessed by the EMA. The project's completion is seen as crucial for Singapore's goal of meeting its 4 GW of low-carbon electricity target by 2035.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
The proposal for Singapore to draw critical energy supply from a source some 4,200 KM away through an undersea cable was deemed a hard sell from the get-go by market watchers.
While it would be a sweet victory for climate goals to see this radical project take fruition, Sun Cable’s fate has been eclipsed by shareholder spat
Cannon-Brookes’s Grok Ventures office aims to progress plans for a first stage project to deliver 900 megawatts of clean electricity to Darwin and to export 1.8 gigawatts to Singapore
Sun Cable's Australia-Asia PowerLink project would have been the longest undersea high voltage direct current transmission cable in the world if it was completed today.

site_title: Two minority shareholders of USP Group seeking to convene EGM for board overhaul
summary: Two minority shareholders of USP Group, Melvin Tan and Lim Shi Wei, have filed a requisition notice to convene an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) for a complete overhaul of the company's board of directors. The notice seeks to remove five directors, including the CEO and chairman, and appoint four new directors. The move comes after a previous EGM was invalidated due to a judicial commissioner's ruling on the requisition notice. USP has stated that it is seeking legal advice on the notice and will update shareholders as necessary.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
USP Group said it received the Acra letter on April 28, and a representative of the company will be required to appear at the State Courts for a mention on May 24.
business, conference room, boardroom
Judicial Commissioner Goh Yihan declared the requisition notice for USP Group's upcoming EGM invalid, as the requisitioning shareholders were not deemed as “members” of USP under the Companies Act.
Minority shareholders of watch-listed USP Group are looking to take the company out of the watchlist by gaining control of its board and injecting it with new projects.

While the requisition of a general meeting may be unwelcomed, boards should consider the merits of the proposals from the perspective of the issuer and its shareholders as a whole, said Tan Boon Gin, CEO of SGX RegCo.

If USP Group does not appoint auditors for an audit of its most recent financial year, release the statements, and either move to exit the watch-list or seek an extension of its cure period, the SGX RegCo will direct it to delist.

site_title: US FCC chair says China’s Quectel, Fibocom may pose national security risks
summary: US FCC chairwoman Jessica Rosenworcel has asked government agencies to consider declaring Chinese companies Quectel and Fibocom Wireless pose unacceptable national security risks due to their production of cellular modules. This move comes after the FCC has taken steps to bar Chinese telecom companies from US networks. The companies' equipment would be subject to federal funds restrictions and FCC authorization, following similar actions taken against other Chinese telecom companies. The FCC's decision may lead to a ban on the use of these companies' products in US networks.

images.alt_text: Huawei was placed on a trade blacklist in May 2019 over national security concerns.

site_title: Delhi G20 – some key issues may be off-agenda
summary: The upcoming G20 summit in New Delhi may omit key issues, as leaders including China's Xi Jinping and Russia's Vladimir Putin will not attend. The summit's format typically results in a leaders' declaration on global economic issues, but disagreements have led to statements that omit pressing challenges, such as the climate crisis and Ukraine war's economic fallout. The G20 has historically addressed urgent issues, but the absence of key leaders may lead to a limited agenda, with other leaders striving to achieve consensus on remaining pressing issues.

images.alt_text: Li Qiang will first attend the Association of South-east Asian Nations gathering in Jakarta, Indonesia, for wide-ranging talks on trade, climate change and global security.

site_title: Oil settles up on expectations of US crude draws and tight supply
summary: Oil prices rose on Wednesday, with Brent crude futures settling 56 cents higher at US$90.60 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures up 85 cents to US$87.54. Traders anticipate further draws on US crude inventory following extended production cuts in Saudi Arabia and Russia. US crude inventories are projected to fall by 5.5 million barrels in the week ending Sept 1, amid concerns about tight supply and potential price rises during US refinery maintenance.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures rose by US$1.04, or 1.2 per cent, to settle at US$90.04 a barrel, closing above the US$90 mark for the first time since Nov 16, 2022.

site_title: Shipping could face shortage of carbon-neutral fuel by 2030, DNV says
summary: Shipping industry may face shortage of carbon-neutral fuel by 2030, according to Norwegian ship certifier DNV. The industry has been testing cleaner fuel options like ammonia and methanol, and trialing wind sails. However, expected shortfall in carbon-neutral fuel availability suggests the need for alternative solutions such as onboard carbon capture and nuclear options.

images.alt_text: Tel Aviv-based Orca AI claims to be the creator of the “world’s first-of-its-kind” automated situational awareness platform to maximise voyage safety and operational efficiency for ships and fleets.
EnterpriseSG has attracted some 400 global traders to anchor their key business activities in Singapore to buy, sell and market a diverse mix of commodities to other countries around the world.

The Port of Rotterdam plans to provide the north-western part of the continent with at least 4.6 million tonnes of hydrogen by the end of this decade, contributing to nearly a quarter of the overall EU goal.

site_title: US: Stocks fall on Wednesday, extending pullback
summary: US stocks fell on Wednesday, extending a pullback, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.6% at 34,443.19. Large tech companies like Apple and others declined, weighing on the broader market. Despite a surprising increase in services sector activity and a "modest" US growth description from the Federal Reserve's "beige book," the market struggled to gain traction due to a lack of positive catalysts. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also declined, with Apple shares falling 3.6% following a report that China barred its smartphones in central government agencies.

images.alt_text: SEC's plan to fund the audit-trail system to track billions of daily equities and options trades faces stiff opposition from industry trade groups and heavyweight players.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average falls 30.29 points, or 0.09 per cent, at the open to 34,611.68.

site_title: Bank of Canada holds rates at 5%, sees excess demand easing
summary: The Bank of Canada held interest rates steady at 5% for the third time this tightening cycle, citing easing excess demand and a weakening economy. Policymakers remain concerned about underlying inflationary pressures, and are prepared to increase rates further if needed. The decision, led by Governor Tiff Macklem, reverses earlier gains for the Canadian dollar and pushes benchmark Canada two-year yield to 4.664%. The next decision is due on October 25.

images.alt_text: Exports and imports in July were impacted by a 13-day dock workers strike in British Columbia that disrupted operations at two of Canada’s three busiest ports.
Statistics Canada reports that the modest increase in June retail is driven by rises at motor vehicle and parts dealers, along with petrol stations and fuel vendors.
In July, grocery prices rise by 8.5 per cent, marking the slowest pace in over a year, according to Statscan.
Street scene in Montreal. Canada booked broad declines in exports in June, with metal and non-metallic mineral products being the largest drag.
Bank of Canada Governor Tiff Macklem takes part in a news conference after announcing an interest rate decision in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada April 12, 2023. REUTERS/Blair Gable

site_title: Turkey’s Erdogan backs high interest rates in surprise move
summary: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan announced a surprise shift in stance, backing high interest rates to slow inflation. This move reverses his previous stance as a self-proclaimed enemy of high interest rates. Erdogan stated that his administration will lower inflation to single digits with monetary tightening. The Turkish lira strengthened 0.1% after his speech, trading at 26.78 per dollar. The government also revised down its economic growth targets, citing a 65% year-end inflation projection.

images.alt_text: By leveraging Turkey’s geopolitical position, Erdogan was able to sustain his spending spree until Turks cast their ballots. But now that he has won another term, an economic reckoning looms.

site_title: GameStop revenue beats estimates on stronger software sales
summary: GameStop reported second-quarter sales of $1.16 billion, beating analyst estimates of $1.14 billion. The company reported a loss of 3 cents per share, excluding certain items, ahead of expectations. CEO Matt Furlong was ousted in June, and Ryan Cohen, billionaire founder of Chewy, took over as chairman. Cohen owns 12% of the company, his largest stake. This marks GameStop's first quarterly earnings report since Cohen's appointment.

images.alt_text: GameStop has struggled to adapt to the increasing share of game sales conducted online and away from stores.
The company has also been shoring up its online sales capabilities in a bid to beef up its digital presence.

site_title: Companies must push for greater transparency on intangible assets
summary: Singapore has launched the Intangibles Disclosure Framework (IDF), a new framework to provide guidance on identifying and communicating the value of intangible assets. The framework, developed by industry experts, aims to increase transparency and understanding of intangible assets, which make up over 90% of the value of S&P 500 companies. The IDF comprises four pillars: strategy, identification, measurement, and management, and is voluntary at launch, but may become mandatory in the future as the knowledge economy grows. The framework aims to give companies more bargaining power and unlock financing opportunities, and is seen as a step forward in addressing the opacity surrounding intangible assets.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
A growing part of companies’ value resides in their IA, including IP.
Improving intangible asset disclosures can lead to better investment decisions, said Second Minister for Finance Indranee Rajah.

site_title: Digitalisation not a disruption for banks; leverage workforce longevity: UOB executives
summary: UOB executives emphasize digitalisation is not a disruption for banks, but a tool for sustainability and growth. The bank supports businesses in Asean through various initiatives, including foreign direct investment advisory services, helping SMEs expand overseas, and creating inclusive and sustainable investments. UOB's managing director So Lay Hua highlights digitalisation's benefits, including a single platform for visibility of all flows. The bank also prioritizes sustainability through green trade financing and green liabilities, as well as leveraging the older workforce through mentoring and coaching. UOB aims to create meaningful jobs and support economic development in Asean.

images.alt_text: Goh Ruoxue
Trade and Industry Minister Gan Kim Yong expressed confidence in the long-term growth potential of South-east Asia at an event on Thursday.

site_title: India’s TCS expands partnership with Britain’s JLR in over £800 million deal
summary: Tata Consultancy Services (TCS) has expanded its partnership with Jaguar Land Rover (JLR) in a £800 million deal over five years. TCS will deliver services including application development, cloud migration, cybersecurity, and data services. This is part of a longstanding partnership between the two companies, dating back to 2012. The deal follows recent multi-million and billion-dollar contract signings by top Indian IT companies, amid concerns of client spending cuts in the US and European markets.

site_title: US services sector picked up in August, along with prices
summary: The US services sector unexpectedly grew in August, with the Institute for Supply Management's non-manufacturing PMI rising to 54.5, the highest reading since February. This indicates growth in the services industry, which accounts for over two-thirds of the economy. Despite elevated inflation pressures, Federal Reserve officials welcome the signs of cooling, which may lead to a steady policy rate at its upcoming meeting. However, the services sector remains key to bringing inflation down to the 2% target, and policymakers view the sector as crucial in achieving this goal.

images.alt_text: The shortfall in goods and services trade grows to US$65 billion from a revised US$63.7 billion in the prior month, Commerce Department data shows.
High mortgage rates have pushed homeownership further out of reach for many Americans.
New orders for factory goods fall by 2.1 per cent in July after rising by 2.3 per cent in June, the US government says.
FILE PHOTO: An employee works on an assembly line at startup Rivian Automotive's electric vehicle factory in Normal, Illinois, U.S. April 11, 2022. REUTERS/Kamil Krzaczynski/File Photo

US-based employers announced 75,151 job cuts in August. A significant portion of the announced layoffs arose from the approximately 30,000 workers reported to have lost their jobs after Yellow, one of the country’s largest trucking companies, filed for bankruptcy.

Times Square, New York City. Consumer spending, which accounts for more than two-thirds of US economic activity, went up by 0.8 per cent in July, the Commerce Department reported on Thursday (Aug 31).

Representative Sara McKethan, left, hands a list of employment descriptions to a job seeker during the Choice Career Fair in San Antonio, Texas, U.S., on Thursday, April 16, 2015. Fewer than 300,000 American workers filed applications for unemployment benefits for the sixth consecutive week, pointing to labor-market strength even as hiring cooled last month. Photographer: Matthew Busch/Bloomberg *** Local Caption *** Sara McKethan

site_title: Domestic-driven stocks in spotlight in Malaysia as new macro blueprints take shape
summary: Malaysia's domestic-driven stocks are gaining attention amid the government's new macro blueprints, which aim to boost the economy. Despite the FBM KLCI 30 constituents' 11% lower earnings in the second quarter, analysts see opportunities to invest in domestic-focused sectors such as banks, construction, and real estate. The government's new blueprints, including the National Energy Transition Roadmap and the New Industrial Master Plan 2030, are expected to enhance investors' confidence in the country. Analysts predict a higher FBM KLCI target range of 1,600-1,700 points, driven by positive growth tailwinds and lower political risk premiums.

images.alt_text: Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim (sixth from left) unveiled the New Industrial Master Plan with other ministers on Sep 1, 2023.
Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim said there is a strong interest  for international collaboration that will provide additional avenues to decarbonise.

site_title: Home stretch in Singapore’s leadership succession
summary: Singapore is in the final stages of leadership renewal, with Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong affirming his confidence in Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong and the fourth-generation (4G) leaders. Lee reiterated his commitment to a clean and effective government, vowing to do his utmost to keep the system free from corruption. The handover of power is expected to occur before the next general election, which must be held by November 2025, and Lee may step down as prime minister before then, continuing as the People's Action Party's secretary-general.

images.alt_text: Revitalising the Singapore spirit one policy at a time
PM Lee Hsien Loong speaking at the National Day Rally 2023.

Tharman Shanmugaratnam's resounding victory suggests that voters did indeed take a non-partisan view – which makes it hard to make any assumptions about sentiment ahead of the upcoming general elections.

site_title: China Premier Li Qiang completes trial run of Indonesia's first high-speed rail
summary: China Premier Li Qiang completed a trial run of Indonesia's 142-kilometre high-speed rail, a $7.3 billion Beijing-funded project. The trial run, which included Li and Indonesian Minister Luhut Pandjaitan, tested a 41-kilometre section of the track. The railway, part of China's Belt and Road Initiative, was originally set for 2019 completion but is now scheduled for a commercial launch on October 1.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An Electric Multiple Unit high-speed train for a rail link project part of China's Belt and Road Initiative is parked at Tegalluar train depot in Bandung, West Java province, Indonesia, October 13, 2022. REUTERS/Yuddy Cahya Budiman/File Photo

site_title: Asean-5 to be hit by rising rice prices, the Philippines to be worst hit: OCBC
summary: The Philippines is expected to be the hardest-hit by rising rice prices, according to OCBC Bank senior economist Lavanya Venkateswaran. The country's largest rice-trade deficit and high rice import costs will exacerbate inflationary pressures, with rice accounting for 8.9% of the Philippines' CPI basket. Other Asean-5 economies, including Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore, and Thailand, will also be affected, with Indonesia and Malaysia expected to see some impact due to their net rice importer status.

images.alt_text: India, which accounts for 40 per cent of world rice exports, sells the staple to more than 150 countries, including a few poor and vulnerable countries in Africa and Asia.
Workers unload sacks of rice imported from Thailand from a cargo ship at Malahayati Port in Krueng Raya, Indonesia's Aceh province, on June 22, 2023. (Photo by CHAIDEER MAHYUDDIN / AFP)
The threat to rice comes as shipment curbs by top exporter India and extreme weather tighten supplies globally, with prices in Asia jumping near to the highest level in almost 15 years.

Rice for sale at a market in Mandaluyong, the Philippines, on Monday, Sept. 5, 2022. Philippines inflation rate rose 6.3% from a year earlier in August, the Philippine Statistics Authority said in a statement on its website. Photographer: Iya Forbes/Bloomberg

site_title: Visiting Champagne country
summary: Champagne lovers can immerse themselves in the region's culture and wine-making process by visiting Champagne, France. The area offers picturesque countryside, art, and architecture, in addition to champagne houses. Reims, Epernay, Cote de Blancs, and Vallee de la Marne are just a few of the regions to explore.

site_title: US SEC set to impose new fees on brokers to fund audit-trail system
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) plans to impose new fees on brokers to fund its audit-trail system, which tracks billions of daily equities and options trades. The fees, which would vary depending on the type of trade, are based on share volumes and are expected to be borne mainly by brokers and asset managers, with exchanges also contributing. Industry groups, including the Securities Industry and Financial Markets Association, oppose the plan, citing concerns over the fees' impact on investment returns and the system's estimated $500 million cost.

images.alt_text: The company says the agency is “rushing to appeal” what it claims is a legal question that applies to every case involving digital assets while “the factual and legal procedural postures of other SEC enforcement actions are different.”
FThe industry is arguing that the SEC lacks authority for the rule changes.
Under the SEC’s new order, market participants were asked to submit a new plan that will be up for public comment.

site_title: Fewer mortgage actions in courts as cooling measures, rising rates see more prudent borrowing
summary: Singapore households are managing household debt well, with the number of mortgage actions filed in court more than halving in the past five years. Despite rising mortgage rates, households' net worth continued to rise, with a five-year low in mortgage actions last year. This trend suggests that Singapore households are becoming more prudent in their borrowing, with data showing a decrease in mortgage actions and an increase in household net worth.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
Residential properties accounted for a smaller share of the pie in Q2, with growth in its asset values slowing down to 9.1 per cent, from 11.7 per cent last quarter.
Potential flat buyers will have to think long and hard about how much they prize these locations versus any investment returns that they could make.
Investors take on market volatility as they expect to be rewarded over the long term with higher returns. There are ways to maximise the market returns.

site_title: Providing sustainable solutions to Vietnam’s prawn farming and food security
summary: Singaporean biotech startup Forte Biotech has developed a patented disease surveillance kit for prawn farming, allowing farmers to detect diseases in their harvest within an hour. The kit, called Rapid, uses a portable diagnostic device and DNA sample extraction sticks, providing an accuracy rate of 90%. The company aims to break even by selling the test kits to at least 60 farms, with plans to expand its market in other countries and develop new prawn diseases. Forte has already secured funding from NUS, Touchstone Partners, and angel investors, and plans to raise an additional $1.5 million to $2 million in funding.

images.alt_text: A model of Airlios' new electric flying car on display at the Vietnam Motor Show in Ho Chi Minh City.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower on renewed inflation worries, economic data in focus
summary: US stocks opened lower on Wednesday, September 6, due to renewed concerns about sticky inflation and key economic data. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 30.29 points, or 0.09%, to 34,611.68. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined, with the S&P 500 opening 6.48 points lower, or 0.14%, at 4,490.35, and the Nasdaq Composite dropping 32.14 points, or 0.23%, to 13,988.81. Investors await the Federal Reserve's report on the US economy, which could influence interest rates.

site_title: How AI is joining the fight against superbugs
summary: Scientists are exploring new strategies to combat antibiotic-resistant bacteria, known as "superbugs," which have developed ingenious defense mechanisms like biofilms to evade attacks. The misuse and overuse of antibiotics have fueled the rise of superbugs, with no new classes of antibiotics discovered since the 1980s. Researchers are looking into alternative approaches, such as AI-powered methods, to tackle the growing threat of superbugs and prevent further evolution of these resistant microbes.

images.alt_text: Pharmacists at the Singapore General Hospital are working out the best combinations of antibiotics to fight off various drug-resistant bacteria. Formulation process step 5 of 5: bacteria shows up as spots on the petri dish. Scientists look for the dishes with the fewest amount of spots to learn which is the optimal combination of antibiotics.
Antibiotic-resistant superbugs killed 1.2 million in 2019: study
Ready to travel abroad again? Watch out for superbugs: study

site_title: Swiss chocolate maker Barry Callebaut announces 500 million Swiss franc investment plan
summary: Swiss chocolate maker Barry Callebaut announces a 500 million Swiss franc investment plan over the next two years as part of its BC Next Level strategy. The plan aims to reduce annual costs by 250 million francs through cost-cutting measures and improve the speed to market of its products. The company will overhaul its structure, increasing the number of regions from three to five and reducing its executive committee to six members. The investment plan is seen as a strong bet on new CEO Peter Feld, who took charge in April, and has been welcomed by Barry Callebaut's biggest shareholder, Jacobs Holding.

images.alt_text: According to Rabobank’s estimates for 2022, Indonesia, Malaysia and Singapore are major cocoa processing locations in the region.

The world’s biggest cocoa producer Ivory Coast is expected to see its upcoming harvest shrink by nearly a fifth from last year, and has suspended sales that bind farmers to delivering goods at specified times in the future.

site_title: Roku narrows core loss forecast, plans to trim 10% workforce
summary: Roku narrowed its adjusted operating loss forecast for the third quarter, raising its revenue forecast and sending shares up 8% in premarket trading. The company plans to trim 10% of its workforce and cut office space, aiming to drastically cut costs and turn a profit in 2024. Roku expects adjusted core loss in the range of $40 million to $20 million and total net revenue between $835 million and $875 million.

images.alt_text: Roku, which had about 3,600 full-time employees as of Dec 31, expects to incur charges of between US$30 million and US$35 million related to the restructuring.

site_title: US dollar steady near 6-month high on growth fears, weak yen draws warning
summary: The US dollar remains near a six-month high as investors seek safety amid concerns over global growth, with the yen strengthening to 147.34 per US dollar. Japan's top currency diplomat, Masato Kanda, warned of possible intervention to stem the yen's decline, which has hovered around the 145-per-US dollar level for weeks. Economic data from China and Europe has fueled fears of slowing global growth, supporting the US dollar's strength.

site_title: Music firm Universal announces streaming overhaul
summary: Universal, the world's largest music publisher, has partnered with French app Deezer to launch an "artist-centric" approach, giving more money to professional musicians at the expense of non-music streams. The deal aims to address the issue of artists not receiving fair compensation for streaming, with Deezer attributing a double boost to musicians who have at least 1,000 streams a month from unique listeners. The scheme will be rolled out in France by the end of the year, with the goal of supporting and rewarding artists across all stages of their careers.

images.alt_text: YouTube has signed up Universal Music as its first partner for the Incubator, and will work with artistes including Anitta, ABBA’s Björn Ulvaeus, and Max Ricther.

site_title: US trade deficit widened by less than expected in July
summary: The US trade deficit widened to $65 billion in July, less than the forecasted $68 billion, driven by a 1.6% increase in car and services exports. Imports rose 1.7% due to consumer goods and capital equipment, with retailers preparing for the holiday shopping season. Exports are down 3.5% from last year, constrained by overseas demand. The data will influence GDP estimates for the third quarter and may impact inflation-adjusted trade deficit, which widened to $88.4 billion in July.

site_title: Swiss financial regulator Finma CEO quits in wake of Credit Suisse collapse
summary: Switzerland's financial regulator Finma CEO Urban Angehrn is quitting at the end of September 2023, citing "high and permanent stress" in the role. The decision comes nearly six months after the regulator faced criticism for failing to prevent Credit Suisse's collapse. Angehrn's departure follows a string of scandals at Credit Suisse, which was eventually bought by UBS in a state-engineered rescue. Finma's Deputy CEO Birgit Rutishauser will act as interim CEO from October 1.

images.alt_text: UBS has already indicated that the results should include an exceptional accounting gain of nearly $35 billion due to the difference between the purchase price and the recognised net assets of Credit Suisse.
“It should be clear to all of us that we still have a lot of work ahead of us to realise the full potential value from this transaction,” according to UBS' memo to employees.
Only about 20 bankers will likely be spared the cuts that will impact Credit Suisse’s 100-people strong investment banking team based in the territory, the source says.
Switzerland’s decision in March to write down the bonds as part of a government-led rescue of Credit Suisse shocked investors in Japan.

site_title: India to offer US$452 million in incentives for battery storage
summary: India plans to offer $452 million in incentives to companies setting up battery storage projects, supporting the development of 4,000 megawatt hours of storage capacity by 2030-31. This is part of the country's goal to expand its renewable energy capacity to 500 gigawatts by 2030. The incentives will cover up to 40% of capital costs and include viability gap funding for critical infrastructure projects. This move aims to boost green energy capacity and enable the storage of energy from solar and wind power.

images.alt_text: Companies are on pace to install 4 gigawatts of panels on top of buildings in India this financial year ending March 31, nearly doubling the previous record.

site_title: Philippine airport project has three potential bidders: official
summary: The Philippine government has announced three potential bidders for a 170.6 billion pesos ($4.1 billion) airport modernization project, including India's GMR Group and a Manila consortium. The project aims to address chronic flight delays and improve facilities at the aging Ninoy Aquino International Airport. The government plans to hold roadshows in Singapore and Paris before opening bidding in December, with a 25-year concession period for the winning bidder. The project is part of the government's efforts to upgrade five airports in the country.

images.alt_text: Unlike the previous administration, which relied on foreign financing, President Marcos has said he prefers to tap private capital to bankroll his infrastructure ambitions.

site_title: US home purchase applications fall to lowest since 1995
summary: US home purchase applications have fallen to a 28-year low, with the Mortgage Bankers Association index decreasing 2.1% to 141.9 in the week ended Sep 1. High mortgage rates, near a 30-year high, have pushed homeownership further out of reach, driving housing affordability to its worst point in decades. Despite newly constructed homes filling some supply gaps, sustained reprieve for potential homeowners is unlikely until borrowing costs subside, and the Federal Reserve signals no immediate interest rate cuts.

images.alt_text: Houses in Meridian, Idaho. US house housing Photographer: Jeremy Erickson/Bloomberg
Public homebuilders on average have raised prices in about two-thirds of their communities, says analyst.
US Commerce Department says a surge in new home sales, rising by 4.4 per cent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 714,000 units in July.
MBA home mortgage application index drops 5 per cent this week, reaching its lowest point since April 1995.
Home resales, which account for a big chunk of US housing sales, fall 16.6 per cent on a year-on-year basis in July.

site_title: Hong Kong office woes mount as most tenants shun expansion
summary: Hong Kong's commercial real estate market faces challenges as vacant top-tier office space has more than doubled over the last three years, driven by companies downsizing operations. Most tenants, including financial institutions and manufacturers, plan to maintain or downsize their office space, with only the IT sector showing expansion plans. Landlords are advised to be flexible with rental levels to capture occupiers and manage costs in a competitive market.

site_title: Toronto home prices fall for third straight month in August
summary: Toronto home prices fell 3.1% in August, marking the third consecutive month of decline, due to higher borrowing costs and economic uncertainty. On a year-over-year basis, home sales dropped 5.2%, while the average home price edged up 0.3%. New listings increased 16.2% year-over-year. The Toronto Regional Real Estate Board expects volatility in the market until borrowing costs and economic conditions become more certain.

site_title: South Korea should maintain current monetary, fiscal policies, IMF says
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) advises South Korea to maintain current restrictive monetary and fiscal policies to address inflation and return to sustainable finances. The IMF recommends keeping interest rates above neutral and supporting monetary policy efforts to contain inflation. The prudent fiscal policy will help limit public debt and support economic fundamentals in the medium term. The IMF also notes a moderate increase in downside risk for Korea's growth, particularly in 2024, due to China's economic slowdown.

images.alt_text: The BOK started its post-pandemic monetary tightening cycle in August 2021.

site_title: China bans govt officials from using iPhone for work: WSJ
summary: China has ordered central government officials not to use iPhones and other foreign-branded devices for work or bring them into the office, citing concerns over data security. The ban was reportedly distributed through workplace chat groups or meetings, but its extent is unclear. The move comes ahead of an Apple event and may raise concerns among foreign companies operating in China amid escalating Sino-US tensions.

images.alt_text: Apple typically makes new iPhones available for preorder on the Friday after their unveiling and begins delivering them to customers and stores one-week later.
Profits for Apple’s third fiscal quarter were US$19.9 billion, up 2.3 per cent from the year-ago period. Revenues again declined, this time by 1.4 per cent to US$81.8 billion.

site_title: China July-Aug economic losses from disasters double from first six months
summary: China's direct economic losses from natural disasters in July-August reached 75.37 billion yuan, nearly doubling the losses in the first six months, driven by record rainfall and floods from Typhoon Doksuri. Northern China, including Beijing, were the hardest hit. Over 8.9 million people were affected, with 168 people killed or missing. The country is bracing for more powerful storms and rain in September, with parts of northeastern provinces and southern China expected to see increased rainfall.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man holding a child walks across a damaged bridge after the rains and floods brought by remnants of Typhoon Doksuri, in Zhuozhou, Hebei province, China August 7, 2023. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang//File Photo

site_title: Is America reverting to isolationism?
summary: A Republican victory in the 2024 US presidential election could signal a shift towards isolationism, potentially disrupting the US-led global order. Candidates like Vivek Ramaswamy and Ron DeSantis have expressed skepticism about America's support for Ukraine in the Russia-Ukraine conflict. This sentiment is reflected in polls showing a divided Republican public, raising concerns about the consequences of an isolationist foreign policy.

images.alt_text: Joseph S Nye
Under pressure from the Republican's Trumpist and isolationist wing, House Speaker Kevin McCarthy has insisted that his party won’t give the Biden Administration a “blank cheque”
T-shirts with an image depicting the mugshot of former president Donald Trump have appeared on retail shelves, like in this store in Los Angeles, California.
The appeal of ‘Trumpism’ remains strong with key US groups, evidenced by polls of Republican party identifiers in 2023.

site_title: Big Tech's core businesses face overhaul under EU tech rules
summary: The EU has designated 22 services of six major tech companies as "gatekeepers" under the Digital Markets Act, requiring them to radically reshape their core business practices. The companies, including Alphabet's Google, Meta's Facebook, and Microsoft, must make their messaging apps interoperable with rivals and let users choose pre-installed apps. Gatekeepers face fines up to 10% of their annual global turnover for non-compliance, with a six-month deadline to demonstrate compliance. The move aims to promote competition and innovation in the tech sector.

images.alt_text: The landmark Digital Services Act compels tech companies, including Meta, to better police content, to protect European users against disinformation and hate speech.

site_title: Singapore-based Wirecard whistleblower building platform for others like him
summary: Singapore-based entrepreneur Pav Gill, a former Wirecard whistleblower, is developing a tech platform called Confide to aid whistleblowers in reporting wrongdoing at companies. The platform aims to safeguard anonymity and ensure companies comply with regulations. Gill hopes to draw on his Wirecard experience to create a solution for whistleblowers, citing the need for companies to take misconduct seriously. Confide plans to launch a beta version by October and raise funding to support its development.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
Wirecard Asia suffered a loss of $123,070 arising from the Yeo’s offences.

site_title: Japan seeks revival as a semiconductor powerhouse
summary: Japan is launching a five-trillion yen ($46.2 billion) initiative to revive its semiconductor industry, with a new joint venture called Rapidus aiming to reduce reliance on Taiwanese chips. The partnership with IBM aims to start mass production of two-nanometre node chips in 2027, but faces significant challenges, including a severe labour shortage and limited manufacturing expertise. Critics question whether Rapidus can compete with rivals like TSMC and Samsung, and the company's financial firepower is also a concern.

images.alt_text: The EU will also be supportive of Japanese semiconductor companies considering operating there, including through access to subsidies.
IBM provides Rapidus key process technology that enables 2nm chip nodes and beyond, using a new type of transistor composition called nanosheet
Japan is bolstering advanced chipmaking at home for cutting-edge chips amid growing US-China tensions and as concern grows about over-reliance on Taiwan.
The agreement comes as US-China relations remain tense, especially over chips.

site_title: Issue 32: SGX sheds 2 tiers, bids adieu to long-time directors; ESG funds underperform in 2022
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has imposed a 9-year limit on independent directors, effectively ending their long-term tenures. This change comes after a review of the two-tier voting system, which previously allowed directors to serve indefinitely. Meanwhile, Morningstar data shows that ESG funds underperformed their less sustainable counterparts by 3.4% in 2022, highlighting the challenges faced by environmental, social, and governance (ESG) investing. This trend suggests that ESG funds may need to reassess their strategies to achieve better returns.

images.alt_text: Kenneth Lim
Most investors in Asia still aren’t making significant deployments into sustainable assets, although the number is expected to grow in the coming years.
An ESG Insights special
The market for ESG data is growing at about 28 per cent per year, according to an analysis by Opimas.
City Developments subsidiary Millennium & Copthorne Hotels is the group’s largest contributor of greenhouse gas emissions.
South-east Asian countries are among the world’s largest consumers of coal.

site_title: China stimulus bets drive record gains in some developer stocks
summary: Chinese authorities' recent stimulus measures have driven record gains in some developer stocks, with heavily indebted companies surging by as much as 73% and 83% respectively. The rally comes after a rout in August, with authorities introducing lower down payments and looser mortgage rules to put a floor under the crisis. However, investors remain skeptical, citing weak fundamentals and liquidity stress, and some point to the rally's speculative nature. The gains have been concentrated in ailing private developers, and the sector's recovery remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: Country Garden last month said it had not paid coupons on two US dollar bonds due on Aug 6 totalling US$22.5 million, exacerbating market fear that the developer was slipping into a worsening liquidity squeeze.
In a deal reached after a vote on its proposal late on Friday, Country Garden is now allowed to repay the onshore debt in instalments over three years, instead of meeting its obligations by Sept 2.
In Beijing, more than 1,800 units of new homes were sold on Saturday alone, more than half of the 3,100 homes in August.
Asia-Pacific lenders are closely regulated and built to withstand the frequent bouts of volatility that roll through the region, said S&P Global Ratings.
Shanghai will no longer disqualify people who have ever had a mortgage – even if fully repaid – from being considered as first-time homebuyers, as long as they do not own a property.
The property sector accounts for roughly a quarter of the world’s second-largest economy
The persistent weakness in the property market comes despite a host of support measures over the past year and more recently.
China’s real estate sector is now unravelling, with Country Garden Holdings posting a record loss and risks spreading to the country’s US$60 trillion financial system.
The housing slump adds to wider concerns about the world’s second-largest economy, where authorities remain reluctant to adopt stronger stimulus to reverse the slowdown.

site_title: General manager of Enviro-Hub unit resigns after CPIB interview
summary: The general manager of HLS Environmental, an 80.25% owned subsidiary of Enviro-Hub Holdings, has resigned after being interviewed by the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB) on August 31. Enviro-Hub was informed of the CPIB probe by the general manager and stated it was not involved in the interview process. The company's board will make further announcements as developments arise. Shares of Enviro-Hub closed flat on September 6.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's tax revenue for FY22/2023 rose 13.1% to S$68.6 billion, driven by the post-Covid economic recovery. Corporate income tax accounted for 33.7% of the revenue collection. Economists cut Singapore's 2023 growth forecast to 1% due to weaker manufacturing. Ten foreign nationals charged in a high-profile money-laundering case remain in police custody. Simmering tensions between the US and China may draw Southeast Asia into a serious conflict. The Singapore Stock Index (STI) finished in the red after a mixed regional session, down 0.1%.

site_title: Big car COE prices continue record-breaking run in September to hit S$134,889
summary: COE prices for bigger cars have set new records in September, with Category B reaching a record S$134,889, up 3.8% from August. Category A and Category E also saw price increases, with Category E mirroring Category B closely. The increase is attributed to the expectation of a larger COE quota in the current period, leading to increased luxury car sales. Industry observers believe the COE market is still tight, with pent-up demand and supply chain issues affecting car dealerships.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong
There are 5.6 per cent more COEs in the August-October quota period than the previous three-month period.

site_title: China warns against ‘new Cold War’ at Asean summit
summary: China's Premier Li Qiang warned against a "new Cold War" during a recent Asean summit, urging countries to avoid taking sides and bloc confrontation. The warning comes amid sharpening geopolitical rivalries in the Indo-Pacific region, particularly over China's increasingly assertive activity in the South China Sea. Asean leaders also discussed accelerating negotiations on a code of conduct for the waterway and expressed concern about China's maritime claims. The US and its allies have echoed Asean's calls for freedom of navigation and overflight in the region.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong with United States Vice President Kamala Harris before the 11th Asean-US Summit at Jakarta Convention Centre on Sep 6, 2023.
The Philippines will be the hardest hit by the recent rise in rice prices, according to a research note by OCBC Bank.

Singapore’s Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong  (2nd L) and his spouse Ho Ching (L) are welcomed by Indonesia’s President Joko Widodo (2nd R) and First Lady Iriana Widodo upon their arrival for the ASEAN Summit in Jakarta on September 5, 2023.     ADEK BERRY/Pool via REUTERS

Asean leaders in a group photo after the opening of the 43rd Asean Summit. Representatives from all member states attended the opening ceremony as well as the plenary session held after, except for Myanmar.

site_title: ECB’s options remain open at coming meetings, says council member
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) Governing Council member Francois Villeroy de Galhau stated that interest rates are near the peak, but declined to indicate if the ECB should hike or hold next week's meeting. He emphasized the importance of keeping borrowing costs high for a sufficiently long period, rather than raising rates significantly again. This stance echoes ECB President Christine Lagarde's position that the meeting could see either a 10th straight rate hike or a hold. Villeroy also expressed confidence that the eurozone will avoid a recession, citing a positive growth outlook for France and the eurozone.

images.alt_text: ECB chief economist Philip Lane says slowing in goods and services gauges are welcome and that underlying pressures will keep weakening.
Lagarde and her colleagues are still waiting to weigh the ECB’s in-house economic forecasts, which are a key piece to the puzzle of rate decisions.

site_title: STI down 0.1% after mixed regional session
summary: The Straits Times Index fell 0.1% to close at 3,222.88 after a mixed regional session. Singapore Airlines was the top-traded counter, shedding 2.2% to S$6.75. The three major banks finished in positive territory, while Japan, Malaysia, and Shanghai indices closed up marginally higher. Economists expect the Federal Reserve to keep interest rates unchanged at the Sep 20 meeting, but may project one more rate hike before the year's end.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
SGX RegCo is issuing the Guide on Independent Financial Advisers as a starting point to improve the standards, clarity and consistency of advice that IFAs render in their opinions

site_title: Del Monte narrows Q1 loss to US$13.1 million; inflation, interest rates weigh on margins
summary: Del Monte Pacific reported a net loss of US$13.1 million in the first fiscal quarter, narrowing from a net loss of US$30.5 million in the same period last year. The loss was primarily due to higher inflation and interest rates affecting the company's margins. Despite the loss, Del Monte expects to achieve a net profit in the remainder of FY2024 and reiterated its full-year guidance for a higher year-on-year net profit. The company's turnover rose 13.2% to US$516.7 million, driven by higher sales in the US and exports of fresh pineapple.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi

Del Monte products sit on a shelf in a grocery store in Manila, Philippines, 11 october, 2013. Del Monte Pacific Ltd., the seller of fruit juices in the Philippines and India, said it agreed to buy the consumer food business of closely held Del Monte Foods Co. for $1.68 billion to expand in the U.S.

Del Monte products sit on a shelf in a grocery store in Manila, Philippines, 11 october, 2013. Del Monte Pacific Ltd., the seller of fruit juices in the Philippines and India, said it agreed to buy the consumer food business of closely held Del Monte Foods Co. for $1.68 billion to expand in the U.S.

site_title: Issue 33: So long, Sun Cable; Wilmar’s sustainability-linked loan
summary: Sun Cable, an Australian company attempting to build a 4,200km undersea transmission cable from Darwin to Singapore, has filed for bankruptcy protection. The project's collapse raises questions about the viability of importing renewable electricity from Australia to Singapore. Despite this, Singapore's Energy Market Authority (EMA) believes it can still meet its goal of importing 4 gigawatts of renewable electricity by 2035. The project's enormous price tag of A$30 billion and high costs associated with distance make it less competitive. Other long-range transmission projects may provide confidence to keep the Sun Cable project alive.

site_title: Issue 28: The Millennium and Copthorne in CDL’s side; the dawn of the orange bond
summary: City Developments (CDL), a Singapore-listed property group, will be dropped from the Dow Jones Sustainability World Index due to its hospitality subsidiary, Millennium & Copthorne Hotels, being a significant contributor to greenhouse gas emissions. CDL cited M&C's post-pandemic recovery and efforts to engage with the hotel operations on sustainability as reasons for the exclusion. Despite this, CDL remains on other indices and has been recognized for its sustainability efforts, including being the only Singapore corporation to be recognized on CDP's environmental non-profit list.

site_title: UK construction orders slump at the sharpest pace in three years
summary: The UK construction industry experienced its largest decline in new orders in over three years, with S&P Global's construction purchasing managers' index slipping to 50.8 in August from 51.7 in July. This signals that the industry is close to stagnation, primarily due to a prolonged slump in housebuilding, higher interest rates, and a weak economy. Despite commercial and infrastructure projects remaining resilient, the property market's woes and cutbacks to projects have dragged down housebuilding, marking the ninth straight month the sector has been under the 50 reading.

Developers have slowed housebuilding on concern about the economy and pressure from higher borrowing costs and inflation.
London has suffered double-digit percentage increases in asking rents.

site_title: Lviv's hottest ticket: a concert hall resurrecting Ukraine's repertoire
summary: A concert hall in western Ukraine, Lviv Organ Hall, is hosting classical music programs featuring a resident orchestra that fled the war zone, packing the house nightly. Despite air raids and power cuts, the hall continues to host concerts, often featuring Ukrainian music, including new compositions and little-known works. The hall's efforts have been met with success, with over 30,000 tickets sold or donated in the first seven months of this year, and a third of the audience being displaced by the war.

site_title: Issue 30: An ESG Insights special
summary: ESG Insights looks back at 2022 and ahead to 2023. The year saw a focus on sustainability-linked bonds, green financing, and the growth of ESG funds. However, concerns remain about the lack of clear ESG rules in Singapore's budget and the need for more effective reporting on natural disasters. The publication also highlights new goals set for 2035 to shape policies and encourages investors to adopt more effective ESG strategies. The trend reversal in ESG-linked pay and the COP29 shortfall are also noted, highlighting the need for private capital to step up.

site_title: Leading investor-focused groups call for ‘urgent course correction’ in climate policy
summary: Seven investor-focused groups urge governments to make an "urgent course correction" in climate policy, citing insufficient financial incentives and underfunding for adaptation. The groups, including CDP and Principles for Responsible Investment, released a report outlining eight key features of "good" climate policy frameworks that can enable and accelerate investments needed to meet the Paris Agreement goals. The features include clear targets, sector-specific policies, and a "just transition" that prioritizes fairness and inclusivity. The groups intend to support efforts to incorporate these principles into governments' climate policies and encourage companies to develop credible transition plans.

site_title: Issue 29: Startups take on ESG data; exchanges chase voluntary carbon
summary: The market for ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) data is growing at 28% per year, according to Opimas analysis. This growth is driven by the increasing demand for ESG data from investors and companies. Meanwhile, exchanges in South-east Asia are launching voluntary carbon exchanges, a move seen as a step towards a more sustainable future. As the ESG data market continues to expand, it is likely to have a significant impact on the way companies operate and investors make decisions.

site_title: Kim Eng founder Gloria Lee dies, aged 97
summary: Gloria Lee, the 97-year-old founder of Singapore's Kim Eng Holdings stock brokerage, has passed away following a private funeral. Lee, a former air stewardess, broke into the male-dominated stock market in the 1970s, becoming the first woman to buy a seat at the stock exchange in 1972. Her firm, Kim Eng, was sold to Malaysia's Maybank in 2011 for US$1.4 billion and became a household name in the region. Lee stepped down as chairman in 2008 at age 82, passing the helm to her son.

site_title: ‘We’re going to sink’: Hundreds abandon Caribbean island home
summary: Hundreds of people on the Caribbean island of Carti Sugtupu, home to fewer than 2,000 Indigenous souls, are preparing to relocate due to rising waters threatening to engulf their homes. Climate change-induced sea level rise is expected to make life even more difficult, with experts predicting the sea will engulf the island by the end of the century. The government has announced plans to move families to a mainland settlement with basic amenities, but the move raises concerns about the islanders' culture and way of life.

images.alt_text: Aerial view of the island of Carti Sugdupu, in the Indigenous Guna Yala Comarca, Panama, in the Caribbean Sea, taken on August 29, 2023. On a tiny island in the Caribbean, hundreds of people are preparing to pack up and move to escape the rising waters that threaten to engulf their homes in coming decades. The government is building 300 houses on mainland Panama to relocate the Guna Indigenous people of the densely populated island of Carti Sugdupu. Some homes have already been abandoned due to rising waters, as experts predict the archipelago will disappear by the end of the century due to the impact of climate change. (Photo by Luis ACOSTA / AFP)

site_title: Google reaches tentative settlement in US Play Store lawsuit
summary: Google has reached a tentative settlement in a US class action lawsuit alleging the company's US Play Store violated federal antitrust rules by overcharging customers. The settlement, details of which were not disclosed, was proposed by parties to the lawsuit, including lawyers representing the attorney general for Utah. Google denied wrongdoing and declined to comment on the proposed settlement. The settlement is subject to court approval.

site_title: Issue 34: Singapore wants to make green plane fuel work
summary: Singapore's aviation regulator is seeking advice on establishing sustainable fuel mechanisms, with implications for Changi Airport and Singapore Airlines. The framework's design will impact the competitiveness of these entities. The move comes as Asia's climate-related losses remain mostly uninsured. This decision is part of Singapore's efforts to encourage the use of green aviation fuel.
