site_title: Thailand stock investor confidence at 7-month high over new government
summary: Thailand's investor confidence in its stock market has reached a 7-month high due to the formation of a new government, according to a survey by the Federation of Thai Capital Market Organizations. The index jumped 69.3% to 141.27, moving from "neutral" to "bullish". Foreign investors' confidence also surged 87.5% to the bullish zone. The new government aims to address people's needs and stimulate the economy, with measures to be introduced late this year. Thailand's economy grew 1.8% in the April-to-June period year on year.

site_title: Sweden’s embattled landlords get ray of hope with bond sales
summary: Sweden's embattled landlords are regaining access to bond markets after a year and a half of being frozen out. Several property companies, including Castellum and Dios Fastigheter, have recently issued bonds, totaling 2.4 billion Swedish kronor (S$295 million). This tentative sign of improvement is attributed to better general sentiment, partly due to the expectation that interest rate peaks may be near. However, bond volumes remain low, and the sector still faces significant funding challenges, with 88% fewer bond deals compared to the same period in 2021.

site_title: DBS and other Asian banks tap US dollar bond markets for US$4.75 billion
summary: Asian banks, including Commonwealth Bank and DBS Group, raised US$4.75 billion from US dollar bond markets. DBS Group raised US$1.5 billion, while Commonwealth Bank raised US$3.25 billion in three separate transactions. This marks a return to the US dollar bond markets for DBS Group after a two-year break. The transactions demonstrate the banks' aggressive efforts to tap into the global debt markets.

site_title: Suspect’s seized assets in money laundering case include 10 Canninghill Piers units; those charged to be remanded further
summary: A money laundering case involving assets worth S$1.8 billion has resulted in 10 foreign nationals, including Wang Baosen and Su Baolin, being denied bail. The suspects will remain in police custody until their next court dates, amid concerns of collusion and witness tampering. The prosecution argued that granting bail would pose a risk of collusion, while defense counsel claimed their clients were not flight risks. The remaining six accused will return to court on Oct 18 for bail review, with some lawyers requesting access for family members and medical aid for a suspect with anxiety and clinical depression.

summary: UK homebuilder Barratt Developments reported a 36% drop in forward sales to £2.44 billion, citing tough housing market conditions due to high mortgage rates and a cost-of-living crisis. The company expects average sales sites to reduce by 6% in the current fiscal year. British house prices fell 5.3% in August, the largest annual decline since 2009. The UK housing market outlook remains uncertain, with predictions of a 21% drop in house purchases this year, the lowest since 2012.

site_title: Lower levies for offsite workers will apply to more pre-fab facilities
summary: The Singapore government is phasing out the man-year entitlement (MYE) levy framework in favour of a more streamlined Off-site Levy Scheme, effective January 1, 2024. The new scheme offers lower levies for offsite construction workers, with rates dropping to $250 for higher-skilled workers and $370 for basic-skilled workers. Operators of design for manufacturing and assembly (DfMA) facilities with higher automation levels can apply for the off-site levy scheme and enjoy lower levies. The change aims to encourage firms to adopt new automation technologies and diversify their work permit holder workforce.

site_title: Issue 31: Singapore ESG flows against the waning tide; India dreams of hydrogen
summary: Singapore's investors deployed more capital into sustainable funds than they withdrew in 2022, marking a significant turnaround from previous years. The country's ESG flows finally turned positive after years of outflows, with a total inflow of $54.3 million for the first nine months of 2022. This reversal is attributed to concerns about greenwashing and returns, with investors increasingly seeking more evidence on the social and financial benefits of sustainable investments. In contrast, India has launched a plan to be an exporter of green hydrogen, aiming to produce 5 million tonnes per year by 2030.

site_title: China’s Tsinghua Unigroup to expand globally, South-east Asia a target
summary: Tsinghua Unigroup, a Chinese state-owned semiconductor conglomerate, plans to expand globally, focusing on South-east Asia. The company aims to increase manufacturing and R&D capabilities in the region, with chairman Li Bin announcing plans to establish an investment platform. China seeks self-sufficiency in semiconductor manufacturing due to US sanctions. Tsinghua Unigroup has expanded rapidly through acquisitions but has struggled with massive debt, leading to bankruptcy and restructuring. The company's expansion in South-east Asia is seen as a strategic move to support China's chip industry growth.

site_title: Australian economy grows modestly in Q2, eases recession fears
summary: Australia's economy grew 0.4% in Q2, beating forecasts, driven by exports and investment, while household consumption remained weak due to high interest rates. Annual growth was 2.1%, above expectations, but economists expect one more interest rate hike by the end of the year to control inflation. Productivity concerns persist, with unit labour costs rising 7.2% annually, and household budgets remain under pressure due to squeezed profits. The Reserve Bank of Australia left interest rates unchanged for a third month, but markets see a chance of a rate cut soon.

images.alt_text: Australia's Prime Minister Anthony Albanese reacts as he speaks to the press outside Number 10 Downing Street in London, on May 5, 2023 following a meeting with Britain's Prime Minister. (Photo by Daniel LEAL / AFP)
Monthly consumer price inflation slowed to a lower-than-forecast 4.9 per cent in July in Australia and away from last year’s peak of 8.4 per cent.
Philip Lowe has moved more cautiously than developed world peers, having raised rates by 4 percentage points, compared with 5.25 points in New Zealand and the US.

site_title: Leicester City crash failure was 'irrecoverable' by pilot: final report
summary: A helicopter crash in 2018 that killed Leicester City soccer club's owner Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha and four others was deemed "irrecoverable" by the pilot due to a tail rotor failure, according to a final report. The helicopter's yawing uncontrollably and descending rapidly at a low altitude led to the loss of yaw control, making recovery impossible. The pilot managed to land softly, but the four survivors died from fire, which would have been preventable with external assistance. The investigation identified problems with the helicopter's bearing, leading to 16 service bulletins issued by the manufacturer.

site_title: Tesla unlikely to pursue Indonesia plant soon, Panjaitan says
summary: Indonesia's coordinating minister for maritime affairs and investment, Luhut Panjaitan, stated that Tesla is unlikely to pursue a plant in Indonesia soon due to concerns over the global economic outlook and oversupply in the electric vehicle industry. Panjaitan met with Elon Musk in August, where they discussed Tesla's potential investment in the country. The meeting led to a price cut and the unveiling of Tesla's refreshed Model 3, but Panjaitan believes that Musk remains uncertain about investing in Indonesia at this time.

site_title: Worst is over for Thailand’s electronics sector, says UOBKH
summary: UOB Kay Hian (UOBKH) upgraded its rating for Thailand's electronics sector to "market weight" from "overweight," citing a recent rebound in second-quarter financials and signs of a semiconductor industry recovery. The brokerage believes the worst has already passed, with share prices absorbing significant headwinds. A projected surge in smartphone and personal computer sales is expected to bode well for the sector. However, UOBKH maintained "hold" calls on some manufacturers due to concerns over currency fluctuations and raw material prices.

summary: RHB Research upgraded its call on CDL Hospitality Trusts (CDLHT) to "buy" from "neutral" due to a 12% decline in stapled securities over the last month. Analyst Vijay Natarajan attributed the weakness to a broader sell-down in the hospitality sector amid concerns about higher interest rates. Despite a low fixed-debt position, Natarajan believes CDLHT is "poised to ride the tourism recovery" with a high-quality portfolio of upscale hotels in Singapore. The analyst also expects a slight increase in the hotel portfolio value upon year-end revaluation.

site_title: Singapore is top Asean destination for companies looking to expand footprint in next 2 years: HSBC survey
summary: HSBC's Global Connections survey found that 36% of companies with operations in Singapore have business expansion plans in the country over the next two years, making it the top ASEAN destination for companies looking to expand their footprint. This is followed by Malaysia (27%) and Thailand (24%). The survey polled 3,509 businesses across 10 countries, including Australia, France, Germany, and the US. The findings suggest that Singapore remains an attractive location for international firms seeking to grow their presence in the region.

site_title: Japan warns on yen after currency hits fresh 10-month low
summary: Japan's currency officials have issued a warning on the yen after it hit a fresh 10-month low against the US dollar, reaching 147.82. Vice Finance Minister Masato Kanda stated that speculative moves could lead to government intervention, citing uncertainty for businesses and households. Officials are watching the market closely, with a sense of urgency, and have repeatedly expressed concern about sharp movements in the yen. The yen's drop has raised concerns about potential intervention, with some market participants seeing the 150 level as a key hurdle before any action is taken.

images.alt_text: Masato Kanda was speaking to reporters after the US dollar broke above 147 yen to edge closer to 148 yen overnight, this year’s strongest ever against the Japanese currency.

site_title: Rich investors swoop in as UK squeezes small landlords
summary: The UK is seeing a surge in borrowing costs, pricing out a generation of tenants from buying their own homes, and creating a supply of desperate customers. As a result, big investors, including private equity firms, pensions, and sovereign wealth funds, are entering the build-to-rent market, filling the gap left by small landlords. The sector is expected to grow, with Savills predicting 30% of UK rentals will be build-to-rent, accounting for 1.6 million properties. This shift is exacerbating a supply-and-demand gap, with prices rising and supply dwindling, as landlords sell up and rent prices increase.

site_title: Toyota says plant shutdown last week due to server malfunction
summary: Toyota's assembly plants in Japan were shut down for about a day due to a server malfunction caused by insufficient disk space on some servers during maintenance procedures. The issue occurred during an update of the automaker's parts ordering system. The company restarted operations on Wednesday after transferring data to a server with a larger capacity. Toyota will review its maintenance procedures to prevent similar issues in the future.

site_title: Bank of Japan policymaker sees signs of change in Japan’s deflationary mindset
summary: Bank of Japan policymaker Hajime Takata said Japan is seeing early signs of change in the public's perception that wages and inflation won't rise much, suggesting conditions for phasing out massive stimulus are falling into place. Core inflation hit 3.1% in July, exceeding the BOJ's 2% target for the 16th straight month, and firms promised wage hikes unseen in three decades this year. Takata believes Japan's economy is finally achieving the BOJ's 2% inflation target and urged patience in maintaining ultra-loose monetary policy amid uncertainties.

site_title: Miscalculation in US-China relations could draw Asean into serious conflict: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong expressed concern that a miscalculation in US-China relations could draw Southeast Asia into a serious conflict. He urged the US and China to "show leadership" to address global issues, emphasizing the importance of dialogue, strategic trust, and cooperation. Lee welcomed US efforts to strengthen ties with Asean, including the establishment of a new US-Asean centre. He also highlighted the need for Asean and China to intensify cooperation on issues such as air transport and the digital economy.

site_title: TPG-backed firm considers sale of Hong Kong oncology centres
summary: TE Asia Healthcare Partners, backed by private equity firm TPG, is considering selling its oncology centres in Hong Kong, potentially valuing the Hong Kong Integrated Oncology Centre at over US$100 million. The sale process is ongoing, with deliberations continuing and the company still considering holding onto the asset. The move follows a rising demand for private healthcare services in Asia, with other companies in the sector also exploring divestments. The divestment is part of a broader trend of deal activity in the sector, driven by a growing middle class in Asia.

site_title: FDIC starts marketing US$33 billion of Signature property debt
summary: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) has begun marketing US$33 billion of commercial property loans from Signature Bank, as part of a larger offloading of US$60 billion in debt. The majority of the loans are backed by multifamily properties in New York City, with US$15 billion tied to rent-stabilized or rent-controlled properties. The FDIC aims to preserve the availability and affordability of residential real property for low- and moderate-income individuals, and will place rent-stabilized loans in joint ventures with the FDIC retaining a majority equity interest.

The FDIC’s Quarterly Banking Profile, which will cover the first three months of 2023, is by definition backward-looking.

site_title: New president of E50 Association aims to develop existing initiatives, launch fresh ideas
summary: Newly elected president Yeah Lee Ching of the Enterprise 50 (E50) Association aims to build upon existing initiatives, such as overseas retreats and ministerial dialogues, while introducing fresh ideas, including opportunities for companies to learn about listing and adapting to being a listed entity. Yeah, who took over from outgoing president Susan Chong, plans to expand on initiatives like quarterly ministerial dialogues and overseas retreats, and introduce new programs to support E50 members. The association has 321 members, mostly comprised of male business leaders, but Chong emphasized mutual respect and tact in managing the association.

(L-R) Susan Chong, Chief Executive Officer, Greenpac; Yeah Lee Ching, Chief Marketing Officer, ValueMax

site_title: Singapore tax collection up 13.1% to S$68.6 billion in FY2023, reflects post-Covid recovery
summary: Singapore's tax revenue for FY2023 rose 13.1% to S$68.6 billion, reflecting the economic recovery post-Covid-19 pandemic. Corporate income tax accounted for the largest share, at 33.7% or S$23.1 billion. Tax revenue collection increased across most tax types, according to the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore. This growth indicates a strong economic rebound in the country.

Lady walking at the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) building.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, GSH
summary: Singtel's digital bank joint venture with Grab has obtained approval to start operations in Malaysia from September 1, with GXBank to begin beta-testing its app. In contrast, shares of GSH rose 1.2% after the sale of nine office units in Raffles Place was terminated due to the purchaser's inability to complete the transaction.

site_title: Issue 27: Singapore’s nuclear option; Vietnam’s sweetened coal offer
summary: Singapore is considering nuclear power as a potential solution to achieve net-zero emissions by 2050, with the Energy Market Authority's 2050 energy transition report outlining three possible pathways, one of which includes nuclear energy. Meanwhile, Vietnam is in talks with developed nations for a $15 billion pledge under the Just Energy Transition Partnership (JETP) framework, which aims to phase out thermal coal. The deal is seen as more proportionate than the $20 billion offer to Indonesia, and Vietnam's consumption of coal is expected to be significantly reduced.

site_title: Elon Musk borrowed US$1 billion from SpaceX in same month of Twitter buyout: WSJ
summary: Elon Musk borrowed $1 billion from SpaceX in October 2022, around the time of his Twitter buyout, and repaid it with interest in November. The loan was backed by some of his SpaceX stock. The reason for the loan could not be determined. Musk's acquisition of Twitter was completed last year for $44 billion, and he took ownership after firing top executives.

site_title: Manchester United share price tumbles with club sale in question
summary: Manchester United's market capitalization plummeted by 18.22% after the Glazer family reportedly halted plans to sell the club, citing a lack of offers meeting their US$7.5 billion asking price. The club's valuation now stands at US$3.15 billion. Despite discussions continuing with potential buyers, including billionaire Jim Ratcliffe and Qatari banker Sheikh Jassim Bin Hamad Al Thani, the Glazers are deeply unpopular with fans, who accuse them of saddling the club with debt and underinvesting in the team.

site_title: Audemars Piguet CEO expects to exit watchmaker with record sales
summary: Audemars Piguet's CEO, Francois-Henry Bennahmias, plans to step down at the end of the year, to be replaced by former Procter & Gamble executive Ilaria Resta. Despite a strong global economy, Bennahmias expects record sales for the luxury watch brand, with annual sales projected to reach 2.4 billion Swiss francs. The company's demand for its pricey timepieces remains strong, with inventory at its lowest ever and a waiting list for popular models. Bennahmias cautions that the world could enter a more troubled time, citing economic and geopolitical challenges.

images.alt_text: The move to authenticate its own pre-owned watches marks a significant shift for Rolex, whose timepieces dominate secondhand sales at dealers and online.

site_title: Issue 26: SGX eyes Japan ESG buzz; Asia’s pricey green offices
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) plans to launch climate change-focused Nikkei 225 futures in the first half of 2023, reflecting growing interest in Japan's ESG investing opportunities. Rental premiums for green offices in Singapore are among the lowest in Asia, but may deter companies from adopting sustainability. To address this, experts suggest shifting resources into green retrofitting, which could increase the share of green office stock by 5 percentage points per year.

site_title: China says economic ‘fundamentals’ are unchanged despite its slowdown
summary: China's economy continues to slow, with the housing sector and related industries struggling, despite official growth figures of 5.5% for the first half of the year. The Chinese government has taken incremental steps to revive growth but has declined to unleash a massive stimulus package to avoid deepening debt. China's embassy spokesperson, Liu Pengyu, stated that the country's "fundamentals" remain unchanged, citing a fragile global economic recovery and contractionary policies in major economies.

images.alt_text: Li Qiang will first attend the Association of South-east Asian Nations gathering in Jakarta, Indonesia, for wide-ranging talks on trade, climate change and global security.

site_title: China’s Tencent to unveil AI chatbot after Beijing clears hurdles
summary: China's internet giant Tencent Holdings will unveil an AI chatbot, Hunyuan, on September 7 after receiving approval from Beijing. The chatbot, developed for months, was previously tested internally and is similar to Baidu and SenseTime Group's released models. This comes after China's approval of AI chatbots for public release last month. Tencent's shares dropped 1% on the announcement, lagging the broader market's 0.5% decline.

site_title: Malaysia seeks return of ex-Goldman banker convicted in 1MDB case
summary: Malaysia is seeking the return of Roger Ng, a former Goldman Sachs banker convicted of helping to loot billions from the 1MDB sovereign wealth fund, before he begins his 10-year US prison sentence. A US judge has delayed Ng's surrender date by one month to allow discussions with Malaysia on allowing him to stand trial there. Ng's lawyers have agreed to the delay, which is also aimed at ensuring the procedures for his return to Malaysia do not delay the service of his US sentence.

images.alt_text: Roger Ng, a former banker for Goldman Sachs, permanently prohibited from performing any regulated activity under the Securities and Futures Act, and from providing any financial advisory services under the Financial Advisers Act.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly drop as oil spike fuels fresh inflation worry
summary: Asian markets declined on Wednesday as oil prices surged to 10-month highs, fuelling concerns of another US Federal Reserve interest rate hike. The price spike, driven by Saudi Arabia and Russia extending crude output cuts, pushed Brent above $90 for the first time this year. The move complicated the Fed's work on inflation, with observers warning of higher energy costs. Markets extended losses, with Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Seoul falling, while Tokyo, Singapore, and Jakarta edged up.

site_title: Gold hits one-week lows on elevated US dollar, yields
summary: Gold prices fell to one-week lows at $1,924.41 per ounce, down 0.1% from the previous day, as the US dollar rose to a near six-month high and US Treasury yields reached their highest level in over a week. This was driven by expectations that interest rates will remain high, making gold less attractive as an investment. Federal Reserve Governor Christopher Waller stated that the latest economic data gave the central bank space to consider raising interest rates again, further depressing gold prices.

images.alt_text: Premiums on physical gold in China eased off recent highs last week as safe-haven buying cooled on hopes that stimulus could help the top bullion buyer’s ailing economy.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Wednesday’s open; STI up 0.5%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.5% or 15.45 points to 3,242.28 at 9:01 am, bucking a global selloff on Wall Street and Europe. Gainers outnumbered losers 51 to 44, with heavily traded securities including Seatrium, Rex International, and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding. Banking stocks, such as DBS, UOB, and OCBC, also rose in early morning trade.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Singtel’s digital bank joint venture with Grab obtains approval to commence operations in Malaysia from Sep 1.

site_title: Early Grab backer raises South-east Asia fund amid tech rout
summary: 500 Global, a prominent early-stage venture investor in South-east Asia, has raised US$143 million to boost investments in the region amid a market downturn. The fund includes a new US$100 million early-stage venture capital vehicle, focusing on pre-seed to Series A companies in rural digitalisation, healthcare, and food security. Despite industry challenges, 500 Global's managing partner Vishal Harnal sees this as a great time to invest, citing undervalued assets and opportunities for growth.

GXBank is a subsidiary of GXS Bank – the digital bank joint venture between Grab and Singapore Telecommunications (Singtel), as well as a consortium of other Malaysian investors including Kuok Group.
Grab's revenue has risen 76.6 per cent year on year to US$567 million in Q2, buoyed by growth across all segments.

“It has been an invaluable experience for me at Grab, as it was an opportunity for me to return to the private sector, to broaden my horizons, hone new skills and allow me to make a contribution in a different way,” Tin said in the post.

site_title: Malaysia could become South-east Asia’s preferred medical-tourism destination
summary: Malaysia is poised to become South-east Asia's preferred medical-tourism destination as the country's healthcare infrastructure narrows the gap with Singapore. The Malaysia Healthcare Travel Council's efforts to boost medical tourism have shown promising results, with 850,000 healthcare travelers visiting the country last year, generating RM1.3 billion in revenue. Analysts expect private healthcare expenditure to grow at a 7.3% compound annual rate, driven by growing demand and digitalization. However, the impact on private healthcare providers is uncertain, with some analysts noting that reforms may benefit medical tourism indirectly.

Thailand has been treading gingerly in the ongoing US-China spat, which has helped attract Chinese companies to South-east Asia’s second-largest economy.

site_title: Issue 25: Who won at COP27?
summary: Asian fund managers are less likely to exclude oil and nuclear assets from their portfolios, preferring engagement over exclusion to influence corporate behavior. This approach has the potential to create more impact, but may be less effective for smaller funds or those with limited stakes. At COP27, developing nations received an in-principle agreement for a loss and damage fund, but critics argue this compromise may undermine stronger emissions curbs. The deal also includes a blended finance model, such as the Just Energy Transition Partnership, which aims to secure private sector funding for low-carbon transition in developing countries.

site_title: Mastercard denies report of plans to raise credit card fees
summary: Mastercard has denied reports that it plans to raise credit card fees in the US this fall, citing a Wall Street Journal article that claimed the company would increase interchange rates in October and April. The company stated that it has no plans to raise interchange rates or network fees in the US, contradicting the Journal's report. Visa also released a statement saying that recent press coverage on the issue was "misleading" and that interchange fees on its transactions have been flat for the past decade.

site_title: Economists cut Singapore’s 2023 growth forecast to 1% on weaker manufacturing: survey
summary: Singapore's full-year economic growth forecast has been cut to 1% by private-sector economists, down from 1.4% in the previous survey, mainly due to weaker manufacturing and non-oil domestic exports. The median forecast for full-year gross domestic product (GDP) growth is between 0% and 0.9%, with nearly a 50-50 chance of this. The unemployment outlook is expected to improve, with the overall unemployment rate expected to be 2% by year-end. Monetary policy is expected to remain unchanged in October's decision.

site_title: Rate hikes curb output for at least a decade, San Francisco Fed study finds
summary: The Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco study found that interest-rate hikes can curb output for at least 12 years, contradicting traditional theories of neutral policy. Researchers found that investment decisions lead to lower productivity and capital stock, resulting in reduced economic output. A 1% interest-rate increase can lower real GDP by 5% after 12 years. The study suggests central banks' efforts to cool inflation may compromise economic growth, requiring policymakers to balance inflation control with growth potential.

site_title: Household net worth grows further in Q2, rising 8.9% as liabilities fall
summary: Singapore households' net worth grew 8.9% to S$2.7 trillion in Q2 2023, outpacing the 7.5% increase in Q2 2022. Household liabilities fell 1% to S$359 billion, while mortgage debt rose 1.8% to S$264 billion. Residential property asset values slowed to 9.1% growth, down from 11.7% in Q1 2023. Financial assets, including stocks and life insurance, rose 7.6% to S$1.7 trillion. Industry watchers attribute the growth to a lower base in earlier quarters and a strong stock market.

site_title: 5 Questions with angel investor and Rainforest CEO JJ Chai
summary: Angel investor and Rainforest CEO JJ Chai discusses his career journey, startup experience, and angel investing approach. Chai, a techie himself, started his career in software engineering and product management before moving into consulting and leading roles at Airbnb and Carousell. He co-founded Rainforest, an e-commerce aggregator, in 2021, focusing on the modern parent market. Chai invests in startups with a growth mindset, founder-problem fit, and ability to attract talent. He believes the current tech winter creates a healthier environment for building new companies, emphasizing cash flow and profitability over growth.

site_title: UBS doubles stock research for Credit Suisse wealth clients
summary: UBS is doubling its stock research coverage for Credit Suisse wealth clients, expanding to over 3,000 stocks, as part of its integration process. This move aims to retain wealthy clients and private banking talent, while shedding riskier assets. UBS will also integrate Credit Suisse's securities research for the investment bank, terminating coverage on September 18. Credit Suisse clients will continue to access "historic" research until early October, while institutional clients will be given access to the UBS research platform in the coming weeks.

site_title: Coinbase begins offering crypto loans to large US institutional investors
summary: Coinbase has launched a crypto lending service for US institutional investors, capitalizing on the vacuum left by firms like BlockFi and Genesis Global Holdco after their collapse. The service, operated through Coinbase Credit, has already seen $57 million in investments from customers of its Prime service. This marks Coinbase's return to lending after it stopped issuing new loans to retail investors in May. The move aims to provide institutions with a standardized lending product that qualifies for a Regulation D exemption.

site_title: Japan won’t rule out options if FX speculation persists: Kanda
summary: Japan's top currency diplomat Masato Kanda warned that the country won't rule out any options to address speculative moves in the currency market if they persist. The yen broke above 147 yen to edge closer to 148 yen, its strongest ever against the Japanese currency. This comes as the US dollar gains momentum due to expectations of a potential rate hike by the Federal Reserve to combat inflation. Kanda emphasized that currency moves should reflect fundamentals, not speculation, as Japan's core consumer prices show little signs of sustainable inflation.

site_title: Oil prices settle at 10-month high as Saudi, Russia extend supply cuts
summary: Oil prices rose to a 10-month high, settling at $90.04 a barrel, after Saudi Arabia and Russia extended their voluntary supply cuts to the end of the year. Brent crude futures gained 1.2% and US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 1.3%. The extension was unexpected, and analysts expect a market deficit of over 1.5 million barrels per day in 4Q23, leading to higher oil prices worldwide.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures for November crept 45 cents higher to settle at US$89.00 a barrel on Monday.

site_title: US Fed’s debt runoff is ‘painless’ at US$1 trillion mark, with bigger test ahead
summary: The US Federal Reserve has successfully offloaded approximately $1 trillion of its bond holdings since the beginning of last year, with its balance sheet now at $7.4 trillion. This process, known as quantitative tightening, has been deemed "painless" so far, with no significant strain on financial markets. However, experts warn that the Fed's ongoing balance-sheet contraction and the Treasury Department's reliance on the private sector to take up federal debt could pose a bigger test on markets in the future.

images.alt_text: Central banks around the world have embarked on the most aggressive cycle of rate hikes in several decades to try and cool inflation.

site_title: US: Stocks dip as oil prices hit multi-month peaks
summary: US stocks declined on Tuesday, September 5, as oil prices reached multi-month peaks, pushing the Dow Jones Industrial Average 0.6% lower to 34,641.97. Treasury bond yields also rose, reflecting expectations of higher interest rates. Despite comments from Federal Reserve governor Christopher Waller suggesting steady interest rates, oil output restraint by Saudi Arabia and Russia led to gains in petroleum-linked equities. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also fell, with the Dow Jones and S&P 500 losing 0.4% and 0.1% respectively.

site_title: GSH to pocket S$3.88 million as sale of Raffles Place office units falls through
summary: GSH Corp announced the termination of a sale and purchase agreement for nine strata office units in Raffles Place, valued at S$38.8 million, due to the purchaser's inability to complete the transaction. The company will recognize S$3.88 million, the 10% deposit, as "other income" in its income statements for the current financial year. The termination is not expected to have a material effect on the company's consolidated net tangible assets per share.

GSH intends to use net proceeds from the sale of the Cecil Street property for repayment of existing financing taken against it, as well as for working capital purposes.
GSH Corp's first commercial paper in the form of digital securities will be listed on ADDX.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall as weak China, eurozone data dents appetite
summary: Europe's shares fell 0.2% on Tuesday, logging their fifth consecutive session of declines, amid weak China and eurozone data fueling concerns about slowing global growth. China's services sector activity expanded at the slowest pace in eight months in August, leading to a 1.2% drop in luxury and construction & materials sectors. Energy stocks helped crimp losses, but the decline was well off its week-low hit intraday.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 index held steady at 457.96 points at Monday's close after touching near four-week highs earlier in the day.

site_title: US commerce secretary doesn’t expect changes to Trump China tariffs until review complete
summary: US Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo stated that changes to US tariffs on China imposed during President Donald Trump's administration are unlikely until the US Trade Representative's office completes its ongoing review. Raimondo expressed her confidence that the Biden administration will not make any changes to the tariffs until the review is completed, but did not provide a timeline for its conclusion.

site_title: China’s No 2 steps onto world stage as Xi skips G20 in India
summary: China's new Premier Li Qiang is taking his first steps into the global spotlight, attending the Association of Southeast Asian Nations gathering in Jakarta and the G20 summit in New Delhi. Li's debut at the G20 will give him a rare opportunity to meet with powerful leaders, including US President Joe Biden and Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi. However, his role is expected to be largely ceremonial, with Xi Jinping maintaining control over policymaking. Li's focus is likely to be on providing details about Beijing's economic policies, which are faltering after years of pandemic-induced isolation and volatile policymaking.

images.alt_text: The investment fund is likely to be the biggest of three funds launched by the China Integrated Circuit Industry Investment Fund, also known as the Big Fund.

site_title: UK’s second biggest city Birmingham declares bankruptcy after equal pay claim
summary: Birmingham City Council, the UK's second-largest city, has declared bankruptcy due to a £87 million shortfall and a potential liability of £650-760 million related to equal pay claims. This decision, made by a Labour-run administration, brings the city into financial distress, joining other councils such as Woking, Thurrock, and Croydon in doing so. The council's financial struggles are attributed to central government cuts, risky investments, and the impact of the pandemic and inflation.

images.alt_text: British consumer price inflation is 6.8 per cent in July – down from a peak of 11.1 per cent in October 2022 but still higher than in any other major economy.
Britain’s annual consumer price inflation rate cooled to 6.8 per cent in July- still the highest rate among the Group of Seven economies.

site_title: ‘Game changer’ agreement to unlock Asean’s potential US$2 trillion digital economy
summary: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) has launched negotiations for a Digital Economy Framework Agreement (Defa), a "game changer" that aims to align digital trade regulations and establish cooperation among Asean member states. The agreement is expected to facilitate seamless cross-border digital trade, improve digital rules, and address emerging trends like AI. If successful, Asean's digital economy is projected to triple to nearly US$1 trillion by 2030, reaching up to US$2 trillion, making it a leading digital community and economic bloc.

site_title: Asean leaders urge Myanmar junta to stop attacks on civilians
summary: Asean leaders urged the Myanmar junta to stop attacks on civilians, houses, and public facilities, including schools and hospitals. The call comes as violence has ravaged the country since the 2021 military coup. The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) meeting in Indonesia's capital Jakarta failed to make significant progress on a peace plan, with host Indonesia stating there had been scant progress. The junta has been directly blamed for the violence, with Asean leaders condemning the attacks on civilians.

site_title: The AI hype has subsided, but the revolution continues
summary: Artificial intelligence continues to advance despite the recent hype and marketing decline. Despite critics' claims of an impending doom, market prices show no signs of AI heralding the end of the world. Generative AI and large language models continue to improve, with new commercial services and open-source models being released. The development of AI is likened to other revolutionary technologies, such as the printing press and electricity, which had periods of slow adoption before their full impact was realized. The transformative power of AI is undeniable, with potential applications in various industries, including fashion and beauty.

site_title: Breaking the Groundhog Day cycle for Singapore construction
summary: Singapore's construction sector faces persistent challenges, including labour shortages, supply-chain issues, and rising material costs. Despite these obstacles, 90% of construction leaders are confident about their industry's prospects in the next 12 months. To break the cycle, leveraging data and technology is crucial. The construction industry produces 2.5 billion gigabytes of data daily, with 96% remaining untapped, offering potential savings of up to 22% in project spending. However, many construction professionals lack confidence in developing and implementing a data strategy, highlighting the need for a more proactive approach to harnessing the power of data.

images.alt_text: Contractors that are still completing contracts received pre-pandemic may not be able to pass on their rising costs.
The Marina Gardens Lane site, zoned residential with commercial at first storey, can yield about 790  private housing units.
An NUS poll shows that BIPV-fitted buildings are expected to enjoy only a modest lead over their counterparts, both in terms of capital appreciation and rental rates.

site_title: Apple inks new long-term deal with Arm for chip technology
summary: Apple has signed a new long-term deal with Arm for chip technology that extends beyond 2040. The deal is valued at around $52 billion and will see Apple continue to use Arm's technology in designing its custom chips for iPhones, iPads, and Macs. Arm owns the intellectual property behind most smartphones' computing architecture, licensing it to Apple and others. The deal is part of Arm's initial public offering (IPO) plans, with SoftBank Group offering 95.5 million shares at $47 to $51 each.

images.alt_text: The new approach has the potential to streamline Apple’s supply chain and kick off a broader shift.
Apple typically makes new iPhones available for preorder on the Friday after their unveiling and begins delivering them to customers and stores one-week later.

site_title: US factory orders fall 2.1% in July
summary: US factory orders fell 2.1% in July, reversing the June gain and ending a four-month streak of increases. This decline was lower than the 2.5% expected by economists polled by Reuters. Orders rose 0.5% from July a year ago, according to the Commerce Department.

site_title: CapitaLand Malaysia Trust to sell Malaysian office property for RM52 million
summary: CapitaLand Malaysia Trust (CLMT) has agreed to sell the 3 Damansara Office Tower in Malaysia for RM52 million, representing a 4% premium to its most recent valuation of RM50 million. The sale, expected to complete by Q1 2024, will strengthen the trust's balance sheet and provide financial flexibility for portfolio diversification efforts. The net proceeds will be used to repay existing borrowings, and the trust expects no material impact on earnings or net asset value.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi

site_title: Huawei's new chip breakthrough likely to trigger closer US scrutiny: analysts
summary: Huawei has unveiled a new smartphone, the Mate 60 Pro, powered by its proprietary chip Kirin 9000s, marking a breakthrough in China's chip development despite US sanctions. Analysts suggest Huawei may have acquired technology from SMIC to produce the chip, rather than collaborating on its development. The achievement is seen as a demonstration of China's resilience in chip technology, but also raises concerns about the costs and potential for increased US scrutiny, potentially leading to tighter curbs on Huawei's access to advanced chipmaking tools.

images.alt_text: The Mate 60 Pro, which went on sale this week, fanned patriotic fervour as it was seen to represent China’s ability to get around US sanctions.

A Huawei store with advertisements for the Mate 60 series of smartphones in a mall in Beijing on Wednesday.  The launch was so low-key that staff at Huawei and sales personnel at stores in Beijing and Shenzhen said they were caught off-guard.
FILE PHOTO: The Huawei logo is seen at its booth during the Mobile World Congress in Shanghai, China June 28, 2023. REUTERS/Nicoco Chan/File Photo

site_title: Malaysia, Singapore natural partners in fast-tracking Asean’s development
summary: Malaysia and Singapore are strengthening their economic partnership through the proposed Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone (JS-SEZ), which aims to boost jobs, investment, and trade in the Asean region. The JS-SEZ will complement the Malaysia-Singapore corridor, a strategic economic zone in South-east Asia. The two countries have already signed agreements on the digital economy and green economy, facilitating cooperation on trade facilitation, digitalization, and sustainable development. The JS-SEZ is expected to fuel greater development of trade and investment between the two countries and across Asean, unlocking opportunities for growth and international significance.

images.alt_text: From left: Johor’s Menteri Besar Onn Hafiz Ghazi, Singapore’s Minister for National Development Desmond Lee, Malaysia’s Economy Minister Rafizi Ramli, and Singapore’s Acting Minister for Transport Chee Hong Tat at a doorstop interview for the 16th JMCIM.

site_title: US homebuyers weigh climate risk in picking a house
summary: US homebuyers are increasingly factoring in climate risks when purchasing a new house, with 83% of respondents weighing at least one climate risk such as floods, wildfires, or droughts. Climate risks are affecting attitudes, particularly among younger buyers, who prioritize home safety from rising waters and extreme temperatures. Despite the concern, most homebuyers aren't moving to less risky regions, and one-quarter are considering moving to areas with more risks, with climate concerns strongest in the West.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq open lower as yields rise, China data weighs
summary: The S&P 500 and Nasdaq opened lower on Tuesday, September 5, due to higher Treasury yields weighing on growth stocks. Downbeat data on China's services activity stoked concerns over the world's second-largest economy. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.02%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite declined 0.13% and 0.27%, respectively.

site_title: SoftBank’s Arm aims for over US$52 billion valuation in biggest US IPO of the year
summary: Arm, a UK-based chip designer, is set to go public with a US$52 billion valuation in its initial public offering, the largest in the US this year. SoftBank, the company's parent, is offering 95.5 million shares at a price range of $47 to $51 apiece. The IPO is expected to be buoyant for the global market and will be a milestone for SoftBank, which has lined up major tech clients as investors. Arm is profitable and has a strong client list, including Apple and Samsung Electronics, which will help reduce investor anxieties.

images.alt_text: Arm has lined up some of its biggest customers – Apple, Nvidia, Intel and Samsung Electronics – as strategic investors for the initial public offering.
Arm, the chip designer owned by SoftBank Group, is expected to set a price range for its offering next week, sources say.
SoftBank plans to sell about 10 per cent of Arm’s shares in the IPO at a valuation of US$60 billion to US$70 billion.

site_title: Improved corporate governance starts with a mindset shift
summary: The Singapore Governance and Transparency Index (SGTI) scores of 474 listed companies in the "general" category rose to 74.8 points in 2023, up from 70.6 in 2022. Although the overall results are encouraging, scores in key pillars such as "board responsibilities" and "disclosure and transparency" were only 64% and 67%, respectively. The improvement is attributed to a mindset shift towards transparency, as investors today recognize that better-governed companies tend to make better investments, with empirical research showing that well-governed companies outperform in the long term.

images.alt_text: Singtel has reclaimed its top spot on the SGTI from ground handler and caterer Sats with a score of 120.

site_title: Singapore to expand ocean CO2 removal project as scientists call for more research
summary: Singapore is expanding its ocean carbon dioxide removal (OCDR) project, aiming to build a demonstration plant with a daily capacity of 10 tons by the end of the year. The project, using technology from US firm Equatic, extracts CO2 from seawater and absorbs it into the ocean. Scientists are calling for more research into OCDR, citing its potential to curb temperature rises, with the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) stating its removal will be as important as cutting emissions. However, experts warn of potential ecological impacts and the need for more funding.

images.alt_text: The overall Marina Bay District cooling network will operate at a total capacity of up to 90,000 RT, said SP Group.

site_title: Growing businesses with intangible asset disclosure
summary: Singapore has launched the Intangibles Disclosure Framework (IDF), a voluntary framework to guide businesses in identifying, managing, and disclosing their intangible assets, including intellectual property. The IDF aims to improve the transparency and comparability of intangible asset disclosures, providing a credible and trusted IA valuation ecosystem. By facilitating more buy-sell transactions, fostering market transparency, and boosting innovation, the IDF is expected to strengthen Singapore's IP hub status and enhance its position as a leading innovative economy.

images.alt_text: Improving intangible asset disclosures can lead to better investment decisions, said Second Minister for Finance Indranee Rajah.
Intangible assets are becoming an increasingly important driver of business value.
In recent years, homegrown brands such as Razer and Irvins have optimised their intangible assets to protect their brands and products to expand successfully overseas.

site_title: Rise of China’s EV makers threatens Western firms, UBS says
summary: Western automakers are set to lose a fifth of their global market share to Chinese electric vehicle (EV) makers, who will almost double their share to 33% by the end of the decade, according to UBS analysts. BYD, led by China's biggest-selling auto brand, will have a 25% cost advantage over North American and European brands, making it difficult for Western firms to compete. Tesla's share is predicted to rise to 8% from 2%, while BMW and Mercedes-Benz Group will also face challenges in the EV market, with their next-gen models not set to hit the market until 2025.

images.alt_text: “For us, to survive, we have to achieve at least 500,000 to 1 million units of annual sales globally. It would take at least two to three years for us to achieve that,”  says .Leapmotor's CEO Zhu Jiangming.
The new Model 3 promises a longer driving range for China.
Li Auto's rivals, such as Xpeng Inc (above), BYD and Nio Inc, all reported increased sales in July; Tesla Inc's deliveries, on the other hand, slid 31 per cent from June.

site_title: Germany’s Scholz praises auto industry amid protests, announces EV expansion law
summary: German Chancellor Olaf Scholz praised the country's auto industry amid protests at the Munich IAA car show, announcing plans to expand electric vehicle charging stations. A new law will require 80% of service stations to offer fast-charging options of at least 150 kilowatts, aiming to make range anxiety a thing of the past for EV drivers. The move is part of Germany's goal to boost EV sales, which currently lag behind the 15 million target by 2030.

images.alt_text: Tesla wants to double capacity to 1 million cars per year and 100 gigawatt hours of battery production at a plant that would make even more cars than produced by Volkswagen at its Wolfsburg headquarters
The attendees’ main concern at Tuesday’s event is how Tesla will manage to expand the plant without using additional water.
Led by BYD, Chinese carmakers will almost double their share of the auto market to 33 per cent by the end of the decade, according to UBS analysts.

The OJK would consider to expand the green label to loans for coal-fired power plants used by industries that make products considered sustainable, such as batteries for electric vehicles, says OJK chief Mahendra.

Mercedes-Benz's Vision One-Eleven electric car at the International Motor Show (IAA) in Munich on Monday (Sep 4).

Opel's president for design Mark Adams next to an Opel experimental car at the International Motor Show (IAA) in Munich. China's offerings are biting on the heels of European carmakers: 8 per cent of new EVs sold in Europe so far this year were Chinese brands, up from 6 per cent last year and 4 per cent in 2021.

site_title: Microsoft expands Abu Dhabi’s G42 partnership to include cloud and AI tools
summary: Microsoft is expanding its partnership with Abu Dhabi's G42 to include cloud and AI tools, offering cloud infrastructure in the UAE and helping organizations comply with local regulations. The partnership will give access to Azure features, including AI solutions, and drive technological advancements across key sectors. The move aims to support responsible innovation, with a focus on data privacy, security, and compliance. Industry-specific AI solutions may be brought to significant projects, including the COP28 climate summit, set to be held in Dubai later this year.

images.alt_text: Microsoft makes an equity investment in Rubrik in 2021 in a round that valued it at US$4 billion.

Under the restructured deal, Microsoft will not be able to release Activision games like Overwatch and Diablo exclusively on its own cloud streaming service – Xbox Cloud Gaming – or to exclusively control the licensing terms for rival services.
In July, Microsoft laid out an aggressive spending plan to meet demand for its AI services.

site_title: SGX’s equity capital global head Mohamed Nasser Ismail to leave exchange
summary: SGX's global head of equity capital markets, Mohamed Nasser Ismail, will leave the exchange at the end of October for other opportunities. Ismail, who has worked at SGX for 18 years, will be replaced by Koh Jin Hoe and Matthew Song, who will lead the merged capital markets unit. The move aims to provide more holistic coverage of clients across products and sectors, with a focus on direct engagement with investors.

images.alt_text: The potential default of Chinese property developer debt has had a spillover effect on Singapore-listed property companies, according to analysts.

site_title: Japan’s Ryusuke Hamaguchi on following his Oscar success
summary: Japanese director Ryusuke Hamaguchi, known for his Oscar-winning film "Drive My Car," has premiered his follow-up "Evil Does Not Exist" at the Venice Film Festival. The film, which explores the threat of a tourism project on a rural village, was inspired by a request from composer Eiko Ishibashi to shoot footage in a remote region. Hamaguchi, who needed a break after the Oscars, found a new project that allowed him to showcase the complexity of his characters, often depicting people with nuanced motivations. The film's enigmatic ending has left critics and Hamaguchi himself scratching their heads, but he remains satisfied with the result.

images.alt_text: Leung says he is about to make his first European film, Silent Friend, directed by Hungary’s Ildiko Enyedi.

American director Woody Allen with French actresses Valérie Lemercier (left) and Lou De Laage at the photocall for the movie "Coup de Chance", presented out of competition at the 80th Venice Film Festival on Monday (Sep 4).

site_title: Saudis, Russia extend oil-supply curbs to year-end
summary: Saudi Arabia and Russia have extended their oil supply curbs by three months until December, reducing global output to its lowest level in several years. The Opec+ members will hold output at about 9 million barrels a day, with Saudi Arabia cutting 1 million barrels a day and Russia reducing 300,000 barrels a day. The move aims to support a fragile global market, with traders expecting a more aggressive move than initially anticipated.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures for November crept 45 cents higher to settle at US$89.00 a barrel on Monday.

site_title: How to position your portfolio as global equities head for a correction
summary: Global equities declined 3% in August, driven by a US equities pullback and rising 10-year Treasury yields. China's economic woes, exacerbated by structural issues, contributed to the downturn. The US Federal Reserve reiterated its focus on fighting inflation, with core inflation still above its 2% target. As bond valuations remain attractive, investors are advised to manage equity exposure and prioritize fixed income. China's rate cuts and stamp duty halving are seen as insufficient to address its structural problems, potentially affecting global markets.

images.alt_text: Shipping containers at the Port of Taicang in China's Jiangsu province. Exports of most goods from Asean to China have generally been down across the board, economists say.
Investors monitor stock prices at a securities exchange house in Shanghai, China on Friday, 31 December 2010.

site_title: Meta to retire Facebook News in UK, France and Germany
summary: Meta announced plans to retire the Facebook News tab in the UK, France, and Germany by December, affecting over 130 million users. Despite this, users will still be able to read and share news on their Facebook feeds. The news tab will no longer be supported, and Meta will not enter into new deals with publishers in these countries.

images.alt_text: Those who pay for Facebook and Instagram subscriptions would not see ads in the apps, said the people, who spoke on the condition of anonymity because the plans are confidential
Instead of lifting its ban, Meta urges Canadians to use the “Safety Check” function on Facebook to let others know if they are safe or not.
COde Llama, available for free, can write code based on human text prompts and can also be used for code completion and debugging, Meta Platforms said.
Meta is making the model available to the public for non-commercial use.

site_title: European asset managers reject plans for tigher liquidity rules
summary: Global financial watchdogs FSB and IOSCO proposed stricter rules for investment funds to boost resilience against market shocks. However, European asset managers rejected these plans, calling them "fundamentally flawed" and stating they would increase costs for investors. The proposed rules would require open-ended investment funds to hold more liquid assets to cope with surge in redemptions, but asset managers argue other parts of the market were also facing difficulties during the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Execution and key man risks in HPL’s plan to redevelop Orchard Road properties
summary: Hotel Properties Ltd (HPL) has received provisional permission from the Urban Redevelopment Authority to redevelop three properties along Orchard Road, including Forum The Shopping Mall, voco Orchard Singapore, and HPL House, under the Strategic Development Incentive. The redevelopment, valued at over S$4 billion, aims to create a mixed-use development with hotel, retail, office, and residential components. However, HPL faces risks, including a potential drop in steady income contributions, high interest rates, and costly delays. The company's managing director, Ong Beng Seng, is under investigation by the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau, which could impact the redevelopment's success. A joint-venture option with a credible partner may help mitigate development risks, and Ong's sale of his stake could resolve the key man risk.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
Responding to queries from SGX, HPL unintentionally reminded investors that Ong Beng Seng's real estate interests are not entirely held under the public-listed company
Forum The Shopping Mall may be redeveloped as part of a mixed redevelopment by Hotel Properties Limited

site_title: Sats appoints Temasek-backed farming startup Sustenir’s chairman Pier Sigismondi to board
summary: Sats appoints Pier Sigismondi, chairman of Temasek-backed farming startup Sustenir, as an independent non-executive director and member of the Risk and Safety committee, effective immediately. Sigismondi's diverse experience in food and beverage businesses is expected to add value and synergy to the board. However, he will recuse himself from transactions between Sats and Sustenir or its competitors. Sigismondi, 57, has no prior experience as a director of a listed stock and will undergo prescribed training within a year of his appointment.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Sats air cargo operations. Airfreight and logistics by SATS Ltd.
Temasek's FY2023 performance was supported by Singapore companies like Keppel, Sembcorp and Seatrium

site_title: Australia unveils South-east Asia trade plan as China doubts grow
summary: Australia is unveiling a South-east Asia trade plan amid growing concerns about China's influence in the region. The plan aims to increase Australia's trade and investment ties with South-east Asia, which has experienced rapid economic growth over the past 20 years. The strategy calls for a whole-of-nation approach, relaxing foreign investment restrictions, and investing in Australian infrastructure. This move comes as Australia seeks to diversify its economy and reduce its dependence on China, with trade between Australia and Asean countries totaling over $81 billion in 2021.

images.alt_text: In the keynote address at the Shangri-La Dialogue defence summit in Singapore, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said the future of the Asia-Pacific region was yet to be decided, and it was harmful to assume that a regional war was “inevitable.”

site_title: Airbus, easyJet, Rolls-Royce join forces in UK on hydrogen-powered flying
summary: Airbus, easyJet, and Rolls-Royce have formed the Hydrogen in Aviation (HIA) alliance to promote hydrogen-powered aviation in the UK. Airbus plans to introduce a hydrogen-powered commercial aircraft by 2035, with easyJet potentially being the first customer. The partners aim to establish the necessary infrastructure, policies, and regulatory frameworks to support the technology. The HIA will publish a report by the end of 2023 outlining the milestones needed to make hydrogen-flying a reality over the next 10 years.

images.alt_text: The EU alone hopes to be consuming 20 million tonnes a year of manufactured green hydrogen by 2030.
Airbus said it was “progressing well” towards a widely watched production goal for its best-selling A320neo-family jets of 75 jets a month in 2026, which it reaffirmed.

“Despite a challenging external environment, notably supply chain constraints, we are starting to see the early impact of our transformation in all our divisions,” says Rolls-Royce chief executive Tufan Erginbilgic.

site_title: World losing race to meet climate goals, COP28 president says
summary: The world is losing the race to meet its climate change goals, according to Sultan Al Jaber, president of COP28, citing the need for faster results in the time required. African leaders are calling for changes to the international climate finance system, citing inadequate funding for the continent, which receives only 12% of the needed financing. The UAE has pledged $4.5 billion to develop clean power in Africa, while Germany and the US have committed additional funds. African officials are pushing for a transformation of the global climate financing architecture and a carbon tax to finance development.

images.alt_text: EU and UAE will work to “ensure maximum support on global 2030 targets for the tripling of renewable energy and doubling of energy efficiency,” a statement says.

site_title: Singapore shares fall on Tuesday amid declines across Asia-Pacific, STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.4% on Tuesday, following declines across the Asia-Pacific region, with the Straits Times Index closing at 3,226.83. Despite a 1.1% increase in July retail sales, which missed analyst forecasts, the market reacted to regional economic concerns. The decline was part of a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with other news including the appointment of OCBC's new CEO, Tan Teck Long, and China's expected slowdown in GDP growth.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
All four categories in Singstat's F&B Services Index record growth in July.
Shipping containers at the Port of Taicang in China's Jiangsu province. Exports of most goods from Asean to China have generally been down across the board, economists say.

site_title: BT team wins Experiential Treat prize at SGX Orb Awards
summary: The Business Times (BT) team won the Experiential Treat prize at the Singapore Exchange's (SGX) Orb Awards for their piece "The rise of the Singapore CSO." The team, consisting of various journalists and artists, analyzed the wave of appointments of chief sustainability officers (CSOs) in Singapore's top companies. The winning piece offered insights into the backgrounds of CSO appointees and their skills, and was recognized for its clear message and graphic representation.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi

site_title: Germans question value of working after new welfare increases: survey
summary: A survey in Germany found that 52% of respondents believe it's not worth working due to the planned increase in welfare payments, which will see benefits rise to 563 euros per month. The increase aims to combat child poverty and inflation, but the survey shows that many Germans think full-time employment on a minimum wage of 12.4 euros per hour does not significantly increase earnings. Finance Minister Christian Lindner emphasized the need to maintain work incentives, stating that employment is key to overcoming poverty.

images.alt_text: People are seen wearing face masks as they walk in a pedestrian street among shops and Christmas decorations in the city of Cologne, western Germany, on December 18, 2021. (Photo by Ina FASSBENDER / AFP)

site_title: Weak global activity data sends US dollar to six-month high, Aussie skids
summary: The US dollar has reached a six-month high of 104.75, driven by global economic concerns, particularly in China, and weaker growth conditions outside the US. The euro and pound also fell, with the euro down 0.56% and sterling down 0.6%. The Australian dollar dropped 1.6% against the US dollar, while the Japanese yen and Canadian dollar also fell. The US 10-year yield rose 5 basis points to 4.2261%, and the Reserve Bank of Australia kept interest rates steady, leaving the door open for future increases.

site_title: Fitch’s US downgrade: The principal-agent problem in modern finance
summary: Fitch Ratings downgraded US sovereign credit from AAA to AA+, highlighting the principal-agent problem in modern finance where investors outsource risk management to rating agencies. This downgrade was not a huge surprise due to the US's deteriorating financial position over the past decade. The issue is complex, with geopolitical factors and rating agency limitations contributing to the clouding of creditworthiness labels. The principal-agent problem also raises concerns about hidden costs and knowledge gaps between investors and financial market actors, emphasizing the need for increased transparency and accountability.

images.alt_text: Fitch's ratings on those notes are cut to “AA+sf” from “AAAsf” after being put on watch for a negative downgrade since late May.
Outside the New York Stock Exchange on Aug 2, 2023, the day after Fitch downgraded the US economy to AA+ from AAA.

site_title: Drumbeat of artificial intelligence powers Big Tech
summary: Artificial intelligence is poised to drive significant economic growth, with Big Tech companies expected to be major beneficiaries. According to McKinsey, AI could add $17-25 trillion to global economic output by augmenting labor productivity, reducing costs, and creating new revenue streams. The rapid growth of AI is also being fueled by advancements in computing power, with companies like Microsoft leveraging tens of thousands of Nvidia GPUs in their data centers to generate responses in split seconds.

images.alt_text: Healthcare, which is tightly regulated and still relies heavily on fax machines, has proven uniquely difficult for tech companies to crack.
ChatGPT and other large language models seem intelligent, but in fact merely regurgitate prior programming.

site_title: Amount in assets linked to billion-dollar bust balloons to S$1.8 billion: prosecutors
summary: Turkish national Vang Shuiming, 42, faces five charges, including one for using a forged document and four for money laundering, in a Singaporean money laundering case valued at S$1.8 billion. The assets seized or frozen include over S$1.8 billion, with around S$200 million seized from Vang, who is also linked to various companies and individuals involved in the case. The investigation is ongoing, with all 10 individuals remanded since their charges in court on August 16.

images.alt_text: ST journalists Andrew Wong and Nadine Chua at Bedok resident JJ's (not pictured) HDB flat last month.
$1b in cash and assets were seized and frozen.
The police seized cash and luxury items, and issued prohibition of disposal orders against ornaments and cars as part of an islandwide raid.

site_title: Chevron Australia labour row escalates with two-week walkout plan
summary: Chevron Australia workers plan a two-week strike starting September 14, amid ongoing disputes over pay and conditions. The strike at Gorgon and Wheatstone LNG projects, which account for 13% of global LNG capacity, could disrupt exports and increase competition for the super-chilled fuel. Mediation talks, hosted by the Fair Work Commission, are ongoing, with Chevron expressing hope for a negotiated resolution. The strike could lead to inefficiencies and supply impacts, but analysts expect the mediation process to resolve the issues before a material supply disruption.

images.alt_text: Employees last week almost unanimously rejected a pay and conditions deal put to them directly by Chevron, bypassing unions.

site_title: Climate Impact X to launch price benchmarking contracts for cookstove projects
summary: Climate Impact X (CIX) will launch a new series of carbon price benchmarking contracts for cookstove projects, aiming to streamline the market and increase price transparency. The contracts will cover 31.6 million credits, representing a significant portion of the global cookstove market, and will be launched in the coming months. CIX's approach deviates from its previous method, using a curated delivery basket of projects to set a global price, instead opting to split projects into four segments based on location and registry. The move is expected to sharpen valuation of comparable registry crediting schemes and increase liquidity.

site_title: ‘Grab the opportunities, ride the storm,’ says CDL’s Kwek Leng Beng
summary: CDL executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng emphasized the importance of seizing opportunities and navigating challenges in the global real estate market. The company has grown from 8 employees in 1963 to become a global real estate company with over 8,000 employees and assets valued at S$31 billion. To celebrate its 60th anniversary, CDL launched a wellness center for children and families at City Square Mall. Kwek aims for CDL to expand its presence globally, despite the potential risks, and ride the storm of market fluctuations.

site_title: Asean’s economic integration needs to be extended to digital and green sectors: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong urged Asean leaders to update the regional bloc's economic agreement to cover digital and green economic activities, as part of efforts to establish a single market. The 2045 vision aims to meet citizens' aspirations, with economic integration at its core. The call comes as Asean seeks to expand its economic integration to new growth areas, including digital and green sectors. Leaders must move quickly to develop these areas, according to PM Lee.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim

Singapore’s Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong  (2nd L) and his spouse Ho Ching (L) are welcomed by Indonesia’s President Joko Widodo (2nd R) and First Lady Iriana Widodo upon their arrival for the ASEAN Summit in Jakarta on September 5, 2023.     ADEK BERRY/Pool via REUTERS
Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong will be in the Indonesian capital for the 43rd Asean Summit and related summits that will take place from Tuesday to Thursday.
Foreign powers are gearing up for engaging Asean ever more closely.

site_title: Hong Kong's top court rules in favour of same-sex civil unions
summary: Hong Kong's top court ruled in favor of same-sex civil unions, but stopped short of granting full marriage rights. The court declared that the government must establish an alternative framework for legal recognition of same-sex partnerships, but did not address same-sex marriage. This partial win for the LGBTQ+ community comes amid growing support for same-sex marriage in Hong Kong, with a recent poll showing 60% of residents support the issue.

images.alt_text: Changing perceptions make the corporate stance on LGBTQ+ matters a potentially high-stakes test.
The South-east Asian nation also made owning one of Swatch’s rainbow watches punishable by up to three years in prison, because of their pride theme.

site_title: Waiting on fear: Bearish outlook for FTSE 100
summary: The article warns of a bearish outlook for the FTSE 100 in September, citing a dismal historical record of crashes during the month. A combination of factors suggests the Nasdaq could experience a significant fall in September with a potential October rally recovery. The London FTSE 100 is also expected to decline, with a prolonged trading band making it vulnerable to September jitters. The US market remains bullish, but the UK market's established gloomy outlook increases the risk of an accelerated downtrend.

images.alt_text: Climate change and its impact on natural catastrophe events drive demand for protection, even as capacity to accept risk is constrained among insurers.

site_title: Toa Payoh site for 775 condo units expected to draw firm but cautious bids
summary: A 5,743 square-metre site in Lorong 1 Toa Payoh is set to attract firm but cautious bids from developers when it goes up for tender in November, yielding about 775 housing units. The site's maximum gross floor area is 66,121 sq m. Analysts expect interest to remain decent, with four to five bids, and top bid prices between S$783 million and S$854 million, or a land rate between S$1,100 and S$1,200 per square foot per plot ratio.

images.alt_text: Samuel Oh
Due to the plot’s attractiveness and accessibility, OrangeTee & Tie deputy chief executive Justin Quek anticipates keen demand from developers.
The Clementi Ave 1 site has an area of 13,451.1 sq m and can potentially yield 500 housing units.

site_title: Grab and Singtel’s digital bank gets approval from Bank Negara Malaysia to begin operations
summary: GXBank, a digital bank joint venture between Grab and Singtel, has received approval from Bank Negara Malaysia to commence operations in Malaysia. The approval was granted ahead of the April 2024 deadline and allows GXBank to begin operations from September 1. This is the first of the five digital bank licence applicants to receive approval, marking a significant step forward for the country's digital banking sector.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
GXS' move to adjust interest rates signal its intention to be more than just a bank to save with.
Grab's revenue has risen 76.6 per cent year on year to US$567 million in Q2, buoyed by growth across all segments.

site_title: TikTok hires Britain’s NCC for auditing data security
summary: TikTok has hired British cybersecurity firm NCC to audit its data controls and protections as part of "Project Clover", a data security regime aimed at alleviating concerns over data security. The regime includes storing user data in Europe, with three data centers in Ireland and Norway, and already has a designated secure area in the US. TikTok will engage with European policymakers to explain the system's operation in practice, amid growing pressure from lawmakers over data security.

images.alt_text: While TikTok Shop is fast emerging as a serious contender against incumbent e-commerce majors such as Shopee and Lazada in South-east Asia, Momentum Works also sees TikTok competing with Amazon in the US and Middle East.

As demand for cremation increases in the United States, TikTok influencers on the hashtag #gravetok are hoping to inspire a new generation of cemetery enthusiasts who can help conserve the country's past.
