site_title: Saudi Aramco considers selling US$50 billion in shares: WSJ
summary: Saudi Aramco is considering selling up to $50 billion in shares through a secondary share offering on the Riyadh bourse, with potential investors including multinational oil companies and sovereign-wealth funds. The sale could happen before the end of the year, following consultations with advisers. This move is part of Saudi Arabia's plan to bolster its main sovereign wealth fund, as Crown Prince Mohammed Salman had previously stated that Aramco would sell more shares to support the fund.

images.alt_text: saudi oil Photographer: Simon Dawson/Bloomberg

site_title: Oil rises to highest in over seven months on supply worries
summary: Oil prices rose to their highest in over seven months, with Brent crude reaching $88.49 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude reaching $85.02 a barrel, driven by expectations of tightening supplies. Saudi Arabia is expected to extend its oil production cut, while Russia has agreed to cut oil exports next month. The robust appetite for oil in the US, with declining commercial crude inventories, has bolstered expectations of a pause in interest rate hikes. However, concerns remain about the sluggish recovery of the Chinese economy and its impact on global oil demand.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A TORC Oil & Gas pump jack is seen near Granum, Alberta, Canada May 6, 2020. Picture taken May 6, 2020. REUTERS/Todd Korol/File Photo
Brent crude futures for October expired up US$1, or 1.2 per cent, at US$86.86 a barrel.

An LNG terminal near Ho Chi MInh in Vietnam. Global gas prices hit record highs last year, after Russia cut its gas supply to Europe; Asian spot prices also hit historic highs. They have since come down more than 80 per cent.

site_title: Oil rises to highest in over 7 months on supply worries
summary: Oil prices rose to their highest in over 7 months, driven by expectations of tightening supplies due to Saudi Arabia's likely extension of a voluntary 1 million barrel per day production cut. Brent crude surged 1.4% to $88.08 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 1.7% to $85.02. Analysts attribute the price increase to below-average supplies, a robust US appetite for oil, and a moderation in wage growth, which may lead to a pause in interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures for October expired up US$1, or 1.2 per cent, at US$86.86 a barrel.
FILE PHOTO: A Saudi Aramco sign is pictured at an oil facility in Abqaiq, Saudi Arabia, October 12, 2019. REUTERS/Maxim Shemetov//File Photo

site_title: Europe: Shares log weekly gain; Novo Nordisk most valuable European company
summary: European stocks closed flat on Friday, logging a 1.5% weekly gain, as commodity-linked sectors rose amid China's stimulus measures and higher base metal prices. Novo Nordisk became Europe's most valuable listed company, with a 2.1% gain, while luxury firms and automakers declined. The healthcare sector rose 0.5% and the oil and gas sector added 1.9%. European automakers were the worst hit, with Volkswagen and Renault dropping 5% and 6.3%, respectively.

images.alt_text: Asia investors traded cautiously on Friday, with Tokyo, Seoul, Shanghai, Taipei, Manila and Jakarta up but Sydney and Wellington in the red.

site_title: JPMorgan found US$1 billion in suspicious Epstein activity, US Virgin Islands says
summary: JPMorgan Chase has disclosed over $1 billion in suspicious transactions linked to Jeffrey Epstein, a financier accused of sex trafficking, after his death in 2019. The US Virgin Islands claims the bank knowingly benefited from Epstein's wrongdoing and ignored red flags, bolstering allegations in its lawsuit. JPMorgan denies the suggestion, stating it reported 150 cash transactions and cooperated with a federal regulator. The USVI is seeking at least $190 million from JPMorgan, which has accused the territory of deflecting from its own inaction in bringing Epstein to justice.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Robinhood Markets, Inc. is seen at a pop-up event on Wall Street after the company's IPO in New York City, U.S., July 29, 2021.  REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo

site_title: UK considers Botox crackdown after complaints of ‘botched’ procedures
summary: The UK government is considering measures to limit high-risk beauty treatments amid thousands of complaints of botched procedures. Proposed plans include banning TV and social media adverts for cosmetic procedures targeting under-18s and age restrictions for riskier services. Additionally, a licensing regime may be introduced, requiring beauty therapists in England to register with their local authority to carry out certain treatments.

images.alt_text: Many fans are trying to mimic the looks of the "Barbie" movie’s lead actress, Margot Robbie, to have slimmer, more contoured necks.
As end to pandemic mask-wearing nears, South Koreans scramble to arrange cosmetic surgery
Business of looking good glows with work-from-home, mask-wearing
Why medical tourism is drawing patients, even in a pandemic

site_title: Commodious new Kona goes to extra lengths
summary: The Hyundai Kona has been lengthened by 14.5 cm, making it more practical for family duties, with a 25% increase in boot capacity to 466 litres. The new model also features a more sophisticated design, including a longer freestanding display and crisp creases, while maintaining its distinctive looks. The Kona Hybrid is a full self-charging hybrid, offering efficient fuel consumption and quiet operation in day-to-day traffic, with a starting price of S$191,999. It is available for purchase now, with the Kona Electric set to launch early next year.

images.alt_text: The V100 feels like a reassuringly easy bike to flick through bends.

site_title: US job growth picks up in August; wage gains slow
summary: The US economy added 187,000 jobs in August, exceeding expectations, but the unemployment rate rose to 3.8% and wage growth slowed, indicating a moderation in labor market conditions. This data may lead to expectations that the Federal Reserve will not raise interest rates this month, as it suggests an easing of labor market conditions.

images.alt_text: Times Square, New York City. Consumer spending, which accounts for more than two-thirds of US economic activity, went up by 0.8 per cent in July, the Commerce Department reported on Thursday (Aug 31).

site_title: Bond traders eye pivot point for rates after cracks in jobs data
summary: US bond traders are monitoring the job market for signs of a pivot point in interest rates, with a steepening yield curve resulting from short-term debt outperforming longer-term debt. Benchmark two-year Treasuries have seen a 20+ basis point decline, and interest-rate swaps show less than 50% chance of another rate hike this year. The jump in unemployment rate to 3.8% has raised questions about the US economy's resilience, with traders awaiting further data to determine if the Fed is done raising rates.

images.alt_text: The site in central Munich of a project planned by Euroboden, a property developer that has filed for insolvency.
Holding cash may seem like a safer option during market volatility but is not ideal as it remains vulnerable to inflation.
The jobs report published Friday shows a bigger increase in the unemployment rate than expected last month.

site_title: Robinhood buys back shares US seized from Sam Bankman-Fried
summary: Robinhood Markets bought back $605.7 million of its shares, approximately 55.3 million shares, from the US Marshal Service for $10.96 a share. The shares were previously controlled by Sam Bankman-Fried, who is accused of orchestrating a multi-billion-dollar fraud. The repurchase was part of an effort to resolve a contentious ownership fight involving Bankman-Fried, FTX, and BlockFi. The move is seen as a positive for Robinhood, with the stock gaining 37% this year.

images.alt_text: Robinhood has been struggling to regain its footing after emerging as the breakout financial technology app during the pandemic.
FILE PHOTO: The logo of Robinhood Markets, Inc. is seen at a pop-up event on Wall Street after the company's IPO in New York City, U.S., July 29, 2021.  REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo

site_title: SoftBank’s Arm set to target IPO valuation of US$50 billion to US$55 billion: sources
summary: Arm Holdings, a chip designer owned by SoftBank Group, is targeting a valuation of US$50 billion to US$55 billion in its initial public offering (IPO). The company plans to price its shares on September 13 and will sell about 10% of its shares, following a reduced stake sale in August. SoftBank will sell its 25% stake in Arm not directly owned by the Vision Fund unit. The IPO roadshow is expected to begin next week, with stock trading to start the following day on the Nasdaq.

site_title: Lion Asiapac enters deal to sell limestone unit for RM49 million
summary: Lion Asiapac has agreed to sell its limestone processing subsidiary, Compact Energy, for RM49 million (S$14.3 million) in cash to an investment holding company of Graymont, a Canada-based lime and limestone solutions firm. Compact Energy, the largest producer of quicklime in Malaysia, has an annual production capacity of 390,000 metric tonnes. The sale is considered a major transaction under listing rules and will require shareholders' approval at a general meeting.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
The SGX sign on 6 April 2021.

site_title: US construction spending rises strongly in July on single-family housing
summary: US construction spending rose 0.7% in July, exceeding expectations, driven by a surge in single-family housing projects. Spending on private construction projects increased 1.0%, with residential construction advancing 1.4%. Single-family housing projects saw a 2.8% increase, partly due to a housing shortage. However, higher mortgage rates may stifle activity. Multifamily housing projects saw a 0.2% gain, while private non-residential structures like factories rose 0.5%. Public construction projects fell 0.4% due to decreases in state and local government spending.

images.alt_text: Houses in Meridian, Idaho. US house housing Photographer: Jeremy Erickson/Bloomberg

site_title: RBC’s C$13.5 billion deal for HSBC Canada gets approval from competition body
summary: Royal Bank of Canada's (RBC) $13.5 billion deal to acquire HSBC Canada, the country's seventh-largest bank, has received approval from the Canadian Competition Bureau. The antitrust body stated that the acquisition will not result in a "substantial lessening or prevention of competition." Finance Minister Chrystia Freeland has the final say on the deal, with completion expected in early 2024. The competition watchdog found limited competitive impact from HSBC Canada due to rivalry with RBC across various financial services markets.

site_title: US manufacturing sector stabilising at weaker levels in August: ISM
summary: US manufacturing contracted for a 10th consecutive month in August, but at a slower pace, according to the Institute for Supply Management (ISM). The manufacturing PMI increased to 47.6, still below the 50 threshold indicating contraction. This marks the longest such stretch since the 2007-2009 Great Recession. Economists attribute the decline to interest rate hikes and a shift in consumer spending towards services, but low inventories and slightly improved order books suggest the sector may be stabilizing at lower levels.

images.alt_text: China’s manufacturing activity fell for a fifth consecutive month in August.

site_title: Thai king commutes former PM Thaksin’s prison sentence to one year
summary: Thailand's King Maha Vajiralongkorn has commuted former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra's 8-year prison sentence to 1 year, following a royal pardon request submitted by the 74-year-old. Thaksin, who returned to Thailand after 15 years in self-exile, had been serving an 8-year sentence for graft convictions. The decision was seen as a mercy from the monarch, with Thaksin's lawyer stating that the king's "grace showed Thaksin mercy."

images.alt_text: (FILES) Exiled former Thai prime minister Thaksin Shinawatra gestures while being interviewed by Agence France-Presse (AFP) in Hong Kong on March 25, 2019. Thailand's billionaire former prime minister Thaksin will return to the kingdom on August 10 after 15 years in self-exile, his daughter said July 26, 2023. (Photo by Isaac LAWRENCE / AFP)

site_title: Dollar drops as unemployment rate rises, wage gains slow
summary: The US dollar dropped against the euro and Japanese yen after the August jobs report showed a rise in the unemployment rate to 3.8% and moderation in wage growth. Employers added 187,000 jobs, beating expectations, while average hourly earnings rose 4.3% for the year, below expectations. The data suggests a softening labor market, which may keep the Federal Reserve from raising interest rates.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. Dollar and Euro banknotes are seen in this illustration taken July 17, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Former Harrods owner Mohamed Al Fayed dies, aged 94
summary: Mohamed Al Fayed, the Egyptian business tycoon and former owner of Harrods, has died at the age of 94. Al Fayed controlled a vast empire of trophy properties and enterprises, including the Ritz Hotel in Paris and a fleet of 40 ships. He was known for his Anglophile tendencies and his attempts to influence British politics, but his life was marred by controversy, including the 1997 car crash that killed his son Dodi and Princess Diana. Al Fayed's net worth was estimated at $2 billion, and he had been denied British citizenship despite living in the country for decades.

images.alt_text: The new club, called The Residence, will open at the end of this year on the second floor of Cha House, a central Shanghai heritage building where a Harrods tea room and bar, which are open to public, are already located.

site_title: Indonesian rice prices surge as drought crimps harvest
summary: Indonesian rice prices have surged due to a severe drought affecting key growing regions in Asia, with prices rising as much as a fifth. The country, which typically imports rice from India, Thailand, and Vietnam, is turning to Cambodia and Myanmar as suppliers, but prices remain a concern ahead of elections in February. The government has launched a programme to boost output and has advanced its social assistance programme to provide more rice to lower-income households, but prices are expected to hit a multi-year high of 15,000 rupiah (S$1.32) a kg if the situation does not improve.

images.alt_text: The latest price jump increases stress on global food markets already roiled by extreme weather and the escalating conflict in Ukraine.

site_title: Tharman Shanmugaratnam leads with 70% of votes in presidential race: sample count
summary: Tharman Shanmugaratnam leads the presidential election with 70% of the votes in an early sample count, surpassing his closest rival, Tan Kin Lian. Former GIC chief investment officer Ng Kok Song secured 16% of the vote. Tharman expressed gratitude for the strong endorsement and thanked fellow candidates and Singaporeans for engaging calmly during the election. The results are subject to final counting and validation.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
A generic photo of a poll card that will be used for Friday's presidential election.
Long queues had formed at some polling stations even before voting started at 8 am on Friday.

site_title: Long queues on Polling Day morning due to system glitch
summary: Long queues formed at some polling stations in Singapore before voting started on Friday due to a system glitch with the e-registration system. At Henry Park Primary School, voters had to queue for nearly an hour after the polls opened at 8 am. Officials had to manually check identification documents and poll cards until the issue was resolved. The glitch affected several polling stations, causing delays and inconvenience to voters.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
This is the first presidential election where an official sample count result is made public.
As at 3pm, 2,004,961 Singaporeans – or about 74 per cent of the total number of eligible electors – had voted, said the Elections Department (ELD).
Voters queue at the polling station at Wisma Geylang Serai on Sept 1, 2023.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher after data point to softening labour market
summary: Wall Street opened higher on Friday after a report showed the US unemployment rate rose in August and wage growth slowed, sparking expectations that the Federal Reserve may pause interest rate hikes. The Dow Jones rose 154.33 points, or 0.44%, to 34,876.24, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained ground. The data suggests a potential softening of the labor market, which could lead to reduced pressure on the Fed to raise interest rates.

site_title: From holidays to mortgage waivers, UK homebuilders dish out freebies to revive sales
summary: UK homebuilders are offering various incentives, including holiday vouchers, discounts on down payments, and free modular kitchens, to boost sales amid high interest rates and dwindling demand. The incentives, which range from 1-6% of the house price, aim to make homes more affordable for first-time buyers and those with low deposits. Despite increasing costs for homebuilders, prices are holding up, with some builders reporting a 4-6.7% increase in average selling prices. The measures are seen as a desperate attempt to revive sales in the UK housing market, which is in its worst catastrophe since the 2008 global financial crisis.

images.alt_text: Nationwide Building Society said the average cost of a home fell 5.3 per cent in August from its peak in the year ago, the fastest pace since July 2009 when the global financial crisis was raging.

site_title: Eurozone August factory activity shows signs of recovery: PMI
summary: The eurozone's August factory activity showed signs of recovery, with the Hamburg Commercial Bank's PMI rising to a three-month high of 43.5 from 42.7 in July. Demand weakened to its lowest in almost a year, but the easing of downturn in manufacturing suggests the worst may be over for the bloc's factories. Germany, the eurozone's biggest economy, remained a negative outlier, contributing to discussions about it being the "sick man" of the region despite its diversified economy.

images.alt_text: The site in central Munich of a project planned by Euroboden, a property developer that has filed for insolvency.

site_title: Line Man Wongnai targets listing as early as 2025, says CFO
summary: Thai food delivery startup Line Man Wongnai has begun preparing for an initial public offering (IPO) and is targeting a listing as early as 2025. The company's chief financial officer, In Young Chung, sees Bangkok as its base case, but would consider a dual listing in the US if investor interest is sufficient. A successful IPO would be a landmark for startups in the region and a win for Line, the parent company of Line Man Wongnai. The company has been expanding its services through acquisitions, including FoodStory and Rabbit Line Pay.

images.alt_text: SoftBank joins a host of investors who have partially or fully exited the company, including US-based private equity firm Tiger Global, which sold its remaining holding for US$136 million on Monday.
Citi Research increases its target price on Grab to US$5.2 from US$4.8 on improving growth prospects.
Thai food delivery startup Line Man Wongnai seeks new investment, eyes IPO

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust to divest Japan property for S$95.5 million
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) has agreed to divest its Moriya Centre in Japan for S$95.5 million to a third-party buyer. The sale price is 12.2% higher than the property's latest valuation. The deal, expected to be completed by Q3 FY23/24, will have no material impact on MLT's net asset value and net property income. Following the divestment, MLT's portfolio will consist of 188 properties, and the trust's manager cited the sale as part of efforts to rejuvenate its portfolio through selective divestments.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai

site_title: Japan's economic output runs above capacity for first time in nearly 4 years
summary: Japan's economic output exceeded its full capacity for the first time in nearly 4 years, according to a government estimate, growing 0.4% in April-June. This marks the first increase in 15 quarters and suggests conditions for ending ultra-low interest rates are falling into place. The positive output gap indicates strong demand, typically leading to upward pressure on prices, and is a key factor in the Bank of Japan's assessment of whether to sustainably hit its 2% inflation target. The data follows the BOJ's shift away from massive monetary stimulus in July.

site_title: Beijing, Shanghai ease mortgage rules for first-time home buyers
summary: Beijing and Shanghai have announced eased mortgage rules for first-time home buyers, allowing them to qualify for preferential loans regardless of their previous credit records. The changes, effective immediately in Beijing and scheduled for Saturday in Shanghai, include smaller down-payment thresholds and lower mortgage rates. The move aims to revive China's crisis-hit property market, with all first-tier cities broadening the definition of first-home mortgage. The central government granted leeway for local officials to execute such policies, following a two-year property crisis that has shattered demand and raised concerns about the country's economy.

images.alt_text: The deposit rate cuts are the third such cut within a year, with the scale of cuts bigger than previous rounds in June and in September last year.
The property sector accounts for roughly a quarter of the world’s second-largest economy

site_title: In wake of Credit Suisse, Switzerland told to better prepare for bank failure
summary: Switzerland has been urged to better prepare for a bank failure following the collapse of Credit Suisse, with experts recommending improved coordination among authorities and greater authority for the regulator Finma to intervene. The country's reliance on two systemically relevant banks, Credit Suisse and UBS, holds combined assets of up to 140% of GDP. Experts criticize the government's handling of the crisis, saying policymakers failed to adequately supervise Credit Suisse and are now at risk if UBS were to fail.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Logos of Swiss banks UBS and Credit Suisse are seen in Zurich, Switzerland March 20, 2023. REUTERS/Denis Balibouse/File Photo

site_title: Huawei’s mystery phone shows wireless speeds as fast as Apple
summary: Huawei's Mate 60 Pro smartphone has demonstrated wireless speeds comparable to Apple's latest iPhones, exceeding 350 Mbps in tests on China Mobile's network. The device, which went on sale this week, is seen as a Chinese breakthrough despite US sanctions. Analysts suggest the phone's 5G chip may have been fabricated by Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corporation (SMIC), marking a milestone in China's semiconductor progression.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Huawei logo is seen at its booth during the Mobile World Congress in Shanghai, China June 28, 2023. REUTERS/Nicoco Chan/File Photo

site_title: Tesla launches pricier new Model 3, adds discounts for premium cars in US, China
summary: Tesla unveiled a restyled Model 3 with a longer driving range in China and other markets, starting at 12% higher than the previous model. The new version features a better acoustic system, improved interior, and display screen for back-seat passengers. The company also slashed prices of its premium cars in the US and China, aiming to boost sales. Deliveries in China are set for the fourth quarter, while in Australia, deliveries are scheduled for January.

images.alt_text: Neither Elon Musk nor a spokesman for the US Attorney’s office in Manhattan, which the Wall Street Journal said was carrying out the probe, immediately responded to requests for comment.
The lower import taxes could help Tesla sell its full range of models in India, and not just the new car it wants to make locally.
The new S and X models were priced at US$78,490 and US$88,490, respectively in the United States.

site_title: PwC Australia flags revenue hole, partner profit cut due to tax scandal legacy
summary: PwC Australia flags a double-digit revenue hole due to the spinoff of its government consulting business and costs from a tax scandal, which will leave partners taking a 30% income hit this financial year. The firm reported revenue of A$3.4 billion for the year ended June, up 11% from the previous year. The scandal led to the departure of 12 partners, including the former CEO, and investigations into the leaks have been commissioned.

images.alt_text: PwC has not publicly identified any client in relation to the scandal.
Three of the partners were singled out for actions that “failed to meet their professional responsibilities”.

PwC's brand is damaged by revelations that a former partner shared with colleagues confidential government plans to prevent tax avoidance, which were then used to pitch multinational companies for work.
The firm has already placed nine partners on leave and named four former partners directly involved in the breach who have since left the firm.

site_title: Japan capex growth weakens with companies wary about China slowdown
summary: Japan's capital expenditures grew 4.5% in April-June, the lowest in five quarters, amid concerns about a slowing Chinese economy and global economic uncertainty. The data reflects caution from Japanese companies, which are worried about a Chinese property bubble bursting and affecting demand for their goods. Corporate internal reserves rose to an all-time high, and corporate profits surged 11.6% in the second quarter. The slowdown in capital investments may lead to a revised down GDP growth rate of around 1% point, according to economists.

images.alt_text: Japan’s exports fell for the first time in more than two years in July, as sharp declines in shipments of chipmaking gear and parts outweighed a jump in demand for cars.

epa10590387 Pedestrians cross a street in Tokyo, Japan, 25 April 2023. The Japanese government's monthly economic report maintained a general assessment that the economy was recovering moderately, despite some weaknesses.  EPA-EFE/KIMIMASA MAYAMA

site_title: UK factory orders tumble in the face of higher rates: PMI
summary: The UK's factory sector suffered its weakest month since early in the Covid-19 crisis, with orders shrinking due to rising interest rates. The S&P Global/CIPS UK manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) fell to 43.0 from 45.3 in July, marking a sixth consecutive decline. Output and new orders contracted at rates rarely seen outside of crisis periods, while input costs fell at the quickest pace since January, potentially easing inflation pressures. The Bank of England is set to raise interest rates for the 15th time in a row on September 21.

images.alt_text: Germany, Europe’s biggest economy, remained a negative outlier among the big players, likely fuelling the discussion about it being the sick man of the region even though it is among one of the most diversified economies.

site_title: Japan's Topix ends at 33-year peak after bargain hunting
summary: Japan's Topix index reached a 33-year peak, closing at 2,349.75, after investors sought bargains and scooped up undervalued stocks. The broader index climbed 0.76% for the day and 3.7% for the week, led by Sony Group and financials. Individual investors, particularly those seeking high dividend payouts, drove the rally. Foreign investors, who had previously lifted the benchmark Nikkei to a 33-year high in June, took a pause from buying, but the market still surged.

images.alt_text: The Nikkei is forecast to trade at 34,000 at the end of this year according to the median estimate of 13 analysts polled Aug 9-21, up 7.7 per cent from Monday’s close of 31,565.64.

site_title: UK house prices fall the most in 14 years, says major mortgage lender
summary: UK house prices have fallen 5.3% in August from their peak a year ago, the largest decline in 14 years, according to Nationwide Building Society. The average home value now stands at £259,153, down £14,600 from August 2022. The decline is attributed to the cost-of-borrowing squeeze and is expected to intensify in the second half of the year, with economists forecasting a 10% slump in prices. The slowdown in the housing market poses a risk to Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's government ahead of an expected election next year.

images.alt_text: The S&P Global/CIPS UK manufacturing Purchasing Managers’ Index dropped for a sixth month in a row, falling to 43.0 from 45.3 in July.

site_title: ‘Barbie Botox’ goes viral but doctors inject caution
summary: A viral trend of "Barbie Botox" has emerged, where women are seeking toxin-based procedures to mimic Margot Robbie's slim, contoured necks. The procedure, also known as "Trap Tox," has been used to treat migraines and shoulder pain but is now being used as a cosmetic procedure. Doctors warn that this trend may lead to resistance among users and hinder medical use in the future, as the demand for botulinum toxins increases. The hashtag #BarbieBotox has gained 11.2 million views on TikTok.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Margot Robbie attends the European premiere of "Barbie" in London, Britain July 12, 2023. REUTERS/Maja Smiejkowska/File Photo

site_title: Japan sees hottest summer on record
summary: Japan experienced its hottest summer on record, with average summer temperatures significantly higher than usual in northern, eastern, and western Japan from June to August. This marks the country's hottest summer since temperature records began in 1898, according to Japan's weather agency. The extreme heat is attributed to "considerably higher" average summer temperatures in the affected regions.

images.alt_text: Grape pickers work in the vineyard of "Chateau de Sours" as they take part in an early morning harvest to avoid the day's heat in Saint-Quentin-de-Baron.

Scorched land following a forest fire in the Gale de Cima area in the municipality of Aljezur, south of Portugal, Aug 9, 2023. Next year could be even hotter than this year because of the Pacific warming phenomenon known as El Nino.
Temperatures have spiked across Asia, the US and Europe this year, such as in Spain (pictured).

site_title: US lawmaker promises 'resolute reaction' if Taiwan attacked
summary: US Congressman Rob Wittman has promised a "resolute reaction" if Taiwan is attacked, stating that any unprovoked attack would result in a strong response from the US. During a visit to Taipei, Wittman emphasized the importance of strength in maintaining peace and stability in the Indo-Pacific region. The US has been providing military aid to Taiwan, including direct aid for the first time, to boost its defenses against China's increasingly aggressive actions. The US remains Taiwan's key ally, despite officially recognizing Beijing.

images.alt_text: Authorities in China have so far resorted to a drip-feed of targeted measures, avoiding the big-bang stimulus approach they deployed during the 2008 global financial crisis amid concerns over elevated debt levels.
China’s manufacturing activity fell for a fifth consecutive month in August.

site_title: Airline SAS to boost capacity after first quarterly profit since 2019
summary: SAS, a struggling Scandinavian airline, reported its first quarterly pre-tax profit since 2019, with a 464 million Swedish kronor (S$57.1 million) profit in the third quarter to July 31. The airline plans to boost winter capacity, citing lower fuel costs, higher ticket prices, and strong demand. Despite labour issues and restructuring challenges, SAS has seen a surge in air travel demand, defying economic uncertainty. The airline now aims to complete its restructuring process by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An IndiGo Airlines aircraft arrives at a gate of the domestic airport in Mumbai February 22, 2012.  Picture taken on February 22, 2012. REUTERS/Vivek Prakash (INDIA - Tags: TRANSPORT BUSINESS)/File Photo

site_title: Australian central bank to hold rates 'higher for longer', former official says
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) is likely to hold interest rates at their peak for an extended period, probably through 2024, according to Jonathan Kearns, the former head of domestic markets. The RBA left its cash rate unchanged at 4.1% for the second straight month, with cumulative rate rises working to cool demand as inflation eases. Kearns believes the RBA will gradually lower rates to a neutral level once it begins to dial back from its current restrictive setting, marking a shift away from its recent tightening cycle.

images.alt_text: The firm has been dogged since January by a national scandal over revelations a former partner leaked confidential tax documents which were then used to drum up work around the world.

site_title: Spam call filter firm is rare beneficiary of Fukushima furore
summary: Tobila Systems, a Japanese call-screening software developer, has seen its shares surge over 10% since Japan began releasing treated Fukushima nuclear plant wastewater, sparking a torrent of angry calls from China. In response, Tobila announced a new feature to block overseas calls from China, aiming to mitigate the impact on its corporate customers. This rare beneficiary among Japanese stocks highlights the economic fallout of Japan's decision, affecting companies reliant on China, such as Shiseido and Nissui. The move's long-term impact on Tobila's revenue remains to be seen.

images.alt_text: Police and security personnel stand outside the entrance of the Japanese embassy in Beijing on Aug 26, 2023. Security has been increased at the embassy since the release of waste water at the Fukushima nuclear plant in Japan on Aug 24.

Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida addresses a press conference during a visit to Qatar on July 18, 2023, as he wraps up a Gulf tour centred on energy security and cooperation with Tokyo's main suppliers. (Photo by KARIM JAAFAR / AFP)

FILE PHOTO: An aerial view shows the storage tanks for treated water at the tsunami-crippled Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant in Okuma town, Fukushima prefecture, Japan February 13, 2021, in this photo taken by Kyodo. site_title: IMF sees interest rates remaining high for 'quite some time'
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) expects interest rates to remain high for "quite some time" due to external conditions becoming more challenging for emerging markets, including rising geopolitical fragmentation, tough financial conditions, and growing climate change costs. According to IMF First Deputy Managing Director Gita Gopinath, emerging markets must rebuild fiscal buffers, boost revenues, and diversify trade to mitigate these challenges. The IMF warns that these conditions will lead to a more volatile and uncertain future for emerging markets.

images.alt_text: A plant in a nursery in Zimbabwe being watered. The IMF report says that 39 countries that are home to nearly a billion people and 43 per cent of the world's poor are classified as fragile and conflict-affected states. More than half of these nations disproportionately hit by climate change are in Africa.

site_title: China to take more action to revive property sector: sources
summary: China is set to take further action to revive its struggling property sector, including relaxing home-purchase restrictions and lifting price caps on new homes. Regulators aim to boost consumer demand over the next few months, following existing policies that have failed to sustain a sector rebound. The measures, guided by the State Council, include lifting curbs in non-core districts of major cities and allowing property developers to raise or lower home prices.

images.alt_text: Concerns are mounting over whether the world’s second-largest economy is coming closer to a crunch point.

Authorities in China have so far resorted to a drip-feed of targeted measures, avoiding the big-bang stimulus approach they deployed during the 2008 global financial crisis amid concerns over elevated debt levels.
Temporary factory closures due to high temperatures and floods reportedly pushed up unfinished workloads.
The PBOC has lowered that one-year medium-term lending facility rate twice this year, most recently a surprise reduction earlier in August.
Russian oil exports have continued despite prices rising above price caps as the West is keen to maintain global supplies and keep prices down.

site_title: About 85% of voters have voted in presidential election as of 5pm: ELD
summary: As of 5pm on September 1, 2023, about 85% of eligible Singaporean voters, or 2,302,996 people, have cast their ballots in the presidential election. Voting was reported to be widespread, with voters from various backgrounds, including the elderly and those with disabilities, participating at 1,264 polling stations. Those who have not yet voted are advised to cast their ballots before the polls close at 8pm.

site_title: India’s rooftops see solar surge as companies seek green energy
summary: India is witnessing a surge in rooftop solar installations, with companies on pace to install 4 gigawatts of panels by March 31, nearly doubling the previous record. Falling panel prices and the drive for clean energy to meet climate goals are driving the uptake, with businesses signing corporate power purchase agreements to meet net zero emissions commitments. The trend is attributed to businesses taking advantage of lower costs, with solar module prices hitting a record low this year.

site_title: Bitter rivals Arsenal and Manchester United collide in early EPL blockbuster
summary: Arsenal and Manchester United face off in a crucial English Premier League (EPL) match at the Emirates Stadium, with the Gunners seeking to exploit the Red Devils' poor away form. Both teams have struggled to start the season, with Arsenal narrowly scraping past Nottingham Forest and Crystal Palace, and Manchester United largely unconvincing at home. The match is also a high-stakes rivalry, with pride and bragging rights on the line. With Manchester United missing key players, the stage is set for a pivotal clash that could impact their EPL title push.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
Read about a Brazilian player being greeted by thousands of fans and whisked off in a Rolls-Royce to banquet with royalty, and Neymar springs to mind.
With record crowds and TV viewership, the Women's World Cup raises hopes of narrowing the financial gap with men's football.

site_title: Dutch government walks back capacity cut at Schiphol amid airlines protest
summary: The Dutch government has walked back its planned flight cut at Schiphol Airport, allowing the airport to operate up to 452,000 annual flights by November 2024, a reduction of 9.5% from 2019 levels. The move follows legal challenges from airlines, including KLM, which argued that the cuts harm connectivity and the local economy. The government had previously proposed banning night flights and private jets, but will scrap these plans. The decision is seen as a compromise between the government's aim to minimize noise and the airlines' concerns about the impact on the local economy.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: KLM airplanes are seen parked at Schiphol Airport in Amsterdam, Netherlands April 2, 2020. REUTERS/Piroschka van de Wouw/File Photo

site_title: Market cap of Singapore stocks down 4.8% in August as China woes, weak data bite
summary: Singapore's market capitalization declined 4.8% in August, largely due to China's economic slowdown and weaker economic data. The Straits Times Index fell 4.2% to S$536.8 billion, with the construction sector experiencing the largest month-on-month decline. Analysts attribute the downturn to the potential default of Chinese property developer debt, which has had a spillover effect on Singapore-listed property companies. Despite this, institutions and retail investors were net buyers of Singapore stocks in August, with real estate investment trusts, telecommunications, and technology counters seeing the most net retail inflows.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
Fitch Solutions unit BMI notes that the year-to-date average for crude palm oil prices stands at RM3,805.20 per tonne, versus last year’s average of RM4,910.
Responding to queries from SGX, HPL unintentionally reminded investors that Ong Beng Seng's real estate interests are not entirely held under the public-listed company

site_title: India's antitrust body allows Tata SIA merger with Air India
summary: India's Competition Commission of India (CCI) has approved the merger of Tata SIA Airlines (Vistara) with Air India, allowing Singapore Airlines to acquire shares in the newly formed entity. The CCI had raised concerns about the merged entity's potential monopoly in the domestic market, but ultimately found that the Tata Group's market share could be more than 50% in seven markets. The deal is expected to pose a challenge to local rival IndiGo, the current market leader.

images.alt_text: Vistara Airlines launched flights to Singapore in July 2019 and now flies to Delhi, Mumbai and Pune. Its name is derived from vistaar, which means infinite expanse in Sanskrit. Its logo is a star based on a yantra, a geometric Hindu design believed to have cosmic powers, and a compass rose. As one of Asia's most connected international aviation hubs, Changi Airport links Singapore to some 140 cities globally, with over 90 airlines operating more than 5,500 weekly flights. The Straits Times look into the lesser-known tail fins seen at the world's best airport.

site_title: Why is China’s economy slowing down and could it get worse?
summary: China's economy is slowing down due to a property market downturn, with troubles at major developer Country Garden in focus. Unlike in the West, Chinese consumers didn't experience a post-pandemic spending spree, instead choosing to save. This, combined with government efforts to curb debt and stabilize the economy, has led to concerns that the world's second-largest economy is approaching a crunch point. Policymakers are trying to address these issues, but the outlook remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: Authorities in China have so far resorted to a drip-feed of targeted measures, avoiding the big-bang stimulus approach they deployed during the 2008 global financial crisis amid concerns over elevated debt levels.
Temporary factory closures due to high temperatures and floods reportedly pushed up unfinished workloads.

site_title: China issues new 2023 batch of 15 million tons of fuel product export quotas
summary: China has issued 15 million metric tons of oil product export quotas in its third batch for 2023, bringing the total volume to 45.99 million metric tons. The quotas include 12 million tons of refined products and 3 million tons of marine fuel, allocated to seven companies. This increases from the same period last year, with previous batches totaling 12 million tons in May and 18.99 million tons in January.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Oil and gas tanks are seen at an oil warehouse at a port in Zhuhai, China October 22, 2018. REUTERS/Aly Song

site_title: Asia’s manufacturing slump worsens as China curbs demand
summary: Asia's manufacturing activity slumped further in August due to weak demand, particularly in China. Factories in Taiwan, South Korea, and Japan experienced weaker new orders, output, and export sales. South-east Asia, which was a recent bright spot, saw its gauges slip into the red for the first time since 2021. China's economic slowdown is curbing demand for exports, and Asian economies rely heavily on China as their biggest trading partner. The region's manufacturing sector is unlikely to recover until global economic conditions improve.

images.alt_text: Temporary factory closures due to high temperatures and floods reportedly pushed up unfinished workloads.

site_title:
From war bunker to penthouse to market flop: 
how Germany’s property boom ended
summary: Germany's property boom has ended due to a sharp rise in interest rates, soaring energy and building costs, and the pandemic, war in Ukraine, inflation, and interest rates. The country's largest property developer, Euroboden, has filed for insolvency after its penthouse, originally built as a Nazi-era air raid shelter, failed to sell. The developer, Stefan Hoeglmaier, and his company have blamed the market environment for deteriorating considerably. Insolvency lawyers and industry professionals fear the downturn could be deeper than the 1990s crash, with many developers running out of steam.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This file photo taken on May 29, 2020 shows a general view of residential buildings with apartments in Berlin. - In Germany's capital Berlin, a citizens' initiative referendum aimed at "expropriating" the large real estate companies puts the subject of rising rents at the heart of the legislative and municipal elections that will take place on September 26, as more and more inhabitants struggle to pay for their accommodation. (Photo by Tobias SCHWARZ / AFP)

site_title: China new home prices fall for fourth month, sales slump: survey
summary: China's new home prices fell 0.01% month-on-month in August, marking the fourth consecutive decline, according to a private survey. Despite government support measures, the property sector continues to struggle with a debt crisis, with new home sales declining 39.2% year-on-year. Only 35 cities saw an increase in new home prices, and the sector's downward spiral since 2021 has dragged on China's economy and global financial markets. The property sector's weakness persists despite recent rate cuts and preferential loan offers for first-time homebuyers.

images.alt_text: Authorities in China have so far resorted to a drip-feed of targeted measures, avoiding the big-bang stimulus approach they deployed during the 2008 global financial crisis amid concerns over elevated debt levels.
Temporary factory closures due to high temperatures and floods reportedly pushed up unfinished workloads.

site_title: Malaysia to allocate RM8.2 billion to fund national industrial master plan
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim unveiled the New Industrial Master Plan (NIMP) 2030, allocating RM8.2 billion to enhance manufacturers' competitiveness. The 7-year plan requires an estimated RM95 billion investment, with private sector funding expected to dominate. The plan aims to attract domestic and foreign direct investment, focusing on key sectors such as electric vehicles, renewable energy, and artificial intelligence. NIMP 2030 is expected to increase the manufacturing sector's value to RM587.5 billion by 2030 and boost median salaries by 9.6%.

images.alt_text: An aerial view taken on March 9, 2023 shows vessels identified by the Philippine Coast Guard as a Chinese maritime militia vessel near Thitu Island in the South China Sea. - As a Philippine Coast Guard plane carrying journalists flew over the Spratly Islands in the hotly disputed South China Sea, a Chinese voice issued a stern command over the radio: "Leave immediately." (Photo by JAM STA ROSA / AFP)
Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim said there is a strong interest  for international collaboration that will provide additional avenues to decarbonise.

site_title: US providing up to US$12 billion to retrofit auto plants for EVs
summary: The US government is providing up to $12 billion to help automakers retrofit their facilities to produce electric vehicles (EVs) and hybrids. The funding, including $10 billion from the US Energy Department, aims to support projects in auto-making communities and retain workers amid the transition to EVs. The administration seeks to have EVs represent at least half of new car sales in the US by 2030. The move comes amid tense negotiations between Detroit auto companies and the United Auto Workers union, which has raised concerns about job security.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: VinFast electric vehicles are parked before delivery to their first customers at a store in Los Angeles, California, U.S.,  March 1, 2023. REUTERS/Lisa Baertlein/File Photo

site_title: Builders drive Swedish bankruptcies to the highest level in decades
summary: A record number of Swedish companies, including several large builders, have filed for bankruptcy, reaching the highest level since 1999. The construction industry accounts for eight of the ten largest bankruptcies in August, driven by a rapid slowdown in new home construction. The number of company defaults increased by 38% in August, with 5,000 defaults in the first eight months of the year, according to a credit reference agency. This trend is expected to weigh on the Swedish economy, compounded by declining consumer spending.

site_title: Indonesia August inflation rises modestly despite climbing rice prices
summary: Indonesia's annual inflation rose 3.27% in August, within Bank Indonesia's target range of 2-4%. Rice prices, however, surged 13.76% in August, the highest since June 2012, due to drought linked to El Niño. Despite this, annual core inflation eased to 2.18%, and consumer prices fell 0.02% on a monthly basis. The central bank approved an import quota to boost rice supplies, and economists predict limited further increase in rice prices and manageable headline inflation.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - An aerial view taken on August 20, 2023 shows buildings and houses under hazy skies in Jakarta. Jakarta and its surrounds form a megalopolis of about 30 million people, and its airborne concentration of the tiny particles known as PM2.5 has outpaced other heavily polluted cities such as Riyadh, Doha and Lahore of late. (Photo by Bagus SARAGIH / AFP)
Last week, the central bank announced that it would hold twice weekly auctions of Bank Indonesia Rupiah Securities.

site_title: Philippines curbs rice prices as inflation worry mounts
summary: The Philippines has implemented price ceilings for rice, capping the price at 41 pesos (S$0.98) per kilogram for regular-milled rice and 45 pesos (S$0.99) per kilogram for well-milled rice, amid rising inflation concerns. This move aims to curb domestic price manipulation and protect consumers. The price ceilings will remain in effect until President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. lifts them. The move follows a 4.2% rise in rice inflation in July, the highest since 2019, driven by factors such as the Russia-Ukraine conflict, India's export ban, and unpredictable oil prices.

images.alt_text: Workers unload sacks of rice imported from Thailand from a cargo ship at Malahayati Port in Krueng Raya, Indonesia's Aceh province, on June 22, 2023. (Photo by CHAIDEER MAHYUDDIN / AFP)
India, which accounts for 40 per cent of world rice exports, sells the staple to more than 150 countries, including a few poor and vulnerable countries in Africa and Asia.

Farm labourers plant rice saplings in a field on the outskirts of Ahmedabad, India, July 21, 2023.

site_title: China ramps up campaign to boost fragile economy, currency
summary: China has intensified its efforts to boost its fragile economy and support its currency, with the central bank announcing a cut to foreign currency reserve requirements for financial institutions. The move, effective September 15, aims to boost the yuan's appeal and stabilize the currency, which has fallen 5% this year. Additionally, authorities have introduced fresh stimulus for the property sector and expanded tax breaks for child and parental care, as well as education. The measures are part of a drip-feed of targeted measures to shore up confidence in the world's second-largest economy, which is facing challenges from a persistent housing crisis and waning global demand.

images.alt_text: Temporary factory closures due to high temperatures and floods reportedly pushed up unfinished workloads.

The Country Garden Holdings Co. headquarters in Foshan, China, on Tuesday, Aug. 22, 2023. Country Garden, the distressed Chinese developer that earlier this month missed interest payments on some dollar bonds, is leaving investors in the dark about the exact date the grace period ends. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as traders prepare for US jobs data
summary: Asia markets experienced a mixed trading session on September 1, with Tokyo, Seoul, Shanghai, Taipei, Manila, and Jakarta rising, but Sydney and Wellington falling. The mixed performance came ahead of the US jobs report and following data showing slightly increased inflation. Investors are also assessing China's property sector support measures. The US jobs report is expected to impact interest rates and global economic trends.

images.alt_text: In early Wednesday trade, Tokyo, Hong Kong, Sydney, Singapore and Jakarta financial markets rose, but Shanghai, Seoul, Wellington, Taipei and Manila fell.

site_title: Inflation has been easing fast, but wild cards lie ahead
summary: The US Federal Reserve's preferred inflation measure, the Personal Consumption Expenditures (PCE) index, is expected to tick up to 4.2% or 4.3% in a report on Thursday, after volatile food and fuel costs are stripped out. Despite this, economists are cautiously optimistic that inflation will ease later this year and into 2024, driven by slowing price increases and lower consumer expectations. However, uncertainties, such as rising gas prices, travel costs, and healthcare prices, could potentially hinder progress. Policymakers remain vigilant, with Fed Chair Jerome Powell vowing to continue efforts to control inflation.

images.alt_text: US-based employers announced 75,151 job cuts in August. A significant portion of the announced layoffs arose from the approximately 30,000 workers reported to have lost their jobs after Yellow, one of the country’s largest trucking companies, filed for bankruptcy.

Times Square, New York City. Consumer spending, which accounts for more than two-thirds of US economic activity, went up by 0.8 per cent in July, the Commerce Department reported on Thursday (Aug 31).
Even with a more tempered pace of hiring, the labour market remains resilient.
Large public companies may also be seeing a renewed upswing in profits.

site_title: Swedish home buyers cancel bookings on new houses at record rate
summary: Swedish households are canceling new home reservations at a record rate, with 65% of contracts for planned dwellings canceled in the past six months. This is the highest share since 2014, indicating a sharp decline in demand for new homes due to a cooling housing market. The construction industry is calling for government intervention to prop up demand and support struggling builders. With construction of only 25,000 housing units expected this year, the sector fears a further drop in activity and potential bankruptcies.

images.alt_text: In 2023, calendar-adjusted gross domestic product is likely to shrink by 0.9 per cent, Swedbank says.

site_title: Gold rises, set for second weekly gain as focus flips to US jobs data
summary: Gold prices rose on Friday, poised for a second weekly gain, as the US jobs data later this week may limit interest rate hikes this year. US gold futures climbed 0.2% to $1,969.40, while spot gold gained 0.2% to $1,942.56 per ounce. The US dollar and Treasury yields were expected to end the week lower, making gold attractive for other currency holders. This follows a mixed European Central Bank inflation report and a decline in factory activity in Japan.

images.alt_text: Gold may extend gains to US$1,948 per ounce, as it has cleared a resistance at US$1,936, said Reuters technical analyst Wang Tao.

site_title: China’s August factory activity picks up unexpectedly: Caixin PMI
summary: China's factory activity unexpectedly returned to expansion in August, with the Caixin PMI rising to 51.0, beating forecasts of 49.3. Supply, domestic demand, and employment improved, suggesting efforts to revive growth are having an effect. However, the data also showed deepening declines in new export orders, with backlogs of work rising for the third straight month. Analysts caution that it's too early to determine if the economy has recovered meaningfully, citing a worsening property downturn and weak household consumption.

images.alt_text: China's official PMI rose to 49.7 from 49.3 in July, according to the National Bureau of Statistics, staying below the 50-point level demarcating contraction from expansion.
The PBOC has lowered that one-year medium-term lending facility rate twice this year, most recently a surprise reduction earlier in August.
Russian oil exports have continued despite prices rising above price caps as the West is keen to maintain global supplies and keep prices down.

site_title: Most Apac banks sufficiently diversified, capitalised to weather property downturn: S&P
summary: Asia-Pacific banks are well-equipped to withstand a property downturn due to their diversified lending and adequate capitalization, according to S&P Global Ratings. The region's banking system is closely regulated and built to handle frequent bouts of volatility. While the property sector is weak in some economies, such as China, no Asian-Pacific banking system is in significant difficulty yet. The ratings agency's report suggests that banks in the region can manage the economic impact of a property downturn.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
China’s real estate sector is now unravelling, with Country Garden Holdings posting a record loss and risks spreading to the country’s US$60 trillion financial system.
China’s central bank kept a key interest rate that guides mortgages on hold and made a smaller-than-expected cut to another rate in August.
Property can be attractive to people looking for safe havens, including money launderers.
Beijing has been under pressure to step up efforts to bolster growth amid material headwinds, including financial stability risks, as its economic growth moderates.

site_title: Water-efficiency efforts expected to mitigate price hike for major manufacturers
summary: Singapore's upcoming 18.2% water price hike will affect major industries such as semiconductor and pharmaceutical manufacturing, but efforts to increase water efficiency are expected to mitigate the impact. Most new semiconductor fabrication facilities in Singapore are designed to recycle over half their water usage. Large-scale industrial users can reduce water consumption through technologies and practices, such as water-saving technologies and recycling. Smaller businesses, particularly in food and beverage manufacturing, may need to absorb higher costs or pass them on to consumers. The government aims to keep the impact manageable, with three-quarters of businesses paying less than S$25 more for water every month.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Paige Lim
A kitchen worker washing cutlery under a running tap at a cafe in Raffles Place.

site_title: Presidential election: Singaporeans advised to vote throughout the day, long morning queues eased
summary: Singaporeans are advised to cast their votes throughout the day in the presidential election, following long morning queues at some polling stations. The Elections Department reported that queues had improved at most polling stations, with some stations experiencing waits of up to 40 minutes. Technical issues with the voter registration system were also reported, but are being resolved. The long queues were attributed to issues with the voting machines and a lack of staff at polling stations.

images.alt_text: This is the first presidential election where an official sample count result is made public.
A generic photo of a poll card that will be used for Friday's presidential election.
Sep 14 will be the inauguration day for the newly-elected president.
From left: Ng Kok Song, Tharman Shanmugaratnam, and Tan Kin Lian. Political impartiality was one of the hot topics in the candidates' broadcasts.
(L-R) Ng Kok Song, Tharman Shanmugaratnam, and Tan Kin Lian.

site_title: Barclays sets aside balance sheet cash for private credit push
summary: Barclays has set aside cash from its balance sheet to invest in private credit, a move aimed at competing with private credit funds in the $1.5 trillion US market. The bank plans to grow this strategy into the billions of dollars, led by Emily Knickel, the head of principal investing in New York. Barclays will purchase debt originated by the bank and participate in new financings arranged by direct lending funds. This move follows a similar strategy by other banks seeking to gain a foothold in the private debt market.

images.alt_text: A Barclays Plc bank branch in London, UK, on Tuesday, July 25, 2023. Barclays are due to report first-half results on Thursday, July 27. Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg

site_title: Hong Kong building public housing on golf course in snub to old elite
summary: Hong Kong's government is taking back 32 hectares of land from the Fanling Golf Course to build 12,000 public housing apartments, a move that has sparked opposition from the city's powerful business elites. The decision reflects the government's urgency to address the city's housing crisis, which ranks as the most unaffordable in the world. The move also marks a shift in the balance of power in Hong Kong, as old business elites are losing influence to more pro-Beijing loyalists. The project has been met with criticism from business leaders and lawmakers, who argue it will harm the development of golf in Hong Kong and create social divisions.

images.alt_text: Emergency response teams use rafts to help transport residents along a flooded road in Quezon City, Philippines, after it was hit by Typhoon Saola. Hong Kong is making preparations for a possible direct hit by the typhoon.
Hong Kong's home prices have retreated again since May after a short-lived bounce early this year from a 15 per cent decline in 2022.
Hong Kong's best-known retail and nightlife districts are a shadow of their former selves.

site_title: Commerzbank vows 3 billion euro payouts over 3 years
summary: Commerzbank has pledged to return 3 billion euros (S$4.3 billion) to shareholders over the next three years, below its previously stated range of 3-5 billion euros. The German lender aims to achieve this through dividends and share buybacks, maintaining a minimum CET1 ratio of 13.5%. The bank's CEO, Manfred Knof, expressed confidence in the bank's development, while Citigroup analysts predict a potential negative reaction to the news.

images.alt_text: epa10493444 Banners of German Commerzbank AG hang at the building of the Frankfurt Stock Exchange in Frankfurt am Main, Germany, 27 February 2023. Commerzbank AG will return into the group of 40 businesses listed in German Stock Market Index DAX with opening of stock trading on 27 February morning. The bank lost its rank in the DAX in autumn 2018 due to severe loss in their stocks value. The bank, that was one of the founding businesses of the DAX, can now return due to the withdrawal of the Linde company from trading at the Franfurt Stock exchange, the 'Deutsche Boerse Group' said on their website.  EPA-EFE/RONALD WITTEK

A man shelters from the rain under an umbrella as he walks past the Euro currency sign in front of the former European Central Bank (ECB) building in Frankfurt am Main, western Germany, on July 27, 2023 ahead of thr ECB's monthly announcement on eurozone monetary policy. (Photo by Kirill KUDRYAVTSEV / AFP)
German consumer prices, harmonised to compare with other European Union countries, rise by 4.3 per cent on the year in September.

site_title: China’s BYD adds second model to Japan EV line-up
summary: China's BYD is set to start selling its second electric vehicle model in Japan this month, the Dolphin car, which will be available for order from September 20. The model starts from 116,800 yuan (S$22,086) in China and will be sold only in Japan, with no plug-in hybrid options. BYD aims to open over 100 dealerships in Japan by the end of 2025, following the opening of its first dealership in Yokohama in February, where it has sold about 700 ATTO 3 electric sports utility vehicles.

images.alt_text: BYD has sold 1.5 million fully-electric and hybrid passenger vehicles this year through July, halfway to its annual target.
BYD’s robust financial performance will help as it navigates another period of discounting in the world’s biggest auto market.
BYD said on Monday its unit struck a deal with US-based manufacturing firm Jabil Inc’s Singaporean division to buy its mobility business in China for 15.8 billion yuan (S$2.9 billion)
BYD's net earnings for the six months ending Jun 30 reached 10.95 billion yuan, up 204.7 per cent from 3.6 billion yuan a year earlier, on a 72.7 per cent rise in revenue to 260.12 billion yuan.

site_title:
Major Chinese banks 
cut deposit rates as efforts 
to prop the economy grow
summary: China's five largest banks, including Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, cut deposit rates by 5-25 basis points in a coordinated effort to ease pressure on shrinking margins. The move aims to prop up the struggling property sector and faltering economy. This is the third time deposit rates have been cut within a year, with larger cuts than previous rounds. The central bank and financial regulator also announced that first-time home buyers with mortgages can apply for lower interest rates starting September 25.

images.alt_text: Temporary factory closures due to high temperatures and floods reportedly pushed up unfinished workloads.

The Country Garden Holdings Co. headquarters in Foshan, China, on Tuesday, Aug. 22, 2023. Country Garden, the distressed Chinese developer that earlier this month missed interest payments on some dollar bonds, is leaving investors in the dark about the exact date the grace period ends. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: HSBC’s Cowper-Coles to exit after deploring UK’s stance on China
summary: HSBC's head of public affairs, Sherard Cowper-Coles, is set to leave the bank after making controversial comments about the UK government's handling of its relationship with China. Cowper-Coles criticized the UK for being "weak" and allowing itself to be strong-armed by the US into cutting back business dealings with China. The comments sparked a backlash from some British lawmakers, and the exact reason for his departure is unclear. Cowper-Coles' exit comes as businesses operating in China struggle to navigate rising geopolitical tensions and the West's efforts to dial back commercial ties.

images.alt_text: The transaction, the financial details of which were not immediately known, will also see Asia-focussed HSBC taking over “a few hundreds” of Citi’s China-based staff, said one of the sources.
Credit also grew more than expected, potentially suggesting some stability in household demand for mortgages as authorities work to bolster the real estate market.
The initiative, called Endoxa, is the first bank-led consortium to tackle global rules on disclosures reporting, according to Goldman Sachs.

site_title: A sea change: Howard Marks on the end of easy money
summary: Legendary investor Howard Marks believes the end of accommodative central bank monetary policy marks a new era in financial markets, forcing investors to rethink their approach. Marks predicts interest rates will not return to ultra-low levels, instead, they will stabilize and potentially rise, making credit investments more attractive. He notes this marks the third sea change in his 54-year career, following the 1970s rise of non-investment-grade bonds and the 1980s decline in interest rates. Marks advises investors to focus on risk-return thinking, allocating capital to credit investments and considering alternative asset classes, such as private equity and private credit, to achieve high returns in a higher interest rate environment.

images.alt_text: Mark Fortune
Investors can now potentially get solid returns from credit instruments, and no longer have to rely as heavily on riskier investments to achieve their overall return targets.
Now may be an ideal time to lean into a stressed and distressed debt mandate. The quality of companies experiencing credit stress has never been higher.

site_title: Niks Professional lodges preliminary prospectus for Catalist IPO
summary: Niks Professional, a Singapore-based dermatology and aesthetic medical services provider, has lodged a preliminary prospectus for a Catalist listing. The company, founded in 1998 by a husband-and-wife team, operates three clinics and distributes its skincare products to 11 regional agents in China. Despite recording a net profit of S$2.8 million in FY2022, the company's revenue fell 5.2% and net profit declined 35.3% in Q1 this year. Niks Professional plans to use the IPO funds to open new clinics, expand its skincare product-distribution business, and engage in strategic alliances.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
The three listings that have taken place on SGX's junior Catalist board so far this year have, raised just S$27.9 million in proceeds.

site_title: Dollar set for best quarter in a year
summary: The US dollar is on track to end the quarter up 2.8% after an 11th straight weekly rally, its longest such run in nine years. Despite falling 0.4% to 105.70, the dollar index is still expected to achieve its best quarterly gain in a year due to a combination of factors, including rising US Treasury yields and oil prices. The yen has benefited from the dollar's decline, trading near 150 per dollar, a level that could trigger currency intervention.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index is down 0.3 per cent on the day at 106.3, though it is still on track for an 11th straight week of gains.

site_title: Holding cash can be riskier than equity investments
summary: Holding cash is not a safe option due to its vulnerability to inflation, according to an Endowus report. With elevated core inflation in Singapore and concerns about market risks, 69% of Singaporeans feel pressure to save more. As a result, investors are reluctant to invest in the market, leading banks to offer higher deposit rates. This shift highlights the need for strategies to maximise money growth in a high-inflation climate, where holding cash is no longer a luxury but a necessity.

images.alt_text: The image of Yusof Ishak, former president of Singapore, is displayed on a Singapore one hundred dollar banknote in an arranged photograph in Bangkok, Thailand, on Friday, Sept. 18, 2015. Singapore's challenge is to find a way to keep its economy energized and sustainable for the next 10 to 15 years, with low single-digit growth expected to be considered a good performance in the future, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said Saturday. Photographer: Brent Lewin/Bloomberg

site_title: There’s a new way to prove a US$38,200 watch is the real thing
summary: Luxury brands such as Panerai and Prada are utilizing blockchain technology to verify the authenticity and origin of their high-end products, including watches and handbags. This move aims to increase transparency and trust in the luxury market. The technology allows for the creation of a digital record of the product's history, ensuring its legitimacy and preventing counterfeiting. This approach is a step towards the widespread adoption of blockchain technology in the luxury industry, as predicted by digital prophets, and may pave the way for greater accountability and consumer confidence.

images.alt_text: Louis Vuitton, Cartier, Prada offer blockchain solution to ensure authenticity

FILE — Balenciaga sneakers in New York, July 18, 2018. “When prices are shooting up and you feel the fear of missing out, you can talk yourself into imagining intrinsic value in anything,” writes New York Times columnist Farhad Manjoo. (Tony Cenicola/The New York Times)

site_title: Messi's Miami fans upset with season ticket price hike
summary: Inter Miami, co-owned by Lionel Messi, has doubled season ticket prices for next season, with cheapest tickets rising from $485 to $884. Seats offering a broader view have increased from $3,600 to $7,650. Fans are upset, with some considering not renewing due to the significant price hike, which may damage the team's ability to build a fan base. The price increase reflects changes on the field, including Messi's arrival, and is expected to affect season ticket holders who are already protected from single match ticket price increases.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - Inter Miami's Argentine forward Lionel Messi celebrates scoring his team's third goal during the round of 32 Leagues Cup football match between Inter Miami CF and Orlando City SC at DRV PNK Stadium in Fort Lauderdale, Florida, on August 2, 2023. (Photo by GIORGIO VIERA / AFP)

site_title: South Korea factory activity shrinks at quicker pace in August: PMI
summary: South Korea's factory activity contracted at a faster pace in August, extending its longest-ever slump with a PMI reading of 48.9. This marks the 14th consecutive month of contraction, with new export orders and output also declining. Suppliers' delivery times worsened, and input prices rose due to competitive pressures. Despite this, manufacturers' optimism for future output reached its highest level since June 2022, signaling some hope of a recovery in demand. The slowdown is attributed to weak demand, particularly from China, and ongoing semiconductor shortages.

images.alt_text: South Korea is seen as a bellwether for global trade because it exports goods that make their way into a wide variety of products, including machines, displays and refined oil.

site_title: Knowledge workers are now panopticon prisoners
summary: Knowledge workers are increasingly being monitored by their employers, mirroring Frederick Taylor's 20th-century theory of "scientific management." With the rise of information technology, companies are using tools such as employee monitoring software, RFID badges, and video analytics to track workers' productivity, collaboration, and even moods. This has led to a "panopticon" work environment, where workers are constantly being watched and judged. Employers argue that this is necessary to prevent fraud, protect proprietary information, and boost productivity. However, critics argue that this surveillance regime can lead to alienation, mistrust, and decreased creativity, as workers feel micromanaged and their autonomy is eroded.

images.alt_text: BT
Ask sincere questions, check your own biases, have empathy -- some ways to check if your business culture needs improvement.
Older workers want one thing more than anything else. They want to make a contribution to their society.

site_title: UBS targets lost Credit Suisse assets after posting record bank profit
summary: UBS posted a record bank profit after acquiring Credit Suisse, but now faces the challenge of winning back $200 billion in lost assets. CEO Sergio Ermotti aims to realign the combined bank around a money management business and has started to see inflows at Credit Suisse's wealth business. UBS plans to cut 30% of its 120,000 global workforce, with some job cuts expected in the investment bank. Despite headwinds from departing Credit Suisse private bankers, Ermotti is optimistic that UBS can recapture lost assets, citing a similar experience from its 2008 financial crisis recovery.

images.alt_text: UBS said it expected to secure more than US$10 billion in cost reductions by the end of 2026 from integrating Credit Suisse.
Logos of Swiss banks Credit Suisse and UBS are seen before a news conference in Zurich Switzerland, August 30, 2023.  REUTERS/Denis Balibouse

UBS has already indicated that the results should include an exceptional accounting gain of nearly $35 billion due to the difference between the purchase price and the recognised net assets of Credit Suisse.
In March, the Swiss government, central bank and financial regulator rushed through a rescue deal for Credit Suisse, resulting in UBS and Credit Suisse merging.
Investors have now reached US$580 million of settlements with five banks, including an US$81 million accord in Feb 2022 with Credit Suisse, which UBS bought in June.

site_title: When will the sample count for presidential election be announced? How does it work?
summary: Singaporeans will receive an early indication of the presidential election outcome around 10.00 pm to 11.00 pm on the day of polling, with the first sample count results expected to be released. A sample count of 100 ballot papers from a random polling station will be conducted in front of candidates and counting agents, with the results taking into account valid votes only. The sample count has a 95% confidence rate and a margin of error of 4 percentage points, providing an estimate of the final voting result.

images.alt_text: A generic photo of a poll card that will be used for Friday's presidential election.
Sep 14 will be the inauguration day for the newly-elected president.

site_title: South Korea’s export slump eases in hopeful sign for global trade
summary: South Korea's exports fell 8.4% in August, a slower decline than expected, raising hopes for a global trade recovery. The country's trade surplus widened to $870 million as imports dropped 22.8%. Policymakers are optimistic that exports will contribute to Korea's economy growth of 1.4% this year, despite China's economic struggles and global semiconductor price declines. Global central banks' fight against inflation is expected to continue, but the trade data suggests a potential turning point in the global trade landscape.

images.alt_text: The industrial output index on a seasonally adjusted basis fell 2.0 per cent in July from a month earlier.
FILE PHOTO: A woman pushing her baby in a stroller shops in the Hongdae area of Seoul, South Korea, June 29, 2016. REUTERS/Kim Hong-Ji

site_title: Thailand’s new PM seeks FTA expansion to lure major foreign investors
summary: Thailand's new Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin has outlined plans to attract major foreign investors by expanding free trade agreements, upgrading infrastructure, and making it easier for companies to hire foreign workers. He aims to transform the country into a major foreign investment destination, including increasing manufacturing of electric and traditional autos. The government will also improve water management, boost tourism through airport upgrades, and compete with neighboring countries for trade.

images.alt_text: On Wednesday, the Bank of Thailand, led by Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput, unexpectedly raised its key interest rate by a quarter point to 2.50 per cent, the highest in a decade, saying growth and inflation would pick up next year.
The Tourism Authority of Thailand is targeting revenue of 2.3 trillion baht this year-with 20 per cent of that coming from food.
Factory output has been impacted by a global economic slowdown, Thailand's industry ministry said.
